Furthermore, despite expressing my concerns to the manager and receiving assurances of a complimentary gift card for a future visit, such a gesture never materialized. Therefore, while the food may be adequate, the poor service and lack of follow-through on commitments made by the staff preclude me from patronizing this restaurant again."

"I have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment, as well as the one situated in Phoenix, off Ray and the 10. My companion possesses a membership at this facility, thus we have become gym companions and are striving to motivate one another to attend more frequently. Occasionally, an individual requires an additional stimulus to propel them towards their fitness objectives! 

This gym offers a fundamental, no-frills atmosphere for those seeking a straightforward workout experience. The cost is approximately $10 per month, or for a slightly higher fee of $20 per month, patrons can enjoy access to multiple locations and bring an unrestricted number of guests. 

I am experiencing some difficulty in determining whether to assign a 2-star or 3-star rating to this venue. As a member of 24 Hour Fitness for several years, I am accustomed to their basic amenities, which are sufficient for my needs and offered at a reasonable price. However, my current gym features a sauna, basketball court, various classes, a pool, and other amenities that Planet Fitness lacks. The absence of a sauna is particularly bothersome, and the presence of a loud, flashing alarm that sounds when a heavy weight is dropped, grunting occurs, or significant effort is exerted seems counterintuitive to the gym's purported judgment-free environment. The questionable necessity of this feature remains a mystery to me."

Very RUDE management- we had to wait over an HOUR to get our car out of valet while we watched people leave left and right...we mentioned this to several people - we were offered many excuses to find out in the end that they completely misplaced our CAR! I would have been satisfied if they had offered us a drink- our table spent over $200 on our dinner- we didn't even get an apology...I wrote a letter and everything!\n\nThe waitstaff was friendly- the meal was ok - nothing special considering Charlotte has plenty of great restaurants . Restaurants have a lot to do with relationships- and they killed mine with this one.  Bottom line the food wasn't THAT good to warrant my return...

I take back what I said about II Vinao being mismanaged.  I guess they where just having an off day.  The owner contacted me wanting details so that all problems could be fixed.  How great is that?  We will definitely be dropping by again sometime soon.  This place has what it takes to get a 5 star review from me I'm sure of it...I'll make sure to keep everyone posted.

"It is my conviction that an appellation alteration would be apropos for this culinary establishment, specifically 'Lobster Mehhh.' Upon entering the premises, I couldn't help but feel a sense of familiarity, almost as if I had stepped into a food court within a shopping mall. This sentiment was reinforced by the ambiance, which, in my opinion, would have been improved had it emulated the spacious seating arrangement typically found in such mall food courts. My dining companion and I opted for the lobster roll combo, which included a side of fries and a beverage. While the lobster roll did contain an ample amount of lobster meat, I must say that I was taken aback by the unconventional seasoning method employed. Rather than the customary mayonnaise and scallion mixture characteristic of traditional Maine lobster rolls, this iteration appeared to be dressed with a tangy, vinegar-based condiment that overpowered the inherent flavors of the seafood. In contrast, the accompanying fries proved to be quite delectable, while the lobster macaroni and cheese fell short of expectations, with only a few pieces of lobster scattered on top and an absence of any substantial chunks throughout the dish, making it an unworthy investment of $9.95. Suffice it to say, I do not foresee myself returning to this eatery in the future."

"Culinary offerings at this establishment are satisfactory, albeit with some caveats. Specifically, hot dishes tend to arrive at one's table at a temperature that is less than optimal, which can be somewhat disappointing. Furthermore, management has seen fit to remove certain items from the menu, a decision that is lamentable as said items were of superior quality. Additionally, the ambiance is not conducive to a tranquil dining experience due to an excessive level of noise pollution, both from the televisions and patrons gathered at the bar area, who often engage in boisterous conversations. Moreover, there appears to be a lack of seating arrangements designated for those seeking a more serene repast. According to our server, this state of affairs is a common occurrence, which unfortunately precludes us from frequenting the premises."

"I must admit that I fail to comprehend the appeal of this establishment, despite its reputation as a local favorite and the frequent recommendations I have heard from patrons. The culinary offerings, with the exception of the satisfactory chips and salsa, left me underwhelmed. Specifically, my burrito lacked flavor, as did my daughter's quesadilla, and the supposedly spicy salsa I requested was curiously mild. While the quality of service, selection at the bar, and ambiance were certainly adequate, the uninspiring fare unfortunately detracts from the overall dining experience."

If you didn't know where it was you'd miss it.  Dining area is sparse, basic tables and booths. Open deli-style.  

Got the chicken parm sub as recommended by Yelpers.  Mine was a little dry but a decent sandwich.  Still not sure i would order it again.  Fries are standard crinkle-cut.  

Summary: good place as alternative to nearby fast food joints but I wouldn't go out of my way to come again.

"It is with profound disappointment that I must convey my utter disillusionment with my recent visit to Elliot & Co. Despite my initial enthusiasm, the experience proved to be a regrettable exercise in futility, particularly with regard to the shaving services provided. While I must admit that the haircut itself was satisfactory, the shave left much to be desired, lacking the closeness and precision that one would expect from a professional establishment such as this. Upon returning home, both my girlfriend and I were struck by the presence of 1/4 inch hairs on my neck, which seemed to have been overlooked by the razor, as well as an unacceptable level of stubble that was easily removable with a standard disposable razor. Whilst I appreciate the attention to detail in terms of the towels and oils utilized during the shaving process, it is simply impossible to overlook the glaring deficiency in the quality of the shave itself. In light of these circumstances, I fear that I shall not be inclined to return to Elliot & Co. in the future, and would advise potential patrons to exercise caution in their expectations."

"Sally's Beauty Supply, an establishment purveying an array of products catering to the beauty and personal care needs of its clientele, boasts a considerable inventory of merchandise. However, it is unfortunate that the quality of customer service provided by the staff does not align with the abundance of goods available for purchase. While the manager demonstrated a welcoming demeanor and acknowledged my presence, the remaining personnel appeared to lack a sincere enthusiasm for assisting me in a courteous and friendly manner, their countenances bereft of the warmth and geniality that a simple smile or display of passion for their work could convey."

I had lunch today at this joint with family... My sis-in law, big fan of this place and makes it a point to stop here when she is in town...  The place is not very big at all but the line was out the door...  I ordered the mixed plate.. I thought it was ok,,, it included a beef, chicken and some fish... The beef though in sauce did not have much taste,,, the chicken was good, i liked it.. tender and moist, it was de-boned thigh,, the fish was ehh,,, rather had extra chicken.. The portion was large, too large for me to finish...  I will try the Mami or Udon noodles next time....  I hesitantly recommend this place... I would eat here again but i wont make a special trip....  Hope this helps

I stayed at the Excalibur the last time I was in Vegas because I was meeting friends and this is where they chose to stay. Ugh. I do not know what is wrong with them. This hotel/casino is not cool. It was very expensive (160$ a night... what?) and the first room we went into smelled like someone poured water all over the floor and let mold grow for a few weeks. After over an hour, they gave us another room which was fine, but still overpriced. The casino is in a bad location, so far from the central strip. Who wants to go to New york New york? cuz that's about the only place that is close to this hotel, oh and the MGM. All of the food in this casino is bad. Overall, I was not happy that we had to stay at this hotel. Never again.
Not very impressive ... tables and floor dirty .. I spilled accidentally and staff watched as I cleaned up with no offer of help.   Left sticky residue and nobody would wipe down properly

"The ambiance was aesthetically pleasing and striking, fostering an environment conducive to culinary indulgence. I opted for the Chicken Meatloaf, which proved to be a delectable selection, boasting a rich, savory flavor profile. In contrast, my companion's Chicken Royale failed to meet expectations, lacking zest and leaving much to be desired in terms of gastronomic satisfaction. Notably, the accompanying vegetables, specifically the green beans and carrots, demonstrated superior taste and appeal. 

Although the server exhibited attentiveness upon delivery of the meals, his presence prior to that was regrettably lacking. 

Given the inconsistent quality of the dining experience, it is unlikely that I shall return."

What a dissapointment when you see such an exciting menu, unable to make a choice then you are served frozen hashbrowns and low quality ingrediants.  The chicken fried steak was consumed by a porky/ smoke flavor. The service was friendly and charming but I can't get over the dissapointment in food quality.

it's partially my fault for not checking the lunch menu before i came, but i was very disappointed in lunch. i came on a recommendation, and was so excited to have tapas, bouillabaisse, spanish, italian, and french food! so i brought my family here at lunch only to see BORING sandwiches on the menu. we had a cuban and the chicken sandwich. lame. vegas is supposed to be a 24 hour city. i felt sad and embarrassed for bringing them here. the restaurant should at least have a few of their signature dishes, even in smaller portions, on the lunch menu.

We have recently acquired a residential property in Mesa, Arizona, which features an evaporative cooling system, and we have been informed by the previous proprietors that the construction of Tempe Town Lake has significantly diminished the duration during which the cooling apparatus can be effectively utilized, specifically owing to the augmented humidity levels in the surrounding atmosphere, and furthermore, the barrier that facilitates the impoundment of water has become compromised, resulting in the absence of a lake at present, which constitutes a negative aspect.

"Although my expectations were elevated due to the favorable reviews I had heard, my dining experience at this establishment ultimately fell short of my lofty standards. Despite the prolonged delay in being seated, which seemed to be a recurring theme, I opted to partake in their morning repast. While the cuisine was certainly passable, it failed to elicit any particularly remarkable sentiments on my part, and the atmosphere was regrettably characterized by overcrowding. In light of these factors, I would have to say that my preference would lie with the comparable venue situated nearby, specifically the Gilbert House."

Sunday brunch, is just average, nothing special. As for the selection I felt it lacked in variety...basic breakfast foods and flatbread pizzas. (Upstream set the bar high for brunch) the food wasn't cold but  could've been hotter. Previous reviews said the beer was watered down, it must be a theme w/their alcohol selections b/c the Bloody Mary was watered down as we'll, I'm not sure if it's the mix they used...have definitely had better.  The atmosphere is cool and it was packed, but just don't see what all the hype is about.

Located in The Golden Nugget On Fremont Street Downtown Las Vegas. Ok so I hate to do this but, this place is just ok. the drinks were good, the service even better. The food was average to not so good. The fish and chips were saturated with oil. The 'tempura' lobster was more like funnel cake. There are much better choices downtown that are a lot cheaper. Live it up, you are in Las Vegas for cryin' out loud!

I DON'T LOVE THEIR BURGERS.

I like it but I don't love it. Food took way too long to come out and my medium burger was well done. I like the different sauces and their fries though. I had a better burger at serendipity and they don't even specialize in burgers. We ordered I love bacon and thanks to the bacon otherwise It's just an overpriced carl's jr. Plymouth's pride... don't even think about it might as well get a frozen turkey patty at the grocery store and microwave it. 

I do love that their have variety of flavors and cuts for fries.

I've had a lot better Ethiopian than I was served at Buraka. There is a decent percentage of veg options, which I appreciate, but the menu overall isn't very broad. They also don't have sampler platters for individuals, except for a two-entree combination option which costs more than one entree for approximately the same amount of food. 

 I ordered a combination of the misir wot and the black beans, both described as spicy. Wary due to other Yelp reviews, I emphasized to the server that I like my food spicy, and she assured me that the two dishes are indeed quite spicy. They were not. More significantly, they simply weren't very flavorful. Nor was the injera, usually a highlight of my Ethiopian restaurant experiences.  Halfway through the meal the server offered hot sauce, which helped,but I ultimately expect more flavor in the food itself. 

The ambiance is nice, and they have patio dining, but I'd give this restaurant a definite pass in the future.

Well for starters I am not a big fan of the Beatles (Yes we do exist) so I was not really looking forward to this. We had reasonable seats and the venue is quite large and with stage being 360 and they way main stage is set it is possible to miss out somethings. Cirque tried to cover it with something going on each side but I found it to be a sensory overload. The soundtrack is good as it is a take on legendary music here. The acrobats are ok but not amazing like other shows. My friend enjoyed it but I wasn't impressed so my take is if you are a Beatles fan by all means go for it but if you are Cirque fan there are much better options.

This is a review of the meeting facilities, and NOT the rooms.  I have no experience of the guest rooms at this location.

I attended a two-day training here and was largely disappointed by the meeting facilities lack of power outlets in the space we were using.  The training was a computer-related course and all of the attendees were forced to fight over probably five power outlets. 

Additionally, the first day of our training there was some sort of awful plumbing problem occurring in the building that caused the entire place to smell of sewer gas and sewage.   The property was not able to combat the smell and we all just had to endure it until the cause was resolved.  Gross.

"Underwhelmed by the dining experience, we opted for the kare-kare, only to be dismayed by the lackluster quality of the vegetables, which were unfortunate soggy, despite the tenderness of the meat. However, the lechon kawali proved to be a saving grace, as it was accompanied by a delectable gravy dip and steaming hot rice. Notwithstanding, we may consider giving them another opportunity, taking into account the unfavorable circumstances of the air conditioning malfunctioning on an exceptionally sweltering day, with temperatures soaring to a record high of 122 degrees Fahrenheit."

Now that I have your attention, let me qualify the 2 Star \"award\". The good: the rooms are excellent; great design and better views. The architecture is captivating, and the prices are acceptable.\nHowever, the shuttle they claim to offer from the airport is pointless for most. Check the online schedule BEFORE you book a flight. The pick up times are sporadic at best.... who wants to wait 2-3 hours for a shuttle? the Taxi will cost $40 w/o tip. When you see the M Resort offer anything \"complimentary\", its NOT. At best, its a 2 for 1 offer.  Forget the buffet if your time means anything to you.... we stood 15 minutes and moved, I'm not joking, 4 feet! We arrived looking forward to relaxing at their gorgeous pool only to be told that the area is closed through March. We tried to get a glass of wine at the Hostile Grape; oops, closed 3 days a week! And if you like to shop, plan on renting a car because there is none at M, and the hotel is in the middle of NOWHERE. Next time I'll try Green Valley Ranch or South Point.

I want to give more stars and really like this place.  Service was ok, carne asada tacos pretty good.  Price is cheap.  They have beer.  Nice layout and good location.   All great things but................The place is filthy.  If you can't or won't maintain the dining room and bathrooms then just imagine the kitchen.  We didn't catch them on a bad day either.  What a shame.

Hash House A Go Go in the Plaza is a family friendly diner with portions meant for sumo wrestlers and competitive eaters.  The food pile is truly a spectacle in a place where quantity seems more important than quality.

We tried the Fried Chicken and Bacon Waffles, the Andy's Sage Fried Chicken Benedict, and a House Salad.  

The Fried Chicken and Waffles was average.  The chicken was crispy enough, but wasn't juicy and didn't have a lot of seasoning.  The waffles didn't have a bacon-y flavor, we wished they had just given us some strips of bacon instead.

The Fried Chicken Benedict was like three separate dishes piled into one--literally stacked right on top of each other.  One dish would be fried chicken and mashed potatoes, another would be a biscuit with gravy, and the last would be an eggs and bacon scramble with spinach, tomato, and mozzarella.  With all that on one plate you can't really distinguish one flavor from another, but you can make every bite different.

The House Salad was the standard bag mix of iceberg lettuce, nothing special.

If you do want to try Hash House A Go Go split a plate with someone and come for a true diner experience.

My second worst crepe experience ever!

I ordered a cheese and prosciutto crepe. The crepe was almost thick as a pancake and really doughy. I like doughy crepes but they should be much thinner. It was also not very hot. The prosciutto was too thick and it was kind of too strong in flavor. Worst of all are the flimsy forks they give you. I had a hell of a time trying to cut the prosciutto.

My BF ordered a decent veggie crepe. Mushroom and spinach I think. This crepe was also doughy and thick. If it were not for this decent crepe I would give this place one star.

The coffee here is awful. I will never return.

Parking is a breeze usually and it's free. It's in the Paris parking structure.

When we got here it was not too busy but when we passed by later on it was really packed. I really wonder why....The only cool thing here is checking out the stereotypical Parisian outfits the employees have to wear haha!

first time here was a year ago. went with 2 of my friends, and we ended up going to their walk-up counter because the wait for an inside table was about an hour. we ordered small frozen hot chocolate. 

i must say - i wasnt really impressed. it tasted like a chocolate shake with sprinkles. maybe its better if you go inside to order it? i dont know...

second time i met some friends in town. they were eating dinner (i didnt eat because i just ate). everything looked really good and portions were pretty decent as well. 

third time we went in was a few weeks ago with my sister and some friends back home. ordered a frozen hot chocolate and a frozen white hot chocolate. i couldnt remember how big they were or how "eh" they were, but my sisters never been and we were already there. my sister ordered the frozen hot chocolate for two because her and her boyfriend were gonna share it. and it was waaaaaaaaaaay too much frozen hot chocolate! and as rich as it is, you really dont need anymore than a small. 

service was alright - the cashier there was a little slow at ringing in orders/putting the tickets up on the rail. and it seemed they were short staffed or something because the girl making the drinks seemed overwhelmed the whole time we were there. agian, maybe the hype was built up so much i expected a lot?

maybe i'll come back, stick out the wait and eat inside?

Should have never changed the recipes. I have been back twice since new ownership. I have to say I will give them one more shot. The place has lost the touch of service that was given. I feel while talking with workers that they can do better since everyone was really nice.

"Although the Peking duck possessed a certain degree of culinary merit, it is, in reality, a dish that is challenging to prepare incorrectly, thereby rendering its quality somewhat predictable. In contrast, the walnut prawns, owing to their excessive sweetness, could potentially induce a state of hypoglycemic shock in individuals afflicted with diabetes, thus warranting a classification as a dessert item. Furthermore, the crab dish, characterized by an overpowering flavor profile reminiscent of licking an ashtray imbued with garlic, demonstrated a discernible lack of subtlety in its preparation. Notwithstanding these criticisms, the service we received from the staff was indeed cordial and attentive, which made the experience marginally more tolerable. Unfortunately, the overall quality of the meal was subpar, leaving me with unpleasant gastrointestinal consequences the following morning."

After a year of basketing, I have  to downgrade Bountiful Baskets. The quality was never exceptional, but nonetheless I'm seeing the quality continue to decline. Too much produce that is spoiled within a day or two. I'm really getting tired of certain staples they throw in EVERY week (lousy apples, romaine lettuce). I bought a case of honeycrisp apples when they were in on special - extremely disappointing. They were tiny and started to spoil after just a few days. (That may have been my fault for not taking them out of the case immediately and checking for \"bad\" apples.) \n\nBountiful Baskets is more concerned with quantity over quality, which is fine because that's their whole M.O. I'm just tired of it and will have to look into a CSA.

"A protracted waiting period of sixty minutes ensued before we were able to secure a table, during which time we had the opportunity to appreciate the picturesque surroundings and relish the welcoming ambiance. Unfortunately, this was where the positive aspects of our experience came to an abrupt conclusion. The blueberry muffins, while visually appealing, were regrettably overcooked and lacking in moisture. The biscuits and gravy, although palatable, would have greatly benefited from the addition of either sausage or bacon to elevate them to a truly satisfying level. The Carne asada burrito, a dish that typically boasts bold flavors, was disappointingly unremarkable. However, the sandwich crafted from French toast, while not exceptional by any means, was the most enjoyable aspect of our meal. Despite these shortcomings, we shall return to the Perch, albeit with tempered expectations."

Ok this place just wasnt funny.  The only good thing about it was the opener.  If it hadn't been for him I might have walked out.  It was also $39 for a one hour show, which seems steep.  In new york its $25 and is more like 2 & 1/2 hours.  The worst part about it was the waitstaff.  Maybe if they had let me get a slight buzz I would have had a better time.  Most comedy clubs have a 2 drink minimum, but I swear this place seemed to have a 2 drink MAXIMUM.  The waitress gave us the first round and didn't come back anywhere in sight for at least 40 minutes.  Plus, we were paying cash and she wanted us to pay each time she brought the drinks, then stood right in front of us so we couldn't see the show while she was demanding the money.  I mean, it was a wednesday night so maybe I shouldn't have expected much, but for this kind of experience I would say the ticket should be more like half of what we paid.  my advice is to wait for a weekend for comedy in this town

Moe's is very average food. There isn't anything that stands out and falls behind similar places-Qdoba, Chipotle etc. 

The food was fresh and tasted alright, but was nothing special. The burritos are on the smaller end and has smaller portions inside the burrito.

My biggest problem was the value. There is NO way a burrito of that size with that little rice, beans, meat should cost over $7.50 for an original size. I've had bigger and better burritos that cost around $5. A small soda for $2.50 is also a bit much (free refills).

With each order you do get chips and salsa. I really liked the chips. Salsa was okay.

One other thing that baffled me. My wife ordered a Triple Lindy burrito in a bowl. You get this in a white box. When you try to throw it away, you can't fit the box in the trash can as the top is configured in a weird way. Good thinking.....

I was amused by the name of the Burritos-Homewrecker, Art Vandelay etc. Good stuff!

Moe's won't be high on list to go back to around Jobing.com for me. There are other places that are better.

2.5

Food is really good but Damn the service is really terrible. This is my 3rd time here and I thought they were just busy before but as much as I enjoyed the food, I wouldnt recommend it to anyone. Wait time for your food is crazy  then they bring you food you didnt order, so u wait, only to tell you that your food was probably laid on someone else's table so u wait some more. Food came, you asked for a bowl and took another century to come and had to physically tackle the server on the other table. You wait some more and the bowl was probably still in the factory. Worst part, Nobody even apologized. Another incidence, ordered food and never came in so you cancelled it coz the appetite just went away, check came in and they still charged you for it and they even fight you and say they delivered it.. OMG. I guess have your food to go? Wheres the management here?

Dirig\u00e9 par les m\u00eames propri\u00e9taires que Sushi crescent et Sushi st-denis, je dirais que cette succursale est celle que j'aime le moins. Service presqu'inexistant (ce qui est probl\u00e9matique dans un all you can eat!), le poisson ne goute pas frais et les employ\u00e9s ne pourraient pas \u00eatre plus b\u00eates. Tant qu'\u00e0 avoir envie de sushi \u00e0 volont\u00e9, marchez un 5 minutes plus loin et allez vous remplir l'estomac au Sushi crescent. Je sais que ce sont les m\u00eames propri\u00e9taires, mais je n'ai jamais eu de probl\u00e8mes \u00e0 cet autre succursale.

We had a reservation on July 4 and we came few minutes early to check in.  Noticed a lot of people waiting and tables empty. We had to wait over  20 minutes to be seated.  Asked hostess what was the hold up she explained they were still seating people that had reservations 20 minutes before ours and the computer tells them who is next.  Got to outside table 108 out there and finally got water 10 minutes while other people seated after us got drinks and bread.  Dinner was ok my husband had seafood and some of the clams were not open sign of bad clam no pasta with dinner they should of not served the non-opened clams daughter's pasta was fine sauce was good, I had lemon chicken and chicken was fatty. Asked for bread sticks never got them.  Also outside there were steamers and they were so overpowering we couldn't see and my daughter got really wet.
Barely mediocre bar food.  Our beers were warm and the food was blah and greasy.  I've had better food from a fast food joint and at half the price.  Not worthy of a return.

Stayed last weekend and did not enjoy. I am a Marriott Rewards member and have to say that I got better service staying at a Fairfield.  Room was not cleaned despite calling room service twice. Light switches in room did not work. Either all lights on or off. Elevator access with room key was a joke because it often did not work right. Never received bill portfolio thru email despite multiple calls. System not working and transferred to another number to leave a message. Would recommend not staying here.

This particular Post Office branch boasts the advantageous feature of an Automated Postal Center, which enables patrons to expeditiously procure postage or dispatch packages with minimal effort, thereby streamlining the process for both the consumer and the postal worker. Unfortunately, the designated receptacle for depositing packages often becomes overfilled, rendering it inaccessible to patrons, much to their chagrin. Despite the convenience afforded by the APC, numerous attempts to alert the counter staff via ringing the bell or knocking on the door have been futile, leaving patrons exasperated and frustrated. On one occasion, the APC experienced technical difficulties on a Saturday morning, resulting in a lengthy queue of customers eager to utilize its services. Upon finally being attended to, the worker was oblivious to the malfunction and expressed surprise at the unusual volume of patrons, highlighting the lack of communication and coordination among staff members. Eager to maintain a positive relationship with the United States Postal Service, I endeavor to provide constructive feedback in the hope of improving the quality of service, as even a modicum of attentiveness and responsiveness would greatly enhance the overall experience for patrons.

I had heard wonderful things about Rossario's (best restaurant in Monona, great Italian food, etc.).  I was extremely disappointed after dining there last night.  I ordered the portabello mushroom lasagne, which consisted of an indiscriminate mass of limp noodles, cheese, and mushrooms drowned in sauce.  Not lasagne.  My husband, who is Italian, ordered the chicken Puttanesca.  He took two bites, then stared despondently at his plate.  Even the salad was disappointing.  In three words: Ugh, Ugh, Ugh.
This 24 Hour location is really busy and the equipment is worn out. I did not like this particular 24 Hour.

I had high hopes that this place was on the same level as Salt River in feel and character but I sure did not have that after visiting it last night.  Maybe as I never have been at Wrigley I am missing some of the customized elements.

By far the biggest issue, minus the stupid prices for t-shirts and concessions, is the exceedingly poor scoreboard.  We sat in the lower level of the first base side and had a heck of a time reading the scoreboard.  Here are my gripes on the scoreboard:

Too small to be useful
At night it is not very well lighted so seeing the non-lighted sections is impossible
About 1/3 was being used for advertising
No stats provided for the batter (take a lesson from Salt River)
The line up on the left side did not highlight the batter but with the letters so small it would not be of much use.

By the way the parking lot lighting but there was no signage as to how to exit and the entrance was blocked off!  

I never have been to a ballpark above a crude kids field that did not have the distances from home plate to the outfield fence shown with signs hanging on the fence.

I went on the indoor ride and we shared a gondola with random people. This was a slight mistake because they were silent the entire time and weren't up for having fun, plus the guy had a huge disgusting wart on his temple that I couldn't stop staring at. Um.\n\nThe gondolier was wonderful. He was really nice, really talkative, had a great voice. He made it fun. But the gondola ride itself, enhhhh. I go in for cheesy fun touristy ripoff stuff like this all the time, but I wouldn't recommend this. It looks way more fun than it is and costs far too much for the level of fun that you have. When you reach the turnaround point, you'll think to yourself, THAT'S IT?? And yes, that's it. Seriously. It's nowhere near as exciting as you'd think it would be. Outdoor one is supposed to be better, so maybe go for that instead. The indoor one can be skipped.

This grocery establishment earns a paltry two stars solely due to its protracted operational hours, which afford customers the convenience of shopping at ungodly hours when all other nearby grocery stores have ceased their operations for the day; however, I only deign to patronize this establishment during such late hours, as the exorbitant prices and irksome security personnel who relentlessly tail me throughout the store render it an unappealing option during conventional shopping hours.

You know, I don't venture in to chain restaurants often, and even less often a chain steakhouse.  So how did I find myself at Outback Steakhouse?  It was a quick business trip to @Vegas.  I was treating for dinner and they asked for steak and convenient.  We were both staying at hotels well south of the strip so this limited the choices - nothing on the strip is convenient.

Didn't I see an Outback by the Outlet Mall?  Yes.  Weary business traveler settles for dinner...

I must say I have not been to an Outback in probably 6 years.  It was not as bad as I remember.  That would not make a great advertising slogan, by the way.

My 6 oz sirloin was fine.  The salad was fine.  The service was fine.  By fine I don't mean "fine dining" I mean "ok dining".

See you in another 6 years, Outback.

Average food for average prices.  I came here with a $30 for $15 deal from Groupon and if I was actually spending the listed price on the menu, I would definitely not be satisfied.  Since my meal was basically half off, I would say that the food was okay and well worth it, but I would not spend more than that. 

I ordered in total about 6 dishes worth $90 that I paid $45 dollars for, and out of all of them I only liked the calamari.  Every other dish was either meatless, tasteless, or overcooked. 

The restaurant was absolutely stunning and nicely decorated.  The lights were dim and perfect for a date, if the food was better.  

The server was very attentive and friendly, one of the better servers I have ever interacted with.

"The airport requires a comprehensive modernization initiative to enhance its overall ambiance and functionality. The current state of the facility is subpar, with limited healthy dining options, a phenomenon commonly observed in airports worldwide. Furthermore, the presence of outdated Oxygen bars highlights the pressing need for a thorough revamp. The sanitary conditions of the restrooms are also cause for concern, while the scarcity of available charging stations results in overcrowding and an unpleasant experience for travelers seeking to recharge their devices. Unless one's travel itinerary necessitates a stopover in Las Vegas, alternative layover destinations are generally preferred."

Food was ok and service was really bad.

We went there for the Christmas Eve dinner. We made the reservation at 11pm via OpenTable which shows that they have reservation available at 11 or 11:30. However after we arrived the waitress said they will close at 12. We decided to just eat very fast which turned out to be a really bad idea because during the dinner the wait staff were really impatient and rude.

Most of the food were also not as good as the other yelp reviewers said...although I am not sure if it was because it was the Christmas Eve.

This restaurant was horrible. We ordered the special murg tikka and the chicken tasted as though they threw a frozen chicken packet into the oven, sprinkled some salt and pepper and served it to us. We also ordered the paneer makhani and it was sub standard.\nThe naan was tasty, so if you're up for some naan and pickles.. go for it. Otherwise i'd steer clear of this place.

"One star for the culinary offerings and an additional star for the exceptional bartender, Emmanuel, whose proficiency in customer service ameliorated the unfortunate dining experience I had on both occasions. I have visited this establishment twice, and on both instances, Emmanuel was manning the bar, exhibiting remarkable hospitality and an innate ability to ensure patrons are enjoying themselves. His warm and engaging demeanor is laudable, and if the option to redirect the gratuity designated for our server to him were feasible, I would have seized it. Emmanuel provided more attentive service during the brief time we spent at the bar than our server did throughout the prolonged period we occupied our table. 

It is comprehensible that not everyone relishes their work daily, but when interacting with clients, feigning enthusiasm and avoiding behavior that suggests their presence is a burden is crucial. Unfortunately, our server seemed oblivious to this principle, and his indifference bordered on negligence. He visited our table a mere three times: once to take our beverage orders, again to accept our food orders, and finally to present the check. The manner in which he inquired about our interest in settling the bill conveyed a sense of urgency for us to vacate the premises. The busser demonstrated greater dedication to ensuring our needs were met, checking in on us more frequently than our server did. 

Given the lackluster service and uninspiring ambiance, venturing out of one's way to dine at this establishment is not recommended. However, if you find yourself at Yard House, opting to sit at the bar may enhance your experience."
When the owner comes by to apologize, I'ts not a good night. Service is slow, pizza is nothing special in a town with some good pie. It's also weirdly loud in there.

"For the purpose of attending a respiratory convention, I have opted to procure accommodations at a hotel that would not necessitate my presence for the entirety of the day. While the rooms themselves are clean and well-appointed, featuring comfortable beds, I cannot help but notice the pervasive odor of cigarette smoke emanating from the supposedly non-smoking area. It seems rather ironic that such a situation should arise in a city renowned for its laxity regarding gambling and other vices. Furthermore, I must express my discontent with the addition of a resort fee, which, quite frankly, strikes me as an egregious attempt to extort additional funds from unsuspecting patrons. Suffice it to say, my experience at Treasure Island has been somewhat tarnished by these unfortunate circumstances, leading me to dub it 'Pirate Island' due to its seemingly predatory business practices."

Come for the endless variety of BBQ, stay because you can't make a decision. Realize the selection of sides is equally expansive, and just sit there eating biscuits with apple butter until someone tells you to get the tri-tip sandwich with a side of cornbread.

I understand why people are lamenting about how stupid the prices are, but come on, y'all. You could totally share a meal with someone here and leave satisfied (as long as you eat yer biscuits.) Now, now, I know what you're thinking, "We don't take kindly to sharers 'round these parts..." But put down your pitchforks, because the portions are proportionally reasonable to their stupid prices.

Lucille's lands at 2 stars for good biscuit and cornbread game, solid tri-tip and peanut slaw, and subpar brisket and mac 'n' cheese. In another region, I might toss Lucy a fourth star, but anything less than the best in this BBQ-splattered town just won't win my stomacheart.

For the kitsch factor, for something to do for a day, this place is fine.  It's got games and the carousel bar and cheesy circus acts.  But it's dirty, it's run down, it's poorly planned, and I wouldn't stay here if my life depended on it.  (OK, MAYBE then.)  I tell people who come to visit all the time to not be taken in by the cheap rates here and at the Tropicana.  There's a reason WHY they're cheap.

I have had the privilege of utilizing irrigation services provided by Salt River Project (SRP) for over three decades. Throughout this period, I have had the pleasure of interacting with exceptionally dedicated personnel who have consistently gone above and beyond to provide assistance. The Zanjeros, in particular, have been unwavering in their commitment to resolving various water-related issues, ranging from minor inconveniences such as a deceased animal obstructing a canal to more pressing concerns. Their dedication has led me to hold SRP in high esteem for many years.

However, my recent experience has been quite disconcerting. Upon visiting the main office to settle my water assessment, I encountered several unexpected obstacles. Firstly, a security guard informed me that I was in the wrong location, and the receptionist was no longer available. Secondly, the payment center had been repurposed as a storage space, housing a few machines. Finally, the customer service area had been reduced to a lone telephone mounted on a brown wall, accompanied by a sign directing customers to call for assistance.

It appears that the Zanjeros' responsibilities have shifted from providing hands-on support to monitoring the newly implemented Water Master system. While the system's intention is to ensure a consistent water flow, its execution has proven challenging. Instead of receiving the full allotted time, users are frequently cut short by the system, only to be forced to wait until the following day to receive the remaining 20 minutes. This process proves futile, as the next day's allocation often suffers from the same issue. It is imperative that the individual responsible for managing the Water Master system be present to address users' grievances, especially during ungodly hours, such as 2 am, when the system tends to falter.

My recent telephone interaction with an SRP representative only reinforced my disappointment. Despite encountering an individual reminiscent of the 'old-style' SRP staff, the physical facility itself felt oppressively restrictive, akin to a penitentiary. It seems that SRP has transformed into yet another impersonal, bureaucratic utility company, where the emphasis on streamlining processes has resulted in the alienation of the customer. The disparity between the original values upheld by SRP and their current practices is striking, and I fear that the personal touch once characteristic of their service has become a distant memory.

"I experienced an intense yearning for delectable BBQ cuisine, which unfortunately, was not satisfactorily fulfilled by my recent dining excursion. Upon ordering $35 worth of culinary delights, my expectations were not adequately met, as the quality of the fare failed to impress me. Specifically, the pulled pork was merely passable, while the brisket proved to be unremarkable. Furthermore, the chicken lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, and the beans, regrettably, were undercooked and rather unpalatable. Consequently, I felt compelled to discard them. However, I must admit that the assortment of sauces available did possess a certain degree of palatability. Ultimately, my quest for succulent southern-style brisket remained unfulfilled, prompting me to seek out alternative sources, including soliciting the culinary expertise of my father-in-law. Notwithstanding the eatery's commendable cleanliness and hospitable staff, the diminutive proportions of the dishes served left me feeling underwhelmed."

As someone from the Philly area, driving by had me pretty excited. Pop's looks like Pat's! However, I got a cheesteak, with whiz, onions, and peppers- but they forgot the flavor.  Everything about it was bland.  I couldn't differentiate between the meat and the onions. It was weird. And the bread was awful- it was soft and did not taste like an Amoroso. Looks were most definitely deceiving. That said, the patio is great! And so were the sweet potato fries.

This marked my maiden experience at Culver's, and I must say that my expectations were not particularly elevated, as I had already formed a mental image of what to anticipate based on my previous encounters with establishments of a similar ilk, such as Wendy's and other fast-food burger joints; in essence, it was not especially remarkable or unique, but rather fell within the realm of the mundane and ordinary.

Walked in to pick something up from the ship to store department, and the register is closed but next to it is layway and there were 5 people in line and the gentlemen at the register said that the other lane/register is closed.  I told him \"call for help then, because I'm not here for layway\"  2 other ladies in line agreed and said they were waiting too because no one would come help him.   Well it happened that we were near the employee back entrance or something and I told someone in that back hallway to immediately go call someone to help this guy out because we are not all here for layaway and no one is helping him.  Within 2 minutes someone came to help him.   They were still a little slow but not nearly as bad as before.  It still took almost 30 min from the time I came in, to the time I finally got my 2 items and they allowed me to pull around back to pick it up because it was too large to wheel through the store on a flatbed cart.  \n\nNot necessarily poor service but definitely LACK OF HELP to properly take care of customers!

I guess I didn't order the right sandwich because out of all the awesome reviews my sandwich was just.... OK. I got the Italian and was not really impressed. It was just a small amount of meat and a slice of cheese with stock Italian dressing. So what's the big deal?? Ok I'm gonna have to go back and order something else because I gotta see what all the hype is about! To be continued...

I live in the neighborhood and have been eating here for years. (Both take out and dine in). I don't know if they have new cooks or what, but the quality of the food has slowly gone down hill in the last (6) months to the point I don't think we'll eat there again. The refried beans WERE FROM A CAN. I know homemade versus canned and these are canned. The Cheese Crisp was really lacking and very oily. The shredded beef taco had a lot of fat on the beef. This place used to serve really good Mexican food. Not so anymore. We're going back to Sylvia's La Canasta or Macayo's. Much better food, and not from a can.

I thought it was over-hyped for what  I spent and received service wise. I was overall very disappointed. i went there to celebrate my BF's birthday and told the hostess it was his birthday, then told the waitress, and even told the water guy....and my BF still DID NOT receive the birthday dessert. :( I ordered sweet potato tempura and a king crab California roll and could not believe how dry the rice was. I get a better California roll at my local place back home for a quarter of the price. When we finished eating, it took them 30 mins to bring us the check!? I was so annoyed at this point. I always tip, but in this instance i did not. I did explain on the receipt why I didn't tip too. For how much hype this place gets I am sad to say I was not impressed.

I'm conflicted about this place.  The wife and I were in LV for the first time since 2003, so we were exploring new places.  We saw this restaurant on our travels before heading to a show and we love sushi so we stopped.  The food was very fresh and drink selection was excellent, however portion size was tiny.  After $72 with tip my wife commented that is was the first restaurant that she had ever left feeling more hungry than when she arrived.  We then had to hurry off to get more food before the show.

First time there and sat at the bar. At first we were over whelmed by the customer service (two waitress helping us out) then after awhile there was absolutely no one we could get to order a second drink. We waited about 20 mins just to get our bill and to leave after waving down someone. The place was busy and I had ordered a sample drink but after getting no service we decided to leave.

Very disappointing.  The evening started off well when I noticed they had foie gras on the menu and it wasn't just a foie gras pate, but the whole foie gras seared.  It was pretty good, although the radicchio didn't go well with it.  It also could have used another 30 seconds of searing.  

Everything was downhill from there.  I have never seen a smaller or eaten a blander ceviche.  Ever.  If you're going to call something ceviche, it should be served in Peruvian fashion and taste something like ceviche.  

The lobster risotto was pretty good and had a nice little kick to it..  All three bites of it.

The black bass was forgettable.  The prime rib eye is misnamed.  If you aren't going to include the eye, which is the best part, then call it something else.  It was ok.

Even with the complimentary soup and appetizer, we left unfilled and went to Smashburger around the corner for our second dinner.

Not four seasons worthy! Food was salty and amateurish, as was the staff. the transition from the bar to the restaurant was awkward. Our sides came after the main dish had been eaten and they were the wrong side dishes, which might have been ok if the entire salt shaker had not been dumped into it!  The only saving grace was the manager who realized how awful the service and food were.  Don't bother driving that far north, stop when you get to Mastro's.

"If you seek a culinary experience characterized by exceptional quality, copious portions, and economic pricing, it would be judicious to avoid this establishment. The fare provided can barely be considered within the parameters of a genuine delicatessen. The level of service is subpar, the selection limited, and the flavors uninspired (particularly the chicken soup, which is excessively salty, and the sandwiches, which are disappointingly bland). Furthermore, the desserts fail to impress, lacking both originality and freshness. Despite their 24-hour availability, it is advisable to allocate your time more effectively by seeking sustenance elsewhere. In essence, this eatery is an inconsequential sideshow at Circus Circus, unworthy of your patronage."

pros:
They showed up on time

cons:
They took 5.25 hours to LOAD my PODS (I did 95% of the packing before hand). It should have taken them 3 hours to do that work. And they charged me $446 in materials!!  So todays damage was $1150. Buyer beware.

Little Darlings is 100% nude, hence. no alcohol was served.  It's a little off the Vegas strip but not hard to find.  If you want an awesome VEGAS strip club experience, this is not the place.  It was dingy and cheap looking.  I felt kind of dirty stepping inside.  The girls were not in their perfect form.  Some of them were old and out of shape (to put it nicely).  If that's what I wanted to look at, I could have stayed home and looked in the mirror.  We were club hopping so this was just another place for us to check out.  We only stayed less than 1 hour and skipped to Cheetah's afterward.  I would say to skip it totally.

I'm torn between the quality product and the poor service and WiFi.  

The coffee is exceptional but the entry fee (getting past the flaming hoops of attitude) to get your coffee is a little high.  Now I guess I'm one of the cool kids at times (working for the man - Buring Man), but unless that comes up in conversation, most often I'm not dressed the part in my business casual and just another target for the staff.

Beyond the slow service and attitude, the WiFi is crap.  They are riding a signal from a neighbor companies (Wet Paint) router.  I wish they'd get their own router and Cox connection!  Hell I'd even set it up for them, and when I suggested putting a WiFi tip jar the customers at the bar were all for it!

I like the location and the product but not the service and WiFi - both things that can be fixed.

I had heard from several people the food here was good.  As I travel to Italy often I'm fairly picky about Italian food but am willing to make allowances for Italian-American restaurants.

I had the lobster bisque which wasn't terrible but not great either.  A little too peppery and some pieces of what seemed to be dried fish.  I had ordered what I thought was the crab/shrimp cake appetizer but was brought the meal.  Since I hadn't actually looked at that part of the menu I didn't realize it wasn't the appetizer until I got the bill.  The crab/shrimp cake was adequate but there was too much filler for my taste.  The grilled potatoes and vegetables that came with the crab/shrimp cake were not warm.  Completely over-priced.

The service was glacially slow.

I will not return.

"I believe this establishment could benefit from a thorough sanitizing, although certain individuals might argue that the grime enhances its charm. Be that as it may, I would prefer not to depart feeling an increased necessity for hand cleanser. The beverages are quite affordable and potent, at least relative to my expectations. I ventured forth solo in pursuit of social interaction and novel acquaintances with whom to imbibe and engage in casual conversation. Unfortunately, it appeared that the majority of patrons were clustered into tightly-knit coteries, exhibiting limited inclination towards expanding their social circles. This dive bar, while unremarkable in terms of musical entertainment during my visit, does possess the capacity to inebriate a group of individuals with reasonable efficiency. I shall revisit and revise my assessment should I deem it necessary."

Not pleased. 

Yes, they have good portions.  Yes, its cool they deliver and are open til 930 every night.  Yes, the receptionist can speak English, which is not a prejudice comment, just a general fact after calling literally 7 Chinese restaurants who could not understand a single word i was saying. 

But the food that I received was sub-par.  It just didn't have any flavor!  The pot stickers were way overdone and oh too crunchy on the outside with very little filling on the inside.  The lo mien noodles were...awkward.  Half were bunched together , some were overcooked, some were undercooked; the veggies were waxxy and the beef in it was overcooked and under seasoned.  Seriously you messed up lo mien???  The generals chicken was just OK, not horrible but I've had better.  

All in all a poor experience, so bad I didn't even bother with the leftovers, which is usually my favorite part of a good Chinese meal!

"We halted our culinary excursion at this eatery for a midday repast, commencing with the crabby mozzarella hors d'oeuvre and the fungal morel bisque.  The crab mozzarella was relatively palatable and the mushroom morel soup was also quite satisfactory.  However, the soup evoked memories of the Cheesecake Factory's fungal soup, which remains my preference.  Absent any opinions regarding the brew, I shall endeavor to sample it on a future visit when I am free from medication. 

The seafood combination au gratin comprised a pair of clams, a mahimahi filet, scallops, and stuffed shrimp.  I was unenthusiastic about the shrimp's tacky imitation crab filling, while both the mahimahi filet and the scallops lacked seasoning.  The clams were adequate. 

For dessert, we indulged in the nutter butter ice cream cake, which was fairly satisfying.  Unfortunately, the fare did not elicit excessive excitement."

Close to my humble abode, I opted to investigate this establishment once more. Upon entering, I was met with an underwhelming experience, as the bartender seemed to prioritize his personal electronic device over providing adequate customer service. Despite my eagerness to indulge in their offerings, I found myself having to plead for a beverage, the cost of which was $45. Perplexed by the lack of attention from the staff, I decided to depart, questioning whether any improvements would be made in the future. Unfortunately, based on past experiences, I harbor doubts about the likelihood of change.
The flavors and toppings were okay.\nI was a little disappointed how few non-fat options there were.\nThey have an okay selection but all were of similar tastes.

"Hailing from the Midwestern region of the United States, I had never had the pleasure of indulging in the culinary delights offered by Del Taco, a fast-food establishment that ostensibly specializes in Mexican-inspired dishes; however, based on my recent experience with their fare, I cannot say that I have been missing out on much in terms of gastronomical satisfaction, as the flavor profile of their offerings seemed to be largely overshadowed by the unremarkable nature of their fries, which were not only lacking in texture but also failed to deliver any discernible taste, and the so-called 'chicken' tacos, which were essentially little more than an amalgamation of wilted lettuce and unmelted cheese, did not exactly tantalize my palate."

"Upon perusing the reviews, I had anticipated a superior dining experience at this establishment. Unfortunately, my expectations were not met, to say the least. The ambiance was not conducive to a pleasant dining experience, as it was a smoking environment, which proved to be a significant disappointment, particularly during dinner. The service was sluggish and lacked warmth, which further contributed to an unpleasant dining atmosphere. Our order consisted of cheese sticks, which were unimpressive and lacking in flavor, beer-battered pickles that were excessively greasy, and a BBQ chicken sandwich that was unfortunately overcooked, resulting in an inedible batter that was nearly burnt. Despite our attempts to salvage the sandwich by cutting and removing the batter, it proved to be a futile endeavor. The garlic Parmesan fries failed to deliver any discernible traces of garlic flavor. Ultimately, the dining experience was a disappointment, with my boyfriend opting not to consume his sandwich. The lone redeeming quality was the beer, which was quite satisfactory."

We went for sunday brunch , i like the fact they open at 7am, i figure everyone still sleeping nursing late night hangovers. I was right at 7 am only a handful of us old folks in line. . The buffet was very limited and not many items. For about 25 bucks a head you should get more. The hot foods were mostly breakfast items what happend to the lunch part of brunch. Very sad. Everthing was fresh as it should be since we were their early. Still can't believe a beautiful casino , ' upscale\" would have a brunch that was so simple. Spend a few more bucks and go to wynn, or bellagio.  Service was fine.

"A further gem in the Fox culinary diadem, boasting an extraordinary appearance and sensation, yet accompanied by exorbitant prices for fare that, while undeniably delectable, fails to justify the cost. In a recent visit, a member of our party opted for the prime rib French dip, to which the server inquired whether they desired mushrooms, peppers, or onions, to which my acquaintance responded affirmatively. Subsequently, they had the audacity to impose an additional fee of $2 per item, totaling $6, for what can only be described as meager embellishments. It is utterly preposterous; I could procure ten pounds of onions for a mere $2... Ultimately, I chose to share a chicken club and a minuscule cheese platter, accompanied by iced tea, amounting to a staggering $24. To compound the disappointment, the server exhibited a discourteous demeanor. In light of this experience, it is improbable that I would voluntarily frequent a Fox establishment again, unless presented with the occasional gift card."

My husband and I were so excited to see a trendy and family friendly restaurant pop up near our neighborhood we couldn't wait to try! We gushed over the decor for the entire time it took to get our wine (15 mins) which was sub par and room temperature. The menu was good, but only if you were on a \"cheat day\".  We ordered the only 3 healthy options on the menu and were VERY disappointed. The hummus app was the smallest portion of hummus we've ever encountered, but the stale pita chips were enough for a portion 10x the size.  My Caprese salad didn't feel fresh and his garden salad was blah.  Again we pondered, \"maybe we ordered wrong\" but come on, you shouldn't have ANYTHING on your menu if you don\"t stand behind it.  It was so disappointing that WE WENT TO ANOTHER RESTAURANT  AFTER ON A WORK DAY THAT CRAZY!!!    This place makes me soooooo sad because its the first trendy thing within 7 miles of our house! PLEASE PLAESE FIX THIS WE WILL BE REGULARS!

Service was slow and the burger came out on a soggy bun.  Asked for a fresh bun but took forever so ended up just eating the meat.  Also, the place was super hot.  Everyone at our table was sweating.  Maybe they were just having a bad night but I wouldn't go back to this place after this experience.

My husband and I came here right before seeing a movie. We chose it based on the fact it is right next to the movie theater. The staff was great, prompt with seating and taking our order. \nYummy watermelon margarita! The food...... Not so great. I got the chopped salad but couldn't eat more than two bites because the dressing was far too spicy. The waiter was nice enough to substitute my salad with a quesadilla, which was nothing great, but at least my mouth wasn't on fire. My husband got the rancho burrito which wasn't too bad. \nWhen we go back to the movies, we'll go somewhere else for dinner. I wouldn't suggest this place to anyone.

It's 7:30 am. Time for breakfast. Let's see... Hmmm... no eggs of any kind. Do I want a plate of sausage gravy or some turkey sausage? Maybe a banana that was ripe about 2 weeks ago. Maybe I can have both the gravy AND the turkey sausage...

After 10 minutes of this and watching Magdelina make sure that there were PLENTY of froot loops to go along with the over ripe bananas, the sausage gravy, and the turkey sausage,, I grabbed a cup of coffee and went on my way... Hungry.

There are literally HUNDREDS of hotels in Las Vegas. Stay elsewhere.

Huge rooms. Soft towels. Comfortable bed with tons of pillows.  
Three things that make me happy when I'm traveling.  

What's wrong with this place, then? First of all, the location is central to nothing aside from the mall which houses several chain restaurants.  Second, the staff could not care less about pretty much anything. While the woman who checked us in was helpful and friendly, that was the end of that. Despite requesting my Hilton status "amenities" (just a package of snacks and water...not much), I never received it.  I was also charged $30 for internet when I shouldn't have paid a thing (got the bill corrected at check out). And housekeeping didn't leave enough towels or replace the water.  

Considering we paid over $200 a night, the blase attitude of the staff is very disappointing.

When you walk in and view the menu, you think you are in \"Chicken Heaven\". There are a variety of flavors and various seasonings you can choose for your fries. However, I was not impressed. I ordered the chicken wing and chicken strip meal with a side of fries. The chicken was cooked to a golden crisp and served hot. I ordered the garlic Parmesan, and thought it was waay too salty. Also, a few of my pieces of chicken were undercooked. The restaurant is small, so I had to get my food to go. I have heard mixed reviews and though my experience was not the greatest, I am willing to give Chicken Shack a second chance.

My friend and I used the recent $25 for $50 Groupon to check out Pewter Rose on a Saturday night. 

Honestly, I thought it was a little bit on the pricey side for what it was so I'm glad that we had the coupon. The atmosphere was pleasant but a little kitschy and I kind of felt that plastic tablecloths were inappropriate when you're charging $20+ a plate. 

That said, it was absolutely packed in there. We had reservations for 8pm and arrived right on time and the hostess was able to find us a seat within about 5 minutes. However the first thing out waiter said was essentially "We're really busy tonight so I hope you're prepared to wait a while for your food". We weren't in any rush and agreed that was fine. The service was good, our waiter was very attentive and kept our water glasses filled but even though we ordered as soon as we were able to, it was after 8:30 before we got our appetizer and 9:20, and honestly that was more waiting than I had expected to do. While the restaurant was full, it is not *that* large. 

I had the seafood risotto and it was pretty delicious and I would eat it again. My friend had the herb encrusted lamb and while it was good, we both found it to be overly salty. 

I might come back and try the brunch but I don't think I'd pay full price for the dinner.

Not the first time and only because it's a party. Horrible service waiter picks up my salad plate take the knife off of it and places it on the table with a big wad of lettuce still on it. Appetizers where horrible I'm hoping I don't get sick from the mushroom caps, drinks where watered down. Main course wasn't so bad steak was ok but potatoes where cold and veggies had a horrible taste.  So many great places to eat in town and they pick this dump.

It took me more than 20 minutes to get my single to-go order at this location. On a thursday night when there was hardly anyone there this was ridiculous. The food was OK, I've had better Hawaiian BBQ in the valley for less money. At almost ten dollars for the whole meal, it was not worth the money. Fortunately they do have a smaller, less expensive portion that would fill most people up for lunch.

I like Durant's out of principle, but this is by no means a great restaurant by my estimation. The three separate times I've been were riddled with lackluster service, improperly prepared seafood, and meat with the wrong temperature (medium means medium, right? or has beef fallen into the \"rare is the new medium\" fashion continuum?). \n\nI remain altogether unimpressed. I would, however, hide here if the law was looking for me. It's just that kind of place.

"Although our dining experience at this establishment did not necessarily qualify as unpleasant or subpar, there are undoubtedly superior alternatives in the vicinity for individuals seeking a satisfying culinary excursion, particularly if they wish to concurrently indulge in sports entertainment.  Given the underwhelming nature of our solitary visit, we have opted not to return."

My boss asked for a referral for an interior designer to decorate our new office building so I reached out to the Yelp community and got turned on to Neilsen. I sent all the contact info on to my boss and she was thrilled that I had a referral for her so quickly! Brownie points for me! 

Nosomuch. While Nielsen might be extremely talented, his follow through and time management were less than adequate. He wouldn't return my boss' phone calls without her leaving him several messages, was 2 weeks late turning in his proposal, and would go out of town for weeks at a time without letting her know he was gone....I could go on and on, but really, I don't want to re-live the embarrassment again. 

I know there is the chance that perhaps there were some crossed circuits here, especially since there are so many positive reviews, but honestly, something was amiss with this experience and that's why the low marks (I don't give a lot of low marks normally and it pains me to do so).

I'm not saying don't use this company, because they are probably extremely talented, but I would evaluate the situation you're in before you recommend them to someone so you don't end up in the same predicament I am in.

"It is utterly exasperating when certain luxury hotels fail to provide fundamental amenities such as a refrigerator and microwave in their standard rooms, which are readily available at more affordable establishments like Holiday Inn Express or Comfort Inn, for a fraction of the cost. Furthermore, it is absolutely preposterous to charge guests for WiFi in the year 2011, especially after they have already paid an exorbitant amount for a room that does not live up to its inflated price tag. This is truly an egregious affront to the principles of hospitality. Additionally, the lack of convenient access to nearby attractions, with the exception of a meager convenience store, only serves to further compound the issue. While the room itself was adequately furnished and comfortable, it did not exceed the standards of a typical 3-star hotel."

I recently consumed a grilled cheese sandwich that was utterly devoid of any semblance of culinary expertise, with a solitary slice of cheese haphazardly placed upon the bread, failing to extend its melted tendrils to the edges of the bun, thereby creating an unfortunate visual representation of the lackluster quality of the dish; I must express my profound disappointment at the stark contrast between this uninspired creation and my previous experiences at this establishment, where the fare was not only palatable but indeed tantalizing, leading me to surmise that the current preparation of comestibles within these walls lacks the fervor and dedication that once characterized the culinary endeavors of the kitchen staff.

I'll be honest, I am hard on Tex Mex restaurants in the Burgh. I want so much to believe that I will find a place that does good tacos and I am disappointed over and over again. Here's the thing about tacos that no one in this city seems to understand: the tortillas are the part of the taco that touches the tongue first and will be the source of much of the mouthfeel that you experience while chewing.  (Yeah, I am a bit upset with myself for using the word \"mouthfeel\" but I wanted to use something besides \"chewiness\" and my thesaurus is out of reach).\n\nI lived in San Antonio for years before moving to Pittsburgh and in most of Mexico and Texas a \"taco\" is expected to be a soft tortilla (can be flour or corn) that is freshly made in house. A fresh tortilla makes a world of difference to the enjoyment of the taco. Some of my favourite tacos in the world are just plain, $1.50 tacos that are with some plain 'toppings' a good verde salsa, in a warm, fresh tortilla. I say all this because I think that Verde puts too much emphasis on the ingredients (Which are still under-spiced and boring with some store bought hot sauces on the table giving all the flavor) and then put those toppings into a boring, store bought tasting tortilla. So there you are spending $5 for a taco that's substantially underwhelming.

I liked the menu a lot and can tell that there is some serious potential here, but had a really bad experience. 

They couldnt help the obnoxious, loud, drunk group that came in, so I will give them a pass on that. 

But when my 1 pound burger came out, the fries were already cold. They seemed like they may have tasted pretty good if they had come out about 10 minutes earlier. 

Unfortunately they also forgot my biscuit until I mentioned it. They then brought it out and it was reallly dry. Again, seemed like it could have been better if it had been quicker. 

Again, I reallly wanted to like this place and was hoping to try a breakfast here before I left, but I'm really not sure I should risk it now. Bummer.

Alas, this place seems to be getting worse and worse over the years. I tried it again last week because it was Monday and Saigon Noodles was closed. I just wanted soup. I ordered the Tom Yum. 
It comes with a little salad. It was fresh and good but the dressing was pure sugar. My daughter had the chicken satay. The peanut sauce barely resembled peanuts. It was also really, really sweet and had a few peanuts in it. My soup was sour-- not that nice sweet/sour mix that is typical with Tom Yum-- just sour. It was edible though so I ate it.
To get in and out for under $20 was nice and the service was pretty good.
Bottom line: if you are on the West Side of Madison on a Monday and want soup... lower your standards and eat here. Otherwise, go to Saigon Noodle or (if you really, really need Thai food) head to Ha Long Bay on Willie Street.

Like many other reviewers said, this is basically an economy motel in the guise of a nice hotel.  The water came out so quickly in the shower that it couldn't drain fast enough and crawled up to ankle level. And there is no control to reduce the water pressure. Brilliant! Especially in these times of water shortages. I actually had them switch rooms because I thought my shower was busted, but the second room was no different and I see that other people here had the same issue.  No premium channels on TV. Like 15 bucks for internet service in the room and no wireless, just plug in with a tiny cord that can't even reach to the bed.  Their business center charged 8 bucks for 15 minutes of internet use!  And the customer service was beyond horrible. Everyone acted like they didn't want me to be there. You'd ask someone behind a desk a question and they'd just ignore you, as if pretending you weren't there.  Maybe an okay place to gamble at, but certainly not worth staying there. I've legitimately had better service at random cheap motels.  The only reason I'm not giving one star is because the room was clean.

If I were in charge of an M&M store on the strip, I would have:

- free samples!
- life-size huggable M&Ms
- a demonstration of M&Ms melting in your mouth, not your hand, even in the Vegas desert 
- hot chicks and dudes clad only in M&Ms
- a glamourous bar/lounge featuring candy-colored cocktails and novelty beer with M&Ms floating in it
- a Cirque du Soleil show where the acrobats only wear M&Ms
- high stakes poker with the life-size huggable M&Ms as dealers
- strippers

But someone else is in charge of the M&M store on the Strip, and so it doesn't have any of those things. Instead it has:

- four floors of stuff that says M&Ms on it for sale
- a cheesy 3-D movie
- a (probably cheesy) tour I didn't go on
- NO FREE SAMPLES

I guess that's probably more in line with the M&M brand than strippers, booze, and gambling, but then I don't really understand what they're doing on the strip. Whatever.

"Four overcooked shrimp on a whole shrimp po boy for 12 dollars?!? It's utterly inconceivable how they could possibly serve such an unimpressive dish without any semblance of embarrassment or shame. The red beans and rice were merely average, lacking the authentic flavor and zest that one would expect from a genuine Cajun culinary experience. As for the gumbo, it was utterly forgettable and unremarkable, devoid of any distinguishing characteristics or nuances that might have made it stand out from the myriad of other lackluster establishments purporting to serve 'authentic' Cajun cuisine. \n\nHowever, it must be acknowledged that the service was somewhat above average, although this fact was ultimately unable to compensate for NOLA's egregious failure to deliver an even remotely passable representation of Cajun cooking. In point of fact, it's highly unlikely that such an establishment would survive for even a brief period of time in New Orleans, where authenticity and richness of flavor are paramount and sacrosanct aspects of the city's culinary tradition."

On the spectrum of burgers, these are definitely pretty good. It's way better than a McDonald's or Burger King. However, I Love Burgers wouldn't want you to compare their experience to fast food, so I won't, either.

When comparing I Love Burgers to other gourmet burger joints, it falls short.

Let's start with the service. There was a small wait to get a table, even though there were tons of open seats. Granted, it was busy, but since the wait time for the actual food was around 45 minutes, wouldn't it have made sense to let us sit? Furthermore, even though we ordered fries, the waiter didn't even think to bring those out first -- we had to ask him. A simple thing like this would've made the time go by a lot easier.

Onto the food... like I said, the burgers are decent, but nothing special. I had the "i love bacon burger," which comes with a patty made up of sirloin and applewood-smoked bacon, toped with crispy bacon, bacon mayo, gouda, and onion strings. Given how ravished I was at this point, I was happy to eat it, but I don't think I'll ever need to try this place again.

"Having had the experience of patronizing this establishment on three separate occasions, I must confess that my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, and I was left with an impression that the ambiance and quality of service did not justify the premium prices charged. Notwithstanding the fact that the staff demonstrated a commendable level of dedication by remaining open late on a Sunday evening, thereby enabling me to receive a hasty repair of a torn nail prior to a significant dinner engagement, I would not consider visiting this salon as anything other than a last resort in the face of an unforeseen contingency or emergency situation."

All of our food had a hint of Italian seasoning, which was strange and unappealing.  The veggie enchilada is chock full of zucchini (the menu just said veggie, and I had anticipated the usual peppers and onions...if you love zucchini, get the veggie enchilada and a side of Mexican veggies - also just zucchini - unfortunately I really don't like zucchini!).  All around the place is nice, service was friendly, but the food just wasn't good.

This place is clearly very popular, it was filled the entire time we were there with many people who appeared to be regulars.  We went there for the veggie options.  The seitan appetizer was really good, and a huge portion, but the rest of the meal was not so great.\nThe service was kinda crazy.  Our waiter was nice, but pretty non-existent, and the rest of the staff seemed crazy and frazzled.

"My significant other and I opted to partake in a nocturnal repast at Hash House, whereupon we encountered ambivalent hospitality; specifically, the hostesses exhibited cordiality and warmth, yet their propensity for lingering near the host stand proved somewhat bothersome.  Compelled to select our victuals from the truncated late-night menu, I opted for the grilled cheese sandwich, which, while palatable, suffered from an overabundance of tomato and a meager portion of avocado, rendering its presentation haphazard and challenging to consume.  Our server, Mike, provided adequate, albeit sluggish, attention, requiring approximately fifteen minutes to procure my strawberry lemonade margarita, a beverage that, despite its delayed arrival, proved quite satisfying, if not particularly pricey at eight dollars.  In conclusion, while the evening's culinary excursion yielded mixed results, we harbor hopes for improved service and fare upon our future visits."
