We ordered Tom Kha Chicken to start which was awesome. They didn't spoon the soup into individual bowls which I thought was odd. I guess I'm just use to Asian restaurants doing that. For our main course we had black pepper prawns, sweet and sour chicken, some kind of curry, and I think Chow Fun. All tasted good but weren't outstanding. I guess I've had better Thai/ Chinese food with better service for cheaper back home. But then again I have to give them credit for being open so late. 

After adding some sodas, beers, and white rice the total was well over $100. Overall I doubt I will return even for late night grub.

This venue has the potential to evoke feelings of slight discomfort and confinement, particularly for individuals who have previously visited the LV North Premium Outlets and are accustomed to a more spacious and open atmosphere. A comparison of the two locations reveals several key differences:  
* While parking may be less challenging at this location, the absence of adequate stop lights may result in delays when attempting to exit the premises due to heavy traffic.  
* The indoor setting provides a welcome respite from the sweltering temperatures during the summer months in Las Vegas; however, the layout and design of the interior space may contribute to a sense of claustrophobia and discomfort.  
* Although the variety of stores at this location is impressive, it falls short of the extensive selection available at the North outlets, which cater to a broader range of consumer preferences and demands.  
* The presence of numerous dining options within close proximity provides convenience for shoppers seeking sustenance; nevertheless, the overall ambiance and appeal of the North outlets remain unmatched.  
* Notwithstanding the drawbacks associated with the North outlets, I maintain a preference for shopping at that location, as the ability to navigate the outdoor spaces without difficulty and conveniently access the primary stores of interest makes for a more enjoyable and efficient retail experience. Our excursion, unfortunately, did not yield the desired results.

Overall a very blah place. The atmosphere is clean and positive, but the staff are not super friendly. The prices are competitive, but not the greatest. My manicure has a lot of air bubbles!! It does not look good. There is a very limited selection of colors as well. I am new in town and trying new places and I will not come here again.

the promise of homemade turkey and roast beef drew me in, much to my dismay it's shredded. As Ramsey would say 'like a dog's dinner!'. I got the bobby with roast beef, so i could taste both. The bread was good, the stuffing was cold. The meat was chokingly dry. Dry dry. Sawdust tasting. I'm sure the other non shredded meats are great on that bread, this might as well had just been the stuffing and cranberries on the bread. Plus, the manager was bragging about how he just stands around and does nothing but micro manage. Donkeys! Lol. Make that guy clean the bathrooms!

I would of gave this buffet a 3 star than I thought to myself I really experienced better...also if i wanted to eat a buffet like this place, than I could of stayed in Cali and ate a buffet that would of been cheaper. \nThe whole appearance does look beautiful though.

I went to The Keg last night for the first time, and I was a little disappointed.  I ordered the filet and lobster tail, and everything on my plate came out over-cooked.  I asked for the filet to be cooked medium rare, and it came out unevenly cooked -- half was well done and the other half was medium well.  The asparagus was so over-cooked that it resembled the pressure cooked stuff that comes out of a can.  I couldn't eat it.  The lobster was the best thing on the plate, but even it was a bit rubbery.  Even if they had cooked my food correctly, I'm not sure the experience would have been much better.  The food quality is only marginally better than Outback, but the price is much higher -- more like an upscale steakhouse. If you are looking for something that's a little better than Outback, then this might be the place for you.  However, since your already paying upscale prices, I would prefer to go to somewhere like Morton's, Ruth's Chris, The Palm, or Donovan's.  At places like these, you pay for quality and you actually get it.  I'm not sure I'll go back to The Keg.

This place used to be great, but it's sad to see what it has turned into. One of their selling points was a variety of classes that were available from 5 am to 11 pm. Now they have very limited classes that are jammed packed with signs stating that's tips are mandatory. Very low class! They no longer offer shampoo or conditioner in the locker rooms and have no place to hang a towel while in the shower. The staff is very unorganized when it comes to class cards and often forget to pass them out. I recently renewed my membership after taking a few months off and needless to say....had I taken a few classes before renewing, I wouldn't have renewed. The only reason I keep coming back is because the instructors are awesome.
So the last couple reviews I've done have been kind of negative. So, I've decided to keep this one positive.\n\nThey have a really nice patio! That is all.

"Our recent experiences at this establishment have been utterly disillusioning, as the culinary offerings have consistently fallen short of our expectations. Specifically, the potatoes have been unacceptably desiccated and the eggs have been cooked to an unpalatable doneness. Furthermore, the overall gustatory experience has been subpar, with the sriracha sauce exhibiting an egregious deviation from its intended hue. We cannot help but suspect that the sauce has been subjected to some form of adulteration, perhaps via the nefarious activities of a charlatan seeking to pass off an inferior product as the genuine article. In light of these findings, we have decided to sever our relationship with this restaurant, as it has become abundantly clear that the issues plaguing it are not merely temporary or superficial, but rather indicative of a deep-seated incompetence or lack of concern for quality on the part of its management."

On a graduated scale of culinary satisfaction ranging from a meager one to an impressive ten, I would confer a mediocre rating of five on this particular dining experience. The flavor profile of the burger patty itself was unremarkable, lacking any discernible depth or complexity, while the bun was utterly forgettable in its blandness. Furthermore, a flagrant mistake in our order resulted in my receiving an unsolicited side of french fries instead of the onion rings I had explicitly requested. Although the staff did offer profuse apologies and eventually brought out the correct item several minutes later, the onion rings proved to be merely passable, failing to impress my palate with their uninspired seasoning and texture. In addition, I found the portion of fries I sampled while awaiting the correction of the error to be thoroughly unexceptional, neither remarkable for their crispiness nor distinguished by any unique flavor component. Considering the price point of ten to twelve dollars for a fundamental burger and fries combo, I must aver that such an exorbitant tariff seems patently disproportionate to the actual value offered by this establishment. However, I must admit that the beer selection redeemed the dining experience somewhat, boasting a pleasing array of choices that were both refreshing and well-chilled. Alas, the quality of service remained stubbornly average overall, leaving much to be desired in terms of attentiveness, responsiveness, and general hospitality. Given the dearth of clientele on a Friday evening, it becomes apparent that discerning gastronomes would be well-advised to seek out more satisfactory options for their hard-earned dining dollars.

The first time I came here was awesome.  The second time.. not so much.

Can't remember the girl's name, but after 30 seconds of starting she stopped to use the phone.  Then, she stood in front of me (while I was leaned back in the chair) for a good 15 minutes just gabbing on the phone.  Three other workers were standing around me as well.. none of them had the decency to finish my brows.  Also, throughout her conversation, she kept holding her finger up and telling me to "wait," even though I wasn't saying anything.  

When she finally got off the phone, she finished my brows.  At one point she yanked really hard and my eye watered.  She then called me a crybaby.  Thanks?

When I went to the register to pay, she asked me how much I was leaving her for a tip.  Wow.

2 stars because both times I've been here, my brows looked pretty good.  However there are a million other places I'll go to instead who can do just as good of a job without the rude service and horrible location.

"Although I consumed a sizable burger, I found the culinary experience to be merely adequate. I would have preferred a smaller portion size with increased gastronomic excellence. Unfortunately, this dining establishment does not warrant a repeat visit. Following a partial consumption of approximately one-third of my meal, I felt underwhelmed. However, the presence of a vintage tractor did generate a modicum of interest."

My first experience was so awesome I couldn't wait to come back.  I thought best service, wine , food and atmosphere.  This time a total 180. Note to our waiter\n\"listening skills\"  \nLast time we split every dish was separated and equally plated. This time he hacked into the steak at the table. Presentation ruined! Steak knifes came after the steak, when does that happen in a steak house? When he came to check on us, it wasn't until I had to reach out to the manager. By that time all our food was cold. When the waiter came to apologize, he said if the chef had to slice it in the kitchen, it would be an extra charge. I challenge him to find that button on the POS  system. If that was not bad enough, when the check came the waiter was swarming around my table like a shark on the hunt. Clearly this experience was not about our celebration, but our waiter.

Not a fan.

Went here upon my sister's recommendation but she also said she hadn't been there in about 10 years. So I chanced it because I live really close.

We sit down and the first question our server asks us rather abruptly is, do you have a Groupon? I was like, uh no. Is there a Groupon? So I look on my phone and sure enough there was so I bought one -$19 for $30.

I was not impressed with the food at all. Every roll had cream cheese and krab mix in it or some variation of that. So not a great selection. Wasn't especially fresh and definitely flavorless. And the rice to fish ratio in the rolls was way off. They were like all rice no fish.

On top of that, our food took forever. Sigh.

Not a great value. Without the groupon our bill would have been close to $60 for some mediocre sushi.

So I guess a lot of people come here for their $20 all you can eat special. We decided not to because of all the rules and conditions. No sharing. If you don't eat it all, you pay for what you don't eat...seriously?

One bright spot was the service was pretty good.

Overall, won't be back :/

"The store boasts an impressive ambiance, further enhanced by the presence of a chocolate fountain, which serves as a visual delight for patrons. However, my experience was slightly tarnished by a less-than-satisfactory interaction with the cashier. Upon inquiring about the sweetness level of their iced mochas, I received a dismissive and somewhat condescending response, which failed to address my concerns regarding the beverage's sugar content. It is imperative that establishments prioritize customer satisfaction, particularly when catering to a diverse clientele with varying preferences and dietary restrictions. Therefore, I implore the staff to adopt a more attentive and empathetic approach towards customers, thereby ensuring a positive experience for all patrons."

If  you enjoy massive quantities of mediocre to substandard food with nonexistent service, you will like this place.  I am torn between one or two stars, but will give them two.  This place just opened and so is cleaner than Hometown Buffet.  

I hated the fat dried out steak that required a wait in line, bad popcorn shrimp, and the tough fried fish.  The fried chicken, barbeque chicken, and rotisserie chicken were blah, but edible.  Some of the food is mislabeled.  

Dessert selection was poor with few choices for a buffet restaurant.

Staff appeared somewhat disorganized.  We arrived early, but had to wait in a long line.  The waiter took forever to pick up the used plates.  I sometimes find it wise to bus my own plates.

We had to get our drinks before paying, which really slows the line down.  You pay an extra $1.99 for a drink or even more for a drink to go.  They charge $5 per pound if you chose take out.

Pretty amazing just to sit there and watch people stuff themselves, but will pass next time.

They obviously have good intentions here but there is just too much to complain about. Firstly, the interior decor is extremely drab and depressing.  Yeah, that's just my opinion, but I can't be the only one. Also, on a 75 degree day in Vegas, the temperature inside was way too hot. Even my wife who is never warm noticed it. The tables are too small, and the couches are creepy looking. We ordered smoothies and I swear they must have grown the fruit trees from scratch in order to make them, they took FOREVER to come out. They were good, though. We ordered the \"hummus delight\" appetizer and even though the hummus was good, there wasn't enough of it to adequately eat it with the sides. My wife ordered the Greek salad and there was no feta cheese. What?!?!  That was a first and it made the salad so-so at best. I got the spicy beef panini and it was really good, but it looked as though they had some trouble with the panini press because it was a bit burnt and had pieces of other sandwiches on the bread.  \n\nSo, overall, the food was good but it took so looooong to get it out that it really marred the experience. Add that to the depressing decor and the high prices and I won't be back.

This place is not very good.  I like their sesame chicken about 30% of the time - very inconsistent!  Everything else I've tried are ok or nasty..  My coworker found a bit of a bug in the plastic wrapping they used to wrap the container.  Would not eat there..

"Our sojourn at this establishment was marked by a succession of contrasting experiences, wherein each positive aspect was promptly succeeded by an unfortunate counterpart. The accommodations, while commodious, were also noticeably unkempt and unsanitary. The sleeping quarters, though well-appointed with a comfortable bed, were accompanied by pillows that lacked adequate support and were generally unsatisfactory. Furthermore, the room's decor, while featuring some aesthetically pleasing elements, was overall outdated and reminiscent of a dystopian, futuristic setting. Additionally, our particular room was designated as a 'robo-cop' space, which added to the overall ambiance of the stay. In terms of connectivity, the hotel offered wireless internet access; however, the policy regarding device pairing was exorbitant, with each additional device incurring a daily fee of $14, which we found to be utterly preposterous. The pool area, while expansive and featuring an interesting gaming facility outside, was offset by the modest size of the pools themselves, which were further subject to a rental fee for seating. This, coupled with the unexpected resort fees and taxes tacked onto the final bill upon checkout, made for a questionable value proposition. The quality of service throughout the hotel was inconsistent, with moments of excellence juxtaposed with instances of mediocrity. Taking into account these factors, it is our recommendation that potential patrons consider alternative lodging options that offer a superior overall experience."

"Hmm, this establishment appears to possess promise, as evidenced by the favorable critiques and enticing menu offerings; however, do not allow yourself to be misled, as the quality of the dining experience falls short of exceptional. 
Upon entering, we opted to sample their assortment of fries, which included zucchini, Mac n cheese, and pepper jack shots (essentially, fried cheese). To our delight, the aforementioned items proved to be delectable. Subsequently, we elected to order burgers and shakes, accompanied by beverages containing alcohol. Unfortunately, the preparation of the burgers did not align with our specifications, and upon conclusion of the meal, we were charged for every item we had requested, excluding those that were part of the burger. The duration of time required to prepare the burgers was considerable. Furthermore, the shake and beverage we had ordered alongside our initial courses did not arrive until approximately halfway through the consumption of our burgers. Moreover, we were compelled to remind the server twice regarding these items. 
The quality of the burgers left much to be desired. Specifically, the pepper bacon possessed an uncharacteristically sweet flavor profile, whereas the meat itself was unpleasantly mealy. While I might consider returning for the Nutella-infused shake, augmented with Godiva chocolate liqueur, or perhaps the pepper jack cheese shots, I would advise against harboring elevated expectations prior to visiting this eatery."

"My experience at China Poblano was a regrettable error in judgment, precipitated by my elevated expectations due to its affiliation with the renowned culinary virtuoso, Jose Andres. Upon perusing the menu, I was dissuaded from immediate departure by the promise of Mr. Andres's reputation, leading me to indulge in an overpriced dim sum serving at $11.00. Mr. Andres is celebrated for his expertise in tapas, which prompted our group to order several tapas servings to share. Unfortunately, the offerings were merely satisfactory, failing to elicit a profound culinary experience commensurate with the price point. A miniature pork sandwich, priced at $8, fell short of my expectation of a mind-blowing experience. The standout dish was an eggplant entrÃ©e, yet it lacked sufficient appeal to warrant a future visit. In an attempt to enhance the dining experience, I experimented with consuming Chinese and Mexican dishes simultaneously, but this endeavor proved futile. The restaurant's concept of fusing two distinct menus under one roof only served to confuse my palate further. While the ambiance was stylish and fashionable, it failed to compensate for the deficiency in flavor satisfaction relative to the cost. Consequently, I shall seek alternative establishments that provide a more harmonious balance between taste and price."

Fairview Grill has opted to metamorphose its moniker to Lucky Louie's, a transformation that, quite frankly, has failed to generate any profound impact or excitement. In point of fact, the quality of the culinary offerings and beverage selection remains subpar and unimpressive, respectively. My recent dining experience at this establishment, accompanied by a companion, proved to be an utter disappointment, as the fare served was not merely unpalatable but also induced nausea, necessitating the utilization of antacid upon returning home. 
  An examination of the menu reveals the following:  
  Wings: It is advisable to avoid the jerk sauce, as it lacks flavor and is generally unappealing. The barbecue sauce, conversely, exhibits some degree of palatability.  
  Sides: The buffalo fries, accompanied by a side of ranch dressing for dipping, demonstrated a certain appeal, specifically in terms of taste.  
  Burger: The bacon cheeseburger, while falling short of my personal preference for a well-done cooking style, was only partially consumed due to the absence of crispiness in the bacon and the lack of A1 sauce.  
  Notwithstanding the aforementioned deficiencies, Lucky Louie's does possess several redeeming characteristics, including:  
  1. A commendable Golden Tee and Silver Strike Bowling Machine  
  2. Pool tables for patrons to engage in recreational activities  
  3. A prominent projector screen positioned at the forefront, complemented by numerous flat-screen televisions strategically placed throughout the establishment  
  4. Access to the NFL Network, catering to sports enthusiasts  
  Given the unsatisfactory dining experience and the unremarkable nature of the food and drinks, it is unlikely that I will return to Lucky Louie's, except under duress.

I've been to Panchero's, and I probably won't go back.  If I ever find myself in that center again, I will be at either Jersey Mike's, Starbucks or Yogurtland!  The flavor of the food was decent.....but they were so stingy on everything that it pissed me off before I even got a chance to taste the food!\n\nGet this...they measure out the cheese in this little scoop....are you kidding me!?!?!  It was probably an ounce of cheese, which if you are like me, is not nearly enough cheese to go around.  Also, when I said that I didn't want the rice, just beans, I still got the same amount of beans that a person who ordered rice got....beans are like the cheapest food on the planet....don't be so stingy!  The carnitas was pretty tasty, but I just felt like I was being so jipped as far as the value and the portions went that in order for me to return...a mass destruction of all the Rubio's, Chipotle's and Baja Fresh's would have to occur...and even then...I would probably still pick taco bell....you just can't beat 89 cent bean burritos!

Just Okay.

The place itself is nice inside.  The staff were not all that interested in helping us.  The prices were in line with what we expected and the food was fine.

What hurts Tusca is that other, better Tapas places are nearby.  Also the clientele at Tusca seemed to be mainly female late 30's to 40's who were there to hunt for younger upwardly mobile young men.  Maybe this was just the few times I was there.

I had such high hopes based upon the recommendations but was sorely disappointed. The wait staff seemed distracted or else just not interested in our table. It took forever just to place our orders, which were not complicated: one crepe, one brownie, one petite pot. Unfortunately, we got two crepes and no brownie. Considering the brownie were for our small children, both of which had had it promised for good dinners,  just compounded the disappointment. We tried and tried to flag a wait person to correct the error to no avail. When we eventually did have someone respond, it was getting too late for us to wait any longer. We received an anemic apology at best. The food was delicious, and we do like supporting local businesses, but this location's service is in need of a reboot.

What happened, Xinh Xinh?  We used to take out of town people here because we were so impressed with the place.

Last time we got take-out.  Three banh mis and an order of wings.  Wings were pretty good and certainly well seasoned with fish sauce.  (If you are not used to the smell of fish sauce, this might not be too appealing.)  My wife's sister's banh mi seemed pretty good, but ours had very little meat on them.  They still had the jalapeno peppers and cilantro, but the mayonnaise seemed less, too.  I got the catfish banh mi and the fish was tiny - especially in comparison to previous trips.  

We'd noticed a decline in the quality of the bubble teas, too.  Originally they were really strong and offered flavors that Cafe Evo didn't.   But last time we got one (it was a while ago), it seemed like it was made with non-dairy creamer instead of milk.

Disappointed.  Probably not going back - I guess I have an excuse to try making my own banh mi or pho instead.

The service was still good, but the food is simply not as good as it was when they opened.

"Recall, if you will, the venerable advertisement for Wendy's featuring an elderly woman querying, 'Where's the beef?' Indeed, we would be remiss not to draw a parallel between that particular televisual promotion and our own experience with the green chili beef chimichanga at a certain establishment, whereupon, upon splitting said dish, we discovered a paltry quantity of beef, barely sufficient to satiate a geriatric canine, let alone a hungry human, and a scant few green chilies, rendering the entire ordeal a rather underwhelming experience, leading one to surmise that, much like the aforementioned matriarch, we, too, might be inclined to pose the inquiry, 'Where, pray tell, is the beef?' and, in light of such glaring deficiencies, offer a prognosis of approximately six months, barring any substantive enhancements to the culinary offerings."

"The meager serving proportions ostensibly justify the elevated price point, rendering the establishment's pricing strategy somewhat dubious. Moreover, the absence of the signature dish, sisig, during our visit within the initial two weeks of operation raises concerns regarding the restaurant's operational efficiency. Furthermore, the asynchronous arrival of our orders magnifies the perception of subpar service, which is further compounded by the server's seemingly adequate yet unremarkable performance. It appears that the staff's primary focus is on maintaining a tidy dining area, rather than prioritizing customer satisfaction. Ultimately, our experience was marred by numerous shortcomings."

Hardly utopian for this beer fan. Nice ambiance, on hip lower rue Crescent, and a nice mix in the crowd.

Ordered the IPA on the recommendation of the very good bartender. What a disappointment -- virtually flavorless. Not what I'd expect of an IPA at all. Probably should have tried something else, but I just moved on.

Oh, and like other independent brewpubs in Montreal - cash only. Boo for the business traveler.

Mediocre at best....
Stopped by on Saturday for a lunch. They had no grilled chicken available! I know... things happen but when place call itself Peru Chicken and has no chicken available it's like hot dog stand with no hot dogs.

Ordered something called Tacu Tacu and plate of Antichuchos and potatoes with cheese sauce for app.

Tacu tacu consisted of huge pile of rice/beans mixture and small slab of grilled meat.  No veggies, no pickle... just that. Come on - work on presentation and quantities and you can probably charge $10 for that otherwise it's a fail.

Antichuchos - slices of meat on a stick with bland side of corn and undercooked potatoes.  Meat was OK. Sides weren't. 

Appetizer (I think it was called pappas a la huancaina) - 3 sad pieces of cold boiled  potato served on a styrofoam plate covered with cheesy sauce (cold as well) - $5 is way too much for it.

"Although I had anticipated a positive experience at this establishment, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as I failed to discern any truly exceptional qualities; the burgers and fries, in particular, were merely average, and the prices, while not exorbitant, were still somewhat elevated relative to the culinary offerings of other eateries within the city limits; nevertheless, the convenience of its round-the-clock operations did somewhat mitigate my disappointment."

Went on a Sunday morning about 10am. It was clearly busier than the staff and kitchen crew are able to handle. The place was packed but the tables were not full. It took a while to order and then the order was not correct when it came to the table. The appetizer cinnamon roll never came, my drink was not refilled and my pancake was burnt (black). The hash browns needed some love and my french toast seemed old. I hope they get their act together, it has the right ingredients to make it happen.

Our quartet was eagerly anticipating experiencing this establishment, predicated upon the favorable critiques we had perused. Upon arriving at 4:00 PM, we were disheartened to discover that the venue only offers a morning repast on weekends, specifically Saturdays and Sundays, and that their evening fare does not commence until 5:30 PM. This rendered it impractical for us to partake of their culinary offerings at such an unconventional hour, particularly given our Monday through Friday work schedules, which precluded the possibility of us ever savoring their midday cuisine. Notwithstanding, we shall endeavor to revisit the premises at a later time for an evening meal.

"Gosh! This establishment's service speed left much to be desired. Upon entering, it became apparent that no host was present to accommodate us; thus, we proceeded directly to the bar, anticipating a more expedient experience. Unfortunately, this was not the case, as there were merely two couples and an additional table that the bartender was attending to, resulting in an extended delay before we received a greeting. Moreover, the bartender professed that she needed to locate mint for my mojito, further exacerbating the wait. Eventually, we obtained our beverages, yet menus were not offered to us. I had to personally retrieve them from the host stand. To my chagrin, I had to request water twice, first from the bartender and subsequently from someone who delivered our meals, as the initial request was ignored. The culinary offerings were unremarkable and typical of what one would expect from an Applebee's. Our appetizer, drinks, and entrees were consumed, but the table was not cleared until the server collected our credit card for payment. What truly incensed me was that a group of three individuals entered the bar subsequent to our arrival and received prompt attention and beverage service from the bartender, who seemed to recognize them. Such disparity in treatment was utterly unacceptable. In light of this experience, I am unlikely to return to this establishment, even considering its proximity to our lodging."

Disappointed. Was recommended, was expecting so much. Was a bit dirty, waited ages to get served, so long we nearly walked out. Looked like loads of managers, no staff. Staff looked bored and poorly trained. What a let down.

Philly cheesesteak not good. Cheap dried up luke warm meet. Not served as described on their menu. My husband got a turkey sandwich, which was ok but nothing to write home about. This place may be good if you're drunk and hungry at 2AM, but if you're just looking for a good quick bite for lunch SKIP THIS PLACE.

I've tried a few of their veg curries, and they're pretty disappointing. They were all seriously lacking in taste and quality. Maybe their non-veg curries are better...\nI understand that since they're so close to campus, they can get away with lower quality food, but still. I wouldn't recommend anyone go there if they're looking for good Indian food.

The service at this place has gone downhill! Ticket price for 2 people $120 plus Platinum flash pass an extra $140! Platinum Flash Pass "supposably" reduces wait time in line. To be honest that's questionable! I feel that this pass is a scam.
http://www.laronde.com/larondefr/flashpass.asp  (Misleading description)

Today I shelled out a total of $400 to have a great time with my kid, yet the rules seemed to change at any given time in regards to the famous Platinum Flash Pass. This bothers me, since they misrepresented the wording defined on website. I WAS UNDER THE IMPRESSION THAT THESE PASSES WERE LIMITED! Why was I told that this was not a VIP pass and why did I have to wait in-line for certain rides? Why aren't all rides covered under the Platinum Flash Pass? 

I also ordered a beer, at $6.50 a beer I expect a proper pour not 3/4 foam 1/4 liquid. The drink in question was poured by a 16 year old! Being in the food industry and being familiar with the law I know that this is not legal. I plan on complaining to the http://www.racj.gouv.qc.ca. Teenagers should not be pouring alcool. Obviously Provincial RULES do not apply to Six Flags in Quebec.

This show was overpriced, performance was mediocre, had very little real dancing and had a bit too much immature sexual insinuation (guys grabbing their crotch too often) and mime comedy. Throughout the whole show, we kept waiting for the real show and exciting performance to start.  It never did. There was one number like it.  Everything else did not have the caliber of their performance on ABDC. \n\nBut while walking out, someone exclaimed, \"it was sooooo good.\"  My husband and I wondered if we were in the same show.  Maybe it's more for the teenage crowd.

"My affection for Kirkland Signature frozen yogurt notwithstanding, I have been consistently subjected to a conspicuously hollowed-out serving whenever I opt for it at this particular food court establishment, leading me to surmise that such a practice may be an intrinsic component of the employees' training protocol. Furthermore, the pepperoni pizza served here is characterized by an excessive amount of grease, necessitating the procurement of an abundance of napkins to effectively address the issue prior to consumption. Indeed, the grease in question is not only present at the base of the pizza but also dispersed throughout the plate, rendering it a veritable challenge to enjoy without considerable preparation."

While in Arizona, I presumed that any Mexican eatery would be satisfactory, but unfortunately, my expectations were not met. My husband's uncle and his spouse highly recommended this particular establishment, so we accompanied them for an evening meal. The restaurant is situated within a plaza, and upon entry, it becomes apparent that the interior design is aesthetically pleasing, boasting Spanish-inspired elements and an inviting ambiance. Following our arrival, we were required to wait momentarily for the staff to prepare a suitable table, during which time we escorted our offspring to the lavatory facilities. The restrooms were impressively maintained, exhibiting a high level of cleanliness. Subsequent to our completion of the necessary tasks in the bathroom, we were seated, and our server promptly emerged to take our beverage and salsa requests. The restaurant offers a selection of salsas, but unfortunately, their primary offering did not meet my expectations - typically, I would consume salsa and chips without hesitation, but in this instance, the salsa was not palatable. The accompanying chips were also subpar. Opting for the cheese dip instead, I found it to be relatively satisfying. However, my experience with the chimichanga was disappointing, as it lacked both cheese and flavor, leading me to return it uneaten. Furthermore, I was unimpressed by my family members' dishes, which further reinforced my dissatisfaction with the culinary offerings. Despite the pleasant ambiance and commendable service, this establishment only merits a rating of two, primarily due to its shortcomings in accurately representing authentic Mexican cuisine.
Pizza tastes good. But delivery is horrible. Pick it up yourself unless you want to wait 1.5 hours to eat.

I'm a frequent visitor to Kabuki, mostly for work lunches during the week.  Today (Saturday) I decided to treat my wife and kids to sushi!  I'm not sure if I'm tainted by the larger and quicker lunch staff, but service was absolutely atrocious.  Our server, Andy, was covering what appeared to be 4-5 tables.  His priorities, however, were more targeted towards complaining to fellow waiters about having to work on such a nice day and discussing weekend plans with the hostess.  To give you an idea on what I mean by \"bad service,\" our appetizers and salad (that comes with the special) came after we were done with our sushi rolls, drinks were not filled, and it took him approx 20 min to pick up my card and check after dropping it off.  It's too bad they couldn't find anybody to work that wants to work!  Buyer beware, bad service, \"okay\" food.

Got to agree with the people weighing in on this Walmart with two stars. I have been going to it for about a year, but I'm changing my prescriptions over to another Walmart because I just can't take the trashiness anymore. \n\nI love Walmarts overall, but this one is the reason that I can't always recommend them to friends. (Had an Walmart-challenged friend come into town and use the restroom, and she heard someone puking in the stall next to her. So of course, she is NEVER going to go into a Walmart again, ever.)

Friday Happy hour menu:
Steak and cheese - $ 6, decent
Neopolitan milkshake - $4, decent
Gyro - $6, no more next time
Panini - $6, okay

Service is slow, despite it being almost empty.

Overall, it's okay if you are starving, hungover, drunk, or didn't think of other options.

Here's why this place deserves a knock off of three stars: the blueberry scone was awful. Blatantly horrible; not sweet, almost savory like, which was odd. Had a weird granular texture as well. My espresso con panna was way more bitter than I expected, bitterer than starbucks'. These were the redeemers: the lemon olive oil cornmeal cake was absolutely excellent. The mocha was great too. The counter worker seemed very friendly and knowledgeable.

Ehh. Nothing to write home about. Good service. Food just average. Unless you are a veggie loving hipster, this place is not worth the 2+ hr wait. Save yourself the trouble and disappointment and cross Butler St to Franktuary.

I will be forthright in my assessment; this establishment does not possess an exceptional quality. I found myself with several hours to kill prior to my late-night flight, and my craving for Mexican cuisine led me to this location. In retrospect, it would have been more judicious to dine elsewhere.

Pros:

* The staff exhibited amicable demeanors.
* The guacamole presented a satisfactory taste experience.

Cons:

* The tortilla chips lacked the flavor and crunch associated with freshness.
* The absence of burritos on the menu, with the exception of Monday through Thursday, was perplexing.
* The chicken quesadilla failed to impress, bearing a resemblance to something easily preparable in one's own domicile. The texture was also subpar, featuring an unpleasant sogginess and an abundance of unfilled space along the periphery, resulting in an overall sensation of mediocrity.

In light of these factors, it may be wise to consider alternative dining options.

We have been to this location many times.  When you eat in the portions are fine but when you order out they cut the size of your order and still charge the same.  Last Friday we ate there, ordered the Mahi Mahi with vegetables and the fish portion was a decent size as was the vegetables.  On Sunday, 7-29, we ordered the same meal to go and when we got home the fish portion was half the size of the one when we ate in.  The amount of humus was also decreased.  \nThis is not the first time that has happened so if you are planning on getting and order to go make sure and look at the portions.  They seen to give less for the same price figuring that you wont see that till you get home.

I love frozen yogurt. But my logic is that if you are getting FroYo, you are gonna want a more refreshing and fruity flavor. If not, you want Ice cream. Every time I have been in here they have had one fruit flavor and it was always something I am allergic to or dislike. They never even had original tart, which I thought all places had.\nThey do however have a pretty nice selection of toppings.\nThe place is pretty clean, the service is alright, and the price is the same as most frozen yogurt places per oz.

This is my second visit and likely my last. I was so disappointed in the food quality and service. I treated a friend to the table d'hote and was horrified that she received a burnt  puck of beef after waiting an unreasonable amount of time. The fact the server did not even acknowledge the poor quality/presentation and never asked if we enjoyed the meal, reflects the nonchalance attitude of this place. I am a firm  believer that a sever is the representative of the food and the establishment. And when they don't take ownership of the experience, there's no reason to go back.

This was such 50/50 place. Out of three different specialty pizzas we ordered, one was really good, one was okay and the other was really bad. Salad was good, but nothing special. Ranch dressing was really good, bleu cheese dressing was really bad. Chicken tenders were burnt, like to the point that when I opened the container, it smelled like a kitchen was on fire. They were so black, I could not believe that they actually delivered those to us. The buffalo sauce was good, but useless since our chicken was not eatible. The baked potato fries were a good concept and had a good flavor, but the fries were soggy, but maybe that was just because they were delivered. Okay, maybe it was less than a 50/50 ratio here, since we did spend over $100 for so much dissapointment.

"Although my preliminary perception of Bottles & Burgers at Tivoli Village was less than favorable, stemming from an underwhelming experience at their sister establishment, I remained open-minded and amenable to exploring its potential. My willingness to give the venue a chance was further bolstered by the presence of outdoor seating, a feature that has become increasingly appealing amidst the current pandemic. However, upon arriving at the location, I was dismayed to discover that the patio area was situated between two escalators leading to the second floor, resulting in considerable foot traffic, noise, and distractions. Despite these drawbacks, I opted to sample their beverages, commencing with a cucumber martini that, while unremarkable, did not entirely disappoint. Unfortunately, the sangria that followed proved to be a significant letdown, boasting an unusual sugared rim and an overpowering, sickly sweet flavor reminiscent of prune juice. In stark contrast, my subsequent order of a honey jack on the rocks was a refreshing respite from the previous drinks, showcasing the versatility and reliability of this classic cocktail. For those seeking a more enjoyable al fresco dining experience, I would recommend Brio, offering plush seating, fire pits, and ample space for socializing, all within a welcoming atmosphere."

\"Disappointed\", \"underwhelming\", \"overpriced\" and \"over-sauced\" are all adjectives that came to mind while eating at Imadake. From reading earlier reviews here, I think we ordered all the right items (octopus balls, okonomiyaki, that fried chicken with wasabi mayo dish, jellyfish salad, black cod), but none of them were that great. The cod was rubbery, unlike at other Japanese restaurants in Montreal (for example, Azuma on St-Laurent had a wonderful black cod). The octopus balls were gummy with un-cooked tempura batter in the center and slathered in salty sauce. The okonomiyaki was so completely covered in sauce, that this was the only thing we could taste. That, and a strange, almost cornmeal-y consistency unlike any other okonomiyakis I've experienced (granted I've only had it once before, in NYC, but it was a wonderful streetfood-style dish there; here, not anything I'd recommend, even if you got the sauce on the side--which I would recommend doing, if you choose to try this dish). We didn't order anything to drink, and to the best of my knowledge, only ordered the five small dishes listed above, plus one order of mochi, and it cost us $67 before tip. I certainly won't be returning. I think this place is more about the scene, as it's got a trendy vibe to it; it's a trendy-slathered-in-oyster-sauce kind of place.

I wouldnt call this a premiere resort. The suite was small, and needed a major update to compete with other area resorts, ie. Tube television. The bathroom was very small and in one of our rooms was missing toilet paper and a working lock. The grounds looked like they needed a major paint job and some pruning of plants.  I had a lovely view of the highway, but luckily the noise was not a problem. On the upside, the kids enjoyed thw waterpark, but at times the lazy river and slides were closed. There was confusion over the opening times on Sat, which left our girls frustrated. If you are looking for a focus on kids waterpark, okay grounds and room, this will work for you.  If you are more interested in an overall resort experience, go to the Fairmont Princess.

A sans-culotte eatery in the proximate vicinity of the Olympic Stadium, offering an unremarkable culinary experience, replete with an abundance of security personnel idly loitering about the premises and a smattering of habitual patrons partaking in the establishment's offerings, notably lacking in feminine clientele, save for the singular presence of this writer, who, in point of fact, constituted the sole distaff devotee of the venue on the occasion in question.

The best thing to say is that the waitstaff is polite.  Mediocre food.  Overpriced for menu options.  If you have to eat here, buy a beer.  It will make the food better.  I ordered a quesadilla (steak) with a side of guacamole and a Coca Cola.  My soda was so anemic looking I thought it was weak tea.  I was never offered a refill.  The quesadilla looked great, despite the nearly two dollar guacamole only containing a tablespoon of guacamole.  The dried and shriveled green onion garnish was unneeded.  After attempting to eat the quesadilla, I discovered that despite the attractive appearance, the filling to cheese ratio was horrible and the entire thing fell apart and had to be eaten by fork.  The steak filling was overdone to the point of being inedible and the corn and black bean relish they put in it just made the small bit of cheese coagulate in a grainy mess.  Save yourself the money and just pick up food at Burger King.
Decent for the money, but not spectacular. Wings were overcooked and dry. \n\nThe western bacon burger was decent. Bread was good.

Expected to be satiated for a paltry sum of $50 to $60, a veritable bargain considering the quality of the fresh fish in Las Vegas, yet ironically, I left a greater amount of currency at the establishment than at the craps table, a phenomenon that can only be attributed to the capricious nature of Lady Luck herself.

The culinary offerings were indeed satisfactory, boasting an impressive freshness and meticulous preparation, but alas, the portions were regrettably diminutive, a characteristic that belied the exorbitant price point, which bordered on usury, even by the standards of the nation's capital, where prices are already egregiously inflated.

However, it must be noted that the libations were surprisingly reasonable, with my Manhattan martini being both copious and affordable, a welcome respite from the fiscal hemorrhage that threatened to deplete my bankroll.

The ambiance of the sushi bar was quite pleasant, enhanced as it was by an imposing and captivating animated display that loomed large behind the sushi chefs, casting an ethereal glow over the proceedings. The service, too, was commendable, characterized by a friendly and attentive demeanor that bespoke a commitment to excellence on the part of the wait staff.

Lastly, I must confess that the recommendations proffered by the waiter were indeed tantalizing, their flavors a true delight to my palate, and thus, I departed the premises feeling suitably sated, if still somewhat financially drained, yet determined to recoup my losses at another venue, for as the saying goes, "fortune favors the bold," and I, for one, am nothing if not intrepid in my pursuit of a favorable outcome.

This was my 2nd time at a Twin Peaks. The 1st was in Austin, TX. This one had the most unfriendly waitresses. Barely saw ours, even when needing our check. The other waitresses were clustered in the back or someplace where they couldn't be seen.\n\nAs for the food. I enjoyed a burger with fries. It was prepared the way it was described on the menu. But there is no reason for me to return to this location in Scottsdale. I can get a better burger elsewhere (Whataburger). I was hoping to see the waitresses. Not at this location, though.

The food was just good. Nothing I would write home about. I found a few things that I thought was weird. The first thing is they charge for refills. Really what is the cost to do refills. Second thing as sitting there eating my food some more people came in and them like me was their first visit. They had 9 people in their party. The lady behind the counter said that they 15 percent gratuity. How do you charge this when you have to order at the counter and they don't have to bring you refills of food or drink. \nOn the positive side the people were friendly.

Not much meat selection,  really slow,  even though,I wasn't crowded.  The meat was really some poor cuts. Ie sirloin.   The salad bar was boring. I have to say I came Here about a year ago and was really impressed.

"Following the submission of my response via electronic mail, as requested by the Customer Service Representative (CSR) below, I received a prompt and considerate reply from the CSR, who demonstrated genuine concern for my grievances. Subsequently, I engaged in a series of written correspondences, totaling two emails, with the initial CSR, as well as a second corporate representative, who augmented their colleague's efforts with an additional missive, infusing a touch of levity into our interaction. Following these exchanges, I was informed that the local district manager would initiate contact with me within the ensuing week. Unfortunately, this communication has yet to materialize, despite the lapse of several weeks since the initial exchange. My dissatisfaction with the overall customer experience remains palpable, particularly in light of the glaring disparities in service quality between the local and corporate levels of the organization. Notwithstanding my desire for no further interaction with DSW, I deemed it appropriate to provide an updated assessment of my experience, in order to ensure a comprehensive understanding of the situation."

Location is clean, service is polite and prompt. I like how they use blue film covers over the fluorescent overhead lighting to keep it from being too harsh, gives the dining room almost a lounge atmosphere.

But the food.
Salt and pepper calamari order was $7 for 14 grease-soaked pieces, without any salt or pepper. Very bland, only tasted like grease, served with cups of sweet and sour sauce? Best part was the random pieces of fried carrot used as garnish.

The "special combination" bahn mi, with a smiley-face next to it on the menu, was a huge disappointment. Meat was all stacked on one end of the sandwich. I opened it up to distribute it evenly, only to find several blackened pieces of meat- the type of coloration that looks like food that has gone bad, not blackened from cooking. Picked out several pieces, then bit in, only to encounter some crazy spicy sauce or seasoning that was so strong it made my eyes water. All I could see were jalapenos (one piece on the entire sandwich?), and I don't mind those.

 This place may be right next to my gym, and the pho may be delicious, but I will not be coming back. If you can't reliably serve unspoiled cooked meat on your sandwiches, I am not going to trust the meat cooked in your soups.

Last evening, I had the privilege of accompanying a corporate assemblage to Harvest, whereupon it became patently evident that their steadfast dedication to utilizing regionally obtained ingredients resulted in an erratic provisioning process. Our culinary experience was particularly pronounced, as they lacked a single fish entrÃ©e on their bill of fare. Furthermore, they possessed merely a duet of their steak specialty, thereby precluding them from accommodating the orders of our gathering. Additionally, they offered a mere trio of their dessert specialty, leading to an analogous predicament. They were unable to furnish a solitary request for a diet Coke, and they exhausted their inventory of straws for a single beverage. It is worth mentioning that our coterie was not considerable in size, nor was the establishment teeming with clientele. Nevertheless, it appeared that Harvest was unprepared to operate last night, which rendered the entire experience rather disheartening. Consequently, I am disinclined to patronize them again in the future.

Although we visited on a Saturday evening, we arrived around six, we were seated within 10 minutes because the restaurant was not very busy.  We were taken to a table which was not yet cleaned. After waiting a while for a waiter to take our drink order finally the manager took the order.  A nearby waiter recognized that we had been sitting for a long time without drinks or a waiter.  Because of him our waiter arrived a short time later and took our order.  We would have enjoyed our mozzarella garlic bread while we waited for our entrees, but it all arrived all together. The food, with the exception of the bread, was lukewarm at best.  While several tables around us cleared out, I never saw a busboy clear the tables.  We were disappointed by the discombobulated staff and disorganization in every step of our dining experience.  I honestly doubt I will returned this location.

Last night, while in town for business, I opted to return to Roland's, despite my previous underwhelming experience, and sample their offerings once again. Upon arriving, I was met with a substantial wait time of over 30 minutes, which led me to surmise that the restaurant's popularity had not waned since my last visit. However, upon entering the establishment, I was struck by the conspicuous absence of patrons, which seemed to be at odds with the crowded ambiance pervasive in neighboring eateries. Furthermore, I noticed that the dining area was plagued by an inadequate air conditioning system, which only served to exacerbate the already sweltering temperature and humidity levels outside.  
Despite these drawbacks, I elected to partake in a grilled vegetable sandwich and a bowl of clam chowder, both of which were merely satisfactory, mirroring my previous experience. Nevertheless, I did notice a marked improvement in the quality of service during this visit. In conclusion, my culinary excursion to Roland's left me unimpressed, and I would advise potential patrons to explore alternative dining options. Notably, the restaurant boasts an extensive selection of beers from diverse regions across the globe, which may appeal to those with a penchant for international brews.

"On February 17th, my significant other and I opted to dine at Pin Kaow 3, a locally renowned eatery in close proximity to my humble abode, prior to engaging in an evening of merriment in the city's central district...a decision that would ultimately prove to be a regrettable miscalculation! The service we received was excruciatingly sluggish, with a prolonged waiting period of 20 minutes merely to receive our beverage order, and a subsequent 20-minute delay in the arrival of our Thai yellow curry. Furthermore, our server failed to exhibit the slightest concern for our well-being, leaving us utterly ignored and disregarded throughout the duration of our meal. A resounding 'Boo' is certainly in order for such an underwhelming experience! \n\nIn light of my recent bout with influenza, which necessitated a convenient and nourishing meal option, I opted to contact Pin Kaow 3 for their acclaimed tom ka kai, accompanied by a side of sticky rice. Unfortunately, the broth arrived in a minuscule quantity, its flavor profile characterized by an excessive salt content and viscosity, prompting me to dilute it with water in order to render it palatable. This unanticipated inconvenience, coupled with the unreasonable price point of $12 for a single serving of soup and a modest side dish, left me feeling utterly dissatisfied. However, I must admit that the sticky rice, although meager in portion, possessed a pleasant warmth and texture. A silver lining, albeit a faint one, amidst an otherwise disappointing culinary escapade."

Good hotel if you just want a place to stay when you are in Vegas. Its location on the end of the Strip is convenient if you are into walking a bit. If not - take a bus, it stops right in front of the hotel. \nYou can get cheap and ok drinks at the hotel bar & the room was clean!

"An extensive array of beverages, featuring an emphasis on craft brews, graces the menu at this establishment, which, in conjunction with its ambiance reminiscent of a public house, creates a setting conducive to relaxation and socialization. However, it appears that the quality of the service does not quite live up to the standards implied by the sophisticated nature of the venue's decor and offerings, as certain patrons have expressed disappointment regarding the attentiveness and responsiveness of the staff. Furthermore, while the culinary selections available may not necessarily be deserving of unbridled enthusiasm, it is reasonable to surmise that the proprietors have made a considerable financial investment in the venture, thereby necessitating a greater attention to detail in regard to the presentation and quality of the fare provided."

This is like a more expensive, less tasty version of Macayos. 

I went here with a group of about nine people, and even though six of the nine people were present, they didn't seat us until everyone was present.  Hmm, ok.  This was on a quiet Monday evening.

We're seated and I will give credit to the server as she was very pleasant and attentive.  There was rarely a time a beverage glass was empty. 

The food leaves a lot to be desired.  I had the carne asada taco plate with a side of guacamole.  It was as if nothing had any seasoning.  I understand Americanized Mexican food, I really do, and I did not go in here with the expectation of getting super-flavorful food, but I did expect some seasoning.  

I definitely won't choose to come back here.

"Bonus points are awarded for the meticulous selection of specialty coffee beans, specifically those sourced from Verve and Forty-Ninth Parallel, however, deductions are made for the overwhelming ambiance that permeates the space, which can be perceived as pretentious or trendy. The layout presents challenges in navigating from the beverage counter to a seating area, as well as accessing the restrooms from said seating area. Although the chocolate chip cookie offered was observed to have an excessive amount of oil, it is acknowledged that certain patrons may prefer this attribute. No criticisms are expressed regarding the quality of the coffee beverages themselves; nonetheless, if one seeks a straightforward, expertly crafted espresso drink to go and does not mind enduring a delay in line, this establishment suits that purpose adequately."

DONT BELIEVE THE HYPE

OK so the reason I came here was because of all the reviews and honestly this place is not all that. First of all you have to wait for an 40 minutes or more to be seated and the service is very slow.

Only thing I liked about this place is the hurricane roll (The extra star is for this roll). The fresh was not as fresh as some reviewers said.

OH and because we were sitting thing there and talking with friends with have not seen for awhile, mind you this is shortly after we paid the bill, they asked us if there was anything else we needed kinda their way of telling us to get the eff out because there were people waiting. I am sorry but if we were at any other place, they wouldnt make us feel that way. 

They are never getting my business again. Get a bigger spot!

"My culinary excursion to Las Vegas for the annual SHOT show led me to an unanticipated extended stay at the luxurious Venetian resort. In search of an authentic Mexican dining experience, I ventured to Taqueria Canonita, a seemingly promising establishment in close proximity to the California border and catering to a diverse clientele. Upon the recommendation of the attentive wait staff, I opted for the Santa Rosa Pork Barbacoa, eagerly anticipating a savory and tender slow-cooked pork dish. Unfortunately, my gastronomic expectations were not met, as the pork was underwhelming in both flavor and texture, lacking the richness and moisture I had hoped for. In retrospect, Chipotle's barbacoa would have been a superior choice. Furthermore, the empanadas we ordered as a table failed to meet our expectations, lacking the desired crispiness, while the guacamole accompanying the tortilla chips was inadequately mashed. Such inconsistencies proved detrimental to the restaurant's reputation, rendering it unsuitable for discerning patrons. However, the tequila offered a welcome respite from the disappointing cuisine."

An apt moniker for a once-enjoyable and frequented breakfast joint. Somewhere along the line, this place lost the plot. Needless to say, I will not be making any new memories here.

Rating Scale:
1 Star: Avoid the town in which this place is located just to be safe.  
2 Star: With so many great places to choose from, why risk this one?
3 Star: I'll try it again or consume here in a pinch.
4 Star: I go here regularly if financially and/or calorically feasible.
5 Star: I look forward to taking my wife or friends here.

This gym is ok. I don't like that the cleaning people always seem to be in my way and yet nothing seems clean. The women's locker room is always disgusting. The gym itself seems to be a bit small and stuffy in my opinion. I wish it was a little wider and had more open space instead of all the cluttering of machines and equipment. The front desk girls seem to be clueless and are not the happiest girls. Except for like two of the girls, I think one of them is named Candice or Candy.

This place gets 2 stars because of the amenities!!! The pool area was worth a lot more than our massages. We got a 50 minute couples massage which was $300, they automatically add your 20% tip in (which I don't agree with considering I am in a customer service based occupation) the spa is beautiful, but there was no area to see each other prior, men's and women's areas are separated, and it seemed very rushed. We both asked for deep tissue and got nothing of the sort. The massage was lackluster and frustrating. I have very bad knots in my shoulders and she never even rubbed my shoulders, so I walked away with so sense of relief?!?! I would not go back to this spa, even if we come back for future trips with the timeshare. I will likely find another spa in scottsdale off of the JW Marriott resort.

Another annoying Scottsdale establishment. 

I gave it 2 stars because the food was tasty, not great--but good. 
The service on the other hand was horrible at best. The restaurant was freezing!! We requested they shut the back door to prevent the draft of cold air pouring in and was ignored. It was lunch time on a Monday and we were only the 2nd table to be seated, I wasn't sure why our request went ignored. 

Shortly after taking our drink order our server vanished for almost 15 minutes. After which did not bring any of us water. We then placed our 2nd, 3rd and 4th request for water and finally receiving it the same time as our entrees. Would you like extra salsa? Too bad, the waitress never was to be seen again till my friend got up and approached the bar to have her soda refilled. It took her this long to realized we were annoyed. The food could have been the most amazing thing ever, but due to the lack of service I will NEVER go back.

You will discover here a plethora of gastronomical options, including but not limited to:

1) Subpar, frostbitten sashimi that lacks the freshness and quality one would expect from a reputable establishment serving raw fish.

2) Scallops that have the potential to induce adverse gastrointestinal effects due to questionable handling and storage practices.

3) A dining area reminiscent of a witches' coven, creating an unsettling ambiance that may or may not enhance your culinary experience, depending on personal preferences.

A detailed explanation of the third point follows:

The cuisine offered can be classified as average Americanized sushi, garnering a rating of three stars at best. The ambiance, while unconventional, has the potential to elevate the overall experience to a respectable 3.5 stars. However, the exceptional quality of the service unfortunately warrants a reduction in rating to a mere two stars.

The wait staff, comprised of Chinese individuals, engage in surreptitious and unethical practices, such as covertly peddling inferior alcoholic beverages to unsuspecting patrons, including myself and my colleagues. This reprehensible behavior necessitates a decrease in rating.

In conclusion, Hiro offers superior dining options for those seeking a truly satisfying culinary experience.

"The patrons' ardent affection for the establishment's coffee beverages is palpable, as they throng the premises during peak hours, creating an extended queue that reaches the entrance. Notwithstanding the prolonged delay, I opt to procure my caffeinated beverage elsewhere, as the waiting time proves prohibitive. However, I habitually purchase coffee beans at this location for home brewing. The management could consider implementing a separate station for expedited service, dedicated solely to accommodating straightforward coffee orders, thereby augmenting efficiency and potentially enhancing customer satisfaction, thereby increasing revenue."

I really wanted to like this place.  It is a fun looking place.  We were there when it was slow.  The downstairs bartender was friendly.  We went upstairs when our friends arrived.  The service was slow, food was boring.  We had a variety of dishes.  This place has potential but they need to bring up the food flavor and service.

"The lodging facility in question does not conform to the traditional definition of a resort, as it is, in fact, an apartment complex that has been adapted for use as a motel. Furthermore, during our stay, we did not have access to air conditioning, which rendered the interior of our room uncomfortably warm, particularly given the external temperature of approximately 60 degrees Fahrenheit in February. When I inquired about this issue, I was informed that the establishment did not possess any air conditioning units and that the thermostat was merely a cosmetic feature that produced a modicum of warm air upon activation. Although the staff members were amicable, the oppressive ambient temperature significantly detracted from our overall comfort level."

This airport is dirty, ridiculous, and not user friendly. What I mean by user friendly is... they need more outlets around the airport, so folks traveling for business can plug their lap tops and cell phones into for charging.  If you have a lay over here... good luck! I hope you're not late! You'll be walking a good mile before you reach your destination. As if traveling isn't already stressful. This airport adds to the stress... not to mention, you have slots machines every where- lose money quickly if you dare.

It has been about 6 years since we dined at streets of New York. This time we ordered a thin and crispy pizza, a Caesar salad and bread knots. From my memory the pizza was better than I remember but not great.   However, the salad was not edible in fact we took it back.  The romain was brown and at least 4 or five days past it's prime.   They took it back without any Question and comped us a piece cheesecake in good faith.  Who ever prepared our meal should be totally embarrassed....        I don't think we will go back..

slow to leave the airport. waited about 20-30 minutes for the shuttle to fill up before we left.

calling for a pick-up wasnt very helpful. they say the shuttle can arrive within a 15 minute window and then take up to an HOUR to get you to the airport. i sucked it up and just had a taxi take me. well worth it the money.

don't recommend this company unless they improve their efficiency.

they do get 2 starts because of their cheap rates. cant beat it if you don't mind waiting

My wife, son and I have been going to Casey Jones now for quite some time, however this most recent time we went the quality of everything kinda seemed to jump off a steep cliff.   We went in with some friends the other night and ordered some of their newest burger the \"Juicy Lucy\", after ordering them medium, we were rewarded with two burgers that not only seemed to be bleeding but the cheese the oozed out of them reminded me of a horror flick where the guy gets stabbed and his guts just pour out.   After taking the burgers back to the kitchen and being assured the would be taken care of, the burgers deffinately came back cooked... almost with a propane torch, talk about hockey pucks! and to top it off we didn't even get cheese in the new burgers making them not so.. Juicy ya know.   Where as before I would have preached this place to others, I can honestly say we won't be making a return trip until they get a better cook in the kitchen, didn't think it was possible to botch a burger, let alone four! this place has astounded me in the wrong direction =/

So, we received at $20 off coupon in the mail and decided to give it a try.  Let's just say...it's been some months since then and we haven't been back...the only time this place has popped up on my radar was when a co-worker was talking about their lackluster experience, too.\n\nThe service was fine.  It was the food that got me.  I ordered cheese enchilada's and my girlfriend ordered the chicken enchilada's.  Now, I expected cheese...but I didn't think I was going to have to go on a search mission to locate the tortillas. My girlfriend was equally displeased with her meal. The sangria I ordered was the only saving grace...not good enough to return, though...

"While the culinary offerings at this establishment were undoubtedly delectable, the exorbitant prices charged for what essentially constituted a meal of galbi and meat left much to be desired in terms of value for money. Furthermore, the restaurant's menu, both in its antiquated and modern iterations, perpetuated an egregious error by claiming that certain dishes included a sweet treat, only to renege on that promise when the time came to present the bill. Such inconsistencies in communication are utterly perplexing and detract significantly from the overall dining experience, thereby warranting a deduction of one or two stars. Additionally, it is recommended that patrons visit this venue solo or in pairs to optimize the value proposition, as the quantity of side dishes and seafood pancake remains static regardless of the number of diners at the table."

"It has been an appreciable duration since my last visit to Dos Gringos, or perhaps this particular establishment is inferior in terms of cleanliness compared to the Tempe location, but my recent experience at this venue was utterly disappointing. The lavatory facilities were emitting an unpleasant odor, and the overall ambiance seemed grimy and unkempt. I would not consider partaking in culinary indulgences from this establishment, given that the state of their bar area raises concerns about the cleanliness of their kitchen. Frankly, I am perplexed by the preference of some individuals to frequent such an uninviting atmosphere when there are numerous alternative destinations in Scottsdale that offer a more enjoyable and sanitary experience."

I have been to this Jasons Deli several times, it has always been good.  We have ordered delivery from here several times, it has always been very delicious.  I ordered delivery from here today, and it was very forgetable.  The butter croissant that held my turkey sandwich together was really dried out, it was actually breaking as I ate it, it was that dry.  I have said before that they have the best brownies I have ever had....... Just not today. The brownies were overcooked,  one of them actually tasted burned.... they were very dry, not moist and fudgy the way they have been, when I have had them before.  Everything was disappointing about this meal...... it might be awhile before I order from here again.

Outrageously priced. I get they have state of the art equipment but we couldn't afford to use any of it. While the staff is super friendly we did have one of the doctors say, after we couldn't pay to have anymore tests done, that it wouldn't be bad if we choose to put our dog down. I have no idea how a person can be so cold. Do no harm, right? Our dog only stayed 24 hours at the place and it ran us around $2000. We took our dog somewhere else that was much more affordable and they saved his life. He stayed at the other place for about a week. Same treatment and it cost us less than the one day at VCA.

"Upon entering the establishment, I noticed that they possessed an array of cosmetic lines; however, the abundance of products available for purchase was unfortunately meager during my visit. Specifically, the selection of items from MAC, the brand I was seeking, was quite limited and many of the products were either already opened, damaged, or appeared to have been heavily utilized. Furthermore, the quality of customer service I received was subpar. The trio of employees stationed at the cash register failed to acknowledge my presence or offer any assistance, leaving me feeling ignored and disheartened. Consequently, I will be venturing to the interior location in the future, hoping to find a more extensive range of options."

"Satisfactory victuals at a reasonable cost. We visited this establishment in the early hours of a Friday morning, following our arrival in Las Vegas. Despite the lateness of the hour, the venue was bustling with activity; however, we were promptly accommodated. I opted to partake in the 7 oz. steak, accompanied by hash browns, eggs, and toast, which I shared with my companion due to my limited appetite. The steak presented a dichotomy of doneness, with one half being well done and the other half falling somewhere between medium and medium-well; we had requested the latter, but such minor inconsistencies were inconsequential given the affordable price point of less than $4. The hash browns lacked the desired crispiness, while the toast was satisfactory, and the eggs fell within the realm of mediocrity. A cursory examination of the culinary offerings revealed an absence of sodium, a characteristic seemingly tailored to the preferences of the mature clientele that frequent this establishment. In summary, this restaurant serves as a suitable option for those seeking sustenance following a night of revelry or for individuals who prefer a more relaxed dining experience, but it does not qualify as a premier gastronomic destination."

Ate dinner there last week. While the food was OK, it is pretty expensive. Side dishes are an extra $11.00+. 

Service, however, is another story. Our original servers numbered 3. The primary server was rude and arrogant, and smiling seemed beyond her capabilities. We could have tolerated this but when the busboy reached across my wife to take my plate, I was flabbergasted. I called him on it, telling him he should know better. Then the manager came by and we addressed the service issues with him. He was apologetic and changed our waitstaff so that our service was much better.

My issue... at a restaurant of this quality and price you should never have to complain to get good service. There are so many high quality restaurants available on the Las Vegas strip, why would you waste your time and money on a place that can't maintain high quality service throughout? My suggestion: find another place for dinner!!

I had dinner at Leroy Fox tonight.  This site used to house the old Hotel Charlotte.

The rennovation was very impressive.  The restaurant was very nice and it was good to see that they had incorporated parts of the old restaurant into the decor of the new restaurant.

The restaurant was packed solid.  The noise level was probably the most negative aspect of the experience.  In addition to the already deafening noise level, live music started up and it soon became impossible to hear the conversation at our table.

I had the "north" chicken which consisted of a breast and a wing.  It was fried and was quite good.  The chicken comes with a choice of a side item.

The menu looked quite good.  The service was also good, but I believe the kitchen got backed up with orders since the restaurant was full.

I wouldn't recommend going to this restaurant, if you have hopes of having normal conversation with the people at your table.

This was a very oridnary hotel, nothing especial. It did not match our expectation of a four star hotel in Vegas. We stayed there for one night, then for the same price we got another hotel that was much better.

I'm giving BJ's 2 stars because the food is pretty darn good when they get the order right. I've been to this BJ's about 7 times and each time (except once) they have failed to give me what I ordered on the first try. I always come in with a group of people from work and we fax our order in before we get there. The kitchen has our order, in writing, right in front of them and still can't execute it properly. I know a veggie pizza with no cheese is a terribly complicated concept but come on! EVERY TIME! I've gotten it delivered with cheese and I've even gotten it delivered without the cheese but with sausage added! Sausage?!\n\nThe wait staff is always apologetic but the kitchen here seems to be inept.

I wanted to love this restaurant and was very excited to try it. First off the place is small and they seem to have crammed as many tables in as humanly possible. While I get this from a business standpoint it is uncomfortable from a customers standpoint. My husband and I had lunch there on a monday and we could barely hear each other. We arrived early and I can only imagine how loud it gets during the noon hour. The menu was pretty limited. My husband ordered the turkey sandwich and I ordered the grilled cheese BLT. The bill for 2 sandwiches and one fountain drink was just shy of $20.00.  Service seemed a little slow, it was nearly 20 minutes from ordering to being served. When we did finally get our food it was just ok. The bacon on mine was hard and oily and had a quality as if it had been sitting out for awhile. My husband's sandwich was missing the vegetables and mustard that were indicated in the description but after waiting 20 minutes he wasn't going to send it back. Overall the place is loud and mediocre, not worthy of the price. My husband lamented that for the same price we could have gone to Capriottis and I had to agree with him.

"The entire assortment of pre-owned vinyls showcased within this establishment's confines are, for all intents and purposes, dilapidated and worn items, with price tags ranging from a meager $5 to an exorbitant amount beyond that threshold, and it is utterly deplorable to note that the quality of clientele interaction is not merely subpar but thoroughly unacceptable, thus impelling me to formulate the unequivocal decision of abstaining from future visits to this purported hub of musical indulgence."

As a San Francisco bay area resident, I thought it would be interesting to try Asian cuisine in Montreal's Chinatown District. Beijing came up as a highly YELP rated place. And, so we gave them a shot. \nTypical, super noisy, large open room, that has too many tables and chairs packed into it. We ordered the Chicken Soo Guy. The server described Soo Guy as a 'special Asian sauce\" . . .UH, your typical sweet and sour sauce is not what I would call \"special\". . . sorry, didn't like it one bit.
