The spicy beef had a bit of flavor, but that was only because we asked for it to come out \"SUPER\" spicy. . . What's it like in the normal preparation?  All in all, I was not impressed with this place, and would not return.

I have availed myself of OnTrac delivery services for an assortment of packages originating from Amazon Prime shipping, however, on a few occasions, they have failed to meet their obligations in a timely manner. Specifically, on the first occasion, they were unable to effectuate delivery subsequent to my payment of an additional fee of 3.99 for expedited delivery, and on the second instance, their tracking information indicated "out for delivery" followed by "UNDELIVERABLE - OTHER REASONS" and then "REDELIVER ON NEXT BUSINESS DAY". 
  The delivery individual could not furnish a reasonable explanation for the non-delivery of my package, leading me to surmise that he was running behind schedule and elected to postpone its delivery until the following business day. Moreover, the initial delivery person who began delivering packages to me displayed a consistent lack of friendliness, failing to return my smile and express gratitude when I received the package, responding only with a grumpy demeanor and hastily departing. 
  It is imperative that OnTrac invests in the proper training of their delivery staff in the realm of customer service skills. Although they generally perform their duties effectively, their shortcomings in comparison to the likes of UPS or FedEx preclude me from assigning them a rating exceeding two stars.

When I went to the recently opened Panera on Friday evening, I knew we were in trouble when my young friend ordered the chicken noodle soup in a bread bowl. \"We're out of bread bowls,\" snapped the staff member taking orders. My friend, who had been yearning for soup in a bread bowl ever since she heard about it, finally settled on a classic salad with chicken and I ordered a Thai chicken flat bread sandwich. We made our way down a narrow passage way into the table area. The decor is blah with bad lighting and none of the empty tables had been wiped off. While waiting for our food, I went to the restroom, which clearly had not been recently cleaned and a huge cylinder of toilet paper was set on top of the empty dispenser. Our food arrived and the person in charge of the kitchen must have been friends with the decorator -- blah. Granted the prices are cheaper than Paradise and the excellent Wildflower but for a lot less money we stopped at Frys on the way home and bought a La Brea Olive Oil and Rosemary round loaf and a can of Progresso chicken noodle soup. Now that was a tasty mean!

"Our culinary experiences at this establishment have been largely satisfactory, with the exception of our most recent visit on a Thursday, which happened to coincide with their burger night promotion. Unfortunately, the preparation of my hamburger was executed prematurely, resulting in a dining experience that was diametrically opposed to our expectations, as the meat was desiccated, lukewarm, and somewhat challenging to ingest. Similarly, the poultry dish we ordered was also afflicted by an unfortunate dearth of moisture and tenderness, making it arduous to consume. In contrast, our previous encounters with their hamburgers have been characterized by their freshness, juiciness, and satisfying temperature. It is worth noting that the cooking method employed by this restaurant, which involves precooking the meat and allowing it to sit in a pan, is not optimal for creating an enjoyable dining experience. In fact, this practice is reminiscent of the methods employed by certain fast-food chains, such as McDonald's. Therefore, we must express our disappointment with the quality of the food and service we received during our most recent visit, which warrants a rating of two stars."

"While it may appear to be a unique establishment, upon closer inspection, it becomes evident that this venue does not offer anything particularly remarkable, unless one is an uninformed tourist seeking novel experiences. The overly saccharine nature of their confectionaries, coupled with the exorbitant prices, renders them unworthy of consumption. Furthermore, the notion that a lollipop holder designed by Katy Perry would warrant a price tag of $25 is utterly preposterous. In conclusion, this location receives two stars, one for its mildly amusing decor and another for providing a modest seating area for patrons to partake in their overpriced treats."

I was very disappointed with my first (and now probably only) experience at Hepatica. I came in to get half a dozen roses and it took almost half an hour, even though I was the only customer in the store. They also threw in greens with large, noticeable bug bites, without mentioning the added cost until they'd already charged me for the flowers. They even mentioned to charge my card twice, which was part of why it took so long.

Last night was the second time I tried it, and still have the same problem. 1. Dough has an uncooked taste 2.they only have a red sauce for the pizza, and that just leads to much acid in my system. So I will stick to making my own our will stick to dominos who at least uses real Spinach not out of a can! So gross!

While it was nice to see vegan options, they were very limited and the assumption seemed to be that vegans really miss meat and dairy.  The food was good, but not great.  The drinks were average at best a drink will cost you more than the meal.  The staff was rushed and unpleasant; the host that was attempting to look like a secret service agent with his earplug and inappropriate suit was obnoxious and rude.  It wasn't worth the money and I probably wouldn't go back.  The noise and smoke from the casino will make any meal less enjoyable.

A few of us went here for lunch on a Friday and while the food was very good the service was very slow and inattentive.   \n\nI had the Blue Petit Mignon and the portion size was just right for lunch.

"The culinary offerings are indeed exceptional, but unfortunately, the quality of the service has precipitously declined in recent times. Upon placing an order, we were informed that the estimated time of delivery would be thirty minutes; however, it took twice as long for the food to arrive. Moreover, only half of the items we ordered were included in the delivery, and when we brought this to the attention of the management, we were met with a dismissive and unhelpful attitude. It has now been an hour and a half since the initial order was placed, and we are still awaiting the completion of our meal, for which we have already compensated in full. This experience has been utterly disappointing and disillusioning, and we can only hope that the establishment will take necessary steps to rectify these issues and restore their reputation for providing excellent service."

I was experiencing an intense craving for some alcohol-infused noodles, and upon observing that this establishment was in close proximity, I decided to venture inside and partake in their offerings. However, upon arriving at 10:58, I discovered that the premises were still unoccupied, and thus, I chose to kill time by visiting a nearby dollar store. Upon my return at 11:14, I was somewhat taken aback to discover that the entrance remained unlocked, leading me to speculate that the staff member who had recently entered the building had done so with her personal belongings still in hand. My curiosity was piqued when I placed an order for takeout drunken noodles and inquired about the expected preparation time, which was estimated to be a mere five minutes. I found myself in a state of flux, unsure whether to feel elated or apprehensive about the impending culinary experience. It became apparent that the dish was prepared using pre-existing materials, as the aroma emanating from the kitchen suggested a blend of recycled oil and stale flavors. As a novice in the realm of Thai cuisine, I cannot profess to be an authority on its authenticity; however, my previous encounters with drunken noodles in San Diego have left me with a lingering desire to sample a comparable dish in this region. Unfortunately, this particular establishment failed to meet my expectations, as the dish was not only lacking in freshness but also imbued with an unpleasant odor reminiscent of aged mothballs.

HORRIBLE customer service. My sister and I went there after having no success at finding a brides maid dress from David's Bridal. No one greeted us. After browsing for 10 minutes I finally had to find someone to help us. I told her what we were looking for and she just brushed us off. It was a terrible experience. That alone caused them to lose our business. They get 2 stars because the dresses were beautiful and they had a decent amount of accessories to chose from. I would never suggest this place to anyone.

It was okay. The server at the counter was more concerned with the call-in orders, which I guess is more common at this location due to the small amount of tables, but disappointing. It took me over 5 minutes to place my order. After being seated, with no one else there, I retrieved my order and was satisfied, but not impressed. The meal was very greasy & the rice and egg roll were so over-cooked. Won't bother again.

Dropped $300 for my spouse and I to get in, it was entertaining but altogether not necessarily worth the price.  Then I discovered that we were among the handful of people who actually had to pay to get in, which was kind of a gut punch as cocktails are tremendously expensive.

A very interesting stage show, some of the players interact with the audience, but the price point is very out of proportion to the actual performances.

If you're amongst the lucky majority that received a complimentary admission, go take a peek but I heavily suggest avoiding this place unless you smoke $90 cigars lit with $20 bills.

The performance art was entertaining and the interaction with the audience brought out a "third dimension" to the show.  Think of well-dressed street performers, a little bit of "Tap Dogs", a little "Blue Man Group"-ish.

I don't want to say it's a rip, but it's certainly priced for the Romanovs and not exactly worth the tremendous entry fee, especially when most of the club seemed as if they were there on comps.

Feeling a little jaded and, well, financially leeched.

It's a stage show and then a standard night club. If you morphed the marquee with a sprinkle of cabaret and a very light touch of Cirque du Soleil, drop $300 for a couple, there you have rose rabbit lie.

I like the ambiance and feel of Grassroots - however, the cook has a bit of an attitude. \nWhen I explained this was the second time I had come in and they were out of what I  wanted to order he said because everything is fresh. Ok-I can appreciate and love that! However, I was asking for a baked potato. How can you be out of baked potatoes? That seems pretty standard. He then went on to say they are doing pretty well.....what?? How about just apologizing for not being able to accommodate your customer. Lose the attitude.  Food is par - I would recommend this place for drinks only.

We ceased frequenting the Sunset road venue of this establishment in Las Vegas approximately a year ago due to a decline in culinary quality. Upon the opening of a novel branch on Stephanie St In Henderson, we decided to accord it an additional opportunity, misguided as it turned out. Gigantic blunder! The steaks were not prepared in accordance with our instructions, even after being cooked for a second time. The assistance was also subpar. The sole redeeming features were the bread and salmon. Disillusionment of substantial proportions, Outback...

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
On a recent Friday evening, my spouse and I visited this establishment with high hopes of enjoying an excellent dinner; regrettably, our expectations were not met. The food was merely passable and overpriced, which was particularly disheartening given the high standards we had set for our dining experience.

The mixed drinks were reasonably priced at ten dollars apiece, but their flavor profiles failed to impress us. They lacked a certain je ne sais quoi that we have come to expect from establishments of this caliber.

Our servers appeared to be inexperienced, which detracted from the overall quality of our meal. Their service was less than polished, giving the impression that they were recently hired staff still finding their footing in the industry.

Moving on to the main event, the cuisine left much to be desired. Our New York strip steak arrived in a meager portion, which was problematic for my robust appetite. Although its flavor was satisfactory, it fell short of our expectations regarding quantity. My wife's sandwich, cooked to a medium temperature, was also underwhelming. Unfortunately, it was served rare, necessitating its return after a protracted wait of ten minutes.

In conclusion, our dining experience was subpar, with each dish costing approximately forty dollars. Considering the high prices and lackluster quality, we were left feeling disappointed and underwhelmed.

I went here once because one of the Pitt clubs was doing a fundraiser here, and I'm not sure if it was just this location, but I wasn't impressed. 

I got a pumpernickel bagel with plain cream cheese. The bagel was thin and pretty bland. There was barely any cream cheese on there, and what WAS there was poorly spread around. 

The location is good and it's cheap, but you'd have better luck going to Einstein's bagels, or even getting a Panera bagel- instead.

"Acknowledged, we are all cognizant of the merchandise; it has an appearance of being costly, and its expensiveness seems to be appealing to everyone...\nHowever, my recent experience with the customer service was problematic. I must confess, I have visited this store previously, and the encounter was satisfactory, but this particular instance was not. Upon entering the establishment, I noticed a sign positioned at the entrance, indicating a discount of forty percent on a single item for men, without any further specifications. (It was intended for Father's Day.) Consequently, I selected a shirt and proceeded to the checkout line. After waiting patiently, I approached the cashier, only to be informed that the item I had chosen was not part of the promotion, as it was recently introduced. I then expressed my desire to return the item. The cashier uttered some words, which I could not decipher whether they were addressed to me or to her headset. She eventually stated that they would still honor the discount. Throughout the entire transaction, the cashier did not make any eye contact, nor did she extend a greeting or express gratitude. In fact, it was I who offered a 'thank you.' The interaction gave the impression that I was imposing upon them by purchasing the shirt! The level of friendliness and courtesy displayed by TSA agents far surpasses that of the cashier's behavior."

While there are, admittedly, fewer tourists down this end of the royal mile, its still clear that the World's End pub is a tourist orientated place looking to cash in on its varied and often grousome and scary past. 

Basically, this place is over priced and so geared to recieving people who are only visiting the city, it seems to forget about us locals. My friends and I were slightly put off by the fact the bar staff asked if we were tourists before moving to another group who were hwen we answered no. Kind of like we had said 'No, we arent tourists, but we are willing to wait until you have served the millions who are.' Not a good experience.

However, once we had been served, we had a pleasent time - but I wont be back.

"It is comprehensible that individuals possess an affinity towards this establishment, as the restaurant offers copious amounts of food, and the presentation of the dishes on the plates is aesthetically pleasing. However, it is unfortunate that the extensive waiting period detracts from the quality of the service, and the culinary offerings are often characterized by an excessive amount of oil and lack a fresh, vibrant taste. Furthermore, the menu does not provide a wide range of health-conscious options, which may be a drawback for some patrons. Nonetheless, it is apparent that the majority of individuals who dine out in Las Vegas are not seeking healthful meals, and thus, the popularity of this location can be understood."

This is probably one place that is a hit or miss for me. Visiting from Chicago, I was excited to see how Asian fare would be in comparison. Satay has a clean and cozy ambiance to it when you walk in. I came with a big group and unfortunately that probably contributed to my overall experience here. We attempted to wait for  everyone's dishes to come out but that was a bad idea. All of our food got cold because it took a good 50 min for everyone's dishes to come out after the first person getting theirs. Eventually we stopped waiting but all those who waited already had cold dishes in front of them.\n\nAside from that, my food and the flavors itself was not really anything out of the ordinary. I ordered chicken pad thai, a pretty basic and popular dish that really cant go wrong. Mine came out pretty bland unfortunately. I don't really see myself coming back here on my next visit unless its for happy hour or something.

Ok. The two stars are because the floors had many sticky diseases on it. WTF? Don't they clean the floors? But the bartenders did make me forget about the nastiness with the strong and cheap drinks. That was the only reason it didn't get one star. I'd go back if I'm in Champaign again.

Update - finally went to the new Lincoln Square Mall location. The decor is just awful, which is sad considering how nice the old place was. Cramped seating, depressing track lighting, drop ceilings, weird art right behind your seats so you keep bumping into it. They were out of the first two things I ordered (one was a special, so fine, but out of a basic bread-based app?)\n\nPasta took forever to come out, and my friend's was so cold that the cream sauce had congealed. Sigh.

During Restaurant Week, we reserved a table for six individuals through OpenTable and indulged in a culinary excursion encompassing a variety of dishes. Our party opted for the appetizer sampler, which featured an assortment of delectable delights such as fish tacos, bacon-wrapped bacon and eggs, and chicken pot pie nuggets. Although the chicken pot pie nuggets lacked a certain je ne sais quoi in terms of flavor, perhaps a pinch of salt would have sufficed, the remaining dishes within the sampler platter proved satisfying. For our entrees, we selected the crispy fried game hen and shrimp and grits, while the other half of our party chose the Niman skirt steak. Unfortunately, these dishes failed to leave a lasting impression on our palates, with the exception of the bacon-wrapped bacon and egg appetizer, which demonstrated a remarkable balance of savory and rich flavors.

Midway through our meal, we finally received our sides, specifically zucchini and mac and cheese, upon request. The dessert menu presented a duo of tantalizing options: freshly baked cookies accompanied by milk or a trio of refreshing sorbets. While the cookies boasted an undeniable charm, their quality seemed unremarkable, mirroring something one could easily concoct in the comfort of their own kitchen.

Upon receipt of our check, we were taken aback by the various supplementary fees we had not previously been cognizant of, including a charitable donation in conjunction with Restaurant Week and an upcharge for the appetizer sampler. My extensive investigation of the restaurant's online menu failed to reveal any mention of such an upcharge fee, nor were we apprised of it during the ordering process. Moreover, the restaurant increased the price from $40 to $50, rendering our dining experience even more disappointing. In retrospect, we would have benefited from selecting a different establishment for Restaurant Week or opting for individual dishes from the standard menu. Despite the underwhelming experience, the Jameson mule cocktail proved quite satisfying.

"Our culinary excursion to Rustic Cafe this morning was motivated by its ostensibly impressive 4-star rating, which we believed would be an accurate reflection of the eatery's quality, given the generally reliable nature of Yelp reviews. Unfortunately, our expectations were not entirely met, as the dining experience fell somewhat short of our standards. Both my spouse and I opted for omelets, which, while filled with various ingredients, were regrettably saturated with oil. Moreover, the hash browns accompanying my husband's dish were unpleasantly cold. Our overall satisfaction with the restaurant was limited, to say the least, and we were left feeling somewhat underwhelmed. Notwithstanding, the prices charged were reasonable. However, I must admit that my uncompromising stance on the quality of orange juice served at establishments of this kind led me to deduct a star from my overall rating, as the OJ provided was unmistakably derived from concentrate, a fact that I find difficult to reconcile, particularly when considering the $3 price tag."

"Underwhelming experience at Terzetto Steakhouse Las Vegas. 

The M Resort Spa Casino boasts an upscale eatery, Terzetto Steakhouse, exuding sophistication and elegance in its ambiance and interior design, reminiscent of high-end restaurants found further north on the renowned Las Vegas Strip. Despite its visually stunning appearance, the menu lacks innovation and creativity, offering only traditional steakhouse dishes. 

A group of seven guests were impressed by the exceptional service provided by their server, who demonstrated punctuality, attentiveness, and helpfulness, despite the restaurant not being fully booked. However, the culinary offerings failed to meet expectations, with steaks lacking rich beef flavor and a satisfying char. Although priced lower than premium steakhouses, the quality did not match the value. The sides were satisfactory but unremarkable. 

In conclusion, Terzetto Steakhouse presented an underwhelming dining experience, with disappointing food quality and unimpressive sides, despite its attractive atmosphere and excellent service."

"I crave an enhancement in the quality of Tom's eatery, but alas, it fails to meet my expectations. Despite its ambiance reminiscent of a beloved television show and commendable customer service, the culinary offerings leave much to be desired. Specifically, my grilled cheese sandwich, a seemingly straightforward dish, falls short in terms of both flavor and presentation. A dearth of butter on the bread and a solitary slice of American cheese hardly constitutes a satisfying meal, especially given the nomenclature of the dish itself. Furthermore, the exorbitant price point of $12 for a mediocre grilled cheese, fries, and iced tea only serves to augment my disappointment. Notwithstanding, I must acknowledge the attentive nature of the servers. In conclusion, while Tom's may possess an extensive menu boasting numerous options for non-carnivores, my hurried demeanor precluded me from exploring said choices and warranted a more streamlined approach. Moreover, I lament the lack of vegetarian-friendly establishments and implore restaurateurs to broaden their menus to accommodate the dietary preferences of all patrons."

Wow did this place suck. I came here for lunch with a work collesfur. I am from out of town but this was the closest place and it did nothing for me. Dirty interior, poor service. I just got a chicken salad and it was not memorable.

I've been here a few times because it's close to my job.  The lady that works in the front is really nice but the food is just alright.  I've never had a major complaint but today my food was not good.  I ordered shrimp fried rice for lunch and it's different, maybe a new cook or they change the oil.  It smells really good but has no taste whatsover.  Even after adding soy sauce and pepper it's unedible.  I'm so surprised because I love fried rice and who can mess that up.  Now I have to find something else to eat for lunch.

Having been told just yesterday about Batch and the fact that they make different types of fougasse breads, I raced over today to try them out.  I am a sucker for great fougasse, and try them out whenever I see them at a bakery.  The trouble is, they are not always so good!  Alas, the Madison fougasse lived up to my fears. Having created something more like a pizza crust in the shape of a pretzel, the Batch Bakehouse would be better advised to stick with less ambitious treats, like the sinful \"Hello Dolly\" 7-layer bar...  Though, of course, I DID manage to consume this  roasted garlic/sundried tomato/rosemary pretzel in disguise, it was heavy and way too chewy, not achieving the standard of firm exterior but soft interior.

"Fuel Pizza situated in the epicenter of Charlotte's upscale district merits a solitary star for its geographical location and an additional stellar accolade for the hospitable demeanor displayed by its staff. Unfortunately, the culinary offerings themselves are rather uninspired and lacking in depth of flavor, with the accompanying side salad boasting a vibrant palette yet lamentably devoid of an adequate dressing to elevate it to a truly satisfactory level. It is utterly perplexing that such unremarkable fare is offered at a premium price point, especially when juxtaposed with the establishment's tantalizing combo meals which, regrettably, fail to deliver on their promised gustatory satisfaction. A veritable gastronomical travesty! For a mere $6.50, one can indulge in a colossal, mouthwatering slice of pizza that rivals even the most exquisite culinary masterpieces. Conversely, at Fuel Pizza, the cost of a single serving surpasses $8.00, inclusive of a beverage and a paltry portion of pizza that fails to satiate one's hunger. It is my conviction that Sabarro's, a nearby eatery, offers a superior dining experience for only a marginally higher tariff. The ambiance of Fuel Pizza, while intriguing, appears unfinished and somewhat disjointed. Furthermore, the facilities designated for personal hygiene are spotless yet aesthetically displeasing, marred by unsightly graffiti and haphazardly positioned sanitary fixtures. In light of its prime location within Charlotte's bustling business district, one would expect a theme restaurant such as Fuel Pizza to maintain a more polished and refined appearance. Alas, the overall atmosphere is chaotic and visually unappealing, eliciting feelings of chagrin and disappointment in those who have the misfortune of partaking in its offerings."

"The accommodations were adequate, but lacked any distinguishing features that would have elevated them beyond the realm of mediocrity. The personnel, however, exhibited a commendable level of cordiality and hospitality. Unfortunately, the parking facility adjacent to the establishment exuded an unsettling ambiance, which was further accentuated by its eerie illumination. The aquatic recreational areas, while ostensibly designed to provide a relaxing respite for guests, failed to impress this particular patron. Moreover, the presence of an adult boutique situated directly across the street from the hotel served to enhance the overall sense of unease and discomfort that permeated the surrounding environment. Despite its proximity to various points of interest, I would not consider returning to this lodging establishment in the future."

"Initially, the service was satisfactory, albeit somewhat sluggish. The wait staff member exhibited remarkable cordiality, whereas the culinary specialist in charge of managing the kitchen operations opted to offer a pecuniary reduction on our entire bill due to the prolonged waiting period surpassing three quarters of an hour for our midday repast selections. However, the carbonated beverage and citrus-flavored liquid refreshment did not meet my expectations in terms of flavor, prompting me to return them thrice. The complementary tortilla chips and tangy dip were relatively palatable. I opted for the mixed grill consisting of both bovine and avian components. Unfortunately, the beef exuded an intense sweetness akin to teriyaki sauce, while the poultry was overcooked, resulting in an unpleasant dining experience. Therefore, it is unlikely that I shall revisit this establishment in the future."

This is not an experience for a tourist.  It's for people with a kitchen.  Walking around, I noticed very few stalls offering samples, and there was next to nothing in the way of ready-to-eat food like you see at many other markets.  Maybe I'm spoiled because Pike Place is my market.\n\nAlso, surprisingly small.  I figured this is the South, and the warmer climates produce a greater variety of food year-round.  It's held in a relatively small parking lot next to Old Town.

After so much initial Yelp praise, I decided to drop into Nourish to give it a shot. I'm not a vegetarian or vegan or glucose or lactose free, but I am a pretty healthy eater and enjoy delicious food that also happens to be good for you. Nourish seemed like it fit a great need for its niche -- the only similar place I can think of is True Food -- but it fell flat. For starters, it's a good thing they have flavored waters, because their regular water tasted funky. Salads are very tasty but super small - appetizer portions at entree prices. Sandwiches are a much better value, but you can find better at many other places. The sweet potato fries aren't bad, for being \"air fried.\" Without that caveat, head-to-head against real fries, not so much (and, come on, isn't ordering sweet potato fries over regular ones already being good enough?!). I will say that the dipping sauce that accompanies the fries is delicious! The setting is very casual and comfortable, and the service was great, but it's the food that brings someone back for a second time...and I can't say I plan on returning.

My spouse had the novel 5-cheese Mac and Cheese with poultry. It appeared visually appealing, and he expressed that it possessed an enjoyable flavor profile. In contrast, I opted for the traditional baby back ribs, which unfortunately did not meet my expectations. The meat was excessively desiccated, resulting in an unpleasant texture, and the edges were overcooked to the extent of being charred. The dish lacked any semblance of moisture, and the absence of copious amounts of barbecue sauce, often used as a makeshift solution, was conspicuous. The overall experience was utterly disappointing and unpalatable. Consequently, I strongly advise against ordering the ribs at this establishment and would caution others against doing so as well.

I really wanted to like this place because I have a soft spot for diners and dives (not so much drive ins). And this place has the traditional diner set up on the inside located in an area of town (the Melrose) that I'm really rooting for to turn into something truly special (it's already pretty cool). But, I just didn't like the food. I ordered the breakfast sandwich which was eggs, sausage and cheese on a croissant. The croissant was ehhh ok. The eggs/sausage/cheese was greasy and not very flavorful. It came with a side of potatoes which were also pretty m'eh. I'll give this one another shot at some point.

Wait staff and service was good.  My steak was excellent (Tabasco peppered Kobe flank). My friends duck was mediocre and the fat was not rendered. We didn't have time to wait for a fix so she just ate it.  The sides with it were good. The worst part of the experience was the fact that they charged $5 for hot water. 35 for mediocre duck and 40 for a steak.  I find charging for hot water ridiculous.

This store is like a Mega store. Maybe they are a little bit over they head because sadly the meats are not the best. They have meat on sale for 3 and 4 bucks and its coloring is brown to black. Meat should be Red. I will shop here but I will stay away from the meat. If you can get pass that the store is really ok.

"I recently endured an extremely unpleasant encounter at Picture People in Henderson, Nevada, which left me feeling utterly dissatisfied and taken advantage of. The pure white backdrop of my photographs conspicuously displayed noticeable scuff marks, indicating a lack of attention to detail and carelessness on the part of the studio. Furthermore, the staff imposed an arbitrary limit on the number of images I could store on my disk, without providing any written documentation or explanation of this policy. When I inquired about the cost of their services, I was met with evasiveness and a refusal to provide a detailed breakdown of prices, leading me to suspect that they were attempting to conceal something. To add insult to injury, they rejected my coupon for a $20 discount on a $100 purchase, citing an ambiguous and unclear exclusion clause that was nowhere to be found in the promotional material. The most appalling aspect of this entire ordeal was that the manager, who was supposed to ensure a positive customer experience, was the very person who displayed such unprofessional conduct and apathy towards my concerns. My husband's intervention prevented me from expressing my indignation and frustration in a more vociferous manner. Currently, I am gazing at the photographs, feeling saddened and disappointed by the whole experience. It is my conviction that Picture People failed to uphold their advertised guarantee of complete customer satisfaction."

Once again, the culinary establishment within the Station Casino premises has undergone a transformation in ownership and management, with the previous entity known as Guadalajara ceding its operational responsibilities to a new proprietorship under the name of Cabo. 
  Upon conclusion of my work-related duties on a recent Friday evening, my fiancÃ© and I opted to partake in a visit to the aforementioned eatery, primarily motivated by my desire to indulge in a celebratory alcoholic beverage, specifically a margarita, in commemoration of the successful completion of my training program. 
  Unfortunately, our experience at the restaurant was marred by an excessive amount of waiting time, as we were forced to endure prolonged delays in the provision of various essential elements of our dining experience, including the arrival of the hostess, the distribution of chips, and the servicing of beverages, resulting in a considerable delay before the gratification of our thirst and hunger. Moreover, I failed to receive a glass of water that I had requested, prompting me to consume my fiancÃ©'s beverage instead, and no offer was made to replenish our depleted supply of chips. 
  The young woman tasked with attending to our table appeared visibly overwhelmed by the demands of her role, while the supporting staff member, referred to as a 'busboy,' proved to be of minimal assistance in addressing our concerns. 
  Notwithstanding the aforementioned deficiencies in service, the quality of the edibles we consumed was merely average, with the exception of my margarita, which was expertly blended and presented a most satisfying taste experience. Additionally, we received complimentary sopapillas as per the restaurant's policy for checking in, which we elected to take away for subsequent consumption. 
  It remains a mystery as to why Station Casinos persist in altering their dining establishments, but it is evident that this particular transition did not result in an improvement in the overall dining experience. The sole reason for my potential return would be to sample another raspberry margarita, as it was truly the highlight of the evening.

"The quality of service is exceptional, the beverages are quite satisfactory, yet the culinary offerings are merely adequate. Specifically, the stuffed peppers and dates stand out as the most delectable options on the menu. Nonetheless, a pervasive odor akin to that of a soiled dishrag permeates the entire eatery, raising concerns regarding the overall cleanliness and hygiene of the establishment."

"Beer: Satisfactory. 

Culinary offerings: Subpar. 

It is my conviction, formed after indulging in an excessive number of culinary establishment rescue programs, that eateries boasting menus of considerable volume invariably serve fare that is, at best, unremarkable. BJs falls squarely within this category. 

Their menu, replete with pizza-esque items, led me to deduce that opting for a flatbread would be the wisest choice. Alas, the execution fell short of expectations. While the dish did contain tomatoes and cheese, the sausage component was conspicuous by its absence. A paltry few pieces of sausage-like matter graced the flatbread, rendering the claim that it featured sausage dubious at best. 

The bread itself presented a dichotomy of texture, with certain areas exhibiting a satisfying crispness while others descended into sogginess. This inconsistency rendered the overall experience less than satisfactory. 

Given that the primary item on their menu (i.e., pizza-like products) failed to impress, it is reasonable to surmise that the remaining menu items, sprawled across a whopping 12 pages (an exaggeration, perhaps, but not by much), are likely to be forgettable, at best."

We dined the last night of restaurant week(which we didn't know until we arrived). The menu was very limited, the appetizer of pork bellies(my husband's) was so greasy he couldn't eat it, his entree was cod and very bland. My entree, sea bass was overcooked and tasted bland and not very fresh.  The only part of the meal that we liked was the dessert.\n\nThis was our first time here for my birthday and was very disappointed considering all the great reviews.  Was this any off night, maybe but will probably not go back. One positive was our waiter-very knowledgable and friendly.

I spent a good three hours studying. Besides having a great facility for wifi, seating, and noise level, the service could use a lot of work. If you're in the service industry, people who apply for this jobs should be mindful that they will be working with people. In other words, they can be more friendly and cheerful no matter how difficult it may be. Other than that, I did enjoy my peach green tea lemonade.

"The gastronomical experience provided by this establishment is satisfactory, but the process of preparing authentic Italian cuisine is indeed arduous, as even esteemed restaurants such as O Garden may struggle to achieve culinary excellence. However, this venue purports to offer 'exceptional Italian food,' an assertion that is belied by its uninspired menu offerings and exorbitant pricing. The dearth of creativity and the prevalence of hackneyed dishes serve as a paradigmatic illustration of the pervasive trend in Las Vegas eateries where high prices, unremarkable ambiance, and unimpressive culinary selections converge, catering to individuals who equate cost with quality without possessing a sophisticated understanding of gastronomy. Furthermore, the bartender's cursory greeting, 'I'll be with you in a minute!', epitomizes the lackluster service that often accompanies such establishments, leaving patrons feeling undervalued and unimportant."

Bad experience during my last visit. Found few strands of hair in chicken curry, posted picture. Naan bread was really flat and dry. Not much chicken in curry . Lot of variety and some other food was good. Expensive compared to other buffets. Not sure if I will come back

This place was a bit of a disappointment. Sure, it's a nice little restaurant in St. Mark's Square at the Venetian, the ambiance in nice, but the experience was not so good.

Service was slow and spotty. When we were seated, the waitress told us she was sending out water. Said water didn't arrive until we had received our meals and drinks, and only after we asked our waitress about it again. When we were offered parmesan on our food, the man who asked just walked away and vanished. We had to flag down or waitress to get it, who was noticeably absent throughout the evening. She then proceeded to absent-mindedly drop a huge chunk of cheese on the table, only to leave it there throughout the meal.

Food was alright and came out very quickly, though it was almost too quickly, as if it had already been prepared before we ordered it. 

After the whole experience, I would probably not come back. There are many other restaurants nearby to choose from (it is Vegas, after all).

Arrowheads Applebee's offers a vastly superior experience, in contrast to the unfortunate events that transpired during my recent visit. Specifically, the karaoke session was marred by the DJ and his associates dominating the performance, rendering the atmosphere rather unpleasant. Furthermore, the presence of rowdy families and boisterous adolescent females, who insisted on vocalizing their renditions of Spice Girls hits, only exacerbated the unbearable nature of the evening. Thus, I implore management to address these issues and establish a more appropriate ambiance for patrons.

This place does have great yogurt, especially The oatmeal cookie which is by far the best. Their service model though is extremely frustrating since they give out samples instead of having sample cups available. i waited for over 5 minutes to get one sample from the guy working who seemed less than interested in helping and barely said hi. No surprise when he rang me up and told me the price and that was it. A thank you or have a good day would have been way too much effort on his part.\n\nDefinitely wont go back to this location, very disappointed

I have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, and my experiences have been overwhelmingly positive. However, my most recent visit was not up to par, primarily due to the absence of the sole English-speaking staff member. As a result, communication proved to be a significant challenge. In the past, I have consistently requested the services of Andy, as his proficiency in massage therapy has been exceptional. Unfortunately, he was preoccupied during my visit, and I was attended to by one of the female therapists instead. It is worth noting that the therapists present appeared to be engaged in conversation amongst themselves, which created a distracting environment. Furthermore, the lady who administered my massage seemed hurried and irritable. This combination of factors resulted in a less than satisfactory experience. Following my massage, I made my way back to the restroom, whereupon I observed a male individual being escorted into a secluded back room with a door. This sight piqued my curiosity and raised concerns regarding potentially illicit activities. I must emphasize that I do not condone such behavior and am currently undecided about whether I shall return to this establishment in the future.

"Underwhelmed, to say the least. Contrary to my expectations, I was part of a considerable gathering, thereby rendering my experience somewhat unremarkable. My tardiness, coupled with the fact that my fellow diners had already placed their orders, likely contributed to the server's lack of attention towards me. Upon requesting a beverage and food menu, I was merely presented with the former, and the server's subsequent visits to the opposite end of the table did not alleviate my thirst. It was only after an extended period of time had elapsed and one of my companions brought it to the server's attention that I was still eager to peruse the menu that I was finally able to place an order. Regrettably, by the time I had the opportunity to sample the culinary offerings, my fellow patrons had already devoured their meals. My selection, the apocalyptic pork with a side salad, fell short of my gastronomic expectations. The absence of moisture and flavor left much to be desired, and the haphazard placement of the aioli on the plate only served to further disappoint. The meat, too, was problematic, as it disintegrated effortlessly, necessitating the use of cutlery to consume it properly. In hindsight, I would have been better off opting for the soup."

2 stars for frozen hot chocolate... yummm
Waiting time to be seated 30 mins
Water to be delivered at your table 15 mins
Another 15 mins wait to take your orders
41 minutes wait for the food :( 
Food was so-so, not bad, not that good either.

I only want the frozen hot choco, so I'll just order at the window next time.

"During the sweltering month of July, I opted to lodge at the Rio, primarily due to its proximity to a conference I was attending. Unfortunately, my expectations were not met, as the establishment presented itself in a state of disarray and neglect. The ambiance was tainted by the pervasive presence of dirt, mustiness, and mildew, which permeated every corner of the premises. Furthermore, the pool was frequently inaccessible during customary operational hours, much to my chagrin. The culinary offerings, while adequate, failed to impress, and the gaming area was characterized by a sense of dilapidation and squalor, evoking an unpleasant odor reminiscent of fecal matter. The elevators were consistently overcrowded, leading to interminable waits amidst a throng of impatient patrons. Reception and concierge services were similarly affected by lengthy queues, further contributing to the overall frustration. Our midweek stay did little to alleviate these issues, and the shuttle service proved unreliable, necessitating prolonged waits for successive vehicles. In light of the numerous superior alternatives available in Las Vegas, I would not consider returning to the Rio, despite any ostensibly advantageous rates. In fact, I would have opted to transfer accommodations after the initial night, had it not been for the aforementioned conference."

"Perhaps owing to its recent opening, this establishment has yet to iron out certain operational wrinkles. We opted to be seated in the bar area, whereupon our server required nearly thirty minutes to return and take our order after we had informed him that we wished to consume sustenance. Upon sharing the General Li's dish, we requested that they partition it into two separate portions; regrettably, they merely provided an additional plate, which, while appreciated, proved somewhat inconvenient and messy for us. Furthermore, the quantity of rice provided was insufficient to counterbalance the saltiness of the soy sauce, resulting in an overpowering flavor. To avoid a similar experience, it is advisable to request supplementary rice."

"The culinary experience was rather unremarkable, as the dishes we sampled did not deviate significantly from the ubiquitous Chinese fare commonly found in strip malls throughout the region. Specifically, the kung pao chicken lacked any distinguishing characteristics, save for an abundance of celery, which seemed to be an integral component of the dish. Similarly, my wife's cashew chicken appeared visually indistinguishable from my own dish, with the sole exception being the presence of nuts, which served as a faint differentiator between the two entrees."

lame routines and mediocre dancing. I'm sure dancing topless was their aim to distract viewers from noticing the sub par dancing. Holly never speaks a word, and this black chick and white dude do all the singin and talking.  For 113 the view would be pretty good, but for 85 the view is hardly worth going for.  Still 113 for dancing tits is debatable. I couldn't  understand why everyone was so pumped to see this show, and even more so when holly showed her boobs, or someone did something sexy.  sorry fake boobs and small b cups just didn't impress me.  save your money go see La Reve at the wynn.. amazing just like the wynn ;)

"I possess an immense fondness for Pottery Barn, to an enormous extent. Their assortment of furniture exudes timelessness and durability, comprising robust, solid materials that transcend fleeting veneers. As an ardent devotee, I conduct a rigorous examination of each piece by vigorously shaking it; if it exhibits even the slightest movement, I promptly proceed to the next item, as I seek furniture that exudes sturdiness and indestructibility. 

Notwithstanding my profound admiration for their products, I have assigned a rating of two stars to this specific establishment, and the primary reason for this lies in the realm of customer service, specifically, the behavior of the store manager. It bears a resemblance to the scenario depicted in the film Pretty Woman, where Julia Roberts' character encounters discriminatory treatment due to her appearance. Similarly, I have experienced dismissal in favor of more affluent-looking patrons, despite my genuine desire to furnish my newly inhabited abode gradually. Hence, I opt to peruse the display models on the floor and procure my desired items from either Pottery Barn Henderson or through online means. 

In my line of work, it is crucial to refrain from judging individuals based on their external appearance. Instead, it is essential to treat all clients with familial warmth and respect, thereby fostering a reciprocal sense of belonging and loyalty."

Decided to give this place a try - there were only 2 other customers inside
The wait staff was very attentive and pleasant  - clean restaurant
The Clam Chowder was very good - I'll give them that....
However, my Angel Hair pasta with Marinara sauce was too bland.
As I was trying to mix my pasta and sauce I noticed that there was way to much water in the bottom of my bowl. All the water should have been drained from the pot the pasta was boiling in because it just results in a bowl of watery yucky pasta!!!!!
I was not pleased at all and returned my dish....
My kid's cheese pizza was OK but not outstanding.
My main concern is that the waiter made my situation known to the owner  (sure looked like the owner) and not once did he come up to me to  apologize or say anything. He had the opportunity as there were only 5 customers inside and that's including my daughter and I. 
They did take the dish off my bill and the owner did say Bye as I was leaving but by him not personally addressing the issue at hand with me it just left me with a  "I don't care to come back" feeling.

Went to ditka's.... It was good. The food was wonderful.  Shrimp cocktail was perfect. Pork chop was wonderful. Burgers were great. Dessert tasty.  The chef is totally on the ball... 
Unfortunately our waiter was horrible. One of our party arrived first, waited 10 min before approached! Beverages took forever, a beer was ordered 10 min later it arrived. Had to ask for bread. Waited 10-15 min to give dinner order. Had to ask for beverage refills. Gave the order he wrote it down.... Then we added a salad, which he did not write down....you guessed it, salad never came. The good thing was we weren't charged for it. 
Thank goodness the meal was comped.... I would have been totally pissed if I had to pay the $100.25 bill with the waiter we had. 
When your in an upscale restaurant you should NEVER have to ask for anything. (Period) no excuses.
Good food, bad waiter. Would give 2.5 if possible for the food only.
Take a chance... Eat in the bar area, dinner specials inn bar not available in dining room. My family usually eats in the bar and they say the waitstaff is great in the bar.

It's bit overrated- definitely not the best show I've seen on the strip. So so jokes, stage and overall is too outdated, I was a bored out of my mind about half way into the show... if you are seeing only one show on your trip to sin city, think twice; but if you get comp for the ticket, go for some loud beat and play the giant beach balls at the end!

I've eaten at Hubbard Ave Diner many times.  Great pie, good service, average food, really inconsistent execution by the kitchen.  If they aren't busy, you've got a good chance to have your order arrive correct (as in get what you ordered as you ordered it) and hot.  If they are busy, forget it.  They really need to have an expediter in the kitchen.

So, most of my reviews are going to be based on the quality and taste of the food.  I don't find that I experience really bad service or great service that often, most is satisfactory.  \nOn with the review.  The bread that they bring at the begining was pretty delicious, but sad when that was the best part of the meal.  Most of us had pasta, mine was extremely bland (I had the creamy garlic chicken)  I had to add a lot of salt and I never salt anything.  My fiance had the fresh tomato mozzarella pasta and it was terribly bland also, the tomatoes hardly even had taste.  The only thing in our group of six that seemed to be good was the chopped gorganzola salad. \nI would much rather support a local restaurant than a chain, but I would have to say that I would rather eat at Olive Garden than here.

My first time there last weekend and let's just say it wasn't the best first experience.  I placed my order and it took quite awhile to get it.  Then we got our food and my order was completely wrong.  By the time they made another and brought it out everyone else was done with their food and I had to get mine to go.  The waitress took the check off the table, I was assuming they were going to give some sort of discount being as I had to take my breakfast to go now, but nope, she came back and there was no offer or mention of my inconvenience.  The only reason I gave it 2 stars is because the food I did get to eat was good, but I won't be going back.  If a restaurant screws up and you miss enjoying your meal with your table, they needed to offer something for the inconvenience.

"My culinary preferences do not include burritos that have been subjected to moisture, as it utterly negates the fundamental purpose of said burrito. During a recent visit to an establishment that specializes in such fare, I was taken aback by the staff's insistence on exposing my unfinished burrito to heat via an oven, followed by their assertion that any additional ingredients could only be applied to the surface of the aforementioned burrito. Suffice it to say, I nearly departed the premises without consuming my underwhelming burrito, which consisted of mediocre chicken, rice, and cheese, and cost me a whopping twelve dollars."

We indulged in a morning repast at this establishment during our leisurely sojourn, despite the fact that I did not select the venue myself, having heard favorable opinions about it prior to our visit. However, upon experiencing it firsthand, I found it to be merely satisfactory, lacking the exceptional quality and memorability that I typically associate with establishments not affiliated with large corporate chains. My dining companion and I both opted for the eggs benedict, albeit with an avocado-based variation in my case, which, while offering a pleasant departure from the standard iteration, failed to live up to the elevated expectations generated by the menu's description. The remaining members of our party appeared to enjoy their meals without issue, selecting salads and skillet dishes as their preferred options. 
  Our waiting time was not excessively prolonged, yet I felt annoyed by the presence of unsupervised young children roaming the premises, and the service we received left room for improvement, particularly in regards to the considerable delay I experienced in receiving my coffee, a crucial component of my daily routine that I find essential to my overall satisfaction. While I would not consider this restaurant to be exceptional, I do not foresee myself returning in the future.

I entered this establishment with elevated anticipations, courtesy of a personal endorsement, and unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled. Following the culmination of the evening's prime dining period, I opted to procure a to-go order, and although the personnel were amiable, their demeanor conveyed a certain lack of enthusiasm towards their occupational responsibilities. The venue itself featured both interior and exterior seating arrangements, which proved to be a welcome aspect.

I placed an order for two vegetarian sandwiches, tailored to accommodate my vegan sibling's dietary preferences, and as a vegan novice, I took great care to request that the dressing and cheese be served separately. Upon arriving home, I was dismayed to discover that both components had been included in the side salads. Furthermore, a hair was discovered in my salad, which somewhat diminished my appetite. The sandwich itself was passable, albeit slightly soggy, and its flavor profile was satisfactory.

Despite my underwhelming experience, I may consider returning to this establishment if I happen to be in the vicinity.

Be prepared to drop some serious cash here at the Shoppes. (I'm wondering myself why they added an 'e' in shoppes - maybe for that added flavor of pretention, haha). They definitely don't mess around here with high-end shops like Barney's New York, Coach, and Burberry just to name a few. Built just across the street from the Wynn Hotel and their own bougie shops, I'm sure they aim to cater to that same crowd. 

My friends and I walked into Michael Kors and there was a purse that caught her eye. She picks it up and then asked an associate how much it was. He casually replies, "That one is $1400." Upon hearing this, she immediately returned the purse to the display, looks at us, says "Okay," and walks away from the bag. With our incomes, we can only dream about getting the stuff here. Unless you can afford all the things here and can actually purchase them - that seems like a lot more fun!

Nothing special about the decor of the Shoppes. But, there is one thing worthy of note, a waterfall that is two-stories high at the center of the mall. Be prepared to see lots of tourists taking pictures. And hey, why not take one yourself? 

For the hard-working middle class schmo and "normal" crowds, I recommend the Miracle Mile shops or Fashion Show Mall. I'm sure once the blazing summer heat kicks in, people will use this mall as an air-conditioned excuse to stay off the strip.

Went on a weekend morning more than a year ago. It says something that I still remember the details of my visit. They were just unorganized. Possibly overwhelmed. Lady who I think was the owner was just barking orders. Maybe we should have waited for a table outside for a more peaceful dining experience...

This last time was my second time to eat at the Parlor, wanted my boyfriend and my brother to try it, I had gone there for lunch one other time and liked it, I think it was around opening week.  IDK what happened to but the service was BAD! the food was JUST OKAY, the people who worked there were \"really\" cool. the attitude smelled so bad, wait maybe it was the food? i will never return to the parlor again it is over glamourized pizza served with a bad attitde! you can get better at NYPD or PIzzano's if you are looking for pizza in that area!

Guy who did my nails was rude and I got a gel manicure that went into my cuticles and onto the skin on several nails. Very messy. Maybe I had a bad manicurist, but I felt the staff was rude to most people who walked in the door. Won't be back.
Well, if your address isn't correct and you don't pick up the phone to help with directions you can't expect a great customer response...  Was really looking forward to eating here, now not so sure.

Definitely overly hyped!

Their bread is good, but their meat is poor, they barely put anything in between the slices of their bread! I felt like I just paid for their bread. I waited in line for 25minutes for the sandwiches with high expectations. Instead, I was still hungry after eating the sandwich and grumpty for having to wait that long for something not so amazing. What was I thinking?!

I'm giving them two stars for their soft, delicious bread. However, if you don't like your bread being a little oily, you may not like it. You can definitely get better sandwiches at other local sandwich shops in Vegas. Definitely over hyped. You can definitely go if the line is short, but honestly don't wait in line. There are SOO many other places to eat in Vegas.

I like to think of Petal has \"hit or miss.\"  Lately it has been a miss.  I feel like I can try on like 6-10 things and nothing will work- it won't fit right, too see through, etc.\n\nAlso, every time I am in there I feel rushed in the dressing room.  They are constantly trying to take things out (I assume for shoplifting reasons).  But I hate feeling so rushed.

My mouth has a weird aftertaste. It could of been the cockroach that scurried across the floor and ended up in my burger. Free wings on Monday night football. That's cool. \nCheap beer. They raised over$1,000 for a nonprofit one night for local teens in need of help. That's cool. We are in Wickenburg

I am not particularly fond of this specific branch, and as a background, I have been a patron of Chase for an extended period of time, possessing two active accounts. Upon entering the establishment, I attempted to cash a sizable check, only to be met by a novice accounts specialist who persistently endeavored to persuade me to open yet another account. Feeling pressured, I hastily provided my contact information in the hope that he would not overhear one of the digits. However, my efforts were futile, as the specialist continued to call me for a fortnight, leaving a voice message urging me to return and open the additional account. Furthermore, during my interaction with the teller, I inquired about a sign posted on the entrance window, advertising a feature that enables users to scan checks and deposit them through their mobile devices. When I asked if this service was compatible with Blackberries, the teller was unable to provide a definitive response, instead opting to search for the answer. While her diligence in seeking the truth is commendable, it is also reasonable to expect that such fundamental knowledge should be readily available to her. Lastly, upon entering the premises, I noticed an unkempt plastic waste receptacle positioned beneath the sole ATM in the room, giving the appearance of neglect over an extended period. This unsightly scene does not present a favorable initial impression, particularly for prospective clients who are considering establishing a new account.
searched this place before we go.went to this place with a friend.the food was ok service was ok,the place is ekkkkkkkkk... I would not go back again !!!

Really don't like the concept of waiting in line to order. No greeter but the bartender tried to help. The cashier was too busy discussing how much money they made in tips to wait on us, but finally asked us what we wanted. Then I don't get a reciept and am told to go to table ??? Don't talk to me or I'll forget the number! The chairs are sooo tall I almost have to jump to get on it.... the burger was under cooked - but better than overcooked. And the whole concept is too expensive if I have to wait in a line to order. Just disapointed....

"Eh pizza, an edible flatbread typically topped with cheese, tomato sauce, various meats, vegetables, and condiments, is merely satisfactory in my opinion. However, it's possible that my lukewarm appreciation for this culinary staple stems from the fact that the delivery process took an hour, despite our proximity to the establishment, which is a mere five minutes away."

I have been frustrated more and more with Danny's Family over the years.  The constant up-selling is out of control.  I brought in a new car (2K) miles on it and they asked if I wanted a buff & wax.  I told them it was brand new and the sales guy still persisted.  Then of course the windshield chip guys.  I have a tiny, and I'm talking tiny, crack in the windshield and the rep basically said that if I didn't get that fixed today the entire windshield might completely shatter while I'm driving.  Serious?  The detail on the washing is good, but the up front selling is ridiculous!  I just wish there was a better alternative, but it seems like this is par for the course with car wash establishments.  Oh well....
Chips and salsa were good but that's where it ended. Dry meat on my tacos, my wife had a really bad salad. Chicken coated with sauce that was more like Italian sauce than anything Mexican.

I have to say St Rose Pediactrics is wearing super thin on me. Appointment time was 11:00am. 45 minutes after we are put in a room. 25 minutes later a doctor still has not come in. It's about time to scale back the number of clients and/or appointments you take. Look, I've even had enough time to write this review AFTER reading all the others.

Food was perfect. i got the galbi burger with house kim chi on the side. why the bad review? we came in with a group of 12+ we called in they accommodated us and had a warm welcome. So still why the terrible review...its courtesy especially when eating with people you havent seen in quite some time to wait for all the food to arrive at the table to begin chowing...2 of our parties food took 30 minutes later than everyone else's to come out. appetizers came in too fast which were fantastic (sweet potato fries) huge gap in between that and the entree. the waitress kept telling us the kitchen was behind and that the burger was being made. 10 minutes later she told us that they forgot the order. finally after 30 minutes the burger comes out. i dont care how many orders you have, the next burger should have been ours but no...we watched tables come in and sit down and get their food faster.\n\nwhen coming to visit vegas, my friend told me this place was great and he wanted to try it. sadly i was a little disappointed not by the food. but its not always bad food that ruins the experience.

First off, I had a blast cause I was able to spend some quality time with my mom and son, which a rare lately  due to my crazy work schedule, with that said I was very very very disappointed in the customer service or just service in general.  The place is very cute and cool, tons of tv's with tons of sports to watch.  Nice and cool inside, and there wasn't many people when we went.  Our server was not good at all.  Kept forgetting about us.  Forgetting to bring us things, small or big, she couldn't get it together.  Now, just because I myself am a server and work in a restaurant doesn't mean I'm picking on her.  She herself said to me 'am I ignoring you guys alot tonight?' ummmmmmmmm yeah!!!!!!!!! 

The little game area was ok, although the machines kept taking my money and I  had to keep getting someone to fix it.  Annoying!  

Food was ok too.  Loved the house salad.  My pizza kinda sucked, was suppose to be thick crust and was thin.  We had to ask three times for more dressing.  My mom ordered a wheat beer and she was brought ??? well it wasnt  wheat beer, so she ordered something else.  Ten minutes later, still no beer.  I finally had to get up fine the server and ask her to get the beer........now!

We had fun just being together and watching the game and my son play.  But, I wont be going back anytime soon. :(

It was just okay.  We've been to numerous Sushi restaurants in Charlotte, Davidson & Asheville, and this was probably our least favorite out of all of them.  It wasn't \"bad\"..just very boring.  We have another restaurant.com coupon from the Ayrsley restaurant so maybe that will be better.

So the waiter brought a me cheese enchilada and chicken taco even though I ordered a beef enchilada and chicken taco I informed him of this and he looked at me in the face and asked me if I wanted a side of beef.  I will not be back

Chips & Salsa were the only things that were good. Margarita on the rocks was ok, spinach dip was ok. Chese enchilada & chile relleno was ok. Husband had a chicken chimi, he did not like it but like the beans and rice. My friend from Canada like the beef enchilada & hard shredded beef taco.  Flan was tough.

The food was awful. My mushroom ravioli was rubbery and so unappetizing looking they should have been ashamed to let it out of the kitchen. My daughters chicken was so overcooked she could not cut it. The waiter told us we should have sent it back but he did not come back to check on us. Will never go back to this location again. Stay away there are a lot of other restaurants nearby try one of those

The only reason I give this a two star is purely because the customer service was fantastic. I will say this was a positive I experienced. I contacted Jay via email, and he got back to me very quickly, and his shop staff were very friendly. My cupcakes were not ready at the time I requested to pick them up, which wasn't too big of a deal, as everyone was very apologetic and sincere. Unfortunately the cupcakes themselves were awful. I can say that I have had better tasting cupcakes from Walmart. I ordered a dozen cupcakes, 6 with pink bows, and 6 with blue ties. The decoration did okay, but seemed liked something I could have done myself with some help, but the cupcakes were nearly frozen in the middle, stale, and the icing was hard. This could have been due to the fact that I was suppose to pick up my cupcakes on a Friday, but due to a car accident I was not able to get them until Monday. I did how ever send an email to Jay letting him know this Thursday evening. To me it tasted as if the cupcakes were made several days in advance and left in the walk in frig. Again, 3 of my cupcakes were practically frozen in the middle. I was pretty disappointed as I had heard great things about KAK, and was looking forward to using them in the future for other needs, but I will not be utilizing their services anymore.

The persistent and unpredictable nature of the internet service disruptions has become an exasperating source of frustration for me, with a total of three instances in the past week alone where my connection has been rendered non-functional due to purported "maintenance" endeavors. Despite the service provider's claims of striving to enhance the quality of their offerings, my personal experience has been marred by a complete absence of connectivity during these intervals, which have proven to be particularly vexing and inconvenient. Moreover, the frequency and duration of these outages have led me to question the reliability and competence of the service provider, with its subpar performance rivaling that of Comcast, a company notorious for its poor customer satisfaction ratings.

I so wanted to like this place, but I was not a FAN! I got the combo with BBQ pork and teriyaki chicken and chicken fried rice.  The BBQ pork was not GOOD at all, chewy and tough to eat.  The teryiyaki chicken was even worse, the sauce was a clump of jello like substance.  GROSS!  The fried rice was so soggy and the beans did not go with the rest of the food.  =(\n\nThey have a friendly staff and hurdle customers in like cattle.

Came here for dinner, waiters took a while to get our order and there was not alot people. We ordered \"The Theresa\" and the Corn on cob with chili, cheese and lime. The food tasted fine but i feel like it was overpriced, $6 for one corn on a cob with chili and cheese? come on now.

Food was no better than adequate.  Service was worse.  Waiter did not speak English well, so our order was messed up.  One hour time limit.  Everything tasted of ginger, and more than just a hint of it. Atmosphere wasn't very good.  Poor lighting makes it difficult to read menu.  We will not be going back, even though it is very close to home.

I have been to this restaurant dozens of times throughout the years. I find the steaks are always good, but the seafood is really hit or miss. Was there yesterday and my lobster was totally over cooked. It was like complete rubber. It was barely edible. I should have known better to order it there, but I love surf and turf so I gave it a shot. Very disappointing.

Several people said I had to go here during my first-ever visit to Pittsburgh so I obliged. Whoa, I've never been this confused about why a place gets such high recommendations. 

Upon entry, expect a chaotic atmosphere. We were first told to find a seat ourselves, but then were told to be seated. Once seated, we waited for several minutes before anyone came by to ask us anything. However, after the first staff member showed up, another two came by within two minutes to ask us for our order as well. 

The food was okay, nothing spectacular. The one interesting part was that the fries came stuffed in the sandwich. As for the taste, really nothing out of the ordinary.

Why this place is so popular will remain a mystery to me. Was it worth going just to say I had gone?  Not really.

"It is patently evident that the quality of service provided by the hotel staff at Caesar's during my recent stay was subpar and utterly unacceptable. Specifically, upon entering our accommodations, we discovered an unfortunate surprise in the form of a previous guest's intimate apparel, which had been carelessly left behind. Furthermore, it took an unreasonable six hours for the hotel staff to furnish us with an additional blanket, and a staggering 24 hours for the procurement of extra pillows. To exacerbate matters further, the wake-up call we had requested failed to materialize altogether. It is worth noting that such egregious lapses in service are particularly glaring given the hotel's self-proclaimed status as a 'world-class' establishment. When I brought these issues to the attention of the hotel staff, their response was dismissive and lackadaisical, with the manager offering a flippant excuse about the limited availability of staff due to the holiday weekend. In light of these events, I would strongly advise against entrusting one's hospitality needs to this establishment."

"The culinary experience is merely satisfactory, lacking an exceptional quality. The term 'Greek' is loosely applied here, as the dishes served barely embody the authentic essence of Hellenic gastronomy, with Gyro-style skewers and sauces being the primary offerings. The service, unfortunately, leaves much to be desired in terms of both friendliness and attentiveness, often leaving patrons waiting for 20-30 minutes with empty glasses. The price-performance ratio does not quite align, but it remains a viable option for those who cannot secure a table at the nearby Socrates restaurant and have an unwavering craving for Greek cuisine."

I came here with several of my co-workers hoping for fun lunch. While the decor was unique and interesting, I felt the black was a bit overdone. It also seems they designed their own chairs and they were really uncomfortable when you sit back. There is some kind of triangular design on the back and it kept digging into my lower back. It forced me to sit on the edge of my seat. Other than the interior decor, the service was prompt and friendly. But there wasn't anyone else in there at the time.

Each of us got a different ramen noodle soup, an order of the waffle with korean beef, edamame, and the sliders.

The edamame was awesome. Super garlicky with some good dipping sauce. The ramen unfortunately didn't live to my expectations. I had the sesame tonkatsu and the broth felt way too thick and it wasn't hot at all. Maybe room temperature. the noodles were a bit warmer but not by much. I couldn't finish the ramen because it was too thick and it wasn't appetizing because it wasn't hot. My other co-workers agreed that their ramen wasn't hot either. The waffles were okay but not something I would order. I didn't get to try the sliders but they said they were just alright.

I hope for the best for this establishment but it's not a place I would return to.

This establishment formerly possessed an exceptional quality, but it appears that they have adopted a more parsimonious approach to their operations. The removal of their delectable queso fundido from the menu serves as a prime example of this shift in policy. Furthermore, the pace of service has become lethargic, and the once-around-the-clock availability has been drastically reduced. Additionally, the staff seems to take umbrage with patrons who request beverages, evincing a reluctance to provide adequate refreshments for those engaging in gaming activities. In light of these changes, it becomes apparent that there exist superior alternatives within the locality, rendering further visits to this venue unnecessary and unwise expenditures of both currency and time.

Sadly, we had a really bad experience. Our guacamole had a really strange texture and unpleasant taste and the tacos were hardly even mediocre. The fish tacos had no cabbage, cilantro, or lime, they were pretty lacking in general and were served with wilted green leaf lettuce. The black beans and rice had no flavor. The party at the table next to us had to send their meal back for being uncooked. It was just not a meal I would ever come back for.

My companion and I opted to patronize this establishment while the remainder of our coterie remained in their lodgings, slumbering due to the previous night's festivities. I was experiencing an intense sensation of hunger, yearning to consume any edible substances. Fortuitously, the smorgasbord had commenced at this locale around 11 am for a nominal fee of 11.99 per individual, excluding beverages. It embodied an Italian-inspired assortment of culinary delights, encompassing spaghetti, lasagna, meatballs, and Parmesan-infused poultry. Additionally, they offered a soup and salad course. Unfortunately, I must admit that the gastronomic quality was subpar. My clam chowder was unpalatable, and the sole item I derived enjoyment from my plate was the fettuccine. I somewhat overindulged in bread due to my concern about not receiving adequate sustenance for my financial outlay. Furthermore, I was taken aback by the chilly temperature of certain comestibles, considering that they had initiated the buffet immediately upon our arrival, and we were, in fact, the initial patrons.
It was ok. It is like someone who is drunk and this is what the craved for munchies. They combined a Panda Express with a Taco Bell into one dish. Also the fried rice was terrible

The best word I can think of to describe this place is 'meh'. I went here for lunch and I was underwhelmed by the menu. I ended up getting chicken salad with fruit. It was a small scoop of mediocre chicken salad on top of a bed of undressed greens with some grapes and two strawberry slices sprinkled on. When I asked for some dressing they told me there was some on the table. They must have been talking about the oil covered squeeze bottle containing a tasteless vinegarette. Not impressed.

I took my parents here mostly because of the view-but also for the food, which supposedly is good (really, 4 stars?). We ordered the peppercorn new york strip, one of the chewiest steaks I have ever tasted, the filet and salmon. The filet and the salmon were ok, but nothing special. The beet appetizer was acidic and did not taste good. \n\nSuch a shame-and very pricey. For 3 people without drinks it was close to 200$. Cannot recommend. Although the view is absolutely fabulous, that's why the 2 stars.

I thought this place was pretty average. We did the all you can drink champagne brunch and that was pretty great. However, I thought the food was pretty bad. The salad was soggy, the eggs were flavorless, everything was sinking in grease, the breakfast burrito was NOT GOOD.
