Usually, when I'm vegas hungover, anything breakfast appeals to me, so you can imagine my surprise when I left this place hungry. For all of the amazing buffets in Vegas, skip this one.

"Samurai Sam's endeavors to create culinary delights inspired by the Far East, albeit with questionable success

A trio of gastronomes, including yours truly, visited this establishment recently, each opting for a distinct dish. My own selection consisted of three chicken tacos, which, while palatable, were regrettably lacking in substance, as evidenced by the dearth of meat visible in the accompanying photographs. A plethora of vegetables was present, however.

My companions chose diverse teriyaki bowls, both of which were abundant in rice, yet limited in other ingredients. Disappointment ensued, as the quantity of sustenance was nowhere near comparable to that offered by Panda Express, a similar eatery. Our total cost, inclusive of two soft drinks and a single water, tallied $24.70, rendering the experience a relatively pricey disappointment. Thus, two stars seems an appropriate rating, given the superior quality attainable elsewhere."

We ate at this place for Thanksgiving dinner, and it gave me an overwhelming feeling of OK-ness.  The selection of dishes is very limited and not too exciting.  The food is passable.  The service is actually pretty bad - they have food runners who never know which person or even which table the food goes to and waiters that are experts at zooming past you avoiding eye contact.  The decor is cheesy.  Skip.

Ok... if you're hungry, hung over and needing something yummy to hit the spot. Don't go here.. ha! The decor and gimmicky stuff is pretty much the only thing that's great about this place. I love that you get a take home glass with your beer :) but the food is just yuck! Bar food that's gotten even blander than it already is! Our service was great, she was fast and friendly but it just didn't hit the spot. I don't even remember what anybody had - but seriously. Go here for the souvenirs, not the food!

I have been to Claim Jumper in CA.  They have been great!  The one in Avondale is just ok, I have been coming back a few times and it still has not changed my mind.  The service has been just so-so.  One time my chicken was served under cooked.  I do not know if I will return.  I still love in Claim Jumper in Deer Valley.

Twice in the last 4 trips to JJs we got home and the sub didn't have the toppings we asked for. Second time it happened we called to complain and they insisted it was our fault. They told us we could drive it back and they would give us a new one. No thanks, won't ever be driving back there.

The overall experience was subpar. No greeting or direction on where to order when we entered. The burgers were cooked a little rarer than our tastes. The food in general was just average. Not much flavor. Smash Burger down the street is much better. And there's no need to make a comparison with 5 Guys. I don't see this place lasting long. The operation doesn't seem to be run smoothly either.

Overrated. 

I think I ordered the wrong steak but at $60 a steak, I still expected a good steak. 

I read the reviews and I still ordered the bone in since bone in has such good flavor. Yes, I understand it wouldn't be the most tender cut of meat, but it was chewy. I have had much better steaks in texas (also corn fed like they highly describe on their menu and by the waiter) than at cut. 

The rest - the sides were ok. i really enjoyed the mac and cheese that gets prepped (stirred) at the table as well as the spinach with egg. But the other sides were just ok. 

Wine/drink: they had a drink menu on an ipad and yes that's impressive but when it's a group of seven (mostly guys - i was the lone girl) it might be smart to give us more than one unit. 

The cheesy bread was amazing - that's the only reason this place got two stars. 

Service was great - but expected at a place of this size. 

All said and done, I paid two hundred dollars for my meal of a bad steak and ok mac and cheese. 

will not come again.

"Cold Tuna, frozen vegetables, unremarkable service! As a frequent traveler, I possess an acute awareness of even the most minuscule details, as well as an appreciation for the overall ambiance, and unfortunately, my second visit to this Phillips fell short of my expectations, prompting me to consider alternative dining options, such as California Pizza Kitchen, located in terminal B, for future visits."

Bus load, after bus load, after bus load of kids with few adults to manage them.  Holy cow, what a disaster.  Throwing balls, running kids, and no adults from the schools nor enough science museum staff to manage it all.  This was quite an annoying experience, and hard to enjoy the exhibits.  They really need to get this under control.

"The culinary offerings were merely satisfactory, with certain dishes lacking the optimal temperature. Despite this, the eatery's ambiance was pleasant, boasting cleanliness and well-maintained decor. However, the upholstery appeared somewhat dated. Unfortunately, the service was excruciatingly sluggish, with an inadequate staff-to-patron ratio resulting in an elongated dining experience. Specifically, there was a dearth of servers, with only a single individual attending to our needs, leading to an unacceptable delay. Notwithstanding, I might consider revisiting the establishment if they address these issues, particularly regarding the temperature of the food and the efficiency of service, which are customarily expected from a Chinese restaurant."

Let me start off by saying, the cookies and bran muffin I sampled were absolutely delicious!! Also, the service was fine - patient and kind - even amidst some VERY rude women with kids who sent the children's food back because the toast wasn't crispy enough.. \nThat being said, I ordered the chopped salad with mixed greens and romaine I believe. The mixed greens were not just old, they were decomposing. Mushy and falling apart. Smelled terrible. This really irks me when you're paying $13 for a high-quality salad. I'm disappointed the chef didn't care enough to check what he puts on the plate. Otherwise, it would have been a great salad!\nI'm not that picky, but a lazy chef who doesn't care about food quality before the plate goes out is a bad sign.

OK, drove all the way from Gilbert to Camelback because the Phoenix Magazine rated Delux as one of the best burgers in the Valley. Two burgers, one mixed fries, one lemonade, one Diet Coke and tip came to $39. Fries were very good but because of the poor service it's hard to say how good our cold burgers were. Susan had to ask one of the other servers where our order was because we didn't see our waiter... everyone around us was getting served and they ordered after us. Too bad, we probably won't go back because of the service. I'm sure if they could make all the pieces fit together the place would be great. Just don't want to pay almost $40 for a couple burgers and take that chance again. We'll go to Burger King or McDonald's where we know what to expect.

"Indulged in an early evening repast at this establishment on Sunday, June 28, opting for it due to its proximity to our accommodations and my spouse's and my desire to sample the culinary offerings of the city with our discerning eight-year-old offspring, who boasts a predilection for fastidious fare. 

The hospitality we received was indeed prompt and attentive, the atmosphere resembling that of a bustling gaming facility, while the comestibles proved satisfactory, albeit at a cost that far exceeded their actual worth, in this patron's opinion. Specifically, the charge of $14 for a rudimentary burger, augmented by cheese and bacon, struck me as exorbitant, especially considering the supplementary fee for fries, which seemed an affront to my sensibilities as a consumer. 

In light of the aforementioned factors, I must regretfully decline to endorse this venue, given the glaring discrepancy between quality and cost."

I was a little disappointed in Pearl.  The sushi was outstanding but the presentation, service and environment left much to be desired.  First, the good.  They had a very large selection of sushi and all day happy hour.  Our food was excellent.  However, the resultant was so hot, we almost felt nauseous by the time we were finished eating.  The plates that our food arrived on were badly chipped.  The waiter kept touching us (patting on back/brushing against us) which was uncomfortable.   The last issue was that our soup was served after we received our entrees which was very odd.  Over all, I probably won't be back to Pearl.

Just placed my order around 8:10 and 40 minutes later it has still not been placed with the restaurant. (they show status updates and it will say \"placed\" when it has been done)  If ALL you do is delivery you better do it D@m*^ well!  I understand if there is a delay getting it cooked at the restaurant or traffic, but they should be placing the order with the restaurant immediately!!  Not cool foodie call, not cool. Not going to use them again unless I have to.  \n\nAlso there is not a great selection of restaurants to chose from.  Maybe Im spoiled, Im from Chicago and every kind of food imaginable is deliverable and super quick, that sure is not the case here in Charlotte!   When I called they just said they were very busy and thin on drivers.  Well hire some more then dude!
"The culinary offerings are of superior quality, but I shall not return due to the subpar service. It ranks among the most unsatisfactory dining establishments, according to government inspectors."

Saturday night. Looking forward to this show and we got here before 8pm. Show started near 930. So freaking crowded you can't see the band.  Its so loud you cant hear the band.  Fire Marshall bill would close the place. So over capacity you can't move. Let alone get to the bathroom. All about greed. Need to stop ticket sales while there is still room to move.

"If I were to offer an assessment of this dining establishment, I would venture to say that while the culinary offerings were indeed impressive, the quality of service was subpar and detracted significantly from the overall experience. It is conceivable that my visit occurred on an off-day for the restaurant; however, even taking that into consideration, the discrepancy between the exceptional food and the lackluster service was striking. Initially, our server, Rodrigo, appeared to be making a concerted effort to provide attentive service, but this proved to be short-lived. Throughout the meal, I encountered considerable difficulty in securing the attention of any server, including Rodrigo, and witnessed multiple instances of tables neighboring ours having their glasses replenished with water in a timely manner while I waited an unacceptable fifteen minutes for a refill. This disparity in service was particularly glaring given the high standards one might expect from a restaurant of this caliber and price range. As a patron, I seek an immersive dining experience that encompasses not only delectable cuisine but also exceptional customer service. Unfortunately, my experience at SOL Cocina fell short of these expectations, leaving a lingering negative impression. In light of this, I would not consider returning to this establishment."

Food was almost average couldve been better had hot  wings and fries blah!..Service incredibly slow on a friday afternoon,had to take my tab and go find the waittress to cash out.Guess cant wrong with the drinks and bottled beer here(only miller and coors on tap).Sports on tvs all over gives it 2 stars.......

Great location, ok rooms, ok restaurants. Horrible staff. I felt like i was inconveniencing them by asking for simple directions. Incredibly rude and everyone looked like they were miserable. Probably the worst part of my experience was the Spa. Please avoid this hell hole even if they offer it to you for free! It is incredibly dirty and smells. I couldnt take more then 20 min and i left to take a long shower in my room. Try calling the front desk and youll wait anywhere from 10 to 20 minutes every time. There are SO many better hotels on the strip around the same price. I will not be staying here again!

I have been meaning to write this review for a long time. My husband and i got married at the Venetian resort, which is an amazing hotel, and we continue going there every year. The night before our wedding we and our four friends decided to go to this cozy looking Italian restaurant mainly the atmosphere seemed very nice and we love Italian food. \n\nHowever, I ordered a pasta dish not sure which one, with chicken and it came without, which I instantly noted to the waiter. Of course the waiter was apologetic, went to the kitchen to ask for the chicken, which I found very strange, perhaps even more strange when the chicken came out in a bowl, they had cooked the already frozen cooked chicken in cream in the microwave, so basically I was meant to add that to my pasta, It was hilariously disappointing, and our friends weren't very impressed about their pizzas either, and barely touched them.
This review is for the food court. It sucks. The price for what you get is ridiculous. Ive had better burgers at McD's and for a third of the price!

"The extraterrestrial ambiance, conveniently removed from the primary foyer and offering an unobstructed panorama of the aquatic facility and the illuminated boulevard, fostered a unique and captivating environment. The prevailing vibration permeating the venue was unequivocally athletic in nature, as numerous flat-screen displays were concurrently transmitting the intense intercollegiate confrontation between the Wisconsin Badgers and the Arizona Wildcats. \n\nThe culinary delight known as a burger was undoubtedly satisfactory, yet the hospitable demeanor and attentive focus demonstrated by our server, Erin, a native of South Dakota, unfortunately did not parallel the quality of the food. A prolonged period of time, specifically forty minutes, elapsed before we received our eagerly anticipated burgers. Furthermore, the temperature of the side dish, specifically the rings, was unacceptably low, rendering them inedible. Although the management elected to compensate us for the deficient quality of the meal by gratis, it would have been vastly preferable to receive our nourishment in a timely and thermally suitable manner. Considering the dearth of patrons within the establishment, it was challenging to comprehend the root cause of the delay. However, taking into account the recurring pattern of dissatisfaction expressed in various online reviews, it appears that this eatery consistently encounters difficulties in regard to the efficiency and effectiveness of its service staff."

Maybe it was an off night?  This is the worst review I have given.  It is my Son's 26th birthday today so we met up with him at Brat Haus.  I had a really good feeling about this place due to it's current star rating on Yelp and the way it is designed.  It  has a really cool vibe.  The service and food were not acceptable.  The Scottsdale market demands good food and this place is not making the cut. My son ordered a Chorizo Dog and he sent it back (no flavor). My wife and I split a burger and they did not ask how I wanted it cooked. The burger arrived and it was well done and the only flavor I could taste in it was a strong taste of pepper?  It was horrible, I am sure they cook it to death because the quality of the beef won't allow them to cook it on the rare side.

I did not drink but we had plenty of beer lovers at the table who were ready to have a beer or two but they had a hard time getting a server to stop by and take their order.  

I tried some of the other's food and the only thing I found to be tasty was the pretzel fundido.  Not sure I will try Brat Haus again.

I wouldn't call it great food. I had lunch here and the wonton soup was good. The Orange flavored chicken was average or even a little less than average. The fried rice that came with it was.....well....it tasted like white rice. Looked similar to fried but was pretty boring too. \nI would compare the quality to panda express. Not great, but an acceptable alternative to fast food. Only downside to that is that you have a waitress you have to tip here. \nThe dining area is odd, with boxes of supplies piled up on the right side of the entrance area. Makes it look cluttered and unfinished.

OK sushi. It has been my fervent desire to partake in the consumption of sushi on multiple occasions. Whenever I find myself engaged in the act of perusing the aisles of various retail establishments such as Home Depot, Target, or Pet Smart in pursuit of items necessary for either home improvement or the satisfaction of my pet's needs, I experience an unwavering inclination towards indulging in a serving of sushi accompanied by a refreshing glass of cold Japanese beer. Furthermore, I have had the good fortune of discovering a dining establishment specializing in the culinary delights of Japan situated in close proximity to the parking area of Home Depot, thereby rendering it easily accessible. However, much to my dismay, my expectations have been consistently thwarted each and every time I have endeavored to sample their offerings, leaving me in a state of utter disappointment.

It was just ok, I got up sold for the hand wax and then tipped pretty well in advance to assure a good job, when It was ready the didn't really do a good job cleaning the inside, still had trash in the floor and door panels... Outside and tires wet pretty good though... I would say just use them for te cheap exterior wash next time

... this was the worst experience with a class/instructior I've had in my 10 plus years practicing yoga.

I decided, on a recent trip to Phoenix, to drop in to a Candlelight Yoga class. Sounded really nice and relaxing. Not ... so ... much ....   I just don't understand why there has to be pop music blaring in the background THE WHOLE CLASS  ?? How about some softer music? Or silence. I found it both annyoing and super distracting.

The instructor was very uninvolved and seemed bored. She paced back and forth in front of the room at the beginning of class ... she did not at any point seem calm, centered or really connected to what was going on with her students. It was like she was distracted, or tired ... or BORED.

What it was, and why I gave it two stars (and not one) was a good workout. Oh, and the studio is really nice ... urban, artsy, hipster style.

I guess this is what they mean by competitive yoga. Everyone decked out in lulu, trying to outpose one another. Nothing wrong with that, but not my thing ... and I would advise anyone who's looking for more depth, presence and actual flow to try somewhere else.

This was my second visit. I had a great experience my first time in- very personable waitress, great service overall and a really great sandwich. I ordered the cheese-stuffed tenderloin with their \"signature\" white sauce. Disappointment. The sauce was yellow (the waitress said it was because of the addition of paprika) but honestly, it tasted like cheese wiz but on the watery side. It did not have a good flavor- very bland. The pork was pretty tough for being a tenderloin and I wished I had a serrated blade with which to saw through it. Not sure what happened today in the kitchen. In the future I will stick with sandwiches. They do that pretty well. And even though I left half of my meal on the plate there was no offer to discount my meal- even by 25%, which would have probably made me happy enough to have not even written this review. Restaurants are a tricky business. You have to be great in the kitchen -or hire someone who is - and have a great business sense- or hire someone who does.

I halted my journey en route to California in this establishment, seeking a gluten-free consumable before boarding my flight. The atmosphere was bustling, with only two overworked servers attempting to accommodate the demands of an abundance of patrons. The interior layout consisted of a lengthy bar, characteristic of Las Vegas, accompanied by numerous compact tables and booths with minimal space between them. 
 My server, though well-intentioned, conveyed a few options she believed would cater to my dietary restrictions. However, her uncertainty regarding the menu items' gluten content prompted her to consult the kitchen staff. Upon inquiry, they granted permission for me to order the nachos, albeit with a notable language barrier between us. Thus, I opted for the nachos, which proved satisfying, comprising chicken, a cilantro sauce, nacho cheese, and jalapeÃ±os. The portion size was generous, and I preserved some for later consumption. Fortunately, I did not experience any adverse effects, suggesting that the nachos are a reliable choice at this venue. 
 Additional observations include a customer complaining about unsanitary silverware, although mine appeared clean. While the food arrived promptly, the service was somewhat lacking regarding refilling water glasses and attending to other needs. The prices aligned with typical airport fare. 
 Ultimately, this restaurant is adequate, and I may opt to sample a different dish during my next visit.

I bought two overpriced drinks -- a vodka soda and a vodka cranberry -- from a grouchy bartender who skipped over people who had been waiting for much longer in order to serve loud drunk girls.  Dude, all I wanted was to buy these drinks and go on my way.  There were, at most, 7 people at the bar.  Took 15 minutes to get a couple of weak drinks.  Should have saved my money.

Just sad how this franchise killed my opinion of this restaurant chain. Quality has gone down drastically since opening. A great burger does not give excuses for poor service and quality. This is my last experience here.... one of my 3 combos of half & half included 3 onion rings and 14 fries. My expectations as a customer that has had Fudd before... 5 to 7 onion rings 20 to 25 fries. No combo my family ate today met my expectations. Dirty tables. Dirty restroom. Dirty floors. Nickel & dime the customers.

"Subpar culinary offerings and beverages. Innovative eatery design. Attentive service personnel and management. 

On the evening of First Friday, which coincided with the establishment's inaugural day, the venue was brimming with patrons. A regrettable choice, indeed. The manager who stopped by our table acknowledged that he had yet to sample the fare or drinks offered. This admission served as an additional indication of the subpar execution evident throughout our dining experience. 

An unfamiliar selection of artisanal beers, mediocre in quality. Batch-made mixed drinks, according to staff, possessed a diluted taste. Unanimously, they were deemed unsatisfactory. 
                                                     
A trio of chip and dip options, including salsa, guacamole, and queso, graced the appetizer menu. The chips, curiously, exhibited a texture reminiscent of undercooking or staleness. Underwhelming in flavor, the salsa, queso, and guacamole failed to impress. The queso, in particular, displayed a remarkable resemblance to potato soup. 

Five tacos graced the menu, each plagued by its own shortcomings. Carne asada and carnitas suffered from an unfortunate dearth of moisture and flavor. Their temperatures ranged from tepid to chilly. Unique, the cactus variety boasted a subtle grilled essence, though its appeal remained limited. Overpowering breading and frying marred the calamari, while flavorless chicken, seemingly reheated frozen poultry, was enhanced solely by a hasty sauce addition mere moments before serving. 

Despite these setbacks, service staff and managers demonstrated genuine concern and attention, frequently approaching our table and ultimately offering complimentary compensation for our meal. An invitation to revisit and assess any potential improvements in cuisine quality was extended. If progress ensues, I shall eagerly revise this critique accordingly."

"Once again, I am perplexed by Yelp's propensity to generate dual pages for the same venue, with the sole dissimilarity lying in the utilization of abbreviations within the street address. 

When this eatery first opened its doors nearly a decade ago, it was truly exceptional. The management exhibited a warm and welcoming demeanor towards patrons of all ages, the prices were reasonable, and the pizza and chicken wings were utterly delectable. In fact, I recall Amore forming a mutually beneficial agreement with my cousin's middle school, whereby they would provide pizza for the students every Friday, much to their delight. 

However, I cannot pinpoint the exact moment when the quality of service and food began to deteriorate, but it is evident that a shift occurred within the past five years. Following the transfer of ownership from the original proprietor, the restaurant underwent a drastic transformation. The staff, once comprised of dedicated individuals who took great pride in their work, was replaced by teenagers seeking supplementary income. Consequently, the quality of the cuisine suffered, with prices escalating steadily over time. 

Nowadays, this establishment has degenerated into yet another money-oriented restaurant, sorely lacking in the exceptional quality and commitment to customer satisfaction that once distinguished it from its competitors. If only Amore remained under the stewardship of its original owner, it would undoubtedly continue to rank among the premier pizza destinations in Scottsdale. Unfortunately, it has succumbed to mediocrity."

"I refrain from frequenting Panda Express due to my previous encounters with overcooked vegetables and subsequent gastrointestinal discomfort. However, given the limited dining options during the renovation of our kitchen, I opted to give their Buckeye location a try. While my expectations were tempered, I was pleasantly surprised by the freshness and crispness of the vegetables, which replaced the customary noodles or rice in my entree. Unfortunately, the chicken and mushrooms, along with the Shanghai Angus steak, lacked distinct flavors and were somewhat forgettable, despite being palatable. Ultimately, while it served its purpose in a pinch, I would not consider Panda Express a primary dining destination, as my culinary skills and budgetary constraints allow me to prepare superior meals at home."

We came as a party of four without a reservation. We had about a twenty minute wait, no big deal so we sat at the bar. I Decided on a mojito that was great. Cheers to the bartender. 

We were sat at our table in the outdoor dining area. There was live music playing below our seating area that was great. This was the end of our positive experiences here.

The service was lackluster, not terrible, just nothing special. Any drinks ordered seemed to take some time before coming to the table. Everyone ordered a different meal from the menu. 

The food was nothing to write home about. Our appetizers came out timely, some melted cheese & chips. Then came entrée. It was $30 for three small tacos that were not very impressive. Finally, the desert. A very bland banana cream pie. 

I'd give this place another shot. There were some other choices on the menu I'd like to try some time.

I was thoroughly not impressed by this place.  Vacant tables were not cleaned and there was generally uninspired staff and service.  The cashier didn't take my order correctly; she asked me about what sauce I wanted with my fish (tartar) and didn't put it in my takeout order.  Another customer approached the counter to ask for bread after it was left out of his dinner.  I subsequently found that it was left out of my dinner order as well.\n\nThe chicken, although nice and crispy, was pretty bland.  I'll say the same for the catfish (Old Bay seasoning, anyone?)  The cole slaw was not very fresh.  The Chicago Harold's left me with a better impression even though it was a hole-in-the-wall storefront spot.  I would not recommend that you waste your time or money at this place.

Panchero's Mexican Grill looked interesting to eat at, I love how they prepare their tortilla's in the big presser they have - but that's the only thing that impressed me; the tortilla's... Since they're freshly made, they're still yummy and \"gooey\" - The staff was really nice when we entered, and was attentive to what we wanted for our orders :)\n\nI got a pretty basic burrito but was disappointed at the rice, the other two people in our party compared it to Uncle Ben's rice, the steak we got seemed \"boiled\", the medium salsa wasn't as spicy as I thought it was (but they do have a counter filled with different hot sauces; of course I grabbed the Tapat\u00edo), although the salsa was flavorful. My friends had ordered a chicken quesadilla - they were good but not great. It seemed they only had Montery Jack as their cheese. The prices were pretty decent, I think next time I will try something else though!

I have had the pleasure of frequenting Rositas for an approximate duration of ten to fifteen years, primarily during the luncheon hours of the workweek. Their tacos possess an exceptional quality, while their enchiladas, though rich in cheesy flavor, have a propensity to induce a state of drowsiness. Despite this, Rositas has remained one of my preferred establishments, garnering a rating of four stars; however, my most recent visit, which included my family, proved to be somewhat underwhelming. The culinary offerings were merely satisfactory, and the service was subpar, with our server appearing discontent and neglecting to attend to our needs in a timely manner. Specifically, one of our orders was incorrect, and it went uncorrected due to the absence of our server for an extended period. Additionally, there was a considerable delay in receiving both the tortillas accompanying the fajitas and the bill itself. While I typically patronize Rositas on a monthly basis, my last visit occurred several months ago, leading me to hope that this experience was an anomaly rather than indicative of a decline in the restaurant's overall quality.

"The erstwhile Nabisco plant has undergone a transformative metamorphosis into what is now known as Bakery Square, an exemplary instance of urban revitalization. This once-forgotten enclave has been resurrected into a thriving hub of activity, boasting an array of cutting-edge enterprises such as Google, Urban Active Fitness, and a charming, albeit diminutive, coffee establishment (whose name momentarily eludes me). Sufficient subterranean parking is available, although it is advisable to avoid peak hours if you seek to avoid the throngs of luxury vehicle owners who seem to take great pleasure in vociferously announcing their presence via the incessant honking of their horns."

"Grossly overpriced for the paltry three items of equipment offered. My five-year-old was utterly unimpressed and bored after a mere sixty minutes, while my twenty-month-old found mild entertainment in the 'Toddler Zone' for approximately half an hour. Do not forget to bring your own socks, as they are sold at an exorbitant rate of nearly three dollars per pair...

The sole attraction suitable for young children under three years of age is the 'Toddler Zone,' comprising a meager six padded shapes and a diminutive bounce house, which, admittedly, my offspring did enjoy, albeit briefly. The remaining equipment caters exclusively to children aged four and above.

Although the staff were amicable, the facility's cleanliness was satisfactory, with the exception of the bathrooms, which required a more thorough sanitizing and renovation. 

In conclusion, the experience was not worth the exorbitant fee of twenty-two dollars for a mere ninety minutes, and I would instead opt to take my progeny to either Bounce Jungle or Bounce U, where the cost is approximately half as much."

Second run to the Indian Land Red Bowl and left disappointed.  The service was just fine, but the food was blah. Won Ton soup was OK, good broth.  Beef a la Szechuan was pretty flavorless and the Sea of Love seafood combo was really blah.

There is a pervasive lack of spice and flavor in their dishes.  Too bad for a nice location and very nice décor.

I doubt if we will return.

"Although I have had the pleasure of indulging in more delectable Indian cuisine, particularly for the price point, my recent dining experience at this establishment left much to be desired. The ambiance, while quaint and charming, did not justify the exorbitant cost of the meal, especially considering the subpar quality of the service. Our server, in particular, displayed an unfortunate lack of professionalism and courtesy, which only served to further mar the overall dining experience. Upon ordering the saag paneer, which carried a price tag of $17, I was disappointed to discover that the portion size was rather meager, despite its otherwise satisfying taste. Additionally, the naan, while undoubtedly delicious, seemed overpriced at $4 per piece. It is worth noting that the restaurant closes between lunch and dinner seatings, which may potentially inconvenience some patrons. In light of these factors, I do not foresee myself returning to this eatery in the near future."

I had aspired to relish this establishment, as they had ostensibly invested a considerable amount of capital in its renovation. However, the culinary offerings and hospitality did not align with their architectural endeavors. I had intended to partake in a rapid repast at the bar, but the environment was somewhat disorderly, with barstools scattered haphazardly, which, although seemingly inconsequential, demonstrated a lack of attention to detail that I had previously overlooked. The personnel appeared to be a group of juveniles left to their own devices, carelessly dropping tableware and engaging in boisterous banter. The pollo fundido was unfortunate, possessing an unpleasant flavor reminiscent of flour and a superficial resemblance to a mushroom soup sans mushrooms. The dish itself resembled a fried fajita wrap, which only added to my disappointment. Despite my initial enthusiasm, this establishment failed to meet my expectations, and I sincerely hope they address their shortcomings.

I presumed that by entering the establishment and placing my order directly, I could circumvent potential errors. Unfortunately, my strategy proved ineffective, as the staff misinterpreted my instructions and included three additional items on the bill that I had not requested and which were substantially costlier than what I had originally intended to purchase. Despite harboring some skepticism regarding the accuracy of the total amount, I did not verify it until arriving home, at which point I was taken aback by the unexpected and exorbitant charge.

Used to like coming here when Market Street had a line (as it so often does) but it's getting harder to find something to order.  The hamburger steak used to be reliably good but this time, it was ... off.  I suspect it is due to whatever was cooked on the grill before they cooked the hamburger patties.  The philly steak sandwich wasn't too good either.  Not enough cheese and the meat kind of tasteless - needed salt.  Was so disappointed we didn't go back for the friend wonton and teri beef, which are our usual standbys.

I ordered her today for lunch at work, I ordered the general Tao chicken, and asked for it SPICY.  I guess that means they just add a packet of hot sauce to your order because the sauce was anything but spicy.  \n\nOn the plus side they use real chicken and nice big chunks.  Not like some places that that are a 1/4 chicken and 3/4 batter.  The thing that will prevent me from ordering there again is they don't do a General Tao sauce to my liking.

Meh, nice patio but lackluster service if it's busy. I don't think we're cool enough to hang here, at least that's how they made us feel, and no one should feel that way as a paying customer. Not worth a return trip.

Never ever will we revert to such an unpleasant dining experience, as the ambiance was tainted by the pungent odor of tobacco smoke and the hospitality was subpar, with the culinary offerings being merely average, and perhaps even surpassed by the likes of IHOP, thereby rendering it unworthy of recommendation to any acquaintance.

"Upon hiring two cleaners for a duration of two hours to perform cleansing duties on an uninhabited condominium, my expectations were not adequately met when I arrived three days post-cleaning. Despite the absence of certain items such as alcohol, spare light bulbs, and cleaning supplies, the overall appearance of the residence remained largely unchanged. Furthermore, I was taken aback by the notion that it was customary to remove all items from cabinets for the benefit of new tenants. In my opinion, a more appropriate approach would be to adopt a 'if it is not yours, do not take it' policy. Notably, the items in question were not classified as garbage. Although the cleaners did perform some tasks such as cleaning the oven, refrigerator, and a select few drawers, their efforts were largely inconsequential, as evidenced by the fact that my bare feet became covered in dirt and grime after merely walking around the freshly cleaned condo for thirty minutes. Additionally, despite their offer to return and provide additional cleaning services, I deemed it unnecessary to invest further time and resources into their subpar performance. Needless to say, I will not be engaging their services once more."

"Gross!!!!

A dearth of diversity characterizes this buffet's offerings, with a meager selection of pasta, pizza, and Chinese cuisine available for a hefty price tag of $30. Furthermore, the establishment touts its'seafood section' as a notable aspect of the menu, yet said section consists merely of an array of fried items, including unpeeled shrimp. 

The pulled pork and chicken dishes were regrettably lacking in texture, having been cooked to a sodden state and inundated with copious amounts of BBQ sauce. Canned beans rounded out the underwhelming experience, and the salad bar's rigid adherence to pre-assembled salads left much to be desired. 

Exacerbating the disappointment was the subpar service, which bordered on neglectfulness and necessitated the intervention of a manager. 

Despite these shortcomings, the edibility of the fare and the appeal of the desserts, including miniature donuts, ice cream, and cookies, warrant an additional star in this review."

"Despite my recurring monthly payments, the quality of service I received was subpar and left much to be desired. The domicile was merely superficially cleaned, with a cursory swipe of dusters and mops, leaving behind an unacceptable amount of grime and dirt. The cleaning personnel seemed to be in a hurry, rapidly completing their tasks without adequate attention to detail or thoroughness. The tiled floors, in particular, were abysmally cleaned, as evidenced by the photographs I took after their purported 'cleaning' and brought to their attention on multiple occasions. Unfortunately, this company's approach to cleaning lacks the necessary diligence and personal touch, rendering their services unsatisfactory."

Disagree with previous post. Went to 1902 tavern for lunch a few weeks back. To start the waiter appeared to be either on crack or speed. Second I was with a party of 4 that all ordered salads. I decided to go with the steak. Awful call on my part. The salad took 45 minutes to arrive, along with the cracked out waiter (who we hadn't seen for at least 30 minutes) The steak was total bullshit. Overcooked and cold. The salad had way too much iceberg lettuce and tasted like crap. I won't be back until Pittsburgh decides to clean up Market square and all of the vargrants that inhabit the area. Where do these people come from? and is there nothing better to do except sit around market square, smoke cigarettes and throw your trash everywhere so city workers can clean up after your filthy asses? My advice to you son, is do the same as your father, and his father did...get a job!!!

If hometown buffet opened a casino, this is what it would be like. 

Paid $25.99 each.   For what you paid for, this place just sucks.  Dining area is like a high school cafeteria, noisy and drafty.  Lots of food varieties cooked to mediocrity. 

Pro: they have beer (served in a solo cup like a carnival). 
Con: they only serve Miller light

Here's a tip: don't drop your fork because you only get one.

Same as the first review.  It's close and near my place of employment but unfortunately every time I try it out the chicken tenders are always dry as hell. The corn and potatoes can be kept on a heat lamp for the most part but when it comes to the chicken it should be cooked to order. Skip Popeye's Louisiana and head to canes.

I was craving dim sum late night, and this was the only place that was open. Since I've been craving dim sum for a few months now, this place got lucky that I devoured everything in front of me. The bad news, I got food poisoning. I knew there was something wrong with the pork shumai when it reeked of bad pork and the cavier on top was still gooey on top, but I was beyond hungry and going through one of my cravings so I forged ahead. There is a limited dim sum menu for night time. Here is the breakdown: Edible and decent: sweet custard buns and shrimp balls. Reminiscent of dim sum: banana leaf sticky rice, shrimp potstickers and pork buns. Either bland or bad: pork shumai and shark fin potstickers. I heard there are much better places to go for dim sum in Vegas...so don't go here for it, unless it's really late and you are beyond crave monster status. FYI - I saw a family order 7 orders of fried rice...maybe that is what I should have ordered....

I placed a telephonic communication at precisely 6 p.m. to inquire about the existence of a designated area for minors, specifically mentioning my youngest child's age of two years. The masculine entity who responded to my query affirmed the presence of such a section, prompting me to express my gratitude and announce our impending arrival. Upon arriving at the establishment at 6:30 p.m., we proceeded to settle our financial obligations, at which point the same individual who had previously addressed me conveyed an additional piece of information regarding the closing time of the aforementioned children's area, specifically 7 p.m. This revelation struck me as somewhat perplexing and inconvenient, considering the fact that it was already past that hour. It is worth considering the potential benefits of apprising prospective patrons of such details during initial interactions, particularly those initiated during the evening hours. Furthermore, I must confess that the notion of restricting access to the children's section during specific periods seemed somewhat baffling, especially given the presence of a nine-year-old and a two-year-old within my group. Following a request for a reimbursement, we opted to seek alternative recreational facilities, ultimately selecting Jumpstreet, which I would highly recommend due to their policy of maintaining a consistently accessible children's area throughout their operating hours, as well as their commendable attention to cleanliness.

"It is my opinion that this establishment did not meet expectations in terms of service and culinary offerings, with the staff exhibiting a lack of promptness and cordiality, and the food, specifically the hummus, being characterized by an overabundance of tahini and a dearth of lemon juice and seasoning, rendering it unpalatable, while the lentil soup was reminiscent of a poorly prepared version of Chef Boyardee's chili, and thus, I would not recommend this venue to anyone seeking a satisfactory dining experience, given the abundance of alternative options in the vicinity."

This place always runs out of items on the menu. I've ordered the chicken fried steak twice and it never comes with the fresh bread they advertise. In this visit alone I've heard the waitress tell two tables they didn't have baked potatoe or a breakfast item. Our waitress appeared lithargic and took a long cigarette break while all her tables waited on her and the cook. It was bad enough she didn't check up on her guest often enough. The team leader is no better. She's helped us twice before. Never smiles. its enough to make someone depressed. Luckly the food they have is great on an empty stomach. Love the unlimited hot coco. Avoid the water. Tastes like algee.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
The text is: "I have been here multiple times and every time I come I am disappointed. The portions are small and the prices are high. I don't think it's worth it. I won't be coming back."
The modified text is: 

"Consistently underwhelming experiences with too much repetition."

This place was nothing fantastic. We started with spring rolls and they were average. Then I had the Pacific Cove salad, which was a little too fishy and I am not sure I liked how each item was segregated on the plate. The crab and shrimp seemed like they were just pulled from the freezer. Everything was just okay. For the money it wasn't worth it. \n\nThe atmosphere was nothing special either... just another regular chain-like setting.

Loved this place for a while. I don't mind that it's closed on Sundays as I work on the weekends. The problem I find is that checkout usually takes about 20 minutes, sometimes longer. Tons of checkout stations with very little staff. 6 stations, 2 open with 30 people in line at one in the afternoon. Usually you hear the manager get on the speaker "cashiers to the front". Not here. Just wait in line, wasting away the day. It wouldn't bother me as much if I didn't see 20 or more employees walking around all over the store. 

Even with the long lines, this was the only store that sold Dill buttons. If you aren't someone that uses buttons that often, this means nothing. Dill makes high quality buttons for blazers and suits. Metal and plastic. The Hobby Lobby brand and most other brands are plastic crap. Recently HL has stopped selling Dill and only offers the store brand so they can do 2 for 1 specials. 

At least I don't have to bother with the lines anymore. Now I order online.

"Astonishingly, the assortment of merchandise available for purchase was truly remarkable. However, in light of the unfortunate events that transpired during my previous excursion to the shopping center on Black Friday, wherein I was compelled to partake in an arduous and chaotic retail experience due to the constraints imposed by a gift certificate that was only valid during that specific weekend, I opted to adopt a more meticulous and strategic approach to my shopping endeavors this time around. Thus, I embarked upon my shopping spree last weekend, commencing at 10:40 a.m. with an eerie sense of calmness and organization permeating the atmosphere, devoid of the customary throngs of shoppers and discarded shopping bags that typically characterize such occasions. Miraculously, I managed to procure every item on my list, including four items, which, regrettably, included a gift item that I was unable to return or exchange due to the restrictions associated with the gift certificate. Furthermore, I was taken aback by the lax policies governing the consumption of alcohol within the premises, which led to an incident involving a young woman ascending the escalator in the incorrect direction, thereby eliciting my utter disbelief and consternation. In conclusion, despite the tranquil nature of the shopping experience, it was still unsettling to witness such anomalies transpire at the Forum Shops, and I cannot fathom how Forever 21 could possibly condone such occurrences."

We were tardy in our arrival, which resulted in the unfortunate circumstance of our accommodations being relinquished, thereby necessitating our transferral to an alternative lodging establishment, only to return to the original hotel the subsequent night. This turn of events was utterly dissatisfying. Notwithstanding this inconvenience, we did receive complimentary morning repasts for a pair of nights, and the continental breakfast offered on the superior level surpassed my expectations considerably. However, it must be noted that the aforementioned executive level boasted a fitness center with restricted operational hours and an additional fee for usage, as well as an internet connection that also carried an extra charge. In my opinion, these aspects were somewhat disillusioning.

"A plethora of establishments offering gastronomical delights at reasonable prices abound, rendering the exorbitant cost of dining at this particular restaurant utterly unnecessary; my taste buds were subjected to an unfortunate assault by the excessive sodium content in the shrimp adorning my salad, which caused discomfort and temporary lingual debilitation; however, the scallops and steak proved to be somewhat satisfying, yet ultimately failed to justify the preposterous tariff."

I have been here about 3 times, twice  for the weekend breakfast buffet and once for lunch. The food is similar to Denny's, so nothing special here. Everything here feels dingy and dirty, there was hair in one of the dishes in the buffet. Service is average, but employees are just as dirty looking as the restaurant..will not be coming here anymore.

I am perplexed by all the 5 star reviews.  As out of towners we just wanted somewhere nearby our work place.   The place was packed and so we had a 30 min wait, no problem, but humorless greeter was downright misog, no smiles all night.  Bad start.  Tofu appetiser with ikkura and condiments was delicious, great tofu.  Hand Scallop Soy roll was badly made, small and not spicy like I asked for.  Edamame overcooked, various rolls including the monster were lack lustre and ingredients just not fresh.  Tuna sashimi was sent back twice.  \nNo alteration to bill was made.  green tea creme bruless, tasty but teeny weeny portion.  Sake was great but for $12 a bottle it should be OK.

"Subpar service experience with too much repetition."  I had a pedicure, and while the polish appeared satisfactory, the remainder of the treatment was disappointing. The young man who performed the service seemed to assault me with cuticle clippers, leaving my skin feeling raw and irritated. Four hours have passed, and I am still experiencing discomfort. The massage component of the service was also lacking, failing to provide adequate relaxation. Furthermore, during the manicure process, both my friend and I were left sitting in the pedi chair, enduring an unpleasant and painful experience as the staff members pulled our arms out of their sockets. Consequently, I do not anticipate returning to this establishment for any future services.

The ambiance is deliciously dark and a throwback to the grand old days of quality tablecloths and real silverware.
The service here was very sub-par.  Perhaps that was because I was dressed like an ignorant tourist that just wanted to be comfortable checking out the city---FYI--tourists have money to spend, too...
I hate the fact that most upscale steak restaurants ignores the needs of patrons who want to watch their waistline.
My husband likes steak, BUT--- I want to eat healthy.  So, how about some healthy options, Capital?  
I had to special order my salad and take off a bunch of junk. There entree-sized salad was fit for a mouse that had already eaten...I  left hungry! Ugh.
Plus---my special order came out wrong and I had to (once again) watch my husband eat while I fantasized about how many carbs were in the napkin...
Oh, I won't be coming back.  There are too many other great places to spend my well-earned money on.

"For the benefit of indulging in a refreshing beverage and enjoying quality entertainment, the temperature of the beer is satisfactorily cool, the televisions are of impressive quality, and the culinary offerings, while not exceptional, are palatable. However, the aspect of customer service unfortunately suffers from a consistent decline in quality, reaching an unacceptable level that is utterly appalling. It has been divulged to me on numerous occasions that the high turnover rate among staff members can be attributed to an inadequate management style and a lack of respectful treatment towards employees. Thus, it is advisable to cease patronizing this establishment, particularly given the abundance of alternative sports bars that boast commendable staff and a welcoming atmosphere."

This place is just too hyped up.  I ordered a burger medium well and it was oozing red on the inside.  i could barely fit my mouth around it.  I'm sorry but burgers are 100% about perfect proportioning of quality ingredients.  If you want to make a bigger bugger, make it bigger in a direction that makes sense.  Burgers are my favorite food, but I was not thrilled by this place.  Stack'd in shadyside is better for 1/4 the price.  Also the restaurant was freezing cold!  I was sat at a teeny high table where our plates could barely fit even though the restaurant was mostly empty.  I didn't like the way the burgers were served also, they were crammed in a tiny basket that made it hard to eat.  Don't get me wrong this place isn't bad, but there are so many other places nearby that will give you better food/atmosphere for a fraction of brgr price.

L'hamburger steak est ok  mais trop ch\u00e8re. Il commence \u00e0 4.50$ mais peut monter facilement \u00e0 une dizaine de dollars avec les extras. Le take out peut prendre facilement une quinzaine de minutes (pour un hamburger). Trop de boucane \u00e0 l int\u00e9rieur aussi lorsque il est en pleine production.

Ok, so I've never had pho before this, so I don't have a benchmark. What I do know was the pho was really bland, so the second time I tried the Asian Invasion cheesesteak... $9 for a sandwich with nothing else, made on a cheap store-bought roll that tasted nothing like french bread. 

When my sister saw I wasn't all that enthusiastic about my sandwich, she offered to let me try her banh mi. It was super salty and on the same roll, with veggies that I thought were supposed to be pickled but lacked any bite.

Put enough sriracha on anything and it's edible, but for these prices, I want better.
Went for Sunday brunch. Edible items include bacon and funnel cake strips. Everything else appeared to have been purchased frozen from Sam's club.

I've been to this establishment twice.  The first time we did not have a reservation.  We bellied up to the bar and waited, and waited and waited...eventually a table opened.  I had no complaints that night.  The food was lovely as was the atmosphere.

Fast forward to tonight.  We had a 5:30 reservation for a birthday celebration.  At 7:09 we were told that we needed to leave as the table was spoken for.  Now granted we were winding down anyways, but A) this was a terrible business practice and B) yes the table was spoken for, BY US.  They knew we were celebrating a birthday and did bring out a very lovely birthday surprise for the birthday girl.  But for 60 bucks a plate I do not expect to be rushed out the door.

So now that we've gotten the service outta the way - onto the food, this is a restaurant after all.  Well, my meal of tenderloin tips was super salty but still pleasant.  The dessert (key lime pie) was really good.  My dining companions had the special - a prime rib/ shrimp combo.  They said the shrimp scampi was really good, but they've had better prime rib.

I'm just flummoxed, why would Beef and Bottle risk alienating customers?  I sure as heck won't be back.  Oh and I got sick from my meal - not sure if it was me or them, but after being rushed out the door I'm gonna say it was them!  I will not be back.

Chez ma grosse truie cherie was not really on my list of must try Montreal's restaurants. I ended up here because with a group on 5, it was not easy to get a reservation on a busy Saturday night. This restaurant seems to catered to large groups with communal tables and family style menu, which seems to be well suited our party of five.

Service was attentive and excellent. I wish the food can match the service. 

We shared: 

Oysters ($15) - Apple ice cider vinegar from Vergers de la Colline
- Not bad, I had better oysters..

Chef Choice Seared Foie Gras ($23)
- The best part of the meal... I would just come back to have that
- Love how the sourness of the fresh grapes compliment the fattiness of the foie gras
- No sharing! All mine!

The Whole Hog ($32/pp) - Baby back ribs, smoked grilled pork chop, braised shanks, braising juices and parmesan cheese French fries 
- The platter looked amazing for photos but most of the meat tasted bland and dry
- The only thing I enjoyed was the shank which was tender and moist
- I did enjoy the roasted vegetables... 

The only saving grace might be some local beers in bottles... Dieu du Ciel did make the dining experience a little more enjoyable.

Sadly I doubt I will be coming back again really soon...... unless I can have that foie gras all for myself!
Food was good. Waitress \"Maggie\" has no common sense. Spoke with owner and got things cleared up. Still won't go back again.

Why do people eat here?  It was packed on a Thursday night.  We had to eat in the bar to avoid a 20 minute wait to be seated.  Everything on the menu is SOOO Expensive.  The only reason we stayed and ate is we had a $50 gift card.

Wanted to order something eat that we could share while having our cocktails.  The waitress could not recommend or guarantee anything that was gluten free.  So I just ate all the free bread and butter they brought and then we ordered dessert.  He got the ice cream sundae and I had a lemoncello raspberry cheesecake or something like that.  The waitress recommended it.  It wasn't very good at all.  I only ate a few bites because I didn't want to waste eating that many calories on something not so tasty.

With three cocktails (A mojito for me and 2 gin and tonics for him), the sundae and slice of cheesecake, with tip was $45).  I think that is quite a bit.

The best part was the free bread, no joke.  Service was pretty horrid as well.

First, this place reeks of being a national-chain-franchise-type restaurant.  The staff is trying to be enthusiastic like they have been instructed, but it feels very fake.  

Otherwise, the burgers are good.  As you have heard, the standard burger contains two patties, the smaller version has one.  The fresh-cut fries were excellent, maybe the best in Tempe.

We may go back, but probably won't go out of our way.

The rooms are very nice, clean and comfortable. 

Family above us was very loud, early in the morning I could hear them eating stomping on the floor.arguing...chairs sliding etc.. really took away from the experience.,

We were in the Lily building right behind the office. The parking was horrible, there were never any spots near the building open. Had to dump the in-laws on the curb since they are not able to walk so much. Then Id drive around praying for someone to leave. the casino next door was closer than the parking garage to our building.

WiFi is an issue too.. 40 bucks for the week on 1 device.. gosh every hotel we were at on our trip had free WIFI but not the most expensive.. .. I only pay 19.99 a month at home.

One of my guests was approached at check in to do the time share presentation. The lady started filling out a form for him for the next morning and he said he may not be able to go but would try, she rudely asked him if he was going or not? He told her he didnt know, she tore up the slip and said never mind have a nice day.. REALLY??? Welcome to Vegas!

My wife goes here ever chance she get, but I refuse to go with her. Coffee deserves 5 stars but the chick behind the counter is so rude. I refuse to spend money at a place that lets it indie hipster staff treat regular Joe's like my self rudely.

We have had the misfortune of experiencing subpar service on three separate occasions during our visits to this establishment, which has unfortunately diminished our overall satisfaction with our dining experience despite the breathtaking panorama that the restaurant boasts.

"Had the pleasure of partaking in a culinary excursion at this esteemed establishment last week, and my expectations were elevated due to its illustrious reputation in the city's gastronomic circles. While the experience was not without its merits, it fell short of my lofty expectations in certain aspects. The ambiance was reminiscent of a bygone era, with its classic Italian restaurant decor and pictorial representations of celebrated patrons adorning the walls, creating an atmosphere that was both convivial and nostalgic. The staff were attentive, courteous, and displayed a proficiency in their duties that was truly commendable. However, the cuisine, while certainly palatable, did not quite live up to the standards that one might expect from an establishment of such renown. My veal dish, in particular, was satisfactory but failed to meet the expectations that I had cultivated based on the acclaim that Rao's has garnered over the years. It seemed as though the kitchen was hesitant to take risks and thus produced a generous portion of fare that, while certainly edible, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi that would have elevated it to the realm of true gastronomic excellence. In conclusion, while Rao's possesses a unique charm and a dedication to service that is unparalleled, a modicum of fine-tuning in the culinary department could serve to enhance an already enjoyable dining experience."

"Indifference was my initial reaction, as the culinary offerings, although of satisfactory quality, did not seem to justify the cost, particularly in relation to the hot dogs, which, while flavorful and abundant in toppings, failed to meet my expectations regarding value for money. Furthermore, my anticipation of experiencing the fabled Poutine, a dish revered by my Canadian counterparts, was unfortunately met with disappointment, thereby necessitating a future visit to Quebec to sample the delicacy in its authentic form."

My #1 pet peeve with this airport is that you must board a tram everytime.  Why?  SFO is bigger yet there's no tram.  

While waiting to fly home, the jacked up PA system near gate D1 was ear-piercingly loud and distorted.  Are they oblivious to this?  They even have to add the 3 loud ass toots after their deafening message just for added pleasure. Everyone was covering their ears from the shreiking.  Are they that busy with checking to see if people are sneaking water bottles onboard that they don't know this?

Also, why is it that a taxi ride to the hotel is $25 and only $15 to the airport?  Isn't it essentially the same distance?

Yesterday, I visited this establishment and unfortunately had a subpar experience compared to my previous visits to other Yard House Restaurants. Upon arrival, we were promptly seated, which merited a positive assessment of one star. Our server approached us in a timely manner, and we placed our orders, consisting of a lunch special featuring pizza and tomato basil soup, a children's meal accompanied by pizza and vegetables, an ahi appetizer that served as a main course rather than an introductory dish, and a beer that required an excessive amount of time to be delivered to our table, allegedly due to a keg replacement process. Following a ten-minute delay, the beverage was finally presented to my cousin. Subsequently, we awaited the arrival of our culinary selections, enduring an extensive period of time before their presentation. Fortunately, I had prepared snacks for my three-year-old child, which helped to pacify him during the prolonged waiting period. When the food was eventually served, the cheese on the pizza appeared aged and desiccated, suggesting that it had been exposed to the heat lamp for an extended duration. We sampled a few bites before shifting our focus to the soup, which my child and I essentially shared due to its delectable quality, earning it an additional star. Ultimately, we discarded the remaining pizza slices since they failed to meet our expectations in terms of taste and quality.

Wait wait wait... this place is still open? No, seriously? Um. I'm confused. No, I mean like, in business? Operating? A manager? Employees? Hours of operation? Transact monies? Uhhhhh. You sure? Because when you define \"Air\" as a smoker's patio and \"Earth\" as weird alien shit on the walls and \"Fire\" as the burning of your ear drums and \"Water\" as a place to buy really expensive drinks that dehydrate you, I just can't really comprehend how our $30k millionaire ballers can afford to keep this place going, even in an economic environment that protects only their class. But that's why I'm a $20k impoverished sycophantic parasite on our society. No business sense. \n\nTwo stars for the money they put into this place in the first place. And the elevator to the private VIP bullshit area. Classy. Retarded classiness.

45 minutes d attente, au lieu des 20 annoncees, pour \u00eatre en terrasse, la salle \u00e9tant vraiment trop bruyante, \u00e7a.commencait mal... \"Les meilleures pizzas de Montr\u00e9al\", bon, ca valait surement le coup d attendre. Et bien non... La pizza du chef n'avait aucun interet tout comme les pates d un de mes amis, noy\u00e9s dans une sauce grasse insipide... une addition elevee m'a convaincu de me mettre que deux \u00e9toiles, le seul int\u00e9r\u00eat \u00e9tant la terrasse, agr\u00e9able. Bref, une adresse \u00e0 \u00e9viter, pour qui aime un tant soit peu la cuisine italienne!

"The precise delineation of two celestial bodies: MEH. I'VE ENJOYED SUPERIOR CULINARY EXPERIENCES. \n\nFor an individual who has an unwavering fondness for Korean BBQ and partakes in it with remarkable frequency, I would not advocate for this establishment as a suitable location for satisfying one's KBBQ cravings. Throughout my extensive exploration of diverse KBBQ locales, I have yet to encounter a restaurant that charges such exorbitant prices, which, regrettably, seems to be a common trait among businesses situated within the Strip. Given the prohibitive cost of a meager serving of kogi, I opted to procure dolsot bimbimbap instead. Unfortunately, this particular dolsot bimbimbap proved to be the most expensive instance of its kind that I have had the misfortune of encountering. The eatery, in general, lacked any distinguishing qualities or exceptional characteristics. In light of these factors, I shall confer upon it a rating of two stars, primarily due to the passable quality of the culinary offerings and the waitstaff's commendable honesty regarding the portion size of the KBBQ meat. Needless to say, I do not intend to revisit this establishment in the future."

"There are two categories of individuals who frequent this venue: senior citizens and those possessing complimentary passes. We fell into the latter category, courtesy of my fiancÃ©'s employer, who generously provided us with a pair of tickets to a Regal cinema. Unfortunately, the Regal chain does not have an extensive presence in this particular region, thereby limiting our options. However, we opted to utilize the passes at this establishment, despite its somewhat antiquated nature. The theater itself was rather desolate, with a limited number of staff members present, including a lone individual manning the concession stand and a single employee stationed at the ticket counter. The auditorium itself was modest in size, with a less-than-impressive audio experience and a distinctly retro ambiance. In fact, the seating arrangement was such that one had to ascend a slight incline in order to reach the screen, which struck me as somewhat unusual. Were it not for the complimentary passes, we likely would have elected to depart and seek alternative entertainment. Instead, we chose to persevere and endure the less-than-ideal conditions. Our intention now is to visit the Northsight location, where the second set of tickets can be redeemed. My assumption had been that the majority of Scottsdale was characterized by upscale surroundings and a significant population, rather than the sparse, geriatric demographic that we encountered in Sun City. It has become apparent that this establishment is in need of a radical transformation or, perhaps, even retirement."

This most certainly does not qualify as a three-star hotel or resort, and it barely meets the standards of a two-star establishment. The rooms exude a pungent odor, suggestive of mold and mildew, while the interior and bedding appear unkempt and grimy, giving the impression that they have not been thoroughly cleaned in quite some time. Furthermore, the overall ambiance of the facility seems dilapidated and faded, perhaps hinting at a formerly grandiose reputation that has since diminished significantly. The beds themselves are quite unsatisfactory, characterized by an uneven surface and an unpleasant lack of support, leading one to suspect that they may harbor bed bugs, although upon closer inspection, no such creatures were found. However, a small, mysterious creature was observed in the bathtub, adding to the overall sense of discomfort and unease. On a somewhat positive note, the Speakman shower heads and water pressure were quite impressive, providing a brief respite from the otherwise underwhelming experience that this establishment offers. In conclusion, I would not recommend returning to this hotel/resort, as it fails to meet even the most basic expectations of cleanliness and comfort.

We found ourselves on the aforementioned side of town, eager to indulge in the culinary delights that this establishment purportedly offered, specifically the zucchini fingers that we had heard so much about. However, upon our return, we were dismayed to discover that the aforementioned zucchini fingers lacked the crispiness that we had anticipated, instead displaying a remarkable propensity to bend in half when lifted, which rather detracted from the overall experience. Furthermore, we were taken aback by the absence of tatziki sauce, which we had been led to believe was an integral component of the dish, only to be presented with a minuscule container for an additional fee. This development struck us as somewhat analogous to visiting an American diner and being charged extra for ketchup, which seemed incongruous with our preconceived notions of what constituted a satisfactory dining experience. 
Additionally, we observed that the zucchini appeared to be in dire need of salt, a deficiency that significantly impacted our enjoyment of the dish. Our beef and lamb gyro, while adequate, was regrettably characterized by a notable dryness, while my husband's Oscar burger, renowned for its inclusion of pastrami, suffered from a similar lack of moisture. The accompanying salad, ostensibly intended as a palliative to the uninspiring fare that preceded it, was instead replete with an excessive quantity of dressing, eliciting a response akin to alarm rather than gratitude. In light of these developments, we reluctantly concluded that a future visit to this establishment would not be forthcoming, as more satisfying Greek cuisine could be obtained at Stephanos, a venue situated closer to our domicile.

Speak up if you want a drink before you've dropped $300 in the machines. It's pretty hard to get served. -especially after 10pm, even if its not busy. When you do get your drink, you may want to order a double b/c it's gonna be a short jigger of whatever you ask for. \nThe only reason I give this the 2 stars is because they have a really great \"Rooster\" salad.\nUnfortunately most of the regulars don't seem like the kind of people that eat much. They seem more like the kind of people that took a break from feverishly cleaning their grout & thought they would take their teeth grinding out in public... Very intense. Lol
They should put the flies on the menu! We went for lunch and were bothered by so many flies that it ruined the meal. Just be prepared!

I was sadly disappointed, after reading all the excellent I thought it was shoe in. not so much. Long wait for food then it was just ok. Id rather pay more for food that tastes amazing and doesn't take forever to get.

I was a skeptic of this chemist of brew.

Needless to say, I wasn't too far off.  This is great for a night out with the boys to watch the game.  That's all I can say since I wouldn't recommend coming here to chat.  

I ordered me a beer and some fried fish and chips.  I don't like soggy food, but I guess that's how it comes here.  The fried fish was laid on top of my garlic fries, which were way greasy.  As the fish and fries came together it was a hot soggy mess.  I might want to add tasteless too.

The place definitely has a pub look and feel.  Live music when I came that night, but the football game was going on too.  Rowdy fans and loud music doesn't go well, but I guess it wouldn't matter after a few drinks.  Our service was good, but splitting checks again can be a challenge. - Enjoy!

I personally partook in their midday culinary offering, anticipating a diverse array of gastronomical delights, only to be utterly dismayed by the paltry selection of fare, which included an unfortunate encounter with a particularly sticky honey-glazed poultry dish that left my oral cavity feeling akin to a viscous adhesive substance, thereby rendering any future patronage of this establishment highly unlikely.

After an exhaustive examination of the evaluations, it was determined that giving it a try would be a worthwhile venture.  WOW, capacity crowd on a Sunday evening with a protracted waiting period of twenty minutes. Familiarity with the culinary aspects of Houston, having resided there for seven years, facilitated an informed decision regarding the consumption of the piquant mudbugs.  The crawfish possessed an exceptional quality, devoid of sogginess and moderately seasoned to accommodate my gustatory preferences, opting for the fiery and succulent temperature.  Unfortunately, the establishment had exhausted their supply of stone and blue crab, thus limiting the options to king legs and snow crab.  I selected the diminutive sized snow crabs, while my acquaintance chose the shrimp platter.  Both dishes were predominantly composed of fries.  This eatery would suffer a swift demise in South Texas or the bayou region.

Pros:  Prompt delivery of the culinary offerings, Miller Lite served at a refreshingly low temperature by the bottle.
Cons:  Limited selection of items available during the visit, purporting to offer alcoholic beverages, specifically wine, though solely by the bottle the previous evening.  Ambiance garnered a zero, as the patrons were compactly arranged, evoking the image of sardines, pardon the pun.  Overwhelmed waitstaff, possibly attributable to a lack of experience.  Lemons had to be requested, prompting incredulity.

"Culinary offerings at this establishment are, in my opinion, unpalatable and lacking in substance. The visual appeal of the dishes is fleeting, as the taste and texture fail to deliver on the promises made by their appearance. Specifically, the pasta and noodle dishes are overcooked and smothered in sauce, rendering them unpleasant to consume. Furthermore, the fried items, typically a reliable option, are disappointing due to an excess of breading and oil. The macaroni and cheese, unfortunately, does not deviate from this pattern of mediocrity. The desserts, regrettably, exhibit a similar lack of quality, with some selections tasting bitter and others being unremarkable. Noteworthy exceptions to this trend include the dinner rolls and sautÃ©ed mushrooms, which demonstrate a commendable level of culinary proficiency."

I booked TWO rooms for my and my friends to have a good time in Las Vegas! We love Vegas but will definitely stay at  a different hotel at our next visit.

First, we checked into our first room at 1:30! Yay, one room was ready! and our 2nd room was suppose to be the connecting room next door, but.. that didn't end up happening. :( our 2nd room was not ready until 6:15pm and wasn't even the connecting room! 

And in our 2nd room we didn't have shampoo or conditioner!! So I had to call for them to bring it up but it took them 1 hour to do so because the runner was all backed up! Aye mi. That was just the beginning... Then we called to go to Marque and the concierge put us down, but later we found out from a promoter the club wasn't even open that night! (Thursday on 4th of July!) only one of the rooms (Boombox, which isn't the main one) was open! The concierge failed to tell us that! 

Anyways, I don't want to keep complaining BUT I will say for a luxury hotel, their staff from the receptionist desk to the concierge, to the security that didn't know where things was or how much the buffet cost all need some training. On the job training is NOT enough! I think for this price, the room and staff definitely could have been better. I would stay at an older but more experienced hotel.

Hope this helps!

This is an alright place if you haven't experienced some of the much better places in Arizona.  I think it is somewhat overpriced compared to similar restaurants and the food isn't anything to rave about.

This fitness facility provides an extensive array of exercise classes, but unfortunately, the drawbacks outweigh the advantages. Notably, securing parking is a challenge, and a fee is associated with its usage. Additionally, the staff exhibits a lack of warmth and friendliness, the cost of utilizing the subpar equipment is prohibitive, and it would be preferable to have a staff member stationed at the downstairs desk rather than the upstairs location. Furthermore, I am eagerly anticipating the expiration of my contractual obligation, which I now regret having entered into. Undoubtedly, superior fitness centers exist in close proximity.

Popped in for a take out order on a very busy Sunday afternoon. I don't know why the OG gets so busy on family holidays like Mother's Day, but on this one it was packed solid with people waiting outside, inside and in the bar area.

We were able to place our to go order with the very busy takeout manager. That guy should get five stars. But the rest of the place, not so much. We sat at the bar for 30 minutes waiting to place the order and then waiting for it. Could someone have asked us if we wanted a drink? Maybe offered a glass of water? Nope.

The food was OG standard but again it was packed perfectly with the salad in an interesting container that kept the lettuce and such fresh with the dressing and croutons separate. They also put a separator to keep the cold stuff from affecting the hot stuff.

Two stars because the place was less than tidy and the bar staff didn't seem interested in customers. Otherwise, it would have been pretty good.

If you are going to serve New Mexican food, then serve it, don't water it down and serve things up like they do in the real state. I spent a month there and nobody in hell would use a whole Green chile in making the Chile Relleno. You use either a Poblano or an Aneheim and then cover it in your green chile sauce. The guy next to us eating his meal was complaining alot about how the sauce wasn't hot at all. \n    Chips and salsa were free at the bar - they were decent with two salsa's. Also noticed like another Yelper did that the food comes out like 2 minutes after ordering.
