Following the postprandial festivities, I must admit that the gustatory experience afforded by the cupcakes was quite satisfying, despite my earlier reservations concerning their visual appeal.

I have NO idea why people are raving about this. I was a fan of them on the ABDC, but as a Vegas show they completely FAIL. The only good thing about the show was the music and when they did the first few moves from "Single Ladies" - that cracked me up. 

Otherwise...  the attempted "plot" was lame and made no sense (what's with the dead janitor please?) The dancers were out of sync. The costumes were boring. And the masks completely detracted from any personal connection to any dancer. 

So my rec is: if you score free tickets, watch it, but don't pay for it!

Dear Beat, 
You may be trendy, and you may be in the vicinity of an awesome center for creative space (Emergency Arts), but the hipster staff who take my order are ALWAYS snobby. Please smile and be helpful.
Except for  Heather (she's great) and the cute foreign guy; I like watching him slice my tomato.

Your food menu IS great, and though I think your coffee and espresso are not the finest, the ambiance and weekly events DO make up for that a little. I wish I could love you, but I just don't think the connection is there yet.

Well... I would maybe have been inclined to give Chez Claudette a higher rating if it hadn't been for the following....

ordered a poutine classique to go, and then because it was pouring rain decided to eat it inside by the front door.  Even though the place wasn't busy, our french quebec waitress told us that "next time we order it to go, we have to eat it outside".

the sauce also kind of tasted like thick canned poutine sauce.  

it was still a delicious poutine and we ate the whole thing.

Our small poutine was around $7.  the same price as any other poutine spot.

"Individual, the culinary proficiency of Outback has ostensibly diminished since my last visit. It is my sincere hope that this was merely an isolated incident, rather than a paradigmatic shift in their operational standards. The menu presented numerous inconsistencies, with instances where the listed items did not align with the actual dishes served. Specifically, my spouse requested the Sam Adams on draft, only to receive the Summer Ale instead, which was seemingly attributed to an inventory shortage of the former without any notification or alternative options offered by the server. Furthermore, the chicken artichoke flatbread, while delectable, was excessively bedecked with parmesan cheese, contrary to the menu's description of a "sprinkling." Had I been aware of this discrepancy, I would have explicitly requested a lighter application of cheese. In addition, my steak salad, ordered medium, arrived medium rare, and was accompanied by gorgonzola cheese crumbles, which were not mentioned on the menu. Consequently, I was compelled to return the dish. Although the manager demonstrated politeness in addressing the issue and graciously removed the flatbread from our bill, his attempt to justify the substitution of the Summer Ale for the Boston Lager, due to an alleged absence of the latter, elicited a measure of irritation. Simply put, it would have been appreciated had the server apprised us of this detail initially, thus obviating the need for explanations. Ultimately, the dining experience was unsatisfactory and fell short of my previous expectations."

We had a nice dinner,, but my wife got food posioning..  She woke up 4am and was ill and continued to be ill that day..  Could keep nothing down and very dehiderated.   The management while polite seemed to think I was shaking them down when I asked for a partial discount off our $300 bill..   Rather hard to accept such an event when dining at such a place..  Better luck..

Ok, so going to Vegas, you have to do at least one buffet. However this place should not be on your bucket list.

Crab legs...yes, prime rib yes....but both were of low quality and the prime rib was super dry. And yah, it's supposed to be a French buffet so they did have some of my macarons, but they were gross and unappealing. They didn't care about the presentation at all with respect to the macarons.

The food handles were sticky and gross. There's no wet naps or purell nearby. It's like someone purposefully lathered the the food handles with syrup and pretty much played a prank on everyone. Gross, and unattended, and lack of ownership amongst the cleaners and food servers.

The waitress knows who you are too, ethnicity, etc...so when she saw a bunch of filipinos, she got into Filipino mode. I guess she really wants to provide that awesome customer service, that or she wants a fat tip at the end. Either way, she was pretty attentive. 

It was a Sunday, so champagne was included. They went all out with the Wycliff Jean champagne....whewwww. Mix with the oj and you get the mimosa. Not bad, they even allowed us to keep the bottle to walk aimlessly throughout the casino and along the vegas strip.

For $30, I would probably invest a little more somewhere else next time. This was more of a cafeteria leftovers like food with mediocre quality instead of the higher more quality food that can be found elsewhere.

Normally, I wouldn't review a chain restaurant but the service warranted me to write a review.  This review is more for the service rather than their food.  OK, first thing first, when we got sat down, our server took our drink order. She got our drink and brought our complimentary bread and we placed our order.  It took 15 minutes to get our Blossomin' Onion.  As if that wasn't enough, it took another 20 for our main dishes to get to the table.  I guess the server saw us getting annoyed and gave us a weird excuse that their computer went down.  That is such a bunch of bull because the people that got seated AFTER us got their orders no problem.  I would rather her to have told the truth rather than making a BS excuse that didn't make any lick of sense.  So we got our food after over 30 minutes has passed and I do have to say, their food is prepared well and tasted good.  We ate our dishes with gusto.  When we finally got our check,after waiting for what seemed like forever after we finished our food (10 mins of waiting) and another 5 mins to get the change.  We spent more time waiting than eating.  Now I usually give at least 20% for gratuity, but for this instance, we gave about 12% so she would know the service was blah.  At that point, I was over the service.

"I must confess that I am not habitually inclined to compose reviews, however, in this instance, I felt compelled to share my experience. My initial excitement to sample the culinary offerings of this establishment was palpable, as it appeared to exude an ambiance that was both stylish and captivating. Despite being cognizant of the fact that the venue was still in its nascent stages and thus, may be encountering teething problems, I opted to afford it an opportunity to demonstrate its capabilities. My companion and I elected to partake in a nocturnal excursion to this location, in the hopes that our dining experience would transcend the mediocrity that had been described in certain reviews. Unfortunately, our expectations were not realized, as the fare provided was woefully lacking in flavor. The chips and salsa, while enjoyable, could not compensate for the dearth of zest in the primary dishes. Our server, however, exhibited commendable proficiency and displayed a laudable willingness to ensure our satisfaction by offering to remove one of the uninspiring entrees from our bill. While I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this restaurant for a satisfying repast, I may consider returning during happy hour, when the margaritas are purportedly discounted, in the hope that their consumption might enhance my tolerance for the underwhelming cuisine."

A decidedly unremarkable athletic pub. Advantages:  well-maintained, visually appealing (albeit somewhat antiseptic) ambiance; congenial, accommodating, and pulchritudinous personnel; expansive televisions and colossal projection screens, ensuring an optimal viewing experience from any seat. Drawbacks:  limited selection of artisanal draft beers; uninspired bill of fare with underseasoned comestibles (specifically, the Southwest Turkey sandwich lacked flavor, while the accompanying coleslaw was devoid of vitality); prolonged interval of ten minutes elapsed before receiving an initial beverage, even during a tranquil Sunday evening. Would confer supplementary celestial bodies for ameliorating any singular aspect, and two stars if all deficiencies were addressed.

"A further Asian-inspired food chain, you say? Oh my, do we genuinely require another eatery of this nature in Champaign? We already possess an abundance of Chinese and Korean restaurants in the campus area, which, might I add, are vastly superior to Flat Top in terms of quality and authenticity.  

Now, allow me to elaborate on the stir-fry concept that Flat Top has adopted. It is, in essence, a form of Mongolian BBQ, albeit with an extensive array of uncooked vegetables and ingredients for patrons to select from. One must admit that the sheer volume of options can be overwhelming, especially when considering the unusual sauces and food pairings available. My own combination, consisting of brown rice, clams, beef, vegetables, salmon, and roti prata, was merely passable, but I fear that without a well-developed sense of culinary compatibility, one's dining experience may prove disastrous.  

Flat Top's 'pick-your-own-ingredients' approach does possess a certain level of ingenuity, as it effectively transfers culpability onto the patron, should the food fail to meet expectations. However, it would be unfair to place blame solely on the customer, as the grill sensei also plays a significant role in determining the final product's quality. Overcooking by even a slight margin can render a dish unpalatable, irrespective of the excellence of the chosen components. My companion's moo shu, regrettably, suffered from inadequate wrapping, leading to certain rolls falling apart. Alas, such mishaps can significantly diminish one's enjoyment of the meal.  

While a single visit to Flat Top may satiate curiosity, repeated visits seem unnecessary. Only time will tell whether this establishment will mirror Bar Louie's fleeting popularity. A 'one-hit wonder,' if you will."

"While it would be inaccurate to describe the culinary offerings at this establishment as anything approaching exceptional, it is undeniable that certain aspects of the dining experience merit commendation. Specifically, the quality of the edibles, which, on a scale of one to ten, with five being the minimum acceptable threshold for gastronomical satisfaction and ten representing an unparalleled degree of epicurean delight, rates a respectable seven. However, it must be noted that the ambiance, while not unpleasant, falls short of truly captivating, garnering a mere six on the same scale. Furthermore, the value proposition, taking into account both the cost and the quantity of sustenance provided, earns a middling rating of eight. Notably, the service, characterized by an almost perplexing lack of attentiveness, leaves much to be desired, warranting a meager five on the aforementioned scale. Nonetheless, it is advisable to sample the creme puffs, which, despite their unremarkable provenance, prove to be a satisfying indulgence. Be that as it may, the experience is marred by an inexplicable tardiness in settling the bill, which, compounded by the sluggish pace of table turns during the luncheon hours, renders the overall experience somewhat less than optimal. In conclusion, while the novelty of the restaurant's conveyor belt system, reminiscent of those found in Japan, may hold some appeal for the uninitiated, it cannot compensate for the various deficiencies in the dining experience."

I utilized him, Paul, about 3 years ago for a termite problem.  I picked him based on Yelp reviews.  He did the treatment and then had to come back to retreat about 4 months after the original application.  I called him on the phone and he said he would come back but he was not going to make anything since it was under warranty.  When he came to the house again he made it very clear that this was costing him money because it was all under warranty.  I have never experienced having a business owner try to make me feel bad for asking them to honor their warranty, a warranty that I paid extra for.  I will never utilize his services again.

Shucks..a bit disappointed, last night I took family for the first time hoping to have the same experience as we did for about 10 times. The Clam Bake was the reason we always go on a Sat to have the $5 off, found that it wasn't anymore...crabs was an added option and you had to pay extra for it. It was still tasty but we should have gone to a buffet for the price we paid...It was still tasty though...Sadly..Shucks is now not on the top of my list..for value as the prices went up immensely...

The pizza is pretty good. Especially at 2am. But when it takes over an hour for delivery, no thank you. I shouldn't have to call 3 times to find out where my pizza is. Then when he finally showed up he asked for a tip. That's the best way to not get a tip.

I visited this establishment with my significant other last week for an evening meal, and I must say that my expectations were not entirely met. Despite the courteous and obliging demeanor of the waiting staff, the culinary offerings took an inordinate amount of time to arrive, and there were only a scant few other patrons present in the dining area. Upon the eventual arrival of our repast, my companion's poultry dish was unfortunately not adequately cooked. The waitress, however, demonstrated great proficiency in addressing the issue by promptly removing the item from our bill and ensuring that it was properly prepared before its return to our table. Although the flavor profile of the dish may have been somewhat lacking, we were, at that juncture, primarily concerned with the satisfaction of consuming palatable victuals. In light of this experience, I would not wholeheartedly endorse partaking in a dinner meal at this venue, but it may prove suitable for those seeking indulgent desserts.

I find it strange that people like this place. The food is not good at all. I adore anything chilli cheese..and all of their chilli cheese stuff is pretty gross. I can make better hot dogs at home. I only keep coming back for their ice cream and lemonade float. Yum. But I really dislike the food. I've tried everything on the menu and have to keep coming back here..my favorite food is the jalapeno poppers which are delicious. I just buy a bunch of those.

This pertains to an excursion that transpired approximately a month prior. During this visit, I consumed a burger and a couple of beverages classified as beer, while my spouse opted for a chicken flatbread accompanied by a pair of mixed drinks. Unfortunately, the fries provided were limp and overcooked, while the temperature of the burger served was tepid. My wife's culinary experience was satisfactory, albeit unremarkable. However, what truly distinguished this establishment was the utter absence of any semblance of urgency in the provision of service. I did not formally time the waitstaff, but various delays became apparent throughout the dining experience, including those encountered during seating, menu procurement, replenishment of beverages, food preparation, and ultimately, receipt of the bill. It became patently evident that avid players of slot machines and a select few regular clientele garnered a disproportionate amount of attention and expedited service from the staff, whereas all others were afforded a markedly inferior level of care. Consequentially, I felt compelled to dock Mr. John a star in light of the subpar nature of the service proffered. Given my proximity to the establishment, a plethora of superior, consistent alternatives exist within the local community, thereby rendering my inclination to return dubious at best.

This culinary establishment offers fare that is economically priced, ostensibly due to its perceived quality. The egg rolls possess an unmistakable texture reminiscent of flour, while the fried rice lacks both flavor and warmth. Although the vegetables in the vegetable lo mein exhibit a satisfying crunch and freshness, their taste is overpowered by an excessive amount of garlic, rendering them unpalatable. The eatery's location, situated on a rather unsavory thoroughfare, belies its interior, which boasts cleanliness and relative tranquility. Given the abundance of Chinese restaurants in Madison, it remains unclear why patrons would opt to dine at this particular venue.

"Although it fails to motivate me to elevate the star rating in my assessment, it is still worth mentioning that David, the General Manager of Rice and Company, reached out to convey his worry and remorse regarding the subpar service I encountered during my visit. Such attentive client care is what I would have appreciated while dining at the establishment. It remains to be seen whether a hypothetical 'trickle-down effect' or any analogous economic phenomenon will manifest itself, but I am skeptical about voluntarily participating in such an experiment on my next visit."

Obviously great selection of Rebel merchandise but outrageous prices. Seriously, the prices are almost twice what they should be. Why does the same hat cost $30 here, $20 at the ballgame, and $16 online from the manufacturer? But... If you want nice Rebelbilia, they've got stuff here that no one else carries. Bring a few quarters for parking.

"Initially, it became apparent that their apparel was organized according to hue, rather than being categorized by dimensions, which, although aesthetically pleasing to the proprietors of second-hand establishments, proved to be inconvenient for prospective patrons seeking attire in a specific size. Additionally, the cost of their merchandise was exorbitant, with many items that piqued my interest available for purchase at a marginally higher price if acquired brand new, thereby rendering the premium prices incongruous with the unkempt and unsanitary state of the store; consequently, we will not be revisiting this particular location."

If we could get my g-parents network switched over, I'd NEVER have them return to this St Lukes.  Quality of care seriously depends on who's on shift and what floor you're on.  Cath-Lab and ICU staff has always been fantastic, but staff on the 7th floor is a hit or a miss.  Likewise with staff in the ER. \n\nSeriously makes me wonder WHY some people get into the medical field, when they clearly are not cut out for working in that type of environment.

It started out really well. Was seated in less than 10 minutes and our server started out great, but it went downhill from there. \nThe food was great but they forgot our appetizer. Trying to find our server was impossible. Had to keep asking for refills n they forgot to bring out the dessert for my friends bday. When it came to paying the check....once again had to find the server. Keep in mind it wasn't that busy.  Got the busboy to finally take our check. Maybe ill just try another location.

Pizza was ok.. I ordered Vinnies, which is your choice of 5 toppings.  Italian sausage, black olives, onions, garlic and basil.  It wasn't bad - but it wasn't great either.  \n\nThe server was exceptionally friendly and helpful - but the service was the high point of the experience.

The food is good, but it is very annoying that they will deliver to my house some days and not other days..... Your delivery range is 3 miles and grub hub says I live 2.8 miles away, mapquest says 3.3.  Either way I think its close enough.  Don't be jerks and deliver me some damn Asian food when I want it, not just on days when you have nothing better to do.

My car became disabled in my garage.  Called this towing company on the recommendation from my car dealer.  1st call placed at 10:30am and was told it would be about 90 min.  12:30pm, still no tow.  I called back at this point and was told it would be 30 min and....she took my information again...what did she do lose it or maybe she forgot to order in the first place.  Ugh.  1:30pm (3 hrs. now)  I contemplated calling another company and then I though what if they both came together or the 1st one came for nothing.   So, I still waited (it's not like I'm going anywhere, right?) Finally 2:30pm they arrived.    4hrs people!!!   and not even a call from the office to say oh they're busy or running behind, nothing.  The guy was nice enough, but had a lot of difficulty jumping it to get it out of garage.  I stood and watch as he hooked up the chains and started to pull it onto truck, I'm thinking there must be something I have to sign, so I stepped in the driveway and away he pulls. No goodbye, no thank you, no I'm sorry it took so long.  \nI will never use them again.\nDoesn't anybody give good customer service anymore???????

Went here for lunch today. Ordered two burgers and a large cajun fry to share. We waited for about 15mins for our food. Normally we would not have minded but we were the ONLY people in the place. When we got our food our fries were not cajun so we brought them back to the counter. The gentleman at the counter, larger guy with glasses, asked us if we want them remade, we said yes. Then he said, \"Actually, here is some seasoning\" He gave us one container of cajun seasoning. We said we would prefer them remade, it tastes great fresh and with the seasoning. At that point, he was ignoring us so we just went back to our table and began eating. \n\nI'm not impressed with their lack of customer service. We ordered something, we should get it. I've had much better service at the location on Val Vista and Baseline at Dana Park. I would drive the extra miles to get great service and quality food.

"The establishment presented itself to be merely adequate, with pancakes that failed to impress. The taste was reminiscent of a pre-made mix, lacking the fluffiness and texture one would expect from a quality pancake dish. Furthermore, the addition of powdered sugar, which I personally find unappealing, only served to detract from the overall experience. The waiting period, both for seating and food delivery, proved to be within the realm of averageness, neither particularly lengthy nor expedient. Unfortunately, the orange juice served did not fare much better, possessing an unmistakable similarity to the economical brands commonly found on grocery store shelves. Despite my initial enthusiasm for supporting a non-chain restaurant, my encounter with the pancakes left me underwhelmed and skeptical about their ability to deliver a truly exceptional dining experience."

I would give STK in Vegas 5 stars but they have the worst customer service so 2stars for them. Blonde chick that checked our RSVP was a snob... Really bitch get a real job. Make sure to have the entire party present otherwise the last person to arrive won't be able to order her food and will just have to share with the others. The waiter rushed us and asked \"are you done now?\" Didn't ask if we wanted to take any food to go and just grabbed our plates while one of my friend was still eating. So we took our time to order and eat desserts and left 10% tip instead of 20% on 400$ tab. No need to be rude when you're making minimum wage, idc if you're busy, they shouldn't have booked 100 ppl in a 50ppl max capacity room. \n\nOther than the horrible customer service, food here is delicious!

Pathetic. $10 just to view Ferraris that are roped off?  They could have done this in a more friendly way, perhaps at least allowing some reasonable viewing from the outside and through the glass.  The Ferrari dealer here in AZ has about the same selection and you can get as close to you want and browse on Sundays when the salesmen are not there.  What a disappointment!
Turns out eating here, appropriately, is a crap game. Food always OK To good. Service, you need to bring your luck.

"Upon our second visit, we opted for a Greek Salad accompanied by Chicken Kabobs; regrettably, the diminutive proportions of the plate rendered it arduous to portion out the meager serving of iceberg lettuce, resulting in an unfortunate cascade of ingredients onto the table. Furthermore, the chicken was excessively sauce-laden, rendering it challenging to consume with any semblance of dignity. However, our previous experience with their gyro sandwich remained a pleasant memory, as it was prepared to perfection. Despite these shortcomings, the staff exuded warmth and kindness, fostering a welcoming ambiance."

We indulged in an impromptu visit to this establishment today, and our culinary excursion yielded a rather ambiguous outcome. While the tofu summer rolls demonstrated a certain degree of gastronomical prowess, their quality was somewhat diminished by a lack of exceptionalism. In contrast, the lemongrass soup exhibited a profound depth of flavor that was nothing short of remarkable. However, my pad see ew, despite its inherent merits, was regrettably compromised by an excessive saccharinity that bordered on the unpalatable. My spouse, whose gustatory preferences are notoriously discerning, experienced a series of unfortunate events that began with the Penang curry, which, much to his dismay, was prepared with coconut milk despite our server's assurance to the contrary. This unforeseen development precipitated a chain reaction of gastronomic disappointment, culminating in a Pad Thai dish that, while undoubtedly delectable, was marred by an overpowering sweetness and a formidable capsaicin kick. In conclusion, while Curry on Murray earns commendation for its ambiance and hospitality, the cuisine, unfortunately, falls short of true excellence.

"Individuals were expressing to us that they were experiencing such intense hilarity that it precipitated lacrimation. However, we did not encounter a considerable amount of mirth or sorrow. It remains uncertain whether this was due to our inability to establish a connection with the content or whether it was attributable to some other factor. Nonetheless, this program appears to be tailored towards an audience of individuals aged 45 and above."

We decided to check this place out after reading some of the reviews.  I guess I am disappointed because I had such high expectations.  This is just a regular coffee shop.  I was there with my husband and one of my twins.  I was going to order the breakfast burrito, but I wanted it with turkey sausage.  The girl at the counter told me they couldn't do it.  Ok, so I chose the Turkey sausage, egg and cheese on an English muffin.  I requested a scrambled egg for my little girl, again the girl at the counter told me they couldn't do that.  The eggs come pre-made in the shape of a patty, that sounded as appetizing as my sneakers after a 3 mile run.  I decided to cancel the food and pay for the coffee and bottled OJ I got for my baby.  Too bad, I am always looking for breakfast places.

Trying too hard to be upscale, with none of the effort you would expect to accompany such high prices and professional demeanor. I don't mind paying more for quality, but the only thing that was 5 star was the view and the price.

Seriously!!!  I would never ever pay $50.00 for a pedicure EVER.. Well again and I wouldn't have paid it this time NEITHER.  We asked for pricing, I stated what I wanted  and the only change i made from time of check in to done was that I now wanted french tips.  Had I wanted to spend this kind of money, i would have gone to TheBathHouse.\n\nthe other thing that puzzled me was \"why, were they mopping the floor at 9 am in the morning, when the salon JUST opened\"  Who really wants to be at a Salon when they are cleaning up yesterday mess.

Uhh... came here on a Thursday night and what an awkward Thursday night it was.

At least our group of about 9 guys all got in free, somehow? Promoter probably put us on guestlist but I don't really remember.

Let me say, this was my first night in Vegas EVER and first club in Vegas EVER, and it was a sad experience.

The club itself was just full of a "dead vibe" where you feel like nobody was excited to be out. The only area of the club that was open was the outdoor patio upstairs. So you would have to try and venture through the crowd of older people, composing of cougars and manthers to find some socialization. Only one bar open which was extremely overwhelmed as you can figure.... really disappointed and haven't returned since!

Service was good, but that is all I can probably say about this place, because the food wasn't.

I ordered the Tuscana Sausage Soup, the potatoes in it weren't cooked/boiled all the way, it was sort of too salty, but the sausage in there was pretty good.

Build your own Pasta seemed like a good choice besides Pizza, but I was wrong. I chose spaghetti, bologonese sauce (meat sauce), meatballs and mushrooms for my pasta. It came out to around $22 - 24 for the pasta and those two added ingredients. While the spaghetti and sauce tasted fine, it wasn't hot, it was semi warm, and everything else that came with it. The meat balls tasted like frozen meat balls from the market, it was also warm like the pasta.

All in all, I didn't like the pasta, maybe I will opt for a slice of pizza instead.

I did not like this place.  I was into the retro look and 'dive' appeal but it basically a dive without anything GOOD about it.  It isn't the cheapest place and the burgers were not that good at all.  Setup is awkward, hard to get inside for soda refills.  I think this place only survives due to tourists.  They don't know any better.  I would not go back.

What to say. Our waitress was so incredibly rude.  If my food wasn't good then I would give have given it one star. This was my first and last time going there. There is another bar/grill a few doors down that is so much better and less expensive. The only good thing about this place is that there are vegetarian items on the menu.

I wish that I could have got ahold of Sherry's Pampered Pets so that I could have made the reservation that I needed. But after 2 attempts at contacting them by phone and leaving them a voicemail that never got returned, I never even got as far as making the reservation. I waited 3-4 days for a return phone call, and then made reservations elsewhere. If I can't even get ahold of anyone or get a return phone call after leaving a voicemail, I am sure not leaving my dog with you.

"We opted for a single night's stay at this establishment, primarily motivated by financial considerations, but unfortunately, our expectations were not met. Despite its visually appealing exterior, the hotel's interior appeared outdated, and the service we received was subpar. Specifically, we requested a 'non-smoking' room, but upon arrival, the room was permeated with a strong odor of smoke and tobacco. Following our complaint, we were instructed to proceed to the'manager's desk' to obtain a new room assignment, but our attempts to secure assistance were met with indifference and disinterest by multiple staff members. Eventually, we managed to engage with a representative who directed us to the farthest end of the desk, where we waited for approximately 10 minutes before being attended to. Unfortunately, the staff member who eventually assisted us seemed annoyed and informed us that we needed to wait further. After another 10-minute delay, a different employee arrived and instructed us to relocate to the opposite side of the extensive front desk, which proved challenging given the size of our luggage. Our overall experience was marred by poor customer service, and while we might consider returning if absolutely necessary, we would generally avoid this hotel due to the unpleasant encounter."

"Due to the dearth of adequate Chinese cuisine in my immediate vicinity, I opted to venture slightly further afield to sample the culinary offerings of Chopstix, based on the acclaim bestowed upon it by patrons. Unfortunately, the establishment's card reader was non-functional, prompting the staff member attending to me to request that I procure cash to facilitate the transaction. In light of this, I undertook a brief excursion to the nearest automated teller machine located within Smiths, incurring an additional fee of three dollars due to the fact that it was not affiliated with my financial institution. Upon my return, I found the premises devoid of any other patrons, with the same staff member who had initially attended to me now engaged in a personal telephone conversation on his mobile device, utterly disregarding my presence. I persisted in waiting for several minutes, during which time another employee was occupied at the counter, similarly neglecting to acknowledge me. Eventually, he glance up and enquired if he could provide assistance, to which I replied that I wished to settle the payment for my meal. At this point, the previously engaged staff member finally terminated his phone call and accepted my payment, without offering any expression of regret, discount, or token of appreciation for my trouble. The culinary items I selected, specifically wor wonton soup, house fried rice, and orange chicken, were satisfactory, but the experience was significantly marred by the unacceptable level of service, rendering future visits unlikely."

No. With all of your other options in Vegas for buffets (Wicked Spoon, Bacchanal), this just doesn't cut it. Food was dry, sitting out too long, and the cheaper price attracts a ...cheaper crowd...if you know what I mean. You're in Vegas, spring for the good buffet!

The service was adequate, and menu choices were a little more than a little overpriced. I ordered the street style pork sandwich, the pork was pretty much the equivalent of a blue rare. The sandwich was the size of a small biscuit, and depressingly unfilling. Before this, i had ordered a pork taco with green salsa (forgot name, sorry, this review is written in retrospect), and the pork was well cooked, except that the taco was soggy as a result of the pork grease. My friend had dim sum, so size wasn't much of a problem for her, she did say though, the dim sum had an off-putting oder, but tasted fine. Overall, the place was sub-par and I wouldn't go here again. Another note: The drinks offered there are served in bottles, which means no free refills. Just know that these bottles are the size of a soda can, and depending on what you order, you may or may not be getting less than your money's worth(or even less still), as some of the bottles are smaller than others. Wouldn't recommend this place to anyone, overpriced and the food is repulsive.

"We have had the pleasure of partaking in culinary indulgences at this esteemed establishment on our maiden visit, and we must say that the hospitality accorded to us by our server was truly commendable. The ambiance of the venue is undeniably captivating, boasting an unparalleled vantage point that offers an unobstructed view of the surrounding environs. However, we were somewhat dismayed by the gastronomical offerings, specifically the pizza, which unfortunately failed to meet our expectations. The flavor profile was rather uninspired, bearing a striking resemblance to a frozen pizza that one could conveniently prepare in the comfort of their own domicile. The sauce lacked the depth and richness that one would anticipate from a dish of this nature, while the crust was disappointingly thin and lacking in texture. It is our sincere belief that given the prime location and fierce competition in the vicinity, the pizza served here should be of a significantly higher quality."

The staff was really unimpressive.  The food, okay.  Overpriced for what you get.  They are really trying to run an upscale restaurant but they have a  long way to go to achieve this.  Wine list is very limited, the food portions are tiny and the staff is a tad bit stuffy.  You can find far better in Charlotte than what they offer here.

I've been wanting to try this place for a while. Now that have, I'm good. 

It's the kind of place you go to after a night of partying when your standards aren't so high. It wasn't all THAT bad, but not great  either.  

I judge Latin-style restaurants on their chips and salsa. If it's not good, I know what to expect from their kitchen. With that said..
the chips were greasy and salsa tasted like Pace picante. 

I had the two taco plate of grilled chicken and steak tacos with re-fried beans and rice. The grilled steak taco had good flavor, but the chicken was VERY dry. I added lime and salsa to try and moisten it up. All and all...it was decent, but not any better quality than a late night taco place. 

Service was ok.

We stayed here last year during a family road trip, and we enjoyed the stay.  The room and bathroom were clean.  It was right near Interstate 77, very convenient.  Very close to a great mall as well.

This time around and only a year later, our room was not all together clean.  The bathroom had hair on the floor, the AC was very loud which kept us up.  

The staff in both cases were friendly.  But we may go elsewhere in the future.

"Underwhelming culinary experience with too much repetition."

The text is: "Cool restaurant great neighborhood concept but the food is so bland. Store bought chips for the dips. Kids Mac and cheese is gritty and flavorless. Chicken in salad is overcooked and not seasoned. Heaping pile of raw arugula on my pizza. Salt is a great resource. Thanks but no thanks, not again."

The modified text is:

"Amidst an ambiance of trendy sophistication, the gastronomic offerings of this establishment fail to deliver a palatable experience, marred by an uninspired selection of flavors and questionable preparation methods. The utilization of store-bought chips as a complement to dips raises questions about the quality of ingredients used in the kitchen. Moreover, the kids' macaroni and cheese dish disappoints with its lackluster taste and unpleasant texture, while the chicken in the salad suffers from overcooking and an absence of discernible seasoning. Topping it all off, a generous portion of raw arugula threatens to overwhelm the senses, rendering the pizza unbalanced and inharmonious. Notwithstanding the value of salt as a culinary staple, the overall impression of this dining excursion sadly falls short of expectations, making future visits unlikely."

The food is still great and terrific value for $4, but unfortunately the `douche factor` has gone up to 11! I should have known better when I heard some fat suit walk out with three others and say `4 people for under $30, what a deal!` I was like, oh no, they`ve invaded it. I got there at around 1:20pm after the Friday lunch rush and usually it`s some students or a couple having a late lunch, now it`s full of soccer moms and cheap douchebag suits who found out about it on FB or Yelp, please stop these greedy people from making long line ups impossible to eat good food!!!

No Reservations available after 5 o'clock which totally sucks. They have no phone charger station which sucks. The waitress was phenomenal and extraordinary. But had to deal with a new bartender tonight who took forever to make dreams because he was new. Outside of the waitress I will not be back here again after 5 p.m.

"For a pizza venue boasting a plant-based culinary selection, it was nothing short of perplexing to discover that post 10:30 pm, not a single vegan pizza remained available. It appeared that every other pizza variety was being offered, yet the absence of a vegan-style pizza was glaringly conspicuous. As a patron who has previously enjoyed their fare, I felt utterly disillusioned by this oversight. It would be reasonable to assume that a vegan pizza option would be readily accessible, particularly during peak hours, in order to cater to the diverse dietary preferences of their clientele. Moreover, the lack of any accommodation or offer to create a vegan pizza was, in my opinion, subpar customer service. My sentiments were akin to disappointment and frustration.":

The only reason I will go back is if a band comes to town that I cannot miss.

I'll start with the good.  Security is so friendly.  My friend proposed to his girlfriend and they were so helpful into making it happen.  If they kick you out, you deserve it!!

Parking sucks.  It costs money to park and they don't have many spaces.  You have to get early to park and it's really the only good parking around the venue.

Sound is meh.  I've heard better, not often do I hear worse.

DRINKS ARE A RIP OFF!!!!  Either don't drink, come there drunk or sneak booze in (I don't support sneaking it in.  They do pat you down as you enter)

So what we have here is a rip off establishment that is one of the only places in town to see national touring acts.  Fuck it.

"My culinary predilection gravitates towards the notion of relishing in savory, wholesome gastronomy. Following four consecutive excursions to this establishment, my expectations have been utterly disillusioned, as the eatery has persistently failed to deliver a reliable dining experience. During my maiden visit, the fare was palatable, yet the hospitality was regrettably subpar. On my second foray, I opted for their signature flatbread, only to discover that it was conspicuously absent from the menu. Perplexed, I settled for a barbecue beef sandwich, which, to my surprise, was quite delectable. Alas, the accompanying sweet potato fries were unfortunate casualties of an egregious culinary misstep, having been charred to an unsightly, inedible state. This blatant display of gastronomical negligence only served to deepen my skepticism. My third visit proved equally underwhelming, with the kitchen seemingly struggling to maintain even a semblance of consistency. Succumbing to curiosity, I decided to sample their morning fare on my fourth visit. An hour beyond the appointed opening time, I found myself standing in a vacant dining area, with nary a soul in sight, nor any discernible indication of a breakfast menu. After a full four minutes of being ignored by the indifferent staff, a solitary employee finally acknowledged my presence with a tardy greeting. It is with profound disappointment that I must conclude that this establishment has failed to meet my expectations and, accordingly, cannot be recommended."

I have been to this location many times, and let me say that Einstein's is vastly superior as far as bagels are concerned. That stated, Bruegger's does serve good softwiches...however, I could get better bread and bagels elsewhere.

There ought to be a law prohibiting Greek restaurants from going corporate.  I expect my Greek restaurants to be family owned and run by ugly, hairy, overweight Greeks (this includes the men and the women).  In fact, the uglier the better, as I suspect there is an inverse relationship between the quality of Greek food and \"looks\" of the restauranteur.  Wasn't there a movie about fat Greeks who owned a diner.... wait... I need to grab some Windex I'm getting a pimple.\n\nAnyway, Daphne's proves my point.  I was in the mood for meat, bread and french fries and Daphne's was nearby.  I would call my gyro a \"styro-gyro\".  The meat was cold and tasteless and had been carved hours earlier.  The pita bread reminded me of an old sun rotted Frisbee that sat on the side of the house all summer.  It crumbled into pieces.  The french fries were hot, but I could taste the frozen bag they came in.  The only high point is that they offer this really tasty diet Soba grapefruit flavored drink at their soda fountain.  That was one tasty diet drink.  Oopah!

Oh dear. Drinks decent but service awful.

Tried to book a table 5 days in advance. Tried 3 times and no one would pick up the phone and gave up as the Germany vs Brazil Blitzkreig was starting.

Called back two days later - after an extended discussion about seating arrangements (size of group & suitable tables) then high table by window was confirmed.

Arrived at designated time, table given to someone else and they didn't know about the booking. Just as well a couple of the gang didn't make it as they'd given away our big table which was made such a big deal of when I tried to book. Saw 4 walk-in's arrive after us and get served before us. No acknowledgement when I arrived. Took 40 mins to get the drinks - cocktails (nearly 25 mins after arriving before the order taken and got some water as knew cocktails might be a bit slow). Then 10 mins after that to get snacks that we had to ask again for. 

The guy that ended up serving us was really nice but he only arrived 25mins in as he was a bit more aware than the girl serving when we arrived.

So Juniper, nah. Had I not been using a voucher, I'd have walked. And the voucher was a 2nd chance after friend's horror stories of bad service...

The place is hit or miss depending on which bartender you get.  They have some really good ones, but they also have at least 1 really bad one.  I won't name names but I wouldn't recommend the place on certain nights of the week.

2/5 for great people working there, and the friendly vibe you get just walking in the door. BAM, smells like a pickling factory but do not fear, the bar area looks fun. Our experience was bad however-- the noodles in our ramen were cooked Al Dente, and you know what that means once an amalgam of them begins to expand in your stomach. They definitely weren't cooked all the way, so thus, I felt like I was going to LITERALLY lose my food after I finished a relatively small bowl. Yeah, I'm a small person, but you know, I can still eat! I just felt so sick afterwards.

The spinach- strange & refreshing.
The carrots- lovely.
The pork- cold, but good.
The nori- you know, your standard nori.
The broth- yeah, a little salty, but good. We tried the Pai Ton, the tonkotsu broth without the Pork ordeal.


But the noodles! They made me so sick, and I really want to love this place because their ramen is so diverse. After the meal, one of the friendly staff members made us some little non-alcoholic shots, so like I said-- SUPER NICE people! I just can't handle their style of food, it doesn't agree with me at all. If you're sensitive like me, try Cherry Blossom Noodle Cafe-- they'll be a more classic and authentic option for you. 
Cheers!

Initial impression when arriving set my standards high as well as the hype over this place. I love the decor and feel of the place itself, but the pizza was over-priced for thin and hard to eat cause the toppings just slid off. Also ordered the cheesy bread which i'd honestly prefer Little Caesar's over here. \nThe waitress was nice but disappeared for loooong periods of time. \nI'd be willing to try again but try something other than Piza cause the Calzone looked good.

"While our culinary excursion garnered a mere four stars, primarily due to the unbalanced composition of our dishes, specifically the excessive cheesiness of the chili and the overwhelming oiliness of the beef stroganoff, which respectively hindered the palatability of both dishes, we must commend the prompt and attentive service proffered by the wait staff, particularly during a peak period on a Thursday evening. Notwithstanding the aforementioned drawbacks, we may consider revisiting the establishment to sample their burger offerings."

After a friend raving about this place for 6 months I had to go.  I'd say my turkey sanwich was pretty average.\nI'd never go again simply for the fact they don't have Sweetener for their unsweetened iced tea.  Boo.

I use to enjoy this place. But, I just had a bad experience for lunch. I even heard my server talking to his colleagues about how bad the tip was from the previous table. Also, they were out of the first two beverages that I asked for.  Will not be going back anytime soon.

Went for my Bday and the service was excellent but the food is another story. The food is not worth what u pay. Bill came out to $250 for two. Had a ribeye, pork, bone marrow, and two glasses of wine. Save your money. Go to Bobby Flays for a better steak and price.

"Airport ambiance permeated by licentiousness; alcoholic beverages, gambling, and unquestionably, strip clubs will succeed. Numerous culinary options abound, perpetually spotless, and effortless navigation prevails. Consequently, five stars would be awarded --- were it not for the interminable queue for taxis. This phenomenon is utterly objectionable and raises astonishment at the lack of efficient methods implemented by gaming establishments to expedite the process, thereby facilitating prompt entry into their revenue-generating premises. The taxi line must undergo enhancement!"

Two stars is about dead on. We were first at a motel 6 and this was definitely an upgrade, but only by one star. The bathroom was the worst part. If Windemere would only do a deep cleaning of their bathrooms once in a while, I could see a full additional star. Other than that, the rooms were pretty big, it was nice to have a balcony, and the pool and hot tub was nice, but would have been a lot better if someone grabbed a net and scooped out the branches and leaves now and then.  \n\nThe service people were friendly and helpful and the breakfast was fine. Just clean this place a little Windemere and you're almost there.

We eat at this deli many years ago inside the Mirage Hotel and remember it was really good. With our recent visit I was so disappointed. The server lady had no idea what the soup of the day was. She was kind of nutty in her response and made us feel like she was in a hurry. Much to my disappointment the food was horrible- we sent it back because it was cold. I also found the prices to be out of line with the lack of quality. With so many options in Las Vegas, I would not plan on returning to this place. They nickle and dime you.

They have great food if you can get service.   Last time I went wewaited 30 min and didn't have any service at all so we left and done 20 min to another restaurant. We just phone order wings and pick them up now

Maybe because I'm use to NY Steakhouses but I was disappointed. 
I was with a party of 10 for lunch. Lunch menu was great however my steak was over cooked. 

Where's the porterhouse steaks???

Wine was good but little expensive, even for Vegas.

"Ew, indeed! My gastronomical sensibilities are hardly so refined as to be unimpressed by the uninspired culinary offerings presented at this establishment. However, I must confess that the flavorless canned mushrooms and frozen spinach incorporated into my omelet lacked even the most basic semblance of seasoning, resulting in an unappetizing, amorphous mass deposited haphazardly upon my plate. Furthermore, the interminable delay between placing our order and its eventual arrival only served to exacerbate my already waning enthusiasm for the dining experience. Hash browns notwithstanding, I remain perplexed by the ostensibly high acclaim lavished upon this eatery."

All it takes is bad attitude and the unwillingness to be flexible for your customers to turn a good experience into a bad one very, very quickly.  Unfortunately, this happened at 360 Physical Therapy, who I was ready to write a pretty stellar review for, based on PT service alone.  I liked my therapist on the whole, and I've felt like I was taken decent care of. 

However, the practice has a rather draconian appointment-cancellation fee. It doesn't seem to matter that I have paid them countless $35.00 co-pays (ludicrous and laughable, I know... but that's between me and my wicked insurance provider) and that I call them if I I'm so much as stuck at a traffic light and will be five minutes late... we are battling to the death over an alleged no-show appointment that I swear upwards and down I rescheduled prior to not attending.  The billing manager will not let it go, and insists that I must pay this fee, no matter how many conversations we have about it.

The point here is, folks: isn't it worth it to keep your customers happy? I know I didn't miss this appointment... but even if I did, I had countless sessions at this facility. I was always on time, and I always paid at the time of service. I was a "Good Customer." And I would be going back, and recommending my friends, if it wasn't for the fact that they are unwilling to let something so small go.  Unfortunate, I think.

The entire property is run down, kinda creepy and pretty yucky.  I had rented some inline skates thad had moldy inserts.  I think they may be the only roller rink in Madison so you don't have too  many options.\n\nObviously this place is popular with kids and they don't seem to notice all the blight so we would just grin and bear it.

Recently visited Frank and Lupes. Food was very good but service was slow. In fact, we had to go to the bar to order drinks because our waiter wasn't coming over to our table.  At the end of dinner, my dinner partner left the table to use the restroom, and our waiter came over and asked me if I was waiting to be seated......this after he had been already waiting on me for an hour and a half.

En pensant \u00e0 ce que je voulais dire \u00e0 propos du March\u00e9 Bonsecours, je me disais un peu la m\u00eame chose que Virginie. C'est un tr\u00e8s bel \u00e9difice et de l'ext\u00e9rieur, il est assez impressionnant. Par contre, pour moi c'est l\u00e0 que \u00e7a s'arr\u00eate. \u00c0 chaque fois que j'y rentre, je trouve que \u00e7a deviens un centre d'achat trop chi-chi qui est fait pour les touristes riches seulement. On dit y exposer des oeuvres d'artistes qu\u00e9b\u00e9cois et montr\u00e9alais, mais on dirait que toutes les choses se ressemblent et sont beaucoup plus dispendieuses qu'ailleurs. Allez-y si vous \u00eates en visite juste pour le voir, mais ne vous attendez pas \u00e0 \u00eatre impressionn\u00e9 \u00e0 part pour l'architecture du b\u00e2timent.

I have been here twice and had 2 different experiences. The first time we liked what the menu looked like so we had lunch here.  Food was good, standard bar food so nothing overly special but good. Service was decent, it was not busy so we were checked on regularly.  We found out they have the UFC fights so we wanted to go here to watch them. Fight night; we show up and it is $10 per person! What!?! Every other place in EV only charges $5/pp. We were already there and they were just about to start so we stayed. Next our waitress informs us that she needs a credit card or id as a security for the table. What?!? We are a 40 something couple, you think we are going to dine-and-dash...really. After a bit of discussion, I reluctantly give up my card. Then the fights start but because it is March Madness, not all the TV's are turned to the fight as they said they would be. So I have to crank my neck in order to watch them, even after the game ended they still did not turn the tv's. \nThe food again was ok and service was good so we will go back for food but not to watch a fight, I will stick with Old Chicago or Tilted Kilt for my UFC viewing.

The burritos are good enough when you're craving breakfast and can't get away from work. I use them about once every couple of weeks. The service our horrible. Almost every time I call I get put on hold only to never get answered. I call back and finally get my order in. If there was another place that delivered I would go there.

This is a pretty crappy and old hotel. The room was dusty and had several missing items such as cups and laundry bags.  The bed sheet was dirty and had a huge bloodstain right in the middle of the bed. I had to ask housekeeping to come and replace the bed sheets.

Limited beer actually available on tap. Hell, I could slap a sticker on a tap and call it whatever I wanted to, doesn't make it true. Even if they did have all of the beer they claimed, it's still not enough to call it a \"world\" of beer. Seriously limited in supply and variety. Our group headed up the street to another establishment after only one round and found better selections.
Super slow service compared to other EBs. IlI go to the one on Sahara even though its 10 minutes out of the way next time.
Lunch special only  till 4 pm . $7.99. Okay food nothing special that would make me want to come back. Service was just OK. Overall, I have had way better thai food else where .

Went there for lunch today. This is my second time visiting and the second time my order was messed up. I had ordered a chicken ceaser salad burrito. It was my mistake I guess, from what I remember a ceaser salad doesn't have tomatoes in it. Well it does here. I don't like tomatoes. Love ketchup but not regular tomatoes soggin up my meal. I had them make another burrito. The menu clearly states what's in a ceaser salad, and tomato is not one of the ingredients. The replacement burrito tastes slightly better than the first but not by much. Maybe they had a surplus of tomatoes and were trying to get rid of em I don't know. Should've went to Costa Vida but as we all know they are almost always crowded. Ugh F me and my burrito cravings.

"My daughter and I embarked upon an excursion specifically dedicated to acquiring these bagels while they were still fresh from the oven in the morning, and I must say that my expectations were not entirely fulfilled. In fact, I would venture to assert that my predilection for New York-style bagels (a preference that has motivated me to undertake similar pilgrimages in the past) was not entirely satiated by the offerings of Montreal's bagel purveyors. While I acknowledge that there exists a certain je ne sais quoi associated with the city's unique bagel variant, characterized by its thinness and subtle sweetness, it does not necessarily conform to my individualized culinary inclinations. Moreover, it was rather disconcerting to discover that a few of the dozen bagels purchased during our excursion exhibited telltale signs of staleness and were only suitable for consumption after a period of maturation. Amongst the assortment we sampled, the sesame variety was perhaps the most satisfactory, but it was not enough to persuade us to abandon our allegiance to the superior quality and authenticity of New York-style bagels. It is my conviction that many Americans who have had the privilege of indulging in premium bagels within the confines of New York City would concur with my assessment. Incidentally, I am of the opinion that several establishments in Boston offer comparable or even superior alternatives. Suffice it to say that Montreal's gastronomic landscape boasts an array of exceptional French cuisine, which, in my estimation, renders it unnecessary for the city to attempt to rival New York's preeminence in the realm of Jewish delicacies. (It is worth mentioning that Schwartz's, a local eatery, is, in my opinion, vastly overrated.)"

I have never been a fan of Olive Garden, but a brand new and shiny one opened up on the west side by home. My husband and I thought OK, we will try it again after years. DUH, dumb decision!! Was a total disappointment. Why do we do that to ourselves? You do not like somethings for some reasons! Sticking with gut feel next time. 

Got the fried mussel de napoli, that was ok. The usual mussel cooked and bathe in garlic butter sauce. I ordered the chicken alfredo pizza. OMG, it was so salty! I could barely eat it. Dipping it into the chicken & gnocchi soup to wash off the salt. I should have returned the food, but I have worked in the restaurant business through high school and college, I know what happens to returns! No thanks... My husband's spaghetti with meat sauce was kind of bland. We did not taste the herbs and spices in the sauce. 

Actually, the food only deserves a 1 star but the service was outstanding from a young lady, so I am forced to gave 2 stars.

"Culinary excellence, ambiance befitting a gourmet establishment, yet a conspicuous dearth of hospitable demeanor amongst the point-of-sale attendants, their facial expressions betraying an absence of joy or contentment in their work, instead manifesting a pervasive lack of enthusiasm bordering on disaffection."

The Stone Crab and Joe's is fantastic if you catch it on the right day.  Sunday afternoon I sat at the bar and enjoyed great service and a terrific meal.  That 1st visit was a recon mission for a future date with the wife.  My honey & I went on a Thursday night.  The crab was horribly spoiled, the texture was odd and it tasted like ammonia.  The waiter was a clod hopping oaf.  I should have flipped my plate on the floor, spit in the face of the idiot and walked out without paying!  Caesars can be like this, hit-or-miss... Caveat emptor!

I got myt first pair of orthotics with this place back in 2001. Back then, I felt like a valued client, and they almost had me believe that they were foot specialists or podiatrists. I paid a little over $100 for two pairs.
However, I visited the same location yesterday and explained that I could not find my inserts so I bought the shoes instead paying $600 for what I had purchased once a long time ago. Yet the shoes were still $130.00. I specifically asked for slip-resistant shoes and felt like being at a roller rink passing through the kitchen. 
I returned this morning, and the male attendant with a feux hawk decided to quote manufacturer's words to me when I tried to return the shoes, or exchange them within 2 sentences of our conversation.
So if it wasn't for their overpriced and prescribed inserts not from someone who has a degree in sports medicine, it would be for the careless treatment I received that I am submitting a low but generous score to the only surviving location in Clark County.
I should add that female that I initially bought products from yesterday, was polite but said that their products would last 5 to 8 months at best, which is piss poor for $130.00.

This Starbucks is owned by Treasure Island and not corporate-owned, so they do not have perks like receiving stars or free modifiers using the Starbucks card. They can take your card number off the mobile phone app though. I only went here every morning because of its convenience. It was real Starbucks (not just proudly brewing).\n\nI found the employees here friendly enough, but nothing more than absolutely necessary. There are no tables and chairs, so don't plan on sticking around. Get your coffee and move on. It's now the only Starbucks ON the street in this area of the strip. Just don't think you're going to have a religious experience with your morning cuppa joe.

We were utterly famished, thus, we opted to peruse the offerings of this establishment, misguided by our palates' cravings, we regrettably partook in an unremarkable dining experience, marred by an absence of delectable libations and an underwhelming menu, devoid of any culinary masterpieces worthy of a second glance, rendering the atmosphere rather uninviting, further exacerbated by the dearth of melodic accompaniment on the day of our visit.
How do you get iced coffee wrong? I asked to have to coffee sweetened , and now I taste rock sugar that's not melted in my coffee! :( what a disappointment .

Kind of a cool atmosphere, good for drinking. Mediocre and slightly overpriced meals for what you get. Irish Pasty was mainly potatoes, some cabbage, little bit of cheese and small amount of corned beef (Cornish Pasty at Guad/Dobson is much better). Every other item was traditional, strip mall bar food. \nI could have been in any other bar and gotten the same experience. \nBasically good for booze, but not much else.

"Upon entering the establishment, we were immediately struck by the subtle yet sophisticated ambiance created by the strategic deployment of subdued lighting, which effectively conveyed an air of refined elegance without overwhelming the senses. Our culinary excursion began with a diverse array of warm bread options, including an Asiago roll, walnut and cranberry bread, and a French roll, all of which were presented in a wicker basket, further enhancing the rustic charm of the dining experience. Our main courses consisted of two broiled walleyed pike fillets, which, unfortunately, suffered from a slight degree of desiccation, but were nevertheless savored with relish. In addition, we shared a baked potato that, while well-intentioned, was regrettably overcooked, and a side of creamed corn that, much to our delight, proved to be the unmitigated highlight of the meal, its rich, velvety texture and delicate flavor profile eliciting effusive praise from both parties. However, our enthusiasm was somewhat tempered by the less-than-satisfactory crÃ¨me brÃ»lÃ©e, which, unfortunately, did not live up to our expectations, ranking among the most disappointing specimens we have had the misfortune of encountering. Fast forwarding to the present, precisely two decades after our last foray into the erstwhile Roberta's, we must confess that our return visit has been long overdue, as the passage of time seems to have wrought a profound transformation, elevating the restaurant to a new level of excellence. Although the ambiance may lack a certain je ne sais quoi, the friendly demeanor of the staff and reasonable prices more than compensate for any perceived deficiencies. Ms. Westie's 8-ounce filet, cooked to a perfect medium rare, as per her request, proved to be a veritable delight, its tenderness and flavor rivaling those of the finest prime cuts. Similarly, my Chilean sea bass, with its delectable crusty exterior and moist interior, paired beautifully with a trio of garlic mashed potatoes, a diminutive fennel salad, and sautÃ©ed spinach, thereby rounding out a memorable dining experience."

"Although my expectations were elevated due to the exceptional quality of the toppings, I felt compelled to provide a more favorable evaluation, as the service was prompt and friendly, the ambiance was charming, and the variety of beer and wine flights was impressive. However, upon sampling the pizza, I was disappointed to discover that the dough lacked the crispness and texture that I have come to associate with artisanal wood-fired pizzas. Don't get me wrong, the toppings were undoubtedly delicious, but the dough itself was somewhat unremarkable, leaving me with a lingering sense of disappointment. As someone who has been diligently seeking out a pizza establishment that serves an egg pizza capable of transporting me back to the memorable pizzerias of Italy, I must admit that this particular eatery fell short of my lofty standards. Notwithstanding, I must commend the proprietors for their laudable efforts in creating a welcoming atmosphere and offering an assortment of delectable toppings, and I sincerely hope that they will continue to refine their craft, particularly with regard to the dough, in order to create a truly exceptional pizza experience for their patrons."

"We had the privilege of experiencing a personalized event at this esteemed venue, which offered an ambiance that was nothing short of breathtaking, thanks in large part to the meticulous attention to detail displayed by the staff, who demonstrated an unwavering commitment to ensuring that our stay was nothing short of exceptional. However, it is worth noting that the culinary options available were somewhat limited for those who adhere to a plant-based dietary lifestyle, and despite our efforts to communicate our specific requirements, the kitchen staff did not exhibit a marked willingness to adapt their offerings to meet our needs, even when presented with the necessary ingredients to create a truly delectable salad."

We were tired from doing tourist crap all day and came back to our cheapie hotel, the LVH, to cool the heels. By dinner time we were too tired to go anywhere else so gave this place a shot. Unlike others, we were actually greeted immediately and seated. From there on, please trust the other reviews and go elsewhere. At 6 on a Sunday nite the place was a ghost town with only 2 other tables seated and Motley Crue music videos blaring. I get the Vince Neil connection but this was over-the-top annoying. Our server was good, very attentive, which frankly we expected with the lack of other customers. Food was very blah. As others noted, chips and salsa were right out of the grocery store, fish tacos were fried/microwaved, and beef \"machaca\" tacos were just cold mushed meat. Ugh. We were tired, it was food and no one got sick so I guess it ended OK. Overall, stay away from this restaurant and more to the point, the LVH in general. New ownership is destroying the place, literally and figuratively.

I've ate at honey bears a couple times because I really like BBQ but this place just doesn't do it for me. The sauce is very different because its more like a broth than a sauce. The sauce or broth doesn't have too much flavor.

Each time I've enjoyed the flavor of the meat (Pork and Chicken) but the sauce and the sides just kill it for me. The Potato salad is very bland without much flavor.

Overall the meat is very good and would be the only thing that I would order. There are many other great BBQ restaurants in Phoenix that top Honey Bears.

"Scottsdale benchmarks? Opt for alternative accommodations and indulge in wagering activities at this establishment, provided you relish the prospect of a middling aquatic facility and unremarkable culinary options, save for the notable exception of Orange Sky, which serves as a veritable oasis amidst an otherwise underwhelming dining experience, reminiscent of the raucous revelry and questionable decorum commonly associated with carnival cruises, replete with inebriated patrons sporting conspicuous tattoos and fashionably attired young women clad in stiletto heels; in essence, consider conserving your financial resources and opting for alternative lodgings, as the ambiance and amenities offered by this venue may not align with your expectations or warrant the expenditure."

I was brimming with anticipation upon beholding the 'Coming Soon' placard prior to their inauguration, and I eagerly looked forward to partaking in a culinary experience at this establishment. Alas, my expectations were not met, as I found the fare to be merely passable and my encounters to be lacking in satisfaction. Not only did they have exorbitant prices, but they also displayed parsimony in their offerings. I vehemently detest eateries that proffer extravagant charges while providing scant provisions. On both occasions that I visited, I opted for the half portion of 'Pollo a la Brasa'; however, during my second visit, I was dismayed to discover that they did not serve fries alongside my meal. Moreover, I was misinformed that they had ceased to include fries with the dish, which constitutes both false advertising and a manifestation of their stinginess. How trifling are potatoes in cost, one might ask? 
  It is not worthwhile to order the yuca fries, as the measly serving consists of a paltry five fries for a price of six dollars. If you are willing to spend more than a dollar per two-inch fried potato, then by all means, indulge in it. The server who attended to me displayed impatience and gave me peculiar glances whenever I attempted to capture her attention. When I requested sauce for the poultry (which should have been included), she gazed at me with an expression that conveyed utter incredulity. Were it not for my colleague's generosity in treating me, I would have ensured that the server received a minimal gratuity. 
  Due to my unfavorable experiences, I do not plan on returning to support a business that operates in such a manner.

"It is a rather anomalous occurrence that this particular establishment, which prides itself on offering an extensive array of delectable libations during its 'happy hour' interval, did not feature any specialized beverage promotions pertaining to beer, a staple beverage often associated with such merrymaking. My personal experience has led me to visit numerous Maggiano's locations, totaling five in number, and it is my impression that there has been a gradual decline in the quality of their culinary offerings. Despite this, my affinity for Italian cuisine remains unwavering, prompting me to continue granting them opportunities to redeem themselves. Ultimately, I find myself increasingly inclined to prepare my own fresh pasta, accompanied by a well-chosen bottle of wine and some crusty ciabatta bread, thereby ensuring a satisfying dining experience within the comfort of my own domicile."

"I had the pleasure of visiting this establishment for the first time on a sunny Sunday afternoon, specifically August 17th, at approximately 3 p.m., with the intention of placing a to-go order. Upon entering, I was greeted by a friendly gal who enthusiastically informed me that the salads were of considerable size, and inquired about my preference for mixed greens. However, upon receiving my order, I was disappointed to discover that the salad was not nearly as substantial as advertised, and to my surprise, did not include the promised mixed greens as explicitly stated on the menu. It is worth noting that a comparable salad bar option, available for a lower price point, would have provided a more generous portion. Furthermore, when inquiring about the availability of dressing with my salad, I was met with a response that implied I had neglected to specify my desired dressing choice, despite the fact that I had not been given the opportunity to do so. Not only was I denied complimentary ice cream during my wait, but I also observed another patron being offered this courtesy. In light of these circumstances, I elected to procure crackers from the salad bar on my way out, which, regrettably, were not included in my original order. Despite these inconsistencies, the quality of the salad itself was satisfactory."

We dropped our vehicle off Saturday to have them check why it sputters upon acceleration. They never called us back (after 3 calls to them) to let us know it was ready.  Monday afternoon they called and said  they \"jiggled some wires\" test drove it and they claimed it was fine, but if the check engine light comes on, bring it back. Not even 24 hours later it came on, we dropped it off Monday night and now it's Tuesday afternoon and not a single call from them.  Their communication clearly needs work, and after 2 whole days of having our car and not being able to find out what's wrong with it is unacceptable.  Even if they find out what's wrong with it before they close today, they will have to keep it another day or so to potentially fix what's wrong with it.  This would not have been such a rotten experience had they just kept us informed once, or even twice, even if to just say \"hey, we are still working on it and will call you\".  At this point, we are getting the vehicle and taking it elsewhere.  If you decide to go with Fletcher's, be prepared to have little to no communication about what's going on with your vehicle.

I've been going to Lee Lee's for a number of years, but it seems to be in a decline over the last year. While the selection and stock of some ethnic sections are still maintained, the Japanese foods aisle is not being stocked regularly. Lee Lee's has never had an outstanding Japanese food section, but it had most of the essentials. Being of Japanese descent, this section was a lifesaver for me-but no more. Instead of the familiar brands and selection of Japanese goods a ten-foot section of shelves was being fronted with CostCo (Kirkland) roasted seaweed. While I do buy seaweed from CostCo occasionally, when I'm having some good rice I look for the slightly thicker and more flavorful Japanese brands. Even their rice section was decimated and lacked stock. I guess I'll look for a new market.

The food here is great - my problem with the place is around two things:  ok although a minor problem it still is a consistent problem...every time I go I get a milkshake and every time it is not mixed well enough.  This results in huge chunks of ice cream you have to mash or wait for it to melt.  I dont like that.  The second problem I have with this place is the service.  I have gone four times at varying times of the day and always the service is subpar.  I end of flagging down the waiter for refills and begging for the check again and again.  But the food is good so if you are only interested in the food and the cute atmosphere then this is your place...not for me though.

"Culinary excellence\nConvivial hospitality (provided that the establishment is not experiencing an excessive influx of patrons at the time of my visit)\nI principally frequent this eatery during the hours designated as 'happy' for the purpose of partaking in their delectable hors d'oeuvres and savoring a cold beverage or two."

I went here on Thursday May 1st, 2014. The two girls that were working on this day were sitting at a table with their friends when my sister and I walked in. One of them reluctantly stood up to help us while the other stayed seated. The employee acted like it was such a chore to help us. Instead of letting us browse she followed us every step of the way in an attempt to make us hurry up and order. In summary, the customer service was bad, the ice cream was great.
I was pretty disappointed to find out that they do not carry any type of yard art or Talavera pottery... \nI'm always looking to add a little something.

I have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on a previous occasion, and my experience was satisfactory, with the culinary offerings being of an acceptable quality and the ambiance of the outdoor seating area being particularly enjoyable. However, my most recent visit proved to be somewhat disappointing, as my companions and I were not acknowledged by any member of the staff stationed at what appeared to be a host stand, and we were forced to wait for several minutes while the servers congregated near the entrance, seemingly oblivious to our presence. We ultimately decided to take matters into our own hands and locate a table ourselves, only to discover that the vast majority of tables sported "reserved" signs, which, while understandable, led me to anticipate some degree of assistance from the staff in securing a suitable table. Instead, our server approached us and inquired whether we had simply "walked in," and whether we required menus, before informing us that the table we had selected was, in fact, reserved, and that any other table would be suitable, and that she would attend to us momentarily. We managed to find the sole remaining unoccupied table, only to be informed by a member of the sizable party responsible for the reservation of the tables that even that table was earmarked for their use. It is my understanding that it is reasonable for a large gathering to dine at a restaurant, but I could not help but feel that the staff's attention was focused primarily on that particular group, to the detriment of other patrons. My friends and I ultimately chose to vacate the premises, feeling both frustrated and impatient. I truly hope that this isolated incident does not become the norm for this establishment, as I have previously enjoyed their cuisine and would hate to miss out on future opportunities to partake in it due to subpar service.

"This location would greatly benefit from the implementation of complimentary or subsidized parking, thereby enhancing its vibrancy and utility.
