Initially, the novelty of the shopping center attracted both local residents and external visitors, who eagerly explored the diverse retail options and dined at the various restaurants. However, over time, the once bustling complex has succumbed to an unfortunate cycle of decline, characterized by an overabundance of chain establishments and a dearth of unique, locally-owned businesses. Notwithstanding this trend, certain eateries still offer appealing happy hour promotions, which remain a notable aspect of the shopping center's appeal."

This theatre is pretty good. The seating is comfortable, the stage is kind of small, but the drinks are SLIGHTLY better priced than what you'll find elsewhere (and also really delicious!)\nI would love to give them a solid 4 stars, but the fact that I went here for a night of improv and heard nothing but the banging of the bass from Tabu next door is inexcusable. Are you freaking kidding me with that poor planning?!? My show (that I spent a good amount of money on) was at 11:30pm. The noise was constant and quickly gave me a headache. You could feel the vibrations and my husband's seat shook. \nIt really was a huge distraction from a show that was pretty fantastic and otherwise, would have been worth every penny. I plan to formally complain. I don't know how you can sell expensive tickets with clear conscience and expect your guests to deal with that for the entirety of the event.

Dim Sum is not good at all.  This restaurant is better than Dim Sum on Central.  That is not really saying much.  The dishes seem frozen and not fresh.  The dim sum was bland and not much variety.  I do not expect Charlotte to have the quality dim sum of large cities.  However, I do expect the staple dim sums such as chicken feet, shrimp rice noodles and other to be at least good.  However, they are not.  Recommendations for dim sum is to drive to Atlanta.

"If you opt for a combination platter at this establishment, be prepared for an element of unpredictability, as one of the two items presented will likely possess an unconventional quality. In my case, the buffalo chicken salad I ordered arrived adorned with an unsettlingly rubbery, crispy fried chicken that I hesitated to consume. Similarly, my companion's apple gorgonzola salad was marred by an abundance of bland, wilted iceberg lettuce. However, what salvages Za's reputation is their assortment of delectable Cheesecake Factory treats, which serve as a welcome respite on days when you require a decadent indulgence to alleviate the distress caused by life's tribulations."

If you are seeking an affordable lodging option, it is recommended that you consider the Excalibur Hotel, as it offers relatively inexpensive accommodations compared to other establishments in the area. However, it is important to note that the Tropicana Hotel, which was once a popular choice among travelers, has recently experienced a significant decline in quality and cleanliness, as evidenced by the personal experience of the author, who stayed at the hotel a couple of years ago and found it to be merely adequate, but upon returning last week, was disappointed to find that it had become extremely unpleasant and unsanitary, warranting the use of the term "supergross.com" to describe its current state.

Their burgers are tasty. Not the best I've had, but good for the price. Our server was friendly and dropped by to make sure we were happy on a regular basis. I wasn't a huge fan of the atmosphere, too much country music for my tastes. They have lots of pool tables and a few bigger games like free throws and boxing games, and plenty of TVs showing whatever games are on.\n\nThe one real gripe I have with the place is that nobody seems to clean the tables, there were crumbs and old drips of ice cream that I had to clean myself.
I was not dazzled by the food.  The place is quaint for an uptown spot.  The food is definitely overpriced. I will not return on my dime, it would have to be someone else's.

This diminutive iteration of Sephora, nestled within the confines of JCPENNEY's lower level floor in close proximity to the mall entrance, presents a convenient location for patrons seeking to optimize their shopping experience by minimizing the time spent navigating through the store to access it. However, the inventory available at this particular establishment falls short of expectations, as it encompasses only a limited selection of popular items and fundamental products within certain lines, thereby restricting the scope of choices for customers. Despite these limitations, the presence of Sephora within JCPENNEY remains a positive aspect. Regrettably, the quality of customer service encountered at this location warrants a subpar rating, as observed during a recent visit where five sales representatives were present at the cash wrap, with two actively engaged in assisting customers while the remaining three appeared preoccupied with personal matters, oblivious to the presence of nearby shoppers. Furthermore, an absence of acknowledgment or assistance was evident when attempting to peruse the fragrances, despite momentarily blocking the path of the sales representatives. Ultimately, a potential sale valued at $100 was lost due to the lack of attentive service, raising questions regarding the affiliation of these employees with JCPENNEY and the effectiveness of management's strategies in addressing the issue through means such as reviewing security footage.

We elected to opt for a mobile groomer for our octogenarian Bolognese canine companion, who suffers from multiple health afflictions, including ocular impairment. The stress associated with transporting her to a traditional grooming salon, replete with cacophonous canines and ear-shattering blow dryers, proved excessively burdensome. Furthermore, our erstwhile groomer of six years failed to fulfill their obligations, precipitating our search for an alternative provider. Following a thorough examination of online testimonials, we selected Green Dog Mobile Grooming and contacted them via telephone yesterday, leaving a detailed message containing our contact information and expressing our interest in scheduling an appointment at the earliest convenience. However, despite the lapse of more than twenty-four hours, we have yet to receive a response, which we deem unacceptable given the importance of prompt communication in establishing a rapport with prospective clients. Consequently, we shall continue our pursuit of a suitable grooming service, albeit with diminished expectations, as the prolonged silence from Green Dog Mobile Grooming has engendered a sense of disappointment and skepticism regarding their reliance and dedication to client satisfaction.

We had an underwhelming dining experience at this establishment, particularly for a special occasion such as my mother's birthday. Despite being the sole patrons in the restaurant at 4:30 pm, our meal was marred by several issues. Our initial order of calamari was overbreaded, rendering the flavor of the squid almost imperceptible. However, the risotto Milanese that followed was truly exceptional. Unfortunately, the quality of the service deteriorated thereafter. When I informed them that it was a birthday celebration, I anticipated a complimentary dessert, but instead, we received a tiramisu that I had already ordered for myself, not my mother. It is essential to remember that on special occasions, it is crucial to specify all the desserts you intend to order, rather than presuming that the restaurant will provide them gratuitously. To compound matters, I failed to receive my doggie bag containing the remaining risotto, despite the waiter's assurance that it would be prepared. It appeared that the wait staff were more preoccupied with processing our payment than ensuring our satisfaction. Consequently, I am unlikely to return to this restaurant in the future. Although the cuisine was passable, the subpar service warrants a rating of two stars. In today's hospitality industry, excellent service constitutes half of the overall experience.

The food is so-so and is severely overpriced for the caliber of the food they serve.  Their runners don't time the food right and even the waiter/waitress that waits on you doesn't even remember who ordered what. They call this place an American brasserie but this is fake French at best, and even that is a bit of an insult if you'd ask a French chef to taste their food. Don't get me wrong.  The food here is good, but thats the problem - It's not 'excellent' , 'mouthwatering' or 'to die for'. It's just ok good.  It's not worth what they charge, and if you're looking for good French, this place definitely isn't it.  With that being said, the ambiance and decor are superb. The mixed drinks are tasty and they don't jip you on the alcohol.  I suppose I expected a lot more out of a restaurant in the upscale Renaissance Hotel near the theatres, where a lot of out-of-towers may frequent. Surely, you wouldn't want this place to showcase Pittsburgh.
If you have a choice, go to the one downtown. I always get the buffalo shrimp, but at this Majerle's the coating was too thick. Not to mention, our ice tea tasted like dirt and service was horrible.

"Belgian ale enthusiasts may find solace in the fact that the brewpub's eponymous offerings are palatable, if not particularly remarkable, whereas the poultry appendages are delectable, albeit in limited quantity. However, the culinary letdown lies in the lackluster, uninspired preparation of the principal dish, which not only falls short of expectations but also boasts proportions that border on the absurd. Happily, the hospitable nature of the staff serves as a redeeming quality, rendering the establishment worthy of a visit, albeit a brief one, for the purpose of partaking in a single serving of ale and an accompanying hors d'oeuvre."

"Mediocrity permeated our dining experience, as the restaurant's inability to deliver culminated in a personal visit; regrettably, the chicken satay's desiccated texture and overcooking eclipsed its flavor, while the basil fried rice suffered from an unbalanced ratio of ingredients, resulting in a mushy, oversauced dish; furthermore, the shrimp and chicken combo, constituting only three minuscule shrimp and six or seven pieces of poultry, failed to satiate our expectations, despite the presence of requisite flavors; however, the chicken and vegetable stir fry, boosted by the subtle zest of black beans and ginger, proved to be the most palatable option; alas, the overall quality did not justify the $30 price tag for one appetizer and two entrees, especially given the acclaim bestowed upon the establishment by Yelp reviewers, leaving us feeling underwhelmed and disillusioned."

Our group decided to do the all day buffet because it was cheap and easy. Maybe we should have saved the stomach aches and long hours on the potty and just spent money on decent food. Well see the foods not that bad.. its just i can't eat three meals of stale food. Breakfast was whateves. Standard stuff but they had fried rice and array of wtf \"breakfast\" foods out.. Lunch rolled around and low and behold the same exact shit we had for breakfast! They added some fried chicken but that was basically it. Dinner was better but i really can't eat stale food all day. Boo

We are staying at the Mirage and happened to walk by this restaurant which looks amazing from the outside. My wife and I are avid sushi fans and thought this would be a fun place to try out. The waitress was very friendly and the Kirin Ichiban beer was great. The sushi, was not worth the high price tag. We ordered the calamari which is thick strips (it's good but also pricey). We ordered 3 sushi rolls and were very disappointed with the lack of creativity for such an expensive roll. We decided to close out our bill even though we were still hungry because we were not satisfied. \n\nThe regular sushi rolls are extremely tiny and are just the item around rice and seaweed.  If you are deciding on this restaurant for sushi alone, don't bother. If you like your sushi to have a variety of the sea's flavors, then don't go here. Maybe we are spoiled because we are from San Diego but I will not be coming to this restaurant again. We are used to much tastier, creative sushi for about half the price of Japonais.

Food was pretty good. Nothing too unique or memorable besides the decor, and the 60s music absolutely killed the mood. They need to keep with the theme and have instrumental chill music. Ciabatta chicken sandwich was ok. Bread lacked the traditional ciabatta flavor. Sweet potato fries were a bit soggy. Hummus was pretty good, though the pita tasted a bit raw?

This place is big. There's bowling, pool, a restaurant with okay food, and games, most of which are played for tickets. There are three major knocks on this place in my opinion. First, it's really not that kid friendly, as it's open on two ends and there's nothin preventing someone from walking out with a kid. I always stress safety when we go but parents really need to stay in top of their kids, which can be difficult if you have more than one child. 

Secondly, it lacks a food selection of traditional arcade games. Most games are extremely violent or involve tickets, neither of which are appropriate for kids of some ages. 

On another note, the games that are played for tickets are really an introduction to gambling, i.e. pay money to play a game of chance in hopes of winning tickets or a prize. I always steer the young ones away from playing games solely in the hope of winning tickets. I stress hat they should play a game that will be fun regardless of whether it involves tickets.

In summation, true kids love the place but I'm not a big fan.

McDonald's will be McDonald's so I've based my review on service alone. cashier had no personality. He didn't smile or even was interested on working. He looked and sounded miserable taking my order. The manager on the other hand gave me my food with a smile and even cracked a joke. it was a morning shift so that employee needs to cheer up and smile more and spread positive vibes especially when people are just starting their day.

carolinas, your enchiladas ruined it for me.

i can't imagine eating another one of your soggy tortillas swamped in a pool of the most horrifying enchilada sauce my taste buds have ever met. mole overload and non-existent chile. lacking any real taste to it whatsoever.

disappointed.

Sorry, diminutive craniums, my visitation to Mia Bella Cafe was merely mediocre and failed to parallel the quintessential experience seemingly indulged by the multitude. My arrival transpired at approximately 11:15 a.m., and the establishment was devoid of any patrons, similar to a barren wasteland. My culinary aspirations sought a light repast, but the conspicuous signage advertising shawarma external to the premises piqued my craving, rendering me susceptible to its allure. Thus, I opted for a shawarma wrap accompanied by a side of potato salad, followed by a turkey panini to be consumed at a later juncture during the day.

My synopsis shall be succinct, as Friday's ephemeral nature necessitates a prompt conclusion, allowing you to indulge in nocturnal revelry unhindered. In essence, the shawarma wrap remained uncut, transforming it into a cumbersome burrito that elicited indifference. Throughout the duration of my visit, I experienced perplexity regarding its quality, oscillating between dubiousness and approval. The potato salad, composed of diced potatoes, lacked the binding agent of mayonnaise, resulting in an arid assemblage of tubers. Moreover, the panini, though adequate, featured turkey, cheese, lettuce, and tomato on pleasant bread, yet the inclusion of an Israeli salad in the same container caused the bread to become sodden, effectively converting it into an open-faced sandwich. Ultimately, my experience at Mia Bella Cafe was unremarkable, and I harbor doubts about revisiting the establishment.

My spouse and I opted to partake in a romantic dinner at this establishment on the evening of February 14th, thus my account may not accurately reflect the customary experience of a regular visit. Nonetheless, I shall proceed to share my thoughts regarding our culinary excursion.

Upon arriving at the appointed hour of 7:30 PM, we were not escorted to our table until approximately 9:00 PM, at which point my patience, hunger, and enthusiasm for indulging in a pricey, mediocre rack of lamb had waned substantially. The fare provided by the restaurant was merely adequate, and the layout of the dining area left much to be desired, with tables positioned too closely together and an inconvenient pillar obstructing the majority of my visual perspective. While the possibility of enjoying a meal at a table situated near the window may exist, I fear that I shall never return to investigate such a possibility further.

2.5 but I rounded down.
This is not a place you go to eat out but it's rather a emergency stop when you have no other place to go perhaps 4 in the morning. Cash only. Doesn't separate the check so if you are eathing with somebody else figure it out among yaselves.
I'm not a big fan of diner's and haven't been to one so I don't have anything to compare to but like I said, if you have nowhere else to go you might try this one.
Food is ok. It's like the food that a mom who doesn't care for cooking cooked. I don't want to be too mean. Waitresses are friendly. They are dressed up in scrubs like nurses.

Came in for dinner on a Saturday night at about 9 PM.  A little busy, but the service was fairly quick.  Large selection - mostly bar food.

Girlfriend had a taco salad which had a very greasy shell. I had a club sandwich with fries and a cup of chili.  Fries were made there, crispy and great. Club was not toasted and had no spread. Chili was tasty.

Prices were a bit higher than a Phoenix bar & grill, but I guess it is Cave Creek.

It's a chain, so I know the food is decent. I'm mostly turned off by the fact that I couldn't come here to watch a baseball game. No sports package at a popular burger place? I'll be going elsewhere for dinner.

I wanted to enjoy pure but it was disappointing from the beginning. We waited for over an hour to get in even though my group had 6 females and 3 guys. They complained of the ratio EVEN though they kept marching in hordes of guys. Inside the club I would see at least 5 guys for every girl that walked by. The floor was sticky and the bartenders and staff were slow and unfriendly. The only good things about Pure was the roof lounge and the fact I made $50 in cash from some \"high roller\" in the VIP making it \"rain\" dollar bills throughout the night. I would never pay to get into this club but at least I made $50.

"EXCEPTIONALLY AMICABLE WAITSTAFF. I have had the pleasure of being served by an affable and convivial team of servers on multiple occasions, fostering an atmosphere of camaraderie and hilarity that has led to the development of a strong rapport between myself and the staff. It has been suggested that this cordial dynamic may be attributed to the fact that the majority of patrons exhibit a reserved demeanor towards the waitstaff, whereas I, conversely, am characterized by my genial nature. 
 Free popcorn and unlimited ice tea refills for a nominal fee of $4 are undoubtedly a remarkable offering. While the culinary options are moderately priced and satisfactory, they do not ascend to the level of exceptional quality. 
 The establishment's television setup, regrettably, does not encompass all seating areas within the bar, which can be a source of annoyance for certain clientele. For instance, my acquaintance experienced considerable discomfort attempting to observe a UFC event. 
 Disturbingly, I have been apprised by an extremely reliable source among the staff that the restaurant engages in the unsavory practice of recycling coleslaw. This reprehensible behavior is truly nauseating, and I must confess that the mere thought of it has rendered me reluctant to partake in that particular menu item ever again. As to whether the staff member in question remains employed at the establishment, I cannot confirm, nor will I disclose their identity."

I was in town on the night the Lakers were also in town. BF and I and a friend decided to try to get tix from a scalper. Not knowing the venue, well it figures we got jipped. We got tickets to something they call the verve lounge. Its like a club in between the lower and upper levels. OK thats fine except there is nowhere to sit and the view is lame.\nNOT worth it, I would rather sit in the nosebleeds, then again I'd rather be at Staples Center.

Firefly is a cool place, but much more for the trendy crowd than for the foodies, like me. It was really loud and crowded. The menu did not have anything very adventurous, in fact quite the opposite. The \"french fries\" tapas were ok. So was the manchego mac and cheese. The grouper was very dry and plain. The salad was acceptable, but the empanadas seemed small for tapas. The albondigas were boring meatballs with no real flavor. The best thing was the paella, and I've had much better.\n\nIf you are looking for great tapas, this just isn't the place.

Had the Maine Lobster Pot Pie and the Shrimp and Scallops for entrees. Crab cakes for appetizer. We do not get it. The Pot Pie was a neat and cool presentation but that was it. All tastes were just weird and sometimes unpleasant, the food overall was a disappointment with a capital D. The service was struggling to not be fake and the night was just not one of our better dinners in Vegas. We have been to a few Michael Mina restaurants and it seems to be the same at all of them. Not up to standards of other Vegas celebrity chef, high end restaurants. Really disappointed. Cost was only 30.00 dollars less then Gordon Ramsay's and no where near the experience.

"The shopping and selling atmosphere would be significantly more pleasant if the staff members were not discourteous, hostile, and inadequate. I am currently stationed within the establishment awaiting their processing of my attire that I am attempting to sell, with an anticipated delay of 45 minutes, which I find perplexing given the fact that there are five employees present and merely three patrons, including myself. Upon entrance, not a single employee extended a greeting or even a cursory smile. I was compelled to stand in wait at the counter for a span of five minutes before an associate finally approached me, albeit in a brusque manner. It is mystifying; do they not desire commercial success?! 

This particular store boasts an impressive array of garments, yet the unpleasant ambiance within the retail space substantially diminishes the overall shopping experience. A sign reading 'like us on Facebook' is prominently displayed, but it appears that they are not interested in fostering a positive rapport with their clientele. 

As a devoted shopper and seller, I shall no longer conduct business with Plato's Closet subsequent to the current excursion. My inclination is to favor the more competent, friendly, and welcoming atmosphere of Buffalo Exchange. I shall inform my extensive social network of this regrettable encounter that I customarily endure upon visiting this establishment."

Went in for a meal on Sunday night.  Not a great move.  The food was really not great even for a chain italian place.  Service was good, we sat at the bar to watch the Sunday night game.  \n\nI'm still not sure if the issue was the poor food, the poor menu, or something I can't nail down.

I love korean BBQ and I love Sura's style concept.  The restaurant is buffet style. You pick the meats and dishes that you wish to have and bring it back to your table to grill. A server will bring you drinks and clean your grill ever so often. 

The food isn't bad but it isn't great. You might find some pieces of meet that are still frozen if you pick from the middle of the tray. 

I went to the restroom while eating here and witnessed an employee leaving the stalls without washing their hands only to later see her behind the buffet line serving meat.  True story. 

I was so disgusted I wanted to return back to the stall and puke. 

Since Sura's AYCE menu is around the same price of the others in town...I'd go elsewhere especially after using their restrooms.

"The Fringe, the International Festival, and the Film Festival, I can all comprehend with relative ease and cognitive fluency, however, the Book Festival, that particular event seems to stretch the boundaries of my understanding, as it appears to be somewhat of an enigma, a conundrum that challenges my mental faculties and capacity for rational thought, nevertheless, I shall endeavor to persevere and attempt to grasp its significance and inherent value, despite my reservations and misgivings. The Politics Festival, on the other hand, strikes me as a tad excessive and perhaps even superfluous, as politics, while undoubtedly vital and relevant to our contemporary world, does not strike me as the sort of subject that warrants a dedicated festival, per se, as it lacks the certain je ne sais quoi, the ineffable quality that renders a topic worthy of celebration and commemoration, at least in my humble opinion. However, I digress, and shall continue to expound upon this theme, as I visualize a gathering of eccentric individuals, unconventional and free-spirited souls, assembled together in a circular formation, engaged in a fervent discussion, a spirited dialogue, regarding the intricacies and nuances of the capital gains tax, their faces adorned with looks of intense concentration and unbridled passion, reminiscent of a group of ancient philosophers, debating the mysteries of the universe, and next, we have the Festival of Accountancy, a spectacle that defies explanation and transcends the boundaries of rational comprehension."

"If this purported spa presumes to proffer a genuine pampering experience, it patently fails to deliver. Following a protracted twenty-minute wait to be seated at a table, I was peremptorily requested to relocate. My nail technician, who appeared to be more engrossed in conversing with colleagues in a foreign tongue than attending to my needs, uttered a paltry pair of phrases in my direction throughout the entire procedure. Moreover, an antiquated array of lotions and creams was relegated to a dusty corner cabinet, while a worn, dilapidated spray tan booth was offered for sale. Despite these deficiencies, the establishment seemed to enjoy a steady stream of clientele. Although my nails did ultimately appear satisfactory, following a $15 fill, I have no intention of returning to this subpar salon."

I went in today to have a look at their selection, i walked in and no one was there. I heard someone snoring in the back so i figured i would take a peek. As i thought, someone was laying on the couch sleeping! ahah. I hate waking people up so I took a few business cards, took note of their products, and went on my way.

Products were some of what i am looking for, drip tips, and batteries, and also looking for new brands of liquid i haven't tried out. I'll be back in a few days maybe, and hopefully someone will be awake to answer a few of my questions.

It's a small store from what i saw, i didn't see any testers i could help myself to, i did see a showcase full of flavors which was nice. I did find a couple that caught my eye as i was reading them. Other than that, it was a shame i walked in at a bad time.

for now 2/5 stars i can't leave this mistake unsaid.

A lot of these reviews talk about how friendly the staff is, but when I went yesterday (6pm on 2/26), I did not experience that at all. We weren't ever greeted or said goodbye to.  The first thing the cashier said to me when I went up to order was just \"hold on.\" Then she took my order (medium tea), then told me to hold on again, so she could finish doing two other orders, one of which was a smoothie. I literally just ordered tea and their tea comes in tea bags. She just left my cup with a tea bag in it on the counter while she went to make the coffee and the smoothie. Maybe it's just me, but I don't see why she couldn't just put the hot water in my cup.\n\nI do understand that it must've been hard since she was the only one working up front, but c'mon, you gotta learn how to multitask and do it with a smile on your face. If she at least greeted us or said something other than \"hold on\" and \"here you go\" to me, then I might've given this place 3 stars, maybe even 4. Customer service can really do a lot for a place and I just didn't experience anything good here. I will, however, be back in the future since this is one of the only coffee shops by my house and I'm always on the prowl for some study spots.

"I had an appointment with Doctor Meghan; however, she did not show up due to illness, which is understandable as everyone gets sick. Nevertheless, that is not the point. The front desk receptionist, Judy, displayed a discourteous demeanor and seemed displeased to be present. Throughout the encounter, she exhibited unprofessional behavior, even going so far as to disparage me to the technicians, claiming that I was rude and foolish, among other nonsensical accusations. Ultimately, patients should not be subjected to such treatment. Despite arriving on time for my appointment, I was forced to wait for an hour before receiving treatment. In contrast, the assistant and Doctor Michaels provided excellent service. Judy requires training in patient communication and professionalism, as do the other girls at the front desk, who frequently engage in unprofessional conversation that can easily be overheard by patients."

Went for Sunday brunch. Ordered a Western Omelet - it was ok. Others at my table got the all-you-can-eat buffet, and seemed to enjoy it - I think this is a quantity over quality kind of place.\nOne highlight was the hashbrown casserole - very tasty!

I have been here three times now. For some reason a lot of my coworkers really like it. It's a popular lunch-time destination. 

They are known for their southern, Louisiana style dishes. I would say it's just pretty typical, heaving-tasting foods. Their gyros are not bad actually, but the creole with shrimp and blacken fish I had as a lunch special were just too salty and heavy for me. I'm sure some who love their soul food would appreciate it, but it wasn't for me. 

It gets pretty crowded during lunch hours, and the spaces are quite tight.
I ordered the spicy shrimp whichis noted as very spicy.  It was so NOT spicy and NOT flavorful.  However I had a nice time inspite of the food.....

"While not necessarily exceptional, the culinary offerings at this establishment are, at the very least, adequate. Those familiar with authentic Cajun cuisine may find the fare underwhelming, but in the absence of alternative dining options, it manages to suffice. Of note, the Rat Toes appetizer showcases a commendable level of flavor and texture."

I have been an ardent devotee of this Fry's since its renovation last year, lavishing considerable financial resources upon it.  My most recent shopping excursion, regrettably, proved to be a profoundly vexing and disillusioning experience, as I discovered upon arriving home that several items were conspicuously absent from my purchases.  This reprehensible occurrence marked the third instance of such an event transpiring at this specific establishment, and my attempts to elicit even a modicum of contrition or empathy from the store's staff (including, most recently, an assistant manager) have been met with a resounding lack of success.  In stark contrast, a previous shopping expedition to Safeway resulted in my acquiring shrimp that, upon arrival at my domicile, proved to be irredeemably spoiled; yet, upon returning to the store, the manager not only graciously replaced the tainted seafood with twice the quantity, but also refunded my original payment in its entirety.  Now, that, my friends, is unwavering dedication to providing exceptional customer service.  While Fry's may boast competitive pricing, the incalculable value of a satisfactory customer experience cannot be matched by any monetary sum.

I'm not sure when this started but tonight I noticed a sign that states from 9pm to 5am there is a 25 cent surcharge on every item sold. The establishment is open 24 hours. It's ridiculous that they would operate in this manner.  Are they paying their employees more in the evening? Highly doubtful. \n\nBread was delicious as usual. Hot and fresh.

Food was awesome but service was terrible.Went on NYE and waited 20 plus minutes for drinks which kinda set the tone for the dinner.Server was OK but the time from which we ordered to when we received our food was much to long.When I questioned the waiter I was told\" Its not my fault they are way behind in the kitchen\" .This is not the response I expect from a place like this.We may go back but why when there are so many other good steakhouses in Vegas.

Agave-how I wish it weren't so:
1. Terrible service- no hostess when we arrived. No utensils when we received our food. No server to take our payment. Everything was just slow. I'm wasn't in a hurry, but having to wait for everything makes any average person a little anxious.
2. Food- Crispy quesadillas - chicken and corn versions: nice corn masa shell but bland fillings. Then we had the fresh fish tacos. They were soggy and a mess. The fish had an old fishy flavor and I couldn't get past it. If I'm able to eat fish sauce like it's ketchup, I think I have a pretty good tolerance of seafood/ocean taste.
3. Ambience- surprisingly nice. From the exterior, I wouldn't never have thought it was that well put-together in the interior. It was a great blend of the colors, the lighting and a Large center bar. But I'm here for food first and thought did not impress.

Worst bar tenders in Charlotte. Inefficient, rude, and mess up a simple orders. I ordered 3 beers and ended up with 3 shots of Fireball. I told her I ordered 3 Two Hearted Ales, she left and I never got my beers even after a bar back told her I was still waiting for my order.
I don't think I saw an employee for the first 10 minutes I was in there. Once I basically ran into one he was helpful.

For Scotland's busiest, most pivotal, and the capital city's central railway terminal, it was utter pandemonium. I opted for a taxi to facilitate my descent to London, and upon descending beneath the surface, I was taken aback by the sheer disarray that permeated the atmosphere. Perhaps it was due to my own inexperience or the ongoing construction that seemed to exacerbate the situation. Nonetheless, all the customary amenities one would anticipate from a contemporary train station were present, including a nearby public house, a convenience store, and an assortment of other familiar establishments. The open-roof design, reminiscent of an urban underpass, did not sit well with me, as the climate in this region tends to be quite inclement, with copious amounts of rain and an abundance of chilly temperatures. Moreover, hailing from California, the notion of being subterranean beneath imposing structures that possess the potential to collapse was profoundly unsettling, nearly as much as discovering that the trains destined for London were isolated on a singular track, independent from the remaining railways. It appeared that individuals either indulged in excessive alcoholic beverages or arose at an ungodly hour to secure their seats on these excursions.

4 stars for the young bear stuffer guy rockin the converse shoes, he tried his best to keep my birthday girl's attention. She just turned 2 (if you read my reviews she is the one that might be autistic or has adhd and is wild nutz) and she was just all over the place.

Now, this is where I have to take off a star... at the check out... my daughter had a build a bear purse that she stuffed with hearts (both the purse and hearts were BAB, I was not buying them). I quickly snatched it without her looking and put it behind my me and on top of a shelf.... obviously so my daughter would not see it and scream. Well Mr. Lazy from behind the counter (not my cashier) starts yelling MAAAAM give it to me and I will put it away...  HERE GIVE THAT TO ME AND I WILL PUT IT BAAAAAACK. My daughter started wondering what he was yelling about and she was looking around. 
The guy was ridiculous, my husband was paying and he even turned around to see what the guy was yelling at.
2x I replied to him that I didn't want her to see it and then I just walked away.

That jackass should know if a mother tries to hide something away from a child that he should not create a scene. All he had to do was put it back after we left.
I like the back area of the bar outside. The music is pretty good. Didn't get to stay there long. I'll have to try it again some time.

I grew up in Las Vegas so I've been here a zillion times. The security lines can be long during peak travel times (Fri and Sun afternoons), there's a nice variety of food chains and random and expensive stores. I always pray I get to fly out of the A and B gates since it is waaaay less crowded and there's never a line for security. Since it's a big airport, it can take a long time to get from your car to checking in your luggage to your gate, so allow for some extra hiking time. \nOf course there's cheesy Las Vegas crap all over the place and slot machines, but that's what makes this place so... Vegas. The TSA clowns are usually pretty easy-going and apparently the taxi lines are realllly long. So save time ad hire a limo. It probably costs about the same. Also, free Wi-Fi!!

I've been here for brunch before and it was amazing! However, I was disappointed by a recent trip for a friend's bday. 

We had a big group and hung out in the bar area, standing/mingling, and occupied the three tall, center tables. It was a Monday night and the service was EXTREMELY slow. It looked like the server, in addition to the bar area, was also responsible for some tables in the dining room.

I ordered a drink and it arrived about 20 minutes later. A friend ordered food at the same time and his food arrived about 10 minutes before my drink. And we were sitting right next to the bar! The drink did not fit the description on the menu (it sounded like a martini, based on the description, but ended up being some sweet concoction served in a wine glass) and I sent it back (something I very rarely do). I asked for a different drink and it arrived, another 15 minutes later.

The dinner small plate and entree options leave much to be desired. With a large group, we wanted to order a few shareable plates, but all the small plates on the menu did not seem very sharing-friendly. Also, why does EVERYTHING have bacon?? The entrees seemed very over priced (tilapia for $22, are you kidding me?). 

I would definitely return for brunch, but never for dinner or drinks.

Ah. This place kills me......for two reasons. Firstly, it USED to be amazing...Then all of a sudden, the quality of the food and service kind of crashed. And secondly, what kind of restaurant DOESN'T ALLOW YOU TO TAKE YOUR FOOD TO GO?!??! This is the reason I won't be back. I had gone there with a friend, and we ordered and appetizer to share and then a main dish each. I had the veal with mushroom sauce which in the past was pretty amazing. However, halfway through that dish, I got full (shocking, I know). At the end of our meal, both of us asked for the rest of our dishes to be packed to go and we were told by a very unhappy woman that this would not be possible. Either eat it all here, or too bad. It was SHOCKING. So.....although the food is ok, I won't be returning here. I don't like feeling ripped off, and the fact that they won't give you the rest of your paid-for food, makes me feel totally ripped off.  :|

"I must have traversed past Frank's A Lot numerous times prior to deciding to give it a chance. Located on the eastern side of the thoroughfare that transforms into Airline Boulevard, directly behind the aerodrome, Franks' unassuming edifice has always piqued my curiosity. En route to my daily employment, utilizing Airline Boulevard as a means to circumvent several signalized intersections, I have had the pleasure of observing Franks frequently. Eventually, my intrigue was aroused, and I opted to partake in their culinary offerings for lunch.  

My expectations were surpassed by the delectable gastronomic experience that awaited me. For a most reasonable tariff, I savored a succulent hot dog, augmented by an exceptionally cordial staff whose familiarity and camaraderie suggested a familial proprietorship. Although I cannot confirm whether the establishment is indeed a family-run enterprise, their proficiency in both culinary and customer service aspects leaves little doubt. 

Franks provides both a drive-through window and a quaint outdoor seating area for patrons' convenience. It is worth noting that they only accept paper currency, but fear not, as the total cost of your repast will unlikely exceed seven dollars. 

Their signature dish, the Chicago dog, boasts an array of flavorsome embellishments, including onions, celery salt, sport peppers, and tomatoes. Pair it with a portion of their freshly prepared French fries, and you will be poised to depart, relishing life's simple pleasures. 

While their bill of fare encompasses other delectable options such as Polish sausages, cheese fries, and even Philly cheese steaks, my predilection for their Chicago dog has thus far precluded exploration of alternative choices. However, I would unhesitatingly recommend a visit to Franks A Lot to anyone who finds themselves in the vicinity."

"In the event of a cerebral explosion occurring within the confines of Grandmother's cognitive faculties on a lazy Sunday afternoon, the resulting scenario would closely resemble a sprawling, chaotic array of artistic paraphernalia, replete with an assortment of vibrant paints, versatile adhesives tailored for diverse surfaces and materials, an array of brushes in varying sizes and shapes, picture frames in assorted dimensions and forms, seasonal artistic endeavors, beads and bedazzlers, candles in abundance, irregularly shaped styrofoam blocks, construction paper, wooden shelving units susceptible to staining or coloration according to one's preference, artificial floral arrangements, glass containers, and other miscellaneous crafting supplies. Moreover, for those who harbor an ardent passion for scrapbooking, a visit to Michael's store would likely transpire as a veritable dream come true, offering an extensive array of materials and tools designed to facilitate the creation of unique, personalized mementos."

"The bartender, a reprehensible and detestable female, ostensibly endeavored to proffer an amicable demeanor; however, her inherent misanthropy and acrimonious disposition proved palpable, rendering her efforts futile. Despite this unpleasant encounter, the potables she served were undeniably exceptional, possessing an explosive and gratifying flavor profile that would unquestionably entice my return. Regrettably, the quality of the beverages was juxtaposed by the deplorable customer service, which was characterized by an uncooperative and indifferent attitude, reminiscent of the spiky, inhospitable plant known as Yucca."

Brass metamorphoses into "The Beat" on initial Fridays, and I'll return! Initial Friday is currently appropriate to visit again.

LOCATION: Fremont, of course. However, rather than being down on Fremont, it's up on Fremont! (huh?) :) It's positioned above Hennesy's Tavern. Head upstairs because that's where the celebration is. There's a balcony, so all you smokers may take a smoke break and observe the crazies walking on Fremont. If you wish to exit, there's no issue; Beauty Bar, Vanguard, and Insert Coins are merely across Las Vegas Boulevard, allowing you to bar hop and throng the remainder of downtown.

MUSIC: I believe KidFunk was spinning records. And he didn't let me down. It was a persistent flow of excellent tracks. Many houses and technological houses, with some electro and dubstep thrown in. It was an excellent evening! For the venue's size, there's a fair-sized dance floor. I explored just the main room, but on the opposite side, there's a much more extensive room with a different DJ, presumably playing distinct music. If they maintain it, I will make this a regular stop on the first Friday.

BATHROOMS: They were revolting and filthy. Drinks and other unmentionable items were strewn about the floor. Before you pop-a-squat, double-check that there is toilet paper. The dispensers were consistently empty, so grab a handful of paper towels before entering.

GOGO: Sorry, but the gogo(s) were utterly underwhelming, both in appearance and dancing.

GUYS: There is no dress code or cover charge when I arrived.

Remember to FOLLOW and RATE!;)

I decided to try this place out despite the reviews, and everyone is 100% spot on. The decor is cool looking. The bathroom was odd. The hand dryer is located on the one faucet. So if there are multiple people, they have to wait to wash their hands while you fight with the awkward dryer. For the ladies...they actually don't have sanitary depositories in the stalls. You have to walk out of the stall to the main trash to throw things away (unless I missed it somewhere). 

I had the veggie burger. It was tasty, but is definitely on the small side. I would agree that it is more like a slider. The fries are good as well. I'd say they are pretty much a normal portion size, but if I'm paying extra, it would be nice to have a larger portion.  The water cups are tiny. You have to sip it like a fine wine. I was not stuffed after the meal. I was able to go to the movies after and down a medium size popcorn without any issues. 

I hate to say, but I don't think this place is going to make it. I think for the cost, it's not worth it. They need to make things cheaper or provide larger portions. I don't think there was an option to double up the veggie patty?

"For individuals who find themselves confined to the vicinity of the convention center, this establishment serves as an adequate venue for consuming alcoholic beverages and traditional pub fare. 

As a scholar pursuing an advanced degree, I have had the occasion to visit this drinking establishment on two separate occasions, concurrent with my attendance at a conference. 

The jalapeno poppers and onion rings possess a certain appeal, while the buffalo wings, though unremarkable, contribute to the overall culinary experience. 

During sporting events, the atmosphere within the establishment becomes particularly convivial, as the large gathering of patrons enhances the sense of camaraderie. 

Therefore, if one finds oneself in the vicinity of the convention center, bereft of transportation and yearning for a beer and snacks, this location is worthy of consideration."

I was a loyal Sakana fan for years up until the birth of my sone.  Going out for sushi is not so convenient with a lil one. So after a 3 year hiatus, my husband and I opted for Sakana on date night.  Would it be all that we remembered? Disappointed to say that it wasn't. We sat at the sushi bar and the chefs were not as personable as they were in the past - very little banter or recommendations. The saving grace was the scallop dynamite - the best I have had in the Valley and the oranges for dessert. Gosh how I missed those.  \nI accept that maybe a 3 year break might have built up my expectations.

I like to go here to grab some subs on the way to the river, since it's between our house and the 17. Just because I don't want to go to Subway or Blimpie's.

Mostly, it's a rather expansive Italian market. Need olive oil? They have 20+ different kinds. Pasta? There's a whole aisle. How about one of those wooden thingies for making gnocchi. Got that too.

In the back, a counter runs along the whole length of the back wall. That's where you'll find all sorts of cheeses, cold cuts, and sausauge, plus a few sweets. 

It's also where you order sandwiches. And you'd better know exactly what your want, and fast. The man behind the counter is perpetually surly and curt. It gets worse if you stand there and try to make heads or tails of all the hand-written sandwich combinations taped to the wall. Luckily, the woman who runs the cash register is always very sweet. So that kind of makes up for it.

I want to love their sandwiches. I just don't. They're OK. The meat is always really good, there just isn't enough of it. Maybe I'm just not ordering the right things. 

Until then, I'll continue to support Romanelli's, but they'll only get a so-so rating for the deli. The product selection, however, is top notch.

This place is just ok for me. The restaurant has a nice setting, good service, and nice entertainment. The food is good but not great for the price. The steaks were slightly over aged for my taste, au gratin potatoes were very tasty though. They have a nice wine list with many options for all budgets. Its worth a try if you are at gvr and looking for a nice meal but I prefer most of the steak houses on the strip over this place.

$4 OPI!  Read Carina's review, b/c I didn't want to pay $8.50 at Ulta... geez, so cheap... alot of the OPI colors already have separated (heat?  age?) so make your choice for price over quality... I'm so cool for $4 though.\n\nOn the same end where China Magic Noodle is, same plaza as Lee Lee's.

"We opted to partake in an early evening repast and selected the Pot Roast Sandwich from the menu. Upon the arrival of our meal, we noticed that the accompanying vegetables were not adequately cooked, retaining a raw texture. Notwithstanding, the meat component of the dish was delectable. Following my communication of this observation to our server, she expressed that such an occurrence was indeed commonplace and proffered an additional side dish as compensation. Although appreciative of her efforts to rectify the situation, I couldn't help but feel somewhat muted by the implication that this was a frequent phenomenon. My spouse, on the other hand, relished his chili burger immensely. Furthermore, the beverages we requested were remarkably potent. It is worth mentioning that this establishment tends to experience a high volume of patrons, and it is possible that our choices did not align with the culinary strengths of the restaurant."

Had a carne assada torta.  It was actually not bad.  For the price it was real good.

A few comments/observations...

- Comically unorganized. There is no process for how this place works.  I got my food but if they actually had something that resembled organization I would have got it a lot sooner.

- The grill was a bit on the dirty side.

- The meat while ok was a bit on the fatty/chewy side.  Chopping it into smaller pieces would have been helpful

- Not the cleanest dining area.

Not really a 3, but not a 2 either.  I gave them the benefit of the doubt.

Sat at the bar, no music or sound on the TVs, after I asked for the second time some music was turned on, some sort of low sounding reggae I think, could barely hear it. No food on the happy hour menu, $3 Cuba Libra's, I enjoyed those. Didn't sample the food. Might come back not sure yet.

Because we are so far removed from the French Quarter my stomach rarely directs me to Cajun. Let's be honest there are few options in this town.  So this becomes the default spot to scratch the gumbo itch.  \nAbove average food, better service, higher than expected prices.

Went to this buffet (gorgeous d\u00e9cor by the way) two weeks ago and although it was great, it's not the best buffet I've eaten at.  I do have to agree with the other reviewers that the options were poor.  The quality was good and the portion control in individual containers helped but other than that, I'd say this was more like a three star place.  Luckily I didn't do the weekend $40-/+ buffet that most mentioned.  We went on a Monday during brunch time and it was about $22 I think.  Not bad for an all you can eat place in Vegas as it kept me full all day, but I felt the lack of options bored me and was done within 45 minutes.  I expected a little more from a place that looks so posh!

Dude, totally didn't realize how many lesboz are in Vegas. But they're like the totally stereotypical mullet-wearing, jean vest with ripped sleeves wearing, big arms type of galz. You know, have you seen that movie Monster with Christina Ricci and Charlize Theron? Well, that type.

Am I seriously the only hot one? Hehe jk.

Sushi's alright. But who pays $15-17 for a roll of fish?
For that money, you can go to Oakland and get yourself some
V
V
V
V
V

The pictures of the burgers looked super crazy and deadly but the portions are actually very feasible. Our group of 5 shared: sashimi \"won-tacos,\" triple T fries, the original ringer burger, and the bacon mac-n-cheese burger. We probably could have stuffed ourselves with another item. My favorites were the fries and the original burger. The fries were super crisp and full of truffle flavor, especially the aioi. The original burger had the flavors I like most, although I think the bacon mac-n-cheese is more unique and a good combination to try.\n\nTo me, the burgers are a little better than your average burger but not a favorite I would want again and again (I still prefer Bachi burger or even Holsteins). The tacos were definitely a let down- super small portion of tuna and not very interesting. Overall, I would only come back for a beer and some of those fries.

While the gastronomical indulgences are delectable and meticulously crafted, the tariffs and hospitality fail to align with the expectations of an establishment of this caliber. The ambiance is permeated by a palpable sense of disinterest among the staff, who appear to be preoccupied with matters unrelated to the provision of quality service. Upon placing our order for the triumvirate of sweet delights, my companion conveyed to the server that we would appreciate the second selection, given that the initial offering had suffered an unfortunate mishap. However, the server, rather than addressing our concern, opted to delegate the responsibility to a colleague, thereby inadvertently perpetuating a chain of miscommunication. Ultimately, we were compelled to rectify the situation ourselves, as the damage to the dessert became apparent only upon payment and seating. Although the process entailed minimal effort, it remains an inconvenience that could have been readily avoided with a modicum of attentiveness and competence on the part of the service staff.

"Alright, so I had to perform an upgrade. 

I was physically present at the BuyBack$ site in Henderson, near the Galleria Mall, when we were unable to locate the desired item. 

As a result, we contacted the Decatur location to determine whether or not they possessed the film we were seeking on Blu-ray. 

Of course, they did! They possess everything; it's unquestionable. 

We then inquired whether they could retain the product for us, stating that we would arrive shortly to collect it since we were located across town but en route. 

Therefore, we drove across the city, and you know what happened? 

These individuals had the audacity to inform us that the item was, in fact, being held for another person. They asserted that it had been previously reserved but ultimately left the decision of who would obtain it up to management's discretion. 

Well, we informed you that we were traveling from across town, and you assured us that you would hold it for us. As a result, I failed to acquire it. 

What I did receive, however, was a review update, which resulted in a loss of one star. 

Although I won't say I wouldn't revisit, I certainly won't go out of my way to return to this particular location again. 

They lost a steadfast and dedicated client."

I've been here several times, and well, it's a chain. I don't usually eat here but my husband wanted to go here. Funny enough, he actually wanted to go to BJ's and was confused. He was disappointed because they only have lager here.

Last night we actually had a 5 star experience. Our server Paul was really phenomenal. Got my kids extra fruit, really knowledgeable about beer (my husband loved chatting with him about beer and brewing) and helped me figure out the rewards program. Great service! Food was pretty good too. Hubby got the fish and chips. Fish was breaded with panko and was nice and crispy. Pretty bland though. The garlic fries were really good. I got the cheeseburger with blue cheese. Nothing phenomenal but good.

Unfortunately, I've had a lot of 1 star experiences here and I think that they are a little too expensive for the quality you get,  that I'm giving GB a 3 star overall. Hopefully last night's experience indicates improvement, but it's really a hit or miss.

The modified text is: "Arrived at this establishment on a radiant, balmy Saturday evening, I couldn't help but feel a twinge of envy towards the individuals reveling in the picturesque backyard patio, their merriment illuminated by the soft glow of suspended white lights, while I was confined to the dimly lit interior. Despite my reservations pertaining to the seating arrangements, I opted for a pear and arugula salad, which, albeit palatable, failed to satiate my hunger, leaving me $8 poorer. It appeared that the majority of my associates had elected to order beverages, which might have been a more judicious decision."

A-OK from me.  In case you can't tell from my other reviews, I'm a happy hour type of guy.  This spot has a good one.  Several appetizers and rolls half off along with good drink specials.  Want a quick roll and Kirin and are on the west side?  Come on in.  \n\nI must say that I prefer Sakana to this if you are going for dinner with someone special, but looking for some rolls and laughs with a few friends, this is a good place to do it.

"The pricing strategy implemented by this retail establishment is quite competitive, with certain items being offered at a significantly lower cost compared to other regional stores, such as Safeway, while others are priced similarly to those found at Fry's. However, it is crucial to note that the affordability of specific products can vary greatly depending on the customer's individual needs and preferences. Personally, I tend to favor Fry's in my local area due to its proximity to my friend's residence, which makes it a convenient option for us to quickly acquire the necessary items we require. Additionally, I must admit that the ambiance of the Albertson's located near my domicile can sometimes be rather unpleasant, with an odor reminiscent of spoiled seafood that can be overwhelming and potentially nauseating. Nonetheless, this particular store boasts a user-friendly layout, facilitating effortless entry and exit, and the staff consistently provides exemplary customer service."

This was the only buffet we tried (first time visitors) so we don't have anything to compare it to in town. It was nice and at $40/pp reasonably priced. The variety is small but great tasting, and I could have eaten the Na'an all night. The husband enjoyed the brisket. Everything was clean and bright but a bit too cafeteria style for my taste. Overall I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here but if it's convenient it's a good option.

We had Lunch there on a Sunday ,pretty busy .
I say the food is ok not a wow but ok.
The service was good and the place looked pretty clean .
They got lots to pick from. 
We did wait a long time for are food.
The prices are not to bad either .
I will give them another try maybe for dinner.

"The sole drawback is the protracted waiting period during peak hours, particularly via the drive-thru. My personal experience has consistently involved extended delays, with today's wait being utterly unacceptable. Despite merely two vehicles preceding me in line, the delay exceeded 15 minutes following my order placement. This was for a straightforward sandwich and smoothie, neither of which could be considered elaborate or extraordinary. Unfortunately, the quality of service has deteriorated progressively with each successive visit, rendering me increasingly wary of patronizing this establishment in the future, despite its once-favorite status."

I was suprised how much I liked Kahunaville. Sandwiches are all very reasonably priced- around 11 bucks- and very large. The drinks are spendy like most of Vegas but be nice and they pour stiff. I highly recommend a Bombay and tonic yard. \n\nOur server was very friendly and professional, She did a great job especially since one of my group pulled a rude dipshit maneuver with an empty ketchup bottle.

Typical Panda Express, but add a drive thru. Service is not exceptionally friendly, but lets face it, who cares. You have to deal with the employees for a whole minute and a half. Food is always good, portions are generally good, and close to shopping.

My date and I decided to try something new and stopped at The Lodge for Happy Hour.  We were really pleased with the prices, and all the bartenders/servers seemed really friendly.  And the deep fried cheese curds were to die for!  (I am from Wisconsin, after all.)  However, the bar stools are INCREDIBLY UNCOMFORTABLE.  We didn't stay long, but thought we liked it enough to try it again...at a table next time.\n\nP.S.  We couldn't decide whether to Yelp about the so-scantily-clad-it-was-almost-inappropriate server.  I mean, I know it's a bar and she's working for tips but...geezuz....it made us look around the bar for her pole.

This West End restaurant holds the honour of being Edinburgh's oldest chinese restaurant! (Or so it claims). It's over 50 years old, and it's become such a local favourite they're some people who've been visiting for quite a few decades. The name is a little bit dodgy, but the food definitely isn't!

The restaurant specialises in Cantonese and Peking cuisine, and there's sooooo much choice on the menu it's difficult to decide what to have. Like many chinese restaurants, the desserts menu isn't elaborate and there is something with banana's in it; this seems to be a constant in just about any chinese restaurant I've been to! 

One great sign in this restaurant is that there are actual Chinese people frequently eating there, as we all know its most difficult to please the home crowd.

Didn't stay at the hotel but the Craps game is the best even though it only pays double on 12, it offers 100X odds!!! Well worth it for cheap gaming on the Strip. The place is a little old but not run down, with low ceilings and the air smelling like smoke. The locals are friendly and the drinks are okay.

It was with a certain degree of anticipation that I had been looking forward to dining at this establishment, albeit with a tad too much trepidation. We shared an order of "croquettes" featuring foie gras, which, quite frankly, were rather unremarkable in both taste and presentation. Subsequently, I opted for the happy pig ribeye, which, while tender and cooked to perfection, was regrettably accompanied by a sauce that did not quite live up to my expectations in terms of flavor. My companion, on the other hand, chose the pan-seared duck breast, which, to be fair, was undeniably disappointing. The pecan tart was truly exceptional, but one cannot help but wonder if it is truly worth visiting this restaurant solely for such a dessert. While I am genuinely delighted to have had the opportunity to partake in the culinary offerings of this esteemed eatery, several other establishments within the same price range leave me significantly more content and satisfied.

This place and other local spots like the Teepee remind us of a far gone time when our Mexican food was predictable and when our standards were low.  But sometimes that hits the spot.  This place definitely has some history, just ask Marty Robbins.

You get what you pay for, yet I wish you could get the basic needs. This place doesn't provide a mini fridge, tea kettle, coffee maker even less a microwave, so you are forced to spend all you pennies buying street food. Also the carpets are pretty old and stinky. Our faucet didn't work, we complained and the next day it was fixed.\nThe plusses were: silent after midnight, so you can sleep pretty well :) and pretty close to everything as well. \nWouldn't mind going back but would check other options first.

This sushi spot is average at best. The rolls have too much rice and hardly any fish. I would rather pay extra and get more substance than just eat a bunch of rice. I wish they had some sort of seating. I go here when I need to grab a quick work day lunch. It's on par with grocery store grade pre made sushi

This place was aight,

$4 Beer specials were a pretty good deal but the sole reason I'm not rating this place any higher is because of the food. (Better options at 4Peaks and Santan)

It was Underwhelming and Overpriced~ The ambiance of this place was nice though

Had the Oyster Po Boy and well.... if you want seafood I guess one should move a bit closer to the W-Coast.

I came here after getting absolutely no help at Fry's. It was nice to see that all of their mini computers,ereaders and the Kindle I wanted were at the very front of the store! I'm glad I didn't have to walk all the way to the back. I was wearing heels for the first time in a long time so my feet were aching. I just wanted to get the Kindle and go. I couldn't leave without a cute case for it though. They don't have a  huge selection so I settled for a bright blue case. My ideal case would have been pink or had Hello Kitty on it.\nThe employees were so much more willing to help here. It wasn't like Frys where it was like pulling teeth to get answers. When we were about to pay the cashier asked if we had their rewards card. We had one but I didn't want to use it because of what happened before. We made some big ticket purchases a couple of years back and the gift rewards were going to some random address in Illinois.  We tried to get it corrected through their call center and even talked to the manager. When we told them that the address on file was not ours and we could prove it they still would not change the address. This is why I will go no higher then a three star rating. I can never fully trust this company.

Club was fairly standard, but the view of the city was amazing on the 53rd floor, although the one drawback of this is the fact that once you look outside, you realize how far you really are from The Strip.  That and the fact that we had very favorable weather conditions, otherwise, going outside would have been an absolute nightmare.\n\nOther than the location of the club, everything about this club screams \"decent, but unspectacular\" which, incidentally, is a very significant accomplishment for the Palms.

We ate here a week or so ago and I have to say it was okay. It's nothing either one of us was blown away by but the food was good. We ordered the gnocchi with marinara and the ravioli al formmagio.  Both were good but the stand out was the marinara sauce. I'm rather picky about it and it's probably some of the best I've had in awhile. We also ordered the caprese as an appetizer and again it was good but nothing wonderful. Service was very good as well. For a restaurant in a strip mall setting it was good however the prices are really high considering.

I'm a Gordon Ramsay fan, love all his shows and his passion for excellence.  He reminds me a bit of myself in my college years striving for perfection over the cast iron grill at Buffalo Wild Wings.\n\nBeing a fan I was excited to try this place.  What to order?  this was the hardest question to answer since the ACT.  I wanted a burger but thought I should get out of my comfort zone and try something a bit more British, so I went with the pie sampler.  I thought this was a great idea so I could sample all the taste Gordon has to offer but it backfired a bit because it really is just an appetizer, so I was still a bit hungry afterwards.  Each meat pie was about as good as a meat pie can get, but that's not saying much.  Looking back I should have ordered either a whole pie or the burger, or maybe the sampler and a burger.  My friend had a burger and it looked amazing, I stole some fries when he wasn't looking, very good.  I will be back to try the burger.

"The computer science program leaves much to be desired, but the institution's size is quite impressive.  Its ambiance is reminiscent of Arizona, with an oppressive heat that can be overwhelming at times, especially for someone who currently resides in Las Vegas.  Despite this, my fellow students were quite cordial, although the instructors occasionally exhibited an excessive strictness.  A peculiar aspect of this school was the prevalence of bicycle thievery, resulting in the creation of Frankenstein-like vehicles, composed of various parts and colors, which provided a source of amusement.  Additionally, there were numerous individuals who enthusiastically promoted their religious or ideological beliefs, contributing to the diverse and eclectic atmosphere that I found appealing, even though my expectations regarding the teaching staff were not entirely fulfilled."

This hotel had it's ups and downs. Checked in late on Friday night and the non-smoking room we requested was given away so we had to settle with a smoking room. They told us to come to the front desk between 12-3pm the following day to change rooms since they gave our room away so we agreed. 

Next day rolls around and after a great time at the pool and gym we called and they kept pushing back the time on when the room would be ready. We wasted 5 hours of our day not being able to leave and waiting for our non smoking room to be available. For someone who comes for the weekend and hours are limited it really sucks to waste time. Finally they gave us a non smoking room after complaining for 5 hours and sounding upset. It was a big disappointment. I'm giving three stars because that was an awful experience but the hotel itself wasn't too bad. The room we got upgraded and it was really nice. 

On a positive light the hotel is in the middle of the strip and it's across the street from Cosmo and Bellagio. Had fun shopping and eating at Gordon Ramsey's Burgr place.

I wish I had better things to say, but this is sadly a joint that should have stayed in my undergraduate days. I wanted to say this is for people on budget BUT, its not that cheap either.

The place is decent, clean and the sushi chef is friendly greeting us when we came in and was leaving.

I would say, I wouldn't eat any raw stuff here, and the cooked dish I got was also so-so. Tonkatsu was dry and batter was not really there. $14.50 instead of the $10 lunch price I get at King Muramoto... nah. not gonna work.

The only saving grace was the hot miso soup on the cold day I visited. 

Just not worth the price you pay, and the low traffic in the restaurant on Friday night makes me doubt the freshness of the sashimi and sushi they have.

"GIGANTIC SERVINGS. ENORMOUS. Located within the unremarkable Imperial Palace hotel, situated on the Las Vegas Strip (upstairs), this eatery boasts voluminous compartments, partitioned into two distinct rooms. Upon entering, I was taken aback by the cavernous interior, which belied its unassuming exterior. A humble breakfast consisting of eggs, hash browns, a biscuit, and coffee was my selection. The biscuit, in particular, was suffused with an abundance of butter, exuding an irresistible aroma and warmth. Unfortunately, the sheer magnitude of the meal proved to be too much for my digestive system, as I was unable to consume the entirety of the biscuit or the remainder of the dish. The culinary offerings were undoubtedly delectable, with prices commensurate to the copious amounts of food served. My entrÃ©e, one of the more basic options, cost a reasonable $9, while other dishes exceeded that amount. However, an unfortunate incident marred our dining experience, as a patron, seemingly recovering from a vigorous night of Vegas revelry, precipitously vacated the premises, leaving behind a trail of regurgitated contents. Witnessing such a scene before even finishing my meal was indeed unsettling. Nonetheless, this establishment remains an optimal destination for those seeking a satiating dining experience, perhaps best enjoyed donning protective attire..."

This hotel looks really nice and the staff are really nice. The fitness room has a few different things and they work. The free breakfast is amazing. The room isn't very functional. There's a refrigerator, but no microwave. When I eat out I have leftovers and I hate wasting food. The shower in the single bed rooms is something you would find in a dorm room. It's a tile shower only with a single shelf and there isn't a full shower door. When you stand in the shower, there's always a draft. I'm getting kind of tired of staying at \"nice\" places that are just pretty and serve no function.

I go to this restaurant usually on Sunday morning because they have their awesome double stamp days. 

Now for the restaurant-The wait can be a little annoying especially on the weekends. But, that's expected. 

The atmosphere-I usually  go to the one in Chandler off of Ray Rd. The atmosphere is very friendly and the restaurant is clean. I like the little breakfast bar they have. 

Food-The food is delicious and they have the perfect portions for me. However, my husband often complains that they don't give him enough food. But, this is where the cool little $1 menu comes in. They have a wide  range of things that you can add to your meal for $1. I usually add the fruit cup or mini-pancakes. I haven't had a chance to try a lot of their menu items. They have a pretty long list of items and I often get overwhelmed trying to figure out what to order. I have had the 7 Veggie Omelette. It was very tasty! What made it more enjoyable was knowing that I was eating a healthy omelette. Some of them have tons of ingredients and even one with all meat. The one thing that I have tried that I DO NOT recommend is the biscuits and gravy. I have had better. The gravy can taste a little bland and the biscuits taste chewy on the inside. 

Services-The service can be hit or miss. But, I do like that they give a large cup of your beverage to go. 

Great place overall.

I've been in here a few times, each time deciding that this time I'll do what they tell me to and I'll feel like Superwoman. I still haven't!!

Basically it's a health food shop. Kinda. They sell the likes of cod liver oil tablets and garlic capsules etc etc, the staff are WONDERFUL. Can'tt fault them on that!! I went in on day hearing that if I took a spoonful of Manuka Honey at bed time it helps your skin and makes you lose weight, and it did! I was glowing. Ok it wasn't like a heap of weight, but enough to make me feel better about myself. The staff gave me the honey and some cider vinegar to cook with, they knew all their stuff....but it cost me over £40!! Hence the missing 2*.

If you're serious about this sort of stuff then this is a great place. If not, then go to Boots.

It's K Mart, not bad just nothing special. Nothing really sets K Mart apart from any of the other conglomerates. Gotta shop here from time to time for MH exclusives so you'll see me busting out my Maverick patch & showing it off with pride

The waiter was attentive and helpful.  The omelet was good.  But holy fatoosh don't order the grape leaves.  Yikes...it had some sort of reddish goo spread over one of the pieces, almost like the others had it scraped off.  Took one bite and sent it back.  The decor was like a yellow mausoleum with small cubby holes surrounding the dining room, like a place for an urn of ashes.  I guess the food would be hit and miss.  Thank goodness the omelet was good.

"The pizza served at this establishment boasts an acceptable level of culinary expertise, drawing comparisons to the esteemed Setabello. However, it is worth noting that the menu has undergone a significant reduction in scope, which may limit the options available to patrons. Furthermore, the cost of the pizza, while not exorbitant, does veer towards the higher end of the pricing spectrum. Nevertheless, the staff maintains a commendable level of proficiency, ensuring that the dining experience is both seamless and hospitable."

"I indulged in the delectable smothered chicken, accompanied by a scrumptious serving of macaroni and cheese, as well as a side of flavorful green beans. Following my culinary excursion from the Balyntyne suburbs, I must admit that the gastronomical experience was indeed worth the journey. Arriving promptly at 11:30 am on a Wednesday morning, I had the privilege of being one of the establishment's earliest patrons, preceding the influx of the lunchtime throng. While I would have preferred a slightly more affordable price point for the quantity of fare provided, I assigned a respectable rating of 3.5 stars. However, due to the discrepancy between cost and value, I reluctantly deducted a star, feeling that a reasonable price for such a dish should have been around $7, rather than the $10 I was charged, excluding a beverage. Unfortunately, this disparity precludes me from considering future visits to this eatery."

"During our most recent leisure excursion, we opted to halt for a repast at Braddah's Island Style for the second time, and decided to partake in a Kalua pig burrito, replete with seaweed rice, black beans, charred pineapple verde, lettuce, and tomato. Despite the fact that the administration had the temerity to deplete their stock of cilantro, an herb commonly used as a garnish, our burrito remained palatable. However, we noticed a perceptible decline in the cordiality and attentiveness of the staff during this visit, as evidenced by the absence of complimentary samples, uncleared tables, and the delayed provision of condiments, which were only provided following a patron's request after a considerable interval of ten minutes had elapsed. Consequently, we would assign a rating of 3.5 to this dining experience."

"This culinary establishment presented itself in a relatively satisfactory manner, prompting us to peruse their menu and select the egg rolls and grilled pork dishes. However, the duration of time that elapsed between placing our order and the arrival of our meals was truly protracted, particularly considering the modest number of patrons present within the restaurant during our visit. 

Notwithstanding this inconvenience, the interior of the eatery appeared well-maintained and organized. Unfortunately, a considerable quantity of smoke emanating from the kitchen region managed to permeate the primary dining area, perhaps indicative of an issue with ventilation. 

Upon receipt of our order, it became apparent that the egg rolls were diminutive in stature and accompanied by a sweet and sour sauce, rather than the customary fish sauce typically associated with such fare. Furthermore, while the flavor of the grilled pork was undeniably palatable, its portion size seemed somewhat meager in relation to the cost. 

In conclusion, although our experience at this restaurant was not without its drawbacks, it did possess certain redeeming qualities that rendered it a worthwhile excursion. However, it remains uncertain whether a subsequent visit would be warranted."
