However, I must issue a word of caution regarding the roast beef sandwich, specifically the 'Overture' variant, as it arrives adorned with a generous helping of horseradish sauce, which, while undoubtedly delicious, proved almost unbearably piquant for my sensitive nasal passages, causing my nose to transform into a veritable fountain of mucus, if you will, thereby necessitating copious quantities of tissues, and, perhaps, a brief respite from the consumption of solid foods, in order to allow my sinuses to recover from the onslaught of spicy flavors. In conclusion, while this restaurant may possess some redeeming qualities, I would, in all honesty, recommend dining at Opa Grill, situated adjacent to this establishment, as the culinary offerings therein are, in my expert opinion, vastly superior, and well worth the nominal additional expense, if one is seeking a truly satisfying dining experience."

Interesting restaurant.  Limited menu.  I assume the menu will grow as this place finds its way.  We had the cheese plate(ok), beets(very good), mussels(very good), iceberg sald(big and good).  Pretty good beer selection.  The music was defintely off.  I am sure this will change as well.  The brunch menu looked very good.  \n\nI'll go back sometime to see what changes have been made.

Went here for breakfast last Monday and had to wait almost 20 mins to be seated as it was very busy. This also showed in the food which seemed to be hurriedly prepared. I had the pancake combo and found the turkey bacon to be extremely salty and the pancakes themselves to be flat rather than fluffy. The other members in our group also felt that the food was lacking. So overall a very OK type of meal and nothing like the IHOP that i normally visit in Torrance.
Very low key kool area. A salon right across and beanch to sit on in front of the wondow. Overall it is like being in San Diego Ca.

"The culinary experience at Delmonico's fell short of expectations, with the quality of the food being subpar. Specifically, the steak, which was advertised as the best in Las Vegas, failed to impress. Despite being cooked to perfection, the seasoning was uninspired and lacked depth, resulting in a mediocre dining experience. Furthermore, the sides, which included creamed spinach and asparagus, were underwhelming and did not live up to their potential. The dessert menu also left much to be desired, further detracting from the overall enjoyment of the meal. However, the wine list was extensive and impressive, showcasing a thoughtful selection of vintages. In light of the high standards set by other establishments in Las Vegas, Delmonico's fails to stand out as a premier dining destination."

"Having had this establishment on my culinary radar for an extended period of time, I decided to pay a visit with a companion subsequent to participating in the National Kidney Foundation Walk. Upon perusing their online menu, I was particularly intrigued by the pear omelet and was eager to sample it. To my surprise, we were promptly seated upon arrival, despite my anticipation of a considerable delay due to the lateness of the morning and the likelihood of a sizable crowd. The ambiance of the restaurant was reminiscent of a private residence, exuding a warm and welcoming atmosphere. However, my enthusiasm was somewhat diminished by the unsettling appearance of the thick gray carpeting, which struck me as unsanitary and questionable in terms of cleanliness. 

The pear omelet, while palatable, did not quite meet my expectations, primarily due to the scarcity of pears within. It seemed to me that the dish's namesake ingredient should have been more prominent. My companion and I couldn't help but notice the delectable appearances of the other patrons' meals, specifically the mouthwatering French toast, which piqued my interest and left me contemplating a future visit. 

In conclusion, our experience at this eatery was merely average, lacking any truly exceptional or remarkable aspects."

"A veritable cornucopia of gastronomical delights at an unparalleled price point, this esteemed eatery offers a diverse array of delectable dishes that cater to a wide range of palates, featuring none other than expertly crafted, hand-scooped ice cream, an unmitigated delight for the taste buds and a true embodiment of value for money. While the meat offerings may not necessarily conform to the lofty standards of haute cuisine, they are by no means inferior, with each dish showcasing a distinct flavor profile that is sure to satiate even the most discerning of diners. An ideal venue for a satisfying repast, especially given the reasonable prices, this restaurant is a veritable gem in the culinary landscape."

Mediocre galettes and that was a really disappointing thing during my recent trip to Montreal.

I told that to my Montrealer friend who said, "told you so". 

That being said, their desserts and coffee choices were fantastic. Anything with chocolate, Juliette et Chocolat does okay. Just don't rely on their dinner menu!

This is small quaint place that sells pizza by the slice or the whole pie if you wish. 

This is a 1000 times better than Sabarro's but nothing to write home about either.  If you want something quick and cheap, this is a great place. 

If you are waiting for someone to arrive at the airport this is also a great pit stop.

We enjoy happy hour here. The Tuscan Taster appetizers are very good. The spicy shrimp and eggplant varies from time to time in flavor and preparation ie., crispy vs oily. The burger is always a solid choice.  It would be nice for a healthy appetizer option.\nYou need to stick with the happy hour drinks or else your tab gets sky high quickly.\nAt the San Tan location, the blonde bar manager is efficient but super serious and curt.  We always leave satisfied but not thrilled.

"Wow, this is truly an unfortunate revelation, as my expectations were set on partaking in a delectable midday meal at this establishment, only to be met with an unanticipated impediment in the form of its unexpected closure. It appears that my lack of knowledge regarding its operational status has led to a profound sense of dismay and frustration, which I must now endeavour to overcome."

"Although my dining experience was generally satisfactory, I must express my reservations regarding the pricing policy implemented by this establishment. Specifically, the cost of the menu items appears to be disproportionate to the portion sizes, with the smallest sandwich and two accompanying sides amounting to a total of $11, an exorbitant sum that may deter potential patrons, particularly those with families to support. Furthermore, the additional fee of $1.99 for each drink, albeit a nominal amount, contributes to an overall sense of dissatisfaction with the value received for the price paid. In light of these concerns, it is suggested that management consider adopting a buffet-style format or increasing the quantity of food provided to justify the cost. Notwithstanding the aforementioned criticisms, the culinary quality of the dishes served did meet my expectations."

"The culinary offerings are of considerable quality, however, the selection could benefit from a more extensive array of options. The hospitality is satisfactory, yet the cacophony of sounds permeates the atmosphere, rendering communication with our server occasionally arduous. Despite this inconvenience, we shall undoubtedly revisit this establishment, as its ambiance evokes the essence of a sports bar, albeit with an excessive level of auditory stimulation."

I haven't stayed here but I've been inside. Hotel looks really nice. Nice lobby and very well decorated. Its located at a descent location on the Strip. However, their casino isn't the best. If you are a gambler, might wanna hit up some other casinos.

"An ostensibly salubrious edifice, however, my companions' culinary selections arrived precipitously prior to mine, despite my having placed my order simultaneously with theirs, which led to a considerable delay in satiating my esurient inclinations. Furthermore, I was perplexed by the restaurant's interpretation of'spicy mayo,' which consisted merely of a combination of mayonnaise and sriracha, an unorthodox approach considering the customary manner in which this condiment is prepared; additionally, the 'eel sauce' was mediocre, yet the 'rainbow roll' and 'eel roll' exhibited commendable gastronomical quality, as did my associates' choices â?an 'arizona roll,' a 'crunch roll,' and a 'california shrimp tempura roll.' Notwithstanding, my penchant for sauces remained unsatisfied, as the establishment seemed to be deficient in this particular aspect."

My sister and I headed over here last week and I have to say, I was a little mixed about our visit.

When we first walked in, there was no one there. Literally. We were eye'ing the ice creams for almost 5 minutes before the server drifted in from the Z Pizza side.

I had the Pink Spot sundae with two ginormous scoops of kona coffee and hot fudge. The ice cream was meh, but the hot fudge was very good and served in generous portion. My sister had the low-fat coffee with ribbons of chocolate and she raved.

The prices weren't outrageous considering the serving size; just one week before I spent three dollars more for the same exact thing at Mary Coyle's.

I wasn't overly impressed with the ice cream, but they get props for always having at least one low fat, sugar free, or sorbet offering.

It probably wouldn't be my first choice for ice cream, but because they are in the neighborhood they get a gold star for convenience!

It took me a while to decide whether to give Diablo's 2 or 3 stars.  I decided to go with three since most decent places in Vegas are expensive and at least Diablo's had very yummy food and generous portions.

However, this was the worst service I have ever experienced anywhere...ever.  Our server, on the rare occasion she stopped by, was straight-up rude.  She was so rude it seemed like it had to be intentional- she even got frustrated with my friend just because she wanted fresh cheese on her nachos instead of both fresh and creamy/processed cheese.  The waitress sighed loudly and said in an irritated voice, "It's NOT going to taste the same" and shook her head when my friend explained that she's never liked that kind of "fake" cheese.  She also grumpily said, "Well, what do you want?" when she came to take our order.  No hello, no eye contact, nothing.

It also took at least 30 minutes for our orders to be taken even though the restaurant wasn't very busy, another 90+ minutes before our food showed up, and another 30+ minutes to get the check.  What was supposed to be a quick bite to eat for 5 of us turned into a 3-hour ordeal.

1 star for service
5 stars for food
2.5 stars for value

I've been to The Joint 3 times--once in the old Joint and twice in the newer, enlarged Joint.

For the current Joint, the flow of people in and out was well designed but I wonder why they didn't install a reversible escalator so part of the crown could go downstairs that way and the rest by stairs.

For this concert of KISS, I got balcony seating.  I liked it better than floor seating because I found the floor seating to be very tightly packed next to each other.  The balcony on the other hand had theatre style seats that were comfortable.

The sound and lighting in the Joint are exceptional.  Needless to say, KISS had a lot of pyro effects and the lighting was great.  It would be nice if they could have raised the catwalk.  It was in the way for some of the stage viewing.

There aren't too many shows that I would go here to see but if I went again, I'd try to get a table seat on the side balconies.

As a tip, park in the Paradise garage for easy access to the Joint.

Forget the casino where your wallet takes a pounding, this is where your body takes punishment. But look at yourself in the mirror, man, you did it to yourself. Leg of lamb, prime rib, wild boar, kalbi ribs, spicy shrimp, mac-n-cheese, gnocchi, cheeses, salads, breads, and then the... OK stuff, which is too much too mention. Eye in the sky sees you eating like a gluttonous pig. Pace self with sanctity. #foodslut

This place had its ups and downs. The atmosphere is lovely , very old school great for a date at night. The food is ok depending on what you get, kinda pricey. And nothing outstanding for the price either. Portions I think are big or at least enough to share.\n The main thing with this place is the service, I wanted to give 2 1/2 stars. The service is just slow, inconsistent and dreadful. By the time we got our food we didn't care and just wanted to leave. A formal complaint was actually made at the end.\n Save this place to try on a busy date night when they got something going on and it might be worth it. I don't suggest coming here for a quick lunch or entirely for food itself. It has location, a vtg vegas feel atmosphere and I don't drink but it also has booze too. However just for the food and the service alone would not be worth the trip.

Decent bubble tea, surly service.  Got a ginger milk tea and asked what type of jelly they have (Didn't see any selections on the menu or on the board).  The woman at the register gave me a really dirty and annoyed look, and said \"What type are you looking for???\".... Not sure why that would cause such annoyance?  Anyways, my ginger milk tea with lychee jelly was OK, a bit too mild for me (just a hint of ginger flavor), and a bit too sweet.  Plus, it was WARM in there!  Please put the A/C on!  (Maybe that's why the cashier was so surly, I would be grumpy in such a warm store too if I had to be in there all the time!)

"Procured two chocolate croissants and a single miniature cake, yet was confronted with an unfortunate dearth of chocolate within said pastries, the paltry quantity of which failed to satiate my craving for a rich, velvety chocolate experience, thereby necessitating the expenditure of an additional 2-3 dollars for a croissant of sufficient chocolaty flavor."

Mr. Lucky's does not possess any extraordinary attributes or distinguishing features, with the exception of their covertly offered $7.77 Special, which comprises a triumvirate of savory elements, including a fresh garden salad, succulent steak, and delectable shrimp, all served in conjunction with a generous portion of creamy mashed potatoes, thereby providing a gratifying dining experience at an eminently reasonable cost, particularly when compared to the prices charged by neighboring establishments, and furthermore, its accessibility is augmented by the fact that it remains open on a continuous basis, twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week, rendering it an ideal refuge for those seeking a satisfying repast during the late hours of the night or early morning, when the majority of other eateries have ceased operation. The rationale behind patronizing Mr. Lucky's resides primarily in the aforementioned $7.77 Special, as evidenced by the preponderance of positive testimonials from contented clientele who have availed themselves of this culinary gem.

Thai Basil is alright, not great but alright. I ordered the Pad-see-ew and the weirdest thing is that the noodles were tasty and delicious but all the veggies and chicken were pretty well tasteless. Plus, my medium to hot dish was much more mild to no spice. 

However, my iced Thai coffee was delicious and the service was very friendly, they even went to find me when I stepped out to Tops while waiting. Also, the the prices are very reasonable, my whole meal was less than 10 bucks.

So, ok for now, I'll try some more dishes and hopefully be more excited.

"It is with profound dismay that I recently traversed past the erstwhile DD establishment, only to be met with an eerie silence and a conspicuous absence of the customary bustling activity that had once been its hallmark, leading me to infer that it has unfortunately succumbed to the pervasive economic downturn and joined the ranks of the innumerable businesses that have fallen prey to the relentless ravages of fiscal instability; a truly lamentable turn of events, indeed."

One word: waterfall.
It makes Tryst amazing... especially in the midst of the swarm of drunkards. There was NO WAY anyone could move around.

My girls and I got invited to a table with bottle service, stayed for a few drinks, then wanted to split... and in turn the guy whose table it was STOLE our purses because we didn't want to stay! We spent the better part of an hour trying to track them down, and eventually a guard gave them back to us.
After asking where they were, he simply stated, "Just be happy you have them back." THEN, one of the guys at the table "coincidentally" had my friend's camera in his pocket.
NOT COOL.

I know this isn't the club's fault, but right after this incident happened my friends and I wanted to get the fuck out of there.

On the other hand, the benefits were that we got right into the clubs, got some of our guy friends in with no charge (rare in Vegas), had fun on the pole and on top of tables, and the outside area with the waterfall was breathtaking.

It's a bit more expensive than some other competing Chinese buffets, but still a hella lot cheaper than anything I can get in New York, so I have no issues.  There's a decent selection and they at least have some sushi and korean food options.  I also like that they have a station to make your own soup with whatever you want in it.  Other than that, everything else is run-of-the-mill chinese food.  I wish they would turn over the fish dishes a little more often so they wouldn't be so overcooked, but it's still edible.

I could tell that they were itching for me and my family to hurry up so they could turn the table over, but I didn't see anyone waiting and there were plenty of other open tables, so I didn't mind taking my time to get my money's worth.

I'd go back if I had to, but wouldn't necessarily go out of my way.

I've been here for the weekend brunch on a few occasions, and for the price, really can't be beat. If you are a local take advantage of a super cheap meal on Mondays and Wednesdays: $3.99 for breakfast, $4.99 for lunch, and $6.99 for dinner. All you have to do is show your Hilton rewards card and local id. 
 
The weekend brunch has crab legs, prime rib, and beer/wine or some days champagne for either the weekend brunch or dinner. There is all the classic breakfast items already made and then a made-to-order omelet station along with grilled meats and sausages. All pretty much traditional buffet food, nothing fancy or ethnic, but solid. 
 
18 bucks for prime rib, cocktail shrimp, and crab legs is a deal...take advantage of it if you are looking for a decent weekend brunch buffet but can't pay for one at the Wynn or Bellagio. Service might not be 100 percent, but come on it's a friggin buffet.

Kinda like a family Italian joint but too bright inside. Food is good enough for what it is and service is sufficient. Food is a 6 on a scale of 1 to 10. Not great not bad. Cutesy place with an \"almost\" feel. Experience it for yourself. You will understand what I mean.

You don't really have to twist my arm to get to me to try a restaurant where pork prepared in any way is the main attraction.  So, when my husband and I had a chance to get away for a meal, I naturally chose Salty Sow.  I wish that I could talk about the wonderful dishes that I had, but they were all only okay.  I had the candied pork belly.  I guess in my head I pictures something somewhat crispy.  I was very wrong.  It's a braised dish.  It's not a bad dish, just not something I would convince me to come back again.

My husband had the lamb burger and I had to sample.  It was pretty good if you enjoy tapenade. It's not really for me.  

Service was good up until we asked for the check.  It felt like a lifetime before it finally arrived, and then it was wrong.

Overall, it was an okay experience.

"Although we conceded that the noodles were somewhat overcooked, it was our expectation that the vegetables would be fresher, rather than frozen, which unfortunately did not align with our preferences. Notwithstanding, it remains worthy of an attempt, yet it fell short of our anticipated standards, particularly when juxtaposed with other build-your-own wok houses we have visited in various locales."

I have had the privilege of firing an assortment of firearms (for further information, please visit http://www.yelp.com/biz/bullseye-precision-indoor-shooting-range-san-rafael), which includes the Uzi, Thompson, and two other automatic weapons, as well as a desert eagle handgun. Additionally, I had the opportunity to discharge a grenade launcher, albeit with a shotgun shell rather than an actual grenade, at a cost of $35 per round. It is worth mentioning that the weapons appeared somewhat worn out, and the ear protection provided by the establishment was inadequate, causing discomfort to my auditory senses throughout the duration of my visit. Notwithstanding, I would suggest this venue as a suitable destination for a group of individuals seeking a diversion from the typical gambling activities, and perhaps even consider renting a limousine for transportation purposes, as securing a taxi back to one's lodgings may prove challenging.

"The sibling of my spouse and his consort were temporarily residing in our city and expressed a desire to partake of the culinary offerings at RigaTony's, as they had a acquaintance who frequently visits the establishment and speaks highly of it. My spouse and I had not indulged in a meal at this particular venue for an extended period of time, primarily due to the fact that we have been frequenting Olive Garden, largely owing to the fact that I acquire gift cards valued at twenty-five dollars through my professional endeavors. However, upon experiencing the delectable fare provided by RigaTony's, it shall undoubtedly become our preferred dining destination when we are financially independent and seeking a satisfying repast and salad. The marginally elevated cost per menu item is more than justified by the superior quality of the cuisine. Personally, I opted for the poultry dish infused with lemon and artichoke, which I found to be utterly delectable. Their house salad is also quite impressive, and one of my associates from my bunco group customarily orders it when she has the opportunity to act as hostess. My spouse not only appreciated the bread accompanying the salad but also relished the lasagna he selected as his main course...up until a later point in the evening when he experienced a sudden onset of severe acid reflux. Unfortunately, the natural consequences of aging can be rather unpleasant. Despite my persistent efforts to persuade him otherwise, my stubborn companion refused to sample my crystallized ginger remedy, which has proven to be remarkably effective in alleviating such digestive issues. Instead, he elected to forgo this potential solution. Following our satisfying dining experience, we decided to conclude the evening with a visit to Angel Sweet, where we indulged in an assortment of delectable treats."

This place is showing its age. I went to see Avatar in their Imax theater and the seats were pretty banged up and the movie crapped out as it was starting due to some technical difficulties. It took a good 10-15 minutes before they fixed the problem and restarted the movie. I do have to say that as far as movie theater food goes, their hot dog and nachos are decent.

"The sushi exhibited an unexpected level of culinary excellence, surpassing my preconceived notions of its quality. However, the remaining items on the menu failed to impress, with their flavors and presentation falling short of my expectations. Despite this disparity, the establishment's maintenance of cleanliness and proficient service remained commendable. Although it does not compare to a luxurious five-star dining experience, my visit was significantly more enjoyable than that of the previous patrons. Considering the vast array of options available, I would unhesitatingly endorse this venue for large gatherings, particularly those comprising children."

"The visual spectacle was captivating, as the female performers exhibited their proficiency in dance, but it appeared that the screenwriters had indulged in some form of substance when conceptualizing the narrative, while Mickey, among the actors, was the most entertaining."

So-so Mexican food.  I have heard people raving about this place and I don't really get it.  Don't get me wrong, it's better than Manuel's or Filiberto's... but that's about all I can say.

Okay, their Pollo Fundido is good (but not great like you will get at Ajo Al's). But let's talk about the purple and teal accent colors that scream "I was remodeled in the 80's"! Lame.

Good chips and salsa but small-ass bowls! 

Oh, and don't expect to park in their little lot during dinner rush.  Also, the surrounding neighborhood is definatly the ghetto-side of the Moon Valley area.

So I recently went here with a friend of mine because they were craving IHOP, and I didn't care were we went to eat as long is it had food.

I got one of there new healthy choice menu items the balsamic chicken and my friend got the club sandwich with a side salad and a side of pancakes...don't ask.

The food was surprisingly really good and the service was excellent.

Some people will be upset with this review, but when we are asked to write a review, Yelp wants us to be honest right? 
Finally tried out Hash House a go go for lunch yesterday. Had read great reviews and many a celebrity have endorsed it. 
The interior is great and the service is pretty good too. That is why I gave Hash 3 stars, but the food did not appeal that much to me and I consider it forgetable.
I tried the mushroom and goat cheese sandwich and have no complaints about my dish, The potatoes au gratin looked very cheesy, but tasted good as the cheese wasn't not all overpowering as I had expected. My wife tried the chicken and waffles and we both agreed: nothing special! The all white meat chicken and waffles were both too dry and bland and we prefer Roscoe's for sure.  
For the average 'white' person, this food probably tastes great, the presentation looked above par, but for those among us who consider themselves foodies, the wide gamut of Asian food offered in this city is soo much more appealing. And finally their lunch prices are a little high at $38 for two. Again, this is just my honest opinion.

My uncle possesses an eating establishment specializing in barbecued meats that enjoys a certain degree of renown in Memphis, Tennessee; thus, I habitually approach barbecue-related culinary experiences with a heightened sense of skepticism and critical scrutiny. Although my sampling of their offerings has been limited to a pair of sandwiches - specifically, the pulled pork and barbecue chicken breast varieties - I must admit that both exhibited commendable quality, extending even to the bread upon which they were served, which was satisfyingly tasteful without being excessively substantial. However, I did notice the absence of chopped egg in the potato salad accompaniment, a detail that struck me as somewhat conspicuous. Furthermore, my visual perception was tantalized by the delectable appearance of certain dessert items borne by fellow patrons, which unfortunately remained beyond my epicurean reach. Ultimately, the veritable litmus test for any barbecue venue lies in its proficiency in preparing ribs, an item I intend to sample during a future visit, at which point I shall furnish an updated assessment. Until then, I bid you adieu, with the expectation that you will indeed return at some point in the future.
This is a great, quality Taco Bell recently built with fast service and consistant food. I love Taco Bell because it's cheap and yummy!

Really great atmosphere, wines, etc... but I didn't think the food was very good, so I give it only 3 stars.  The bread is very thick and maybe uncooked, no oil.  It was not what I expected.  I was hoping for crunchy bread with creatively delicious toppings.  The toppings are great combinations, just not executed like I expected.  I thought the bruschetta would be warm, but instead it was cold, nothing melded, and the bread was very large.  Great concept, but I don't get all the great reviews.

"Fundamental victuals, devoid of any extraordinary attributes, yet still managed to tantalize our taste buds with their inherent flavors. A concise culinary catalog, featuring a roster of familiar favorites, albeit lacking in diversity, particularly in regards to the vinous offerings, which failed to include such esteemed Italian varietals as Montepulciano or other customary options. Instead, an assortment of ubiquitous, entry-level vintages were presented, rendering the overall experience somewhat predictable, yet surprisingly satisfying, given its proximity to a well-known thrift store."

This only gets three stars cause the food is amazing! Other then great tasting food, place is very confusing. When you walk in there is a line that no one has any idea what line they are in. The first two are for tacos, but if you want a burrito or fish tacos you have to go to another line.  They tell you to go there but then you pass 10 people and I feel like I'm cutting everyone in line.

Everyone stood and looked at each and was  like what line are we in? Once you get to that line your suppose to be in, they don't speak English.  I ordered a carne asade burrito, and they tried to give it to someone else. I told them that's mine and he said ohhhh, and had to open it, but looked at me weird cause he did not speak English!

I would give them a 1 star but the food is amazing! Great prices too! Just really confusing.  We also came on a Tuesday night and damn if there wasent 50 kids running around up and down making a ton of noise!

"If you peruse my Yelp reviews thus far, you will discover that the vast majority of them focus on barbecue establishments. Indeed, we possess an affinity for barbecue. My spouse and I each have a sibling residing in Austin, Texas, thereby enabling us to boast a comprehensive understanding of the authentic variety. Dickey's may not entirely embody the genuine article, but it constitutes a welcome addition to Madison's barbecue scene, and I sincerely hope it endures.  

The meats exhibit a palpable smoky flavor and tenderness, although they are occasionally overcooked. This phenomenon can be attributed to the fact that fast-food/fast-casual establishments like Dickey's may not smoke their meats in-house daily. Instead, they might be smoked off-site and subsequently transported. However, given the affordable pricing, this compromise proves acceptable. The ribs and brisket warrant ordering. The chicken, on the other hand, consists of a grilled breast that can be obtained from any run-of-the-mill eatery.  

The sauces, available in both original and spicy varieties, are presented at a piping hot temperature, much like their Texan counterparts. Their texture adheres to the thinner, characteristic Texas consistency, which I find appealing. Additionally, the opportunity to embellish your meal with jalapenos and onions exemplifies a further Texas-inspired element. Unfortunately, the smoked sausage fails to live up to its Texan counterpart. The slaw and potato salad qualify as adequate sides, while the remaining options prove unremarkable.  

Dickey's offers complimentary soft-serve ice cream, allowing discerning patrons to concoct a root beer float within their ample yellow drink containers. On Sundays, children can partake in a complimentary meal alongside each adult entree purchased. Upon departing, we generally experience feelings of satisfaction. Given the reasonable prices below $20, what more could one reasonably expect?"

We have been patronizing the Dragon Noodle for an extensive period of time, and our experiences have been rather inconsistent. While the culinary offerings are generally satisfactory, the prices are somewhat elevated and the service is merely adequate. In concurrence with certain fellow Yelpers, we have found that the ambiance in the rear section of the establishment tends to be somewhat melancholy. Prior to the renovation, the atmosphere was more convivial, with kitschy embellishments and souvenir t-shirts available for purchase. 
  Following a prolonged day at a trade exhibition, we seek to unwind and avoid venturing excessively far from our lodgings. The Dragon Noodle is rarely crowded, thereby enabling us to secure a table for any size gathering with minimal difficulty. 
  Our preferences lean towards the Chinese menu, as the sushi options appear overly pricey and our previous experiences with them have been underwhelming. Specifically, we enjoy the Kung Pao Chicken, Mongolian Beef, and Wonton Soup. During a recent visit by a group of six, the total cost was approximately $140.

I dined here on a recent trip to Vegas.

I had the Kobe beef sliders.  They were ok, but not worth the $13 I paid for them.  (Side note:  My friend almost got sick from eating them because they were too rich for her liking.)  I also had their Shichimi fries.  Those were good - nice & spicy.  Also had some Yukon Gold mashers, and those were good too.

They poured decent cocktails.  

I would probably go here again next time I go to Vegas if I am hungry and in the area.

Came here for a networking event a couple weeks ago. They had some apps out to try and my friend ordered the quesadilla that was on happy hour. Nothing remarkable about this place food wise. I ordered a moscow mule and it was good.

We were outside on the patio which is super cute. Definitely a great place to have some wine and sit outside and enjoy the perfect weather. 

I need to try the main dishes because I wasn't that impressed with the food we had. We tried their chicken wings, ahi avocado salad of some sort, flatbread and parmesan, and then my frriend's quesadilla. It wasn't that the food was bad, it's just not something that I'm ever gonna think about and be like "hey, remember xyz at Kitchen 56?". 

Worth a shot to try but it's just whatever.

One shouldn't expect too much from restaurants centered around the main touristy drag of a city. I've found that these restaurants are typically expensive and low on service but that might just be me.

We started with a tasty platter of cheeses which included four local cheeses I forget the names of. Except for brie, all others were new and I quite enjoyed them, especially the goat cheese variant.

We had a variety of mains. I got the pasta Arrabbiata(don't know why I order that dish), and it was expectedly very ordinary. Others in our group got mussels and a quarter chicken respectively. Overall the portions were decent and the food was A-OK.

I invariably proceed directly to the gold check-in area, as I possess the esteemed status of Hertz Gold Member, thereby allowing me to bypass the conventional queue. My experiences at this location have been inconsistent, vacillating between exceptional and subpar. On occasion, the automobile I have requested is readily available, awaiting my prompt acquisition, while on other occasions, I have been provided with vehicles exhibiting excessive mileage, cosmetic damage, or unsightly decals. Furthermore, the representatives adhere meticulously to the stipulation that the fuel tank must be brimful, which has led me to refuel adjacent to the airport terminal. It is crucial to scrutinize the vehicle thoroughly before accepting it and, if necessary, request an alternative, ensuring that any issues are addressed. Additionally, verifying the tire tread's integrity is essential. In spite of these occasional drawbacks, the gold service proves advantageous, particularly when juxtaposed against the lengthy wait times often encountered at the standard counter.

Today, I was rushing from one place to another and needed some fast food.  Not feeling like a burger, I thought that Panda Express sounded convenient.  I was not disappointed though at the same time, the meal was not a gourmet one either.  There was only one person working the register while at the same time serving food so there was a bit of a wait (and the staff member was a bit flustered with much going on at once).  I am guessing that another staff member was on a break as there was a second person there by the time I left.  The restaurant was also kept quite clean though it appeared that the forks and napkins needed some restocking.  \n\nThe food, however, was fresh and as tasty as I had hoped it would be.  I got a two-item combo with fried rice, beef & broccoli, and string bean chicken.  I also added on a chicken egg roll.  The restaurant had several families, a few people on their own, and a couple all also eating, and it appeared that everyone else was also pleased with their meals.

Sep 25 2011 2:10 pm

1 item lunch combo -$5.50
Comes with soup, entree, appetizer 

Red curry- 3/5 little too oily for a Thai dish
Garlic and pepper stir fry -3.5/5

2 Thai iced tea- 4.5/5

Customer service- 4.5/5

Stopped in here for lunch today, joined by Arlin B, Robyn N & Mike C.  Scott's was a bit of a disappointment for me this time.  My expensive bowl of Kreplach Soup was lukewarm & only contained one little Kreplach the size of a Ping Pong ball!  Even the smaller cup sized soup should have two or three of them.  My corned beef sandwich was good but the service was only so-so.  Considering all of this and the prices, it's down to 3 Stars this time for Scott's.\n\nCorned Beef Sandwich $10.95, bowl of Kreplach Soup $7.95 (!)

I was drove past there this weekend, and then read yesterday on azcentral.com that they have closed their doors.  I had never dined there but the building & decor looks awesome, huge outdoor patio with a glass enclosed fireplace, guess it's just another sign of the struggling economy....

"Perhaps it was the prolonged duration of my journey that induced a state of bewilderment, rendering me incapable of navigating the labyrinthine corridors of the terminal, thereby necessitating a circuitous route to the exit; however, upon encountering the high-velocity tram, I experienced a momentary cognitive dissonance that hindered my ability to comprehend its functionality, leading me to erroneously assume that it would impede my progress. Despite this minor setback, I must commend the airport staff for their cordial demeanor and the meticulous upkeep of the facilities. While it may not boast the same level of grandeur as Portland International Airport, it remains a serviceable and efficient transportation hub."

My coworker recommended this place so I decided to give it a try. I had the Gyro lunch with fries. It was pretty good, nothing outrageous and I've definitely had better but given the area and it's limited lunch options I can see myself coming back here in the future.\n\nThe restaurant was small and service was friendly. The \"bar\" was awkward; looked like it didn't really belong but I guess it's always great to have the option of enjoying a drink with your meal. I guess I see this more of a quick service dine and dash kind of joint, that's why.

I'm reviewing my rating. After Mor telling me i had to wait for them to come inspect the table (i'm moving dont have time for this) and i left my review, i ended up getting a call the next day from a manager & they actually delivered a brand new table, said the old one turned out to be from a bad batch- 

So overall i'm NOW happy with the customer service- and i'll take their word that it was a bad batch and not bad quality overall.



Old Review: Bought a dinning room granite countertop table from here, within 6 months the legs are cracking, the marble actually stains real easy from heat. Absolute garbage, $800 wasted

I ordered a spider roll, a lobster roll and Uni. The rolls tastes delicious, especially a spider roll. A fried soft crab in the roll was fresh and crispy. But for Uni, it tasted fishy, not fresh when I had it. Maybe you have to ask a waiter about its quality before order it.

It wasn't horrible. The girl seemed like she couldn't be bothered and wanted to be else were. The guy was trying to be impressive with all his different topics. He was be over bearing and ignoying  to me. I wasn't  impressed by his conversations.\n\nThey job they did was standard.

"Although I harbor a certain skepticism towards public car washes as a whole, my recent visit to Classic Car Spa proved to be a refreshing exception to this rule. Not only were there an absence of streaks or droplets on my windows, but also the meticulous attention devoted to buffing the rims of my BMW left me feeling truly satisfied. Opting for the comprehensive package, which encompassed a thorough cleaning of both the vehicle's exterior and interior, I was impressed by the staff's fastidiousness. It is worth mentioning that my modest Z4 happened to be the most economical automobile in the queue, surrounded by an array of luxury SUVs, a Porsche Panamera, and even a Maserati. Such an assemblage of high-end vehicles served as a poignant reminder that, were I able to afford the latter, I likely would have had the means to engage the services of a professional detailer to come to my residence and pamper my car for me."

I am originally from NYC, where the Chinese food reigns supreme... and when I moved out here it was hard to find anything that was even remotely close to good.... While China Red is still not NYC amazing Chinese food, it definitely comes close. The portions are nice and big, the flavors are great, and the egg drop soup is fab! They offer lunch specials, which are hard to beat since the price is about $6 for 2 meals worth food :) PLUS, they deliver, which is hard to find out here in AZ!

We visited this past Sunday and had an enjoyable experience overall, with the exception of the culinary offerings, which were not only unpalatable but also exorbitantly priced. Hence, I am compelled to express my dissatisfaction via this review. In light of this, I would strongly advise against purchasing any sustenance within the park and instead recommend splurging an additional $10 for priority parking, thereby enabling you to bring your own provisions. This strategy not only ensures a more satisfying dining experience but also allows you to save money, as the cost of two slices of pizza and a couple of breadsticks was a whopping $14.

"SSSSSsssssshhhhhhhhhhh.............. DON'T TELL ANYONE. I have an affinity for Hooters. 

Consequently, allow me to elaborate on the narrative: We had reserved a remarkable bargain at the Hilton; however, it was merely for two nights. We required a place to stay for our final night in Las Vegas and desired a cost-effective and proximate location to the airport due to our extremely early departure. Hooters corresponded to our requirements. Positioned at the southernmost point of the strip, the taxi ride to McCarran is relatively brief. Although it lacks luxury, there are affordable rooms available, and the staff member at the registration desk was incredibly cordial. We requested a nonsmoking king room situated on a higher floor, and he accommodated us with an impressive panorama of the Tropicana, Excalibur, and the roller coaster at New York New York. The lodging was fundamental, yet acceptable. 

We traversed the street to the MGM for the majority of the day. 

Later in the evening, we returned to the Hooters Casino, and surprisingly, we experienced immense enjoyment! The minimum wagers are minimal, permitting a genuine sense of recreation. The ambiance is more relaxed compared to the high-stakes casinos, and the clientele is youthful, eliminating the pressure to be a seasoned player. Frankly, I am not a dedicated gambler, nor would I desire to be, so the environment at Hooters aligned perfectly with my preferences."

Bacchanal's culinary offerings are satisfactory, boasting an array of diverse stations that cater to various gastronomic inclinations. However, it is worth mentioning that nothing particularly extraordinary or memorable was encountered during my visit, with the exception of the unique dessert options such as the orange beer sorbet and mango habanero gelato, which exhibited a distinct departure from the norm and possessed a palpable fiery quality. 
The crab leg offerings, both hot and cold, were adequate, benefiting from the convenience of being plated for ease of consumption and limiting the potential for overindulgence by fellow patrons. Unfortunately, the absence of dungeness crab was a notable disappointment. The prime rib and lamb chops, while satisfying, failed to leave a lasting impression, with the latter being slightly saltier than expected. Noteworthy mentions include the flavorsome Chinese chicken wings, though marred by a perceptible excess of sodium, and the unimpressive oysters, whose lack of freshness was readily apparent to seasoned consumers. To avoid prolonged waiting times, it is advisable to visit during off-peak hours, with seating times ranging from 30 to 45 minutes.

"This critique pertains to the Tiffany Showroom and its latest production, 'Yesterday - A Tribute to the Beatles.' The showroom's interior boasts three distinct levels, each offering a unique seating arrangement. The uppermost tier features individual chairs and a smattering of diminutive round tables, while the middle level is appointed with banquettes and chairs. Lastly, the floor level offers an array of seating options, including two rows of banquettes and several minuscule table settings. The stage, of considerable proportions, benefits from exceptional acoustics and illumination, courtesy of the meticulous planning that has gone into this homage. The performance itself is characterized by the vocal prowess and instrumental proficiency of the male cast members, who excel when harmonizing. However, during solo passages, the sound deviates slightly from the iconic Beatles' sonic signature, albeit momentarily. The duration of the show approximates sixty minutes, leaving this reviewer with a desire to assign a rating midway between three and four stars, given the minor inconsistencies in the performance."

Indulge Burger is a fun place to stop & grab a bite.

They are a dog friendly place, with water bowls outside in the patio area.  We first started coming here when a coupon appeared in our mail box, and we've been back every few months.  

The food is generally good and they have a wide degree of choices.  The sweet potato fries, onion strings, and the garlic chips are great.  The burgers are in the $10 to $14 dollar range.  But they are very large one half of pound burgers.  That's why it important to remember to check for coupons before you come.  

I just noticed after posting the above review that there is a current "Yelp Deals -- $15 for $30 Deal at Indulge Burgers & More"

The Cajun Queen is a really nice neighborhood restaurant for me. The service is consistently good especially in the bar. I love the atmosphere and the live Dixieland jazz is a wonderful plus.\n\nWhat troubles me now and has troubled me from the first time I started going to the CQ : it seems like the kitchen believes everything must be really hot (spicy) since it's a Cajun restaurant. But some things just shouldn't be hot. Tonight I ordered the crawfish scampi appetizer. Scampi is generally shellfish flavored with garlic and herbs. Red pepper flakes are sometimes added but not as a predominant flavor. The CQ  added so much chili that it overpowered the crawfish. There is not a lot of difference between the scampi and etouffee which is supposed to be hot. If they would just not be so heavy-handed with the Cajun spices.....

The food is pretty good for a chain restaurant.  The prices are very reasonable and portions are huge.  I ordered the Chicken Katsu with a side of gravy fries...hit the spot!  Katsu curry had corn in it; guess that's Hawaiian style? Fires were the best, but only mediocre, would be better if gravy had more richness to it.  It's not the best I've ever had but far from the worst.\n\n-I'm still really confused as to why they don't redecorate.  The entire outside and interior resembles a 50's diner...it's been like this since they opened and hasn't changed.  It would be more comfortable if they could change the decor and clean it up a bit; the right side of the restaurant has been under renovations for some time now and looks really shabby.

This establishment was situated at a considerable distance from the location where my acquaintance resided (West Side), necessitating an arduous journey to arrive there. However, the culinary experience was well worth the effort, despite the fact that the venue was crowded during the luncheon period. The eatery maintained a high level of cleanliness, and the preparation time for the dishes was surprisingly swift, even when considering the large number of patrons present. On days when the temperature rose significantly, it was possible to take a seat outside beneath the misters; however, as an individual hailing from California, I found the heat in Arizona to be excessive, even when taking advantage of the cooling effects provided by the misters.

Food: The Fontina burger, topped with blue cheese, was remarkably fresh and bursting with flavor. The juiciness of the burger was complemented perfectly by the addition of the blue cheese, which greatly enhanced its overall taste. I appreciated the diverse options available for selecting side dishes. Unfortunately, the garlic fries were excessively oily, which detracted slightly from their appeal. Nonetheless, the beet salad offered a delightful and revitalizing contrast. Although the strawberry cheesecake, which was prepared from scratch and not listed on the menu, was merely adequate, it was still a pleasant surprise. Additionally, the fried okra was overcooked to a degree that rendered it unpalatable. On the other hand, the BBQ pork sandwich appeared delectable, and my companion expressed great satisfaction with their meal.

In conclusion, I thoroughly enjoyed the culinary offerings and would highly recommend paying a visit to this establishment.

This review is for the upstairs:

I give this place a resounding "meh."  Got the $75 tasting menu and while some of the dishes were pretty good (pork belly, salmon, beef tartare), most of them were entirely forgettable.

But the worst part was our server, hell-bent on up-selling us to death.  He actually told us that the 5 course tasting menu was "just a jumping off point," before encouraging us to start our meal with 24 oysters, and insert several ounces of wagyu beef into the meal.  I kid you not.  It was pretty annoying.

Overall, there are many many better places to spend your money in Vegas.

One of my staples for my old school Vegas days. I used to come here a LOT, because I could charge everything on the room and it wouldn't be TOO expensive. Had breakfast the other day...quite a good version of the standard staple of Steak and Eggs.  Minus a star for it being $20 though....this is Vegas, its only supposed to be $9.99.  \n\nI did love that the waitress brought some Heinz 57 though.

I've been to this yard house 3 or 4 times.  I think if I would have written a review the first or even second time, I would have given 4 stars... But, I just don't think it deserves that high of a rating...

The beer selection is fabulous.. Mostly because they have Triple Karmeliet.. my favorite :)  

The food is pretty darn decent too.  Great place to grab a steak and I am a huge fan of the hawiian pizza.  Good is good.

A little on the pricey side if you are planning to stay for awhile.. which is fine, but I don't like to have to spend 100 bucks for a diner and drinks for two.... especially when it's only a couple of drinks.. Boo on that.  Pretty much my only complaint.. I'll get over it though and go back soon I'm sure. :)

Oh, and one las thing, I love the music selection.. Always playing good tunes.

"Indulged in a culinary experience with a valued patron at this establishment for the initial time today, relishing the delectable yellow curry dish of medium piquancy and the pre-prandial soup, albeit the hospitality was somewhat tardy, necessitating a protracted waiting period of sixteen minutes for my primary course to arrive, despite which numerous staff members inquired about the possibility of replenishing my beverage."

3 1/2 STARS

This is Marriott's TIME-SHARE complex across from their luxury hotel. We traded a time-share for a week here in May. I must say, the place was packed - it appeared to be fully occupied.

Our room was small but just fine for us. The employees were all friendly and the grounds were kept in good shape.

We found this to be a good place to use as a base for a week's holiday while taking day-trips to the Grand Canyon, Sedona, Prescott, Scottsdale, the Phoenix Botanical Garden, and so on...

"Upon entering this establishment, I was immediately struck by the pungent aroma of chemicals, which served as a harbinger of the ubiquitous fumes that would accompany my visit. Following the standard protocol, I was invited to select my preferred hue from an array of options, after which I was gestured towards the specific seat designated for my accommodation. The staff, though limited in their proficiency of the English language, endeavored to establish a rapport with me through their cordial smiles and halting attempts at conversation. The ensuing experience was one of unremarkable familiarity, as the service was neither exceptional nor deficient, but rather fell within the realm of the mundane. Notwithstanding this, the salon did boast an impressive array of color options, which served as a modest source of consolation. Furthermore, the staff demonstrated a commendable level of proficiency in their attention to detail regarding my cuticles, which distinguished them from their peers. Ultimately, the combination of their adequate performance, comparable pricing, and congenial demeanor led me to conclude that a return visit would not be unwarranted."

If Spearmint Rhino and Treasures were siblings then Spearmint Rhino would be Charlie Sheen and Treasures would be Emilio Estevez. Spearmint Rhino is a lot more fun with a lot more going on. Treasures is small and booooooring. Bottle service is a lot cheaper though.

My family and I serendipitously encountered this establishment while perusing the retail offerings in Townsquare, and upon entering, we were immediately captivated by the aesthetically pleasing ambiance. Our attention was graciously captured by an exceptional waitress who informed us that the duration of the happy hour was rapidly approaching its culmination, with only twelve minutes remaining until the prices would increase exponentially. In light of this information, we unanimously decided to expedite our order, ensuring that we could partake in the discounted beverages prior to their transformation into double the original cost. However, much to our dismay, the bar manager, Jessica, declined our request, maintaining that the designated time frame for happy hour had already elapsed. Despite this setback, we opted to continue dining at this location, investing $160.00 in delectable cuisine that thoroughly satiated our palates. The impeccable service we received further enhanced our dining experience, yet unfortunately, the actions of Jessica left an indelible impression, precluding us from future visits. As an ardent patron, I habitually demonstrate loyalty towards establishments that cater to my preferences, frequently returning with my acquaintances and loved ones; regrettably, the $18 saved does not justify the relinquishment of our custom.

This minuscule canine recreational area, confined to a singular expanse of land adjacent to a baseball field, presents a rather limited scope for canine exercise and socialization, which, in conjunction with its questionable maintenance, renders it an inferior choice for discerning dog owners seeking a suitable venue for their pets. Despite the occasional visit from myself and my spouse during our tenure in the vicinity, the dearth of upkeep and the recent, albeit ineffectual, "renovation" have rendered this park somewhat disappointing, particularly in light of the presence of more well-appointed facilities in the surrounding area. Notwithstanding, its proximity to my place of employment shall continue to facilitate my patronage, though an inclination towards alternative, superior destinations persists.

I had unwittingly traversed past this unassuming edifice numerous times prior to discovering the enchanting experience awaiting within. Upon entering the establishment at approximately 9 pm on a Friday evening, I was immediately struck by the captivating sight of ducks and turtles leisurely gliding through the water, thereby creating an idyllic atmosphere that was further accentuated by the presence of amorous couples occupying the alfresco seating area. An elderly gentleman was serenading the patrons with soulful Spanish ballads while skillfully strumming his guitar, thus adding to the already romantic ambiance of El Encanto. The portal leading to this hidden gem seemed to be shrouded in secrecy, and I couldn't help but feel a sense of gratification upon having stumbled upon such an undiscovered treasure.

As for the culinary offerings, I opted to share the pollo fundido with my companion. Although it failed to elicit an overwhelming impression, primarily due to the fact that X Tapa Joe's rendition remains unparalleled in my opinion, the accompanying yellow rice was truly exceptional. Typically, my expectations for the customary dry and lackluster Mexican rice are not particularly high; however, the variant presented at El Encanto was conspicuously distinct, boasting a delightful combination of moisture and rich flavors that closely mirrored the yellow rice I personally prepare. While the margaritas were somewhat too saccharine for my taste, they remained passable. In general, I found the establishment to be an ideal setting for an intimate escapade, steeped in an aura of romance that warranted a three-star rating. My desire to sample additional menu items still lingers, as I am eager to assess their full gastronomical prowess and potentially elevate my appraisal.

Although the food, wine, and atmosphere are all good, sadly I must say I have been let down. One of my problems is the sometimes slow service. Also we decided to go here for a friends birthday and they ran out of food. It was not fun feeling like you had the angel of death for a server ready to kill your order. I really would love to give the place four stars, because the food and wine are certainly worth it, but due to my traumatic experience its just a-ok. Maybe I will get a chance to go back and update my review to what I know it really could be.

I'm local and saw part of the infomercial and decided to try the place. Club card benefits are average except when you first sign up. I like smaller casinos and this has a good mix of new & older machines. I didn't win much but my spouse had good luck. We used coupons to eat at the deli and liked the food. I had the breakfast special & spouse had a burger. The burger was tasty, tomatoes & lettuce fresh and the fries were really fresh & hot. You can't do much harm to eggs, toasted muffin & sausage and it was good. \nWe'll go back & see if it's consistent.

"On a Tuesday (December 18, 2012), we embarked upon a culinary excursion to an Italian eatery in Edinburgh, which, regrettably, did not live up to our expectations in terms of gastronomic excellence. Despite the presence of some delectable antipasti, the crostini unfortunately exhibited a discernible staleness, thus somewhat diminishing our overall satisfaction. However, the pork belly proved to be a redeeming factor, boasting tenderness and flavor, while the roast potatoes were cooked to perfection, earning them high praise. Unfortunately, the chocolate tart that followed left much to be desired, as its richness bordered on overwhelming. Notwithstanding the shortcomings in the food department, the ambiance of the establishment exuded a certain charm and appeal, rendering it an enjoyable experience for all. Nevertheless, in light of the middling quality of the fare, it remains uncertain whether a return visit would be warranted, especially when considering the abundance of superior, family-run establishments in the vicinity, such as Nonna's in Morningside, which undoubtedly outshine their competitors in terms of sheer excellence."

"It constitutes a sizable storage establishment, boasting an array of diverse unit sizes. The premises are relatively well-maintained. In light of my requirement for storing documents, I opted for the smallest available unit. The administrative staff appears to be cordial and competent. Notwithstanding, I have certain reservations pertaining to the considerable amount of dust that manages to infiltrate the units, as well as the considerable distance between the facility and my domicile. Improved entranceways with enhanced dust-proofing capabilities would be a worthwhile investment."

"As I embarked upon my journey through the bustling streets of downtown Chandler, I chanced upon a singular establishment that piqued my curiosity; a freestanding edifice housing none other than a Jimmy John's franchise. This particular venue boasted an unprecedented distinction - it was the first of its kind that I had ever laid eyes on. 

The menu offered the customary array of delectable items associated with the esteemed sandwich chain, albeit at a marginally lower price point (approximately fifty cents less) in comparison to the Chandler Fashion Center location. My affection for Jimmy John's notwithstanding, I felt compelled to deduct a half-star from my overall rating due to the multitude of distractions that permeated the interior of the store. 

Upon entering the premises, I was struck by the striking similarity to a typical high school cafeteria. Staff members vociferously engaged in banter, their voices raised to an earsplitting volume, while the ambiance was further heightened by the blaring music. Such an environment made it challenging to fully appreciate the culinary experience. 

We have all, at some point in our lives, cherished memories of our formative years spent within the hallowed halls of high school. Have we not, dear reader? For instance, who could forget the inimitable Ferris Bueller and his unforgettable exploits?"

I like that Pei Wei will let me get a kids' meal, even though I'm not a kid. 

Truthfully, I need the help with portion control when it comes to rice and sauces and allowing me the kids' meal option makes this one of the first places I think of when I'm looking to satisfy a rice craving -- and, it's definitely the only "guilt-free" place that comes to mind. 

The parking lot here STINKS!! Otherwise, I'd totally give you one more star.

I have been to Toby Keith's a couple of times over the years. The first time was a couple of years ago for a local concert that became ridiculously overcrowded and claustrophobic but I will disregard that initial experience and review only this experience today. I met my mom here for a late lunch around 3pm because we were in the area so it was convenient. Our waitress was really nice and attentive and we wanted to take our time and she didn't have a problem with that.

I ordered a green chili chicken sandwich (with no bun) and a side of coleslaw. My mom had a turkey club sandwich. My chicken was pretty good. It was a little overcooked but it wasn't bad. Nothing to write home about. My mom's turkey club was a HUGE serving and she said it was just okay.

Overall for a midday dining experience we had an okay experience. The food was okay, the service was good. Would I be back? Maybe...

It wasn't spectacular... Started 10-15 minutes late... The Comedian was the highlight of this show... I'm still googling her youtube videos with no luck... Some girls were really pretty but they weren't in sync much...

We arrived at this culinary establishment due to our possession of a Restaurant.com gift certificate, which we utilized with the hope of experiencing a delectable dining experience. Our expectations were moderately met, as the comestibles served were merely satisfactory, with the exception of the taco shells, which were freshly fabricated in-house and displayed an agreeable texture. Unfortunately, the rice was overcooked, resulting in a lackluster consistency. Additionally, the cheese employed in the dish was pre-shredded cheddar, which did not contribute to an authentic Mexican culinary experience. Despite these shortcomings, the meal was relatively inexpensive and fulfilled our hunger.

This place is located in a pretty low end locals casino but with that said it's a fun spot for a quick & hearty breakfast. It's also super cheap! They have a fully stocked bar so having some cocktails with your breakfast is always a good idea. The menu has a little bit of everything but I think the breakfast options are the tastiest. Service is always great as well!

It's so difficult to pick a place to eat in Vegas with the multitude of options. I guess a packed house, like one is sure to see at Mon Ami, is a good sign.

I found the bread to be stellar and a cute display (served as baguette style, as one would find in France; although in France, they don't have paper bags for their baguettes. I'm just sayin'). I had beef bourguignon and I bet even Julia Chiles would be proud of this version. Although, she might have been disappointed by my noodles that were waaaaaaay too soft.

I'm pretty disappointed by my cocktail. How can a French restaurant mess up a French 75? 

The ambiance was nice with the heaters, the music and the Bellagio fountain show. I did feel a bit crowded on the patio though. There was little space to move. 

All in all, I would like to have my money back to try an equally expensive restaurant with a higher quality food and experience. You know Vegas has it. When you find it, let me know.

Oh Espee, you have gotten way too expensive.  A three item combo is, get this, SIXTEEN DOLLARS!   I can go to a beautiful restaurant like Agave and not pay this price for a taco meal.  And it really seems like the tamales at Espees have gotten smaller.  And the salsa bar is completely disgusting now - what happened to the pico de gallo? \n\nThey still have a pretty good happy hour with 2 for 1 margaritas and half price nachos - but I had to knock down my four star review to a three because of the ridiculous prices and shrinking portions.  Why do order at the counter restaurants try to charge the same prices as a sit down restaurant?

I am fervently desirous of conferring a rating of four stars upon this establishment, as my previous experiences have been largely satisfactory. Upon multiple visits, I have endeavored to sample a variety of items, and each dish has proven to be delectable, to say the least. However, due to my proximity to MTO Cafe, I frequently opt for their delivery services, which regrettably, have proven to be somewhat unreliable, as certain items are often omitted from my order, such as green drinks, salads accompanying chicken and waffles, and side dishes like mashed potatoes, among others. Despite these inconsistencies, the food remains flavorful and nutritious, providing an ideal solution for alleviating hangovers or enjoying a leisurely weekend brunch at home. Furthermore, the recent opening of a second location at the new Summerlin Mall has piqued my interest, and I intend to visit it in the near future.

"I have had the privilege of partaking in numerous sushi dining establishments, ranging from economical to luxurious. However, upon visiting Yokoso, it became apparent that their sushi offerings were not their forte. The sushi pieces were predominantly composed of rice, with an unfortunate lack of moisture. I opted to sample both the Rainbow Roll and The Pitt Roll, but unfortunately, they did not meet my expectations. While the pricing was reasonable, the quality of the sushi was subpar. I cannot comment on the remainder of the menu, as my focus was solely on the sushi. Nevertheless, I would only recommend visiting this establishment if you have an unwavering desire for sushi. On a positive note, the service we received was both attentive and efficient."
The prices are a little high and the food is ok. I have had better pizza. The wings where also ok. The people where nice both times we have eaten there.

Came here a few weeks ago with friends. Breakfast was good, tea was nice, atmosphere ok. I wasn't blown away but I also wasn't disappointed. I love the location and the interior is vintage and original. The outside was ok to have breakfast and enjoy the weather. Moderately priced.

For a place that's supposedly known for wings, it wasn't so good. I was very hungry but couldn't finish the 20 wings I was sharing with my friend. The 10 grilled wings were tossed in this super spicy tangy Cajun sauce. Eeee. Should've had the sauce on the side. The other 10 wings had sauce on the side but the batter was chalky tasting. Eeee.\n\nThe shrimp and spinach salad was good. Tsk. Was so craving good wings though.

"Rio De Janeiro, a city synonymous with vibrancy and extravagance, boasts an array of captivating attractions that warrant a visit from even the most discerning traveler. In order to elevate the experience at this esteemed establishment, certain enhancements are proposed, including but not limited to: looser slots, cordial security staff, additional cute shops, and entertainment tailored specifically for the under 21 demographic. Furthermore, aesthetic improvements, such as glitz and glamour upgrades, would greatly contribute to the overall ambiance. Already renowned for its delectable seafood buffet, spacious accommodations, and lively atmosphere, the implementation of these suggestions would undoubtedly revitalize the Rio, transforming it into a premier destination once again. Needless to say, my return is imminent, thanks in large part to the allure of rewards points."

Solid food, but nothing exciting or different. I'm not sure what kind of theme they are going for, which makes the place lack personality.

Strengths - good wait staff and some good beer options

Downfalls - not sure it is worth the price and nothing too exciting.

I went here tonight for a girlfriends birthday. Food was great. Our server was attentive but it did take a while to get our food and drinks.\nI highly recommend the soft pretzels with fondue, so yummy! Everyone enjoyed their entrees. I had the Sweet Corn Cannelloni; the flavors were very rich and I was happy to see they had several vegetarian options. We also got to choose a complimentary desert, and had the Monkey Bread. Sounded so-so but was delicious. Also, I love decor! Comfy chairs, that are different at every table and the gorgeous chandeliers make it feel very upscale.\nMy only complaints would be the amount of time we waited to get our food/drinks, it was pretty loud, a bit too dark, and the portions were fairly small for the price.

Let me state that this initial review is pretty old (sat as a draft that I forgot to post), but I can't update it yet. Review 1,  2 stars : Poor service. Had to wait 6 minutes or so just for someone to come to the front and take our order. Asked for mayo and ketchup only on the burger and the girl taking our order was a smarta**, stating that if we had been here before we would know that ketchup and mayo was on the table. Of course the whole burger came out wrong because the girl interrupted us when trying to order it with her smarter-than-thou attitude. The second girl I talked to fixed it and was really nice.\nReview 2, 4 stars : We got some food while we were bowling for my little sister's birthday. Service was good. Food was pretty good. Overall, a pleasant experience.

Ok, this place can get pricey quick, but if you know how to get \"bang\" for the buck like me you'll be ok.  My friend and I got the Veggie sandwich with extra roast beef.  I really need to invest in a real camera, because what we got was a 5 star Roast beef sandwich for 15 bux.  With Coffee and cake we were under $30 bux for the both of us.  I will say this....if you eat more food than what came out you really need a diet.  It was MORE THAN enough.  Split your food here as its just too much for one person and you don't want to take leftovers back with you do you?  Great sammy, half sour pickle with decent coffee.  Geez the chocolate cake is good.  Fries mehhhh.

"The venue boasts an endearing ambiance, augmented by a spacious outdoor area featuring a bar, thereby creating a picturesque setting conducive to leisurely dining experiences. Upon visiting during the daytime, I opted to sit outside on the synthetic grass, admiring the string lights that would undoubtedly imbue the atmosphere with a captivating charm come nightfall. While the culinary offerings proved satisfactory, they failed to elevate my dining experience to an extraordinary level. Specifically, my garden salad was unremarkable, and my fellow patrons' chicken panini sandwich, though flavorful, featured chicken breast that lacked succulence, while their strawberry salad showcased mushy fruit. However, what truly hindered my enjoyment was the sluggish pace of the service, as we placed our orders expeditiously only to endure an extended wait for our meals to arrive. In light of this, I surmise that addressing the efficiency of their service would be crucial in realizing the establishment's potential, particularly within a locality that lacks similar stylish and contemporary eateries."

"Peruse the menu, select your preference, and prepare your palate for an authentic culinary excursion, as this establishment's commitment to genuine flavors and traditional preparation methods is unwavering. Although linguistic barriers may exist, the staff's hospitable demeanor and willingness to accommodate curious patrons more than compensates for any potential communication difficulties. Indeed, an inquiry regarding the taste of the barbacoa was met with an offer to sample the dish, graciously provided by the attentive server. The robust flavors present in each taco are a testament to the culinary prowess of the kitchen staff, with the chicken variety boasting a satisfying spiciness and the guacamole maintaining a refreshing simplicity, comprised primarily of fresh avocado and a squeeze of lime juice. However, it would be remiss to neglect mentioning the somewhat questionable state of the seating area, characterized by utilitarian metal chairs and worn, torn booth cushions, with the occasional rusty nail protruding from the frame. Despite these shortcomings, the booths remain a preferable option for those opting to dine in. Unfortunately, the quality of the meat leaves something to be desired, thereby precluding this venue from becoming a regular haunt for this writer, who is admittedly particular about such matters. Nonetheless, the unique experience merits documentation and recommendation to intrepid gastronomes seeking an authentic taste of Mexico."

I relished a delectable dinner at Fleur de Lys last month, yet nothing truly astounded me.  I opted for the $59 prix fixe menu, which encompasses an appetizer, entree, and dessert - ultimately, a commendable value!  

I savored the rich, earthy onion soup, served with shaved truffles and duck, its presentation was unforeseen.  Next, I indulged in gently heated salmon accompanied by julienne vegetables and a green horseradish sauce.  My salmon was cooked to perfection, and the dish's appearance was aesthetically pleasing; however, the sauce, frankly, tasted akin to grass clippings - bitter and overpowering.  My companion seemed to relish her stout braised short ribs.  The trio of chocolate desserts fell short of my expectations: a dry soufflÃ©, a salty peanut butter shake, and Baily's ice cream.  None of the desserts genuinely impressed me.  Perhaps my expectations were excessively high, given that it is Hubert Keller's establishment.  Nonetheless, I would be willing to return and sample their regular menu, although, with such an array of exceptional dining options in Las Vegas, I cannot guarantee future visits.

PROS: Excellent service, extensive wine list, and reasonable prix fixe menus. 

CONS: Disappointing dishes outnumbered impressive ones for a four-star restaurant.

"Subpar, at best, was the quality of the culinary offerings presented before me. Specifically, the buttermilk pancakes, potato pancakes, eggs, and sausage links appeared to lack the requisite level of doneness, despite the expedited manner in which they were delivered to my table, a mere three minutes after placing my order. In fact, I would have willingly tolerated an additional two-minute wait to ensure that my meal was thoroughly cooked. Furthermore, it is worth noting that my mother's pancake recipe remains unsurpassed in its excellence."

This establishment warrants a three-star rating due to the fact that while they have never proffered an exceptional dining experience that would obliterate my expectations, neither have they precipitated any untoward incidents that would impel me to eschew their culinary offerings altogether. Geographically advantageous, this eatery lies in close proximity to my domicile, rendering it a convenient destination for satiating my nephew's penchant for pizza. Consistency and cordiality are hallmarks of their service, as my orders are invariably prepared punctually, and any occasional errors are expeditiously rectified, eliciting my genuine appreciation. In point of fact, I am unable to conjure any derogatory remarks concerning their operations. They demonstrate a proficiency in fulfilling their obligations as a purveyor of sustenance.

We indulged in a culinary excursion at this establishment on a Thursday evening, bringing along our 14-month-old progeny. Despite the availability of infant seating accommodations, we would advise against introducing young children to this venue, as it is not particularly suitable for their presence. However, we would enthusiastically endorse partaking in gastronomic delights at this location. Our repast began with an order of crabcakes, which, while satisfying, could have benefited from a slightly crisper exterior. This deficiency could have been remedied by extending the cooking duration in the pan. The accompanying spicy aioli presented a delightful complement to the dish.  
I relished in the delectable brie and bacon burger, characterized by exceptional quality bacon and beef, enveloped within a soft, yet robust bun. The burger was cooked to a perfect medium, with an adequate amount of juiciness. Unfortunately, it did not arrive with fries, much to our dismay. My spouse opted for the lobster bisque, which, despite its commendable flavor, was overpowered by an excessive amount of sherry. Additionally, she sampled the beef and blue salad, which emerged as the highlight of the meal. This dish showcased exceptional quality blue cheese, eliciting our utmost appreciation.  We eagerly anticipate our next visit to this culinary haven.

So much better than I remembered.  Last time we had breakfast here and it was horrible.  This time, we tried dinner. 

24 hour buffet pass for $40...how can you go wrong?  Except after the 2nd buffet, you really want to run straight towards a toilet or grab a roll of Tums.
