Seriously, no one should be eating more than one buffet within 24 hours.  Heck with it all though, this is Vegas...the city of losing wages and eating just as much as you freakin can!

This was our 3rd buffet on our pass...a dinner stop. 

Highlights:  
CREPES!!!  Yummy delicious crepes...I take em plain with some powdered sugar. Really nice lady making em...the crepes were perfectly chewy...I had 2.  Ugh. 

Seafood.  A combination of crab, shrimp, mussels, and clams.  Not the greatest...but good enough.

Dessert.  Probably the biggest display out of all the buffets we went to.  They're your usual buffet fare...nothing was really wow but enough to satisfy your dessert craving. 

The duck was also pretty good...it was made with orange sauce and rice pilaf.  Can't think of any of the other standouts as the buffets mostly had the same things.  

Pretty decent buffet...#3 on our buffet list.

When I have needed to be in the Las Vegas STRIP area and yet didn't care to pay the LV STRIP surcharge, I discovered and stayed here ever so slightly just OFF LV STRIP.

There is a POOL and free wifi with your room.

Food just around the corner.
Parking included completely with their parking lot.

It looks just like the Hofbrau Haus in Munich. I think the only Germans in the place were in the band! Service was good. Music was good. Beer was good. The food was another matter. My wife's Jager Schnitzel was so tough you could barely cut it with a knife. The sauerkraut with my wurst plate was bland and over cooked. The mashed potatoes tasted like they were made from a mix. We definitely had better German food.

"I have a penchant for the luxurious suite at Mandalay Bay, primarily due to its expansive dimensions of 750 square feet, which affords me ample space to relax and unwind in opulence. Moreover, I must commend the courteous and attentive demeanor displayed by the front desk staff, who consistently demonstrate a willingness to assist me with any queries or concerns I may have during my stay. However, I do take umbrage with the fact that despite my room being complimentary, I was still charged for the duration of my stay, which I found to be both perplexing and vexing. Furthermore, I failed to notice that I had been billed for two nights, which were ostensibly gratuitous, until several days had elapsed, thereby rendering me unable to rectify the situation in a timely manner."

This is a great bar for a Tuesday night and highly recommend going after 9pm to get the $3 burger special.  Go early to get a seat because this place fills up slightly after 9. I sat all the way upstairs and the bar was quiet but it was a Tuesday night after all.  They had a great list of draft beers including Pumking which I would have normally gotten but at $10 for a small glass that was a little much for me. I ended up with a bottle of Purple Haze another favorite of mine. The bartender told me there was a glitch in the computer system and it only rang up for $3-nice surprise.  Unfortunately this didn't happen for the second round but the bartender made sure to tell me in advance which was perfectly fine.  I stayed for the 9 o'clock burger special and it was declivous. Pleasantly surprised by the double burger and highly recommend the Stack'd special sauce!

I would give it 3.75. Never would guess a cool little breakfast spot would be located under some shady apartments on 7th street. Sat at the bar and ate. Could see right into the very small kitchen. I only had scrambled eggs and bacon which are nothing to rave about but it's hard to mess those up. Some of the other dishes that came out of the kitchen looked great!  I'll have to try the pancakes next time!  Would definitely come back.

I'm not sure what the hype is about this place. I came here expecting a lot given the large amount of 4-5 star Yelp reviews, and I left disappointed. I ordered the original because I figured that I couldn't go wrong with an original. I guess I should just not expect so much when I eat at a 4-5 star according to Yelp restaurant. The sandwich was tiny. The flavor tasted off because of the horseradish. I was so, so, so disappointed. \n\nI also got the chicken noodle soup because it was cold, and I wanted soup. That was average. I'm glad I got the soup or I'd have still been hungry after that tiny sandwich. To be fair, I was eating buffets during the earlier part of my trip to Vegas. But, I still think the sandwich could have been a lot better given all these rave reviews.

I had been cognizant of numerous laudatory remarks pertaining to Noca, and thus, I was eagerly anticipating partaking in a culinary experience at this establishment. However, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as my dining encounter was somewhat disappointing. 
  All four of us opted for the tasting menu, with two individuals selecting the wine pairing option as well. The visual aspect of the dishes was undeniably impressive. We initiated our meal with a preliminary palette cleanser of sorts. The first course consisted of either a mushroom soup or a salad, wherein I chose the former, and my spouse opted for the latter. While both dishes were satisfactory, they failed to elicit an exceptional degree of culinary delight. 
  The second course, which comprised pasta accompanied by a meat-based sauce, was indubitably the most delectable offering thus far. Moving on to the main entrÃ©e, we were served a flat iron steak, which, albeit enjoyable, did not quite attain remarkable status. The concluding dessert course featured blue cotton candy and chocolate cake accompanied by banana gelato, the former of which proved to be a pleasant surprise. 
  Lamentably, the wine pairings fell short of our expectations. Our server seemed to possess limited knowledge regarding the wines, and rather peculiarly, he adhered to identical pairings irrespective of whether we selected the soup or salad, and fish or steak entrÃ©e. Moreover, the entire wine selection was confined to the red family. 
  In summary, while Noca presented visually appealing dishes, adequate portion sizes, and passable service, the overall experience did not prove extraordinary. If one seeks a truly remarkable dining establishment, I would instead recommend Alto at the Hyatt Gainey Ranch.

I honestly love the decor in the place really industrial meets classy, but thats just party of the experience. The food here is like any other brazillian steak house. You start with salad and soup ( unlimited offerings even throughout the meal ) , when your ready a flip of a card brings sides and entrees to the table. Steak's of all cut from top sirloin to flay ming yong wrapped in bacon. There is also rib which are excellent, lamb which is fair, chicken. Why anyone would consume more chicken here then steak is confusing but its there and offered wrapped in bacon! Sides are Pao de Queijo ( baked bread rolled into balls with cheese ) , fried bananas, and gralic mash potatoes. Deserts here are pricey but a good way to end a meal. \n\nI am really unimpressed with a few things. Though my service was excellent the food really wasn't. Bacon wrapped steak was good, i've had better and larger pieces at Fago de Chao. The other meats were so so, lack of seasoning and  meat options ; as we came a little after they opened. The lobster bisque was OK. Reading some people who raved over its taste is amazing, because it really wasn't that great and probably the least liked thing by my party.

This McDonald's is conveniently nearby the Pepsi Center.

It opens late, and was perfect for the post-clubbing crowd I was with.

A friend bought me a McChicken sandwich (not sure why, but I appreciated it), which I made short work of - it tasted normal, as expected.

As usual, the food and service is very good here but can you please refinish the floor? It's really showing it age. Worn and discolored, it takes away from the overall experience. The ottomans in the lounge area also need cleaning or even better, reupholstered. \n\nThe place is looking rundown and that's really a shame for a high end, Summerlin dining spot.

Cute spot and lots of fun for the kiddos.  However, when we went out to the pumpkin patch to pick pumpkins, I saw one sitting in the field with a sticker on it from a store, complete with bar code.  I don't mind paying a little extra for locally grown pumpkins, but I am not paying $12 for a pumpkin they paid $4 for at Walmart!  I immediately put our pumpkins back.  I know they grow pumpkins there, you could see the vines, but if you sell them all, it feels wrong to me to supplement your inventory with store bought ones!

Oliveo's is a good place to get decent food, whether it's late night or lunchtime. They are slightly pricey, at least to me, but it is Greek food. I have never gotten a bad dish from them. I've had the chicken souvlaki, gyros and chicken breast plates. All are great, cooked well and have lots of flavor. The bonus is that Oliveo's is open extremely late, so they are usually my go to if I want late night food that isn't McDonald's. I recommend if you want healthy in a college town!

"This eatery exudes an ambiance that transcends the conventional 'pub' experience, with a menu that boasts an array of sophisticated offerings. My culinary adventure began with a novel dish, chicken tacos, which presented an unconventional twist on the customary shredded poultry. Instead, each taco encompassed a substantial, deep-fried chicken finger, proffering a satisfying crunch and delightful flavor profile. While the execution was generally successful, the sizeable nature of the chicken piece occasionally hindered the ease of consumption. Furthermore, our table exhibited minor signs of wear and tear, with a subtle stickiness that suggested a need for heightened attention to detail in the cleaning process. A comprehensive approach to sanitizing the surface, involving the removal of all items, would greatly enhance the overall dining experience."

"Gosh darn it! I thoroughly forgot about my significant other discovering an extensive dark-colored strand of human hair in our culinary creation proximate to the point of completion of our repast. How on earth could I have overlooked such an occurrence?! It's absolutely unacceptable for any eatery to have such a disgusting situation transpire, particularly when the victuals were as delectable as they were."

I'm not sure how this made it onto eaters list but I wasn't impressed. I've been a couple times and had different experiences each time. 

Price is decent. Style is fast casual but chicken was too greasy.  Burgers are very messy but decent in flavor. However I would  consider come here before going most fast food places.  Honestly, I've had amazing burgers so I have high expectations. 

I liked the French fries and flash fried veggies... Probably not healthy at all because it was too salty but I give them credit because it very unique.  It's not something I would order frequently though.

"My personal opinion is that the macaroni and cheese dish served at this establishment is perhaps the most delectable item on their menu, particularly when paired with their bologna. It exudes an essence of comfort food that is simply unparalleled. Furthermore, their cheese plate appears to be quite appetizing, and their onion rings, which are abundant in the thinly sliced variety, are undoubtedly a delight for those who relish such delicacies. However, I must express some disappointment regarding their perch, as it fails to meet my expectations as my preferred choice among the fish offerings. Nonetheless, I did have the pleasure of partaking in a bowl of their beer cheese soup during my visit, albeit accompanied by an uninspiring garnish of popcorn. In conclusion, while the remainder of their menu may not necessarily excel in terms of creativity or taste, it does possess a certain charm that is reminiscent of traditional Wisconsin cuisine, whatever that may entail."

I was actually at the Staples next door, but had seen this place several times before and was curious enough this time to stop in, not knowing at all what to expect. I was here in the early afternoon, and it was plenty busy, but nothing like the megacrowds that others are describing, presumably dependent on the time and day. I didn't get a chance to experience the aggressive customer aspect, but most likely because I wasn't shopping in the women's section, and 95% of the other customers were women, who did look a bit frenzied; the four or five men in the store were, by contrast, subdued. I will have to come back again when I have more time to explore what they have, but to say I was "impressed" with the selection of (men's) shoes would be understating itâit was wingtip heaven in there! Unlike many of the items in this place, most of these shoes were in great condition, with the worst thing being a missing lace or two, which is an easy fix anyway. I came out with a $30 pair of Maison Forte boots which have no imperfections at all and were originally priced at $215.00! (I should add that I'm not designer/brand aware at all, so I'm mostly impressed that the shoes are gorgeous and don't so much care about their brand names.) Will definitely come back, even if just for more shoes! :)
Good food overall but the storefront could use some work to make for a nicer dining experience. The place was clean and service was fine. I would absolutely order take out or delivery from here.

Decided to have dinner at Tofu Hut tonight. Overall experience was not bad, but I wouldn't call it great either. 

They were a bit short staffed when we first walked in. I would say it took them over 5 mins to even acknowledge our presence even though they did see us walk in.  I expected a "Hello, or Welcome" at the very least.

We passed on the AYCE tonight & went ala carte. We ordered short ribs & spicy chicken. Both orders were good, but nothing memorable or anything to rave about. I did love their banchan offerings! I liked the fish cake, japchae, spicy cucumber, and I don't recall the others but it was yummy!

I would go back.. but don't think I'll be a regular at this place.

"I have an immense fondness for this hotel, yet my allegiance remains with the Bellagio, as it continues to excel in my esteem. Upon arrival, my family and I were graciously upgraded to the 60th floor, affording us a breathtaking panorama. The accommodations themselves were quaint and immaculate, featuring a television set in the bathroom, which elicited a humorous response from me. Unfortunately, the primary television in our room failed to function properly, despite the presence of detailed instructions on the remote control. Additionally, we encountered an unexpected issue with the walls, which proved to be remarkably thin, allowing us to overhear conversations in the corridor throughout the night, as well as the neighbors' nocturnal activities (albeit, the latter may have been attributable to a heated argument). Notwithstanding these drawbacks, I remain a devotee of the hotel's overall ambiance, La Rev the production, the lavish buffet offered for both brunch and dinner, and the array of upscale shops situated within the premises."

"The sushi exhibited palatable quality, however, the service was merely adequate. Notwithstanding, the numerous servers' frequent comings and goings rendered it challenging for us to maintain their individual identities. Furthermore, our dissatisfaction was exacerbated by the fact that the various types of sushi rolls we had ordered were being served in an uncoordinated manner, arriving at disparate intervals rather than being presented simultaneously. Despite the proximity of the Wynn, where we were lodging, we opted to partake of this dining experience."

"The cinematic experience offered by this establishment possesses both beneficial aspects and drawbacks. On one hand, the relatively diminutive size of the theater enables the exhibition of merely six to seven films simultaneously. Nevertheless, the auditoriums themselves boast exceptional comfort and generous legroom between seats, much to the delight of tall individuals. Unfortunately, the luminosity of the pathway illumination within the theater is excessive, resulting in an annoying distraction akin to having a light source directed into one's eyes throughout the entire film. Not exactly an optimal viewing environment. 

The pricing scheme adopted by this cinema is generally unremarkable, with the exception of a discounted rate of $5.50 for students. To take advantage of this offer, it may be necessary to employ creative methods such as presenting an outdated student identification card or sporting orthodontic appliances to convincingly portray a youthful appearance. 

For convenient access to the theater, park your vehicle in the adjacent parking garage and traverse the food court on foot."

Seeing as I've been reviewing my recent Vegas adventures, I should probably get this one out of the draft burner.  I have a habit of letting drafts collect dust on Yelp.  So allow me to finish my four month old thoughts:

Zumanity is said to be "adults only," but it's no Absinthe.  It caters to adults with a few raunchy jokes here and there.  And it caters to Vegas with a few topless acts.  But for the most part, it's very tame and even a bit campy.  I didn't find the show pushing the envelop on anything and it didn't appear at all sensual to me.

I brought the boyfriend.  he enjoyed himself but didn't see why I fuss over Cirque du Soleil so much.  On reflection, I should have taken him to see something a bit more awe-inspiring (like "O").  

A lot of the comedy is just heckling the nearby crowd.  And a lot of the acts highlighted in the program were absent during our particular show.  No midgets, no fat twins.  Perhaps that would have added some flavor to an otherwise lackluster evening.  Maybe I was suspecting something too outside the norm and my expectations were bridging on pornographic?  To me, this was a typical Cirque show with some dirty jokes and sexier outfits thrown into the mix.

50% off tickets for military.  So a good deal to fill a few hours of your time.

We made the conscious decision to patronize this culinary establishment based on an abundance of favorable critiques, thus fostering elevated anticipations on our part. Unfortunately, our gastronomical experience fell short of our lofty expectations, as the victuals served were merely adequate. Specifically, the fish taco exhibited a notable lack of moisture and flavor, while the guacamole accompanying the rolled tacos failed to impress our taste buds with its blandness. Furthermore, we sampled the carne asada taco, which, albeit palatable, did not live up to our expectations. Our spouse opted for the steak and eggs, the appearance of which resembled machaca. Although the dining area appeared well-maintained, the state of the lavatory left much to be desired. In light of our underwhelming experience, we would only consider returning to this eatery in the event that it was the sole option available and our hunger was unrelenting.

"Goodness gracious, the atmospheric conditions within this eatery were utterly saturated with the pungent fumes of tobacco, to the extent that visibility was significantly impaired, thereby diminishing our capacity to fully appreciate the culinary offerings. Notwithstanding this unfortunate circumstance, we opted to sample their renowned 'Steak Special,' which, to our delight, proved to be quite delectable. The accompanying vegetables, specifically the green beans and mashed potatoes, were likewise palatable."

As a \"gastropub\" Public House has the mandatory dark wood decor and decadent dishes like poutine and fois gras.  Being Vegas, all restaurants have a hook or gimmick, and Public House is no different with its expansive wine list  stored in its fancy schamcy ipad for guests to play around with it - half the fun was picking the wine.  \n\nPublic House also excels at some light fare as well.  Went with a group of girls, and half of the table ended up getting the scallops entree - the scallops were super sweet and tasted very fresh.  The salads were great, pomegranate seeds added a nice burst of acidity.

I am a huge fan of North Kierland, but this was my first time at North Arcadia. Other than the decor of this restaurant (which was beautiful and cool) I was totally underwhelmed. We were there for lunch and we were about the 4th/5th table seated as we were there before 11:30.  There was nothing offensive, but the service was really slow and had a bit of an attitude. The zucca chips (one of my favorites at North Kierland) were over cooked. The $17 lunch portion of bucatini with meatballs was pretty small in size for the price. Nothing here was terrible, but out the door we were at $59.00 for 3 people for lunch with no drinks. Just saying you should go have a less than $20/person lunch at a much better place nearby like T. Cook's or Coup des Tartes.

The good things about City Cafe: their breakfasts, their pool table, their beer pitchers (which save you a few quid), their nice atmosphere which has the American diner feel down. Their big burger challenge, though it is painful to watch let alone attempt. Their chips which come in their own little wire fry baskets.

The bad things: their cocktail pitchers are very, very weak. You could drink from them all evening and only get mildly buzzed (this was my experience with their elderflower one, their long island iced tea, and their Pimms). Their food is odd. Their nachos would be OK, except that their guacamole tastes exactly like mayonnaise. I once had their veggie burger as well, and something in the way the cheese on top of the patty stuck to the upper bun made said bun go extremely soggy and frothy in an extremely unappetising way. It was liquid bun by the time I neared the end. This burger inspired me to make a yelp account.

That being said, I go there a lot and will probably continue to do so. But I will stick to pints and chips.

This place has a great location in Tivoli Village. They have a good indoor outdoor bar and several inexpensive offerings for happy hour. One of the best features of this restaurant is that they allow your dog to sit out with you on the patio while you dine. 

The food is not traditional (authentic) Mexican food which doesn't bother me. But, the poor execution is an issue. We have eaten here a handful of times. I guess because I keep hoping to select something on the menu that I love. Unfortunately, that hasn't happened. The highlight of the menu is their guacamole and chips which are made table side. Their complimentary salsas are also very tasty. 

I would give Cantina Loredo another try. It's a shame that we haven't found a good Mexican restaurant in the Summerlin area. My husband likes this place a lot more than I do. He is a fan of the fajitas. So, the 3 star review is an average of both of our opinions.

"The culinary offerings and hospitality were satisfactory, albeit not exceptional, and certainly not deserving of commemoration. The cacophony of sounds within the establishment's confines was oppressive, rendering communication between patrons and servers arduous, and necessitating elevated vocalizations on the part of the waiting staff to delineate the day's specials, et cetera. This phenomenon was not exclusive to the bar area, but permeated the dining space as well. Furthermore, the tables were positioned at an uncomfortably proximate distance from one another, making for a less than ideal dining experience when compared to other establishments in the vicinity."

"I have had the pleasure of visiting various Red Robin establishments throughout the Bay Area, and while it is undeniable that the uniformity of menu items across all franchises is commendable, my personal experience at this particular location was somewhat underwhelming. Admittedly, I do not frequent this restaurant with sufficient regularity to justify a zealous recommendation, but I do acknowledge the appeal of certain menu items. Specifically, the colossal onion ring tower, despite its unremarkable taste, commands respect for its sheer magnitude. Additionally, the chicken pasta dish we shared fell short of my expectations, rendering it an unlikely candidate for future orders. Nonetheless, I must concede that Red Robin does offer some delectable options, such as their fish, fries, and shrimp sampler appetizer, which I have had the pleasure of enjoying on previous occasions. In conclusion, while this establishment may not warrant an enthusiastic endorsement, it is not entirely without merit, and I would still advise others to sample their fare."

I have eaten here two times now the first time it was pretty dead in the place and there was what looked like a group of kid's part of the family... My server seemed to cater to that group over me I am a paying customer keep that in mind... I ordered the General Tso's Chicken (Crunchy fried white meat tossed with scallions in a spicy sauce. I was a good meal nothing above and beyond... The second trip was for a lunch and I ordered the Mongolian beef (Spicy marinated beef saut\u00e9ed with scallions and sweet yellow onions served over a bed of crispy rice noodles and sprinkled with sesame seeds... This was a really good meal and great service so let's hope the third this as good.

In my search for great BBQ this place stands out.  Not only is it tasty but it doesn't irritate my stomach.  That is a major plus in my book.  The one drawback is service.  I've ordered online and arrived at the specified pick up time 30-60 minutes later to still have to wait another 15-20 minutes.  So be advised to just go to the take out counter and order, as it will take just as long.

"I am delighted to be partaking in an evening repast with my dearest kin at this picturesque establishment, the Pointe Hilton Squaw Peak Resort, boasting a tranquil ambiance and delectable culinary offerings. Upon perusing the extensive bill of fare, I was pleased to discover an array of options catering to diverse gastronomic inclinations. Although the service was merely satisfactory, the fare itself was, for the most part, expertly prepared, save for a minor mishap involving the overcooking of the lamb entrÃ©e for one member of our gathering. In conclusion, while not flawless, our dining experience was, on the whole, acceptable."

The place was a lot of fun because I was with a group of girls and comped drinks kept on coming to our table.

The service and staff were amazingly friendly.  Although I wasn't there for the food, it wasn't too bad.  In fact, I don't remember much of what I ordered but it was only from the appetizer menu. 

The place does get really busy, so make sure you call for reservations.

GRIMALDI's PIZZERIA possesses an abundance of advantages, with state-of-the-art equipment and refined techniques representing the pinnacle of their proficiency. In my opinion, the utilization of a coal-fired oven produces a crust that is unparalleled in its excellence, and GRIMALDI's has mastered this method with remarkable consistency. However, the quality of their toppings fails to surpass the standards of the large chain restaurants that employ acne-ridden youths to deliver subpar sustenance to one's doorstep when exhaustion dictates that dining at an authentic establishment is not feasible. Furthermore, I must confess that their sauce does not align with my personal preferences, as it is prepared using a raw, lightly drizzled formula that prioritizes the preservation of crust crispiness, whereas I favor a rich, long-simmered variant that offers a more complex and profound flavor profile. Consequently, my pursuit of the ultimate pizza continues unabated...

Ah.. the Flamingo.  First time I was there was back in 1987.  My buddy's parents went to Vegas to gamble and I tagged along to keep him company in the arcade as we weren't old enough to drive yet let alone gamble.  We spent a couple hours on a turbo speed Ms. Pacman machine and walked around the strip.  \n\nI haven't been back in that place since, until last week.  It seemed a bit nicer back in the day.  It's a bit dingy now, and walking in from the parking garage you get hit with a wall of stale smoky air reminiscent of a smoking room at a Super 8 Motel.  Blech.  Circulation is better once you make it through the hall.  The layout is confusing, but I was able to enjoy a few Sam Adams on tap at the bar with the owner of my company who had just flown in from Germany so that was nice.  I refrained from playing here though as I have issues with Harrah's properties after enduring some horrendous customer service at their Rincon San Diego casino.

When I was a resident of the locality, I had the propensity to frequent this establishment with regularity, both for on-premises consumption and takeout purposes. Unfortunately, there has been a discernible decline in quality over the past year, as evidenced by the subpar service during our most recent visits, a reduction in portion size, and an inordinate emphasis on vegetables at the expense of protein. Nonetheless, their Pad Thai remains exceptional.

It's a new small place, clean, order at the counter fresh fish fry. They had several types of dips and the french frys were good. No beer :( sad hope that's too come soon. There was plenty served in one serving didn't need more. Husband wished his was crisper and wanted Texas toast.  Fish was white and very good. Coleslaw ok.  Hope they stay and grow - we'll be back.

My maiden voyage to the shooting range transpired to be an enjoyable escapade; however, certain drawbacks tarnished the overall experience. Firstly, the staff members exhibited proficiency in their field, imparting valuable knowledge and ensuring a seamless experience for patrons. Additionally, an extensive array of firearms was available for utilization. Unfortunately, these advantages were counterbalanced by several negative aspects. Specifically, the range was characterized by a high volume of patrons, leading to extended waiting periods, particularly during peak days of the week. Furthermore, the physical space was limited, resulting in a cramped environment with individuals occupying every available spot, including the floor and corners, and shoulders were literally rubbing against each other. Moreover, the range officers appeared flustered, struggling to manage the throngs of people and maintain order amidst the chaos. Lastly, the cost of utilizing the range was deemed steep, with a shared lane, gun, and ammunition for a mere thirty minutes totaling a whopping eighty-eight dollars, which included a fifteen-dollar fee per weapon. Despite these limitations, the range still presents itself as a suitable destination for those interested in partaking in such activities, though it is crucial to be cognizant of the aforementioned constraints.

"In pursuit of Shrimp Pad Thai, I conducted a Google search, which led me to this establishment. Upon placing an order for pick-up, I was informed that it would be ready within 15 minutes, much to my delight. However, upon arriving at the venue, I encountered a rather unsettling situation regarding parking. Specifically, the designated parking area was situated down a dimly lit drive-thru/alleyway, which caused me some apprehension due to the presence of a worker who appeared to be smoking in the corner. To avoid any potential discomfort, I suggest that patrons consider parking their vehicles on Spring Mountain and walking around to Valley instead.  

Upon entering the restaurant, I was immediately struck by the warm and welcoming ambiance created by the friendly staff. Moreover, the dish itself was quite flavorful, with a spicy level of four that left a lasting impression on my taste buds. However, I must admit that I was slightly disappointed by the noodles, which were noticeably thinner than what I was accustomed to - almost akin to angel hair pasta, if you will. Additionally, the shrimp used in the dish were of a smaller variety, which didn't quite meet my expectations. Nevertheless, despite these minor shortcomings, the dish remained enjoyable, and I would still recommend it to others. In fact, I might even go so far as to suggest ordering larger shrimp in the future, provided that one has the opportunity to sample the regular dish initially, as I did."

"An abundance of seating options and diverse ambiances within the establishment rendered it an exceedingly comfortable venue, particularly during the warmer seasons when the outdoor patio area can be utilized extensively. However, certain aspects detracted from the overall satisfaction, specifically:  
1. The practice of pouring cream into coffee without first inquiring about preferences regarding dairy substitutes resulted in an unintended addition of half-and-half to my spouse's beverage, despite my desire to customize it with skim milk. Although the staff accommodated my request for a new drink, it would be preferable to have control over the creative process behind my coffee concoction.  
2. The background music consisted of a radio station featuring recurring advertisements, which created an atmosphere akin to being trapped in a shop playing the same irritating tunes and commercials repeatedly. A simple solution would be to curate a playlist or employ an iPod to create a more enjoyable auditory experience for patrons.   
3. While the coffee was satisfactory, the menu items appeared appetizing, but comments regarding the cost have been voiced. Nonetheless, it seems illogical to visit a coffeehouse anticipating a full meal. Prices were only marginally higher than expected.  
4. The availability of beer and the prominent display of a large pizza banner near the entrance raised questions about the establishment's identity. It appears that Hob Nobs may be struggling to define its purpose and target audience. A decision on the type of establishment would alleviate confusion and enhance the overall experience.  
Despite these issues, the visit remained generally pleasurable, with only minor shortcomings detracting from the enjoyment."

I harbored lofty expectations for Cheddatruck, as I possess an unwavering fondness for a delectable burger, which, unquestionably, ranks among my most beloved culinary indulgences. Alas, Cheddatruck failed to captivate my taste buds, leaving me feeling underwhelmed and unimpressed. My companion, who shares my ardor for burgers, eagerly anticipated the opportunity to sample their mac-n-cheese embellished burger, only to be thwarted by the absence of this pivotal ingredient. Thus, he settled for an alternative option, adorned with an egg, while I opted for a straightforward cheeseburger. In addition, we elected to order tots, handcrafted, no less.  

Unfortunately, our burgers proved to be merely passable, with mine suffering from a slight overcooking and a general dearth of flavor. My companion concurred, describing his burger as unremarkable and forgettable. The tots, despite their artisanal preparation, disappointed us, lacking the rich, savory flavors we had anticipated, even with the presence of cheese within them and the accompaniment of an herb-infused cream cheese dipping sauce. Moreover, the price of $3 for a mere seven tots struck us as somewhat exorbitant. 

In conclusion, taking into account the cost, numerous superior burger alternatives exist in the vicinity, rendering Cheddatruck's offerings inferior and, thus, not worth consideration. My apologies, Cheddatruck; your culinary endeavors have fallen short, prompting me to bid thee adieu.

"While on vacation in Phoenix from Chicago, I opted to dine at this establishment based on a recommendation from a friend. Upon arriving, I was met with an extensive wait time that I deemed rather excessive, had I not been on holiday and disposed to relax and pass the time, I would not have waited three hours for a table elsewhere. However, the delay was rendered tolerable by the entertaining ambiance of the adjacent bar. The pizza served was undoubtedly flavorful and the wine selection was satisfactory, yet, having been accustomed to the superior quality of authentic Italian pizza in my hometown, I found the culinary experience to be merely adequate, rather than exceptional. Nonetheless, the eatery presented a commendable display of fresh ingredients and a satisfying dining atmosphere, ultimately yielding an enjoyable evening once seated."

"My experience at this establishment has been limited to cinematic pursuits, as I have yet to engage in any gambling activities or partake in culinary delights within their restaurants. My interactions with staff have been cursory, primarily pertaining to the procurement of cinema tickets. Notwithstanding, my impressions thus far have been favorable, characterized by effortless parking, affable staff, and clear wayfinding. In the absence of elevated expectations, I am unable to articulate grievances. However, I shall reassess my appraisal should I opt to engage in more substantive endeavors on the premises."
One of the larger Second Cup around.  Always tons of fresh goods.\n\nCan get busy on Sundays where students come to study.

"I recently partook in a culinary excursion to this establishment, seeking to indulge in their gastronomical offerings, specifically their pizza, as part of my ongoing quest to sample an array of pizza varieties from diminutive, family-owned restaurants. Prior to my visit, I had cultivated a predilection for such establishments, as they often exhibit a more personalized and hospitable ambiance, in contrast to the more impersonal nature of larger pizza chains. Upon entering the premises, I was greeted by a congenial staff who displayed a welcoming demeanor, contributing to an atmosphere that was inviting and pleasant. However, my enthusiasm was tempered by the dearth of patrons, which raised concerns regarding the eatery's popularity and reputation. Following a brief interval of approximately 20 minutes, my pizza was presented, yet its appearance seemed somewhat haphazard, prompting apprehensions regarding its quality. Unfortunately, my concerns were substantiated upon consuming the pizza, as it lacked a certain je ne sais quoi and failed to elicit an extraordinary degree of culinary satisfaction. Despite this, I remain open to revisiting this establishment in the future, as I believe that each dining experience presents an opportunity for growth and improvement."

Came in super late for some munchies and to cure our sweet tooth. I got the bread pudding and my friend got the french toast. The food was solid, but the service was less than desirable. The bartender was more concerned with her phone and gossip than being personable to us.

If the cafÃ© out of Eastenders were real, I'm pretty sure this is what it would be like. I've never seen somewhere that better encapsulates the definition of "good old greasy-spoon cafÃ©" as well as Brambles.

It's only just opened, and I assumed it would be yet another of these sandwich/wrap/panini type places that Edinburgh is teeming with, but I was very wrong. Although Brambles do offer things like baked potatoes and paninis, their specialty is anything fried served with chips and buttered bread. And I mean literally everything - from traditional chicken nuggets, chips, and beans that are reminiscent of school dinner days, to deep-fried haggis and chips and mushy peas.

They did have some slightly healthier options on the menu, such as lasagne (served with chips, of course!) but it's not really the kind of place you go to consume healthy cuisine. The lace curtains, neon sign in the window, and plastic tables should be the most off-putting thing you've ever seen, but it works in that sort of way that it's so bad it's good. It's kitsch, a bit tacky and dated, despite only being open a few weeks, but it does exactly what it says on the tin and serves good honest junk food at really reasonable prices.

"Certainly not comparable to the exceptional standards set by Ka or O, yet still a mildly entertaining spectacle in the city of Las Vegas. 

It is essential to note that the acrobatic feats performed during the production were undeniably remarkable. Nonetheless, the overall pacing of the show was somewhat sluggish, leading to occasional moments of somnolence experienced by my mother. Additionally, the brief interludes between the main acts seemed excessively prolonged and lacked significant relevance to the overall narrative. 

In conclusion, while Mystere may prove visually captivating for first-time viewers of Cirque du Soleil productions, those familiar with the company's superior offerings would be better advised to explore alternative options for their entertainment."

My partner and I partook in a preliminary dinner at a novel eatery. The ambiance was reminiscent of a masculine refuge, which was quite agreeable to my preferences. This establishment would be an excellent venue to indulge in a delectable burger and beverage on a Saturday afternoon while enjoying a sporting event or to treat a romantic companion on a weeknight. The Grind has proven to be a valuable dining alternative for the Arcadia community!  

The hospitality staff displayed exceptional cordiality and attention to detail. Kudos to them for their well-organized efforts during the inaugural evening.  

My partner and I opted to share a delectable melted rosemary brie complemented by strawberry relish. The brie cheese exuded rich flavor, and its texture was enhanced by the subtle infusion of rosemary essence. The accompanying strawberry relish showcased notable intensity. A balsamic reduction sauce would elevate this dish to new heights.  

Our culinary exploration continued with the BLT burger and the Sweet and Spicy Burger. The 1000-degree coal fire oven effectively sealed in the juices and produced a satisfying crunch on the exterior of the patty. Freshness and palatability characterized all additional components. The bun exhibited a delightful contrast between its toasted surface and soft, spongy interior.  

The fries could benefit from refinement; however, it is essential to consider that this was merely a preliminary launch.  

The beverage menu boasts innovation and educational value.  

I eagerly anticipate revisiting this establishment in the future.

This place is good, don't get me wrong. I love this Italian style pizza, the service was good, and i enjoyed my meal. The thing is, if you go a few blocks over to eastern there is Grimaldi's pizza, which is that same Italian style pizza, but its just much better. The pizza was a bit cold and soft, so maybe mine was just undercooked, i dont know. Also the flavors were a little bland. So try this and you wont be too disapointed, but missing out on Grimaldi's would be the crime when its so close.

"The culinary establishment boasted an impressive magnitude, its expansive interior exuding an air of opulence that was further accentuated by the warm welcome we received upon entry. Our server, a consummate professional, promptly escorted us to our table and presented us with menus, his affable demeanor putting us at ease. Opting for the 12 oz New York strip steak, cooked to a medium rare temperature, I eagerly anticipated the arrival of my culinary indulgence. Alas, the duration between placing our orders and the actual serving of our meals proved to be somewhat protracted, approximating thirty to forty-five minutes, which, coupled with the fact that my steak was overcooked to an unfortunate degree, left me feeling somewhat disenchanted. Despite this setback, I chose to maintain my composure and conveyed my dissatisfaction to our server, who expressed regret on behalf of the kitchen staff and extended an offer to prepare a fresh steak. However, given my pressing schedule and ravenous hunger, I elected to forgo this option and instead consume the steak provided, albeit with some reluctance. In spite of this experience, I remain willing to accord the establishment another opportunity to demonstrate its culinary prowess during my future visits to Las Vegas."
 Establishment rating: 4/5
 Waitstaff/Service rating: 4/5
 Cuisine rating: 3/5
 Price rating: 2/5 (lower score indicates higher price)
 Cleanliness rating: 4/5
 Overall rating: 3/5

Vovomeena's whereabouts proved to be rather elusive and challenging to pinpoint, as its inconspicuous location made it nearly invisible to the naked eye, even when traversing thoroughfares such as McDowell or 7th Avenue. The absence of conspicuous signage only exacerbated our difficulties in locating the establishment, leading us to circumnavigate the surrounding area in search of the enigmatic eatery. Ultimately, it was only by virtue of my sibling's guidance that we were able to unearth the hidden gem, albeit with a modicum of perseverance and determination. 

My culinary exploits at Vovomeena were somewhat underwhelming, as my order of the "banging pocket" failed to live up to its promising moniker. The dish itself consisted of a pita stuffed with sausage and eggs, accompanied by a side of potatoes; however, the lack of additional ingredients such as onions or mushrooms rendered it somewhat unremarkable. 

The restaurant's seating capacity was also somewhat limited, making it advisable to arrive at an early hour to secure a table, lest one finds themselves relegated to the outdoor seating area, exposed to the sweltering temperatures. An installation of misters could potentially alleviate this issue. Notwithstanding the aforementioned drawbacks, the quality of service at Vovomeena was quite satisfactory, despite the considerable distance traveled for a merely passable dining experience.

This establishment would warrant a rating of three and a half stars, taking into account its antiquated Vegas ambiance, reasonable pricing, dazzling illuminated spectacle, and predominantly local clientele. The frozen chocolate-covered bananas available for a mere ninety-nine cents are an absolute delight! Hennessey's restaurant offers an exceptional value with a menu featuring delectable options. The opportunity to engage in twenty-dollar blackjack games and partake in complimentary performances (ranging from mediocre to impressive) further enhances the appeal of this venue. However, it is important to note that the presence of discourteous individuals is ubiquitous and cannot be avoided entirely. Additionally, the low ceilings within the gaming facilities result in an atmosphere heavily saturated with cigarette smoke. While it is not advisable to venture too far away from the light display, it is reassuring to know that there is an adequate number of security personnel present along the main thoroughfare. In summary, this destination presents a refreshing alternative to the contemporary, large-scale corporate character of the Las Vegas Strip, lacking perhaps in gastronomical excellence but simultaneously offering a considerably more affordable experience. Ultimately, it caters to those seeking amusement and entertainment, providing a unique blend of attractions within a compact three-and-a-half block area. It is essential to recall that the essence of Las Vegas revolves around enjoyment and diversion, and the Fremont Street Experience effectively distills these qualities into a concentrated and captivating encounter.

"From a perusal of diverse reviews, it emerges that my encounter mirrored the experiences of numerous others: an ambiance suffused with conviviality, culinary offerings of merit, and yet, regrettably, service characterized by inattention and dilatoriness. 

In pursuit of a replenishment of my coffee, I ascend to the counter, only to discover a staff member stationed before the espresso machine, engaged in the act of self-indulgence, specifically, imbibing successive shots of espresso with seeming relish. Following a brief hiatus, I elect to interrupt this indulgence, addressing the worker with a query regarding the feasibility of securing a refill. The response, though tardy, ultimately materializes in the form of a briskly poured refreshment. 

Despite the barista's tardiness, the coffee and sandwich both proved to be of superior quality, yet, I cannot help but feel that the deferral of my refill until the conclusion of the barista's personal espresso consumption was an unwarranted inconvenience."

It's not a bad hotel for the price.  Really.

The room I stayed in was fine (save for some odd stains on the curtains), the casino and show offerings are about standard (Carrot Top, Criss Angel), and there's a fairly diverse selection of restaurants.

That said, if you want to drop an extra $40 or $50 a night and stay somewhere else, I'd probably recommend doing that.  While I'd take the Luxor over the Imperial Palace, it's certainly no Caesar's or Mandalay Bay.

Dalkeith Road is so sad-looking. I don't know how a street can looks sad, but it does. It's sort of saying 'I'm out of the way, I'm long and there are other roads parallel to me that are much better and get there quicker. sigh.' Is it possible to feel sorry for a road? 

Anyway

C's Tasty Bites thus lacks the va va voom I look for in a snack shop. It tries, nonetheless, and 10/10 for effort. 
The place itself is small, I think too small to breathe so only ever come here for take-away. The price is alright and the food isn't amazing, but maybe i;m lacking enthusiasm because when I leave i'm left with Dalkeith road. aw.

Came for a drink after work before I went home to surprise and was told that if was going to pay by debit that I would have to spend $10 minimum. Why can't you pay for what you order regardless of what type of payment you use. Normally I would drink more than $10 worth but today happened to be a day that I can't stay long. And to top it off I asked if I could pay with cash for my one drink with cash, which you can but, the ATM was out of service... Normally I don't care but that I did...

MGM is an acceptable lodging establishment if one can procure a reasonable tariff... The check-in and check-out processes at MGM, like those of its fellow hotels along the Las Vegas Strip, necessitate a considerable amount of time devoted to queuing. However, upon gaining entry to my accommodations, I was pleasantly surprised by their quality, particularly in regards to the efficacy of the blackout shades, which performed exceptionally well in obstructing solar illumination. Additionally, the internet connectivity was relatively rapid, the miniature bar offered an adequate assortment of potables, and I had the good fortune of being assigned to a floor that was relatively tranquil. 

It is worth mentioning that the superior dining establishments affiliated with MGM surpassed my expectations, with the notable exception of Fiamma, which failed to impress. 

Unfortunately, several drawbacks were also encountered, including uninspired and, on occasion, discourteous blackjack dealers, inadequate cocktail service in the blackjack area, a lack of shaded areas around the pool (which, given the intense heat of the Las Vegas sun, made lounging by the water somewhat challenging), an inability of the room's air conditioning unit to effectively cool the space, and substantial throngs of people in all public areas. 

In conclusion, while MGM may not be the optimal choice for lodging among the multitude of options available along the Strip, it remains a passable alternative for those who prefer to stay in this vicinity.

"The staff members appear to be selectively attentive, wherein they opt to listen only to the aspects of customers' orders that align with their preconceived notions or preferences, thereby conveniently disregarding the remaining components of the instructions. This phenomenon was exemplified when I barely managed to utter the word 'cafe' before the staff member in question hastily departed, leaving me wondering whether my desire for condensed milk had been adequately conveyed. Furthermore, the menu's layout seemed to be intentionally designed to perplex and confuse, with an absence of rice plates as the primary option, which struck me as a glaring oversight. Notwithstanding my grievances, the egg rolls were indeed impressive, boasting an abundance of filling; and the coffee, though served via an antiquated metal drip mechanism, was nonetheless palatable, particularly when accompanied by a cup of ice. As for the pho, while its quality was undeniable, the sweltering temperature of 105 degrees Fahrenheit made consuming a sizeable, steaming bowl of noodles somewhat less appealing."

The restaurant is located in the lobby of the Westin.  I was staying at the hotel but avoided the restaurant given that it was less than 3 stars on YELP.  The last night, I was tired and worked until 9PM, so decided to give it a try.

The menu itself is good.  They have seafood and sushi and there were plenty of dishes that caught my eye, though settled on a couple of sushi rolls.

The sushi rolls were good, and they have a good draught beer selection.  From a food perspective, I would give it a 3.5 stars, approaching four, but then I only had the sushi.  Still, just based on food, I'll try it again.

However, where it may get a bad reputation is service, which isn't very good.  The bar was about half full, otherwise the restaurant was at most 10% occupied.  Still, anyone sitting at the bar had to wave to the bartender to get his attention, and it took about 25 minutes for my two rolls to come out.  That might explain the 2.5 star rating.

Since I'll likely be staying at this Westin for awhile, probably will try it again.

The good: great flavors- the pork is delicious, different options, clean and friendly team

The bad: this is my first time here so my biggest concern was the temperature of the food. I came for a late lunch, I get it, but didn't feel like the items were super fresh or hot. I think this would have been different should I have come during lunch or dinner hour. My other suggestion: the sauces should've served warm, not cold.

Overall, I enjoyed it and would try it again. Love the concept.

Tried the brisket the other day, and it was excellent.  Juicy and tender, it's a definite re-order.  They put the sauce on top, next time I'll ask them to put it on the side, so I can just eat some brisket by itself.

"Expended two hundred dollars on a culinary experience for two individuals at an upscale dining establishment, precipitating elevated anticipations. Unfortunately, my significant other's cut of meat, specifically the steak, was overcooked and lacked succulence, while the supplementary sauces presented were not merely unimpressive but also unpalatable. In contrast, my Beef Wellington was of satisfactory quality, albeit not exceptional. Furthermore, the macaroni and cheese accompanying the dish was excessively arid, prompting inquiry into the cause of such an anomaly. Considering the totality of factors, including ambiance and service, a sense of disappointment permeated our dining experience, leading me to conclude that future patronage would be unwarranted. However, I may opt to sample their burger alternative at a subsequent date."

Located in close proximity to the renowned Rio All-Suite Hotel and Casino, the Flamingo hotel boasts an unparalleled position, rendering it easily accessible by foot for those who relish a leisurely stroll along the Las Vegas Strip. However, it is worth noting that the pedestrian route traverses an overhead bridge above the highway, which may not be the most scenic or enjoyable trek. Despite its unpretentious nature, this establishment offers exceptional value for money, with tariffs that are considerably reasonable compared to neighboring luxury resorts. As a subsidiary of Coast Properties, this hotel benefits from an abundance of on-site facilities, effectively rendering it self-sufficient and obviating the need for guests to venture beyond its confines in search of dining or entertainment options. Thus, for travelers seeking a relaxed ambiance and economical accommodations, this venue is certainly worthy of consideration, allowing them to experience the vibrant spirit of Las Vegas without breaking the bank.

Didn't come here to eat just drink but can't really go wrong with 2.50 coronas this is definitely is a college bar and a bit noisy what's wierd is there Oregon duck fans and not ASU fans? Great place for day drinking though

"A typical shopping mall, characterized by an assortment of retail establishments catering predominantly to the needs and preferences of tourists, with prices that are considerably higher than those found at local venues. Despite its reputation as a 'tourist trap,' this mall does feature a select number of unique specialty stores and occasional sales events, rendering it a worthwhile destination for visitors seeking a distinctive shopping experience. Additionally, the mall boasts an exceptional coffee establishment, as well as complimentary yoga classes offered at Lululemon on Sundays, further enhancing its appeal to patrons."
Popped in for a few tacos today... The carne asada was lacking in flavor, no marinade, and pretty bland. The carnitas were very good and I'd eat a dozen at one sitting :)

Nice local establishment with great food and fantastic patio to hang out on in the summer . The interior is dark and the tvs need to be bigger and placed in better viewing areas . If you don't know where this place is , it is Kind of hard to explain to people how to there . Still a nice clean and safe place to hang out .

This is your average Chinese restaurant. Cheap but average food. They have a really cheap lunch menu, for only $5.95 you get an entree and a drink.
Their customer service is very good. They checked on us on a regular basis and refilled our drinks in a timely matter. 
The food is just ok, but again you get what you pay for.
I found it kind of strange that they do not believe in plates.  The food is delivered on styrofoam and no serving spoon, which makes the food look even less appealing. 
Overall, the restaurant is just ok if you are looking for a cheap and quick meal.

I have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, and I must say that my experiences have been thoroughly satisfactory, with both the service and culinary offerings meeting my expectations. In fact, I recently indulged in their delectable Peanut Buster Parfait, which not only tasted divine but also bore a striking resemblance to the advertised image, a rarity among dining establishments. Consequently, when the craving for a Dairy Queen treat arises and I find myself in close proximity, I will unhesitatingly patronize this particular location for a satisfying repast.

After experiencing such a deplorable episode at Babystacks (refer to previous review), my acquaintance and I opted to venture towards Lulu's, seeking a more satisfactory dining experience. The stark contrast between the subpar service we had endured and the hospitable treatment we received at Lulu's was indeed palpable. Despite the fact that orders are placed at the counter, the eatery offers the convenience of seating in the Metro pizza area, which is particularly advantageous for families with young children. Additionally, the staff kindly delivered our beverages to our table, further facilitating the dining experience for us. When my companion requested that her egg be prepared over hard instead of over easy, the kitchen staff did not display any signs of annoyance or reluctance, illustrating their commitment to customer satisfaction. On previous occasions, the manager has exhibited exceptional kindness and made conscious efforts to ensure that we felt welcome.  

My culinary selection for the morning was the Herman breakfast sandwich, priced at approximately $8, which, although somewhat expensive, offered a satisfying combination of flavors and textures. The sandwich itself consisted of a pretzel bun adorned with a fried egg, sausage, cheese, and a tangy stone-ground mustard. While the chocolate croissant failed to meet my elevated standards, as I am a self-proclaimed connoisseur of the classic French pastry, the lemon tart proved to be a delightful surprise, evoking memories of a delectable sour cream lemon pie crafted by my spouse. The establishment customarily offers complimentary samples of cookies and muffins, contributing to the overall pleasant ambiance.

Read the reviews on Yelp while I was visiting Phoenix.  I am a Doo-Nut fiend, so was looking for a place.  Lamar's was middle of the road.  I am a classic glazed donut kind of guy and I love them even more when they are hot and fresh.  I think had I been there when the donuts were hot and fresh I would've enjoyed them more.  Yet, it wasn't bad.

Reid's purports to offer distinctive comestibles, and indeed, their gastronomic offerings are somewhat remarkable. Upon entering the establishment, one cannot help but be struck by the visually appealing display of artisanal meats and Fromagerie. The proprietors have curated an impressive selection of vintages, which patrons may sample in the adjacent wine bar, an intimate setting conducive to conviviality. Service is generally efficient and personable, particularly during the noontide hours when the throngs of hungry patrons descend upon the premises seeking sustenance. Observing the culinary creations emerging from the kitchen, one notes that they appear fresh and appetizing. Regrettably, the parking situation is less than ideal, necessitating a moderate hike for those who opt to drive. Furthermore, this writer found the grilled pimento cheese sandwich to be somewhat disappointing, lacking the piquancy one might expect from such an offering and bordering on excessive lubricity. Notwithstanding this minor setback, Reid's remains a suitable option for those seeking a hasty, satisfying repast or a brief wine-tasting excursion, although nearby competitors may offer more delectable alternatives for the discerning epicure.

"The delectable crepes boast an array of flavors, ranging from the traditional simplicity of lemon juice to the richness of Nutella complemented by bananas. In contrast, the savory crepes appear unimaginative and lacking in inspiration. However, the inviting ambiance of the coffee shop, enhanced by the well-crafted coffee, compensates for the deficiency. Unfortunately, the service has been inconsistent, marred by the presence of a bothersome fly during our last two visits."

"Upon entering the establishment, one is immediately struck by the presence of a mechanical bull, which serves as a central focal point within the venue and lends an air of rugged excitement to the proceedings. The atmosphere is further enhanced by the abundance of masculine patrons, whose boisterous revelry contributes to the overall ambiance of the establishment. The auditory senses are similarly stimulated by the high volume of the musical offerings, which serve to augment the convivial nature of the gathering. Of particular note, however, are the exceptional quality of the lettuce wraps served by the establishment, which truly distinguishes itself from the standard fare typically associated with such establishments. While the author's experience with similar venues may be limited, it is evident that this particular location offers a unique and enjoyable initiation into the local nightlife."

"I have been frequenting this establishment for approximately a decade, and while I have had a strong affinity for their culinary offerings in the past, recent experiences have left me feeling somewhat disillusioned and disappointed. The issues that have been raised by other patrons, such as the limited quantity of meat on the sandwiches, the high prices, and the sluggish service, have unfortunately become increasingly apparent. Furthermore, I must express my dismay at the lack of environmental consciousness displayed by the restaurant, as evidenced by their refusal to reuse punch cards and instead opting to discard and replace them, resulting in unnecessary waste. Despite these criticisms, I may still continue to visit, albeit with reduced frequency."

The Pros: Inexpensive menu, fresh food, great malts, clean restaurant, friendly smiling employees, pepper bar. 

Cons: Stale and not creative dining area, awkward layout in the dining room, seen before menu options, pre-made salad dressings.

Good for a quick burger. In my opinion there are other burger options in town that I prefer.

"This establishment undoubtedly offers an excellent venue for procuring delectable and affordable sushi for a hasty luncheon, thereby catering to individuals seeking a quick and satisfying repast. Nonetheless, it is essential to note that this eatery does not possess the optimal ambiance for a leisurely dining experience, as the seating arrangements are limited and the table settings consist of disposable utensils and Styrofoam cups. Furthermore, the waitstaff may exhibit a certain degree of inattention to detail, as evidenced by the delay in preparing the sushi rolls and the absence of sugar for the tea. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the rainbow roll and green tea offered by this restaurant are indeed exceptional, thereby rendering it a suitable destination for those seeking a satisfying and expedient meal. However, it is not recommended for dates or dinner due to the aforementioned limitations."

Nice seafood place away from the casinos.

Food: 7.5/10 - Nice menu selections. Well prepared.  The flavors will not wow you but they are a solid meal.  

Service: 8/10 - No problems. Nothing spectacular either.

Cleanliness: 8/10 - No visible issues.

Decor: 8.5 / 10 - Sat outside on a beautiful night.  Was very nice.  Inside looked nice as well.

Restrooms: 7/10 - no problems.

Parking: 9/10 - Tons of parking.  

Overall: 7/10 - A nice place to eat.  I personally like the Texas de Brazil located right next door MUCH better.

Upon entering the establishment, it became apparent that the SeaHawkers club had recently vacated the premises, leaving behind a scene of disarray and chaos, with the staff struggling to restore order and tidiness to the dining area, in preparation for the impending arrival of new patrons. Notwithstanding the prevailing bedlam, the restaurant managed to maintain an acceptable level of service, offering delectable fare and potables at reasonable prices, further enhanced by the availability of a discounted beverage promotion through the utilization of the 4Square mobile application, even during the peak hours of the day.

"A hospitable ambiance and proficient service are hallmarks of this establishment, rendering it an ideal setting for patrons seeking respite from exorbitant prices associated with mediocre beverages. Although the selection of draft beers may not boast an extensive array of options, the bartenders demonstrate a commendable level of attentiveness and helpfulness, ensuring that each patron's experience is optimized. Instances of inadvertently dispensed extra beverages are met with considerate explanations, fostering an atmosphere of transparency and customer satisfaction. As a frequent visitor, I have had the pleasure of witnessing such exceptional service on multiple occasions, leaving me with a favorable impression of this business and motivating me to continue offering my patronage."

I gave it a 3 star because overall the hotel was just ok, I did expect It to be better..  First time at the Trump hotel and found mold food in the refrigerator!! Customer service is not that great..Housekeeping took forever to clean my room, I did call early in the morning to inform them I need housekeeping which was provided but finish around 3pm... The hotel is away from the strip..we have to take taxi to and from Caesars Palace even though there was shuttle provided because we have to wait at least more then 25 min. Shuttle does stop at midnight which sucks because we can't enjoy ourselves just worrying the shuttle will stop soon and that's why we have to take taxi which charge us $20 plus tips and taxi driver doesn't want just $1 tip, they want more....
It's best to stay on the strip so no more taxi or shuttle rides !!
Pros:
Quiet, luxurious, doesn't smell, kitchen in the suites, luxurious bathroom
Cons:
just a few minor things. The shuttles stop way too early and it take a long time to pick you up. It's far away from the strip if you were to walk..there's really nothing to do at the hotel..it's just a basic hotel with a pool and a gym..

great eats, even if you don't get the all you can eat spaghetti. Had the arugula and white bean salad plus two penne pasta dishes. Both very good. Good Italian food in a nice atmosphere at decent prices with good waitstaff.

We have frequented this venerable establishment, which boasts an eclectic array of culinary delights, gaming facilities, and artisanal brews, on several occasions, and we must confess that the experience has been nothing short of delightful. The breakfast menu, in particular, offers an unparalleled combination of quality and affordability, with the steak and eggs option being a personal favorite, available for the remarkably reasonable price of $3.99. It is worth noting that this eatery also houses a brewery, which produces an impressive selection of craft beers, including an exceptional root beer that is not to be missed. While this may not be the most luxurious or high-end destination, it undoubtedly provides an excellent value for the money spent, and we would highly recommend it to anyone seeking a satisfying dining experience without breaking the bank. On a previous visit, we had the pleasure of enjoying a promotional offer, which allowed us to indulge in an unlimited number of Corona beers for a full hour, sans any obligation to make a purchase, and we were able to sample an impressive total of 22 Coronas, an experience that we found to be truly remarkable.

Service: our server was flustered with too many tables and we felt like a burden when we asked her for a refill of celery sticks.


mango-spicy: very spicy and good
garlic asian: not as spicy
jerk chicken: not spicy at all!!

Overall very good buffalo wings, though they could just throw in more celery sticks.

2X celery refills =$1.20 seriously???

Beware. You will get charged for extra celery sticks even though a stalk of celery is less than a buck each.

Napa location is on a different level compared to Vegas. The food and service at the bar were both a little rough. Our server/bartender completely forgot about us several times and we had to reorder a few times as well. In addition, I overheard the bartender blame the chef for an error in food to a customer. I thought that was very unprofessional. Quality of the food did not seem up to par from my previous experiences in Napa.

"I must confess an unwavering fondness for Trader Joe's; may I be so bold as to express my enthusiasm for this establishment? The prices and quality of their nuts (encompassing almonds, pecans, walnuts, et al.) and nut-based products (including almond butter, and so forth) are, in my humble opinion, unparalleled. Furthermore, their produce is of exceptional quality, and they offer an array of unique items that are simply unattainable elsewhere. Allow me to emphasize my unequivocal endorsement of Joe Joe's; indeed, it is nothing short of magnificent! 

However, I must deduct two stars from my rating due to the following factors:

1. The quest for a parking spot during peak hours (specifically between 12 pm and 1 pm from Monday to Friday) borders on the impossible. Accept the challenge at your own peril, dear reader! 

2. Lamentably, the store's dimensions are rather diminutive, leaving me with an inescapable feeling of disappointment. In spite of these drawbacks, I maintain that Trader Joe's is an outstanding retailer."

Oh Treasure Island, and your old-school pirate show, where have you gone?  Welcome to TI, and the scantily clad pirate show...my have times have changed.  Across the street from the Venetian/Palazzo sits TI.  Definitely has seen better days, and by that I mean pretty much everything.  Rooms, casino, food.  If you want to save a few bucks and stay down at this end of the Strip, this is your place.  Just be prepared to hear the pirate show every night!

You know, after going back to the convention for a second year and eating at the Golden Palace Buffet again, I have to say that ordering off of the menu provided a significant improvement over the buffet.\n\nThe food wasn't nearly as greasy and was actually quite flavorful.  I was pleased with my meal and I'm sure my friends were, too.  My friend, who was wearing a giant costume, was treated with courtesy.

"Preferring a culinary experience characterized by a pleasant combination of texture and flavor, specifically, a dish wherein the tofu is cooked to a satisfying firmness, devoid of excessive softness or squishiness, I placed an order for the yellow curry tofu, anticipating a delightful repast. Unfortunately, the restaurant's interpretation of this popular Thai dish fell short of my expectations, as the tofu was presented in a state of uninspiring softness, lacking the crispy exterior and tender interior that I had hoped for. Instead of being expertly fried or otherwise prepared, the tofu was merely cut into small pieces and added to the curry without further ado. While the rich, well-spiced curry sauce and generous portion of vegetables did somewhat compensate for this disappointment, the overall effect was diminished by the absence of a satisfying textural contrast. Notwithstanding this letdown, the eatery does offer a diverse selection of Thai dishes at reasonable prices during the lunch hour, and the unpretentious ambiance of the establishment, replete with high-top tables by the window and conventional tables inside, provided a suitable setting for a casual meal. However, the dearth of patrons during our weekday visit suggested that the restaurant may struggle to attract a consistent clientele."

"Upon returning to Las Vegas from an excursion to Phoenix, we opted to halt at this particular Subway establishment, strategically positioned on the right-hand side of the thoroughfare leading towards our destination. 

My order consisted of a 6-inch BMT sandwich, augmented with jalapeno cheddar bread, which I requested to be toasted. Furthermore, I customized my sandwich by adding an assortment of vegetables, including tomatoes, lettuce, green peppers, pepperoncinis, mustard, mayonnaise, oil, vinegar, salt, and pepper. The accommodating staff expedited the preparation of my meal, enabling me to partake in it without any significant delay. 

The quality of the ingredients utilized in the sandwich was exceptional, thereby contributing to its delectable flavor. This impromptu dining experience served as an optimal respite during our journey. Additionally, it is worth mentioning that the establishment boasts well-maintained restrooms, which are a welcome amenity for travelers seeking a brief pit stop. In light of the fact that every service station in Wickenberg was brimming with travelers availing themselves of the facilities, it is judicious to consider this Subway location as a viable alternative. 

In conclusion, based on the positive experience we had, it is highly likely that we shall revisit this eatery on future excursions between Phoenix and Las Vegas."

"During our most recent sojourn in Las Vegas, my associates and I opted to take advantage of an offer that allowed us to lodge at Treasure Island at a price that was considerably lower than usual. Upon arriving at the establishment, we observed the presence of a restaurant specializing in Vietnamese cuisine, which we found rather peculiar. Furthermore, we expressed our skepticism regarding the quality of the fare served within said eatery, as evidenced by our derisive comments directed towards those who had chosen to partake in their meals there, and presumably, pay an elevated price for the experience. Ironically, we would later find ourselves returning to the very same venue, albeit under different circumstances, as we sought sustenance to alleviate the unpleasant symptoms brought about by our excessive consumption of alcoholic beverages during the previous night's festivities. In conclusion, while the cost of dining at this particular Pho restaurant may be somewhat prohibitive, it remains a viable option for those seeking nourishment in the midst of a debilitating hangover, particularly for those already lodging at Treasure Island."

"It is rather perplexing that the culinary offerings at mainland L&Ls seem to lack the distinct flavor profile associated with those from Hawaii. The fare is palatable yet uninspired, which is somewhat disappointing given the brand's reputation for serving quality local-style comfort food. Furthermore, patrons should exercise vigilance when settling their bills, as the menu board prices may not align with the actual amount charged. Upon bringing this discrepancy to the attention of the staff member responsible for processing my transaction, their response was dismissive and unhelpful, citing the computerized system as the basis for the inconsistency. This raises concerns regarding the establishment's pricing policies and practices, which could potentially undermine customer trust and loyalty."

Had dinner with a large group. We had a superb wine, but I'm sure it was not cheap and was chosen by the host of the dinner. The food? Well...the chopped salad was pretty mediocre, and too filling with all the red kidney beans it it. The table breads and muffins were too dry, kind of inedible.

Duck pancake...like someone had poured half a bottle of cheap, sweet syrup on it so who knows what the duck tasted like.

The porterhouse lamb chops - very good. This was by far the best thing I had. The lamb was perfectly grilled, and the sauce was inoffensive so you could enjoy the meat. 

Dessert - that warm, pudding-like cake that I can't remember. It was good, and chocolate. Like many restaurants they served the dessert and then came around asking for coffee as kind of an afterthought. The coffee service took so long that it was tough to wait on eating the cake. Dang, I like coffee WITH dessert. But, most restaurants haven't figured out how to serve both at around the same time.

The restaurant is a nice spot in Caesars so I don't want to dissuade people from going. But, I'd make the grilled meat the centerpiece of what you order and not get too high on hope for the rest, based on what I experienced. And get a nice bottle of wine to go with it!

It is a Wal-Mart store location that has recently opened its doors to the public, and my initial thoughts were that perhaps it might possess a distinct ambiance, a departure from the conventional Wal-Mart experience to which I had grown accustomed. However, upon entering the premises, I was quickly disabused of such notion, as it became apparent that this establishment adhered to the standard template associated with the Wal-Mart brand, complete with an array of unremarkable products offered at prices designed to appeal to budget-conscious consumers. Furthermore, the clientele that frequents this store appears to be drawn from the same demographic that has come to be synonymous with the Wal-Mart shopping experience, as depicted on websites such as peopleofwalmart.com, characterized by an atmosphere in which children vociferously proclaim their knowledge of numerals, while adults engage in behaviors that impede the progress of others, all within an environment that seems tailored to accommodate the preferences of senior citizens who prefer a leisurely pace when navigating the various aisles.

This is a 'Superstore' and the biggest close by supermarket for Leith / Shore residents.
