It has 2 entrances one at the Tesco Car park at the back and the back entrance on Duke Street. 

It is a Tesco supermarket and they do what supermarkets do. In addition to that they have also clothes and electricals available.

For a so-called Superstore it is a little small. but it supplies what is needed and it is open from 06:00 till Midnight. 

Be aware that the law of baying alcohol before 10am  and after 10pm also counts for supermarkets.. Some Leith residents tend to 'forget' that rule and get into a discussion a the till. - happened a few times. 

They have a section dedicated to self-service tills and 2 fast lane basket only cashiers. 

They are not as frequently visited by me, certainly after the whole Horse meat scandal. But they are a handy go to for packaged products. Whiskies, spirits, wine and chocolates. - that's about it. 

Not the worst of shops, but not the best either

"Based on the copious acclaim this establishment had received, I was anticipating an exceptional experience, but unfortunately, it fell short of my expectations. Notwithstanding, I must commend the ambiance and aesthetic appeal of the venue, which were undeniably impressive. My beverage of choice, a nonfat chai latte, was somewhat unremarkable and lacking in distinctiveness, which may have contributed to my underwhelming experience. However, I must emphasize that the company was pleasant, the atmosphere was agreeable, and the interior design was indeed captivating. If I were to revisit, I would perhaps reconsider my beverage selection and opt for their coffee offerings instead, in the hopes of a more satisfactory encounter."

Not bad. Better than other fast food joints in Scotland. Actually WAY better than the fast food joints in Scotland. \n\nI kinda expected more, but was won over by the rootbeer float. That was definitely worth going. OMG, you have not experienced American fast food/diner fare til you've had a rootbeer float. Brought me back to the days of Dairy Queen and the likes. Yet the burger wasn't all that. It was ok but it just felt like there was something missing, to make it a home run. Also, I probably should've ordered the cajun fries. I ordered the onion rings. They were good but clearly frozen. So now I'm on a mission to find fresh made onion rings, any rec's?

"Although I had aspired to procure a reservation at the central area, I would have opted for the Flamingo establishment for a slightly higher tariff, considering my current knowledge. Nonetheless, I cannot express any dissatisfaction due to the fact that, despite its minor shortcomings in terms of cleanliness and maintenance, our accommodations provided us with an outdoor balcony, which surpassed my sister's lodgings at the Mirage hotel. Furthermore, the breakfast spread presented an adequate variety of edibles, without any notable culinary highlights, but also without any adverse gastronomical repercussions, which I deem a paramount aspect of any hospitality experience. Therefore, while the lodging may not constitute a substantial upgrade from a Motel 6, it still represents a marginal improvement and a reasonable value for a location situated at the heart of the Strip."

Went here for dinner last night. 3 courses and a glass of wine (making use of the £10 set menu) strikes me as good value for money. The service from boath the greeter and waitress was pleasant and attentive and my sardine starter and hake main course w/ side of spinach were both very well cooked and presented.


 I'd like to give them a further half star but as ever having to dock a full one instead. The cheese board was the one minorly negative aspect of the meal. It could have done with a couple more oatcakes and maybe more onion marmalde and the slice of brie had clearly been allowed to dry out and harden a bit + the cheese knife had seen better days (the plastic handle was cracked clean through on both sides near the base of the blade).


 No idea if the interior's changed much since it was a Harry Ramsden's but it's well decorated and gets a lot of sun. I intend to go back.

"Utopian haven for hipsters. Bring on the 1920s era boots with dungarees that are a perfect match. 

Exquisite ambiance. A magnificent, vintage roaster is showcased and utilized extensively. 

Evidently, there is a scarcity of artisanal coffee in my hometown. A queue extended nearly to the entrance. 

I managed to acquire an espresso. It was presented promptly and proficiently. In my modest opinion, the coffee was satisfactory...not exceptional. An excess of fruitiness/acidity. Insufficient rich, velvety texture reminiscent of chocolate. However, that's merely my taste. Not necessarily everyone else's preference.

Nonetheless, my companion ordered a pour-over. And, pour-overs require a considerable amount of time. Following ten minutes of waiting, we inquired. Oh! We neglected your pour-over coffee! Wait an additional ten minutes. Derrrr...I'm unwilling to wait another ten minutes, but I suppose I must since my girlfriend and I both have an addiction to caffeine and cannot function adequately without it. 

Fortunately, I had the opportunity to sample my companion's brew, and it was delightful. 

In summary, they possess a successful formula, but minor adjustments are necessary. I would certainly revisit."

We ate there with the family, nice, cozy environment, it was kind of dead for a Sunday. At the entrance of the buffet it smelled like sewer, we were grossed out but wanted to give it a try. We eat sushi 15 times a month... no joke! This place is NOT grade A sushi at all.. you can compare it to Grocery store sushi... it was OK. \nThe variety of the buffet was really good, it would even be better if everything tasted good for that amount of money!

We saw this place on Bar Rescue and wanted to check it out. My wife and I showed up about 9:30 PM. I was starving and planned on eating here. Unfortunately the bartender said the kitchen was closed because they had a slow night. I had one beer and left only because I couldn't keep drinking without getting some kind if food in my belly. Next time in Vegas I will definitely give this place another shot. And maybe more stars. The locals were extremely friendly and greeted us as soon as we walked in. The bartender was also very friendly. Wish I could have experienced the food.

"I thoroughly relished the culinary offerings, specifically the chicken fried steak, which was served with an ample portion of mashed potatoes and a savory gravy that complemented the dish perfectly. Additionally, a side of green beans and a preliminary salad preceded the main course, contributing to an overall satisfying gastronomical experience. However, upon entering the establishment, we encountered a degree of perplexity due to the absence of a clear greeting protocol. Despite the cozy ambiance, it is crucial for the staff to maintain a vigilant attitude towards welcoming patrons and clarifying the waiting process, which currently seems to rely on an informal 'first-come, first-served' basis. Notwithstanding this drawback, my evaluation of the restaurant remains neutral, augmented by my appreciation for its family-owned nature and the palatable fare."

Food and service were okay. Among the dishes I ate were sweet & sour soup and tofu with baby bok choy.\n\nThe decor seemed fancy. I liked the jellyfish lights near the entrance and the wood-covered menus.

Very nice bar and the prices are very reasonable, if they put 2 (diamond) tables in there instead of 1 bar table and 1 build at home type pool table it would make this bar a very awesome place to hang out at and take pool league teams all week 24/7.

"Average American eatery providing satisfactory culinary offerings, yet lacking any truly distinctive features. Suitable for those seeking an unremarkable dining experience. The bar section tends to be rather boisterous, making communication and auditory comprehension somewhat challenging."

Pros: Nicely laid out store with a wide variety of vintage merchandise.\nCons:  Booths are not individually signed with percentage off discounts for store sales which makes things rather confusing.  Employees are hard to identify as they don't wear aprons, badges, etc.  Your purchase will be wrapped in used newspaper instead of clean wrapping paper.  All things that can be improved upon for a better shopping experience.

I liked this place.  The ambiance is nice and the service is superb.  The mojito was delicious and so was the waffles.  My daughter was excited by the red velvet pancakes.  The down side was price - SO EXPENSIVE!  An order of pancakes was $13!  I can't afford to frequent this place very often.

A good place to eat, trendy. You can't call ahead or make reservations so expect to wait about 20-30 minutes for a table. The food is good, but when I went there I got an Eggs Benedict and it was more of a hard boiled egg, though it was well-seasoned. \n\nI'll be giving it another try, but I was much more excited about this place before I tried it.

We halted our perambulation at this establishment for the purpose of partaking in a midday repast, as we were experiencing fatigue and an absence of inclination to continue our pedestrian journey. Both of us opted for the creamy potato and leek soup, which proved to be a delectable choice. My companion had the tuna sandwich accompanied by a side of fries, while I selected the unembellished green salad, also with a side of fries. I was dismayed to discover that my salad contained several leaves that were not as fresh as they could have been, yet the waitress, Dana, did not include them in the calculation of our bill. The fries were served hot and crispy, their flavor being enhanced by the addition of aromatic herbs. While the culinary offerings were certainly satisfactory, they did not possess any exceptional qualities that would render them memorable. Nonetheless, Dana's hospitable demeanor and attentive service left a favorable impression upon us.

Quite disappointing when I expected the same flavor and price when I was in LA. 

Don't get me wrong, the waiters/waitress were super friendly. We ordered bulgogi and ribs. The food was flavorful but average. No refills for the side dishes when you are grilling at the grill-your-own-bbq table. 

Extra: went with a groupon deal but still ended up paying way more than expected and received less food. 

TL;DR: ok place for food, clean, but does not justify the price.

Upstream, an eatery situated in Charlotte, is presumably perceived as one of the premier dining establishments within the city's culinary landscape. As an individual hailing from Philadelphia, a metropolis renowned for its exceptional gastronomic offerings and celebrated chefs, my perspective might be slightly biased. Notwithstanding, the comestibles presented by Upstream were undoubtedly satisfactory, albeit not remarkably extraordinary or astonishing. Each dish, excluding the humble house salad, was regrettably imbued with an excessive quantity of salt, which somewhat marred the overall flavor profile. My spouse indulged in the tuna, while I opted for the seabass. Although both dishes were palatable, they failed to ascend to the lofty heights of truly exceptional cuisine. We would consider revisiting Upstream for its raw or sushi options, but our enthusiasm for the cooked dishes was somewhat tempered. The aforementioned house salad proved to be the zenith of my dining experience, whereas the crab bisque demonstrated considerable gustatory appeal as well. In terms of service, the restaurant's staff exhibited commendable proficiency, although their pace was somewhat languid. Our server, in particular, distinguished himself as one of the most erudite and knowledgeable members of the waiting staff we have had the pleasure of encountering since relocating from Pennsylvania.

After Harlow's down the road was so packed we couldn't park, we decided to give this new breakfast cafe a try.  The portions are extremely generous and overall the food was really good.  The prices are a little high I think, but not so much that I wouldn't return.  I knocked down a star because the ham I received was \"off\" and tasted like it was past it's shelf life, and the oj was just so-so.  They do give complimentary chocolate covered strawberries that are epic!

"In the event that you are hankering for some barbecue while at an airport, rest assured that your dining prospects are somewhat restricted, my dear companion. However, this particular establishment offers a relatively affordable and satisfactory culinary experience within the confines of an airport eatery. While the quality of the barbecue may not be exceptional, it manages to surpass the alternatives situated nearby. For your perusal, I opted for the tri-meat platter, which included a rather generous portion of brisket that, regrettably, was largely composed of fat. The pulled pork was moderately tender, while the smoked turkey, though slightly dry, boasted a discernible smokiness. Patrons are given the option of a solitary sauce variety, which, although not mustard-based, is nevertheless recommended due to its subtlety. As for health-conscious side dishes, I implore you to maintain realistic expectations, considering the nature of the establishment."

....and boy are my arms tired!

Comedy clubs are easy to review when focusing on the club itself, and not the talent.  You could be in the perfect comedy club and see a horrible act, just as you could see something amazing at a dive bar's open mic night.  

This "club" is really  a conference room that has been converted into a comedy club.  The staff sets up chairs around the room for the patrons the night of the show, adding seats when needed.  There are a few VIP couches, but since this intimate setting is quite quaint, there really is no reason to pay the high price for them.

There are two waitresses who run around frantically trying to fill all the patrons' orders, but be ready to wait for your beverage.  Walking up to the bar in the room is usually a better way to go.  

I saw the late (9pm) show on a Saturday night.  Seating starts at 8:30, so get there early if you want to sit in the front.  Really, there isn't a horrible seat in the house though.  

I saw Todd Paul the night I went in, and laughed my A$$ off.  He was charismatic and hilarious.  His act was a mix of magic, stunts, and comedy.  He did an amazing job of making fun of Las Vegas shows, specifically magic shows.  I would definitely return for another fun night.

We indulged in a culinary experience at this establishment several weeks ago, pursuant to a suggestion proffered by the lodging facility in which we were residing. Although I do not partake in the consumption of steak, a number of my associates do, and they expressed their satisfaction with the quality of the dish. I opted for the Chicken Peppered Penne, which proved to be an exquisite selection. Following my request for an additional degree of piquancy, the culinary staff accommodatingly augmented the spiciness of the dish. The pasta was cooked to perfection, the sauce exhibited a velvety texture, and the flavors present in the dish were truly delectable. The attentiveness of the servers and the reasonable pricing further enhanced our dining experience.

This culinary establishment serves the most delectable and flavorsome Pho within the confines of Scottsdale; however, in relation to the quality and magnitude of the dish, it can be classified as merely average or unremarkable. The broth, which is the fundamental component of the dish, is rich and savory, but unfortunately, its quantity is rather limited and its cost is disproportionately high. It appears that the restaurant is reluctant to provide an adequate amount of noodles and meat, leading to a sense of dissatisfaction and underfillment. Despite this, the service staff is quite attentive and friendly, which somewhat compensates for the deficiencies in the food. Ultimately, it is recommended to patronize this establishment, but it would be wise to supplement your meal with additional noodles and meatballs to ensure a satisfying dining experience.

"This public house exudes an aura of pleasantness, albeit with a strong inclination towards catering to the sensibilities of travelers and sightseers. Within the confines of its upper level, the culinary offerings are undoubtedly delectable, yet the ambiance fails to compare favorably with the environs situated below. Downstairs, an impressive array of authentic ales awaits discerning patrons, raising questions regarding the logic behind offering a glass of effervescent wine as a token of appreciation for relinquishing one's calling card, when either a sampling of these exceptional brews or a dram of fine whisky would prove far more apropos. Furthermore, the establishment takes pride in meticulously tracking the volume of hand-pumped ales dispensed on a weekly basis, as evidenced by the tally of 1987 recorded during the previous week, which I found rather fascinating."
Not a big fan but Tax free yeah!  Off base has more selection and you can find deals. Unless your buying a high price item i would shop elsewhere. The lines get bad so don't be in a rush.

"Alright, the embellishments within this establishment are rather kitsch and over-the-top, yet they seem to be an integral aspect of the overall experience, perhaps even intentionally so, as if to convey a sense of steadfastness and tradition amidst an ever-changing landscape; furthermore, the wait staff's attire, while aesthetically displeasing, seems to be a deliberate choice, evocative of the utilitarian and somewhat oppressive nature of workplace attire, as seen in films such as Office Space; we visited this venue for breakfast, and while the culinary offerings were satisfactory, the divergence from the typical buffet-style fare found in nearby Disney-fied Las Vegas strip locales was palpable."

"Although the beer did not possess any extraordinary qualities, it was still palatable. It is worth mentioning that the establishment boasted an agreeable ambiance. However, it appeared that their primary emphasis lay in offering beverages with a sweeter flavor profile. Upon further inspection, it became apparent that they had depleted their stock of lighter brews, including the blonde variety. Consequently, we shall endeavor to sample their wares at a later time and reassess our initial evaluation."

I would not endorse this airline if you are embarking on a journey with minors, as it offers only basic amenities and lacks entertainment facilities, particularly on lengthy flights; there was no television on our five-hour voyage from New York, which resulted in the children on board becoming restless and irritable due to the lack of diversions; the seating was also quite confined and diminutive, which further exacerbated the discomfort; additionally, the aircraft appeared to be somewhat antiquated. Instead, I would suggest opting for Delta Airlines, which offers a more comprehensive range of services and amenities tailored to accommodate families with young children.

Decent place, good food, great  atmosphere to watch a game. Thank god the karaoke was not there tonight. Service could be better, mainly faster. The servers are spread too thin, as there seem to never be enough top handle the crowd. Otherwise a decent pace too have a drink, grab a bite and watch sports.

This place is open 24 hours and is located outside in the Paris Hotel Casino. It very nice and the Ambiance is really nice and classy. Food is actually OK, but nothing special. The dessert are great though and actually cheap for the amount you get. I got the banana split and share it with two other people and we didn't finish it. Cost like $10 bucks or something. The Sugar Factory store however is over price. Mints and such are like $5-$8 for a small tin. It one of those place you should try once. It a fun place and has outside seating. Dessert and Drinks is what they known for.

"Gastronomical assessment on a scale of one to ten, based on a singular visitation:
Eight for comestibles
Five starred beverages
Eight for hospitality
Eight for ambiance
Seven for value

Personally, I found the culinary offerings to be relatively satisfactory. Particularly noteworthy was the manner in which the yolk of the eggs rested atop the dish, a hallmark of New Mexico's gastronomical tradition. The blue corn tortillas accompanying my enchiladas were substantial and possessed an appreciable texture. Regrettably, the margaritas failed to meet expectations, exhibiting an unpleasant sweet and sour taste, devoid of any discernible bite or depth. Furthermore, the machine-made quality of their production was evident, detracting from the overall experience. Lastly, the serving of salsa, while possessing a commendable level of piquancy, lacked distinction in terms of flavor profile."

During our excursion to Fiesta Mall accompanied by my offspring who was undergoing a haircut, we opted to partake in culinary indulgences. Following a circuitous route throughout the food court, we were approached by a representative of Sarku Japan extending an offer of complimentary samples of their teriyaki chicken. Upon sampling the delicacy, my progeny felt compelled to procure a meal from the establishment. The personnel were affable, and the cost was reasonable. He selected the teriyaki chicken and shrimp dish. The quantity of sustenance he received surpassed expectations, and he expressed contentment with its flavor corresponding to its intended essence. A definitive venue for future visits and one that we highly endorse!

The hostess, Maria, exhibited a discernible expression of incredulity by rolling her eyes, which appeared to be indicative of an attitude predicament, whereas Kyahl, a name phonetically reminiscent of Kyle, demonstrated a relatively adept proficiency in responding to the queries posed by my spouse's mother, despite the culinary offerings being somewhat inconsistent in quality, with the veal parmesan garnering approval, while the macaroni rosa suffered from an unfortunate lack of flavor and the broccoli within remained undercooked, and the pasta maintained a firmer texture than what we are accustomed to.

I've been here a few times and its decent food. There is nothing special about this place that makes me want to specifically go back. Although, if someone is holding a party or special occasion here I doubt I would avoid this place.

I've never been here just for lunch or dinner, so that may effect my review. Although, I've eaten this food on multiple occasions for events at the restaurant. Its good Indian food, and you can never say no to good Indian food. It just wasn't spectacular. I would give most Indian food places 5-stars if the quality of the meat they used was better and if the quality of everything they use is just better. The salads weren't green, the meat in the korma and tikka was very small. It just felt like they were cheaping out on us.

Desserts weren't really special either. If you give me gulab jamun or some jelebi, I am a sucker for that stuff. Theirs was decent, but there wasn't much of it available. However, there really isn't much better stuff in AZ in this vicinity. I'd say India Gate is a little better, maybe try that place out first.

"Oh my goodness, what a disappointment! I have penned a review of their Pecos and Washington site, which I adore and yearn for during the summer months when hankering for seafood. Nonetheless, this particular establishment seemed to be lacking in a certain je ne sais quoi. I requested the shrimp ceviche and fish tacos, and unfortunately, they failed to impress me with their flavors. The ceviche had an overpowering fishy taste, necessitating copious amounts of lemon and salt, while the tacos were uninspiring and lackluster. \n\nThe eatery's ambiance was pleasant, and the server was friendly and attentive. However, the overall experience fell short of expectations. My dining companions concurred, having experienced the exceptional quality of the other location. I shall not be returning to this site, particularly given the elevated prices, although the cost would be warranted if the "Islitas" experience were replicated here. Unfortunately, that was not the case. Instead, I recommend visiting their north Las Vegas location, despite their steep pricing, as they possess the potential for improvement. Thus, I award them three stars, or else I would have given them two."

Ordered the white pizza with tomato onion and kalamata olives and was pretty tasty. They recommended that the pizza be cooked for an extended amount of time because of the wet ingredients which caused the crust to be slightly burned with a tad too much crunch for my tastes.  Plenty of staff inside.  Interior atmosphere was o.k.  The only markdown I give them is the price. It seemed to lack value and was over priced.  Probably will not return given it is too far away from me...and even if there were one closer, other places would get my dollar first.

This place was not what I expected.  It is a huge open space with a large bar stuck right in the middle.  The menu is more upscale than the usual sports 'bar' selections, but I guess that is the difference between sports bar and sports grill?

The food was good, but if I remember correctly they had little to no draft beer.  They could have had Bud or Coors or something, but to me that translates to no beer on tap.  

They have a lot of flat screen tvs as they should,  but I like a little bit more character in my sports bar.  This is much too commercial for my taste.

"While there may not be anything particularly extraordinary about this hotel within a hotel, aside from perhaps the convenience of abbreviated check-in queues, which is indeed a welcome amenity, the ambiance of the accommodations themselves does exude an essence of Asian-inspired elegance. However, it is somewhat unfortunate that the overall experience fails to meet the expectations typically associated with a five-star establishment. This is largely due to the fact that Caesars Palace, despite its venerable reputation, appears to have fallen victim to the pitfalls of aging infrastructure and inadequate staffing, resulting in sluggish service and an overall atmosphere that falls short of the luxurious standards set by comparable resorts such as Wynn, Bellagio, and The Venetian."

Joe's has been the recipient of our patronage on multiple occasions, and we have consistently savored the culinary offerings presented by this esteemed establishment. Unfortunately, the quality of the service we have received during these visits has been subpar, bordering on the unacceptable. Despite this drawback, we would still advocate for a visit to Joe's, as the ambiance is convivial, and the fare is delectable. However, it is crucial to cultivate an attitude of patience, as the tardiness of the staff can be exasperating. By doing so, you can optimize your dining experience and ensure that your evening is free from undue stress and annoyance.
Great selection of beer. Plenty of it! The food is so-so. Typical bar-food. Very nice wait-staff and bar tenders. Large enough place to accommodate a busy night. Worth the stop.

I visited this establishment for an evening meal with my significant other last night, and I must concur with the prevailing sentiment expressed in previous reviews, specifically regarding the outdoor seating area, which boasts a remarkable panorama and an unexpected sense of seclusion despite its proximity to Indian School Road. The wine and beer selection is indeed impressive, offering an array of local options that I found particularly appealing. However, my culinary experience was somewhat disappointing. I initiated my meal with the fries, which were flavored with rosemary and parmesan and accompanied by a dipping sauce akin to a thousand island dressing. While they were certainly palatable, they failed to exceed my expectations. For our main courses, we opted for the sausage and mushroom pizza, as well as the penne ragu. The pizza was undoubtedly delectable, featuring caramelized onions, three varieties of mushrooms, and Italian sausage, all atop a crust that struck the perfect balance between crispness and tenderness, rendering it suitable for consumption with utensils. The ragu, on the other hand, was rather unconventional; it brought to mind the assortment of ingredients typically found within a shredded beef burrito, but instead of being enveloped in a tortilla, it was served in a bowl with penne pasta beneath. Although it was not unpalatable, it was unexpected and left me feeling ambivalent. I do regret not indulging in their dessert offerings, as they appeared quite enticing, and I intend to sample them during a future visit. In conclusion, I consider this establishment an excellent venue for enjoying appetizers and beverages, particularly on their exceptional patio.

"Prodigious coffee connoisseurs who relish the rich flavors of expertly brewed beverages may find it challenging to accurately assess the quality of a cafe's signature edibles, such as doughnuts or bagels, if they are currently abstaining from consuming them; thus, it is advisable to solicit my opinion on these culinary staples at a later time, when I have had the opportunity to indulge in them and formulate a well-informed evaluation, perhaps after a 40-pound weight gain."

I came here with some friends yesterday and we shared a number of items. As I walked in, I noticed how lovely it smelled and was excited to try their waffles.
 
We sat and perused the menu for a while and I was a little disappointed that no one really checked on us or even asked if we wanted waters or more menus than just the one for our group of three. We finally figured out what we wanted and went up to the counter to order.

The lady behind he counter kept interrupting my dining companion as he started to order by yelling behind to another person who worked there. I thought that was a little rude, so that definitely put me off.

Our food took a while to come, but it looked really pretty. 

What we ordered:
-red velvet wafflenut 
-Nutella and almond wafflenut 
-The Fat Elvis waffle
-Strawberry and chocolate waffle
-Vegas churro waffle with honey, cinnamon, sugar and vanilla ice cream

Everything was solid. The consensus was that the churro waffle was the favorite and I personally enjoyed the strawberry waffle, minus the chocolate sauce. 

Service needs work and the location is awkward, so I don't see myself making much effort to come back to this place in the future.

"Notwithstanding the celerity of the service, the ostensible quality of the burger, hotdog, and fries did not justify the exorbitant tariff, thereby precipitating a sense of disappointment and disillusionment among patrons who had anticipated a more satisfactory dining experience commensurate with the escalated prices; nevertheless, Inn n Out remains my preferred fast food burger establishment, while Bachi Burger maintains its distinction as my top choice for an upscale burger venue within the Las Vegas metropolitan area."

"It is a location frequently visited by travelers seeking leisure activities, and it is not uncommon for the delay in securing a table to be utterly abysmal. Thus, it is imperative to be cognizant of this fact beforehand. The dish consisting of noodles topped with a crispy duck confit is, without a doubt, utterly sublime. However, its cost relative to its quantity is somewhat disproportionate, as the serving size falls short of expectations considering the premium price point. This, in essence, constitutes my primary criticism of LOS. Either the portion sizes should be more generous given the tariff or the culinary offerings should exhibit flawless execution. Unfortunately, this disparity between quality and price resulted in the deduction of two stars from my overall rating."

My wife dragged me in here after she tried their surf n turf and raved about it. I can't comment on that yet.
We sat at the bar and played poker for awhile. Not a big deal but they make you play max bet for a 2nd drink. They were nice enough to warn me about that and still comped my 2nd drink. Might be a reason why we were about the only ones playing.
We ordered food and then sat at a table and brought our drinks with. The portions were big for the sandwiches (philly is great) and very good BUT wait till you get the bill. Yes, we saw the prices but by the time we got done with food and tip it was almost $40 for 2 sandwiches and we didn't have any drinks to pay for. 
It was good but I just don't see the attraction for a sandwich place and their prices.

We indulged in an intimate dining experience at this establishment for our engagement celebration with our dearest family members. The ambiance was vibrant and bustling on a Wednesday evening, with a scarcity of parking spaces that proved to be a minor inconvenience. Our party of thirteen was accommodated in a cozy corner proximate to the entrance, where the influx of chilly air and pungent cigarette odors occasionally permeated the atmosphere. Fortunately, my siblings possess diminutive statures, which enabled them to occupy the seats adjacent to the wall without any significant discomfort. However, it is worth noting that the seating arrangement was somewhat cramped and would have posed a challenge for individuals of average build.

The culinary offerings were diverse and included traditional Chinese delicacies such as lobster, red trout, fried flounder, chicken, beef, and an assortment of vegetables. While the fare was satisfactory, it did not exceed my expectations, and a minor mistake in one of the children's orders slightly marred the dining experience. Nevertheless, my grandmother appeared to enjoy the meal, and her satisfaction was of paramount importance to me. In conclusion, although I prefer other establishments, I would not object to revisiting this venue in the future, provided that I am not subjected to the discomfort of sitting beside the entrance during inclement weather.

Paul Martin's has a lot going for it - too bad the stuff on the periphery was bad. 

Paul Martin's is a nice and rather classy steakhouse that definitely reminds me of D.C. steakhouses. The lighting is dark but pleasant, the music energetic but quiet, and the ambiance rather pleasant. 

The food is also good. I had the Sunday special offering, which is salad, prime rib, and ice cream for $25. The salad was good and had a decent flavor palette without being overwhelming.  The prime rib was tender and had an amazing spice rub that took it to the next level, but the interior was something of a vast wasteland of okay meat. The desert didn't happen for me - they had no options for lactose intolerant patrons, which was rather disappointing (and perplexing, given the upper echelons this place places itself in). 

The service was rather poor. The server was clearly overwhelmed at times - at one point, he responded to our lactose intolerance inquiry by telling us that the ice cream was gluten free. It actually became rather offensive when we were made to feel guilty about using one of their gift cards - I have no idea why a steakhouse would make paying customers feel so awkward about using a gift card they sold!

Long story short, the food here is four stars, the service two. Three seems appropriate.
Staff here is usually very nice and helpful and not overbearing. Everything is kept nice and tidy. I just feel that this location does lack in variety and sizes...

"Consequently, it is our considered opinion that Uncle Bears constitutes an ideal venue for social gatherings and casual dining experiences, facilitating as it does, an agreeable ambiance conducive to conviviality and relaxation. Although the menu may not boast an extensive array of culinary delights, it does feature a selection of delectable offerings, specifically including the slider variety, which consistently impresses with its satisfying flavor profile. Furthermore, the chicken fajitas merit high praise for their palatable quality, refuting as they do, unfounded claims of rubbery texture. 
  A most appreciable aspect of this establishment lies in its impressive beer selection, featuring an assortment of locally brewed Four Peaks varieties alongside an array of nationally recognized microbrews. The interior design and motif, characterized by elements reminiscent of canine companions, contributes further to the welcoming atmosphere, prompting patrons to ponder, albeit bemusedly, the curious absence of images showcasing their own cherished canines. Ultimately, Uncle Bears qualifies as a quintessential neighborhood tavern, offering a hospitable setting suitable for casual dining, socializing, and indulging in a diverse range of beverages."

D'Arcy McGee's serves up a mix of various cuisines that can be best summed up as Anglo-Saxon origin.  Ranging from dishes such as Irish boxty, corned beef and cabbage, Scotch eggs, Canadian poutine, and British Yorkshire pudding, portions are hearty and service is cheerful and pleasant.  The food quality itself is just OK, but it's a nice change of pace from your standard wings, pizza, or sandwiches that you find at other bar-type restaurants.

"Although the pho served at this establishment may be of satisfactory quality, it fails to rank among the superior offerings of its genre that are available in the city of Pittsburgh, particularly when considering the absence of fresh lettuce and herbs as an accompaniment. However, it is worth noting that the proprietor of this business exhibits a commendable level of cordiality towards patrons."

This Marble Slab Creamery is located in Stonecrest Shopping Center, towards the front of the development near JoJo's, Miro, Dean & Deluca, etc.  It's your standard ice cream shop.  It had a decent variety of flavors, along with some \"Ice Cream Cupcakes\" that I had never seen before.  Whole ice cream cakes in various sizes were also included in a stand-up freezer.  A few chairs and tables scattered about, but this is located near the plaza with plenty of outdoor seating near the big fountain, should weather permit.  \n\nOn this visit, I decided to get one of the ice cream cupcakes to try later - it was fine.  I purchased a Birthday Cake milkshake along with that, which wasn't blended particularly well, so the first sips were just sweet milk, followed by clumps of ice cream.  Again, fine.  Nothing special.  The employees were nice enough.  I wasn't wowed, but wasn't expecting to be - it was A-OK.

This particular venue boasts a proximate location in close vicinity to an outlet mall, thereby rendering it easily accessible to patrons. Within the establishment's premises, staff members proffer packing tape to customers upon request, a convenience notably absent at certain alternative locations where purchase is mandatory. Furthermore, the personnel assigned to customer service duties exhibit a demeanor characterized by kindness and helpfulness, a stark contrast to the demeanor displayed by certain individuals employed by the United States Postal Service.

My spouse and I decided to make a brief visit to this establishment prior to attending a cinematic production. As we had already partaken in our evening meal, we opted to solely indulge in alcoholic beverages and sweet treats.

Upon entering the premises, we elected to sit on the outdoor patio, which offered a pleasant atmosphere. Despite being the lone patrons occupying the patio, we were concerned that our presence might be overlooked by the staff. However, our concerns were quickly assuaged, as the service we received was quite satisfactory.

My companion opted for a bottled beverage, specifically a beer, while I chose to sample their frozen strawberry margarita. Unfortunately, the margarita lacked the intensity of flavor that I had anticipated, with the strawberry essence being somewhat diluted. My spouse, on the other hand, was pleasantly surprised by the taste of his beer, a brew named Victoria, which he found to be quite palatable. In addition, I requested a serving of frozen ice cream, selecting the vanilla variety. The visual presentation of the dessert was quite appealing, and I thoroughly enjoyed the crispy, deep-fried ice cream.

Prior to departing for the cinema, I took advantage of the facilities, specifically the women's restroom. I was favorably impressed by the spaciousness and cleanliness of the bathroom, which featured a large, full-length mirror. Additionally, the handicapped/nursing facility was exceptionally roomy and well-appointed.

In conclusion, our brief excursion to this eatery proved to be an enjoyable experience, and we may consider returning for a future dinner date.

Rented a twenty-five footlong recreational vehicle that encountered thrice electrical malfunctions during a ten-day excursion. Fortunately, the rental company's customer support staff proficiently arranged for a field technician to visit us at distant national parks to diagnose and rectify the issues. Regrettably, the motorhome had been inadequately maintained prior to our rental, resulting in persistent problems. Despite this setback, we enjoyed our journey after resolving the battery-related difficulties. I would consider renting from them again, but I would insist on a more recent model with lower mileage and thoroughly inspect the vehicle before embarking on my trip.

We indulged in a culinary excursion to Fairview Grill one evening, anticipating a convivial ambiance, delectable pub fare, and an assortment of potables. Our expectations were thoroughly fulfilled, as we savored an array of flavorsome dishes and beverages. Utilizing a complimentary entree voucher, we discovered the prices to be eminently reasonable, with most entrees, primarily consisting of sandwiches and burgers, priced at approximately $8, constituting an exceptional value given the copious portions served. Both of us opted for burgers, which we found to be exceedingly satisfying, accompanied by fries and onion rings that garnered favorable reviews. Our server demonstrated impressive proficiency, accurately recalling our orders, including specific requests, without resorting to note-taking. She maintained a high level of attentiveness, ensuring a steady supply of beverages and fostering a welcoming atmosphere. The setting itself exuded a relaxed, casual aura, mirrored by the cordial demeanor of patrons, including two gentlemen who warmly greeted us upon entry and inquired about our well-being. Given our proximity to Fairview Grill, we shall certainly revisit this establishment, potentially taking advantage of their pool tables for a recreational diversion. While it remains to be seen how Fairview Grill ranks among local pubs, our experience was undoubtedly pleasant and fulfilling.

"The lodging establishment and its personnel are exceptional. I have a predilection for Hilton hotels and, in terms of accommodations, this particular venue is satisfactory. However, the location is not optimal due to the necessity of utilizing taxi services to reach destinations beyond walking distance; nevertheless, the guestroom and overall structure are quite pleasant. 

It is advisable to avoid participating in a timeshare sales presentation if feasible. The reduced tariff for the hotel stay was not worth the unpleasant sensation lingering in my mouth after enduring a prolonged sales pitch lasting two and a half hours. 

In the event that you already possess ownership and have dedicated yourself to taking vacations, then indeed, this would be a suitable place to lodge. 

In the event that you resemble the majority of individuals and are unable to tolerate aggressive sales tactics, I would refrain from accepting any offers that may appear appealing in exchange for attending a sales presentation, as it is unequivocally not worthwhile. I would willingly return in time and compensate someone to avoid reliving that experience once more."

I am fond of the concept of this establishment, as it offers the opportunity to partake in live musical performances while enjoying a meal before proceeding to witness a comedic act in the adjacent venue. The culinary offerings were indeed delectable. However, my sole grievance pertains to the sluggish pace of the service, as it required an excessive duration of time to receive our initial course of fried potato slices. Despite their flavorfulness, the prolonged wait was unacceptable. Nevertheless, the assortment of beverages available on tap was impressive. It is my hope that the efficiency of the service will improve with the passage of time.

I expected more...Overall, the food was very good (thus, the three stars), but the experience overall was a big let down.  My entree came before I was finished with my appetizer and the dessert was a disappointment.  I expected impeccable service and a long leisurely dinner.    Instead, I felt rushed and let down.  Not worth the money.

It's a decent paper with great access to their writers. Plus, I really like the location! (They are located directly next to my office, so whenever I need something...I just walk over) \n\nIt also makes a great filler in my fire pit! Lol

"In conclusion, an enjoyable night was had within the confines of this vibrant, pseudo-loungy Portuguese establishment, boasting a dynamic ambiance that afforded patrons the opportunity to observe the culinary process, while simultaneously socializing with an upscale clientele. The advantages of dining here include a wide-ranging menu replete with delectable options and an atmosphere conducive to conviviality. However, it is imperative to note that the cost of indulging in a diverse array of tapas, main courses, beverages, and wine can quickly add up, resulting in a substantial financial investment, especially considering the premium pricing of certain seafood and fish dishes, which hover around the $40 mark. Therefore, those with limited financial resources would be wise to exercise caution when deciding whether to partake in the culinary offerings of this esteemed eatery."

This is my first time to this Hampton Inn location. The set up is typical of other Hampton Inns. But, the staff is friendly and helpful unlike some other locations I have been to. I arrived before 3 PM and the front desk was able to put me into a room right away without fuss. The room is clean.\n\nI went to the Fitness Center in the late afternoon and discover the fitness closet instead. It was mislabeled as a Fitness Center. It was a small space with three pieces of equipment and a few balls. This fitness closet cannot accommodate more than 4 people at at time. So disappointed.

"The culinary experience was, at best, unremarkable. The lamb entrÃ©e, while adequately prepared, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi in terms of flavor profile; specifically, a dearth of fresh vegetables on the plate, instead relying heavily on legumes, resulted in an underwhelming sensory experience. Furthermore, the absence of any discernible herbs or spices, such as rosemary, rendered the dish utterly forgettableâakin to the uninspired fare one might encounter in a British gastropub. The service, while not unfriendly, was somewhat haphazard; our server, though pleasant, appeared unversed in the finer points of table management, necessitating that we ourselves rearranged our table settings to accommodate the dishes he brought forth. Overall, an unfortunate confluence of factors led to a disappointing dining excursion."

During the frenzied holiday season, department stores metamorphose into an atypical realm where the maniacal consumer culture assumes a captivating form. Amidst the throngs of shoppers, an unwavering emphasis on display transpires, attaining an unprecedented level of urgency and fixation. As an ardent observer of human behavior, I derive a perverse satisfaction from immersing myself within the midst of this spectacle, relishing the opportunity to witness firsthand the intriguing dynamics that unfold. Despite my lack of purchases, I must confess that I enjoyed the 25 minutes spent meandering through the multilevel store, indulging in people-watching while accompanying my sibling in his quest for a necklace suitable for his significant other. Furthermore, I must note that this specific department store boasts a veritable perfume section of gargantuan proportions, replete with an endless array of aromatic offerings. Each individual aisle within this vast domain is tended to by a personable, model-like attendant, eager to lavish unsuspecting passersby with generous spritzes of fragrances endorsed by none other than the illustrious Cher herself. This surreal atmosphere, simultaneously hellish and hypnotic, serves as a testament to the allure and absurdity of our contemporary consumerist culture.

those that know me know i like to have a good time. 

i usually do.

went with a group of around 30, so yeah it was crazy.

for some strange reason, i just wasnt feeling this place. yeah the usual things youd find at a strip club are here..  cute to a few HOTT ladies walking around preying on drunk folks. random ass femalecustomer getting it on with a group of said ladies.... hella expensive ass drinks......

but strip clubs are like masturbation.... in the begining it all seems like a great idea, youre all excited and during, youre having a great time..... but after a few minutes after, you realized, damn i just fucked myself.
 
+1 star for that cute stripper that actually seemed like she was enjoying chatting and took me over to an abandoned area not being used that night just to chat about random ass shit and not to clean me out of all my money.

"Culinary indulgence, atmospheric delight, and aesthetic appeal are hallmarks of this establishment, but regrettably, the service experience falls short of expectations due to evident ineptitude and inefficient management, leading to an unfortunate and prolonged waiting period for patrons."

Last Saturday, I experienced an eagerness to partake in a nocturnal excursion to witness the comedic stylings of none other than the illustrious Billy Gardell; however, I was cognizant of the likelihood that my financial resources would be considerably depleted due to the exorbitant pricing policies implemented by the establishment, thus, I made a concerted effort to mentally prepare myself for the monetary ravaging that was forthcoming.

Upon entering the venue, I was immediately struck by the charming ambiance and cozy seating arrangement, which provided an unobstructed view of the stage from any vantage point within the intimate setting. Furthermore, I must commend the management on offering tickets at a reasonable price point, as well as providing complimentary parking validation and serving palatable fare at a cost that did not entirely decimate my wallet. Additionally, the staff exhibited a remarkable level of proficiency and cordiality, ensuring that my visit was further enhanced by their prompt and attentive service.

However, I must caution potential patrons against the rather claustrophobic seating arrangements, which seemed to disregard personal space and comfort. Moreover, I found the beverage prices to be utterly preposterous and was taken aback by the requirement to purchase two drinks, ostensibly to satisfy some arcane minimum order quota. To further compound my consternation, an arbitrary percentage was added to my total bill under the guise of a gratuity, which I deemed to be an unwarranted affront to my fiscal sensibilities.

In conclusion, while I cannot deny the comedic talents showcased during my visit, I must emphasize that the blatant avarice displayed by the management has left an indelible stain on my overall experience. Consequently, I shall refrain from returning to this establishment until such time that they choose to revise their exploitative practices or feature a comedian whose performances are of such exceptional quality that I am willing to temporarily suspend my fiscal principles.

My friends love this place but I just thought it was okay.  It really depends on the style of pizza you like.  I don't like pizza that is really more bread based than sauce based.  The sauce makes or breaks a pizza for me.  The pizza here doesn't use a lot of sauce or cheese.  If you are a fan of good crust you may love this place but it is not my cup of tea.  I am spoiled since I am from Chicago where there are great pizza places everywhere.  Phoenix has a lot of places people tell me the are really good but I find most of them to be average at best.  It is hard to compare Lou Malnattis or Giordano's in Chicago to anything here.

It's Carowinds. Some good rides. Most surrounded by stuff you won't ride or games you won't waste money on. The kids will have fun, no doubt. The people are nice enough. The group hospitality is very good with great brisket and chicken. They make you feel welcome. Just enjoy it.

Came here as one of the stops for the \"Buffet of Buffets\" 24 hour pass thing. It's nothing compared to the buffet at the Wynn but I don't think this buffet deserves so many one and two star reviews. Yes, the selection is limited but the food isn't crappy either. The interior is inviting. The line sucks unless you're a diamond/platinum member.

Need a 1/2 star button. 3-1/2 stars here. Tried tamale chx salad and raspberry tea. The chx salad was good (grapes, celery, green onion, almonds) sliced so thin makes not one thing overpowering..tamale was not bad not dry somewhat flavorful...they were out of strawberry honey tea, settled for raspberry-typical... Meal was only $8, not bad..probably won't be back except to try this strawberry-honey tea ppl are yelling about..very friendly and fast

We arrived too late to be seated and were quickly told as much the second we walked through the door.

But we were hungry and so very pleased to find out they would let us order take out. 

The food was prepared fast and tasted good. It was my first time eating at this chain so I'm not sure how it normally tastes. I really liked the garlic aioli that came with my pasta. The salad was tasty.

The manager Adam Wilcox, accommodated some of our party's particular requests.

They have gluten-free options - make sure you order them specifically even if you are ordering off the gluten-free menu.

"I had the pleasure of indulging in a delectable burger at this establishment during my previous visit, which boasted an unpretentious charm reminiscent of a home-cooked meal prepared by one's mother when time is of the essence. However, despite its humble appearance, the culinary delight did not disappoint in terms of flavor. When accompanied by a few cold beverages, specifically an abundance of beer as suggested by the venue's name, it amounted to a satisfying repast. \n\nThe ambiance of the P-stone exudes a laid-back, relaxed atmosphere, which may go unnoticed by passersby due to its unassuming exterior. Nevertheless, those who venture inside are likely to encounter a convivial throng that gravitates towards a tranquil environment, making it an ideal setting for socializing with a group of acquaintances on a low-key evening."

"I recently visited this unpretentious venue, situated in a rather unremarkable shopping plaza, to partake in an evening of auditory indulgence, featuring none other than the illustrious Fu Manchu - a stoner rock ensemble of considerable renown, I must add. Formerly known as Chaser's, this intimate establishment has played host to numerous local acts of varying musical inclinations, including the likes of Zen Lunatics and One Foot In The Grave, the latter of which boasted a peculiar novelty some two decades prior, owing to the advanced age of its members - a characteristic that has since become somewhat commonplace among pioneering punk outfits. Upon entering the premises, I was struck by the lack of significant alterations to the interior design, which seemed to have remained largely unchanged since its Chaser's era. The atmosphere was lively, with a respectable throng of patrons that necessitated occasional bodily contortions to navigate the compact space. The gentlemen's restroom, while devoid of a door, did feature functional lavatories - a welcome departure from the necessity of utilizing improvised urinary receptacles, as encountered at certain alternative venues. Following a single gin and tonic (the taste of which was somewhat diluted), I opted against further imbibing, primarily due to the eardrum-assailing volume of the headlining act - an intensity that bordered on the need for a Sign Language For Dummies guide. While the sonic experience was undoubtedly exhilarating, I would not consider revisiting this establishment unless absolutely compelled by an exceptional performer."

Best way to describe this place- you get what you pay for. It wasn't a super classy or fancy joint, but it was a decent, cheap place to crash.  Can't complain too much about it.  The service was good, my room and bathroom were clean, and there was shuttling to and from the strip (if you don't mind walking a bit of distance... it only goes to the mall on the Stratosphere end of the strip) and to and from the airport. All my needs were met, thus I was content. Overall, decent hotel at a very good price (especially for such an expensive place like Vegas).
friendly folks and unusual items. I've always found the quality good and the produce fress. I like the dried fruit and nut selection too.

Positives:  muddled cocktail is sublime.  Service was friendly and attentive.  A variety of menu items at different price points.  A great environment & stylish moderndecor.\n\nNegatives:  the food.  It's nothing special.  Lots of highly stylized menu choices, where the title outdoes the reality.

We were eager to indulge in a culinary escapade at Julian Serrano, primarily due to their extensive selection of tapas and their renowned ceviche. Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the mixed seafood ceviche, which, unfortunately, did not live up to my expectations, as it lacked a certain je ne sais quoi that I had anticipated. However, the steamed mussels proved to be a satisfying alternative, with their tender texture and subtle flavors. Our companions opted for the spare ribs and mushroom risotto, respectively, neither of which particularly impressed them, sadly.

It is alright.

Ordered a chicken pita sandwich. The pita bread itself was good, wished more of the cucumber sauce, and the chicken was thick and enough - to make your money's worth. Just needed something else to give it a 4 or 5.

Of course there are plenty of other options to go to, if not feeling for chicken pita sandwich.

BEWARE. THEY USE LEAN MEAT!!\nhaha, Just sayin', the burger was kinda dry. but definately a pretty good burger and fries. got 2 burgers, and shared a thing of fries. total bill $30. Not bad, wouldn't go back though

"For an unparalleled price of $2, patrons can indulge in a wide range of coffee concoctions every Wednesday, where size is no barrier to savings, be it a compact yet flavorful small latte, a medium latte that strikes a perfect balance between volume and value, or a large latte that offers an uncompromising experience for those who crave a truly satiating cup; the choice is yours, but rest assured, the price remains constant and unbeatably advantageous."

"There isn't a remarkable amount to articulate regarding this establishment, as it embodies a quintessential character that is reminiscent of numerous other similar venues. Its aesthetic appeal is pleasant, yet unremarkable, and the culinary offerings, while satisfactory, do not possess an exceptional quality that would render them memorable. Although I did not have the opportunity to sample their signature pizza, my impression remains that the experience was unexceptional and unlikely to prompt an enthusiastic return visit. However, I would suggest this location to groups of acquaintances seeking a casual atmosphere where they can enjoy beverages and fare while viewing sporting events."

While holding a divergent perspective regarding the superior quality of the fried poultry served at this establishment, I concur with the notion that it constitutes a remarkable local discovery within the city of Charlotte, offering delectable fried cuisine that caters to both regional patrons and visiting gastronomes with equal proficiency. The venue experiences a high volume of patronage, with a constant influx of customers from 11 am onward, culminating in either the exhaustion of the daily menu items or the closure of the eatery. It is imperative to note that the restaurant only accepts paper currency, thus it is advisable to verify the availability of funds in one's wallet prior to arrival, and refrain from allowing the presence of pedestrians gathered adjacent to the sidewalk to deter you, as this phenomenon is customary and not indicative of any anomaly. The ordering process is expedited, resulting in the rapid procurement of culinary items, followed by a prompt departure to accommodate the succeeding patron in line. The menu features a variety of fried delicacies, including chicken and fish options; personally, I advocate for the unwavering preference of poultry. Supplementing the meal with hush puppies and coleslaw contributes to an enhanced dining experience. I recommend paying a visit to this establishment to form your own opinion.

I failed to acquire any edible items to consume during my visit due to the fact that I was in the process of recuperating from a bout of food poisoning. However, my significant other managed to procure the spicy pork tacos, which he asserted were the most delectable tacos he had ever had the pleasure of consuming. This establishment exudes an aura of authenticity, as evidenced by the lengthy queues and numerous patrons in attendance. My companion awarded five stars in recognition of the culinary excellence displayed by the eatery. 
  Notwithstanding, one cannot help but wonder if the prolonged waiting period is truly justified. The duration of the queue significantly diminishes the overall rating, relegating it to a mere three stars. The system employed for organizing the queue was utterly perplexing. Numerous patrons have pointed out that there are separate lines for various types of fare. In total, there are six distinct lines, divided into two sets of three. The first set consists of lines dedicated to pork (abodaba), offal (including brains, tongue, stomach, tripe, intestines, et cetera), and beef (encompassing asada, et cetera). Despite its apparent length, the queue moved at a glacial pace, making the prolonged delay seem utterly absurd. 
  Upon drawing closer to the front of the line, it became apparent that the sluggishness was attributable to a single individual performing the duties of two people. Although he demonstrated remarkable speed in crafting the tacos, he was responsible for preparing a minimum of five tacos for every patron. Moreover, he produced an excess of fifty tacos while we waited, ostensibly for takeout orders (wrapped in foil and placed on paper plates). The combination of the time required per person and the additional tasks undertaken by the taco artisan for the benefit of those not present in the queue contributes substantially to the interminable delay. It appears that there must exist a more effective method for them to manage their operations!

Gorgeous casino, décor scheme seems to be taken from the Bellagio gardens- good mix of stores, restaurants, and gaming. Really appreciate how spacious this casino is, lots of space to walk around without cramming slot machines into every available nook.

Service is typically very top notch, and restaurants on site are known for being able to accommodate any dietary restriction and have several vegan, vegetarian, and vegetable-laden options at each.

Parking garage is smaller than most but easily accessible, casino itself is on the smaller side but more intimate and upscale rather than crowded and gaudy.

Had the popcorn with bacon for an appetizer - it was ok, but nothing great. We split the chicken and waffles - not bad, but not maybe I'm just not a fan of chicken & waffles in general (don't hate me). But - we also ordered the short rib, which was quite delicious! It came with some greens that were quite un-delicious and we didn't take more than 1 bite of them. \n\nIf you try it, get there early otherwise it gets VERY loud inside and you'll be yelling across the table to have a conversation.

This eatery presented an aesthetically pleasing ambiance, with tasteful ornamentation that contributed to a welcoming atmosphere; however, the culinary offerings proved to be merely adequate. Our dining experience was initiated due to a recommendation from a patron who had partaken in their beef noodle soup approximately one year prior and expressed immense satisfaction with its quality; regrettably, their expectations were not met during our visit, as they conveyed disappointment regarding the lack of flavor. It is worth mentioning that the prices listed on the menu were considerably elevated, particularly when compared to other establishments within the vicinity; nevertheless, as we were recipients of complimentary meals, I cannot express dissatisfaction with regard to cost. My individual order consisted of Hainan Chicken Rice, which unfortunately exhibited an excessive degree of dryness, as the grains were not adequately saturated with sauce or broth, resulting in a comparatively unremarkable dish. In addition, the Beef Chow Fun failed to impress, despite being cooked to an acceptable standard. Noteworthily, the Iced Coffee we ordered was the highlight of my meal, priced at six dollars per cup. Furthermore, the Fried Shrimp Balls garnered favorable reviews from our party, appearing on a dim sum trolley. To my dismay, the Soupy Dumplings, which I eagerly anticipated, were not characterized by an abundance of moisture, leading to middling enjoyment. Ultimately, the majority of dishes sampled fell short of exceptional quality, thereby rendering future visits unlikely.

I recently had a quick bite to eat at this location.  My usual......Bean Burrito and 7 Layer Burrito.

Order was accurate.

Place was clean.

Food was ok.

It's Taco Bell....not much to say.

Will I return?  Sure.

"I had the privilege of partaking in a culinary experience at this esteemed establishment on Valentine's Day, and thus, I was presented with the opportunity to sample their pre-fixed menu. Unfortunately, the cost of the meal was somewhat prohibitive due to the festive nature of the occasion. Moreover, the quality of the cuisine did not quite meet my expectations, perhaps owing to the fact that the kitchen had to prepare large quantities of food for the influx of patrons. Notwithstanding the diminutive proportions of each dish, I failed to complete any of them, as my palate was not sufficiently impressed. Furthermore, my companion and I still felt a lingering sense of hunger subsequent to our meal. Nonetheless, the ambiance of the restaurant was quite pleasant, as we were seated in close proximity to a window that offered an unparalleled panoramic view."

It's an airport. You get to Vegas and then you immediately go straight to partying. Even the airport is calling for a party with the slot machines located at the baggage claims. \n\nThis airport moves pretty quick too. They get the job done and fly you to your destination! wohoo!

"Minus a star for not possessing an EPL ticket to display all the matches. For Pete's sake, you are THE English bar in Phoenix and I cannot observe my adored Gunners unless they are on channel 167? Come on! If you are going to hang the flags and scarves, at least have the game available, especially when it's 7 a.m., and I yearn to become intoxicated while viewing Arsenal-Chelsea in the fifth most populous city in the United States, and I am unable to do so; this does not make me a contented individual. Haha. All things considered, not a terrible establishment. Fantastic selection of beverages. Nice dÃ©cor, to sum up, it's one of those places where you can indulge in libations for 2-3 hours, exit, and exclaim, "Good Lord, the sun is still up?!"

Took my Playstation 3 here after it stopped reading discs.  Had to take it back twice, still wasn't fixed.  In all fairness, the problem was beyond the scope of the repair, and they gave me a full refund.  That's superior policy/customer service.

On the downside, they removed my yet-unplayed copy of GTA 5 and stuck it in a ziplock bag after I offered to leave the case for them to put it in.  Disc looked like someone ate a bucket of chicken and put their hands all over it.  Also, I came back twice to have it re-repaired and each time was like I'd never been there before.  "Can I help you?"

I'll consider this experience a wash, as I left with the same broken unit but was not charged for the time invested.  Not certain I'd take anything else there.

"While in Phoenix for a corporate conference, I had the pleasure of dining at Tutti Santi, a culinary establishment that was graciously recommended by my colleague's father-in-law, who had previously visited the restaurant on multiple occasions. Absent this suggestion, it is unlikely that I would have discovered this eatery on my own accord. 

On the evening in question, the restaurant was bustling with activity due to a special promotional event, which appeared to have caught the staff off guard. As a result, there was a considerable delay in placing our order, during which time we opted to sample a bottle of wine from their extensive selection. While awaiting the arrival of our appetizers, we indulged in the accompanying bread, which proved to be quite satisfying. However, owing to the sluggish pace of service, our initial bottle of wine was depleted well before the main courses were served. 

Upon the arrival of our food, we elected to procure an additional bottle of wine, which unfortunately failed to materialize. Despite bringing this oversight to the attention of our server, no further action was taken. This unfortunate sequence of events detracted significantly from our overall dining experience, transforming what would have otherwise been a four-star review into a decidedly less favorable assessment."

Table of 4, wait was 20++ minutes late on a Thursday night.   No bar to wait in, plus no alert system (buzzer or whatever) so we couldn't wander around the casino.   Once we were seated, the food was great.....  Just burgers but lots of toppings, etc.   Nothing bad nor was it overly memorable.  Very sufficient for a bite in Harrahs!

I am not too picky about movie theaters. We usually go to the theater with the show times we like best. They all could use a more frequent deep cleaning, and this one is no different.\n\nIt bothers me, though, when people think it is the movie theater's job to clean up after them, so they leave their trash in the aisle and on the seats. You bought it, you own it, you dispose of it up. Didn't your mom teach you to clean up after yourself?

Applebee's is usually good for reasonably priced, decent tasting food. My experience at this particular Applebee's wasn't horrible but also wasn't anything that would make me want to go back. 

Our party of three was seated quickly but service got fairly slow after that. Our waitress brought out wrong type of beer for one of the people with me, took a while to bring out the correct one and then took ages to bring extra napkins.

I had a lunch special that included half of a sandwich and a small salad. I had the shrimp and spinach salad which was excellent. The sandwich I went with was the California turkey club. The lettuce tasted sour, I had to pick it all off... And the bread was greasier then I would have preferred.

The sangria was damn tasty but could have used more fruit.

"I have had the experience of visiting this location on a previous occasion, and my impression was that it possessed a diminutive size, which was compensated for by an abundance of commercial establishments and a plethora of live musical performances. However, the ignition of the praying mantis at approximately 9 pm failed to resonate with my personal preferences, as I found the overall ambiance to be tailored predominantly towards family-oriented patrons, thereby engendering within me a sense of incongruity and prompting my companion and I to seek alternative forms of entertainment. Although I cannot rule out the possibility of revisiting this venue at some point in the future, I must confess that it does not currently hold a prominent position on my list of preferred destinations."
"Excessively expensive, considering the quantity of the dish. Although the culinary quality is undeniable, the cost does not align with the value received, leaving a sense of dissatisfaction."

Here's the thing, I genuinely desire to endorse this establishment. It proximates my domicile, the minuscule cakes perpetually appear delectable, and an agreeable aroma permeates the atmosphere. I've visited this location on multiple occasions, and each time, I've encountered distinctive and imaginative flavors that I've seldom witnessed elsewhere; Pink Lemonade, Chocolate Covered Banana, and Peanut Butter and Honey, who would conceive of such combinations?!

However, possibly I frequented this establishment during inopportune periods. The cake presented itself as succulent and appetizing. Nonetheless, the icing proved excessively abundant and overpowering, even for my better half, who relishes sweets to an extent where he could effortlessly devour an entire tray of brownies unassisted and in a single sitting. He needed to extract the icing midway through consumption since it became too copious for his taste buds.

I won't relinquish my yearning for their products though! I shall likely revisit this venue due to my infatuation with cupcakes (we even incorporated them into our wedding celebrations), as I ardently aspire to appreciate their offerings.

"While I acknowledge that certain individuals may hold the opinion that this particular Buffett is of superior quality, I must respectfully disagree with such sentiments. In my personal experience, the breakfast offerings at this establishment far surpass the quality of the dinner options, and it is worth noting that the menu items for both meals share a considerable amount of overlap. Furthermore, I find it somewhat perplexing that there is such a significant discrepancy in the level of satisfaction between the two meals, leading me to question the validity of the claim that this Buffett is indeed the best."

I will start by saying this, the midnight Diner is probably one of the better staple restaurants in Charlotte. However my experience tonight did not reflect that. After being sat and refused to change my order by our server, Ashley - we then received beyond mediocre service.  Feeling somewhat stereotyped into the mold of \"black people don't tip\". Luckily a server by the name of Larry a.k.a \"Showtime\" managed to salvage what remained of an otherwise horrible experience. He definitely exempified the prototype of what anyone would call excellent service. Needless to say our server received no tip. Hopefully she learns something from her peers. Definitely will be back...and requesting \"Showtime\" as our server for the duration of his tenure there.

I always know I'm in Vegas when I come here and spend 20 bucks on a subway 5 dollar footlong lmao! Seriously how is it even legal for subway to rip you off like that haha. \n\nSlots of fun is like a 20 ton boulder going down hill....once it gets going...unstoppable. I don't even gamble here. When I stay at riviera I usually just come over to slots of fun to grab a nathans hot dog or some Over priced subway sandwiches. That being said there is something I like about the place. Just really old school vegas. Vegas actually needs more places like this. Hate to say it but I will be back lol

Being from Chicago and San Diego, my spouse and I are poised to experience a culinary culture shock while dining in the Carolinas, and this particular establishment served as the inaugural dining experience, which we entered with trepidation due to its unfamiliar ambiance characterized by plastic-coated checkered tablecloths. Despite our initial reservations, we opted to persevere and sample their gastronomic offerings. 

Upon scrutinizing their menu, I sought the ubiquitous California wrap, adorned with bean sprouts and avocado, but instead discovered an array of Southern-style dishes, including southern fried chicken, skillet-fried chicken, veggie lasagna, meatloaf, coleslaw, fried okra, collard greens, and, of course, BBQ. My curiosity was piqued regarding the nature of BBQ, wondering if it encompassed a specific sauce, pork, beef, or chicken. Lacking familiarity with this regional cuisine, I was genuinely perplexed. 

Notwithstanding, we placed our orders from their extensive menu, which boasted an impressive selection of fried "veggies," albeit with a prevalence of breading and deep-frying. It is worth mentioning that, in our opinion, a well-balanced flavor can be achieved without reliance on excessive breading and copious amounts of fat. 

Fortunately, the food proved to be palatable, with generous portions, and our server exhibited kindness and attentiveness, addressing us with courteous "yes ma'ams" and "no ma'ams." In conclusion, we aspire to discover a dining establishment that showcases a greater diversity of options beyond sandwiches, traditional Southern home cooking, and an abundance of artery-clogging vegetable dishes.
Good location for a decent bite to eat before the game. Gets busy, but the food and service is good. Little on the pricy side.

This place is ok for a vietnamese restaurant. First impression walking in- this place smells of cigars! Later I realized it's the smell of the cigar bar next door. 

Service was rather quick. The man who attended to us seemed to be the owner, he was approachable and would give recommendations if you ask. 

Our food was out pretty fast. I ordered the beef pho with eye round steak and beef balls while the bf got his usual chicken pho. We also got the vietnamese iced coffee. 

I love the broth! It was not as greasy as some of the other vietnamese places I've been to, and you can actually taste the herbs. The rice noodles was meh, it was a little too starchy for me, for some reason. The eye round steak was a little overdone. Iced coffee was a tad too sweet, there's a little too much of the condensed milk. 

Overall, a decent experience. I'll probably come back again. 

Side note: if you like spicy food, ask for the ot satay sauce. it's basically Thai chillies fried with garlic paste and it is SPICY- a much better alternative to siracha, in my opinion.

This place... how could one not love it?! The drinks are amazing and the price is just right!! I personally recommend the \"G Spot\" or a martini. The food is excellent here as well. I usually get the Fez burger. I am not sure what all is on it, but I can tell you that it tastes amazing!! So why the 3 stars?... Unfortunately I woke up later that night very ill. Since this place was not the only food I had all day, I can't say for sure that I got sick from here. However, I'm hesitant to visit again now.

Evidently there's a zagat survey list on the best chain restaurant steak.  Which I find preposterous.  Would they have a list judging the best movie about grass growing?  "In the end, Crabgrass beat out Ragweed just because of the potential allergens."
