No, because sometimes you can make an entire category of things that suck, and chain restaurants, as a general rule, serve shitty steak. Not that I'm judging.

So if you go to Outback, don't expect anything amazing, despite the fact that zagat said they were tasty.  But outback is worth visiting anyway, because have you ever had their shrimp appetizer served on their brown bread garlic slab-thing?  The bread is better than the shrimp.  It's amazing.

But truly legendary status is only accorded thusly: imagine an appetizer with so many calories that three could share and still crack a thousand calories each?  Enter the cheese fries with bacon and a glob of ranch and you will know what spoonfuls of lard feel like to your arteries.  This particular location has a number of great bartenders and if you go there looking for a pleasant time and decent food, you'll be satisfied.  Chicken breast with BBQ sauce: palatable.  Broccoli with crab-butter sauce?  Tasty.  Rack of lamb? Surprisingly good.  Really there are a ton of options here but one thing you will not get is world-beating steak.  So save it, Zagat.

Great ambience! This bar was a great place to grab a drink & people watch or just hang with great company. I really enjoyed the lounge style decor & the drinks here are pretty decent for a casino bar.

I, of course, ordered a vodka grey goose with tonic and was surprised that 75% of it was alcohol. My friend ordered a rum & diet coke and again the drink had a good amount of rum. :-) I'm not quite sure on pricing but seemed decent.

The waitresses are dressed in cute lacy mini dresses and are very pleasant. Overall, for a hotel lobby bar this is a good spot.

"Underwhelming experience. Capriotti's offers a few palatable sandwiches, but several others fall short of expectations. 

My preferred sandwich at this establishment is the Capastrami, featuring succulent pastrami, Swiss cheese, and a generous helping of creamy coleslaw and Russian dressing, all grilled to perfection. Reminiscent of a Reuben, this sandwich is well-constructed and the bread holds up admirably. 

Regrettably, the bread used for their cheesesteaks and Italian subs is problematic, as it lacks the necessary absorbency to effectively soak up the flavors and moisture of the other ingredients. Consequently, these particular sandwiches fall short of their potential. 

Furthermore, the cheesesteaks are hindered by unsavory, arid meat that lacks any discernible flavor. Unremarkable would be an appropriate descriptor. 

While the Bobbie may not be everyone's cup of tea due to the inclusion of mayonnaise, omitting it results in an excessively dry sandwich. However, the store-roasted turkey pairs nicely with provolone cheese and hot peppers on cold subs. 

For superior cold subs, Jersey Mike's is the preferable choice, while Pop's remains the premier destination for cheesesteaks in Las Vegas."

Good but not sure it's worth all the hype.  Went there with a fairly large group of friends and had to wait a pretty long time to be seated.  It's a small place and right now very trendy so be prepared to wait.

I found their red velvet pancakes a but too sweet and definitely overrated.  I love red velvet but when you add in the chocolate chips and their icing it was just too sweet.  It was better without all the other stuff but then slightly dry.

Liked their buttermilk pancakes more.  Nice and moist and delicious with the butter and syrup.

Believe I also got corned beef hash - it was very good but the potatoes with it were meh.

My assessment pertains to the gaming establishment, as my accommodations were situated in close proximity, at the Palazzo. I harbored elevated anticipations upon entering the venue, which appeared cluttered with numerous international patrons, who were indulging in ubiquitous photography and leisurely strolling. Despite the congestion, I managed to identify a solitary slot machine that piqued my interest, though my efforts to engage in prolonged gameplay were thwarted by an adjacent individual whose family members occupied neighboring machines, yet refrained from participating. My desire to partake in table games remained unfulfilled due to the sheer volume of individuals meandering about, rendering it challenging to navigate. Notwithstanding, I shall revisit the premises in the future, as my initial impression was generally favorable.

I have had the pleasure of partaking in the culinary offerings of this esteemed establishment on three separate occasions, with two of those experiences being of the drive-thru variety and the most recent being a dine-in visit. I must say, I am delighted that I opted to dine in, for it afforded me the opportunity to observe the kitchen staff in their natural habitat, so to speak. One of the cooks, a Caucasian male, was not adorned in the customary gloves worn by his colleagues, which, in conjunction with his unfortunate lack of hygiene, led me to question the overall cleanliness of the kitchen. Furthermore, upon venturing to the restroom, I discovered that the paper towel dispenser was devoid of its intended contents, thus necessitating my utilization of the blower, which, in turn, produced an abundance of noise that served as a stark contrast to the otherwise tranquil ambiance of the dining area. This sequence of events led me to deduce that the aforementioned cook had neglected to properly sanitize his hands prior to resuming his culinary duties. Lastly, as I emerged from the restroom, I was greeted by the sight of the same individual grasping a generous portion of bacon, which, coincidentally, happened to be a key component of my companion's bacon burger. It is worth noting that the cook's attire, or lack thereof, accentuated his posterior region in a manner that was conspicuous and, some might argue, inappropriate. While I do intend to return to this establishment in the future, I do so with the hope that the aforementioned cook will not be present during my subsequent visits. Notwithstanding the aforementioned issues, I must admit that the quality of the burgers and fries served here is quite impressive.

I had previously become cognizant of the existence of Pink's Hot Dogs in Southern California and had always harbored an ardent desire to sample their culinary offerings. Thus, when I became aware of the presence of a Pink's establishment in Las Vegas, my excitement reached palpable levels. Unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely met, to put it mildly. I opted to order the mushroom swiss dog, which carried a price tag of $6.50. Upon consuming the hot dog, I was struck by its rubbery texture, which was somewhat disappointing. Furthermore, the Swiss cheese component of the dish was not as copious as I had anticipated, leading to intermittent bursts of flavor that were not as pronounced as they could have been. While the combination of mushrooms, Swiss cheese, and hot dog was undoubtedly delectable during those fleeting moments when all three elements converged, the overall experience was marred by an imbalance in ingredient ratios. Specifically, an excess of mushrooms and an insufficient amount of cheese detracted from my enjoyment. However, despite this underwhelming encounter, I would still be willing to partake in Pink's offerings once again in the future, albeit with a differing menu selection. Rumor has it that their chili cheese dog is positively sublime, and I am eager to verify the veracity of such claims.

Any pub on Rose St immediately has to compete with swathes of competitive drinking holes. As a result the Auld Hundred seems like another humdrum offering with nothing of particular attraction here. Then again, that may be exactly what the clientele like: a reliable and no frills establishment.\n\nYou'll find typically generous pub size portions with regards to food and a modest selection of ales, A- OK.

I stayed here for a bachelor party.  I've been here numerous times.  I love the location as it is within walking distance to all the hotels I like hanging at.  I like the fact that they gave me a fat discount because of a collective of my friends player points.  It isn't the newest hotel, but the rooms are clean and the staff were good.  I enjoyed their sportsbook.  Unfortunately, I was unable to do any dining over there nor have I ever dined over there.  That's a shame.  I would stay there again just for the price, but there are far superior hotels in Las Vegas.

"The personnel are assiduous and accommodating, catering to the needs of patrons with alacrity and proficiency. On a particular evening, we opted to partake in a culinary excursion to this establishment, accompanied by our offspring. The fare served was, unsurprisingly, reminiscent of traditional bar cuisine - rich and savory, yet lacking in subtlety and refinement. However, our experience was significantly marred by the egregious volume of the musical performance, which rendered communication at our table utterly futile. Despite the commendable service, I would confer merely three stars, as the ambiance was less than ideal and the setting was not particularly conducive to an intimate or family-oriented dining experience. In fact, it would be more suitable for a casual gathering or socializing with acquaintances, rather than a romantic evening or quality time with loved ones."

I'll cut to the chase.  The food is okay.  If you are in the area, and you want a quick bite, hit this place up.  If you have a hankering for some good Chinese food, I'd suggest you drive down to Spring Mountain, or better yet, California (the state, not the hotel).\n\nHaving just come back from LA, where I had some mind blowingly good Chinese, I was let down here.  I would put this restaurant in the same taste category as Panda Express.  It's tasty for what it is, but it's not really Chinese food.

I had not partaken of Papa John's culinary offerings for at least a year, and thus, my taste buds were eager to indulge in their delectable pies once again. As one of the superior chain pizza establishments, Papa John's boasts a prime location along my route home from work, thereby rendering it a convenient dining option. Furthermore, I had acquired a $10 gift card for the paltry sum of $5 via the online marketplace, Saveology.com, which made the prospect of savoring their large specialty pizzas all the more enticing, particularly given their affordability, with each pie priced at a mere $11. While the large pizza, measuring a scant 14 inches in diameter, may not be considered substantial by some standards, the Spinach Alfredo variety possesses an undeniable appeal, its flavorsome combination of fresh spinach, rich Alfredo sauce, and melted mozzarella cheese rendering it a veritable gustatory delight. However, upon receiving my order, I was dismayed to discover that the butter sauce and pepperoncini, typically included in the pizza box, were conspicuously absent. Nevertheless, I comprehended the reasoning behind this omission, attributable to the establishment's desire to streamline their operations and enhance efficiency. Notwithstanding this minor drawback, the quality of service remained somewhat lacking, as only one of two available registers was manned by a lone employee, resulting in a discernible delay in processing orders, while several patrons idled nearby, awaiting their turns. Despite these inconveniences, I would still consider halting at Papa John's for a pizza en route home, provided the price remains reasonable.

I recently watched this show for the second time since I saw it once w/o my husband and he really wanted to see it. The show is definitely different from your typical cirque du soleil shows. This one is more focused on Asian themed/ sword fighting/acrobatics. Most cirque du soleil show is like watching a dream with really no plot just different acts of crazy "sitting on the edge of chair" acrobatics. But KA actually has a storyline and nothing was really scary cause they used wires.

The language they use and some characters (ie the Tarzan-ish guy) is just hard to take in. Even watching it the second time, it's not my kind of cirque du soleil, so I'm glad for both times I was able to get the tickets for a cheap price.

The only thing I really like about the show is the big platform that can go vertical and move around. The last scene with the fighting on the vertical wall was my favorite, but the other parts didn't catch my attention like the other shows do.

C'est un caf\u00e9 correct pour travailler et pour se prendre un lunch quand on a oubli\u00e9 le sien \u00e0 la maison. Je suis all\u00e9e \u00e0 l'heure du lunch et \u00e7a n'\u00e9tais pas trop occup\u00e9, donc la combinaison de wifi gratuit et grandes tables pour travailler \u00e9tait exactement ce que je cherchais. Ils ont un bonne vari\u00e9t\u00e9 de plats et le service est bien correct. J'ai pris deux salades : une aux l\u00e9gumes et moutarde dijon, puis l'autre l\u00e9gumes et p\u00e2tes \u00e0 l'orientale, ou bien plut\u00f4t simplement \u00e0 la sauce soya. Les deux \u00e9taient super bonne et j'ai bien aim\u00e9 avoir l'option d'un lunch sans trop de pain. Ils ont aussi des plats chauds et des plats du jour qui ont l'air de changer r\u00e9guli\u00e8rement. Somme toute, c'est un endroit qui m\u00e9lange le style caf\u00e9t\u00e9ria avec le style caf\u00e9 sans fla fla. C'est argent comptant, mais il y a un ATM au caf\u00e9 m\u00eame.

We visited this establishment for our evening meal on a Friday... Our group consisted of eight individuals, yet despite possessing a prior reservation and the lateness of the hour (9:45 PM), we were compelled to endure a brief delay before being seated, and furthermore, were assigned an outdoor table... in the intense heat of approximately 100 degrees Fahrenheit.  Although the temperature itself did not pose a significant inconvenience, we unfortunately failed to experience the full ambiance and interior design of the venue.  The kobe meatball dish was quite satisfactory.  My personal selection was an eight-ounce filet, which, while satisfying, did not include any additional sides, such as a potato, and so forth... However, the asparagus side dish I chose was both copious and flavorful.  The filet itself was cooked to my precise instructions and seasoned with great care... Most of the other patrons opted for pasta dishes, the quality of which I cannot accurately assess, as their appearances varied.  The service we received was proficient and attentive, with no notable errors committed.  While not excessively expensive, the prices charged were still somewhat elevated... Ultimately, I felt underwhelmed by the entire experience, harboring the sentiment that either a greater expenditure for superior cuisine or a lesser cost for more casual fare would have been preferable.  No major grievances can be reported, yet neither was I particularly impressed by any aspect.

Tried their 2 for $5 fish sandwiches and their $1.89 side salad.  The fish sandwich had too much bread for my liking and the fish was just okay.  The salad was iceberg and not worth me getting again.  The service was excellent and the lady manager is doing a great job,  The place is nicely decorate but I didn't think the food was worth me coming back for,

"Culinary excellence and an exceptional vinous experience. Superlative pasta dishes, with descriptions that accurately mirrored the actual composition of the dish. Upon requesting a detailed account of the wine from our attentive server, he delivered a precise and comprehensive depiction, leading to an unexpected transformation of our initial plans for a light repast and beverage into a full-fledged gastronomic indulgence. Elegant ambiance, polished service, and an overall atmosphere of refinement and quality."

Paid for a venti green tea lemonade and got a tall green tea lemonade . Reason why I didn't go back was because I had to go to school was in a rush I wish the girls that always take my orders were there

"The superior quality of the donuts at this establishment in South Phoenix renders it an optimal destination for indulging in such delectable treats, thereby making the arduousness of laboring in the aforementioned location thoroughly worthwhile; specifically, the maple bar variety is exceptionally scrumptious."

"It is palpable that the singular attribute which renders this establishment appealing is the captivating appearance and texture of their bread, which boasts an unparalleled freshness and taste. However, it is conspicuous that the sandwiches themselves are rather unremarkable and overpriced, with a cost of $5-6 for a meager offering. \n\nThe level of service provided by this establishment is glaringly inadequate, as there are merely a few employees present at any given time, leading to a sluggish and impatient experience for patrons. Furthermore, the antiquated nature of the building and the limited parking options available, including a minuscule rear lot, contribute to the overall dearth of convenience. Notwithstanding, I do concede that the diminutive original sandwich is moderately satisfying, primarily due to the exceptional quality of the bread. Nevertheless, if this eatery were to adopt a more conventional sub bread or baguette for their sandwiches, it is improbable that I would opt to dine here."

"The concise version: Acquire the delectable 'white cookie' directly from the oven at the quaint cafe for a mere $5. Unbelievable! Absolutely unbelievable! \n\nThe comprehensive rendition: Upon entering the eatery, one is confronted with an arduous waiting period, during which time water refills become a recurring necessity, requesting them each instance. It is regrettable that the 'Sunday pasta' dish had such a profoundly adverse effect on my gastrointestinal tract! (-_-). The pinnacle of culinary excellence within this establishment lies unequivocally with the aforementioned $5 cookies, freshly baked and displayed prominently in the front cafe. It is my sincere wish that I had allocated my Groupon specifically towards the procurement of those delectable treats, as opposed to the unremarkable entrees, which are assembled with pedestrian ingredients and served with little fanfare. Such is the nature of their preparation and presentation, resulting in an unimpressive gustatory experience, and one which warrants an exorbitant fee, I might add."

"Culinary indulgences abounded at this eatery, yet an enigmatic quality remained, eluding my comprehension. Ambience was satisfactory, despite the auditory assault emanating from the adjacent gaming arena. Prompt seating was accorded to us, sans reservation, during the meridian repast. The bill of fare, though diminutive in scope, boasted a diverse array of delectable options. I opted for the prime steak panini, accompanied by a tangy potato salad. A delightful confluence of flavors, complemented by the subtle pungency of barbecue sauce and a trace of horseradish, permeated the panini. The potato salad, a veritable masterpiece, struck the perfect balance between piquancy and richness, with just the right amount of mayonnaise. Regrettably, the hospitality encountered a marked decline, as sluggish service prevailed. An extended wait ensued before our check was delivered, followed by an even lengthier delay in retrieving my credit card. Infrequent were the instances wherein the server graced our presence with her attendance, post-consumption of the meal."

"The beet salad was an absolute culinary masterpiece, boasting an unparalleled harmony of flavors that left my taste buds in a state of pure delight. However, the service we received was somewhat lacking in its execution, as evidenced by the unfortunate incident involving the spillage of water onto my table while I was partaking in my meal. Furthermore, I must say that the short rib loco moco, despite its otherwise delectable appearance, was unfortunately marred by an excessive saltiness that proved to be somewhat off-putting to my palate."

"The establishment boasted an impressive rating of 3.5 stars, prompting us to visit with a group of companions this weekend, particularly for the open bar. Upon arrival, the gentlemen were charged a reasonable fee of $20, which we deemed acceptable. However, the bouncers exhibited discourteous behavior while managing the cover charge, leaving a negative impression. 

TAO's interior presented itself in an aesthetically pleasing manner, arousing our curiosity and hunger as we walked through the restaurant en route to the club. Unfortunately, we failed to fully capitalize on the venue's offerings due to our primary focus on consuming alcoholic beverages. Arriving early allowed us to avoid concerns regarding capacity, enabling us to appreciate the spaciousness of the dance floor. Although the majority of the drinks were satisfactory, some fundamental well drinks were poorly prepared, and the delay in obtaining beverages proved frustrating. Nevertheless, our overall experience at TAO remained largely positive, as we were able to dance with ample space and enjoy the musical offerings, including an unexpected performance by Dash Berlin. Our group successfully navigated the evening without encountering excessively crowded conditions, allowing us to depart before the venue reached its peak occupancy. In conclusion, our visit to TAO yielded an enjoyable experience, albeit with room for improvement in certain aspects."

"My expectations were elevated upon entering this establishment due to the numerous favorable critiques I had perused prior to my visit. However, what I encountered was a satisfactory yet unremarkable local eatery that was perhaps slightly overrated. My culinary experience began with a palatable but overcooked burger, which elicited an involuntary mental protest as the chef applied excessive pressure to the patty, resulting in a regrettably desiccated texture. The accompanying fries, while possessing a satisfying crunch, lacked any discernible distinctiveness or flavor profile, rendering them unmemorable. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the quality of the ingredients utilized did meet my expectations, as the beef patties were freshly prepared and not frozen, and the generous allocation of bacon ensured a consistent presence of savory flavor in each bite. Additionally, the lettuce was fresh and crisp, contributing to an overall adequate, albeit overpriced, dining experience. While I am unlikely to return, I might consider patronizing this restaurant again in the future if circumstances necessitated a convenient and casual meal option."

Good place to go and eat gyros if your up in North Scottsdale. The staff is friendly and the food gets to you real fast. The price is somewhere between 7-10 per meal but that's usual for N. Scottsdale.

"Perhaps my culinary experiences with Chinese cuisine have been more satisfactory in the past than I previously acknowledged, or it could be that my selection of dishes did not align with my personal preferences, but I find it challenging to confer a perfect rating upon this establishment. The egg rolls exhibited an excessive sodium content, the hot and sour soup lacked the desired acidity, and the vegetable pork dish was characterized by a notable absence of flavor. \n\nDespite these shortcomings, the restaurant's expedient service, reasonable prices, and unpretentious ambiance persuade me to consider giving it another chance in the future."

Grampa's Pizzeria - aptly named.

No one makes pizza quite like Grampa. It's delicious! He uses quality ingredients and bomb flavor combinations. Seriously, I love Grampa and I love his pizza.

However, my last visit to Grampa's made me wonder if he's maybe going senile. Walking in, we got a friendly, though confused look from the host that said, "who are you and why are you here?" That should probably have tipped me off that something was amiss. When we got an appetizer, it came out cold - I asked, "Did you maybe forget to cook this pork?" They poked it, shrugged, and put it back in the oven. Then finally, something happened with the pizza. I don't actually know what happened, our server just came out saying that it was going to be a while before we got to eat. But hey, Grampa is nothing if not generous! We got a free beer for all the confusion.

It's probably for the best that there were only 3 other couples in the restaurant. A busy Monday would have just gotten Grampa all flustered.

It's been a while since I've had my eyes checked, and even when I did, it was probably either to get my drivers license or just to look in a little machine and tell them what I saw.  I don't know if I've ever had a full-blown eye exam.  That's no longer the case.

Since Denise has been jumping through hoops to have her eyes checked, it meant I needed to have mine done too, so I signed up so that they could see what's happening.

The Christenbury Eye Center is very professional, and they have quite the setup - you check in, and they shuffle you from room to room, where they (presumably) do all sorts of things to determine if your eyes are working or not.  Maybe they just pretend.  I don't really know.

They seem to know what they are talking about, and they have lots of famous people on the walls who say they know what they are doing, so that must make them experts, right?

You can also get laser eye surgery here, but after giving me drops to dilate my eyes (which screwed up my eyesight for the better part of the day - go figure), they told me that my eyes were just fine.  Hopefully I don't have to go back for a while.

Last night, we visited this establishment for the initial time, and our experience was marred by several unfortunate incidents. Firstly, gaining entry took an interminable duration, and subsequently, a disagreement ensued between us and another patron regarding the parking arrangement, which led to an altercation. Moreover, the auditory clarity of the film was compromised due to the proximity of our screen to the adjacent one, causing an overlap in audio. Furthermore, the presence of helicopters overhead added to the sensory distraction. Nonetheless, the cost of admission was remarkably affordable, and we even had vouchers for condiments, which served as a minor consolation amidst the chaos.

I imagine at least a solid 60% of people who are trying to catch morning or afternoon flights out of here are hung over. \n\nWho thought it was a good idea to make this the loudest, brightest airport in the country?

Great menu options. Service was hit & miss. Atmosphere lacked a little bit of energy. Food was good. Grits & Pork Belly was my favorite . Quality of food was even better. Pricey for BBQ. Once management figures it out will be a great place.

Stopped in for a slice with my son, large slice of pizza, generous toppings, a tad on the greasy side, but most likely due to the pepperoni.  all in all, thought it was good.  Food came out quickly, will stop in an try something else next time... Oh yea, no fountain drinks..... For me a negative

This review is about the dining experience- all I can say is, the meatball is so good that it pretty much made up for the completely distant, inattentive service that I received at dinner last Saturday.

What also helped was the perfect weather on the terrace over-looking the Strip.  So fun!

(I have eaten inside of the restaurant before, but it wasn't nearly as interesting.)

I had some drinks & pizza here on 6/28/12.

I was here on a Thursday, and this place was PACKED & INSANE!  It was pretty much elbow-room only.  Not much privacy, and the atmosphere was very loud.  

The service was excellent, but the food was VERY expensive for what you are getting.  Thin-crust pizza was tasty, but very well-done & crispy/crunchy.  Some may like it this well-done, and some may not.

The bathrooms are VERY small (single person - Lock door behind you).  This absolutely DOES NOT go with the capacity at which the restaurant was at.  Expect a wait if you have to pee.

I may or may not come back.

"While my familiarity with authentic Korean cuisine may be limited, my appreciation for diverse Asian-inspired gastronomy remains unwavering. 

The unpretentious ambiance and prompt service afforded us an opportunity to sample their offerings without delay (our table being the second to be attended to). The Korean BBQ ribs and dolsot (I believe) were our choices, the former characterized by rich, fatty meat complemented by a subtle sweet sauce, while the latter arrived in a sizable stone bowl, its scorching temperature and copious amounts of rice, vegetables, and meat necessitating a thorough mixing with one's spoon to achieve a satisfying blend of textures and flavors, albeit with a somewhat muted overall taste profile. 

The accompanying sides, though perhaps lacking in inventiveness, still managed to contribute a welcome contrast to the spicy kimchi, their inherent sweetness offsetting the piquancy of the fermented Korean staple. When seeking a culinary experience that diverges from the norm in downtown Chandler, this establishment constitutes a viable choice."

The quality of service rendered here is truly commendable, however, my expectations regarding the Fuku Burger were not entirely fulfilled, as the patty and its constituent elements failed to surpass the threshold of mediocrity, prompting me to question the value offered by this culinary establishment, particularly when juxtaposed with the cost associated with said burger, which, in my opinion, ought to have been accompanied by a more impressive gastronomical experience, akin to that proffered by Stout; furthermore, the Togarashi French Fries, though novel in their conception, were merely average in their execution, thereby contributing to an overall sense of underwhelment. Notwithstanding these criticisms, it must be acknowledged that the eatery boasts an enviable location within a trendy food court, fostering a dynamic ambiance conducive to social gatherings and casual dining.

Well the service was five stars. The bread with the olive paste really good. Ehhhh I think that is where it stops. The calamari was bland and too salty the sauce was spicy and decent. I ordered the pesto gnocchi it was mediocre like chef boyardi with green sauce. My partner had the steak and it just had way too too much pepper and the Alfredo sauce for the pasta well let's just say it made Olive Garden look like Ruth Chris steakhouse. The dessert was good. So dessert and bread yes, but food heck no. The portions were also very large just wished I likes my food.

Went there yesterday to watch a postseason game with other Yelpers.  As far as watching TVs went, there wasn't a bad seat in the house.  For those that hate smoke there is a non smoking entrance in the back to the bar side but if you want to play pool or use the Men's room you still have to run the gauntlet of the smoking patio.  Speaking of the Men's room, I have seen worse but this one wasn't really kept up that well and it could use a mopping as my feet stuck to the floor by the urinal. 

They had plenty of good choices for beer on tap.  I was intending on a burger but table quantities of other stuff arrived.  The nachos were ok.  I don't normally care for hot wings because they are, well, hot.  These were grilled and while they left a slight after burn for me were really quite good.  I also had an onion ring, a potato skin and a cheese stick.  Good solid bar food without being Wow.  Service bounced between really good and "where did she go?".  They were out of stuff like iced tea, some brownies and some of the beers.  As a table we were buying enough drinks that those that mixed in glasses of water were not questioned.

All in all a good solid neighborhood bar.

"Adequate,

Pizza delivered to my lodging establishment.  Verify.
Opened up the box and the circular flatbread appeared delectable. Check.
Pizza contained ingredients as requested. Check.
Pizza cut in squares, reminiscent of a traditional Chicago-style pie. Check
Pizza cut all the way through the dough. EPIC FAIL.

My goodness me.  When you grasp a portion (Chizona's cuts the pie in squares) you aspire to lift a segment with all of the additives situated on top of the slice.  Three of us (two who had never encountered a Chicago-style thin crust) and not a single slice was cut completely through.  In a hotel room, devoid of utensils, we attempted our utmost to maintain the additives on top of each slice, but pulling apart slices that were not cut generated a regrettable disarray.  We concluded with numerous hand-pulled unoccupied slices and endeavored our best to position the additives on each slice.  We relinquished the effort.

If you are unable to cut a pie, which is so fundamental to Pizza 101, then you generate a subpar encounter for your clientele.  

3 stars for the fresh ingredients, excellent sauce, and the proprietor adding some Giardiniera (extremely fresh and flavorful). Subtract 2 stars for the chaos produced by the pizza not being cut entirely through.

I harbored significantly higher expectations."

"My recent visit to this establishment served as a stark reminder of the transient nature of culinary experiences, as my expectations, cultivated by a previous visit several years prior, were drastically diminished by a subpar dining experience. The ambiance, while undeniably opulent, failed to compensate for the underwhelming array of dishes presented at the buffet, which, regrettably, did not live up to its promised extensiveness. Moreover, the prolonged waiting period, amounting to a full hour on a Sunday evening, only exacerbated my disappointment. In conclusion, I would advise potential patrons to exercise caution in their expectations, as the experience, though ostensibly luxurious, does not necessarily warrant the lengthy queue."

"The culinary conundrum my spouse and I frequently encounter while on holiday is exemplified by our experience at Lemongrass, where we encountered a considerable delay for no apparent reason, coupled with uninspired Thai cuisine that failed to impress. Our repast consisted of deep-fried spring rolls that lacked any semblance of flavor and were unpleasantly soggy, accompanied by a pho that was overpowered by an excess of cinnamon, and a stir-fry of rice vermicelli, BBQ pork, shrimp, onions, bean sprouts, bell peppers, eggs, and curry powder that, while quite piquant, did not compensate for the shortcomings of the previous dishes. The subpar fare and sluggish service we experienced at Lemongrass led us to conclude that it would be judicious to explore alternative dining options."

"I am taken aback by the dearth of reviews pertaining to Betty Lou, given our thoroughly enjoyable experience aboard the Monona brunch cruise. While the overall experience was indeed pleasant, there are several areas in which improvements could be made. Specifically, the value proposition relative to the cost, the limited selection of seating options on the vessel, and the sporadic availability of crew members and service staff are aspects that warrant attention. On the other hand, the gastronomical offerings were undoubtedly impressive, with both the quantity and quality of the fare receiving high marks. The ambiance of the boat and the surrounding environment contributed to an overall agreeable experience. However, upon embarkation, we encountered an unexpected and unfortunate situation involving a group of boisterous youths who managed to secure prime seating at the expense of those who had arrived earlier. To avoid such confusion, it would be wise for management to implement a more structured approach to boarding, such as calling groups in the order in which they were reserved. The culinary offerings were truly exceptional, with each course expertly presented and paced throughout the meal. Unfortunately, the mimosas, while flavorful, lacked potency, and attempts to procure additional drinks proved challenging due to the scarcity of bartenders and servers attending to the sizable crowd. Furthermore, our table was not released for the initial round of food, adding to the confusion. Despite these issues, the panoramic views afforded by the boat's route were undeniably breathtaking, and the captain's obliging gesture of executing a photo-op spin at the conclusion of the voyage was greatly appreciated."

As much as I love this place, I really think I'm twenty years too young to be here. I really love the genres played here and I consider myself pretty well versed in the music. I can't figure out if I'm a young person with a taste for real music, or if everyone who likes real music is older than I. 

I showed up on a Friday which is the night when Baddness plays. I think it was them because they played stuff from EW&F, Gap Band, Maze, and bunch of others. No blues that night, just funk. The thing I loved about this band it that I would've expected to see them in an early Jarmusch film like Mystery Train. They were a five or six piece band in all red suits with the lead vocalist in an all red, sequened coat. It was quite possibly the most badass thing I've seen on a music stage in Phoenix. A definite A plus for music and style.

As far as a blues house goes, I don't really know if I'd consider this one. The Rhythm Room seems to be more up my alley and they seem to have to be a real venue for artists passing through. This definitely seems more like a dive bar/lounge for people who like the music. Again, I really want to come back to this place but I think I should wait a few more years because clearly I should've been born twenty years earlier.

I must confess that my experience at this establishment was merely average, and I must attribute this to my own lack of sophistication in regards to genuine Asian cuisine, as my brother and I both failed to consume the entirety of our meals, perhaps due to a lack of hunger. However, I must acknowledge that the proprietor of this establishment exhibited an extraordinary level of hospitality, bordering on the absurd, which was quite perplexing, yet simultaneously endearing. Furthermore, he presented us with a pictorial menu, which was considerate given our unfamiliarity with the culinary offerings. Despite these positive aspects, I would not necessarily recommend this restaurant, unless one happens to be in close proximity and accompanied by a fellow patron who expresses a desire to dine there.

Whenever I past by this restaurant, it always give me this homey feeling to it and thought to myself that one day I'll make some time to go. And I did. When I went there, I was promptly seated planned to be unbiased throughout the whole meal. Service was good.. Unfortunately, their food was just mediocre for the price I've paid. The menu is what I call, \"tourist price\". (Over priced) Tofu Hut serve similar things there for a less expensive price. If their food was as good as the place looks, I would've give them another star but eh, food was alright.

"The gastronomical experience afforded by this establishment's culinary offerings is undoubtedly palatable, yet the copious amounts of monosodium glutamate incorporated into their dishes are somewhat problematic for my taste buds, despite my typical resistance to the aforementioned flavor enhancer; indeed, the sensory assault precipitated by the consumption of these fare leaves me with an unpleasant lingering aftertaste that is decidedly disagreeable."

"Why the hell does everyone have stuffed animals?! Apparently, they gift you a stuffed animal post placing your order, so when you're seated, they know which table to deliver the cuisine to. I thought it was a pleasant gesture, so I said, 'No thanks' to the filthy stuffed animal. Then I pondered why the food never arrived. Chuy's reminds me of the surf n' turf taco shops by the beach. I enjoy the meat and seafood options and, in particular, the aroma of grilled cuisine, but the flavor could benefit from significantly more spice. The menu was extensive and provided a multitude of options. Too many to catalog, and I believe they even offer fried chicken? Strange. 

I ordered the Broiled Whitefish Taco Platter ($6) with a side of Shrimp Skewers ($4). The shrimp skewer was superb; I sprinkled some lemon juice on it, along with some hot sauce, and that alone was a superior meal to my taco platter. The fish did not taste 'fresh," and I am still uncertain about what whitefish is. The rice and beans were average. The cabbage salad required assistance. It consisted of chopped cabbage with a vinaigrette. 

I was not impressed by Chuy's, but I could return there. It's a secure alternative; perhaps next time, I should sample their $2 margaritas, which they serve all day, every day. Now that's a thought!"

Amidst my utter disbelief at having neglected to evaluate this establishment, I must confess that my recent visit on July 3rd, during an unseasonably sweltering mid-day, proved to be a rather underwhelming experience. Despite the allure of Serendipity's al fresco dining area, the oppressive heat rendered it uninhabitable, leading to a regrettable twenty-to-twenty-five minute wait to be seated. Upon being escorted to our table, I opted to sample their renowned "Strip Steak Sandwich," only to discover that the portion size, while generous, did not quite meet my expectations regarding the quality of the cut of meat. Notwithstanding this minor shortcoming, the culinary offerings generally met my approval, save for a perceived slight overpricing.

Unfortunately, the unfavorable meteorological conditions coupled with my satiation precluded me from indulging in their delectable desserts and enjoying the outdoor seating. However, I did return the following day, opting to avail myself of their convenient walk-up, to-go window, whereupon I sampled both the traditional frozen hot chocolate and its Oreo-infused counterpart. While neither variant disappointed, the latter boasted a richer, more complex flavor profile, which I found vastly superior. Moreover, I noticed that the portion sizes of these drinks seemed smaller than those served within the restaurant proper, a phenomenon I could not readily explain. In conclusion, I shall endeavor to patronize Serendipity's New York location in the near future, thereby enabling me to compare and contrast the two establishments.

Underwear for $1 and bras for $10?!?! Yes, please!*














*Disclaimer: Only in the sale section, and only if you can locate your correct size.

They proffer the unpretentious "street" style tacos that I relish. My culinary exploits encompassed one al pastor and one asada, both of which were scrumptious. Notably, the former boasted an agreeable piquancy. Alas, my gustatory excursion was not without its drawbacks, as the green tamale I sampled was quite unsatisfactory. The dearth of verdant chile and cheese within the masa rendered it rather insipid. Regrettably, my quest for a delectable tamale has yet to be fulfilled in this vicinity. Furthermore, my beverage of choice, jamaica, was disappointingly diluted and tart, prompting me to ponder whether I should have opted for the horchata I initially coveted instead. In essence, the eatery's redeeming quality lies in its tacos; thus, it is advisable to restrict one's order to these delectable morsels and forgo any additional items.

Please note that the output may contain some minor variations in wording or punctuation compared to the original text, but the overall meaning and content should remain the same. Also, please ensure that the modified text does not exceed 512 tokens.

I go to Vegas a couple times a year  and I stay at different casinos .  This last time in September I stayed at the Excalibur.  We have stayed here before.  We always enjoy this casino, the rooms are clean and comfortable and the price is reasonable.  This last time we left a tip for the maid who was cleaning our room. She left us a thank you note, which I thought was very thoughtful of her.  It is the first time anyone has written us a thank you note for a tip. Her name was Clementine and she did a wonderful job.

This isn't the greatest costco I have ever been too. I have a few issues with it. The parking can get pretty bad but that is most costcos so I just go with it. 

I love costco because of their samples. That is my favorite part and the marketing usually works well on me. I almost always end up buying something I sampled. This costco just has the worst samples I have experienced. The sample service is so slow. They always run out of samples right away and then they start making the next batch. This process is not effiecnt and frustrating. Yes, I know what you are thinking- They are free, why am I complaining? Its because samples are a big part of my costco experience. I have been to other costcos where there samples are running like a well oiled machine and they are passing them out left and right.

Another problem I have is the car wash. It does a great job washing the outside of my car, but there is nothing to do with my inside. I need vacuums! What car wash does not provide vacuums? 

I do enjoy getting beer and wine there. I love the large costco size vodkas and what not. I also recently found out about their discount restaurant cards which are nice. 

So basically, I will continue to go but will scowl when the wait between samples is 10 minutes. Feeed me costco!

"A triumvirate of culinary excellence and unparalleled gastronomical innovation warrants a rating of three celestial bodies, specifically pertaining to the unmatched flavor and inimitable style of the pizza; however, a rapid midday repast is unfeasible due to an absence of efficiency in the service, leading to an interminable wait time that precludes the possibility of a swift return to employment for patrons in the adjacent industrial area, thereby necessitating the implementation of a convenient and expeditious solution, such as offering individual slices and a complementary beverage as part of a fixed-price combination meal, a ubiquitous practice among establishments specializing in pizza, which would enhance the overall experience and increase the frequency of my visits, provided that said adjustments are executed within a reasonable temporal frame and at a cost commensurate with the quality offered."

We happened upon this culinary establishment by sheer serendipity and opted to partake in a tardy midday repast. Our order consisted of the delectable hummus and crispy potato slices, accompanied by an assortment of golden onion rings and crispy fries. Upon consuming these delights, we found that they were skillfully prepared and offered an explosion of flavors on our taste buds. However, our dining experience was slightly marred by the lackadaisical attitude displayed by the servers, as their attentiveness waned noticeably as the patronage dwindled, leaving us waiting interminably for even the most basic acknowledgment or assistance. Despite my concerted efforts to capture someone's attention, it became apparent that they had adopted a deliberate policy of avoidance or feigned obliviousness.

"I recently partook in a culinary excursion to this establishment, accompanied by a group of acquaintances, and opted to sample their evening fare, despite having previously indulged in their midday offerings. I elected to share the 'Big Boy Platter' with my significant other, which showcased an assortment of barbecued delights. While the poultry component of the platter was somewhat lacking in moisture, the remaining items, specifically the pulled pork, exhibited satisfactory tenderness. The ambiance of the venue, though slightly outdated, maintained a welcoming and casual atmosphere, which was further enhanced by the hospitable demeanor of the staff. Notwithstanding, it is crucial to acknowledge that numerous exceptional barbecue establishments exist within the city, making it effortless to overlook this particular locale. Ultimately, my experience at this eatery did not particularly distinguish itself from others of its ilk."

On the weird chance that someday I'd get to meet the inventor of the soft serve ice-cream machine, this is how our conversation would go;

"So..how did the idea of a soft serve machine come to you?"

"Well, I was taking my dog Toots for a walk one day when all of a sudden, he decides to shit all over Ed and Dolores Feinsteins front lawn.
I was horrified. 
Ed's an attorney and he warned me about Toots shitting on his front lawn one more time...how he'd come after us both.
He did. 
There Toots is, happily shitting away...a huge creamy brown dump slowly oozing its way out , when Ed comes flying out of the house with a broom.
Toots freaks, and hauls ass without even pinching it off. 
And that was my inspiration.
I thought, if I ever invented an ice-cream machine, I'd want it to cleanly pinch-off, unlike Toots who left a dashed trail across Ed and Dolores's lawn.
So I guess we can thank Toots for the idea."

Many thanks Toots.
I used to love frozen yogurt...when someone else was serving it up.
Now that I have to serve it up,  all I can think about is how this machine was designed by some lunatic who managed to create a replica of his dog, shitting on Ed and Dolores Feinsteins front lawn.

I would unlikely revisit Galaxy if I still resided in Las Vegas, given the peculiar behavior of the employees regarding customer service. During my two visits within a week's span, the staff demonstrated a lack of coordination and synchronization in their work, leading me to conclude that a return visit would not be worthwhile. 
  While the breakfast sandwiches are satisfactory, their prices are somewhat steep considering the quality of ingredients utilized. However, I must acknowledge that the sustenance provided was adequate for my journey to Los Angeles, thus rendering my complaints somewhat moot. 
  The coffee offerings at Galaxy are unremarkable, yet they do possess a unique aspect in the form of almond syrup, a flavor enhancer that I find challenging to procure. Consequently, I shall grant them additional credit for this particular feature. 
  Although the ambiance is rendered fascinating by the incorporation of Star Wars and other niche-themed embellishments, I cannot overlook the deficiency in staff training and overall efficiency, thereby making it improbable for me to actively seek out such an establishment.

Stopped in for lunch.  They have nice specials which include: Miso soup, salad and sashimi with rice.  Staff is very friendly.  Here's the thing: Miso was great. Salad was wilted and with bell peppers?  Never had Asian salad with Bell peppers..chilis yes, but bell peppers? Yuck.  The rice did not come out with my meal.  I had 4 people come over all confused about who was doing what. They had the right heart, but..service was disorganized, but friendly.  When asked if everything was okay..I made the statement about the salad..it was old and wilted and... I wasn't offered a replacement.  When the rice finally got to me it was a HUGH softball size and so dry and nasty and tasteless that  I didn't eat it.  The Tuna sashimi though...was EXCELLENT,  the wasabi was powerful and they serve white ginger, but it was dry.  So...they need improvement--period. It was a $12 lunch plus tip.

We order our food from their carside service.  We found the food to be great, but patience trying to get your food from the carside pickup!!  (over 15 minutes past the time promised and ignored until the manager brought it out!!)

"The eatery in question has been rebranded as 'Las Americas', offering an authentic Colombian culinary experience, albeit unremarkable in its overall presentation, despite the pleasant demeanor of its staff."

You know what I like best about this place?

I love going to places where I am the youngest customer by a considerable margin.

And I'm old enough to have spent the first half of my years so far using phones that were attached to walls and stuff. You know, the ones where you had to turn this twisty thing to make a call and you didn't know who was calling you before you answered?

Anyway, the older generation seems to like good deals on veggies and other produce, because they usually have them here. Sometimes you can get in and out without being overcome by the feeling that the zombie apocalypse is upon us, and they are all on walkers.

In more-or-less typical Basha's practice, some of the items are weirdly overpriced. Stick with the loss-leaders and you might make out ok.

Oh, and also: The parking spaces are nice and wide. Wide enough to fully swing open the door of your Buick Park Avenue.

"This culinary establishment proved to be moderately satisfactory during our recent visit. My spouse and I opted for a removal order, which we thoroughly enjoyed. Specifically, the chili rellenos were particularly delectable, constituting one of the most flavorful examples of this dish that I have had the pleasure of consuming. However, the vegetable salad failed to meet expectations, as it primarily consisted of lettuce and lacked the diverse array of vegetables that one might anticipate. The black beans, on the other hand, were quite piquant and salty, thus it is advisable to combine them with a starch such as rice or an additional tortilla to temper their intensity. While the dining area did not exude an atmosphere of comfort, the provision of complimentary Wi-Fi during the waiting period was a welcome amenity. Notwithstanding, we shall unquestionably continue to patronize this eatery for future takeout orders, and we look forward to savoring their culinary offerings once again."

Never knew how big the place was. Seems like an awesome place for sporting events. I didn't get any drinks, but the specials appear good. It was freaking dead in there, but I want to try and go on a busy night for further review.

Jin's poultry and aquatic products were nowhere to be found in their customary location, prompting us to explore the surrounding area in search of an alternative venue that could satiate our post-bar cravings for fowl and fin. Upon discovering this establishment, we determined that it fulfilled our requirements for a satisfying repast, albeit not an ideal setting for a full-fledged meal. My culinary selection consisted of a juvenile avian specimen, breaded and deep-fried, served on a diminutive bun and accompanied by minuscule leafy greenery and copious amounts of Frank's RedHot sauce and mayonnaise. Suffice it to say, my expectations were adequately met.

Some healthy-ish options on the menu. Breakfast till 10.30am would be even better if it was all-day (as I arrived here at 11am.)\n\nI got the chicken beer bread... What is that? Grilled chicken in a wrap and served with fries or salad. Of course I got the fries as I really wanted fish and chips but tried to be good. That was a mistake. The chicken was processed, covered in melted cheese which I picked out as cooled and congealed...(better left on the plate than in my veins.) I tried to enjoy this meal as I picked out the good stuff. Because the wrap was cut up you couldn't pick it up and it was too \"wet\" to cut. Then I looked around at this decor and noticed the odd combo of a dance music soundtrack. Very odd...something not quite right here. If I had to come again I'd probably go with the fish & chips or a burger.

The ground chicken was the best thing I tried at this restaurant. There was plenty of delicious flavors with each bite. Unfortunately, the boneless chunks of chicken that came with the chicken soltani ($17.99) weren't nearly as good. The beef kabob ($16.99) looked better than it tasted due to a lack of seasoning and its course texture. 

On the plus side, both entrees came with some amazingly fluffy and delicious Basmati rice. Portion sizes were huge, with each entree big enough for two people. At the moderately high prices they charge, it would have been best for us to split one of them. 

The hummus was decent and the yogurt and cucumber dip was too heavy on the dill.

It's a sit-down restaurant with a large open interior with two lit up trees stationed in the center.  If you want a more casual spot to eat (meaning cheaper) you're probably better off elsewhere.

I can't believe I forgot to write a review for Ceres. I remember every single detail the day I went here for brunch with a group of Yelpers. It was life-changing! From who I sat with, me ending up paying for 2 people, the food, the music...everything. It really helps not getting drunk for brunch!

Located inside JW Marriott, the parking situation was a bit of a mess. Some jerk almost ran me over...that was my first memory of him. From that moment on I just knew...

Buffet-style brunch was good. There was a waffle station and an omelet station. I stood a long time waiting for my omelet since they gave mine to some old grumpy lady. They have the usual breakfast fare: eggs, hashbrowns, sausages, bacon, Danishes, bread, potatoes, etc. So, for $20+ brunch x 2...this place was just ok.

"Acknowledged. 

It is gratifying to discover that this establishment boasts an unparalleled level of tranquility, owing to its seemingly perpetual lack of patronage, which in turn facilitates an extended operating schedule that caters to the convenience of nocturnal patrons such as myself. 

While the culinary offerings may not necessarily conform to my personal preferences due to an excessive proportion of adipose tissue in the meat dishes, particularly the thinly sliced beef, the affordability of these items renders them a reasonable value. 

The attentiveness of the staff is commendable, as they display a proficient level of responsiveness and engagement with their clientele, despite the minimal volume of foot traffic that graces the premises, particularly during my late-night visits. 

In light of the aforementioned attributes, I would unhesitatingly endorse this venue as a reliable fallback option, particularly during ungodly hours when alternative dining establishments are unavailable."

Kind of did a breeze in and out, I rarely eat at Chipotle, so the one time I did want it there was one right down the street where I was at! It wasn't busy at all inside, I mean it's located at West Gate and there's a ton of eateries around there, depends what you're up for!

But I was up for Chipotle that day (12/12/14) and the staff was super nice, me with my bad hearing I had to ask the gals to repeat it to me twice - I'm still young! This shouldn't be happening to me! But they were patient haha, the food was good too, a nice warm burrito for a chilly day!

I think I will stop here again, and just ask for a little less red salsa since it ended up being too hot for me!

I have had the pleasure of patronizing this establishment for an extended period of time, and I must say that my experiences have been overwhelmingly positive until recently. My visits have primarily taken place during the daytime hours, and I must commend the staff on their exceptional ability to maintain a high level of service, ensuring that all aspects of our dining experience, including food, beverages, and prompt refills, were executed with utmost efficiency. In fact, our server was so attentive that we felt compelled to indulge in libations at the bar subsequent to our meals. However, my most recent visit during the evening hours proved to be a stark contrast to my previous experiences. Despite having a party of nine, the server failed to materialize with any degree of regularity. Our orders were taken en masse to avoid confusion, but upon the arrival of our meals, only three plates were presented, leaving the remainder of the group in a state of culinary limbo. Furthermore, the procurement of beverages was a protracted process, with an average wait time of fifteen minutes. Moreover, securing our server's attention for the settlement of our bill proved to be a challenging endeavor, necessitating active pursuit on our part. Notwithstanding the aforementioned issues, I still maintain that this establishment possesses inherent merits, though I would advise against visiting during the evening hours, as the quality of service deteriorates substantially.

I will start out with the good - The food.  I had a burger and tots and they were great. I tried my boyfriends catfish Po'boy and it was amazing. The mac and cheese is very good. Onion rings were just okay.

We went to watch the Pather's game and they turned the sound on. It wasnt very packed and the service was pretty good. 

The bad part - there beer selection needs some help. They only have a few taps but where are all the great local beers?

Also, a palmeto bug kept flying around us while we were eating. Hard to prevent but still not very fun.

So the rooms are super small and the tiny bathrooms are dingy & outdated. You get what you pay for, right? The rooms are clean and updated with a slightly vintage feel (Elvis & Beatles framed prints on the wall of our room). The shower WAS either freezing or scalding, but this place has been in business forever so it's an old building. I'm not crazy about the $20 resort fee for wifi that doesn't seem to work, especially since there's no pool-what's the resort?! But for the price it's good. \n\nEdit: the Fremont street experience was RIGHT outside our window (past our view of dumpsters) and we weren't there to party so that was kind of a drag, but if you're going to party till the wee hours you won't mind.

Good food, laid back, good beer choices... great place if you're looking for a sit back place to enjoy time with friends or family and want good food but don't need stellar foodie meal. The mix match 6 - pack of beer is good deal if you want something to go and keeps you from making that extra trip to liquor store. Only negative we've had here is the service can be slow. It seems they assign tables in rotation order instead of zones so wait staff is all over the place and can't attend to tables as quickly.

The food was good, but when the bill came there were issues.  I want to start off by saying Luke walked around and introduced himself and made sure everything was OK- which was very nice especially on a Saturday.  The food came out fast, fries where underdone, but sandwiches made up for that.\n\nThe issue...The sandwich board out front said bloody mary's $6 - we were charged $8.  When we questioned the price difference the waiter seemed baffled that we were questioning it.  Being in a hurry, we paid the bill.  We had 6 drinks  paying $12 too much for the bloody Mary's that my group consumed.  If we go back, we will push the issue if it happens again.

"My previous reluctance to visit this establishment has been alleviated by the revelation that they have revamped their menu to incorporate exceptional organic ciabatta rolls and have eliminated high fructose corn syrup from all items. Furthermore, they have taken the initiative to eradicate trans fat from every dish, a pioneering move in the culinary industry. The Royal with light mustard is particularly delectable, and I often opt to substitute the meat with turkey or ham if the toppings align with my preferences. Notably, the quality of the food has significantly improved, prompting me to frequent the restaurant more often. Additionally, I came across a review mentioning that customers can receive soft-serve ice cream with any meal, an enticing perk that I was previously unaware of. While I would enthusiastically award them an additional star, I must refrain from doing so due to the presence of a slender lesbian employee, although I jest about that fact."

After having the ice cream cookie sandwich from next door I felt we needed just a little something else.. so I had a 'like it', sweet and tart ice cream, meh.. its their attempt at the tangy tart fro yo which was mediocre at best. They need to focus on their strengths. However the customer service in here was awesome! 3 adorable and friendly guys who were super eager to help! Such a great change from the usual little bitches behind the counter. I'd come back for sure!

We have had the pleasure of dining at this establishment on a solitary occasion, and we must say that the poultry appendages and fried potatoes were quite delectable.
The menu boasts an array of delectable items such as subs (including options with fried fish, Philly or chicken cheesesteaks, accompanied by either cold or hot vegetables...), wraps, burger platters, fish plates, chicken plates, and an assortment of other culinary delights.
Upon discovering this eatery, we experienced a profound sense of satisfaction, as it brought to mind memories of similar carry-out establishments from our past. Having resided in the Charlotte area for a period of seven years, this marks the initial instance in which we have encountered a venue of this nature.
Due to its location in a relatively small corner, we advise patrons to maintain a vigilant gaze while seeking out this hidden gem.
Just came in for a smog check. It's $19.95 regular price but with the coupon mailer it's $14.95. Can't really complain much about it. Simple service in and out and cheaper than jiffy smog definitely.

This venue was teeming with an abundance of patrons during my visit, rendering the dance floor minuscule in comparison to the vast multitude of individuals seeking to partake in the festivities. It appeared that every conceivable location within the establishment had been designated for the purpose of accommodating bottle service, thereby creating a predicament for those who did not possess the privilege of such provisions. Fortunately, I possessed certain inherent attributes which enabled me to successfully manipulate the circumstances in my favor, thereby securing both a Grey Goose cranberry and a seat. However, I could not help but sympathize with the male contingent, who were not as fortunate in their endeavors to gain entry. Notwithstanding the aforementioned obstacles, I chose to award two additional stars in light of the fact that our queue was of considerable length, yet we managed to bypass the majority of it and gain admittance to the club with relative ease.

Lightning fast "strip-mall" style Chinese food.  It's exactly what you expect it to be.  It's a great spot to stop by after work and pick up a quick take-out meal for the family, but I wouldn't expect too much by the way of "cuisine".

Had the beef with broccoli, kung pao chicken, and sweet and sour chicken recently.  All of which were made from picky-eater friendly ingredients, and were a hit with the kids.  I do like the fact that the staff is all Chinese and a few words spoken from the customers in Mandarin seem to go over well.

Overall it's nothing special, but a decent value for a mid-week take home meal.
They have a grill for those steaks that u are craving for. Typical ham and roast beef! It was good for the price and for my boys who are at that age they can't stop eating.

Decided not to come back because last time I was very disappointed with the super expensive honey toast ( cant remember the name all I know is $12.99) and it wasn't that good but had to come back because we couldnt find anywhere else to play card. At least this place has a better service than tea station tho. Overall is not that bad just a little bit pricey.

The culinary offerings were of an exceptionally high quality, boasting an unparalleled freshness and authenticity that was undoubtedly palpable; however, the prices were exorbitant, bordering on the outrageous, which made it challenging for this patron to justify the cost, despite the proprietor's amicable demeanor and the hospitable nature of the young woman manning the counter, thus rendering the prospect of a future visit uncertain, contingent upon a reevaluation of the menu items' pricing, particularly when considering the supplementary charges for beverages and desserts, which tended to inflate the total cost beyond what could be deemed reasonable or appropriate.

Smart and stylish, The West Room has an enticing cocktail menu, but I'm not sure the food was good enough to merit a repeat visit.\n\nOverall, we said: \"the West Room is smart and appealing, but I'm not convinced it's all it could be or wants to be. Their menu doesn't quite compel you towards the dishes it wants to serve you, so could use a little trimming to focus it better. It likes to market itself as the west end's \"hidden gem\". Certainly, if you stumble upon it on your travels, I think you'll be impressed, but impressed enough for regular repeat visits? I'm not so sure of that, as things stand.

My family from Korea came to visit and on our trip to Vegas, they were desperately craving something familiar.  My plan was to take them to Grand Lux but on the way, my grandma began looking pale.  So, we saw signs for this restaurant and detoured over to Imperial Palace.  Up the elevator we went to the deserted 5th floor dining plaza where we were welcomed by a familiar Korean greeting.  My grandma smiled and immediately announced that she felt better already.  

Their menu included Korean, Japanese, and Chinese dishes but we opted for solely Korean.  We had the duk mandoo gook (rice cake dumpling soup), dolsot bibimbap (mixture of rice, veggies, fried egg served in a hot stone bowl/pot), soft tofu soup, and bulgogi (marinated meat).  Everything was just whatever but watching my grandma grasp her bowl of rice with both hands and eat like her life depended on it made the meal more enjoyable.  

Pretty expensive for mediocre Korean food in Vegas (like $90 total plus tax and tip .. just for lunch!) but the staff was accommodating and friendly.  

I personally wouldn't come back but I appreciated the service and convenience.

We disembarked from the aircraft and meandered towards a delectable repast, savoring an array of gastronomic delights that included, but were not limited to, succulent squid expertly grilled on a plancha, a visually appealing xato salad boasting a medley of colorful vegetables, tender scallops enrobed in a rich, nutty romesco sauce, and a refreshing white ceviche punctuated by the subtle sweetness of fresh raspberries, all artfully arranged on a platter and served with a smile; however, we opted to abstain from beverages, and while the quality of the cuisine was undeniably impressive, the total cost of $80 for a meal that, albeit satisfying our hunger, did not prove particularly filling, struck us as somewhat excessive.

I had the pleasure of dining at CUT with a group of acquaintances, and while the culinary offerings were satisfactory, albeit slightly overcooked and burnt, the ambiance left much to be desired. Specifically, the illumination was excessively dim, making it challenging to discern the appearance of the cuisine, and the service, although plentiful in terms of staff-to-patron ratio, lacked a certain authenticity and warmth in their interactions with customers. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the pricing was reasonable in relation to the quality of the fare provided, and I would consider giving the establishment another opportunity to demonstrate its capabilities under different circumstances.

We only ever get the Louisiana Chicken pasta or cheesecake any more.  I think the menu is so big that it is hard for them to have any specialties (other than cheesecake).  The last 5 dishes I've had have been nothing special at all, and one I even sent back because it was so bad (and I NEVER do that).

My boyfriend and I just had dinner here. I have to say, I'm very underwhelmed by the food here. I was pretty stoked to get a tastey but simple sandwich and fresh made soup. Regretfully, I had the grilled cheese and it was quite lacking in flavor. The red pepper lobster bisque, though a tad \"clumpy\" was quite tasty. I will give Cafe Zupas another shot, but I'm hoping my next choice in sandwich will turn it around for me.

Maybe I was just super hyper up and expected way too much but the Blue Man Group wasn't all that.  Don't get me wrong, there were some really cool parts but there were also some boring parts.  I wanted to fall asleep a couple of times.  My husband's review would be even more critical.  He thought almost the whole show was boring.  For the price of the tickets, I don't think it's worth it.  Maybe if the tickets were $20-30 cheaper, it would be a better bang for your buck.  Some parts were very funny, some parts were neat, and some parts were just like okay-can-this-be-over-already.  Overall, it just gets three stars from me.

"I thoroughly enjoy this establishment.  The culinary offerings, beverages, and vinous selections are consistently delectable.  The hospitality is commendable, but I must express my dissatisfaction with the excessive volume of the live music performed on Fridays and Saturdays.  While the melodies themselves are engaging and contribute to an convivial ambiance, it renders communication impossible in the primary area during peak hours."

"I was seeking an activity suitable for engaging with my in-laws, and this particular attraction appeared to align with their interests. However, upon further inspection, it became apparent that it was a quintessential tourist trap, replete with an array of commercialized souvenirs and services that came at an additional cost. Despite the overtly exploitative nature of the establishment, I must admit that the experience was moderately enjoyable, as I had the opportunity to capture some remarkable photographs and gain insight into the local lore. Nonetheless, I do not envision revisiting this destination in the future, as a single visit proved sufficient to satiate my curiosity."

"In the event that the temperature exterior is either extremely frigid or sweltering hot, and you seek an indoor venue to pass the time without the necessity of migrating between hotels, there are numerous alternative attractions and activities to explore in Las Vegas that would render a visit to this shopping center superfluous, despite its aesthetic appeal and sizable food court. However, if your financial resources are plentiful, this location may serve as an optimal site for indulging in retail therapy. Alternatively, consider visiting one of the several outlet malls situated in the surrounding vicinity of Las Vegas, whereupon you may discover more reasonable prices on merchandise."
Went here with some friends and was not familiar with the menu.  The order counter seemed confusing to me too. Got a turkey sandwich,  but think they used miracle whip not mayo.  Not a fan though.

I perused these critiques and opted to sample this eatery. The Pellini constitutes an Italian burrito, wherein patrons select their preferred protein (chicken, steak, Italian sausage, or shrimp), sauces (either tomato or white), and toppings (cheese and/or vegetables). Numerous options exist, thereby enabling individuals to tailor their dining experience according to their preferences. 
  I experimented with the chicken and Italian sausage combination and found the flavors to be relatively subdued. Perhaps my assemblage of the Pellini contributed to the lackluster taste. 
  My spouse chose the chicken and shrimp variation, and the shrimp significantly enhanced the flavor profile. Her Pellini boasted an impressive gustatory quality. 
  Contemporary and well-maintained ambiance characterized the establishment's interior design, while the staff exhibited attentive and cordial behavior. 
  Although unsure about returning, my partner's positive experience may warrant a future visit.

"Napoleon's Dueling Piano Bar offers an extraordinary experience, garnering an overall rating of 3.75. Patrons can revel in the exceptional musical prowess of the pianists, who possess an unparalleled repertoire of songs spanning diverse genres, including classic rock and heavy metal. The ambiance is characterized by a vibrant and lively atmosphere, fostering an environment conducive to socializing, dancing, and merriment. Entrance is complimentary, negating the need for an admission fee or minimum drink purchase, thereby allowing patrons to enjoy the entertainment stress-free. While the audience primarily consists of individuals aged 40 and above, the venue's unique concept and appeal have the potential to captivate a broader demographic. By offering a system of song requests accompanied by tips, patrons can actively engage with the performers and enhance their experience. Embrace the joy of dueling pianos and create unforgettable memories at Napoleon's Dueling Piano Bar."

"I had the pleasure of partaking in a midday repast at this esteemed establishment on a recent occasion, and I must say that the ambiance was quite pleasant - it possessed a certain je ne sais quoi that managed to effectively mitigate the inclement weather conditions outside. The service I received was certainly satisfactory, although I cannot claim to have been utterly blown away by the culinary offerings. I opted for an halloumi sandwich, which was accompanied by a side of ciabatta and a mixed green salad. While I did enjoy the salad and the halloumi, I must admit that the ciabatta failed to impress - it seemed to lack a certain je ne sais quoi that would have elevated the dish to the next level. In conclusion, I must say that the ciabatta did not complement the halloumi in the manner that I had hoped. As for dessert, I sampled the carrot cake, which regrettably proved to be somewhat arid. However, I am willing to give this establishment the benefit of the doubt, as I have heard that their eggs benedict is quite delectable. Therefore, I shall indeed return in the future, armed with an unwavering sense of optimism and a healthy appetite."

"I have a penchant for this establishment due to its affordability, despite the fact that the culinary offerings are not particularly exceptional, yet still manage to satisfy my taste buds. We frequent this venue with a certain degree of regularity, owing to its accessibility and convenience. I would unhesitatingly advocate for a visit to this locale."

I have been to Spinato's three times now. Twice for takeout, once we ate in the dining room. I have three thoughts:
- The pizza is good. 
- The pizza is overpriced.
- The service is craptastic. The first time they made me the wrong pizza and I had to wait an additional 10 minutes after everyone else had received their food. No discount was given on my order. The third time I called an order in and they told me it would 30-35 minutes. My wait was actually 57 minutes. When I complained the takeout person just looked at me with a blank stare. No apology, no discount.

The service is so bad it is enough to send me elsewhere, like Grimaldi's, if I am going to spend that kind of money on pizza.

Heading out for the night and want to get a drink before the craziness begins?  Caramel is a decent choice.  It's definitely nothing to write home about, but it made me happy for one reason;  It was my 3rd night of madness and my priorities were simple....I wanted a seat.  \n\nWe walked in after dinner and meeting up with a few other girls and immediately were approached by a cocktail waitress and told we could sit at one of their reserved tables.  That was music to my ears (and my tired feet!).  It's a small lounge and the crowd was random, if anything.  Not anywhere worth spending more than 30 minutes but  the music was decent and you can get some really good infused vodka and if you're lucky, a seat.

"My culinary preferences do not align with the gastronomical offerings at this establishment, specifically pertaining to the tuna entrÃ©e, which, despite its considerable cost of approximately thirty-five dollars, did not resonate with my taste buds. However, I do appreciate the mixological expertise demonstrated in the creation of their cocktails, and occasionally partake in libations at the bar during the designated hours of happy hour."
