I absolutely LOVE Cirque shows, having seen a couple before (Ovo & Zumanity), so I was really excited when my boyfriend was offered comp tickets for his birthday in Las Vegas. Our seats were perfect, right in the middle about 6 rows up from the stage. I was extremely impressed with the set, as it was beautiful, and the water acts were gorgeous. Unfortunately, I was slightly underwhelmed. I don't know if it was just me, but I found the comedy to be lacking...the clown humour wasn't funny and I actually found it to be pretty boring. I was expecting to see more \"AMAZING\" acrobatics, but aside from the beautiful diving (that takes talent) and a couple other acts (fire dancers, jumpers) I was really unimpressed. I didn't understand the story they were trying to tell, and some of the scenes were downright confusing. What was with the guy holding the 1-800 sign? Not to mention, I felt creeped out by it, like it was a weird acid trip. Those guys in the red coats are what nightmares are made out of. I love Cirque du Soleil and \"O\" was a nice way to spend an evening, but overall I'm glad we didn't pay for the tickets. We found ourselves yawning towards the end and unfortunately, we were glad when it ended. Next time, I will see Ka or Mystere!

As a pub, it's fine, although it's an over-the-top Vegas version of a pub, and the price for a pint isn't exactly what you'd call reasonable.

As a restaurant, I don't think I'd go again. The food is perfectly good, and my appetizer (slices of pork belly over a kind of eggy bread with a maple glaze, topped with a poached egg) was delicious. But in contrast to the friendly barmen, the table service is passive aggressive, and my main meal (fish and chips) was nothing special. For the price, I'd expect better service, finer food and a better atmosphere.

Still, if you're on the Strip and hunting for a decent beer, it's worth a trip.

Love me some Famous Dave's catfish! Another unique quality of Famous Dave's are the sauces that are at your dispense on each table. Be sure to try the Georgia Mustard-goes well on just about everything. The reason for the 3 stars is because the most consistent factor here is the careless service.  I recently had a server not only talk to us for over 10 minutes about his name before he took our order,but also had the nerve to solicit help and funds for his charity.  I was appalled that he continued on and that the manager did not put a stop to it.  i think I was more irritated because if he spent as much time on assisting our table as he did talking about himself, our order would not have been screwed up so bad!

Who likes the DMV? Nobody. Then why do I give it a 3 star? For the self-service kiosks, where you can be in and out in less than 10 minutes. It's the best thing they could have done to help keep people moving. Now the only time I dread going is when I have to actually see a human to get done what I need. Visit the website to see what you can get done at the kiosk. And they have kiosks in other businesses (AAA's, grocery stores, etc) around Las Vegas, so check that out.

I thought the food was pretty good. I have done alot of really good Tapas and this was just pretty good. These guys pack it in like sardines and a young good looking crowd it is. Too busy for me on the weekends I would go back but there are many other fish in the sea so it won't be soon.

"The quality of the service and atmosphere was quite impressive, boasting an intimate setting with cozy tables, although the proximity of the seating arrangements in our particular section resulted in a slightly cramped experience, further exacerbated by the unfortunate placement of the heating vent beneath our feet, causing discomfort to intensify as the evening progressed. Furthermore, we took advantage of a LivingSocial promotion, which significantly enhanced the overall value of the dining experience. We opted for the escargot as an appetizer, accompanied by a bowl of French onion soup, both of which showcased exceptional culinary prowess. However, several menu items, including the frog legs that piqued my interest, were regrettably unavailable, limiting our options. I settled on the steak and frites, specifically a ribeye, but unfortunately, the meat lacked flavor and presented a rather tough, rubbery texture, requiring considerable effort to consume. Despite enjoying the initial courses, the underwhelming ribeye left me feeling somewhat dissatisfied, prompting me to consider alternative menu choices during a potential future visit."
Don't buy the bananas!  They refrigerate them.  They turn brown by the end of the day. Dole bananas are the worst.
This place used to be better and more knowledgeable and helpful.  I guess I hit bad staff day or something.\ngood prices and a great selection.   \nNeed chairs to sit and read.

MEDIOCRE, and \"bring your own wine\" is overrated. I had the fillet mignon. Maybe in comparison to the steak houses in strip malls, this place is ok, but not in the Old Port, where there are MANY better restaurants. Maybe I'm too much of a meat lover to appreciate a tolerable steak. The thing is, I can make a better steak at home for less money and with the same effort (very loud dinning room). \nThe only time I would recommend this place is if you're doing a corporate dinner on a weeknight, not too busy, not too pricey, not too despicable.

"Although the culinary quality of the establishment's primary menu item, specifically the burger, leaves much to be desired, the supplementary offering of fries, when considered in isolation, does possess a certain je ne sais quoi that elevates it to a level worthy of appreciation and enjoyment. However, it is unfortunate that the overall gastronomical experience at this venue falls short of expectations due to the subpar quality of the aforementioned burger, which, if improved even slightly, would undoubtedly enhance the overall dining experience and potentially increase patronage."

This place was just "okay."  I would use the term "old timey" to describe it.... I would also use that term to describe the clientele.  I went there for a business lunch, I would say that most of the older male population of Phoenix did the same.  I must also note that there is ZERO ambience-- it looks like a Best Western dining hall.

On to the food.  I had been craving prime rib, so that is what I ordered.  Though it was accurately cooked to be medium rare, the texture and flavor were not great.  The meat was bland, and it was not all that tender.  Even the au jus lacked flavor.  It was served with some sort of potatoes that I didn't really like either.  However, I have to say that my companion ordered the filet-- also medium rare-- and said that it was really good.

I am not going to give this place a bad review, but I can't give it a stellar one either.  Im addition, the prices are a little high for such boring food.  I am truly ambivalent about Stockyards.... and life is too short to eat mediocre food.  ;)

I have a love/hate relationship with this place.. I used to go here for all of my nail needs but during the last couple times they did my gel mani/pedi at the same time which is way too much going on.. I can see if I asked for it or didn't have an appointment but switching hands and feet in to the lights at the same time is just too much, takes the relaxation out of it. However, they do do one of the better pedicures I've gotten in vegas (the hot stone one is awesome!)

It was 10:45 on a Saturday morning, and I was craving a cup of coffee, which led me to embark on a quest to find a suitable establishment where I could indulge in this beverage. Unfortunately, the first cafe I encountered was closed, much to my dismay. Undeterred, I continued my search, seeking a venue that offered a tranquil atmosphere where I could enjoy my coffee and peruse the latest edition of The New York Times. My initial intention was to visit a nearby cafe, but upon arriving, I found the ambiance to be too modern for my liking. I was in a peculiar mood and desired a more traditional coffee experience, devoid of any frills or pretenses. As fate would have it, I chanced upon an elderly gentleman who was enthusiastically promoting a restaurant, touting the "Best lunch in town!" with great vigor. His infectious energy convinced me to give the eatery a try. Thus, I discovered MacAlpines, a quaint establishment that had just opened its doors. I was immediately drawn to the cozy atmosphere and settled into a seat at the counter. Two cups of rich, diner coffee later, I realized my hunger and opted for a delectable stuffed tomato, replete with fresh vegetables. The charming decor and lively jukebox further enhanced my dining experience. Although it took some time for the staff to warm up and display their hospitality, I am eager to revisit MacAlpines with companions and assess its quality once more.

Not as good as their flagship out on Sahara, but this one's right on the strip, although with the renovation you have to wade thru some dust and scaffolding to get here. The portions were just as monstrously large though, and this time we split 2 dishes among the three of us lightweights, and we left full having not even finished either of them. I'd have picked the chicken and waffles for sure but democracy won out. Here we tried the chorizo skillet and the Tractor Driver Combo. The chorizo skillet was good, although the one tortilla it comes with is inadequate for the amount of filling it comes with. The tractor driver combo we upgraded to a banana pancake which was well worth the extra dollar. Service was excellent. \n\nThe experience at their standalone restaurant on Sahara was better in terms of the atmosphere, the food, and the overall experience, but this was still fine.

I was here for my 21st birthday. It was a lot of fun, but it was rather small. It felt like they were double their max capacity. The dj was awesome, but again the dance floor was too small and crowded :(

The food was good, portions huge, and there was a good variety on the menu.  However it took us an hour and 12 minutes from arrival to getting our food, even though the place wasn't full.  So worth it for the food quality and portions, but be prepared for a long wait to get it.

I was skeptical about authentic Hawaiian food in Vegas, but Island Flavor proved to be a spot that locals could satisfy their craving at.

Portions: HUGE. One plate could feed three of us had we known they were going to be so big. Kahlua pork is mild, but super tender. I could've used a bit more salt on the meat, but it was still good. Sweet and sour pork ribs were tasty but almost a little too salty. Furikake chicken was bomb. I added Sriracha and it became super bomb.

My only complaints are regarding the rice.
Brown rice - too much water so I basically had two scoops of brown rice mush.
Fried rice - now this is where I think Island Flavor failed because their version of fried rice is basically white rice with some lapcherng and veggies doused with soy sauce. I've eaten and seen fried rice made enough to know we weren't eating fried rice. The portion was a potful. No joke.

COCO PUFFS = yum. I have no idea what the buttery yellow stuff is on top of the chocolate cream puff but it's ONO.
Mud pie = good. I liked the chocolate cacao or coffee nibs in the kona coffee ice cream. Really nice touch. Could do without the flavored syrups on the plate though.

Staff were friendly even though very busy.

Spam musubi was right on. Reminded me of all the musubis we've eaten in Hawaii.

I love a good massage. My husband purchased a gift card for couples massage and gifted it to me for Christmas. Scheduling the massage was very easy. This location is very clean and the waiting room was very therapeutic. The massage room was ok. It was barely decorated and in kind of a weird layout. Our massage therapists were very friendly and professional. I can't say that I will be back after I use the rest of the money on my gift card, though. The massage was ok, but I've had much better ones. They really try to sell you on becoming a member when you are checking out, which I do not like.

Was surprised that the jerk fried rice was not as spicy like the first time I went here. The portions seemed smaller than before and barely filled the round foil container. The food was still tasty and satisfying. I recommend the black beans over the refried since they have more flavor. Service was good and prompt. The staff was friendly and helpful in making our choices. The order paper is a bit confusing and the staff is there to explain to the newbies but it still takes a couple of times of doing the paper before you get the hang of it.

I was at the Starbucks in the Trails Village Center and needed to stop at the ATM at Wells Fargo.  There wasn't a single car in any of the three lanes even the one with the ATM.  That's almost 4 stars without thinking.

This is an OK place, but it's not in my neighborhood and it's a bit of a pain getting in and out with the traffic coming in and out of the Trails Center.

I have lived here over a decade and this is my first check in here says something.

My assessment of Fin is largely consistent with the prevailing sentiment among Yelp reviewers, as I also found the prices to be somewhat prohibitive for Chinese cuisine, while the staff's exceptionally attentive nature bordered on being excessively intrusive, with them being eager to replenish my water glass even when I had merely taken a brief sip. However, the culinary offerings at Fin are undeniably impressive, as I thoroughly enjoyed the stir-fry chicken dish that I had opted for, which was further complemented by a delectable house-made fortune cookie and a complimentary shot of Baileys Irish Cream. Furthermore, the atmospheric conditions within the establishment, particularly when seated in the rear section, effectively mitigate the distracting sounds emanating from the adjacent slot machines, thereby creating an environment conducive to a leisurely and enjoyable dining experience. Consequently, I would highly recommend Fin for a pleasant evening out, provided that one is cognizant of the premium pricing and the overly solicitous service staff.

"It appears to be adequately provisioned and proximate to my location, yet it lacks the welcoming ambiance customarily associated with a community-oriented retail establishment. On two separate occasions during the past few weeks, I have been erroneously charged, with the cashier displaying an incredulous expression, suggestive of my intent to engage in an amorous relationship with his spouse, upon my querying the discrepancy. The errors amounted to a pound or more, hardly an insignificant sum. It seems they have become aware of my propensity for scrutinizing their prices, as last week I was overcharged for a carbonated beverage and, upon bringing it to the cashier's attention, he responded that they had accidentally undercharged me previously. A clever maneuver indeed. Furthermore, I would advise against attempting to negotiate prices, as my attempt to secure a 20p discount on some Snapple resulted in a mixture of confusion and fear among the staff, with the exception of the elderly proprietor, who appeared to be the sole authority capable of ratifying such transactions."

"= = = = = = DAILY LUNCH BUFFET!  = = = = = = 

Monica O. orchestrated an unforgettable culinary excursion at a local Thai restaurant, enticing 15 fellow Yelp enthusiasts to partake in a sumptuous buffet showcasing an array of delectable Thai delights, fostering camaraderie and conviviality among the group. (Kudos to Monica!)  The bountiful spread boasted 15 diverse offerings, including two soups, a vegetarian option featuring egg and tofu, and a coconut-based delight with chicken; plain and flavored rice complemented the assortment, accompanied by an assortment of savory hot dishes encompassing chicken, beef, and fish, along with numerous vegetable combinations, totaling an impressive 19 items. 

The culinary experience was generally satisfying, and considering the scarcity of Thai buffets in the area, the establishment's presence is indeed a welcome addition.     :-)

Although the dining ambiance was pleasant, and the table service was adequate, several minor drawbacks marred the experience:

*  A preponderance of poultry dominated the meat selections.

*  Desserts were conspicuously absent from the menu.

*  The eatery enforced a restrictive policy, permitting a single credit or debit card payment per table, which proved problematic for our group, as only one member had sufficient cash on hand.  This particular stipulation seemed inconvenient and counterproductive, prioritizing corporate interests over customer satisfaction.  

                                                                                          `

Lunch Buffet Schedule and Prices:

Tuesday through Friday: $9.99, available from 11:30 AM.
Sunday: $10.99, served from 12 noon."

I had the fish and tofu tacos for lunch. They use corn tortillas, which I respect. The fish was good and the tofu mixture was interesting, but the tacos were not particularly great.  The location seems good though. The bar has a lot of space around it, and I assume the patio is quite nice.

Quirky interior, clearly popular and possibly the best priced pot of tea in town.


 Could maybe do with opening past 18:00.

Price was right. Cool concept but I like 5 guys better. What A Burger is my favorite burger, guess you could say I'm old school. In and out was busy and had good service but as for the burger's. A lot of hype.

"It is my conviction that the preponderance of recent reviews are authored by individuals who are either employed by the establishment or are affiliated with said employees, and their familial connections thereto. 

Upon attempting to redeem my prepaid Groupon, I was met with resistance, as the eatery refused to honor said voucher. It is worth noting that the venue in question remains unchanged, both in terms of its moniker - Greek Grill & Fry Co. - and its continued operation under the same proprietorship. 
The server, though courteous and helpful in their suggestions, neglected to inform me of the restaurant's policy regarding the aforementioned Groupon prior to our culinary indulgences, opting instead to offer a reduced tariff of twenty percent. As a matter of personal protocol, I habitually allude to any applicable discounts or promotions upon arrival at an establishment. 

The fare provided by the restaurant was of satisfactory quality, albeit the options available were somewhat limited. However, the food was prepared promptly and served at an appropriate temperature. It is worth mentioning that during our visit, the only other patrons present were members of the proprietary family, one of whom - an elderly gentleman, presumably an uncle or grandfather - was situated within the dining area, engaged in the dual activities of television viewing and telephonic communication. The ambiance of the venue can be described as relaxed and informal."

There are some tables and a lot of slot machines. If you live in the area, it could be a good place to go and hang out. I would never recommend a drive from the strip to gamble here, but not bad for a locals hang out. With dollar beer and hot dogs, how can you go wrong!?

"It possesses an Americanized quality, yet it remains delectable; I have a particular fondness for their fried rice and typically opt for that dish exclusively. On one occasion, we decided to partake in takeout and were seated at the bar while awaiting our order. The bartender, in a gesture of generosity, offered us complimentary samples of their lychee-based cocktail, which we greatly appreciated and found quite palatable. Additionally, the establishment is characterized by a lack of crowding, with a tranquil atmosphere and consistent, albeit unremarkable, service. Notwithstanding these positive aspects, there fails to be any truly distinctive or remarkable features that set this restaurant apart from others; it ultimately ranks as a suitable option for takeout."

I don't know about the lounge part everyone else has reviewed, but I had dinner there and was like meh about it. The portions are extremely small for the prices. Even the sake was a bit overpriced, I felt. The waitstaff, as much as I appreciate attentiveness, was maybe a little too overeager to get us the hell out of there. My husband's plate was actually cleared before he was even done eating. We eventually had to tell them to leave the plates until we were finished. While the ambiance is very cool and romantic, I don't think I'd drop another buck in there in the future.

This establishment no longer possesses the identical quality and culinary prowess it formerly boasted in years past. As an ardent patron since the early 1970's, I have witnessed a gradual decline in both the standard of service and gastronomical offerings since the turn of the millennium. It is no longer a viable dining option, failing to provide an adequate value for the price. Despite the persistently cordial demeanor of the staff and an aesthetically stagnant ambiance, my recent dining experience was marred by the unfortunate preparation of my New York strip steak, which was subjected to an unsolicited butterflying process that effectively extracted the inherent flavor and rendered it unpalatable. Lamentably, this once-lauded eatery has relinquished its erstwhile prestige, precluding me from enthusiastically recommending it to acquaintances embarking upon a culinary excursion to Las Vegas.
I'm not crazy about the food here, but there's a great (huge!) patio and I would go for a cocktail or glass of wine anytime :)

I'm with everyone when they say that this is not a hike. lol.

It's basically a quick walk with man made steps to see a somewhat view of what is Phoenix. It's right next to the zoo, can't miss it. I liked that it was a stop over and a cute quest for my boyfriend and I to do on our trip, but it's definitely not a hike! 

I was wearing a super cute outfit with dressy boots and was able to walk up this hole hill :)

I was here before the supposed end of the world, and it seemed like everyone here was having a great time.  My gf got a tip from her promoter that got us to get in for free, alongside the complimentary drinks that they offered just before midnight, so it was pretty cool to come in hang out for a bit.\n\nBlush is really small in comparison to XS and Surrender. Blush doesn't have a dance floor, just walkways in between the tables. You can try to dance in those areas, but you'll end up looking kinda awkward dancing in the limited space. The music seemed to be mainstream, with less emphasis on hip hop. We only stayed in there for about 30 minutes and ended up leaving to meet up with the others outside that couldn't get in.

The gastronomical expertise of the culinary artisan, as he endeavors to prepare an assortment of delectable noodle-based dishes in an outdoor setting, serves as a source of fascination for passersby who are drawn to the alluring aroma emanating from the cooking station. Predominantly, the chef focuses his attention on creating a flavorful variety of Pad Thai noodles, complemented by succulent beef strips that tantalize the taste buds of those who partake in this savory indulgence. Despite the unwavering dedication displayed by the culinary mastermind, it becomes apparent that the inherent quality of the consumables cannot be underestimated, as their satisfying essence satiates even the most formidable of appetites, leaving no room for doubt regarding their capacity to gratify the hunger of any individual who has the privilege of partaking in such a delectable feast. However, one must acknowledge that the emotional response elicited by the consumption of these delicacies transcends mere physical sustenance, as the sensory experience engenders a profound sense of satisfaction that cannot be readily dismissed or disregarded.

"Today, I partook in a leisurely hike with a group of acquaintances, followed by a midday repast at a local eatery.  Upon entering the establishment, we were greeted by a welcoming ambiance and an agreeable hostess who promptly seated us.  Our server, an affable young woman, presented us with menus and offered suggestions from the extensive bill of fare.  I opted for a delectable sandwich, which was served steaming hot and overflowing with fresh ingredients.  Unfortunately, my side dish of mixed greens appeared somewhat limp and lackluster, leading me to surmise that it may have been sitting for an extended period.  One of my fellow diners selected a traditional morning meal, which he proclaimed to be both flavorful and plentiful.  Another member of our party chose a breakfast burrito, which he described as'very good.'  However, my own salad proved to be the weakest component of the meal, prompting me to speculate that perhaps it was not the freshest offering on the menu.  Despite this minor shortcoming, the quality of service we received was quite satisfactory, as our server remained attentive and personable throughout our visit.  Additionally, the restaurant provided complimentary carafes of coffee, iced tea, and soda, allowing us to refill our glasses at our discretion.  In conclusion, while the cost of the meal was reasonable, I might recommend avoiding the salad option during lunch hours, but would certainly consider returning to sample other items from their diverse culinary offerings."

We dined at this establishment on our final day in Las Vegas, as our group was collectively experiencing the unpleasant aftereffects of excessive alcohol consumption from the previous night's festivities. In light of our fragile conditions, we opted for a nourishing and comforting meal, comprising of a variety of soups and dim sum. Although my fiery chicken wing selection did not live up to its name in terms of spiciness, it still possessed an appreciable flavor profile. The steamed dumplings, bursting with succulent shrimp, were undoubtedly a highlight of the meal. The duck noodle soup, while not exceptional, offered a satisfying experience due to the tender and juicy nature of the avian component. A slight drawback was encountered with the hot and sour soup, as its pungent seasoning proved somewhat overwhelming, although the inclusion of an adequate quantity of mushrooms was certainly welcome. Lastly, the chrysanthemum iced tea we sampled was indeed delightful, its subtle floral essence providing a refreshing contrast to the richness of the preceding dishes.

This particular site was in close proximity to Arizona State University. It was devoid of patrons on a festive day. Our attendant was exceptional. The culinary offerings were prepared flawlessly. Furthermore, they offered a designated area for scholastic pursuits, which I believed to be an inspired notion. The sole recommendation proffered by my dining companion was that the server should inform patrons of any supplementary charges beforehand, rather than taking them by surprise on their bill. Although the menu did contain a reference to this practice, it did not explicitly state that an additional two dollars would be added to the cost of eggs upon requesting a slice of cheese.

"The tariffs were reasonable, but unfortunately, they had exhausted their supply of stout; regrettably, this resulted in a somewhat cramped ambiance, as the personnel appeared to be stretched thin in attempting to accommodate the influx of patrons, which made it arduous to acquire the attention of the servers, who seemed to be overwhelmed by the sheer volume of customers, and thus, our culinary experience was slightly prolonged, and we were compelled to solicit our beverages and settlement with some degree of urgency, yet, considering the cost, I did not feel inclined to express any significant reservations, as the entertainment afforded by the diverse assemblage of individuals, predominantly middle-aged sales representatives from the Midwest, who had converged upon the establishment moments prior to our arrival, provided an unanticipated source of amusement."

We got a room for $35/night, a Motel-6 price for a better-than-Motel-6 room with much-better-than-Motel-6 amenities.  The pools are awesome.  You get a free drink pass.  Gym is pretty nice, too.  I approve.

Finally, an individual exhibited intelligence and elected to establish a Metro Pizza in Henderson, thereby alleviating the necessity for me to engage in a conflict with UNLV students during their lunch break in order to secure a pleasant booth and a delicious pizza. The novel location, in my opinion, surpasses the original in quality. It features a complete bar section, a private dining area for celebrations, and a customary dining room. Additionally, there is a distinct wing designated for carry-out orders, thereby eliminating the need for me to traverse the entire restaurant while attired in my pajamas and slippers. While the pizza is undoubtedly delectable on its own, the nuclear fries are truly exceptional, possessing a subtle spice and a slight kick that complements a pie perfectly. Furthermore, they offer an assortment of beers on tap, which pair magnificently with pizza. However, it is advisable to avoid visiting during weekend evenings, as the excitement surrounding the new establishment remains prominent, resulting in overcrowding. Instead, opt for the lunch period, when the atmosphere remains relatively peaceful.  
Recommended pizza: Margherita  
Recommended beer: Hefeweizen accompanied by a few lemons.

This is the cheapest option if you are in Paris, which isn't saying much. We'll actually there's a place two doors down that had sandwiches in a display case but for an extra dollar or two we got a much more appetizing sandwich here. \n\nI definitely would not go out of your way for this place. However, if it is 2pm, you just got in from your flight and don't want another airport refrigerated sandwich, then just maybe this is the place for you too.

First and foremost, I am more than willing to expend financial resources on acquiring a high-quality cup of coffee, as I believe that the inherent value of such a beverage far surpasses any monetary consideration. However, I must admit that the ambient surroundings in which said coffee is consumed have undergone a marked transformation over the past six months, resulting in an atmosphere that is now vastly different from the one I had grown accustomed to. Specifically, the familiar faces of my preferred baristas are now conspicuously absent, leading me to speculate that their departure may be attributable to the recent relocation of the establishment. While I cannot assert with certainty the cause of this shift in personnel, I must confess that the coffee itself has become somewhat less satisfying to my palate, a development that fills me with a sense of melancholy, as it has necessitated a modification in my previously steadfast patronage of this establishment. In essence, the alteration in staff serves as a poignant reminder of the profound impact that individuals can have on the overall ambiance of a given setting.

This constitutes an assessment of Flavors, the sumptuous smorgasbord situated within the premises of Harrah's. Every time I venture out to Las Vegas, I make a concerted effort to partake in a culinary excursion to this establishment. While the prices may not be considered economical, the vast array of delectable options more than compensates for the additional expense. Patrons can indulge in a diverse selection of enticing cuisines, including Mexican, Italian, seafood, fresh fare, Chinese, and an assortment of mouthwatering desserts. Each visit has yielded a novel gastronomic experience, as the menu boasts an impressive array of innovative additions. The standard tariff for a single individual is approximately $20; however, participation in the timeshare program can result in a substantial discount, with the possibility of securing two admissions for the price of one. Unfortunately, my recent visit proved disappointing, as I discovered that access to the timeshare opportunity is restricted to individuals aged 28 and above. Although I am only 24, I successfully participated in the program during a previous visit a few months ago. It is worth noting that the timeshare promotion is conducted at the casino's entrance, and staff members are proactive in approaching potential participants, particularly couples or those who appear to be part of a pair.

Last week, my spouse and I opted to partake in a midday repast at a local eatery, whereupon we encountered a somewhat underwhelming culinary experience due to the mediocre quality of the fare and the sluggishness of the server. Despite these drawbacks, our meals did come accompanied by several complimentary items such as a bowl of broth, a crispy cylindrical pastry, and a trio of deep-fried dumplings. However, the soup did not conform to my expectations of a traditional Thai soup, the spring roll was excessively oily, and the wontons lacked discernible flavor. My partner chose the yellow curry, while I selected the Panang variant; furthermore, I requested that my dish be prepared at the Thai spicy level, yet it was merely moderately piquant. In light of this experience, we have decided to explore alternative Thai dining options in the future, specifically the Thai Cafe, which lies approximately a mile distant from our current location.

"The fruit and vegetables procured from this establishment may not consistently possess optimal quality, as I have previously purchased a bag of plums from this location at a discounted price, only to discover upon consumption that they had deteriorated in freshness. However, I was able to successfully slow cook them, resulting in an unexpectedly delectable culinary experience. It is essential to exercise caution when acquiring items at a significantly reduced cost or those that are out of season, as there exists a heightened risk of compromised quality. Nonetheless, it is crucial to emphasize that a plethora of satisfactory products can be found among the offerings, thereby rendering it judicious to maintain vigilance in the face of potential disappointment."

"Commencing with the culinary offerings, I must say that they were quite satisfactory. My spouse thoroughly enjoyed the juiciness of the steak, while I relished the flavorful halibut. The baked potato accompanying the dish was indeed exceptional, and the 'wine of the month' promotion, available for a mere $20 or complimentary with the hotel coupon book, was an added bonus. 

However, the quality of service left something to be desired. While the staff was attentive in certain aspects, such as promptly serving our beverages and wine, they were conspicuously absent in other regards. We were forced to request our entree after an extended wait time of approximately 75 minutes, and even then, it was served with haste, necessitating our swift departure to make our scheduled show. Moreover, the server displayed an unusual defensiveness and offered explanations, which we found perplexing, given that our query was delivered in a genial manner, devoid of any trace of annoyance. 

Despite these drawbacks, the eatery's ambiance exuded an air of elegance suitable for special occasions, particularly for guests lodging at the South Point hotel. While the prices may seem a tad high, the experience, on the whole, proved satisfying."

"It is patently evident that securing a reservation at this establishment during the festive Christmas season is an absolute imperative, particularly for parties comprising more than two individuals. The dearth of vacant tables during our visit underscored the pressing need for a prior appointment, as we were compelled to occupy seats at the bar owing to the absence of availability. The prices charged for the culinary offerings were considerable, with a modest soup costing a tenner and a special combination of soup and pasta setting patrons back by nineteen dollars. Notwithstanding the elevated tariffs, the gastronomic experience was merely passable, as one of my colleagues was obliged to return the special due to the uncooked state of the meat. However, the eatery's personnel demonstrated commendable alacrity in recognizing and addressing the issue, which merited a generous gratuity."

I thoroughly enjoy Lavo as a nightclub; however, I have yet to experience a meal here, so my assessment pertains solely to the club's ambiance and amenities. Although the space is somewhat diminutive, it does not feel oppressively congested, unlike Tao, which tends to be overwhelmingly packed. The dance floor, albeit modest in size, does not detract from the overall enjoyment of the establishment, particularly when the crowd has thinned out and patrons can appreciate the surroundings without feeling suffocated. The DJs play an eclectic mix of hip-hop and nostalgic tunes, eliciting a sense of familiarity and delight among the clientele. In my opinion, Lavo rates a solid 3.5 out of 5, with the primary factor being the generosity of our promoter, who provided open bar service and complimentary admission for the gentlemen in our party. The central bar area is well-appointed, but we opted to procure our beverages from the secondary bar, which, despite being crowded and understaffed, was manned by a charming and attentive bartender. In summary, everyone in our group had a pleasurable experience, and I would certainly consider returning, especially if we are lodging at the Venetian or Palazzo.

It's OK.

The good:
- Nice location (glad to have something at Town & Country)
- The parking was fine
- The service was great
- Prices are cheap
- Chocolate milkshake was really good

The bad:
- The Wreck
- Sandwiches had hardly any meat and hardly any toppings
- If you like a sandwich that is mostly bread then this is for you

On the cheap, I'd rather go to Subway.  Ho hum, at least at Subway I get my lettuce and tomatoes.

"I would assign a rating of 3.5 to this establishment, as my expectations for an exceptional culinary experience were not entirely fulfilled, despite the fact that it is a specialized pie restaurant. While the pizza was undoubtedly palatable, I have had the pleasure of indulging in superior specimens. However, the ambiance of this venue is quite captivating, with dim lighting, dark tables arranged in a manner that respects patrons' privacy, and an open-concept bar adjacent to a warm fire emanating from the oven. Additionally, their wine selection is quite impressive. We opted for the cheese board, which offered a satisfactory assortment of flavors. Both my companion and I chose to order pizza, yet it failed to surpass our expectations, although it was by no means subpar."

I do not go to Fresh and Easy very much.  The stores just aren't appealing to me except for a couple of items--generally snacks.  They have peanut butter filled salted pretzel nubs, some good salted kettle chips, and very decent trail mix for hiking.

That's about it for me.  I was going by here yesterday and thought it would be a quick and easy stop and it was.  Since I have no preconceived notion where things should be, I just walk around like a zombie with a purpose to find what I want.

Checkout was quick--I only had two items, and then I went across the street to Albertsons where I did a bit more serious shopping.

Really great salsa bar, tacos, quesadillas and burros.  This is 'authentic' mexican; not Macayos.  \nA few downsides though, it is really small & not really built for families or large groups; plus, I wouldn't park in the neighboring streets.  I got yelled at by one homeowner saying if they saw my vehicle again they're having it TOWED!.

The burgers are as good as one could hope for the price and the setting sure makes for good conversation. I like the fact that it's not a chain fast food place, but its missing some beer variety (i.e. other than Molson/Labbatt) and the fries could really be improved.

Food is great but service is terrible. This is one of my favorite restaurants, but this location doesn't make the grade. Waited 15 minutes in an empty restaurant at 1:30 for a bean burrito to go. Seriously...

"The pizza demonstrated an appreciable degree of culinary excellence, with a flavor profile that was decidedly pleasant and satisfying. However, the experience was somewhat marred by a prolonged waiting period, which, though inconvenient, was ultimately offset by the friendly and accommodating demeanor of the staff. Furthermore, it is worth noting that the pepperonis, while undoubtedly delicious, were regrettably undercooked, thereby necessitating a subsequent visit to Grimaldis in Brooklyn for the purpose of comparing and contrasting the two establishments' offerings. In conclusion, while nothing particularly remarkable or exceptional was encountered during this dining excursion, it is nevertheless evident that the restaurant possesses certain qualities that are worthy of commendation and appreciation."

"For those who relish the prospect of partaking in a Sunday night concert series, an event characterized by an amalgamation of familial units, canine companions, and an assortment of pedestrians meandering aimlessly throughout the vicinity of one's seating arrangement, accompanied by the cacophonous symphony generated by the confluence of blaring train horns and subpar audio equipment, and further exacerbated by the unenviable task of securing a parking space within close proximity to the venue, may find the aforementioned concert series to be an ideal addition to their schedules. My companion and I managed to secure a relatively advantageous position, removed from the central performance area yet still susceptible to the multitude of distractions mentioned previously, none of which proved particularly bothersome to our collective sensibilities. However, it is essential to note that attendance at this event may necessitate tolerance of the aforementioned factors, and potentially, the presence of numerous children and canines under the stewardship of a single individual. Furthermore, it is advisable to arrive prematurely to ensure procurement of a desirable vantage point, ideally situated across the street from the performance arena. It is plausible that the throng in attendance may have been augmented due to the coincidence of a holiday weekend, although such speculation remains uncertain in the absence of subsequent visits to the event."
Went on a night that they had a live band on the patio.....was a nice atmosphere. Drinks were good but food was just okay. May go back if other places are too busy.

Nice room.
Stayed here for 3 nights.

Early checking cost $50 extra. Better than napping in the parking lot with wife, baby and mo in law in our tiny Honda insight.

Not many places to plug in all of our chargers for cell phones so we took turns and used the restroom plugs.

Check in line was always long, with not enough staff to handle it...

Check out was a mad rush too. Vegas wasn't very busy this time of year. End of march.

Parking was free. 

The iPod dock didn't charge the iPod and it had the wrong time.

They had a fridge and safe in the room.

No coffee pot in the room.

The checkout was kind of weird.  I suggest an easy checkout.  Get the folio under your door and just walk out if there aren't any problems with the bill.  We ended up standing in a 30 minute line just to check out.

Good Job TI, but I think for the price, I might stay somewhere else.

Last evening, we opted to partake of a culinary excursion to the esteemed eatery known as Mert's, whereupon we indulged in their delectable Fried Catfish and Beef Rib Combo. Alas, our gastronomical experience was not without its drawbacks, as the whole fried catfish presented some difficulties in navigating the bony terrain, ultimately yielding a meager amount of succulent fish. Furthermore, "The Beef Rib" dish was found to be somewhat lacking in quantity, with the meat being chopped into small pieces and intermingled with an abundance of bones. However, we must commend the kitchen staff for their proficiency in preparing the sides, particularly the Mac and Cheese, which boasted a satisfying crust on its surface, and the Corn Bread, whose texture and flavor were both pleasing, although a minor quibble could be raised regarding the slightly overcooked nature of the piece my spouse received, resulting in a somewhat dry and unfortunate conclusion to an otherwise enjoyable repast. In summary, while not without its flaws, our visit to Mert's proved to be a generally satisfactory dining experience.

I love John Hughes movies, but this Breakfast Club did not live up to its namesake. The eggs were serviceable, but the potatoes O'Brian (I learned a new thing here!) were nothing special--kind of soft and oily, with large chunks of pepper. The jalepeno biscuits, which sounded conceptually grand, were not quite what I'd call a biscuit. They were tough, unflavorful little disks with jalepenos baked in. The heuvos rancheros looked like something my cat barfed up, however, they tasted fine, according to my breakfastmate. \n\nOverall, I think this was a shade greasier than we were expecting. And outdoor seating is nice, but a mixed bag when abutting a busy road. The service was good, but something about the waitresses reminded me of the Stepford Wives.

"In conclusion, it can be inferred that the venue possesses certain attributes that render it an enjoyable destination, however, various factors, such as the charges associated with parking, entry, and storage, in addition to the limited number of functional water slides, may potentially hinder its appeal, ultimately leaving the decision to visit up to individual preferences."

Fairly typical Chinese food with a Sushi menu and nice restaurant seating area.  I wasn't as wow'd as I was hoping after reading all the rave reviews here on Yelp, but it is a pretty decent offering.

I tried the egg drop soup, which was a good value, the pork dumplings, which were meh - I think the sauce was overly sweet, the kung pao chicken, which was pretty good, and the chicken lo mein noodles, which were meh (but aren't all lo mein noodles pretty meh?).

Overall I would come back and get some take out because it does lie somewhere in between your PFChangs and your strip mall cheap Chinese take out place.  However, I don't believe it's that great of a value offering.  The prices are a bit high for cheap Chinese, and the quality is only just a bit higher.  Doesn't feel like you're getting a great deal.

The decor here is adorable. It made me want to sit and stay a while. I had my first macaroon, well two, mixed berry and raspberry. People always rave about them (not necessarily from here, but in general) so I decided to indulge. I didn't love or hate them. I'll definitely be back to try other options.

Footlocker isn't that exciting, it stocks all the shoe brands you would expect to find in a trainer shop such as; Reebok, Nike, Adidas and a seemingly unnecessary amount of basketball sneakers. The prices are medium to expensive but they often have sales on where you can bag yourself a bargain but the sales usually only offer terrible looking shoes that nobody else wants.\n\nI guess Footlocker is more of a guys shop because whenever I've popped in they've had hundreds of guys shoes but a rather a measly amount of ladies ones so it's not somewhere I pop in that often. If I am looking for a new pair of trainers I will pop in to see what's on offer but more often than not I find myself going elsewhere.

My fiancÃ© recommended that I compose a review, and I responded by expressing my ambivalence towards the eatery, describing it as unremarkable and lacking any distinctive qualities that would warrant a positive or negative appraisal. I assigned a rating of 2.5 stars, which I deemed appropriate given the establishment's unexceptional offerings. The service was adequate, eliciting neither praise nor criticism from me. The culinary selections available during the happy hour period featured two tacos for $3, with the chef selecting the varieties. I thoroughly enjoyed consuming the salmon taco, finding its flavors to be quite satisfying. However, my expectations for the guacamole were not met, as I had hoped for a more impressive experience. While the inclusion of dried cranberries added an intriguing element, my preference remains with the superior quality of Trader Joe's guacamole. The food at this establishment could be described as "rico," a term denoting richness or abundance in Spanish, often used as a compliment. However, in this case, the term "rico" applied more to the caloric content rather than the culinary excellence. Although I wouldn't object to returning, my desire to do so isn't particularly strong either.

"It is not a cinematic establishment that I routinely visit, given my residence in NLV, but the alterations implemented since Rave acquired ownership of the venue appear to be advantageous. They have incorporated supplementary armrests between each seat, featuring sturdier cup holders than customary, presenting both benefits and drawbacks; although facilitating the sharing of beverages and snacks, the immobility of the armrests constitutes a hindrance. 

Advantages:
Enlarged armrests
Expanded snack bar relative to others

Disadvantages:
Delayed commencement of the film (White House Down) by approximately twenty minutes, ostensibly due to the absence of an individual in the operational chamber
Insufficient quantity of M&M's within the package procured at the snack bar."

"Indubitably, 'Ja... perfectly fine.' However, there seems to be a certain je ne sais quoi missing from 'Jawohl. I rather enjoy that.' Perhaps it's the lack of a tangible element, such as a location with a similar ambiance to a fast-food chain, but with a more refined and sophisticated atmosphere, akin to a restaurant rather than a bar. Perchance, the concept of offering a build-your-own menu, where customers can curate their own dishes from a selection of premium ingredients, might help to establish a more coherent and well-rounded culinary experience. It's worth mentioning that the service has been consistently friendly and attentive, without being overbearing or intrusive. While the location itself is not necessarily problematic, the overall concept and pricing strategy may benefit from further refinement to fully realize its potential. At present, it appears to be a fusion of a trendy Berlin-Mitte scene restaurant and the currently popular Munich 'Currywurst bars,' resulting in a unique yet somewhat disjointed dining experience. Notwithstanding, the establishment boasts a commendable gender diversity among its staff."

A group of us went here to eat some burgers since we heard they had good burgers. The food was good but somewhat oily and dry. I woul of given the restaurant 4 stars if it wasn't for the horrible service provided by Olivia. She had a bad attitude throughout the whole time we were there for no reason at all. We asked for a To Go box and she just threw it on the table, which we thought was so rude. We asked our waters to be filled 3 times before she actually got around to it. The restaurant is expensive, so I expected better service. Overall, it's worth going if you enjoy a good burger. Hopefully, you get a better waitress/waiter.

"I decided to indulge in an afternoon delight, opting for a frozen yogurt treat from Golden Spoon. With an array of delectable flavors to choose from, I settled on Irish creme, adorned with almond roca topping. Initially, I relished every bite, savoring the richness of the frozen confection. However, as I progressed through my treat, my thoughts became increasingly preoccupied with the unmistakable zest of Twangy Tart. The tangy, fruity essence of this flavor captivated my taste buds, leaving me in a state of utter fascination. It was as if the Ice Tango had performed a tantalizing dance on my tongue, leaving an indelible impression. From that moment forward, I found myself irreversibly enamored with the Twang, and no other frozen yogurt establishment could compare. Golden Spoon, once my go-to destination for frozen delights, had suddenly become secondary. My taste buds had been forever transformed by the magical touch of Ice Tango, and nothing would ever be the same again."

Its good food.  Its just not the greatest food for the price you pay.  I had a spicy chicken of some sort, and they dont mess around when it comes to the spicy stuff.  This stuff was HOT.  I enjoyed it quite a bit, but I just didnt feel like the food justified the price.  $11 for a lunch special?  No thanks.  I would give the food 4 out of 5 stars though.

"Although my culinary expectations were not entirely fulfilled by the pho I had ordered at this establishment, I did observe that certain menu items consumed by fellow patrons appeared to possess a level of gastronomical quality that was ostensibly superior. This observation instilled within me a sense of curiosity regarding the potential merits of the restaurant's offerings, leading me to consider the possibility of future visits during which I might sample a broader array of dishes. It is worth noting, however, that my initial impression of the venue was that it seemed to be more heavily influenced by American culinary traditions than its counterparts in the Spring Mountain area, which may have contributed to my relative disappointment with the pho."

This used to be the best mall in the area.  Then along came Arizona Mills, Chandler Fashion Center, and Tempe Marketplace.  Those three places, in my opinion, seems to have taken at least those patrons who live in Chandler, Tempe and Gilbert.

There are still good stores here, including many of the same stores you will find at the other malls.  We have found that Fiesta is now much less busy and crowded than it used to be.  This is particularly nice during Christmas season/sales.

And they have an area of covered parking which the other malls don't.  Very nice in summer.

I know I said that they were professional and all, but the other day we received a bill for what the insurance wouldn't pay.  It came in a decent envelope, but then we opened it.

Plain sheet of paper with printing.  No tear-off portion, no return envelope (not to mention return postage - I wouldn't expect that from anyone).  Just a sheet, badly folded, printed out on a cheap printer.

So much for professional.  I guess that only extends to examinations - and presumably procedures.  Definitely not to the billing department.  We get a lot of medical bills since we started buying our own insurance, and this is definitely the cheapest of the bunch.

I get that it's only a few cents for an envelope and all - but it can't cost them much more to have some reasonably pre-printed invoices with tear-off return portions, much less a return envelope.  It would just make for a nicer experience, you know?

Awesome location, cool place....the Chopped Salad is by far the most amazing salad I have ever had in my life (but way...and I mean way to small)...If it were double the portion for the price I would probably visit more. I had a flight when I was there...it took forever (as I know flights are supposed to)...but this was ridiculous...the buffalo meat is so gross...it reminds me of when a stray dog visits my lawn...

The BBQ sauce is good....the staff is just OK. Nothing mind blowing. I think staff in a place with a pricey menu should spoil the guests a bit...Give away a free desert when you know the service and meal is just OK...this may bring your customer base back to visit just because you redeemed yourself at the end.

Overall its a cool place. It fits with the downtown Scottsdale lifestyle. But stay away from the buffalo, because it will give doggy bag a whole new meaning....

The food here was really good. It was filling and tasty. However, when compared to other taco joints or mexican food, it is just very average. I love mexican food and the food here lacks the authenticity of other places... But this should be obvious since its in a casino. \nMy problem is that they are very very pricey. For two people, it was $54. The food was good and it was discounted for gamblers, but if I had to pay over $50 for the quality I would be upset.\nDefinetly people should come here and try it out, just know the quality isn't worth the price.

Decent food for the price however I've been to better sushi places for the similar price(and sometimes its worth pay extra for better food). Their makis are often sloppy and unfinished looking and certain fish(fresh tuna or yellow tail for example) are not the freshest. I guess it's good for quick lunch once in a while but not for a fancy dinner.

Met someone here to play on the tennis courts.  Surprisingly the courts were in good shape, the nets were missing the straps, but we played through it.  Overall it's a nice complex.... my one complaint would be that the parking lot is a bit of a maze to get out with a lot of curves (which means a lot of blind spots if you are backing out).  Yes, it keeps the place looking interesting, but I would hate to be a grounds keeper here since there are no straight lines in sight.\n\nThe apartments look pretty solid, all-brink.... there is a lot of highway noise coming from 485 though.... I didn't go inside one unit, but it was fairly loud from the tennis court.

Applebee's is just one of those boring chain restaurants.  I do really love some chains, but alas, Applebee's is not one of them.   Everything is just ok.  Nothing ever blows my socks off or makes me crave to come here, but it isn't bad either, just blah.

I found myself here yesterday because I was outvoted by the group I was with.  Oh well, it happens.  We went for lunch and it was an ok experience.  I had the Bourbon Black and Bleu Burger.  It was surprising yummy.  It had a lot of kick and I had a small party in my mouth.  It was better than I was expected, which was a nice surprise.  The other people in the party both got the 3 cheese penne and chicken dish.  I didn't sample it, but they both enjoyed it.  My picky eater, my 18 month old did surprise me by eating half of her grilled cheese.  She never eats anything, so that made me happy.  I tried a bite and it was quite good with the bread being a sweet, eggy bread, like brioche.  

The service was really good and we always had what we wanted without having to ask for it, which made for a pleasant meal.

So over all, the food was good, the service was great, but I am still bored with the overall place.  Give me Chili's anyday, but this Applebee's did a good job today.  Way to go Applebee's for slowing changing my opinion about you.

This was my second trip to this location and I noticed their salad bar had fewer items from before.  It was still very good but am disappointed that they seemed to have eliminated some items. I am not a big meat eater and came for the salad bar so I noticed these things. It was still really really good however.

I enjoyed my meal at Spago, but wasn't as impressed as my companions. The wedge salad is good but not notable, however the heirloom tomato and burrata salad special was outstanding - the best overall dish of the night.  

We ended up splitting 3 pizzas - I have to say, I found the crust to be disappointing on all of them. Not much flavor at all - more of just a vehicle for the toppings.  As for the specific pies:
-Margherita - crust was a bit undercooked, and overall I would call this a pretty average Margherita pizza
-Proscuitto - this was the best of the 3 - the Proscuitto and Fromage blanc worked perfectly together.  With a great crust this pizza would have mind blowing potential.
-Lamb Chorizo - a very nice pie overall - enjoyed the chorizo, and the toppings all worked well together. 

Service was excellent.

Great place for the price. Not the most luxurious place on the strip but the amenities are decent, the service is good, and the location is fantastic. Very good value overall.

This is the 4th or 5th time we've stayed here. The rooms are clean and comfortable, and there is a decent selection of food downstairs ranging from McDonald's to 5 star French, and everything in between. The casino floor is a bit small and smoky, but perfect for when you're not in the mood to get dressed up and go out. The spa is small and reasonably priced. And it's only a few minutes' walk to other casinos, restaurants, and shopping at the many malls nearby.

The only things we didn't care much for were the showers (high pressure mist that's definitely not my idea of pleasant) and on our most recent trip the TV didn't work properly (but we didn't call to have it fixed because it just wasn't that important to us).

Yes, you can stay at a nicer, trendier, and/or more luxurious place on the strip but you'll pay about twice as much. We prefer to stay here, where we're always satisfied, and use the cash we saved to eat, play, and party while we're in town.

Kind of tucked away and hard to notice, especially being next to the really glammed out Ella's Deli. But worth a visit if you're looking for a good gyro or kebab. :]

The donuts are alright too. They have a wide variety! Myself, I really rather like their cookies. They also offer homemade baklava.

Really though I can reccomend their sandwiches with a side of the seasoned fries. Quite yummy! Vegetarian options also available such as potato kahbi or falafel sandwiches. And they had a lot of beverages to choose from too.

Although the location is not ideal, it's worth a stop if you're in that part of town. :]

When this establishment first inaugurated its operations, it boasted an exceptional quality, thereby warranting a perfect five-star rating. However, over time, its standards have subsided, rendering it merely satisfactory. Despite this decline, my father continues to patronize this venue, and thus, we visited it together. Our meal commenced with the grilled artichoke, customarily a delectable option. Unfortunately, this particular instance proved disappointing, as the artichoke exhibited a pronounced rigidity and lacked discernible flavor, perhaps due to the off-season availability of this ingredient. Nonetheless, the accompanying aioli sauce compensated for the artichoke's deficiencies, offering a savory delight. The prime rib, though tender and possessing a satisfactory flavor profile, failed to impress, as its portion size has diminished progressively during my visits. This consistent reduction in magnitude was coupled with a uniform selection of sides, specifically a baked potato. Ultimately, our dining experience concluded without the customary sweet treat. Despite these shortcomings, the prospect of future visits remains viable, primarily owing to my father's persistent fondness for this eatery.

Barneys is a multifaceted drinking establishment that offers a unique experience for patrons seeking a more relaxed atmosphere than the typical bars in the vicinity. For individuals desiring an unpretentious environment where they can enjoy themselves without the necessity of dressing up or paying covers, Barneys may be the ideal destination.

The second floor of the bar particularly stood out to me as a preferred spot, owing to the hospitable demeanor of the bartender and their promptness in refilling drinks. Although the rooftop area has the potential to be an attractive spot during warmer weather, the presence of smoking therein serves as a deterrent for some.

One notable aspect of Barneys is its innovative method of pouring beer from the bottom up, creating a distinctive and entertaining experience for customers. Moreover, for those who have had a few too many drinks, the bar features an amusing arcade game involving a lobster claw, reminiscent of the classic claw machine found at carnivals and arcades.

Overall, Barneys earns a rating of 3.5 stars for its distinctive ambiance and diverse offerings that cater to various preferences.

My better half indulged in a personal visit to the destination in question, opting to partake in an excursion alongside several acquaintances during a recent weekday afternoon, specifically on a Monday. Her account of the adventure conveyed a sense of underwhelming, as the actuality of the experience did not align with her preconceived notions, boasting fewer fauna than anticipated. Furthermore, the entrance fee of ten dollars for local patrons appeared somewhat exorbitant upon reflection, given the limited scope of the park's attractions. Additionally, the sweltering heat, surpassing one hundred degrees Fahrenheit, coupled with the absence of potable water, raised concerns regarding the well-being of visitors, as every water fountain my spouse encountered displayed signs indicating they were out of commission. Such circumstances pose a significant threat to tourists, emphasizing the necessity for uninterrupted access to hydration.

"As an individual enrolled at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, this eatery presents an extraordinary value, offering five tacos, two sides, and a beverage for a mere $5; the tacos, though diminutive in stature, are abundant in terms of protein, thereby obviating any concern of being shortchanged; it is an ideal venue for socializing with companions, indulging in a pail of fermented beverages, and engaging in lively conversation; the protocol involves ordering at the counter, with the staff summoning one's attention via a vocal announcement when the culinary items are prepared; reportedly, the establishment occasionally features live musical performances or a disc jockey, typically showcasing a Latin-inspired theme, which, while unsurprising given the restaurant's heritage, may strike some patrons as unexpected."

I am very torn about First Friday. I absolutely love community events. Especially art walks, and more creative culture, but this is very lacking. I want to love it because it's in my back yard, too! 

However, First Friday leaves me with a sense of empty feeling. Located in the arts district downtown should be plenty of reason why this event should boast art, but it doesn't. 

The art galleries are lacking, and the street vendors that sell art are more there to just get a buck than they are about art. 

Then there's the riff raff of downtown trying to join in, and so many kids everywhere! I guess police try to crack down on curfew, but there's always so many grungy kids that are up to no good running around. 

The food stalls are nice during summer hours, winter many vendors decide to stay home. 

I'll probably end up going back in the summer, but I'll go early before it gets dark, and the crazy kids (literally kids) come out at night.

I had a profound affection for the ambiance and the personnel who were responsible for creating it, as they exhibited an exceptional level of competence in their respective roles. However, the culinary offerings did not quite live up to my expectations, despite being satisfactory in terms of taste and presentation. Furthermore, the tariff charged for the meal did not seem to align with the value proposition offered by the restaurant, leading me to question the overall value for money.

Came to TMI for dinner the other night.  It was good, but nothing that special.  We started with the TMI toast which was probably my favorite part of the meal.  Yes, the bread was a bit hard, but still delicious.  I had the Mac & Cheese and was less than impressed.  It was very oily and lacked flavor.  I've never really met a Mac & Cheese that I didn't get along with...until TMI.  The other people in my party had sandwiches and salads and they seemed to like their dishes.  \n\nOverall, nice atmosphere but REALLY hot inside, a little too loud to have a decent conversation and the food was just okay.  Probably won't be back here in the near future.

I was surprised to find that had a TON of brand new irrigation supplies. As a gardener, I am always fiddling with the irrigation, and am in constant need of emitters, hose, and connectors to support my filthy habit. They have it all (at least when I went), and at a fraction of what the hardware store charges.

"It serves as an enjoyable venue for social gatherings, facilitating the relational dynamics of communal dining. My culinary inclinations lean towards familial-style sharing, which this establishment accommodates seamlessly. However, our ordered dishes displayed inconsistent quality, with a notable eggplant and goat cheese entrÃ©e featuring an excessive proportion of cheese that overpowered the subtle flavor of the eggplant. In contrast, a dish comprising eggs, potatoes, and another component (the specificity of which escapes my memory) presented an unbalanced ratio of potato to other ingredients, prompting a sense of disappointment. Nonetheless, both the filet mignon and Thai beef salad showcased remarkable taste, rendering my overall experience gratifying. Despite some reservations, I am content with having visited this restaurant, yet I harbor doubts about returning in the future."

We had not visited this establishment since its previous incarnation as Cafe Del Sol, and our recent visit was facilitated by a Groupon we had procured approximately one month prior. Upon arriving at the venue, we were struck by the somewhat unconventional layout, which featured a primary dining area and a smaller, segregated section designated for'red-headed step children' and located around the corner from the main area. This configuration seemed to create an atmosphere that was somewhat lacking in vitality. Arriving during the latter portion of happy hour, my spouse opted for a glass of Sangria, while I selected a glass of Tempranillo, which unfortunately did not meet my expectations. Subsequently, I ordered an additional glass of wine, the name of which escapes me, and found it to be relatively satisfying. My culinary selections included the cola and pineapple braised short ribs, jalapeno cream corn, and a chile corn casserole. While the sides were generally well-prepared, the corn casserole was slightly overcooked. The short ribs, on the other hand, were quite flavorful and did not possess the dubious taste often associated with lesser quality braised short ribs. Although the sauce accompanying the ribs was slightly too viscous for my liking, it did not detract substantially from the overall enjoyment of the dish. My spouse's grilled shrimp appetizer, served with avocado and mango sauce, was greatly enjoyed, as were the empanadas. However, my personal preference did not extend to the empanadas. Nonetheless, the shrimp dish was fairly impressive. Considering the totality of our experience, we would classify this eatery as a respectable local option, and while we might not elect to return, we recognize that our spouse may potentially persuade us to do so at some future date.

"A refreshing submergence into an atmospheric drinking establishment, offering a brief respite from the conventional Las Vegas landscape. We entered the premises on a Friday evening, subsequent to receiving complimentary beverage vouchers on Fremont Street. The ambiance was relatively desolate for a weekend night, which rendered the decibel levels of the bartenders' megaphones marginally excessive and potentially annoying. Nonetheless, the experience was enjoyable, albeit tainted by the realization that the bartenders employed a subtle ploy to coerce patrons into purchasing potations for both themselves and the staff, resulting in an unexpected escalation of our tab."

"I have had the pleasure of experiencing the accommodations offered by the Hotel Monte Carlo Las Vegas on multiple occasions, and I must say that while the establishment has served me well in the past, I am now eager to explore alternative options.  The hotel's decor and amenities, while once considered stylish and cutting-edge, have become somewhat outdated and no longer meet my expectations.  Furthermore, the culinary offerings at the hotel's primary dining venues, specifically the main cafe and buffet, leave much to be desired in terms of quality and variety.  However, I must admit that the rates offered by the hotel were quite reasonable and competitive compared to those of other luxury hotels in the area, particularly the newer establishments that have recently entered the market.  One aspect of the hotel's service that I did find particularly appealing was the concierge's willingness to place hotel guests on the VIP list for entry into Haze and other nearby nightclubs, which provided us with an added layer of convenience and access to exclusive entertainment options at no additional cost to the concierge.  If you are seeking a hotel that offers a balance of affordability, decent accommodations, and convenient location, then the Hotel Monte Carlo Las Vegas may be worth considering."

"I have had the pleasure of patronizing the establishment located in Henderson on Sunset and the one situated on South Rainbow on multiple occasions, and I must say that my experiences have been thoroughly enjoyable, particularly when it comes to their breakfast offerings, specifically the steak and eggs, which have been cooked to perfection and served with a smile by the friendly staff. Additionally, I have taken advantage of their happy hour promotion at the South Rainbow location, which boasts an impressive selection of $2 draft beers and 1/2 price appetizers, making for a truly exceptional value. However, I must express my disappointment regarding their recently revamped reward card program, which has undergone significant changes to the earning levels, effectively rendering it nearly impossible for me to accrue sufficient credits to redeem a $10 credit within a reasonable time frame, thereby warranting a subpar grade. Consequently, taking into account the substantial disparity between my previous experiences and my current dissatisfaction with their loyalty program, I would assign an overall rating of three stars, which falls midway between an 'A' and an 'F', respectively."

It was ok.... the ordering system was a little confusing, but I am a smart girl and I figured it out. I was looking for a good burger and I found one just the way I wanted it, and the onion rings were good. Its just missing a little personality....?

This was a customary resort eatery where the culinary offerings were moderately aspirational, and the prices were correspondingly elevated. I opted for the poultry dish, as the vast majority of the other entrees were excessively steep, with an unwavering emphasis on high-quality beef. Notwithstanding, the fare was relatively palatable, and the hospitality was of a superior quality. Regrettably, the adjacent table ignited their cigarettes, resulting in a pervasive haze, but we had already concluded our meal and elected to sit alfresco, thus I cannot hold it against them. Ultimately, the cost was slightly exorbitant for the quality of the cuisine, although it was a luxury resort, and I would not anticipate anything else. I probably will not return, but our server was quite pleasant, which is the sole reason I feel a twinge of guilt about awarding this establishment three stars. Apart from that, it was a generally satisfactory experience.

It's amazing what a few blocks can do, in this case... not much if you're heading further East. I love me some Lao Laan... never really had Lao prior to moving to Madison. But I just don't get the same attentive service, sweet menu recommendations and authentic experience I so often found on Willy. What gives? The menu is more compact but the dining room is bigger, so it's perfect if you need room to groove, but other than the size, I think Willy is probably you're best bet if you're looking for curry east of the capitol.
Good Burger but on the pricy side for what you get. I work nearby and was hoping for a lunch deal but they aren't open for lunch. Pleasant staff and service was good but no lunch no return trips.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition in the menu offerings over an extended period of time, specifically six years, in a cosmopolitan city such as Montreal, Canada, where culinary diversity and innovation are expected; however, the radish oyster dish stands out as an exceptional delicacy, worth every penny of the twelve Canadian dollars charged for four pieces, while the remaining dishes fail to impress or provide sufficient value for the price."

I entered the establishment with the intention of acquiring a novel laptop charger and upgrading my operating system to Lion OSX, yet my experience was tainted by an array of inconveniences and illogicalities. Firstly, although obtaining the charger was a straightforward process, I was confronted with the revelation that, due to my current operating system being Leopard rather than Snow Leopard, I would need to purchase two upgrades to attain Lion. This was not only unexpected but also perplexing, as one would assume that a linear progression within the realm of operating systems would be readily available. However, much to my dismay, the retailer did not possess the Leopard to Snow Leopard upgrade disc in stock, leaving me with limited and impractical options. I could either embark on a quest to locate a Best Buy that might potentially possess the coveted upgrade disc in their inventory, or opt to procure it through online means, thereby subjecting myself to an excruciating waiting period. It is utterly confounding that the Apple store, a purveyor of cutting-edge technology, would fail to maintain a supply of such an essential component. Notwithstanding this absurdity, the physical location of the store was acceptable, the atmosphere was clean and well-maintained, and the employee who facilitated my transaction was adequately courteous.

"Culinary experiences that are reasonably priced and of sufficient quality. Enter with the expectation of a restaurant providing typical diner fare and you shall be gratified. The hospitality is adequate, the cuisine is passable, and the cost (particularly considering its proximity to the Las Vegas Strip) is quite favorable."

decent... i had the \"sin city\" burger. i liked it very much. my wife had a classic which i didnt like but i'm not sure what she had on it. she liked it so i guess thats what counts. the sweet potato fries werent that great. i didnt like the way they were seasoned. the regular fries were ok. all in all it was pretty good. its better than most fast food burgers....
Pretty good for kids, average to below average for adults.  Friendly staff, good price.  Not the best tasting, but you can tolerate a slice or 2.  Limited dessert and salad options.

If you're looking for a sweet, maybe one with some chocolate or even a big sundae - this is your place. Nice old-fashioned ice cream shop located in old town. This place still has the retro pink vibe and decoration going on inside. \n\nMy friend and I came here when we were looking to splurge with the buster brownie sundae. BOY is It sweet but worth it! Sugar Bowl also serves food, which I was unaware of but probably wouldn't order. Service is friendly.

I've had dinner here a few times including delivery, and the hype really died down.  There are so many 5 star reviews that yelpers may start thinking it's flawless, when really it's just a fresh wing with awesome sauce (lol, awesome sauce). I really enjoy the Golden BBQ & order that each time. We've also had the Citrus Chipotle, Jamaican Jerk & Sweet Chili. All had their own unique flavors.

The boneless wings still are delish & large (chicken tender size). The delivery is fast and efficient.
