Service is deff hit or miss. I've had really great service somethings, but not-so-good counter service a number of times (i eat here reallllly often, so not sure of the ratio lol) 

My waffle fries that I upgraded to were completely well done. Not a taste of potato.. more like potato chips. I love waffle fries too :/

So again, great wings & and great mix of sauces, but don't let all of these fabb reviews fool you.

So, I have this weird affliction that makes me feel really uncomfortable when someone puts a HUGE plate of food in front of me. I wanted the chile rellenos, but not the supersized plate! Alas, such is the state of dining in most restaurants these days, but seriously, if I would have known the portions were this big I would have shared my dinner with my friend.\n\nStill, for Vegas we got a table on a Friday night with no wait and no reservation, the service was very attentive, and the bill was reasonable. My mojito was quite tasty also. So go, share, and enjoy!

A Charlotte staple in need of a makeover. Generally solid food but sometimes inconsistent - biggest challenge is the atmosphere which is stale and hasn't kept up with the rest of the Charlotte restaurant scene. You can't go wrong by a visit to PC - especially if the weather is nice and you get to sit on the excellent patio. Salads are great here.

"Halted by this establishment to acquire a potable beverage prior to partaking in an evening meal elsewhere. The atmosphere within was boisterous, verging on cacophonous, owing to the vociferous patrons gathered around the numerous screens displaying some form of athletic competition involving gentlemen gliding across ice surfaces; raucous birthday celebrations manifesting themselves in various areas throughout the premises; and an audio system emitting sonorous melodies at an intensity that bordered on the excessive. Despite its primary focus on gin, the venue's beverage list proved unremarkable in terms of its beer offerings, yet the selection of gin-based concoctions piqued my interest. Following the recommendation of our hospitable server, we opted to sample a particular mixture featuring Ungava gin from Quebec and maple syrup, which, despite my limited affinity for gin, proved quite palatable (it is worth mentioning that any beverage fortified with maple syrup is likely to elicit my approval). A cursory examination of the menu revealed prices that could be described as moderately elevated, with a single beer and cocktail combination costing $20, exclusive of taxes and gratuities, which, I must confess, struck me as somewhat steep. Notwithstanding this, the quality of the service we received was commendable, as our server, despite being occupied with attendance to the multiple large gatherings scattered throughout the establishment, managed to tend to our needs in a timely and attentive manner. All things considered, I am pleased that we decided to visit this locale, as it has been on our list of potential destinations ever since our relocation to this vicinity."

This is easy to confuse with Central Library, but this is hwere they keep the special books - all the special books.  Central Library is just a normal library.

To come read these books you will have to apply at the registration desk for a pass (with ID) that will last for either a few days or about 3 months.

If there is a secific old book here you want to see then you should definitely come here to see it, but if not then this is a lot of fuss over reading a book and you'll be better going elsewhere.

"A satisfactory sports bar and restaurant, provided that such an establishment aligns with your preferences. 

I had the pleasure of visiting this venue in the company of my father, who recommended it as a contemporary and enjoyable dining experience. 

The stuffed portabella mushroom appetizer we ordered was undoubtedly delectable, although its indulgent nature was almost excessive. The carnitas libre pizza was also quite tasty, yet similarly richâthe flavors were pronounced to the point where one could almost palpably sense the arterial congestion it might induce. 

Regrettably, the pollotate pizza we sampled was somewhat lackluster, with the potatoes on top detracting from the overall culinary experience. However, we did notice that the omission of onions, while unintentional, may have actually improved the flavor profile. 

Despite this minor setback, the staff demonstrated commendable attentiveness and courtesy, and they even offered a partial complimentary discount on our bill. Considering their relatively brief tenure (a mere two months), such minor mistakes are forgivable. 

This establishment boasts an impressive array of televisions and an extensive bar offering a wide selection of draft beers. Therefore, if you are an enthusiast of sports bars and restaurants, this particular venue might rank among the superior options available. Personally, I find that such establishments must offer truly exceptional cuisine to justify the considerable caloric intake involved, and unfortunately, this restaurant did not quite meet that standard."

Popped in for lunch after a little AM yoga sesh today.  Had been by after my initial trip to Union on opening day - they weren't open when I was there then.  Weirdly, at 11:45 today half the stores in Union were open, half weren't.  Anyway, TDP is super cute.  Love the tables, love the outdoor seating and the small bar.  The staff was super friendly and helpful with our orders.  I could really taste the olive oil on my sandwich and the bread was nice. 

Overall, the food was good, but not great and definitely overpriced. $9 for a Caprese sandwich is ridiculous - and the tomato on this one wasn't ripe.    The meatball sandwich needed more sauce.  The chicken salad sandwich looked great, but again, for such small sandwiches I would expect fruit or salad or something.

I think next time I'll just enjoy the free smells, and buy a bottle of delicious olive oil from their store across the way.

"Although my dining experience at Jersey Mike's did not induce feelings of debilitating infatuation, the restaurant's ambiance was undoubtedly tidy, streamlined, and hospitable. The menu's layout presented a minor challenge for a novice such as myself, prompting a sense of hastened urgency upon ordering; however, the bustling atmosphere during peak lunch hours underscored the establishment's popularity. The diminutive sub sandwich, dubbed'mini,' could easily suffice as a standard portion size, while the larger option proved sufficient for a trio of patrons. The abundance of meat in the club sandwich catered to my carnivorous inclinations, while the subtle distinction between the white and wheat sub rolls remained somewhat enigmatic. Nonetheless, the quality of the bread did not detract from the overall enjoyment of the meal. Of greater curiosity was the assortment of beverage cups, each emblazoned with narratives pertaining to diverse Jersey Mike's locations that have engaged in philanthropic endeavors for worthy causes. While the veracity of these claims warrants further investigation, the notion of supporting an altruistic enterprise undoubtedly resonates with consumers. Though mere branding may be at play, I am intrigued by the possibility of genuine charitable involvement. Sufficiently satisfied with my initial visit, I anticipate returning to sample a spicier variety of sandwich in the future."

Los 7 Compadres boasts an array of twenty diverse combination platters, available for a mere seven dollars apiece. My spouse and I opted to share one platter between us, selecting seven individual items to combine in various ways. This resulted in an astonishing number of potential combinations per bite, factoring in the rice, beans, sour cream, and guacamole accompaniments. For instance, a single bite of chicken enchilada could be savored on its own or paired with rice, beans, guacamole, sour cream, or any combination thereof. The possibilities were truly staggering.

Extending this concept to other menu items, such as burritos, cheese enchiladas, tamales, beef enchiladas, bean enchiladas, and so forth, afforded us an extensive palette of flavors and textures to explore. While all dishes were palatable, the tamales proved to be the least impressive, possessing a slightly arid quality and a predominantly spicy jalapeno flavor profile. Notwithstanding this minor shortcoming, the overall culinary experience at Los 7 Compadres warranted a solid three-and-a-half-star rating, rendering it worthy of a future visit. It is worth mentioning that even the mild dishes possessed a tangible kick, emphasizing the authenticity of the cuisine.

Well, this place is puzzling and I'm not going to save the bad news for last.  They seem to pride themselves on allowing and maybe even promoting smoking.  It's puzzling because the beer selection is extensive.  The menu is above average, as is the food.  Lots of pizzas, sandwiches, appetizers.\n   BUT, who wants to go home smelling like a filthy ashtray?  It would be great if they joined the rest us in the twenty-first century.

Well...I'm super excited that there is finally, finally some V-food in downtown Phoenix.  The more ethnic cuisine around the better.  It is in a convenient location on 1st and Adams.  The kitchen area is open to the public (a first I think I've ever seen).  I ordered take out and everything I needed was in there.  The plus, fast service.  The minus, I felt like things were not quite as tasty as some of my other standbyes.  The prices also reflect the snazzy downtown locale, a dinner for two came out to be closer to 30 bucks (which is still a bargain) but I'm used to about 15-20 at the divier joints.  I'm still going to support them when I'm in a pinch for takeout or lunch downtown, but if I'm craving the authentic and frenetic pace of a Vietnamese eatery I'll have to head out to the avenue's for some of the more established dives.\nDidn't have the bahn mi (they were out).  Had a standard buhn dice which was nice but i'm used to the nom plah a little sweeter with more garlic.  The egg rolls are good, (not filled with just veggies).  The spring rolls are missing my favorite, shrimp!  The omlette dish is an acquired taste, and I'll leave it at that :)

"The Chinatown district in Montreal is relatively diminutive in size, yet it remains a consistent and dependable purveyor of delectable, affordable roast pork and duck dishes served over a bed of rice. While their beef pan-fried noodles may not necessarily qualify as a gastronomic masterpiece, their wonton noodle soup and General Tso's chicken offerings are decidedly more palatable, with the latter two dishes garnering sufficient acclaim to warrant repeat orders during our dual visits to this establishment. It is worth noting, however, that the quality of service one receives can vary greatly depending on the linguistic proficiency of their server, with those possessing a greater command of the English language generally providing more satisfactory interactions. Furthermore, while the speed at which the food is delivered may be considered a positive attribute for those with pressing hunger needs, the overall dining experience at this venue does not necessarily constitute a must-see attraction within the city of Montreal. Lastly, it is worth mentioning that their bubble tea offerings, while adequate in satiating a thirst for the beverage, do not particularly excel in terms of taste or quality."

Dropping down to three stars ... On a recent visit, I saw TWO roaches on the main floor of the restaurant. No one seemed to care, so I got up and stepped on one.  I pointed out the other, and one of the staff killed it, but they didn't seem surprised.  I know that roaches are hard to control, but having two of them wandering about in a busy restaurant just isn't a good thing. 

Also, our waiter was an overly chatty guy who seems to think we are interested in his voice.  They had some good staff in the past, but I suspect the owner, who likes to get drunk and hang out on the patio, gives me the impression of a guy who would be difficult to work for! 

The food is still decent and better than anything else I've found, but I'm looking for alternatives ...

While $29.99, $32.42 with tax, proved to be too much for this feast.  While there was a lot offered at good quality, it wasn't worth the price as compared to some of the finer hotels.

I was there at 10:15am on a Saturday.  Mimosas are served, and I had two (delicious).  They had a good amount of breakfast and lunch items,  and I had a little of each.  Yes, lunch is already served.  Brunch.

Nothing was outstanding, but all was good.  It isn't an enormously large buffet, but ample nonetheless.

I think I would go back if 1) I was drunk, 2) I had a hankering for AYCE, 3) I was stuck without my car, 4) held hostage, 5) I was drunk.  Oh I said that.  Well, if the price was less...I would go.

I like Mexican food and I like Chinese food, so why not? Interesting menu. The Jade Red Chicken is as good as any Orange or General Tso's you'll find, and I like that there is a wide variety of choices here. Good food, especially if you like spicy!

I have one beef with this restaurant, and that is the cleanliness. Walking in, you'll notice that the decor and general feel of the place is very low budget. Uncomfortable seating, very weathered ceilings, and generally messy. No big deal. But the restrooms were disgusting, the eating area was dirty, and the trash was overflowing. The place was busy, but there's no excuse for the condition of the men's restroom! It looked like something (or someone) exploded in a truck stop restroom on a state highway. I would have chalked it up to a busy night, but the door and walls were filthy (almost black) with handprints from weeks (if not months) of neglect. All but one of the trash bins were over-stuffed, and most of the tables were dirty. We didn't see anyone cleaning anything. I'm glad I didn't go into the restroom until after I ate!

If it were my business, I would put at least a few dollars toward general maintenance and upkeep. Maybe even invest in a few nicer tables & chairs. If it were close to clean, I'd give at least 4 stars.

Just quickly ran in and grabbed some stuff for dinner. Never been inside of this store until today. It's okay. I don't think the fruits and vegetables are the best but they'll do in a time crunch (because the store is located near the house) but I would prefer Safeway for fruits, vegetables and possibly meats. Prices are average - specials on some things but nothing out there that makes this store stand out.

My first visit was decent, but didn't quite live up to my expectations.

I food just wasn't that good for a steakhouse. Neither my wife and I cared for our appetizer. We got the Fire-Grilled Fresh Artichoke. They say it is a popular choice, but I didn't like it at all. My burger was very plain and lacked good taste. It made me wish I had gone to Five Guys instead. My wife got the steak and thought it was OK, but later she ended up getting sick. She ordered off the gluten-free menu as she has sensitivities, so this place may have issues with cross-contamination.

One positive was our friendly server. Cassie was excellent and we were very pleased because we rarely get good service when we go out. She kept up with refills and offered to replace anything we didn't like. I also wrote about my visit and explained how I didn't like the food. The manager said he would send us a coupon, so I can appreciate that they are reaching out to their customers.

I got good vibes from sitting at the restaurant. I like their tables and seats. I think I will give it a second chance, but the food has to be better if they want to win me over as a customer.

We were the only ones in there on a sunday afternoon which I thought was weird after my friend raved about this place. Our food came out so fast that they would not even have had time to microwave it and put it on a plate so I know everything was pre-made. Food tasted alright just tons of bones in the chicken and the fried pork was so hard I almost chipped my tooth. Is this how you cubans prefer it? 

Parking lot is around back. Absolutely ensure that you lock your car and DO NOT walk alone in this immediate area. 

I would go back but I would try to order something on the menu that they hopefully will make fresh. I gave them three stars for being very friendly, being bilingual, and for not giving me food poisoning.

Is this place closed now, or just \"under renovation\"??\n\nI've been many times for lunch, and have decided that the barbacoa torta is my absolute favorite menu item.  Nothing else on the menu seems very special.  Actually, I tried the breakfast burrito, too....a little disappointed in the proportion of potato to chorizo, especially considering the price and size.

Food was creative, flavored were good. Appetizer portions reasonable for the price and quality. Main courses however is where they fall short. Portions were far too small for the price, about $6-10 more than should be depending on what you order. Bread was a but dry for brioche but a nice light bread to have with the meal. Wine selection is very good and varied. Coming from a food town like Portland, this restaurant is nothing special but is a great addition to the chandler/sun lakes area. I would not return for dinner but would for apps and a glass of wine. They were not very busy for a Friday night either so I suspect many others feel it is overpriced for dinner, too. Would re-evaluate that for longevity.\nNice atmosphere too despite odd strip mall style location.

"A profusion of exceptional cocktails graces this establishment, although certain mixologists excel at their craft more than others. Particularly fond of their mint-infused mojitos. Prices are reasonable, ambiance pleasant, clientele congenial, tunes melodious. Partook in brunch, specifically a lobster omelette. While the dish presented an array of diverse flavors, my fastidious palate found it somewhat overwhelming. However, I surmise that less discerning gastronomes may relish such culinary complexity. Regrettably, the guava mimosa failed to impress."

I'm upgrading to 3 stars because the service is awesome.  Of course, there was about a 1:1 ratio server to guests so....

This place is not doing very well so I do feel bad, however, there are some obvious reasons.  The prices are very high and the portions are not very big.  So for the amount of food you get, the items are very overpriced.  Burgers, skewers, sandwiches and salads are all around 10, pizzas between 10-15.  Everything is a la carte and you get about 3 appetizer size skewers for the entrees.  Appetizers are about 10 as well, and desserts are 7 even with the option to add ice cream for 1.  

I will say the burgers are better than the Grind - they actually stay together!  (the bun falls apart easily at the Grind and makes eating hard after a couple bites).  The fries were good ($5).  The pork skewers were passable but nothing special.  The Dorito potato skins were nothing special - just had a wedge of cheesy chip stuck in the middle of it.  The cupcake was good, but the chocolate was a little grainy.  Very small portion for that one..

All in all, I probably won't go back for anything but happy hour - for the burgers.

"It was indeed a culinary revelation nestled within the picturesque confines of Verdun that we had the pleasure of discovering through a personal recommendation, and given our previous exposure to delectable Persian cuisine, a certain level of skepticism was inevitable. Nonetheless, Parisa managed to surpass our expectations with their unique interpretation of traditional Persian flavors.

Their signature house soup, while containing an incongruous element in the form of noodles, proved to be a truly exceptional offering. It was followed by a delightful assortment of sauteed mushrooms, which, despite lacking the anticipated sweetness, still showcased the kitchen's proficiency in executing simple yet elegant dishes.

The main course featured two distinct protein options: tender, juicy lamb that literally fell off the bone, and succulent chicken drumsticks that, while not necessarily memorable, contributed to the overall satisfaction of our dining experience.

The hospitable demeanor of the host and the tranquil ambiance of the establishment further enhanced our enjoyment, making it an ideal venue for a BYOW excursion. In conclusion, a visit to Parisa is highly recommended, particularly for the unmissable soup, a true masterpiece of culinary artistry."

I tried this place after seeing it in the loafer so many times with rave reviews. I enjoyed my burger and fries although my guest didn't so much. I will note that they DO NOT have air conditioning. I was melting...

"Although this establishment may not exude an extravagant ambiance, it nevertheless possesses an acceptable level of quality. Upon arriving with a group of twelve, we had the foresight to reserve a table in advance, thereby avoiding any unnecessary delays. Our server, a consummate professional, exhibited remarkable proficiency in catering to our diverse needs, deftly navigating the numerous requests and preferences expressed by various members of our party. Unfortunately, the culinary offerings did not quite live up to the high standards set by the exceptional service. Specifically, my potatoes were overcooked to an unfortunate degree, while the flavor profile of the sausage deviated somewhat from the expected norm. Additionally, my omelette displayed a peculiar texture that could be described as rubbery. Thus, while the service we received was truly commendable, the food itself fell short of our expectations."

"An establishment offering an adequate selection of alcoholic beverages and a partially enclosed outdoor area, suitable for relaxation, yet, owing to its proximity to the heavily trafficked East Washington Avenue, susceptible to auditory disturbances. While the assortment of Belgian brews failed to meet expectations, the ambiance and location render it an appropriate addition to the array of similar establishments along Williamson Street, with the added benefit of proximity to an adult entertainment store."

The decor of this place is really neat. It's dim and intimate inside (in fact, it's so dim they have to give you a menu that lights up!) and they have some really comfy chairs to sit on. The DJ who was working on Saturday night was playing some fun music, but the volume was a little too loud for a \"lounge.\"  I could only talk to the people sitting immediately next to me, and even then I had to yell a little.  The patio was a nice escape from the loud music.  They had a lot of seating out there and a nice view of the courtyard to people watch.

I often stop in this place when Im at Tempe Marketplace to get a drink and relax.  They usually have some decent drink specials and they have a nice big bar.  The bartenders usually take a little effort to order from, not really sure why that is, maybe I just have bad luck.

"As an American who spent my formative years in the NYC area, I can confidently assert that I possess a refined palate for authentic Italian cuisine. However, my dining experience at this establishment did not quite live up to my lofty expectations, despite its inclusion in The Guardian's list of the top 10 restaurants in Edinburgh. While the service was indeed exceptional, characterized by friendly and attentive servers, the portion sizes were excessive, leading us to erroneously assume that the starters were designed to be shared. This resulted in us consuming unnecessary amounts of food, as the entrees themselves were sufficient to feed 2-3 individuals. Furthermore, the ambiance of the restaurant struck me as somewhat contrived, evoking the kitschy atmosphere commonly associated with Italian eateries in suburban New York/New Jersey, complete with Frank Sinatra's melodies playing incessantly in the background and servers adopting an exaggerated, stereotypical 'Italian-ness' that bordered on caricature."

"In the previous fortnight, I have visited this establishment on two separate occasions, seeking medical attention for distinct health concerns. Initially, I sustained a fracture of my coccyx (tail bone), owing to my own foolhardy actions. Following a brief waiting period, I received prompt and comprehensive care. Dr. Guy demonstrated proficiency in managing my situation, requesting an immediate radiograph and subsequently discussing my results, available options, and methods of pain relief. One's appreciation for a particular bodily component is often realized only when it becomes injured, leaving one utterly debilitated and experiencing excruciating pain.  

On a separate occasion, I experienced intense, sporadic abdominal pain. Due to its proximity to my residence, I opted to visit this clinic, necessitating urgent medical attention. Presenting with visible signs of distress, including pallor, trembling, and uncontrollable sobbing, I was surprised by the facility's inability to accommodate me due to an excessive patient load. Considering the gravity of my symptoms, it would have been more appropriate for a physician to tend to my needs temporarily, offering some measure of pain alleviation as I awaited transfer to the emergency department.  

Despite the subpar nature of my most recent encounter, I shall continue to seek medical assistance at this location when necessary. However, the aforementioned experience has illuminated the fact that, in extraordinary situations involving a person's health and well-being, this clinic may not be willing to adapt their policies."

I harbor neither acrimony nor ardor towards it. My sentiments regarding this establishment are rather tepid and noncommittal. Initially, my curiosity was piqued by the visually captivating images showcased on Instagram, which inspired me to visit this venue. My expectations were predicated on the assumption that the snow-based offerings would resemble those available at Hawaiian snow-themed eateries, such as Snow Factory or Frost City. Alas, my experience did not quite live up to my expectations.  

In collaboration with my associates, we sampled three distinct flavors - #3, #4, and #5, respectively. However, I was not particularly enamored with the "popping pearls" incorporated into my #5 selection, so I opted to substitute it with a butterfinger variant instead. While the texture of the snow was somewhat reminiscent of a creamy consistency, the flavors left much to be desired in terms of depth and complexity. I had the opportunity to taste a few other options, including taro, green tea, and the mysterious "kuma snow," but unfortunately, they failed to elicit any profound enthusiasm on my part. 

It is my sincere hope that this enterprise will strive to expand its range of flavors, emulating the diverse array offered by Snow Ono, a mobile food truck specializing in shave ice. In particular, I yearn for the return of the beloved horchata flavor. Notwithstanding my underwhelming experience, I must acknowledge that the interior design of this establishment exudes an endearing quality, replete with vibrant colors and playful accents that evoke an unmistakable air of cuteness. This aesthetic, coupled with the potential for Instagram-worthy moments, served as a significant draw for me. 

In conclusion, while my initial visit did not quite meet my expectations, I remain optimistic about the future prospects of this business. With time, I trust that they will continue to refine and enhance their offerings, thereby warranting my return. Moreover, I am eager to introduce additional acquaintances to this venue, thereby facilitating a more comprehensive assessment of their menu items.

I have heard of this place, but never made it over until now.  I was there to support a fundraiser for an elementary school.  What can I say, it looks just like the skating rinks I grew up with in the 80's.  Not sure what kind of improvements have been since.  The evening we were in there the A/C must not have been working because it was hot as heck and smelled like a gym locker room.  But the concession stand prices can't be beat, the music was current and fun, and ALL the skaters, of every age group, looked like they were having a blast!  And you can even bring in your OWN roller blades if you prefer the single row of wheels versus the four wheels.  They even knock a $1 or so off your price.  So as long as you are looking for an old school joint, and not a modern updated place, check it out!

"An establishment that offered a satisfactory ambiance, with a culinary experience that met our expectations. Upon entering, we were greeted by an atmosphere that exuded cleanliness and warmth. Our meal began with the clear egg rolls accompanied by a delectable peanut sauce, a staple dish that we often indulge in when partaking in Vietnamese cuisine. The flavors were adequately represented, without surpassing our expectations. Subsequently, we opted for the combo pho soup, which presented generous proportions and a commendable execution. Although the broth lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, it was reminiscent of fish sauce, mint, and other indispensable components. One might argue that the soup catered to American palates, with a subtle spiciness that left room for personal adjustments. However, for those seeking a more genuine experience, a more robust foundation would be necessary. The menu, though limited, helped avoid the paradox of choice, but we couldn't help but feel that certain Vietnamese delicacies were absent. The staff provided friendly and efficient service, contributing to an overall positive experience. We may consider revisiting this establishment in the future, curious to witness its evolution."

We held a co-worker's going away party here and I have to say that for a group of 16 people and one child-they did really well at serving us. The guac was good and I really liked their \"hot\" salsa that you have to ask for. The sangria is overly sweet but the house margarita on the rocks was better. The meals were so-so. I had some tired chicken enchilada's, but they werent horrendous, just pretty boring. My favorite thing about the whole night was hitting up the Trader Joe's in the same complex after dinner!

The view is amazing for 360 degrees... The ambiance is quite chill and the DJ on Friday night is decent. Mostly top 40 and EDM infused mixes playing through the speakers. 

The late happy hour is only for food and the reason this place gets a couple of stars knocked out of the sky is because of the service and the food that is served. The buns on the sliders were hard enough to break a window on impact and the calamari was soggy (probably microwaved for happy hour). It also took forever for the waitress to make her way around to us. I could have taken the stairs to level 0, walk to the liquor store and walk back up the stairs to Level 107 before she came back with our order. 

This place has a lot of potential, it just needs a facelift in a few places. The view is main reason this gets 3 stars.

The people here are super friendly and nice. Yhe reason I gave only three stars is one their liquid flavors was missing somethin.  I think if they remixed a few  flavors it would be a little better. And the second reason is that their liquid is pricey. Like 21 bucks for one bottle.

Heard A LOT of good things about this place but somehow I don't seem what all the good rants about this place where. I came with high expectations due to the fact that friends and colleagues but they have come to disappoint me in Las Vegas. We came around 1 so it was considered to be the brunch time. It was majority breakfast food with some salads, and other lunch options. \nBut what I ca say was good was their chicken wings, saian chow meain and fried rie, the alfredo pasta, and the calamari skewer. Everything else was just plain jane to my eyes and my stomach. All my friends know that i'm a huge dessert fanatic so I went big on the dessert bar, but I only find just a mere of the plates appealing and taste worthy. The chocolate dipped strawberries, cheesecake and the thai ice cream were my favorites out of my whole plate! THE THAI TEA ICE CREAM IS THE ONLY REASON WHY I GAVE THEM AN EXTRA STAR! IT is a must try for all my thai tea lovers out there! \nJust your average buffet for about $30 a person with a okay food, with an exception of a great dessert which was in fact the thai tea ice cream!
= = = = = =  CLOSED  = = = = = =\n\nSorry to see Him's JL close.  I liked the place.     :-(

"A pleasant and hygienic smorgasbord, proffering an abundance of accommodations for patrons. Although I did not object to the tariff of thirteen dollars per individual, my satisfaction was somewhat diminished upon discovering that an extensive array of porcine delicacies constituted a significant portion of the offerings. As I am not particularly enamored with swinish cuisine, I might opt to expend my resources elsewhere in the future, perhaps at Buffet@asia, where a greater diversity of options, including an increased emphasis on seafood and Mongolian barbecue, is available."

During our peregrination through the industrial and commercial district of Phoenix in pursuit of a delectable meal, preferably of Mexican provenance, my spouse and I encountered an assortment of approximately five eateries specializing in Mexican cuisine. Following a deliberate process of selection, we opted for Salsitas, a restaurant chain prevalent in the Valley of the Sun. It is worth noting that, despite the culinary staff's proficiency in the preparation of our repast, I couldn't help but wish that the young woman who attended to us had exhibited a greater proficiency in both the comprehension and articulation of the English language. Although the order was accurately fulfilled and the victuals were copious and reasonably priced, we were not provided with utensils, specifically forks, despite our explicit request. This necessitated my excursion to the hotel lobby, where I solicited the assistance of the desk clerk in procuring a pair of plastic forks.  
The burrito, generously proportioned and gustatorily satisfying, elicited our approbation. My own culinary exploits involved the consumption of two mini-tacos featuring grilled chicken, which, though palatable, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi and featured a few unpleasant fragments of gristle. My spouse, whose gastronomical inclinations leaned toward a chicken burrito, expressed gratification with her selection, describing it as both ample and delicious. Additionally, the complimentary provision of piquant carrots earned the establishment brownie points with her. In conclusion, our dining experience at Salsitas, while not without its drawbacks, proved generally satisfying, and we departed sated and content, having partaken of four distinct salsas and a dollop of sour cream, all for the reasonable sum of ten dollars.

Its an ok place... I wouldnt reeeeeeeally go here if we weren't invited with a table. The place is very small which would be great if there wouldn't be 200 people cramped on 2squaremeters. I felt like I was in China or subway in NYC. At least the people smelled good, unlike NYC subway. A lot of fake plastic chickerias running around there. Hard to guess their age so I felt comftable, being only 27 myself of course.
The drinks are EXPENSIVE!! I got us 3 shots since I didnt feel like some metrosexual spikedhairguy buying me drinks, and I can afford my own. Well... it was 36$, yes you read right, for 3!! shots. I asked where the diamonds are cause I couldnt find them in there.
I wrote on the slip too that " I aint no rich bitch " under gratidue. SORRY bartender dude. But with these prices you should get the novel price.
Oh well, its still fun. Make sure you PRE BOOZE heavily or bring a dude along that has a platinum credit card.

This is your perfect place to bring someone after going out.
Instead of going to macdonald or some fast food joint this place is cheaper,healthier and quicker than any fast food store.
Plus you can grab something for breakfast the next day.
No matter what time i go i always see people baking fresh bagel.
I'm more of a conservative guy so i usually take sesame bagel or butter bagel.
Hope this help,

Cheers,

Eric Van Nguyen

As Demetria said, this place is definitely hit and miss. If you want some good eats, get here early. They tend to run out of the real goodies.

Fried-chicken, when it isn't too overcooked/dried out, is a home run. I just wish they would perfect cooking it. I swear it alternates every other visit having it cooked perfectly.  Their six-cheese spaghetti is pretty good but can suffer the same fate at the chicken. Sides are plentiful to choose from. Mac-n-Cheese..same case as above. It's a home run if it hasn't been too burnt on top. Love their blackeyed peas and cornbread too. They might just have the best lemonade in Charlotte and I'm too scared to ask if it's just a brand-name mix. I really don't want to know. If you can bypass one of the volunteer's who fills up the drinks, you can make yourself a pretty slammin' Arnold Palmer.

Speaking of the volunteers, they're always extremely friendly and will even give you an extra dollop of mac-n-cheese if you know how to charm 'em like I do. Be sure to tip at the register.

Your pal,
Walter

"Cautionary statement: This evaluation is predominantly grounded on the parameters of service and informational proficiency, rather than culinary offerings. We visited this establishment during happy hour and, while intending to confer four stars, a deduction of one star was necessitated due to the absence of communication regarding seating arrangements for said happy hour. Specifically, we were not apprised of the fact that happy hour seating was exclusive to the bar and adjacent bench. Furthermore, our ignorance was not alleviated by inquiring about the protocol, as we were informed to occupy any vacant seat of our preference. Notably, by the time of our departure, a sole couple remained, and they too were oblivious to the proper seating arrangement, thereby resulting in their failure to capitalize on the discounted prices.  

Our culinary experience was satisfactory, albeit not exceptional, with a few notable exceptions. The red sangria was unremarkable, while the lamb, though flavorsome, was diminutive and overpriced. The croquettes were uninspired, whereas the Patatas Bravas, essentially roasted potatoes enrobed in a tomato-based sauce, was straightforward yet gratifying. The total cost of our repast, excluding gratuity, approximated $60, with an additional $20 expended unnecessarily due to our unawareness of the happy hour stipulations. A comprehensive examination of the menu revealed that several items we ordered were available at a reduced rate had we been seated at the bar."

This place is beautiful inside. I really enjoyed the process of watching the owners transform this great piece of historic modern architecture into something a lot of people could enjoy. 

The other location is cool too, sans the DB scene. I found this location to have scary parking, but good valet service. 

The service was good on my Friday 3pm visit. Was there to celebrate a friends birthday. We had some of the apps (The Trifecta, Double Down, and Crabmeat and Artichoke Dip) and they were good. The waitress was always coming by to check on us and even told us when happy hour started. 

You could tell it was getting close to 5pm. The place was a mad house with 40 something dudes trolling for a place to sit all sweaty from a golf outing. The place is chill and there seemed to be no pretencious DB's. Sure there is a healthy mix of an older crowd, but there was a good mix of younger groups too. 

Good amount of TVs so there is always something to watch. It was kind of noisy near the enclosed patio, but we were at a table being loud anyways. There is alot of room to move and enjoy the space, and not to be bumped into. I have only visited just once for a Friday happy hour, stay tuned for a dinner visit.

I would assign The Green Owl a rating of 4 to 5 stars in relation to the culinary aspect of their offerings, but regrettably, their service falls short, leading to a decrease in their overall evaluation. In conjunction with my romantic partner, I had the pleasure of dining at this establishment last week. Following our seating, it required some time to hail the attention of our server, thus impeding our ability to place our order in a timely manner. We opted to share an order of crabby cakes, while my companion selected a bowl of chili complemented by sour cream and cornbread, and I chose the "meatball" sub, accompanied by kale chips as a side dish. The crabby cakes were served promptly, enveloped in a delectable creamy sauce, which we devoured instantaneously. Noteworthily, my companion, who habitually consumes meat and eschews tofu, relished these dishes. Our server informed us that our main courses would arrive shortly after presenting the crabby cakes. However, our food did not materialize for an additional 40 minutes, during which our server failed to provide any updates or explanations for the delay. Despite this setback, the quality of the food remained impressive. My sandwich was delivered scorching hot, with a crunchy bread roll and flavorful eggplant meatballs that maintained their texture within the sandwich. Unfortunately, the price point of $6 for an average-sized portion proved too prohibitive for me to indulge in a dessert. Notwithstanding the deficiencies in service, I harbor the intention of revisiting the Green Owl, as my curiosity lingers regarding numerous menu items that pique my interest.

The culinary offerings were merely satisfactory, but the prices were exorbitant, far exceeding what would be considered reasonable or appropriate. We opted for a rapid midday repast, and while the hospitality was adequate, the fare was subpar, failing to meet the elevated standards one might expect from a city renowned for its gastronomic delights. Additionally, we strongly advise against ordering the kimchi, as it was not merely unimpressive, but genuinely disappointing.

"I patronized this establishment due to the overcrowding at Oregano's on a Saturday evening. It begs the question of how many patrons share a similar predicament. My initial yearning for Mexican cuisine rendered me indifferent to the alternative dining option. 

The hospitality was exceptional, the brew was nearly frozen (a desirable attribute), and the salsa was delectable. I opted for the signature chimichanga, while my maternal figure selected rolled tacos. The portions were considerable, bordering on excessive. Moreover, I must emphasize that cream cheese enhances the flavor of chimichangas, rendering them even more scrumptious. YUM. 

While not the most exceptional Mexican restaurant I have had the pleasure of experiencing, the quality of the fare and the welcoming ambiance justify future visits for local patrons."
I went on a hip hop night and not  much hip hop was played. However, it was still a good time there.

This sushi restaurant has fresh fish and is the best I've found for a reasonable price in the valley (This coming from an east coast foodie who LOVES sushi.) However, the service is bad more often than it is good and NEVER go here in a hurry. I've never made it out of there in less than an hour. Once I went in there and asked for an itemized check, it took them 25 minutes to bring the check back AND it still wasnt itemized. In fact, I still don't know what it was. I love their sushi but its about time for me to find a new sushi restaurant after how many times I've had waitresses be rude and even ignore me. \n\nTheir redeeming quality that kept me coming back so long was their happy hour prices Sunday-Thursday. Its a lot of sushi for a small cost. So if you have plenty of time and don't mind a bad waiter or two check it out!

"A satisfactory retail establishment with accommodating personnel, albeit at slightly elevated price points compared to alternative stores. A staff member suggested an appropriate collar for our canine companion, which effectively addressed its tendency to pull on the leash. The atmosphere is welcoming, and the extensive array of products catering to diverse animal needs is impressive. Although the pricing may be perceived as marginally steep, it remains reasonable. However, it is advisable to avoid engaging with Banfield, as their services are associated with costly and unnecessary treatments, according to the experiences of my aunt and ourselves. Their aggressive sales tactics and pressure to procure additional services beyond what is necessary or desired are concerning. Canceling their plans requires persistence, and the purported savings often include substantial costs for services that many individuals would not typically purchase. Instead, consider visiting this store for your pet's exercise needs during the summer months, acquiring food, litter, and other essentials while keeping an eye out for discounted prices. Additionally, you may wish to support the partnered pet rescue organization or treat your pet to a special item."

-Note* Review is for casino/shops/ pool area only. 

I don't love it nor do I hate it.

Shops: They have a new renovated shops it looks great and clean.  I would probably only enter the Urban Outfitters store. 
Pool: I love the beach pool they have going on. They have the waves and sands in their pool.  I always have a great time here and it is never too packed here which I like. 
Casino: It's pretty self-explanatory. All casinos in las vegas is very similar. I do love they have these chandeliers in the ceilings, it is a very nice touch.  

Overall: The casino is clean and pretty much okay.  I don't mind coming here or passing through the casino.  They offer a lot of great restaurant and they have the house of blues. Families can have a great time here and can even check out the Shark Reef in this hotel.

"An ideal location in Las Vegas to host one's parents, offering delectable cuisine, albeit at a slightly elevated cost. However, considering the city's reputation for extravagance, it would be unwise to compromise on fiscal constraints. The menu presented an intriguing array of options, yet the dishes did not possess an exceptionally unique flavor profile. Rather, they constituted a fundamental American breakfast with subtle variations here and there. The service was efficient, and we were accommodated in a timely manner (although a notable queue began to form around the peak period for brunch)."

Interior can certainly be modernized, however the food is solid. I'm not a fan of paying to sub hash browns and a english muffin for fruit. Seeing as how I am now paying more for less food. All in all, US Egg is a solid stop in spot every now and then. One of those resturants you're glad that exists, but you'll never take anyone there to show them.

The Chilenita they have the best empanada in town. It's a great place to take out or sit down for lunch. The staff is friendly. The food is so good. The price is affordable. There no other place that has 13 different empanada's to choose from. I love the Chilenita.

Food is average with sandwiches being $8-$10.  Had a burger with Pork Barbecue on it and onion straws and an iced tea for about $14.  Little pricey at lunch.  Surprised there was only 1 bartender/waitress for the whole bar area, but she did a good job managing it.  There were probably 20 people at the bar.  The restaurant has a bunch of TV's on sports or trivia.  The restaurant was crowded which is probably due to its location in the USX building.

We went to Red Lobster for lunch just after 2 PM.  It was moderately busy but we were quickly seated.  All three of us had the Endless Shrimp and between us, we had most of the varieties.  All were good, but nothing spectacular.  Service was not exactly speedy, but wasn't slow enough to put me off either.  Everyone was extremely courteous and pleasant.  $57.00 for three lunch specials was more than I am used to paying in a town known for inexpensive food, but it wasn't unexpected.  All-in-all, just as the rating says \"A-OK\".

It could have all 5 stars if the service was better... Food is very good most of the times, but yesterday my pork kebob had way to many bones! They made me wait for my drink and then for my sauce, so if you like your food without soda and ketchup go for this place:))
The locations in phoenix have chicken we can add to our meal. This location does not. We drove an extra 10 minutes to get here  to find out they don't have chicken was not a pleasant surprise.

Food is good, service is bad.  Have been here twice...both times our order was screwed up.  The second time we received no apology.  Wait staff is reactive instead of proactive.  Food is decent but expect more for the money.  I really wanted to like this place but I have been given too many reasons to go elsewhere.

"Culinary experiences at this establishment are distinctive and flavorsome, particularly the supreme grilled cheese sandwich. However, the quality of service is subpar, as evidenced by the lackadaisical demeanor of the staff, who appear to be preoccupied with personal conversations rather than attending to the needs of the sparse clientele. Despite the satisfying culinary outcome, the overall dining experience is marred by the perception that the staff seemingly lacks vigilance and dedication to providing an optimal customer experience. Furthermore, it appears that management has made some questionable decisions regarding operational hours, which may potentially impact the longevity of the business. Nonetheless, the pricing strategy for pool play during promotional periods remains attractive."

"The conjugal partner of my closest acquaintance arrived for a sojourn from Austin, possessing an academic background in architectural design, which rendered this location an obligatory destination for our excursion. The experience of being present at this site was undoubtedly remarkable... However, I must express my indignation regarding the exorbitant cost associated with participating in a guided tour, which fell within the price range of $30 to $80, a truly preposterous expense. Consequently, we opted to circumvent the tour and instead explored the peripheral areas of the estate, including the gift shop, which we found satisfying, yet tinged with regret due to our inability to partake in the comprehensive tour."

This culinary establishment constitutes one of our most cherished destinations for a brief gastronomic interlude, especially when we possess Aria resort credits that necessitate expenditure. My personal predilection at this venue formerly consisted of procuring an assortment of baked items and chocolates for my acquaintances and loved ones back home (I have always been particularly fond of the bear claw). However, I have recently opted to sample their crepes, which I find quite delectable. We devoured a savory crepe filled with ham, cheese, and sauteed mushrooms, accompanied by a side dish consisting of leafy greens and diminutive tomatoes. Our preferred dessert crepe contains a filling of vanilla custard cream, topped with a mixture of berries in the form of a rich sauce. The queues at this eatery tend to be rather lengthy whenever I visit, yet the staff manages to process the clientele with remarkable efficiency. Although the prices may be considered somewhat elevated, the quality of the cuisine and the overall experience justify the cost.

Can't understand why this place is always so packed. Well actually, the sound system is probably the best out of any club on mill. So that part I liked. There is room to breathe once you make it to the pool tables, but it's a battle to get there in the first place. There is a good amount of tables. Overall, so so. But I'll visit another time for further review.
Very colorful, especially if you want to smoke weed surrounded by a bunch of weirdos playing African drums...other than that it is rather boring

After reading all the good reviews we came here because my wife was in the mood for Indian food.  Its not a big restaurant and It is a buffet.  The mother's day special included a mango lassi (yum!) and  a dolsa (a rolled up pancake with lentil in the middle).  

The cold bar had varius kinds of churney, a salad, some fruit, and other sauces.  There were also 3 different kinds of soup.  A tomato soup that tasted a bit sour, a lentil based soup, and a spicy soup.

Its got a lot of the standard Indian fare.  What stood out to me was the goat curry.  The goat meat was fall off the bone tender and the curry had an excellent flavor.  Also, the tandoori chicken was nice and juicy.... not dry like a lot of other joints.  The paneer sagg (a spinach and cheese dish) was also pretty good.

There were some vegetarian dishes but being the carnivore that I am, I did not partake.  I got a taste of India without blowing out my palate on ridiculously spicy food.  That makes this a decent restaurant in my book.

"It is utterly perplexing to comprehend the grounds upon which numerous individuals base their expectations when patronizing establishments serving rapid culinary fare, as the quality of the consumables and the demeanor of the personnel are often subjective and variable factors; however, in this particular instance, my associates and I opted to sample the wares of this eatery, utilizing a promotional coupon to facilitate our indulgence in an array of menu items. Upon entering the premises, we encountered a hospitable staff who exhibited great alacrity in providing us with an assortment of comestibles, including the signature beverages and sundry accompaniments. Our gastronomical excursion proved to be a gratifying experience, as the lactose-based drinks were indeed remarkable, and my companions expressed unanimous approbation for the savory patties comprised of bovine flesh. Furthermore, we discovered that the cylindrical tubers, although ostensibly the most sought-after item, were surpassed in palatability by the slender, crispy fries."

UltraStar is new to the Phoenix area. It has a spacious lobby with all the warmth of a airplane hanger. Its corporate vibe is immediately apparent in every aspect of the consumer experience. One can almost sense the calculated, committee-approved decision making that dominates the theatre. \nThe concession stand and gourmet coffee bar must seem amusing to Europeans. The seating area has little ambiance and is certainly not a place I'd spend any time hanging out. Boring.\nThe theatre I viewed the film in was serviceable, but nothing outstanding comes to mind. The film started on time. The UltraStar management really would benefit from a visit to a Harkins theatre to get this whole thing 'figured out.'

"Satisfactory victuals and the customary servers are occupied but vigilant.  The greenery-based dishes are palatable, yet caution is advised regarding their preparation time, as they tend to require an equally prolonged duration, if not more, compared to other menu items to arrive at your table.  The poultry strips are delectable, and reports suggest that the wraps are exceptional. 

Beyond that, the remaining options are passable but not remarkable.  The potato-based soup is quite tasty, but avoid ordering it with excessive frequency, as it is featured as the daily special approximately 90% of the time. 

A suitable alternative when seeking a respite from fast food in the central business district or desiring something beyond a simple sandwich."

While the restaurant itself was nice and the staff was also very nice the food was nothing that I can say was truly amazing. We were expecting a very 5 star experience when it came to the food and we were surprised when the food came out just a few minutes after we ordered. Most everyone in our party thought the food was average, nothing to right home about. We have a restaurant near us called Frida Mexican Restaurant in Glendale,CA and there food is much much better. On the bright side I did order the Nachos and this seem to be the hit on the table So much so that everyone started munching away at my food \n\nSo heres the deal for me, I am always looking for amazing Mexican Food, something above and beyond what I can expect living in Los Angeles. Diego was not it for me, Great looking place, Friendly Staff, with So-So Food.

"Commencing with an expression of my profound affection for the culinary offerings and flavor combinations presented at Layers, I must say that my enthusiasm for this establishment has been unwavering since its inception. Organic produce, an aspect that earns my utmost approbation, serves as an indubitable testament to the restaurant's commitment to quality. Notwithstanding, my recent experiences have been somewhat disconcerting, prompting me to confer a rating of three stars, down from the perfect five stars I had previously assigned. While the baked items maintain their exceptional quality, the kitchen fare has, regrettably, fallen short of my expectations during my last few visits. Specifically, the pasta dish I ordered was marred by an excessive amount of oil, rendering it unpalatable. Moreover, my most recent visit saw the meatloaf sandwich, dubbed 'The Conservative,' arrive in a state of disarray, with the bread being unacceptably soggy and fragmented, compelling me to consume it with utensils rather than enjoying the customary convenience of a handheld sandwich. A prior experience with a comparable sandwich, when the restaurant first opened, yielded a more satisfactory outcome, leading me to surmise that either a change in bread or a disparity in culinary expertise might be responsible for the decline in quality. In conclusion, although I would not advise against ordering any item from the menu, I sincerely hope that Layers will strive to restore their former excellence, as they remain one of my preferred dining establishments."

Make sure they know if u r in a hurry.  Was disappointed bc I called ahead and gave very specific directions (Please make sure the 3 dozen bialy's are in plastic bags bc I need to pack them in my suitcase.  Unfortunately, they were not and I had to make the taxi wait...  costing me more money.  UGH!  In the long run, it ended up costing $72 for 39 bialys (including taxi)

Been here twice... the selection seemed about the same... but not so sure. 
It's like walking into an aunt's house. The workers there are friendly, speak Tagalog to you right off the bat, even if you don't speak it (good or bad? Hmmm) and make sure you're ok for the most part.
I like the pork gisantes they have, and the pancit is pretty tasty! At $7.99/ person there's not much to complain about. They also sell other goodies and snacks at the register.
Probably will be back with the fam soon.

Honorable mentions:
Pusit
Diniguan (dinardaraan)

Ohh, parking is somewhat odd. One way only, so make sure you take the correct entrance! Although the lot is small, I usually find parking right away!

"Upon perusing Yelp in pursuit of a novel culinary experience, I chanced upon this establishment and decided to pay it a visit. Upon entering, I was struck by the diverse array of fresh, authentic Poke available, which exceeded my expectations and piqued my interest. Furthermore, I appreciated the opportunity to sample the various options prior to making a purchase, which allowed me to make an informed decision. Eventually, I opted for the spicy avocado ahi, which proved to be a satisfying choice, boasting a subtle yet palpable level of spiciness that complemented the dish without overpowering it. Indeed, this meal served as the sole sustenance for my midday repast, and I must say that I was thoroughly pleased with my decision to patronize this unassuming eatery. Despite its unpretentious appearance, this venue offers a truly delightful Poke experience that is not to be missed."

After a day at the park I was really hungry and not in the mood for the usual fare on East blvd. so I trekked up to Thai Taste. Walking inside it was the usual traditional Thai decor. The restaurant was small and cozy, but I imagine if I had went at a busier time it might have just felt crowded.

The menu is laid out so you pick your entrée and combo it with choice of meat. I went for the green curry with chicken. Usually when I have green curry it has a decent kick to it due to the paste being made from green chilies and balances out the sweetness of the coconut. This green curry while pretty aromatic seriously lacked some much needed heat. After reading some reviews on here though I'll probably try it again and request it extra hot.

The prices are pretty reasonable and the service is attentive enough to keep my water glass full which is much appreciated! My meal arrived in a very timely manner and I left full and happy. Probably one of the better Thai places I've been to in Charlotte, I'll have to come back and try out their Pad Thai along with a hopefully spicier green curry.
What can I say it's The House of Blues, if you've seen one you've seen them all. mostly standing room unless you pay for bottle service or the balcony is open. Good sound I have no complaints.

Normally I wouldn't bother to write a review for a Pizza Hut. Or even check in on Yelp. Some secrets are best kept in the family. It's Pizza Hut after all. Everyone knows what they're going to get. 

So what's the motivation this time? I noticed some really bad recent reviews for the carry out location I occasionally use. The workers there, however, are consistently nice and really seem to be trying to do a good job given the limitations that Pizza Hut presents. I just wanted to give them a little "thumbs up". 

Three stars, the maximum rating allowed by law for a Pizza Hut.

I've used this restaurant for large dinner parties that were held in their private dining room and they have all been A+ experiences.   This time I made a reservation for 2 in the dining room for a happy birthday dinner.  The restaurant was full and busy and we were seated upon arrival.  Our drink orders were taken promptly but then we waited....

Our waitress took our salad and entree orders and the salad arrived pretty quickly.  She was also assigned to a 10 top table that the chef/owner was hosting so we were ignored by her for the rest of dinner.  We had to flag down the bus person for water refills, asked for additional bread while we waited for our entrees, another request for water refills and a final request for the check.  

The food was okay - I had angel hair with tomato sauce and husband had gnocchi.  Both were good portions and served steaming hot.

"Initially, the aromatic ensemble manifests its presence with an artful blend of cloves, badian, coriander seeds, and cardamom, proffering diverse variations on the same theme. The Classics are characterized by their impersonal nature, boasting cleaner cuts of meat and immaculate presentation. In contrast, the Adventurers showcase a less polished bovine anatomy, featuring succulent flanks and crunchy tripe. If the absence of aseptic conditions bothers you, it may be wise to refrain from partaking in this culinary experience. I deduct a star for this reason."
Pasta was good. wine was good. but I cant trust an ITALIAN restaurant that puts Herseys syrup on their tiramisu. Sorry.

I was impelled to visit this establishment due to the fact that I was the fortunate recipient of a complimentary voucher, courtesy of a radio station contest, and I must admit that I would not have opted to partake in this culinary experience had it not been offered gratis.

Upon perusing the menu, I noticed that there was a sampler entrÃ©e/mix grill option available for a mere $70, which included an assortment of delectable cuts, specifically filet, kobe shirt, and a New York cut. Although the Kobe shirt was undoubtedly palatable, it is worth mentioning that I have yet to encounter a less-than-satisfactory cut of Kobe beef, thus rendering its quality somewhat predictable.

Furthermore, I opted to sample their trio of mashed potatoes, which featured an array of distinct flavors, including the tantalizing truffle and lobster variety. While these potatoes were indeed quite delectable, I cannot help but feel that they fell short of exceptional.

In conclusion, taking into account the multitude of superior dining options available, I fear that I would not consider returning to this particular restaurant, despite the occasional availability of complimentary vouchers.

"Capriotti's captivating culinary creations have captured my gastronomical inclinations, albeit at an exorbitant expense. Lamentably, their menu lacks the healthier whole wheat bread option, rendering them somewhat antiquated in comparison to their competitors, such as Firehouse Subs, Subway, Port of Subs, Quiznos, et cetera. It is my fervent hope that Capriotti's will remedy this oversight by introducing whole wheat French bread to their offerings, thereby elevating both their nutritional value and contemporary appeal."

"The Mass Transit District (MTD) offers an effective solution for traversing the campus during inclement weather conditions, but it's essential to be cognizant of the fact that the buses tend to operate with a degree of tardiness, hence it's advisable to select a bus that will arrive at your desired destination a few minutes prior to the scheduled time, thereby ensuring a timely arrival. Moreover, it's worth mentioning that MTD buses are complimentary for students, which serves as an added convenience."

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."  We have visited this establishment on multiple occasions, and unfortunately, our expectations have not been met.  

The appetizer platter was mediocre, with the mozzarella being the sole redeeming factor.  The bruschetta was overpowered by an excessive amount of pesto, rendering the flavor of the bread insignificant, while the calamari lacked the desired crispiness.  The chicken marsala was unimpressive, with the grilled taste overshadowing the marsala sauce.  The mashed potatoes were satisfactory, but they failed to compensate for the shortcomings of the dish.   It is evident that our preference for pasta at Carrabba's remains unwavering.  

The quality of service, however, has consistently met our expectations.

"It appears that an individual has expressed a sentiment which suggests that the English language is not necessary, and that the individual's nation can adequately function without it. Furthermore, the individual seems to be advocating for the abandonment of the English language in favor of their native tongue. This attitude towards language is not uncommon in certain parts of the world, where there is a strong emphasis on preserving cultural heritage and promoting linguistic diversity. However, it is worth considering the potential consequences of such an approach, as it may lead to communication barriers and hinder global understanding. Additionally, it is worth noting that language is not just a means of communication, but also a powerful tool for shaping one's identity and worldview. Therefore, it is important to strike a balance between preserving cultural traditions and embracing global connectivity through language."

We opted to patronize Einstein for our morning repast, despite the considerable queue that had formed outside, stretching beyond the entrance and into the street, owing to the popularity of this establishment among the local denizens. It being just shy of 9 am on a tranquil Sunday morning, we pondered the feasibility of seeking sustenance elsewhere, but ultimately elected to endure the delay, which, much to our relief, proved to be relatively brief. Following a mere thirteen minute interval, during which we placed our order and tendered payment, we were able to secure a table in the spacious dining area, whereupon our culinary selections were promptly prepared and presented to us, requiring but a scant four additional minutes of waiting. My personal preference was for the flavorful applewood bacon and cheddar cheese-adorned egg sandwich, served upon a plain bagel, which, while perhaps a tad overpriced in relation to its constituent elements, was nonetheless thoroughly enjoyable and satisfying.

I attended a gathering at this establishment, whereupon our group consisted of approximately twenty individuals, thereby enabling me to sample an array of culinary offerings. While some selections proved to be delectable, others unfortunately did not meet my expectations. However, I must commend them for offering an assortment of European beverages, which undoubtedly contributed to the ambiance. Unfortunately, the arrival of our repast was delayed significantly, despite our reservation being made well in advance. It appeared that the family-operated enterprise was unprepared to accommodate such a sizable assembly. Nonetheless, it is gratifying to note that our patronage supported a local family business, as the proprietors, including both parents and their offspring, were actively involved in the culinary and hospitality aspects of the operation.

"Upon venturing to this establishment for the first time, I found it to be an adequate location for satiating one's boba cravings without the necessity of traversing to Chinatown. My order of boba milk tea, enhanced by the inclusion of jelly, bore a striking resemblance in taste to volcano tea, thereby eliciting my satisfaction. However, my companion's selection of a taro smoothie yielded an unfavorable assessment from him. It is evident that the quality of the beverages served here is inconsistent and varies depending on the specific item ordered. Additionally, I deducted points due to the limited array of options available, as well as the unremarkable ambiance within the store, which features a compact, unadorned interior that does not foster a sense of leisure or relaxation. A more extensive offering of snacks would have been appreciated."

I was very excited about playing golf here since its firmly entrenched in one of the more exclusive housing areas in Summerlin called The Ridges.  I was here for a fundraiser so we played shotgun.  

The golf course is billed as Jack Nicklaus' best holes in one round.  I can definitely see the potential but this time around, I don't think the potential was actualized.  Granted it was over 100 degrees but the course was very dry and the greens spotty.  It was definitely punched recently but wasn't healing as well as it should.

Checked out the club house to see if there's anything to purchase but the guy working at the counter looked right at me then looked away.  I do not expect to be pampered but a hello would be nice.  Needless to say, I didn't buy anything.

Again, every hole has the potential to be phenomenal with great views of all the beautiful homes as well as views of he strip on a couple of holes.  Unfortunately, I think I caught it during a bad stretch.  I will be back and re-review if I find the experience to be different.

Salads are delicious there jumbo shrimps go perfect on top! There unique dressings to choose from Lime infused ranch was amazing! \n\nCons- Poor customer Service, not helpful when it comes to being undecided or asking for their recommendations

I have been to NY and had pizza and I am sorry to say this was nowhere near what you would get in NY. We ordered the NY style pizza and it just okay. The place is nice and the service was good, but I do not see myself going there ever again.

"It is highly unlikely that I would have had my vehicle's oil changed with such regularity were it not for this particular establishment. The convenience of having a single location where both an oil change and a car wash can be obtained has proven to be an invaluable resource. Additionally, the presence of a Wendy's restaurant in close proximity allows for the satisfying of hunger pangs while awaiting completion of the necessary maintenance tasks. Of late, the scope of services provided by this enterprise has been expanded to encompass various other automotive needs, including replacement of headlights and drive belts. My most recent visit entailed an oil change, installation of a new air filter, and a car wash, all for the eminently reasonable sum of $47, inclusive of tax. It is worth noting that a basic car wash is available for a mere $3.99, while a more comprehensive version, dubbed the "super wash," can be had for $7.99. While I have never opted for anything beyond the basic package, I must admit that I have occasionally discovered minor oversights on the part of the service personnel. Nonetheless, the convenience of having all these tasks addressed in a single location cannot be overstated. Furthermore, this establishment offers a 48-hour guarantee on their car washes, which provides an added measure of assurance. Upon completion of any work, customers are presented with a limited-time discount coupon for future services, constituting an additional perk."

"John's watering hole possesses qualities that render it an agreeable venue for individuals seeking a casual drinking establishment within close proximity to their domicile. The interior design exudes an aura of cleanliness and aesthetic appeal, while the culinary offerings, though unremarkable in quality, provide sustenance sufficient to satiate one's appetite. Patrons have the option to peruse menus from both the esteemed Mario's Pizza and the more limited selection offered by the bar, thereby affording them a diverse array of edible options. Of particular note are the delectable sliders, available in either chicken or cheeseburger varieties, which elicit praise from this writer due to their exceptional flavor. During sporting events, numerous televisions scattered throughout the premises afford patrons an optimal viewing experience, complemented by the presence of enticing drink specials. Although service is generally satisfactory, lapses in attention occasionally occur, understandably so given the steady stream of loyal clientele drawn from surrounding neighborhoods. In summary, John's place presents itself as a welcoming and comfortable local pub, well-suited to meet the needs of those seeking a relaxed, convivial atmosphere without necessitating extensive travel."

"Prior to departing our accommodations, we partook of a delectable morning repast at Gertrude's, situated within close proximity to the botanical garden featuring an exhibition of Dale Chihuly's works. As we customarily endeavor to explore the botanical gardens of the cities we visit, it was quite convenient to have a dining establishment located on the premises. The breakfast offerings were satisfactory, despite my personal reservations regarding the nomenclature'sammie'; the coffee, however, was robust and satisfying. Our sole criticism pertained to the infrequency with which our cups were replenished. We were afforded the opportunity to enjoy our meal on the outdoor patio, which was particularly pleasant given that our journey to this region was motivated, in part, by a desire to escape the inclement weather conditions prevailing in our native locales. The ambiance was tranquil and aesthetically pleasing."

Went here for lunch last week and the place was packed, with a long line! We almost left, but they enticed us back with a fresh tray of lechon kawali (roast pork belly). I had Filipino-style corned beef and potatoes and oxtail stew (\"kare-kare\"). Boy were they good. Small, homey place, in a busy strip mall in a Chinese plaza. Lots of other foodstuffs for sale. The name of this place means \"neighbor\", but literally it means \"house-connected\" - shows you that Filipinos have close ties to their neighbors, as a culture. Price is reasonable as $6.50 for two viands and rice.

Store carries high end merchandise and a nice enough selection. But I would have to agree with previous reviewer, the staff needs basic customer service training. Contrary to what one would expect, the older staff members are extremely nice, courteous and helpful, while the younger ones are rude and exhibit totally inappropriate behaviour: talking loudly about personal matters in the presence of customers, showing annoyance and irritation, eye rolling, or completely ignoring shoppers. It's hard to believe a store that brands itself high end does not ensure its staff behave accordingly.

Well, I'm sitting here while my son plays.... Music is so loud you have to shout to communicate.... I asked them to turn the volume down a bit, they did but then turned it back up..... Inappropriate songs come on and staff needs to be told to turn it.... I mean what parent wants their kid listening to a song about a$$ and twerking? Other than these issues (that can definitely be addressed), it's a great place....

There is nothing really exciting about the Boozery, which is disappointing for it's location. The bar itself is pretty small but they are able to accomodate more with outside seating. It has a nice ambiance inside but the small size of the place cramps the style a bit. They have very limited special drink menu with your average Freemont street drink prices ($7-$10).\n\nThe Boozery is just your average downtown bar. Nothing to complain about, but also nothing to brag about.

I planned an event here with some girlfriends for an early dinner. The place is easy to miss, because it's a small building so if you blink or aren't paying attention you will get lost (trust me...I know). Also, just a head's up with the place being so small parking is a bit of a pain. In fact it's pretty non-existent. There's a few spaces in the front and if you're lucky they have a few in the back...if all those are full....good luck! 

That being said, the menu is pretty simple. I think they are going for down home favorites. There are your staple dishes like meatloaf, burgers, fish and salads. But I just wasn't overly impressed with the menu. I opted for the Veggie Burger and fries. It's your typical Morning Star veggie burger so nothing to be amazed about there and the fries were just okay. 

The service was great but I'm just not sure I'd make it a priority to give them another try. Based on the reviews, their brunch might be worth another visit. We'll see!

"The decibel level within the establishment was remarkably high, rendering conversation challenging, albeit suitable for revelers seeking to partake in fermented beverages, sporting events, and grilled culinary delights. Notwithstanding, the selection of artisanal brews was truly exceptional, while the gastronomical offerings, though slightly delayed, were expertly prepared and undeniably savory. Our hospitable server and the proprietor himself extended warm welcomes, and the complementary side dishes, specifically the gravy fries and macaroni and cheese, showcased pronounced flavors. Despite my residence in Glendale, I wouldn't venture across the Valley solely to visit this venue again, however, I would unhesitatingly endorse it to acquaintances residing in close proximity who seek an exhilarating atmosphere to enjoy a football match or two alongside superior quality beverages."

(+) The lodging boasts an enviable location, nestled within close proximity to a plethora of iconic landmarks, cultural hotspots, and urban amenities, including the revered Notre Dame, the historic Old Montreal, the vibrant Chinatown, the charming Latin Quarters, and the bustling St. Catherine's, as well as an array of art museums, a convenient metro station, and a diverse selection of shopping and dining venues.
