"I received exceptional service, as they meticulously ensured that I was properly fitted with the ideal bicycle, following an unfortunate incident involving incorrect sizing from another Landis store. They dedicated considerable time to assisting me in selecting the appropriate footwear, and provided comprehensive responses to my numerous queries regarding my first road bike purchase, despite some reservations I had regarding their unconventional methods. Although I have yet to utilize their repair services, I am eager to assess their proficiency in that regard once I bring in my dilapidated mountain bike for maintenance."

"The performance was ostensibly satisfactory, as the comedic individual executed merely four daredevil feats to substantiate his proficiency, while expending the majority of the time engaging in banter. The spectacle prompted curiosity regarding the methodology behind his cognizance of such information. Upon culmination of the production, he divulged the winning lottery numbers to the entire assemblage, evoking amusement and intrigue. Notwithstanding, I wouldn't attend another presentation, as I possess a predilection for novel experiences and endeavors, and thus, it is imperative for me to progress forthwith."

I absolutely love this place for breakfast.  I have never seen so many selections for breakfast.  I'm definitely coming here again when I'm out in Vegas.\n\nDinner:  its 108 for 2 people and I don't really think its all that.  Yes, they have crab and a seafood selection but I was disappointed.  I thought dinner was going to be better than breakfast.  For that amount of money you can get a nice meal at Mesa Grill located in Caesar Palace.
Not a huge fan. It was okay at best. I've been to a few of these types of places around town and this one was average.

I was excited when this breakfast restaurant opened up in my neighborhood as I love to go out for breakfast almost everyday.

I have eaten there 3 times now but I only order 1 thing on the menu which I do enjoy quite a bit because their other items are a little unusual for me.

I went to eat there again yesterday and I was very sorry to see they have removed all side items off their menu. So I cannot order an omelet or 2 scrambles eggs with bacon, or a side of toast. Its one of the nine items or nothing. That does not work for me so that is why i have given this restaurant 3 stars. I hope they reconsider offering the basic breakfast items or I will probably not be back.

This was my second tapas place to visit in Las Vegas. 

The food was ok, nothing really stood out other than the paella. It was a 40 minute wait, but worth it to try at least once!

The service was top notch, from the moment you walk thru the entrance to the wait staff, manager, everyone made you feel welcome. 

The price, OH THE PRICE!   Only complaint I would say.  The entire menu is seriously over priced, even by Las Vegas Strip standards. It's the reason it will not be coming back. There are far better places to go for tapas on the Vegas strip for a better price & value. And important a better selection.

The atmosphere is great!  Plenty of light, open, not stuff. It has a bar area as well. The noise level is on the average. And the place is clean, they did a pretty good job clearing the table as you was done.  

All in all, I thought this place was OK at best.  But there are much much better places to visit.

This eatery is characterized by inconsistency, with the quality of service ranging from mediocre to inadequate. The culinary offerings, while diverse, are often unpredictable in terms of taste and texture, specifically regarding the chicken fried rice, which can be excessively oily or unpleasantly dry. Furthermore, the orange chicken dish is frequently overcooked, resulting in an unpalatable chewiness that does not contribute to a satisfying dining experience. While the prices are reasonable, they do not justify the variable quality of the food. In conclusion, this establishment does not rank among the superior options for Chinese cuisine in North Phoenix.

A luncheon in commemoration of a colleague's departure led me to this establishment, whereupon I was less than enthused by the precursory popover bread, possessing an unmistakable ovum flavor that nearly satiated my gastronomical inclinations, yet thankfully, my fungi and gruyere panini proved to be delectable and of generous proportions, accompanied by an abundance of fries, and ultimately, all patrons relished their culinary selections, furthermore benefiting from a minor rebate extended to financial institution staff members, constituting an added advantage.

I was gratified to discover this eatery within my lodging establishment, as it afforded me the convenience of not having to venture outdoors, particularly given the lateness of the hour. The bar area, however, presented a surprising spectacle, characterized by a greater number of patrons than I would have anticipated for a Monday evening. My culinary selection for the evening consisted of gnocchi, which I noticed was incorrectly spelled on the menu as "gnocci." Prior to bringing this to the attention of the waiting staff, I was struck by the peculiar manner in which the server pronounced the dish, specifically employing the phonetic rendering "knock-y." This led me to ponder whether she might also refer to her place of employment as "Bigelow Grill-e," a supposition that somewhat diminished the perception of refinement associated with my dining experience. Notwithstanding this, I found the overall atmosphere to be agreeable, with the exception of the dense cigarette smoke that permeated the bar area. Furthermore, I found myself perplexed by the enigmatic statement "Bigelow is serving innovative and imaginative interpretations of ethnic Pittsburgh classics," a phrase that piqued my curiosity and left me eager to acquire further insight from local individuals familiar with the culinary landscape of Pittsburgh.

"The early riser does not necessarily secure the prized vermiculate at Marche Atwater, particularly on a frigid winter Sunday morning when the majority of establishments remain unopened, with only a select few merchants offering their wares; however, fortune smiled upon us, enabling us to procure an assortment of delectable pastries at Boulangerie Premi\u00e8re Moisson, which served as an excellent initiation to the day's culinary pursuits. As the clock struck 8:30 a.m., a gradual influx of vendors began to populate the market, showcasing their fresh produce and artisanal goods. Marche Atwater, though smaller in scale than anticipated, still presented an array of options for those seeking gastronomical delights, although the absence of outdoor vendors during the winter season was palpable. In hindsight, a visit to Jean-Talon might have proven more fruitful."

Since my culinary predilections incline towards delectable lobster rolls, I opted to partake in this establishment's offerings during the meridian hour. In conjunction with my spouse, we elected to apportion a combination platter. The lobster roll itself was merely adequate, as the minuscule fragmentation of the meat evoked memories of canned tuna. Furthermore, my contentment was diminished by the superficial incision of the bun, which only extended partially through the bread, leading me to surmise that the restaurant was endeavoring to conserve their lobster supply. As my companion and I indulged in each bite, the lobster meat had a propensity to escape from its bread-based confines. The chowder fries, while not particularly remarkable, were palatable. However, considering the price point of over $20, I felt that the quantity of sustenance provided was insufficient to satiate my hunger, leaving me feeling underwhelmed.

I chill at White Castle 'cause it's the best
But I'm fly at Fat Burger when I'm way out west!

So the lyrics led me to this place but I must say it didn't live up to the hype.  The burger wasn't terrible, but I've had better.  WHAT-A-BURGER beats the hell out of it.

The burger patty reminds me of the patty at Freddy's Frozen Custard, Culver's, and Steak and Shake.  I had mine built with the default config which includes sweet relish.  I knew that going into it and thought i would try it.  It was a mistake - just plain weird.  Hold the relish next time.

Good & decent lunch specials! However, I had to knock a couple stars because waitress came to our table at least 3 times & did not bother to fill water glasses. And we had to remind her for our roll that comes with lunch entre\u00e8! Fish was ok, not that fresh!

One of the stops on the Light Rail Bar Crawl, I felt that the Gin Mill was the most \"dive-y\" with a lot of dented chrome and scarred wood a bathroom that needed a flamethrower and some seriously loud music. I sat at the bar with my beer and watched the young-uns dancing to the DJ's tunes on the \"stage\". This vantage point gave me a great opportunity to see the bartenders in operation. Fast, efficient and friendly. Picking up abandoned empties and serving out drinks quickly. Impressive.\n\nBouncer at the door checking ID's. Taxi stand outside ready to take the wobbly folks home, but I was good. It's a very short walk to the Light Rail station that gave me time to sober up (I only had four drinks over five hours) while riding back to my parked car.

I have been thoroughly enjoying Dos Chandler for an extended period of time, having previously been content with merely consuming their Negra Modelo and Dos X; however, I have recently developed a penchant for savoring their delectable, viscous chimi, which I would highly recommend to any individual. Their quesadillas are truly exceptional, reaching a pinnacle of culinary excellence that is challenging to surpass. While I am employed in a New Mexican style kitchen, I believe that Dos Chandler should expand their selection of Mexican beers on tap and provide a more extensive assortment of tequila options. Unfortunately, their frozen margaritas fail to impress, and the tables tend to be unpleasantly adhesive upon my arrival, indicating a lack of consistent maintenance. Furthermore, I have noticed a high turnover rate among servers and bartenders, leading me to question the quality of management support on the floor. Despite these shortcomings, I award Dos Chandler three stars, primarily due to the subpar cleanliness, limited beer selection, and uninspired tequila offerings, all of which are aspects that a Mexican restaurant should strive to improve upon.

"Upon entering the establishment at approximately 8:45 a.m., I opted to partake in their breakfast offerings, specifically 'the handful,' comprising of two eggs, two pancakes, potatoes, and an additional two slices of bacon. However, upon requesting a substitution of said bacon for vegetables, I was informed that such a modification would incur an additional fee of one dollar, despite the fact that the cost of the bacon exceeded that of the vegetables on the menu's side item list. Perplexed by this incongruity, I elected to proceed with my original order, the quality of which was satisfactory yet unremarkable, thereby precluding me from offering a resoundingly positive endorsement."

"Our August excursion culminated in our arrival at this esteemed establishment via taxi, a significantly more economical mode of transportation compared to the alternative shuttle service. Upon our arrival, the courteous Bell-Man expedited our check-in process by assuming responsibility for our luggage, thus obviating the necessity for us to endure an extended wait in the luggage claim area. The duration of our check-in process was approximately thirty to forty-five minutes on a Sunday, a time frame that we found to be quite reasonable given the influx of guests during the peak travel season. We had the pleasure of residing in the recently refurbished Grand Tower, which boasted an array of amenities designed to enhance our comfort and convenience, including a plush king-sized bed, an expensive yet functional mini refrigerator, and an impressive upgraded view that we thoroughly enjoyed during our anniversary celebration. Unfortunately, our spa experience was slightly marred by the presence of a nude female patron within the women's hot tub area, which engendered a sense of unease and discomfort due to the potential health risks associated with shared facilities. Moreover, we would like to caution prospective guests against utilizing the pool facilities, as we unfortunately contracted a persistent bacterial infection on our legs that required four weeks of antibiotic treatment to resolve."

This is the Grand Lux Cafe located inside the Venetian. There's another one in the Palazzo but supposedly this one is better. The only other Grand Lux Cafe I've been to is the one in the Beverly Center in Beverly Hills and in comparison, they're pretty similar in terms of ambience and food, but this one is open 24 hours!!

We had a huge group of about 15 and we were lucky enough to get seated right away even though it was peak dinner time and we didn't have reservations (you have to make them 2 hours in advance). 

My friend and I shared a sausage, pepperoni, and mushroom pizza. It was super doughy (a little too soft for my taste). I couldn't even break the pieces apart cleanly without all the toppings and cheese falling off all over the place. But the CRUST was delicious! My friend and I found ourselves just eating the crust off of each slice towards the end. They have all kinds of food here--it's really similar to Cheesecake Factory because it's the sister restaurant. But I'd avoid the "asian" food if I were you, especially if you're looking for something authentic because you're probably not going to find that here.

I was somewhat skeptical regarding a cafe that publicizes coffee that lacks the characteristic flavor profile associated with coffee, yet my reservations were partially alleviated upon sampling their espresso, which demonstrated a level of quality that surpassed my expectations, although it failed to elicit an exceptional degree of enthusiasm within me, and its overall quality was inferior to that of Starbucks' offerings.

"Gastronomical excellence notwithstanding, the sluggishness and inattention exhibited by the waiting staff at this establishment significantly diminishes the overall dining experience. My previous visit, which occurred almost precisely a year ago, was marred by an analogous set of circumstances, wherein the manager demonstrated commendable attentiveness while the servers displayed an utter lack of concern towards our needs. The elapsed time between ordering and consumption stretched to an unacceptable extent, warranting my personal intervention to inquire about the delay not once, but twice. Notwithstanding these issues, the culinary offerings did indeed prove satisfying. Thus, if one prioritizes gustatory pleasure over promptness of service and the demeanor of the staff, Kona Grill may still be a suitable choice."

My partner and I traversed into Phoenix via aerial transportation last week during the festive season and elected to partake of a meal at this establishment prior to proceeding to our familial gathering.   I must admit that I was rather taken by the culinary offerings and the overall atmosphere of the restaurant.  
I opted for a delectable burger accompanied by an array of tantalizing accoutrements and it was cooked to perfection.  While I could have indulged in a greater quantity of fries accompanying my burger, I likely did not require them from a nutritional standpoint.  
It must be noted that the visual presentations of 80's hair bands that were being projected within the dining area struck me as somewhat peculiar.  
In the event that I find myself in Phoenix once again, I would not hesitate to return to this eatery and indulge in their gastronomical delights.

This is exactly what I was looking for in a hotel during my one night stay in Pittsburgh. Close to the city, but far enough out to get free parking and a reasonable rate (under $100).

The room was fairly small, but I was only planning on sleeping in it. It was clean so I couldn't ask for much more. The people at the front desk were very friendly too.

If I go back to Pittsburgh, I will absolutely stay here again.

"I had the pleasure of dining at Rigatonys this evening in the company of my sibling and niece, partaking in a delectable array of culinary delights. My niece and I opted to share a serving of manicotti, which, while not the most extraordinary example of its kind, was still palatable enough to warrant consumption. My sister, however, elected to sample the Mahi special, which was served with a side of asparagus and quinoa pasta. Her enthusiasm for the dish was unbridled, praising the creamy dill sauce adorning the fish and the generous helping of salami, cheeses, olives, pepperocini, and other assorted vegetables accompanying it. To conclude our repast, we indulged in a portion of spumoni, the authenticity of which was undeniable and satisfyingly sizable. Our server, Bryce, provided attentive and informed service throughout the meal, taking care to apprise us of the supplementary fee associated with splitting a plate. Additionally, a complimentary basket of bread was brought to our table, contributing further to the overall enjoyment of our dining experience. In conclusion, our visit to Rigatonys was thoroughly enjoyable, and we look forward to returning in the future."

I visited this establishment on a Saturday afternoon with the intention of partaking in their midday repast, but upon arriving, I encountered an abundance of patrons already present, thus leading me to opt for taking my sustenance with me instead. Upon eventually consuming my torta ahogada, I noticed that it had become saturated with the piquant sauce in which it was submerged, rendering it unpleasantly soggy and prone to disintegration at an accelerated rate. While I typically possess a certain degree of tolerance towards pungent culinary creations, I must admit that the overwhelming sensation of fiery heat permeated my taste buds to such an extent that it eclipsed any other discernible flavors. My companion elected to sample three fish tacos, which, regrettably, proved to be minuscule in size. Consequently, they remained unsatisfied and sought sustenance elsewhere, thereby leading to an overall experience that fell short of my expectations, given the copious favorable assessments I had previously encountered on Yelp.

Food good sometimes ,remodel nice. 
2 times there .  1 waitress had attitude over easy eggs runny did not eat nothing done.
2 attitude waitress again we were a group after bowling  some women playing. Mah jong told us to be quiet it is a restaurant we were paying they were playing for free.
Maybe we should start a poker group there and not pay then IHOP would listen to our complaints.

I've made plenty of bad decisions here.\n\nHave you ever been somewhere where it means nothing, but somehow, means everything? I like coming to Maz. They don't have a good selection of beer. Or drinks. They don't have good pool tables. There are plenty of shady things that go on here. But still I find myself here every once in a while; generally I'm in a really crappy mood, or I'm feeling to good to go home and too mashed up to go anywhere else.

The service was a bit slow but the food made up for it. The sushi was delicious and the burger was unique and flavorful. We also got the mixed delux fries basket which was phenomenal. I would definitely come back.

"A moderate lodging facility, offering a comfortable respite in a prime location, proximal to an array of amenities, including a shopping mall, cinema, and various dining establishments, while remaining accessible to primary tourist attractions within a mere 10-15 minute distance. Additionally, this accommodation boasts a tranquil atmosphere, nestled amidst a picturesque neighborhood, replete with charming cafes and boutiques, mere steps away. Guests may enjoy the inviting ambiance of the hotel's lounge area, complete with a fireplace, ideal for relaxing with a refreshing beverage, whether alcoholic or non-alcoholic in nature. Furthermore, a comprehensive dining experience is available on-site, catering to guests' culinary needs, should they opt to forego venturing out into the city. However, it is worth noting that the rooms themselves suffer from somewhat diminutive soundproofing, resulting in an increased auditory awareness of fellow patrons' comings and goings. Moreover, the complimentary wireless internet connection, while appreciated, exhibits sluggish speeds, hindering productivity and efficiency. In summary, this establishment offers a suitable temporary abode for travelers seeking convenience and accessibility, without necessarily serving as a prolonged haven for leisurely activities."
Came in. Waiter was alright. Gave me a stair like I didn't know what I was doing. He gave mediocre service. I'm full

Qdoba is merely adequate, as it employs a similar concept as Chipotle Grill, but regrettably, the culinary offerings fail to impress, lacking an indispensable element that would compel repeat visits. Additionally, the uninspired ambiance, characterized by the utilization of concrete floors and metallic tables, contributes to a chilly and somber atmosphere, even during the peak summer months.

I recently had the pleasure of dining at this esteemed establishment to commemorate the birthday of one of my colleagues. Prior to this experience, I had never encountered any issues with this specific chain of restaurants; however, on this particular occasion, upon ordering the shrimp and spinach salad, I discovered an unidentified synthetic substance intermingled within my culinary masterpiece. The manager and waitstaff promptly expressed their sincerest apologies for the unforeseen occurrence and demonstrated an expeditious willingness to rectify the situation. I was presented with a novel salad, which I opted to consume off-premises due to my associates having already completed their meals, and upon the food being delivered to me, the manager once again extended his deepest regret. My repast was also complimentary. Despite the fact that I do not attribute blame to either the manager or waitstaff, I cannot help but surmise that the culinary artisans responsible for preparing the victuals may have been remiss in their duties. Notwithstanding, my salad was indeed quite delectable!

I customarily visit this establishment every Sunday during the football season; however, today's visit was an impromptu decision. Upon entering, I sat down at the bar and was greeted by my preferred Asian bartender in the United States. She enthusiastically recommended their delectable chicken wings, which I ordered along with the Kobe burger. Upon arriving home, I opened the box and was utterly dismayed to discover two putrid tomatoes that not only had an unpleasant appearance but also emitted a foul odor reminiscent of organic fertilizer. I promptly returned to the restaurant to request a replacement, only to be informed by the assistant manager that the tomatoes' condition was allegedly "normal." It became evident that this individual lacked a fundamental understanding of culinary quality and customer satisfaction. Fortunately, the general manager was present to mediate the situation and prevent any further dissatisfaction on my part. Notwithstanding, I must express my gratitude towards my bartender, whose exceptional service was the sole redeeming factor of this unfortunate experience, and the primary reason I might consider returning to this establishment in the future.
Horchata is delish! Familiar faces is nice. Pretty good veggie burrito, bomb breakfast burrito, seriously good. Decent prices, but their guacamole could use some work.

I go to this facility usually 3 nights per week at about 2am and love it. Its jot crowded at all, usually having about 3-5 people in it. I can have the basketball court to myself I wanted and move freely through workout stations.

Upon initial inspection, this establishment appeared to conform to the conventional characteristics of a tourist trap, given its location within the historic district and its assortment of traditional Mexican knick-knacks. However, upon further examination, the prices were discovered to be reasonable and not exorbitant, as previously assumed. A vibrant straw sombrero was acquired for a mere $5, and various other items within the store were observed to possess price tags that were similarly fair and affordable. This store serves as a veritable treasure trove for those seeking to create an unforgettable festive experience, offering an extensive array of items tailored specifically to the celebration of Dia de Muertos, including but not limited to colorful masks, plates, cups, and even ornaments for garden decor. Unfortunately, the staff members present within the store did not exhibit a warm or welcoming demeanor; however, the overall ambiance of the store was well-maintained, ensuring a satisfying shopping experience for patrons. The vast selection of trinkets available guarantees that customers will undoubtedly depart the premises with a sense of contentment and satisfaction.

We have been patronizing Pediatric Partners (PP) for an extensive period of seventeen years, during which time Drs. Chiles and Salek have been rendering exceptional medical care to my offspring, having witnessed numerous personnel changes within the facility without any detrimental impact on the quality of service delivered; however, subsequent to the merger between PP and a comparably sized healthcare organization, the ambiance of the office has undergone a transformation, resulting in a diminished sense of familiarity and warmth, despite which, our unwavering loyalty towards the practice remains steadfast, primarily attributed to the continued exceptional care extended by our attending physicians, whose proficiency and dedication have proven invaluable, particularly now that my children have matured, necessitating fewer appointments.

Patience is required as they take their sweet time and it isn't even busy. It's been 30 minutes and I don't know that they'll be done soon. I would come back because it's cheap but definitely not during 'rush' hour.

"This establishment is truly a behemoth; its gargantuan proportions are simply staggering. Attempting to navigate the vast expanse of the casino from the sidewalk entrance on the strip is an exercise in futility, as the labyrinthine layout and contradictory signage will inevitably lead to disorientation and confusion. Despite its impressive grandeur, the hotel's age is beginning to show in various aspects, with remnants of its former Wizard of Oz/Hollywood motif now conspicuous only by their absence. A pervasive verdant hue envelops everything, creating an ambiance that is both surreal and overwhelming."

Just wanted to update. Manager contacted us. Was willing to give full refund or have the top installed for free. Seems there was a communication issue. Issue was resolved, even kept the truck box cover. Did have an issue, but company did resolve in a timely manner and apologized for the miscommunication

"Although I would rate Dolce a mere 3.5 stars if given the opportunity, I must admit that the ambiance of this establishment is quite inviting and conducive to a relaxed dining experience. However, my culinary exploits at this location have been limited to a few select appetizers, specifically their delectable hummus and crispy pita chips. Yet, based on the opinions of others, I may consider elevating my assessment after partaking in their more comprehensive menu offerings. As an ardent devotee of vinous delights, I find myself drawn to this wine bar, eager to indulge in a rich, full-bodied glass of red wine while engaging in lively discourse with companions. Unfortunately, my experiences with the service staff have been somewhat mixed, with some members exhibiting a certain aloofness or reserve in their interactions. Nevertheless, such sentiments are merely anecdotal and do not detract significantly from the overall appeal of the venue. Additionally, I lament the meager selection of wines available, a sentiment shared by a previous reviewer. In light of these factors, I would still recommend paying Dolce a visit, particularly if you find yourself in close proximity to the NoDa neighborhood."

We halted our journey at this establishment for an interval of recreation and relaxation during the evening hours, as I was feeling rather indolent and it was in close proximity to my place of employment. As it transpired, they offered a satisfactory happy hour with diverse potable specials, half-priced chosen appetizers, and a select two culinary delights special that persisted from opening until closing for the modest sum of $6.99. I opted for the Tortilla soup and cheese enchiladas, which proved to be palatable and satisfying, accompanied by a side of rice and beans. Our server exhibited exceptional hospitality and I regret not committing her name to memory, but after indulging in a few of the happy hour Margaritas, my cognitive faculties were somewhat impaired.

"My culinary excursion to this establishment was predicated upon a glowing endorsement from an acquaintance who vehemently asserted that this was, without a doubt, the optimal pizza proffered within the city limits of Las Vegas. While I find such a claim to be somewhat dubious, given the city's limited reputation for exceptional pizza establishments, I decided to indulge my taste buds and form my own opinion. As a lifelong devotee of New York-style pizza, my standards are unwaveringly high, and I find it challenging to believe that any other region can surpass the culinary prowess of the Big Apple. Thus, I embarked upon this gastronomical adventure with a healthy dose of skepticism.  

Upon perusing the menu, I noticed they were offering a special promotion, wherein all pizzas were being offered at a fifty percent discount. Seizing the opportunity to sample their wares without breaking the bank, I opted for a large pie adorned with pepperoni, sausage, and black olives. Alas, my expectations were not entirely met, as the quality of the pizza left something to be desired. Specifically, the crust lacked the requisite crispness that I have come to expect from a truly exceptional pizza. Furthermore, the sausage and pepperoni toppings contributed to an unfortunate sogginess that permeated the entire pie. Admittedly, the crust exhibited some promise, but it was not enough to salvage the dish from its overall mediocrity.  

In conclusion, while this establishment may lay claim to being the best pizza in Las Vegas, it falls short of the lofty standards that I have established for truly outstanding pizza. My culinary journey, regrettably, did not culminate in the discovery of a gastronomical masterpiece."

"On multiple occasions, I have partaken in culinary indulgences within the confines of both the dining room and hibachi grill at this eatery, and I must say that my experiences have been nothing short of exceptional, particularly when it comes to the quality of the fare and the captivating performances put on by the chefs manning the grill. However, my encounters in the dining room have been somewhat less than satisfactory, marred by prolonged waits for my meals, which have consistently exceeded thirty minutes, despite the staff's acknowledgment of these delays and their attempts at compensation, such as offering complimentary edamame to waiting patrons. It appears that there is a dearth of sushi chefs and/or wait staff, resulting in an inadequate level of service that falls short of my expectations. While I would greatly desire to bestow upon this restaurant a more favorable rating, I fear that I cannot do so in good conscience until such time as I witness a marked improvement in the overall quality of service provided throughout the establishment."

Took my commuter in for an oil change and was very pleased with the cost and speed that it got done.  The location is perfect as well to just take a walk over to Costco to shop or snack while waiting.  \n\nFYI Check for coupons on their Yelp page before going it might save you some money like it did me :)

This establishment was purported to be the most recent and illustrious nightclub in Las Vegas; however, upon our arrival, we were met with an overwhelming throng of patrons that rendered it arduous to partake in any semblance of rhythmic movement, let alone maintain a stationary position without being inundated by an unyielding sea of humanity. Despite this, we elected to migrate towards the Hip-Hop section of the venue, which, unfortunately, proved to be similarly congested, albeit we were able to discover a relatively diminutive and secluded area in which to execute a few dance moves. Subsequently, we were extended an invitation by a hospitable female patron to join her in a reserved table area, whereupon we were treated to a live performance by none other than the renowned artist Warren G. As West Coast natives, my associates and I were intimately familiar with his musical repertoire and thus were able to derive immense enjoyment from his show. Due to the extreme density of the crowd, we opted to vacate the premises shortly thereafter, as it became increasingly taxing to navigate through the multitude of people. Additionally, it is advisable to avoid purchasing bottled water at this establishment, as the cost for a minuscule container is exorbitant and egregiously disproportionate to its contents.

"My initial experience at this establishment was enjoyable, and I intended to bestow a perfect rating, as the culinary offerings were satisfactory and I consumed them on consecutive days. However, upon my return, I perceived a decline in quality regarding the sandwich I ordered. Specifically, the absence of lettuce in all four Earl's club sandwiches was glaring, and an excess of bacon resulted in an overpowering saltiness. Consequently, my enthusiasm for this venue has waned, and I shall not experience cravings for its fare in the future."

A viable alternative to Pita Jungle, albeit with a tad elevated price point relative to the quantity and quality of the fare in comparison to its competitor. My personal experience has been limited to the Togo option, which, while satisfactory, may not always provide the most pleasant dining experience, particularly when taking into account the ambient atmosphere. Notwithstanding, they accommodate Hooka smoking on the patio, a feature that, although potentially bothersome to some, does not detract from the culinary enjoyment. Upon collection of my Togo order, I must steel myself against the pungent Hooka odor that permeates the outdoor seating area. Despite these minor drawbacks, the cuisine generally meets expectations, leaving room for only slight adjustments to enhance the overall dining experience.
The tacos were greasy and unflavorful. I was quite disappointed with my order. There was also dirt on the floors and the people making the food didn't speak much English

Kitty's cafe, nestled within the esteemed El Cortez Hotel and Casino, offers a dining experience reminiscent of a bygone era, replete with the warm, personalized service that has become synonymous with this venerable establishment. Patrons can indulge in traditional counter service or occupy cozy booths, all while being addressed with endearments such as "honey" or, for regulars, by their given names, courtesy of the affable servers. The menu, though unpretentious, boasts generous portions; case in point, the grilled sourdough melt, featuring turkey and ham, which, albeit unremarkable, proved satisfying. However, a novice culinary artisan helming the kitchen on the day of our visit resulted in a tardy turnaround time for dishes. Notwithstanding, Kitty's remains an optimal destination for a late-night repast, catering to those seeking sustenance following an evening of revelry within the hotel's confines or, alternatively, for individuals yearning for a modest, nocturnal dining experience. It is worth noting that the once ubiquitous "$1.99 specials" have, regrettably, become a distant memory.

This Starbucks is I guess owned by NY NY hotel so they don't use the App...sucky store!! No fare to the app users when you don't have cash on you! Good thing I had money this time and didn't loose to the slot machines here!  \n\nIt's always busy here but goes pretty fast and has a good selection of goods to eat. They open 24/7 which is a good thing. They make their coffee good. Of course, I will be back since this Starbucks is in our hotel but start using the app payment and have them work with Starbucks so we can get our points! Hahaha

Here we are at another DDD visited restaurant...

Melissa, our server, offered a bubbly good morning and 

After the customary 10 minute wait. (No wait usually means not great)

Coffee full bodied and rich, diet coke properly carbonated.

Our eggs were delivered so fast I only got three sentences of this review completed before arrival.

Our glasses were always kept full!

Nice breakfast place.

"We traversed the distance between the FireSky hotel and the restaurant with ease, commencing our culinary excursion with the green pork chili, which, while possessing an appreciable degree of flavor, lacked the fiery zest we had anticipated. Our order also included the lamb fondue, comprising succulent lamb racks accompanied by a savory squash sauce for dipping. The fondue component of the dish boasted a rich, velvety texture and a subtle sweetness that complemented the lamb nicely. However, upon sampling the braised short ribs as our primary course, we were somewhat disappointed by their relative lack of flavor depth. Despite its generous portion size, the dish failed to impress due to its absence of salt, pepper, and other essential seasonings. While the meat itself was undeniably tender and juicy, the overall taste experience fell short of our expectations. Although the cuisine generally satisfied our palates, we couldn't help but feel that each dish could benefit from a more robust seasoning profile, thereby elevating the gastronomic experience to a higher level of satisfaction. Consequently, we have decided to award this establishment three stars for their efforts."

Tapas great, paella salty.  Never had it before thought it would be good here,  tapas were tasty especially the mushroom risotto ,  oxtail was tender ,  potatoes yummy,  garlic chicken was good but I ate a clove of garlic by mistake vampires beware.  However, the paella was way too salty.  And the service for a restaurant in the Aria was only so so.  Service was alot better in cafe in the Aria

There were limited options for dinner before the show we were seeing at the Luxor. The 20 year old ticket agent suggested T&T. Said it was great. I should have known we would not have the same palate. We started our meal with a set of mojitos. Our waiter indicated they were very good. I order them whenever I can so I have had my share of mojitos. These were very very sweet. I ordered club soda twice to add to our drinks to reduce the sweetness. Nothing saved these drinks. We didn't even finish half of it. Horrible.
The chips and salsa were also not very good which is fairly unusual. Pretty easy to make good chips and salsa. I had tacos for dinner and my friend had a shrimp dish. Both were very average.
Our server was friendly and even came around at the end and offered free tickets to the show. We already had purchased our tickets but the offer was very kind.
I wouldn't go back to this restaurant because if I had known the Asian restaurant had a good menu I would have gone there.

Easily the best meal I enjoyed in Vegas this past week. I was on a vacation with my sisters. Knowing we would be eating out for 6 days we tried to keep the budget in check. This restaurant was recommended by a friend of my sister did not disappoint as far as the food was concerned. It is tucked away in the back of the food court. Location isn't great...I suppose that is how they keep the prices down. \"Outdoor tables\" are actually inside. Lighting in the interior of the restaurant is way too bright.\nService was very average...our waiter was a hyper-macho Italiano who kept himself busy fawning over the young girls eating next to us, and chatting with his buddies out in the food court plaza. At the end of our meal he was so carried away with his buddies that he had totally forgotten about us, and need to be retrieved by a bus boy. \nThe Caeser Salad that we shared was good. Filet mignon meatballs with spaghetti and red sauce were delicious, as was the wood-fired Quatro Stagioni pizza. I highly recommend the food...the service not so much.

Loved spotting The Dog empire during my show long weekend trip to Edinburgh.  Awesome and funky design and great restaurant concepts (The Dog, UnderDog, SeaDog and Amore Dog).  Wished I had more time to try all of 'em!  \n\nMy flank steak salad was ok (2.5 stars), a bit tough but the sweet balsamic reduction was just the right tough for the bitter arugula.  Boyfriend's mushroom risotto (4.0 stars)  was decadent and cooked perfectly.  To ended the meal we had the tiramisu (3 stars), unfortunately, the dish lacked the punch of espresso, was chilled as I like the desert and the dark chocolate cocoa powder (when taken in a mouthful) overpowered the light dessert.  We ended up scrapping the top power off the dish.
Food was great and reasonably priced with restaurant.com coupon. I would've gave five stars if the waiter wasn't so cocky and direct.

"An extensive array of artisanal brews graces the taps at this establishment, yet, if predictability is a patron's preference, they might be dismayed by the constantly shifting roster of craft beverages available. However, the culinary offerings proved to be a pleasant surprise, surpassing expectations typically associated with tavern fare. A convivial ambiance permeated our gathering of numerous companions, facilitated by the provision of entertainment in the form of board games and trivia queries. Unfortunately, the hospitality and ambiance left much to be desired, as an overwhelming crush of clientele necessitated an inordinate wait for a solitary server's attention, resulting in prolonged periods of neglect. Despite these shortcomings, the eatery's redeeming qualities, including its diverse beer selection and delectable victuals, may warrant future visits, albeit sans any gastronomical inclinations."

I have been a patron of this establishment for a considerable duration, and my satisfaction has been contingent upon the attendance of Dr. Finch, whose proficiency in veterinary medicine and bedside manner have engendered a sense of confidence and tranquility in me, as a concerned pet owner. It is worth mentioning that he has executed a relatively minor surgical procedure on my canine companion, Dozer, which involved the employment of a laser to excise a small growth from her eyelid, and his performance was exemplary, characterized by a commendable level of composure, erudition, and a propitious demeanor towards our cherished animal. Furthermore, it has come to my attention that he will likely be undertaking a second, considerably more complex operation on her, specifically an ACL repair, and I am entirely at ease with entrusting her care to him. Notwithstanding, I have chosen to revise my evaluation downward by a marginal extent, motivated by two primary factors. Firstly, my initial assessment may have been somewhat generous, as I was still in the process of formulating my criteria for evaluating veterinary facilities; and secondly, certain acquaintances have expressed unwavering devotion to their respective veterinarians, whereas my relationship with this establishment, although satisfactory, does not quite rise to that level of enthusiasm. Additionally, I must admit that I have periodically sought alternatives, but procrastination has led me to rely on Dr. Finch's services when Dozer has required urgent medical attention.

"Thus far, my culinary experiences at this establishment have been limited to the breakfast menu, specifically the corned beef and farmer's omlette. While the fare has been satisfactory, it fails to elicit any exceptional praise. However, I do appreciate the option to substitute a blueberry muffin for toast. The server has demonstrated politeness and accommodating behavior, exemplified by their willingness to provide ranch dressing with my hash browns, an unconventional yet personal preference. Additionally, this venue enjoys the distinction of being the sole dining option beyond 10 p.m. in close proximity, excluding those situated within gaming establishments, and boasts reasonable pricing. Consequently, it presents itself as a suitable setting for a relaxed meal in the company of a friend. Nonetheless, I must express my disappointment regarding the absence of dark chicken meat on the menu, as the lighter variety tends to possess an undesirable dryness."

Okay, I'm giving 3 stars because the food was pretty good and the service was great.  But $18 for enchiladas?? Whoaaa now.  $5 roach coach enchiladas could stand up to theirs.  $9 chips and guacamole?? It was good but not $9 good!  I think this place has a complex... You can put cloth napkins and fancy paper menus on the table but in the end you're still a mainstream Mexican restaurant with TONS of competition... CHEAP competition that's just as good.  I won't go back just because of the price unfortunately...

Mert's is one of those places you would see on Diners, Drive-ins and Dives. The decor has a quintessential southern comfort feel and will make any out of towner feel welcome. \n\nI don't suggest eating lunch here though; if it happens, it's a wrap. You'll be knocked out like a newborn after boobie feeding. Service is good, food is decent and overall an okay spot to grab a meal.

Harrah's has a smart business module when it comes to Carnaval Court. It is situation on a pathway that sucks tourist in. With all the kiosks around, it has useless souvenirs within drunken reach. Even though my friends and I were not inebriated, we still bought those shirts that light up to the music. Thinking they were the epitome of cheesy tourist, we all bought matching shirts to signify our unity. 

Entering the party scene with our newly acquired garments garnered so much attention and compliments. The dance floor is large and provides enough room to get down. Being outside helps alleviate the overheating that sometimes occurs when the dance floor gets too crowded. 

The flare bartenders are fun to watch and make a decent cocktail. If you want to alternate between partying and gambling, this is the perfect venue because they have table games set aside as well. It has everything someone coming to Vegas is looking for.

It was nice to relax for dinner on night this week and if you want to relax this is the place to do it at.  The view is just amazing and the staff was very friendly.  I had the Rib eye steak and it was cook just perfect.  Blue cheese potatoes were really good but I think the Blue Cheese was a bit over powering for the potatoes.\n\nI also had some cake for desert but the ice cream  had started to melt and the cake was a bit dry.  For the price I expected a bit better on the details like that.  In the end it was worth the trip for the view.

Recommended by a friend. He made it sound exclusive since dim sum was open twice a year, I felt that the dim sum style food could have been better if they focused on that and left the buffet of sea food out. It was tasty but some that came out was cold. They didn't have the chili oil like most Chinese restaurants I go to in San Diego, that was ok though since the items we had were a tad salty. The non dim sum items are  great though, fresh raw oysters, crab legs, lobster, nigiri, I actually asked the guy behind the sushi bar if I could have pieces with out rice, he said they usually don't give it out like that but he made an exception for me, to bad those pieces were so thick. I wanted to ask for a piece of the octopus but felt like I was going to inconvenience him so I walked down the buffet line, there was a yummy octopus and cucumber salad, probably the best thing on the buffet. They had a surplus of fresh fruit, mandarin oranges, cherries, rambutan, I didn't feel like working for my food though. Desert bar was pretty cool, decent, but not great. I really wish they more focused on dim sum though.. Next to sushi, dim sum is my favorite. Maybe I'll go this weekend when I get home to San Diego..

"It's analogous to gambling. Occasionally, one experiences substantial success...while at other times, the outcome is rather meager. 

The production commenced auspiciously. Our Master of Ceremonies was engaging and hilarious, possessing an unwavering comfort in his own skin while utilizing his personal experiences as fodder for his humor, yet maintaining a keen awareness of social conventions to avoid traversing boundaries. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for the subsequent two comedians, whose performances were marred by crudeness, excessive vulgarity, and a tendency to forcefully impose their questionable humor upon the audience, regardless of conspicuous signs of discomfort. At one juncture, a female spectator felt compelled to rise and request that the comedian move on, only to be met with further exploitation of the situation as a means of continuing his set. While employing someone as the focal point of humor may be acceptable, it becomes problematic when literally no one else is participating in mirth. Fortunately, our capable MC effectively applied a makeshift solution to salvage each of these two underwhelming performances. 

The featured act, Jay Reid, significantly redeemed the entire evening...which would have otherwise been a resounding disappointment at $20 per ticket. Mr. Reid capitalized on the stage's potential, incorporating the stool and microphone stand into his routine and presenting jokes pertinent to contemporary affairs and customarily delicate or taboo subjects. His humor was tasteful, and he demonstrated great class and coolness by lingering afterward to interact with the audience."

I commemorated the milestone of my eighteenth year of existence by partaking in a culinary excursion to this establishment in the company of a select group of acquaintances. It is pertinent to note that their hours of operation, specifically the period designated as "happy hour," are limited to weekdays between the hours of two and six post meridiem, thereby rendering our arrival at seven o'clock somewhat inconvenient. Notwithstanding this minor setback, I opted to sample their grilled chicken sandwich, which, while palatable, exhibited a certain pinkish hue that might have been attributable to an abbreviated cooking duration. Furthermore, the prolonged preparation time of approximately forty-five minutes, coupled with my considerable hunger, precluded me from returning said item to the kitchen for further culinary refinement. In addition, we collectively decided to partake in a shared consumption of their frozen hot chocolate beverage, which, despite its latent promise, unfortunately necessitated a significant amount of mastication upon its icy constituents throughout its duration. It is worth mentioning that the pace of service was somewhat leisurely and that the cost, while not drastically exceeding that of Cheesecake Factory, still fell within a higher price bracket. Notwithstanding these observations, I am willing to accord this eatery a subsequent opportunity to demonstrate improvement.

This isn't your Grandpa's Flamingo anymore. I would even venture to say this isn't your overweight Chain smoking uncle Larry's Flamingo we all knew and didn't love from 5-10 years ago!

Before My recent trip to The Flamingo, the thought of staying there would immediately trigger thoughts of Depressing 1980's decor, overweight fanny pack wearing gamblers & The over exuberant expressions of Donnie & Marie as they stared longingly into each others eyes trying to forget about that one night back in 77' when things went a little to far. But to the contrary I must say the Flamingo has really cleaned up its act. The new decor is nice and the casino floor is clean and 80% fanny pack clear. 

Now saying that I have yet to stay in a room, but I will say that , where as before I would've only taken a side chick I was slightly ashamed of. Now I would be ok with taking a side chick I was not ashamed of, as well as possibly a girl that I have been dating awhile, all the while  insisting "Why do we have to put labels on what we are" here without hesitation!

All in all The Flamingo is an OK place with a GREAT location that I would recommend anyone walking the strip to try out. Hey, who knows you may finally be the first person to see Donnie and Marie finally consummate 35 years of tension and frustration!

"On two separate occasions during my sojourn at Treasure Island, I have partaken of sustenance at this establishment, and while the Pho has been merely adequate, it has possessed a certain je ne sais quoi that has rendered it marginally palatable in a pinch. Furthermore, I have sampled their vegetarian spring rolls, which, while not devoid of culinary merit, have been somewhat overshadowed by the ambivalent quality of the accompanying peanut sauce, which has struck me as vaguely coconut-flavored. On one visit, I opted for the Pho Tai, while my companion selected the Veggie Pho; unfortunately, my soup proved to be somewhat lacking in gastronomic appeal, containing as it did an abundance of beef but a dearth of noodles, whereas my friend's soup, replete with bak choy, mushrooms, and corn, was more enjoyable. It is worth noting, however, that the pricing of the Pho here strikes me as somewhat elevated in comparison to similar establishments in Los Angeles, where a superior-tasting bowl may be obtained for a mere $7. Notwithstanding these reservations, I must commend the waitstaff for their congeniality and the premises for their cleanliness."

Not a huge fan of this Target.  It's the closest one so I find myself going there but the store is so large and it feels like everyone inside is an ASU student at times.  Which basically means it is always crowded with people and I find myself waiting in line to check out.  Otherwise, it's has a lot of good things.  Lots of parking, great staff and like I said before it's super sized so you can find anything and everything you need in one location.
The employees spend too\nMuch time with there backs to the customers talking amongst themselves instead of focusing on providing better service!

I just happened to be in Vegas this new year and since I saw this place in the past i decided to try it. Salad bar is ok, the meats a bit too salty and really raw (bloody) but I was surely disappointed with the service. Waitress show up only 3 times, when we first sat at the table, when she brought us the drinks and when she gave us the check!, I have to literally ask the servers to bring the meats to our table since the seem to just pas us by, I guess the just want you to eat from the salad bar :( \nIn other words, the price service/quality ratio is not good at all

We stumbled upon this place after failing to go to the Bacchanal because of the nasty line. By the time we found this place, we were starving! This is a cool little cafe place with pretty modern decorations throughout the restaurant. They blast top 20s hits here, so if you're looking for a nice quiet place to chat, this definitely isn't the place.\n\nPortions here are pretty large but we really didn't think anything of the food. Nothing stood out or was spectacular. I got a pastrami breakfast sandwich and I felt like it was missing something. If they had added some extra condiments or had a special sauce it would be much better. It felt like the pastrami, egg, and other ingredients didn't flow that well together. Nonetheless it filled us. I did enjoy the tator tots though, they were crispy, crunchy and delicious.

"This location possesses an intriguing ambiance and offers a plethora of knowledge. My enthusiasm for the establishment was amplified by the thoughtful division of the exhibits into four distinct ecosystems. However, I lamented the lack of comprehensive representation in the polar/arctic sector. In my opinion, the entrance fee is exorbitant relative to the value offered. Nonetheless, the gift store boasts an array of unique items, including innovative bags crafted from recycled juice containers, delectable insect-based treats, and minuscule crystalline formations, among other fascinating novelties. It is not advisable to squander your resources on the elevator ride to the summit of the metropolis, as the same panoramic perspective can be obtained gratis from the pinnacle of Mount Royal."

"It is imperative that one does not make a hasty judgment based on external appearances, as this establishment offers an array of exceptional bargains for those who are willing to invest time in their pursuit. A diverse medley of items, including apparel, artwork, and various domestic ornaments, are available for perusal and purchase. During my recent visit, it appeared that the proprietors were in the process of expanding their inventory to include an increased assortment of floor coverings and visual art pieces, which will undoubtedly be a boon for individuals seeking to revamp their domiciles. My excursion was enjoyable, and I would unhesitatingly revisit this location in quest of additional hidden gems."
Well they no longer have the Chicken Strip Cheese sandwich and what they replaced it with pretty much sucks. Other than that its like a normal hooters with some new wing flavors and steak fries.

This lodging establishment caters to individuals who seek fundamental accommodations and are financially constrained, thereby providing a suitable venue for those seeking basic amenities at an economical price point. During our sojourn, we found that it fulfilled its intended function admirably and would unhesitatingly suggest it to others who do not prioritize luxurious appointments or an extensive array of services. Within close proximity, we noticed the presence of eateries such as Pizza Hut, Subway, and Fatburger, as well as a cinema, watering holes, and numerous slot machines. Our stay was primarily characterized by slumber, and we did not partake in any notable activities within the hotel's premises themselves. Furthermore, our culinary experience at Fatburger proved to be disappointing, both in terms of taste and the prolonged duration required for its preparation.

I was motivated to go here because I saw it featured on the Food Network, and I was hoping it could hold a candle to the Boiling Crab.  While to seafood was pretty good, it wasn't as spicy & flavorful as I had hoped for.  Go early as it tends to get crowded.  We went at 11am on a weekend and by the time we finished our meal, there was a line for tables.
Solid 3 star red curry tofu.\n\nNot 5 star, not 4 star...but hey!  They did great with the one classic dish I ordered...

"We arrived at approximately 8:30 PM, and upon our arrival, we observed that the queue extended beyond the entrance. Undeterred by the lengthy wait, I advocated for our participation in the line, as my craving for ice cream was unwavering. Following a 15-minute interval, we successfully placed our order; however, the delay was reasonable given the crowded atmosphere and the staff's diligent efforts to manage the influx of patrons. Notably, the employee who assisted us mistakenly provided a larger portion than requested, which they generously offered at no additional cost. It is worth mentioning that the limited seating area within the establishment was largely unoccupied, likely due to the personnel being fully engaged in fulfilling orders. Consequently, we opted for takeout. As an enthusiast of Cold Stone's unique blend of frozen delights, I have grown accustomed to enduring prolonged waits, and in my opinion, the experience merits the temporary inconvenience."

This place reminded me of Whiskey River without the shit kickers on the beach side and more of the laid back people. There were dance offs on the floor it seemed people were having fun. 99 cent Jaeger bombers and I heard 99 cent tacos or something. There was a wet t contest with only 3 contestants it was kinda sad but entertaining nonetheless. I'd probably go again.

The Grandview Saloon has one of the best views of Pittsburgh from Mt. Washington from its patio. The views from the interior of the restaurant are not bad either.  To go with your view, you can choose from a good selection of drinks and more mediocre Pittsburghesque (i.e., comfort) food. The design of the patio is fine, but the interior of the restaurant is very plain. This is a shame, because with a little work on the interior design and menu, the view could make this one of the city's most interesting restaurants. \n\nIn short, I would not go here to celebrate an anniversary, but it's a good place to take first-time visitors to see the city while enjoying a tasty beverage.

"Excellent, amicable, and assiduous service was proffered to us, complemented by a delectable Caesar salad, succulent duck, and a mediocre serving of scallops. Although the salad was scrumptious, the duck was somewhat rich and filling, while the scallops were merely average and not particularly memorable. In conclusion, our dining experience was passable but not particularly remarkable, thereby rendering it unworthy of future repetition."

I've been going here during the week, and in bad weather it is hard to tell it is even open.  There are some things I really love here and some that I don't.  The flowers are a steal and beautifully arranged, though they do not last very long - maybe two or three days.  There are some really good deals on produce, and I have gotten some great tomatoes and peaches in season.  However, about half of the stuff is not local.  I had a hard time finding a local apple, and a lot of the produce has sku stickers on it telling you that it's from california or washington or whatever.  Still, there are some local farmers interspersed in there and they make it worth it.  I still will visit regularly.

I have a profound affection for The Coffee Bean, as I frequently indulge in their delectable brews. However, this particular establishment seems to have some sort of anomaly affecting the quality of their coffee. It appears that there is an inconsistency in the taste, which I can only surmise is due to the water used in the preparation process. This has led me to question whether there is a deliberate attempt to undermine my mental state or if it is merely an unfortunate consequence of the hotel's water source. Despite my fondness for a robust cup of coffee, I find myself consistently disappointed with the offerings within the Venetian. Notwithstanding, I must acknowledge that the convenience of having a cup of coffee delivered to my doorstep each morning by a particularly attractive and thoughtful individual almost makes up for the subpar quality of the beverage itself. Thus, I have assigned a rating of three stars, comprising one star for the coffee and two additional stars for the exceptional service I received.

"Adequate retail establishment offering an extensive array of merchandise that I would indeed utilize. Notably advantageous reductions on comestibles. Well-organized physical space, albeit susceptible to disarray due to the presence of numerous patrons. The sole drawback I have encountered during my visits is the considerable delay incurred while waiting to complete my purchases. A protracted queue at the checkout counter is a minor inconvenience given the substantial economies realized. Prepare to devote approximately 15 minutes or more to conclude your transaction."

It is a clean place and they have good service. The Koi pond is pretty cool. The sandwich I ordered was pretty awful, don't get the turkey because it is like packaged meat you can buy at a supermarket. The prices were on par with other delis, but you can get a much better sandwich for the same price elsewhere.

*sigh*  I really wanted to love this, but it was just ok.  After reading all the positive yelps and testimonials on Pop's website, I was expecting a fun and delicious experience.  I imagined myself giving my order to a gruff but charming grill master, who would ask me 'wit' onions? in an authentic Philly accent.  What I really got was a grill master who was just gruff and apparently couldn't hear my order, because when I got my cheese steak home, there were no onions on it at all!   

Ok, the cheese steak itself:  the meat was not fatty or greasy, but slightly bland.  I enjoyed the cheese whiz and the bread was very good.  I think if they had included the onions, things would have been tastier.  Also, in the hours since eating the steak, I have been a bit 'indisposed', but this in and of itself has never been an index of whether I would return to a place if the food tastes good.  (masochist!)

So all in all, I think I would try it again probably.  But I'll also try their competition in town and yelp the results.  :)

"Cabo is indeed a bustling venue, even on an ordinary Tuesday evening, and fortunately, we were promptly accommodated, albeit as a party of two. While the culinary offerings did possess a certain je ne sais quoi, I must admit that my expectations, predicated upon their acclaim in Charlotte, were somewhat higher. In point of fact, I was anticipating a more piquant and nuanced gastronomical experience. 

Notwithstanding certain dissenting opinions, I did not sense any undue haste, despite the restaurant's brisk pace. My companion and I indulged in a leisurely conversation, during which our hospitable server graciously afforded us ample time to savor both our meal and each other's company. It is worth noting, however, that parking in the vicinity of NoDa can be somewhat problematic, thus it is advisable to allocate a few extra moments to circumnavigate the area in search of a suitable parking spot. 

In summary, Cabo boasts a convivial ambiance well-suited for socializing over refreshments and a light repast; yet, it falls short of being a truly exceptional or extraordinary dining destination, warranting a special effort to visit."

We were on our way back from a trip to Mexico and Cuba* when we arrived here for a short layover. This airport is easy to navigate, especially when you are coming through immigration -- there are lots of signs telling you exactly where to go. 

There was a long line at immigration but it moved fairly quickly. My honey and I had all of our research license paperwork in order for the Cuba portion of our travels in case we were asked for it** but the not-even-a-hello immigration officer guy just scanned our passports, looked at us with his best stern face, and stamped us on our way. We then picked up our checked suitcases, zoomed right through customs (after handing over our customs form) and rechecked our bags. 

The part that ended up taking the longest amount of time was going back through security, thanks to long lines. I do have to say that the security personnel were working very hard to move everyone along and were really nice as well.

If we had more than 5 minutes to spare, I would have picked up some local BBQ to eat on our San Francisco bound flight. Thanks a lot, security line. 

*You won't hear much more about our trip to Mexico and Cuba since they don't have Yelp. (At least not yet.) I'll just summarize to say that almost everywhere we slept, ate, drank, visited, etc. were unquestionably five star. 

** Apparently Beyonce and Jay Z did as well. http://www.reuters.com/article/2013/04/09/entertainment-us-usa-cuba-beyonce-idUSBRE93600V20130409

This hotel exterior is a little worn down and in need of a refurbishing. Everything about it just looks dated and tired. The rooms had obviously been updated since other parts of the hotel and they were not that bad although the tile grout looked a little dingy in my room. I did not hear the people in the room next to me as others have complained about. However, I found the food to be very good especially for a hotel. They had a decent bar with a few local brews on tap and service was friendly. The hotel location is convenient but still a 6-8 block walk to the more popular attractions downtown. We took advantage of the free shuttle service and the friendly and knowledgeable driver, Christian. Its fairly easy to get to though off I-277. For the money, it wasn't bad.

The restaurant is cozy and somewhat dark with a separate bar area and dining area. Service was quick and attentive. They have some different beers to experiment with and even let you sample some you're not familiar with before you commit. 


Food was OK but not great. I had half a turkey sandwich and salad. My turkey sandwich was a bit dry and bland and the salad was forgettable. As bars go and as bar food goes you could do much worse.

I've been wanting to try this place for awhile after hearing good things about it and reading the menu. I realize now why the website doesn't list prices-- the mission is hideously overpriced!

We ended up on the patio since they weren't seating in the main area yet (at 6:30pm? For reals?) Our waitress was nice and attentive. She noticed my water had something floating in it and replaced it quickly. My husband's water glass was dirty too. She brought us out two sample size frozen peach and strawberry margaritas which were awesome. Much better than the rocks margarita.

No complimentary chips and salsa which would be ok if they offered something else like Barrio. No happy hour either which was disappointing.

The street corn was good, but I've had much better. The butternut squash tacos were out of this world. My husband liked them better than his mahi tacos. I just can't believe they have the gall to charge $12 for 3 tiny (3 inches in diameter) tacos. They also charge $12 for guac made from 2 avocados. I'm not sure how they have survived in this economy. They must be very slow when the tourists leave for the summer.

"The positive aspects of this establishment include the provision of a magna doodle for young patrons to engage in creative expression, a courteous and attentive wait staff, a pristine dining environment owing to its recent opening, a diverse array of pasta options including whole wheat and rose sauce, the opportunity for patrons to personalize their pasta dishes with various toppings, karaoke amenities available on Friday and Saturday evenings, culinary offerings that are palatable, reasonable prices for those who refrain from adding supplementary toppings, and a distinctive dessert menu."
"However, there are several drawbacks to consider, such as the limited visibility of the children's menu, which is printed on the reverse side of the magna doodle, and the fact that kids' beverages are served in adult-sized to-go cups. Additionally, the cleanup process after a spill was quite sluggish, taking nearly 10 minutes to address my daughter's spilled milk. Furthermore, the menu selections are somewhat restricted, primarily consisting of pasta, pizza, and paninis, with limited variety in terms of entrees. Moreover, the cost of individual pasta toppings is $1.50 each, and my cannelloni dessert was disappointingly unremarkable."

We encountered an unwelcoming reception upon arriving at the entrance, whereupon the security personnel exhibited a discourteous demeanor, rendering it improbable that we would proceed any further had our celebratory companion not persistently advocated for our admittance.
Fun store if you are looking for Korean. To the poster that identified this store as Japanese, was wrong. Korean and Japanese foods are similar but not the same.

"Red 8, an establishment offering Americanized Chinese cuisine, boasts a delectable Oxtail soup, complemented by their mouthwatering Mongolian beef and rice. The eatery's ambiance exudes elegance, while the staff provides exceptional service. Although the dessert menu could benefit from some refinement, it remains satisfactory. However, the prices are somewhat steep, seemingly attributed to the venue's high-end atmosphere and association with the renowned Wynn resort. Personal preferences aside, Red 8 may not be the optimal choice for authentic Chinese fare, yet its unique offerings and hospitable environment make it an acceptable dining experience, especially when partaking in a meal as a guest."

It's getting harder to find awesome deals for meals in Vegas.  Gone are the days you can get buffets for $5 or prime rib dinners for $7.99.  Oh Sahara, how I miss you!  

Visiting family in Henderson, we headed over to Sunset Station for some dinner. They had prime rib dinner for $9.99, so I had to get it.  For a Saturday night, it was packed and we had to wait 15 minutes for a table.  

My prime rib dinner was good, but I should've ordered it medium rare, because medium well wasn't as tasty.  

Service was good and food was decent.  I just wished the prime rib dinner was little bit cheaper and then I would've given them a higher rating.  Their t-bone steak dinner special was $12.99, which I thought was a bit high for Vegas.  

Grand Cafe is way better than Denny's, so for a local 24 hour spot, I'd come back to eat.

I really want to like this place, but it was extremely disappointing. Maybe it was overhyped. The food was just okay, nothing sets it apart from other buffets. \n\nBased on other reviews, I might give it another shot next time I'm in Vegas, but I'd rather go back to the seafood buffet at Rio before dining here again.

The food is good which is the best part, I had the endless shrimp (shrimp alfredo x 2, breaded shrimp and shrimp scampi). The worst part is the wait to be seated and served. You have to wait 30 minutes to get seated and then another 15 minutes to be served. They need better service to get a higher rating from me. The food as I said above is very good and hot and once we were served, the service was decent. The cheddar biscuits that you receive after you are seated are excellent.

"Although the cost of the sashimi may be perceived as somewhat elevated, the quality of the seafood served at this establishment has consistently met my expectations, with each piece of fish exhibiting exceptional freshness and being presented in an aesthetically pleasing manner. Following three separate visits, I can confidently attest to the consistent excellence of the culinary experience offered here."

I don't have much to say about this hotel because I wouldn't stay here again.

Hotel rooms-I stayed in the back tower and the walk to the tower was horrible. Walking through an entire casino with your luggage is the biggest pain in the ass, not to mention walking the bridge across the pool to get to the tower. Big thumbs down. Room was really nice, decor was nice, beds comfy, but bathroom was a motel 6 bathroom. Very old looking. Not what I would expect if owned by a hilton chain.

Casino-casino was actually nice and fresh. Because it was newly renovated it smelled clean and didn't smell like a shit hole like some of the older casinos. Lots of options.

Accommodations-pool was awesome, staff is nice, house keeping staff nice, but check in was a nightmare. Checked in at 2pm and line stretched to the casino. I was in the hilton honors check in and that line was in the casino as well. If it takes 30 mins for checkin, then you have already lost me as a customer that will not stay there again.

"The dearth of options was palpable, with a meager assortment of products available, which was further exacerbated by the cramped and cluttered nature of the store; however, the parking lot, despite its capacity, appeared to be congested, creating an incongruous juxtaposition between the exterior and interior spaces, although the staff members, who were few in number but abundant in cordiality, managed to facilitate a semblance of order amidst the chaos, and I, after conducting a thorough examination of the premises, was able to procure a set of diminutive yet aesthetically pleasing beverage receptacles for the nominal sum of sixty-nine cents, which, given the limited variety and somewhat disorganized ambiance, seemed a veritable bargain."

I stopped by here a while ago while staying at the Aria on business.  We had walked past the patisserie when headed up to our rooms and the brightness of the area along with the cakes really caught my eye. So the next morning whenever i was craving some coffee I decided to head down and get my fianc\u00e9 and I each one.  Whenever I got down there I was able to see the multi tiered cakes up close and they were truly amazing!  It made me wonder how long it took to make them.  After a short wait I made it to the front of the line and ordered two Americanos only to watch them punch something into a machine and have it spot them out.  For the $10 it cost I was really hoping to have the barista take a minute and pull the shots.  The coffee itself was decent but not great.\n\nThe bottom line for me is that I would not head back here again in the future for coffee.  However I would definitely give it a try if I was looking for a baked good.

"The ale is merely adequate, but its price point is exorbitant. It would be judicious to await the replenishment of stock at the warehouse club, whereupon you may procure a case for a sum $10 less than its current price at the brewery. The personnel at the establishment were indeed cordial, yet their hospitality alone does not suffice to justify a revisit at present. However, the possibility of an on-site dining establishment materializing in the future renders the venue potentially worthy of a second visit."

This particular establishment is one of those culinary destinations that it is imperative to visit at least once in one's lifetime, as it offers an enjoyable experience for the taste buds, with the meat consistently being of high quality, albeit it is advisable to avoid visiting during major holidays, as the level of service and gastronomic excellence may not be maintained with the same rigor and dedication.

"The pricing structure at this establishment is patently exorbitant, with minuscule, tapas-style plates of culinary fare commanding a premium price point in excess of $30, while larger, yet still diminutive entree-sized portions fetch a whopping $50 to $60. Despite my prior awareness of the menu prices, the inflated cost of my meal still managed to surpass my expectations. The ambiance of the restaurant, characterized by a color scheme dominated by red and black hues, was somewhat redeemed by the novelty of witnessing the culinary process firsthand from our perch at the bar. However, the quality of the food, though undeniably satisfactory, fails to justify the egregious markup. If the aim of this dining experience is to foster a sense of casualness, a reduction in prices by at least 25-30% would be imperative."

Is the best bagel place I've been to? No. I came here for a \"to go\" breakfast with my man. As we were waiting for our food, he whispered to me \"this place is filthy\". The vent above the bagel rack was so dusty! The counters, floors and tables looked like they hadn't been wiped down either. We had already paid so we just decided to get our food and go. The guy who helped us was very sweet but incredibly slow. We spent almost 20 minutes waiting for 2 bagel sandwiches and a chocolate chip muffin.
